entry.name: account_kglobalconfig_help_1
entry.text:
The "account" command allow you to specify behavior related to failed login attempts of locally defined accounts.
"max-login-failure" <count> Set the number of consecutive login failures to allow before the account is locked out. Failures must be consecutive. A successful login clears the count. The count persists across restarts. "lockout-duration" <minutes> Set the duration in minutes an account remains locked out after the set number of failed login attempts. After the duration elapses, the account can successfully login in with the correct password unless the duration is 0. A duration of 0 means the account is locked out until reset.

entry.name: account_kglobalconfig_descr_1
entry.text: Set default accounts parameters.

entry.name: account_lockout_duration_kglobalconfig_help_2
entry.text: Set the duration in minutes an account remains locked out after the set number of failed login attempts. After the duration elapses, the account can successfully login in with the correct password unless the duration is 0. A duration of 0 means the account is locked out until reset.

entry.name: account_lockout_duration_kglobalconfig_descr_2
entry.text: Set duration of account lockout.

entry.name: account_max_login_failure_kglobalconfig_help_3
entry.text: Set the number of consecutive login failures to allow before the account is locked out. Failures must be consecutive. A successful login clears the count. The count persists across restarts.

entry.name: account_max_login_failure_kglobalconfig_descr_3
entry.text: Set the number of failed login attempts to allow.

entry.name: audit_delete_backup_kglobalconfig_help_4
entry.text: This command deletes the backup audit log. It should be done only after the audit log has been backed up.

entry.name: audit_delete_backup_kglobalconfig_descr_4
entry.text: Delete the backup audit log.

entry.name: audit_level_kglobalconfig_help_5
entry.text: This command specifies the amount of audit logging to record. "full" Create an audit record for each accepted or rejected request as well as all standard security events. "standard" Create an audit record for only standard security events

entry.name: audit_level_kglobalconfig_descr_5
entry.text: Specify the amount of audit logging to perform.

entry.name: acl_kglobalconfig_help_6
entry.text:
Enters ACL Configuration Mode and creates an Access Control List that consists of IP address ranges to allow or deny access. All addresses that are not specifically allowed are denied. Use the "allow" and "deny" commands to construct the list
name The name of the ACL. Alternatively, use one of the following keywords to assign the ACL to a specific management/security service. rest-mgmt Edit the ACL for the REST Management service. ssh Edit ACL for the SSH service. web-mgmt Edit the ACL for the Web Management service. xml-mgmt Edit the ACL for the XML Management service.
For example:
acl ACL-1 Enters ACL Configuration Mode and creates the ACL-1 ACL. acl ssh Enters ACL Configuration Mode to edit the ACL for the SSH service.

entry.name: acl_kglobalconfig_descr_6
entry.text: Enters ACL Configuration Mode

entry.name: acl_kglobalconfig_help_7
entry.text:
Enters ACL Configuration Mode and creates an Access Control List that consists of IP address ranges to allow or deny access. All addresses that are not specifically allowed are denied. Use the "allow" and "deny" commands to construct the list
name The name of the ACL. Alternatively, use one of the following keywords to assign the ACL to a specific management/security service. rest-mgmt Edit the ACL for the REST Management service. ssh Edit ACL for the SSH service. web-mgmt Edit the ACL for the Web Management service. For example:
acl ACL-1 Enters ACL Configuration Mode and creates the ACL-1 ACL. acl ssh Enters ACL Configuration Mode to edit the ACL for the SSH service.

entry.name: acl_kglobalconfig_descr_7
entry.text: Enters ACL Configuration Mode

entry.name: action_kglobalconfig_help_8
entry.text:
Enters Processing Rule Configuration Mode to create a processing rule.
name The name of the processing rule.
For example:
action sign-wssec-1 Creates the sign-wssec-1 processing rule.

entry.name: action_kglobalconfig_descr_8
entry.text: Enters Processing Rule Configuration Mode

entry.name: application_security_policy_kglobalconfig_help_9
entry.text:
Enters Application Security Policy Configuration Mode and creates an Application Security Policy.
For example:
application-security-policy portal-sec-policy Enters Application Security Policy Configuration Mode and creates the portal-sec-policy Application Security Policy.

entry.name: application_security_policy_kglobalconfig_descr_9
entry.text: Enters Application Security Policy Configuration Mode

entry.name: cache_schema_kglobalconfig_help_10
entry.text:
Adds the specified schema to the schema cache maintained by the XML manager.
xmlmgr The target XML manager. url A URL that specifies the location of the target schema.

entry.name: cache_schema_kglobalconfig_descr_10
entry.text: Caches a specified schema.

entry.name: cache_wsdl_kglobalconfig_help_11
entry.text:
Adds the specified WSDL document to the WSDL cache maintained by the XML manager.
xmlmgr The target XML manager url A URL that specifies the location of the target WSDL document.

entry.name: cache_wsdl_kglobalconfig_descr_11
entry.text: Caches a specified WSDL document.

entry.name: cert_monitor_kconfigcrypto_help_12
entry.text:
Enters Crypto Certificate Monitor Configuration Mode. While in Crypto Certificate Monitor Configuration Mode, you can specify the frequency with which the operating firmware scans crypto certificate objects and issues certificate expiration alerts. For example:
cert-monitor Enters Crypto Certificate Monitor Configuration Mode

entry.name: cert_monitor_kconfigcrypto_descr_12
entry.text: Enters Crypto Certificate Monitor Configuration Mode

entry.name: compile_options_kglobalconfig_help_13
entry.text:
Enters Compile Options Policy Configuration Mode and creates a named Profiling Policy. name The name of the newly-created Profiling Policy. For example:
compile-options Profiling-1 Enters Compile Options Policy Configuration Mode and creates a Profiling Policy named Profiling-1

entry.name: compile_options_kglobalconfig_descr_13
entry.text: Enters Compile Options Policy Configuration Mode

entry.name: manage_local_tam_db_kglobalconfig_help_14
entry.text:
Copies and/or removes an IBM Security Access Manager local database. Note that the IBM Security Access Manager object will be restarted during the operation.
tam-object The name of an IBM Security Access Manager object defined in the current domain. The object must have been configured to use local mode for the local database to exist. copy-database Set to 'yes' if the local database is to be copied to temporary:. remove-database Set to 'yes' if the local database is to be removed.

entry.name: manage_local_tam_db_kglobalconfig_descr_14
entry.text: Manage IBM Security Access Manager Local Database

entry.name: configure_terminal_kprivileged_help_15
entry.text: Leaves Privileged Mode and enters Global Configuration Mode.

entry.name: configure_terminal_kprivileged_descr_15
entry.text: Enters Global Configuration Mode

entry.name: create_tam_files_kglobalconfig_help_16
entry.text:
Creates IBM Security Access Manager client files. The following files are created: Client configuration file Key database file Key stash file Client obfuscation file
The created files are named using the output file parameter. If ISAM files are created with app1 as the output file name parameter, the created files are app1.conf, app1.kdb, app1.sth, and appl.conf.obf.
The configuration and obfuscation files are written to local:, and the key database and stash files to cert:.

entry.name: create_tam_files_kglobalconfig_descr_16
entry.text: Create IBM Security Access Manager Client Files

entry.name: crl_kconfigcrypto_help_17
entry.text:
Enters CRL Update Policy Configuration Mode and creates a named CRL Update Policy. name The name of the newly-created CRL Update Policy. http and ldap Mutually exclusive keywords used to identify the the protocol used to fetch the CRL. For example:
crl ldap1440 ldap Enters CRL Update Policy Configuration Mode and creates a CRL Update Policy named ldap1440. The update policy uses the LDAP protocol to fetch the CRL.

entry.name: crl_kconfigcrypto_descr_17
entry.text: Enters CRL Update Policy Configuration Mode

entry.name: crypto_kglobalconfig_help_18
entry.text: Enters Crypto Configuration Mode.

entry.name: crypto_kglobalconfig_descr_18
entry.text: Enters Crypto Configuration Mode

entry.name: disable_kglobalconfig_help_19
entry.text: Exits Global Configuration Mode and enters User Mode.

entry.name: disable_kglobalconfig_descr_19
entry.text: Enters User Mode

entry.name: disable_kprivileged_help_20
entry.text: Exits Privileged Mode and enters User Mode.

entry.name: disable_kprivileged_descr_20
entry.text: Enters User Mode

entry.name: documentcache_kglobalconfig_help_21
entry.text:
Enters Document Cache Configuration Mode for the specified XML manager. xmlmgr The target XML manager. For example:
documentcache mgr1 Enters Document Cache Configuration Mode for XML manager, mgr1

entry.name: documentcache_kglobalconfig_descr_21
entry.text: Enters Document Cache Configuration Mode

entry.name: document_crypto_map_kglobalconfig_help_22
entry.text:
Enters Document Crypto Map Configuration Mode and creates a named Document Crypto Map. name is the name of the Document Crypto Map. For example:
document-crypto-map DEM-1 Enters Document Crypto Map Configuration Mode and creates a Document Crypto Map named DEM-1

entry.name: document_crypto_map_kglobalconfig_descr_22
entry.text: Enters Document Crypto Map Configuration Mode

entry.name: domain_kglobalconfig_help_23
entry.text:
Creates an application domain and moves to Application Domain Configuration Mode. domainName is the name of the application domain. For example:
domain App-3 creates an application domain named App-3

entry.name: domain_kglobalconfig_descr_23
entry.text: Creates an application domain

entry.name: dns_kglobalconfig_help_24
entry.text: Enters DNS Settings Configuration Mode and enables domain name resolution services. Use the no form of this command to disable DNS service.

entry.name: dns_kglobalconfig_descr_24
entry.text: Enables domain name resolution services.

entry.name: enable_kuser_help_25
entry.text: Enters password-protected Privileged Mode.

entry.name: enable_kuser_descr_25
entry.text: Enters Privileged Mode

entry.name: failure_notification_kglobalconfig_help_26
entry.text: Enters Failure Notification Configuration Mode.

entry.name: failure_notification_kglobalconfig_descr_26
entry.text: Enters Failure Notification Configuration Mode

entry.name: flash_kglobalconfig_help_27
entry.text: Enters Flash Configuration Mode.

entry.name: flash_kglobalconfig_descr_27
entry.text: Enters Flash Configuration Mode

entry.name: ftp_quote_command_list_kglobalconfig_help_28
entry.text:
Enters FTP Quoted Command List Configuration Mode, and creates a named FTP quoted command list. name the name of this FTP quoted command list. For example:
ftp-quote-command-list mvd Enters FTP Quoted Command List configuration mode, and creates the "mvd" quoted command list.

entry.name: ftp_quote_command_list_kglobalconfig_descr_28
entry.text: Enters FTP Quoted Command List Configuration Mode

entry.name: fwcred_kconfigcrypto_help_29
entry.text:
Enters Firewall Credentials Configuration Mode and creates a named firewall credentials list. name The newly-created Firewall Credentials list. For example:
fwcred FWCred-1 Enters Firewall Credentials Configuration Mode and creates a Firewall Credentials list named FWCred-1

entry.name: fwcred_kconfigcrypto_descr_29
entry.text: Enters Firewall Credentials Configuration Mode

entry.name: gateway_peering_cluster_create_kglobalconfig_help_30
entry.text:
Creates a gateway peering cluster with the specified number of replicas for each primary node in the primary list.
replica Indicates the number of secondary nodes required for each primary node. primary-list Specifies the comma-separated list of primary nodes by address:port. This list must contain 3 primary nodes. secondary-list Specifies the comma-separated list of secondary nodes by address:port. This list must contain a minimum of 3 secondary nodes and must be a multiple of 3 based on the value of the replicas parameter.
The following example creates a cluster of 6 nodes across 2 data centers. The primary nodes are the ones with IP addresses that start with 111.222. The secondary nodes are the ones that IP addresses that start with 333.444. All nodes use port 18532. gateway-peering-cluster-create 1 "111.222.125.2:18532,111.222.126.2:18532, 111.222.127.2:18532" "333.444.125.2:18532,333.444.126.2:18532,333.444.127.2:18532"

entry.name: gateway_peering_cluster_create_kglobalconfig_descr_30
entry.text: Creates a gateway peering cluster.

entry.name: host_alias_kglobalconfig_help_31
entry.text:
Enters Host Alias Configuration Mode. In this mode, you can map an IP address with an alias.
alias The alias to be assigned to a specified IP address.
For example:
host-alias Ragnarok Enters Host Alias Configuration Mode for the alias named Ragnarok. ip-address 192.168.12.12 Maps alias Ragnarok to IP address 192.168.12.12.

entry.name: host_alias_kglobalconfig_descr_31
entry.text: Enters Host Alias Configuration Mode.

entry.name: host_alias_kconfigcrypto_help_32
entry.text:
Enters Host Alias Configuration Mode and creates a named host alias. alias is the name of the newly created host alias. For example:
host-alias Local-1 Enters Host Alias Configuration Mode and creates a host alias named Local-1

entry.name: host_alias_kconfigcrypto_descr_32
entry.text: Enters Host Alias Configuration Mode

entry.name: httpserv_kglobalconfig_help_33
entry.text:
When executed with a single argument, server-name, enters HTTP server Configuration Mode and creates the named HTTP server. HTTP Configuration Mode supports enhanced server configuration options. For example:
httpserv Server-1 Enters HTTP Server Configuration Mode and creates the named HTTP server
When executed with multiple arguments,creates a named HTTP server on the specified IP address and port pair. For example:
httpserv CustomerSupport 192.168.0.6 80 creates an HTTP server (named CustomerSupport) on the specified IP address and port number

entry.name: httpserv_kglobalconfig_descr_33
entry.text: Creates an HTTP server.

entry.name: acl_httpservice_help_34
entry.text:
Assigns an Access Control List (ACL) to the HTTP service. Assignment of an ACL to a HTTP service is optional. If an ACL is assigned to the service, only those IP addresses specifically allowed by the ACL can initiate access to the HTTP service on the DataPower Gateway; if an ACL is not assigned, access to the HTTP service is unrestricted.
name Specifics the name of an ACL.

entry.name: acl_httpservice_descr_34
entry.text: Assigns an ACL

entry.name: identifier_httpservice_help_35
entry.text:
The "Server" response header field generally contains information (name and version) that describes the server application software. By default, inclusion of the "Server" response header field is suppressed.
NOTE: Consider security implications before revealing software version information.
string The contents of the "Server" response header field. Use double quotes to bracket strings that contain spaces.

entry.name: identifier_httpservice_descr_35
entry.text: Specifies the contents of the Server header field

entry.name: local_address_httpservice_help_36
entry.text:
Specifies the HTTP server local address. ip-address The local interface monitored by the HTTP server for incoming HTTP client requests. port-number is an integer within the range 0 to 65535 that identifies the port monitored by the HTTP server for incoming HTTP client requests. For example:
local-address 192.168.10.10 8080 Specifies that the HTTP server monitors port 8080 on 192.168.10.10.

entry.name: local_address_httpservice_descr_36
entry.text: Specify the local address and port

entry.name: port_httpservice_descr_37
entry.text: Specify the local port

entry.name: local_directory_httpservice_help_38
entry.text:
Identifies the directory from which the HTTP server serves documents.
config: references the configuration directory image: references the firmware image directory store: references the general storage directory temporary: references the temporary directory For example:
local-directory temporary: identifies temporary: as the served directory

entry.name: local_directory_httpservice_descr_38
entry.text: Specify the local root HTTP directory

entry.name: start_page_httpservice_help_39
entry.text:
Specifies an HTML file to display when an HTTP client accesses the server. file-name The target file. In the absence of a specified start-page, the HTTP server displays a file directory. For example:
start-page store:///welcome.html Identifies the HTML file initially displayed by the HTTP server

entry.name: start_page_httpservice_descr_39
entry.text: Specify the start page

entry.name: mode_httpservice_help_40
entry.text:
Use the keyword echo to specify a loopback server. For example:
mode echo The operational mode

entry.name: mode_httpservice_descr_40
entry.text: Specify HTTP server operating mode

entry.name: priority_httpservice_help_41
entry.text: Assigns a priority for scheduling or for resource allocation. When system resources are in high demand, higher priority services will be favored over lower priority services. low Receives below normal priority. normal (Default) Receives normal priority. high Receives above normal priority.

entry.name: priority_httpservice_descr_41
entry.text: Assigns a service-level scheduling priority

entry.name: ims_kglobalconfig_help_42
entry.text:
Enters IMS configuration mode and creates a named IMS Connect object.
name The name of the IMS Connect object.

entry.name: ims_kglobalconfig_descr_42
entry.text: Enters IMS Connect configuration mode

entry.name: source_imsconnect_kglobalconfig_help_43
entry.text:
Enters IMS Connect Handler configuration mode and creates a named IMS Connect Handler object.
name The name of the IMS Connect Handler object.

entry.name: source_imsconnect_kglobalconfig_descr_43
entry.text: Enters IMS Connect Handler configuration mode

entry.name: include_config_kglobalconfig_help_44
entry.text:
Enters Include Configuration Configuration Mode. In the mode, you can create an include configuration object. The include configuration object references a local or remote configuration file. The referenced configuration file might be included in other configuration files.
name is the name of the include configuration object.
For example:
include-config standardServiceProxies creates the standardServiceProxies configuration object and enters Include Configuration Configuration Mode.

entry.name: include_config_kglobalconfig_descr_44
entry.text: Creates an include configuration object.

entry.name: input_conversion_map_kglobalconfig_help_45
entry.text:
Enters HTTP Input Conversion Map Configuration Mode, and creates a named input-conversion-map. name The name of the input-conversion-map. For example:
input-conversion-map ICM-1 Enters HTTP Input Conversion Map Configuration Mode, and creates an input-conversion-map named ICM-1.

entry.name: input_conversion_map_kglobalconfig_descr_45
entry.text: Enters HTTP Input Conversion Map Configuration Mode

entry.name: known_host_kglobalconfig_help_46
entry.text:
Adds an SSH peer as an SSH known host. host The fully-qualified host name or IP address for the peer. key-type "ssh-rsa" identifies RSA as the key type. key specifies the host public key for the peer.
For example:
known-host ragnarok.datapower.com ssh-rsa AAAAB3NzaC1yc2EAAAABIwAAAIEA1J/99rRvdZmVvkaKvcG2a+PeCm25p8OJl87SA6mtFxudA2ME6n3lcXEakpQ8KFTpPbBXt+yDKNFR9gNHIfRlUDho1HAN/a0gEsvrnDY5wKrTcRHrqDc/x0buPzbsEmXi0lud5Pl7+BXQVpPbyVujoHINCrx0k/z7Qpkozb4qZd8= adds an SSH peer as an SSH known host.

entry.name: known_host_kglobalconfig_descr_46
entry.text: Adds an SSH peer as an SSH known host.

entry.name: loadbalancer_group_kglobalconfig_help_47
entry.text:
Enters Load Balancer Group Configuration Mode and creates the specified load balancer group. name is the name of the newly-created load balancer group For example:
loadbalancer-group LBGroup-1 Enters Event Load Balancer Group Configuration Mode and creates the load balancer group, LBGroup-1

entry.name: loadbalancer_group_kglobalconfig_descr_47
entry.text: Enters Load Balancer Group Configuration Mode

entry.name: logging_category_kglobalconfig_help_48
entry.text:
Creates a custom log category and enters Log Category Configuration Mode.
categoryName is the name of the newly created log category.
For example:
logging category CryptoLogCategory enters Log Category Configuration Mode an creates the CryptoLogCategory log category.

entry.name: logging_category_kglobalconfig_descr_48
entry.text: Creates a custom log category.

entry.name: logging_target_kglobalconfig_help_49
entry.text:
Enters Logging Configuration Mode and creates the specified logging target. name is the name of the newly-created log. For example:
logging target CryptoLog Enters Event Logging Configuration Mode and creates the event log, CryptoLog

entry.name: logging_target_kglobalconfig_descr_49
entry.text: Enters Logging Configuration Mode

entry.name: matching_kglobalconfig_help_50
entry.text:
Enters Matching Rule Configuration and creates a named match template that can be used to implement policy-based XSL filtering and transformations and XML schema validation. name is the name of the newly-created match template. For example:
matching Star Enters Matching Rule Configuration Mode, and creates a match template named Star

entry.name: matching_kglobalconfig_descr_50
entry.text: Enters Matching Rule Configuration Mode

entry.name: message_matching_kglobalconfig_help_51
entry.text:
Enters Message Matching Configuration Mode and creates a named traffic-flow definition. A traffic-flow definition describes a traffic stream that is subject to administrative monitoring and control. name The name of the traffic-flow definition. For example:
message-matching TFDef1 Enters Message Matching Configuration Mode and creates a traffic-flow definition named TFDef1

entry.name: message_matching_kglobalconfig_descr_51
entry.text: Enters Message Matching Configuration Mode

entry.name: message_type_kglobalconfig_help_52
entry.text:
Enters Message Type Configuration Mode and creates a named message class. A message class is a list of one or more traffic-flow definitions, and identifies a traffic stream that is subject to administrative monitoring and control. name is the name of the message class. For example:
message-type Extranet Enters Message Type Configuration Mode and creates a message class named Extranet

entry.name: message_type_kglobalconfig_descr_52
entry.text: Enters Message Type Configuration Mode

entry.name: metadata_kglobalconfig_help_53
entry.text:
Enters Processing Metadata Configuration Mode and creates a named object if it does not exist. If the object exists, allows for editing the object. A Processing Metadata object contains a list or manifest, of metadata items that are returned in an XML nodeset to the object using the Metadata. This is typically an AAA Policy. name is the name of the Processing Metadata object. For example:
metadata HttpHeaders creates a Processing Metadata object named "HttpHeaders" and enters Processing Metadata configuration mode.

entry.name: metadata_kglobalconfig_descr_53
entry.text: Enters Processing Metadata Configuration Mode

entry.name: soap_disposition_kglobalconfig_help_54
entry.text:
Enters SOAP Header Disposition Table Mode and creates a named object if it does not exist. If the object exists, allows for editing the object.
A SOAP Header Disposition Table object contains a list of instructions provided by customers to control how the SOAP headers and/or children elements are handled. This object is used by an "xform" action with store:///soap-refine.xsl.
name The name of the SOAP Header Disposition Table object. For example:
soap-disposition header-processor Creates a soap-disposition object named "header-processor" and enters SOAP Header Disposition Table configuration mode.

entry.name: soap_disposition_kglobalconfig_descr_54
entry.text: Enters SOAP Header Disposition Table Mode

entry.name: monitor_action_kglobalconfig_help_55
entry.text:
Enters Message Filter Action Configuration Mode and creates a named control procedure. A control procedure is an action or set of actions that are implemented when a monitored message class exceeds a configured threshold value. name The name of the newly-created control procedure. For example:
monitor-action Squelch Enters Message Filter Action Configuration Mode and creates a control procedure named Squelch

entry.name: monitor_action_kglobalconfig_descr_55
entry.text: Enters Message Filter Action Configuration Mode

entry.name: monitor_count_kglobalconfig_help_56
entry.text:
Enters Monitor Count Configuration Mode and creates a named incremental monitor. An incremental monitor consists of a target (a monitored message class), a configured threshold, and a control procedure that is triggered when the message class exceeds the threshold value. name The name of the newly-created incremental monitor. For example:
monitor-count Squelch Enters Monitor Count Configuration Mode and creates an incremental monitor named Squelch

entry.name: monitor_count_kglobalconfig_descr_56
entry.text: Enters Monitor Count Configuration Mode

entry.name: monitor_duration_kglobalconfig_help_57
entry.text:
Enters Message Duration Monitor Configuration Mode and creates a named duration monitor. A duration monitor gathers statistics on certain internal and external processing transactions. name The name of the newly-created duration monitor. For example:
monitor-duration RateLimit1 Enters Message Duration Monitor Configuration Mode and creates a duration monitor named Ratelimit1

entry.name: monitor_duration_kglobalconfig_descr_57
entry.text: Enters Message Duration Monitor Configuration Mode

entry.name: mtom_kglobalconfig_help_58
entry.text: An MTOM policy provides a mechanism for optimizing the transmission and wire format of an XML/SOAP message. Optimization is performed by selecting elements with base64-encoded character data. The selected elements are decoded and attached as MIME attachment parts before transmission. Decoding before transmission reduces the overhead that is associated with base64-encoded data.

entry.name: mtom_kglobalconfig_descr_58
entry.text: Defines an MTOM policy.

entry.name: include_content_type_mtompolicy_help_59
entry.text:
Determines whether the processing of the MTOM policy adds the "contentType" attribute to output messages when the input message does not contain this attribute. If the input message contains this attribute, the MTOM policy passes through the "contentType" attribute regardless of the setting for the "include-content-type" command.
on (Default) Adds the attribute to the output message. off Does not add the attribute to the output message.

entry.name: include_content_type_mtompolicy_descr_59
entry.text: Indicates whether to include the contentType attribute.

entry.name: mode_mtompolicy_help_60
entry.text:
Specify encode or decode.
The encode option optimizes (serializes) input messages. For serialization, provide an XPath expression or a list of XPath expressions to identify the content to extract. Optionally, per XPath expression, exercise control over the Content Type and Content ID values. These two values can be determined automatically using the xmlmime:contentType declaration and namespace declaration.
The decode option decodes (deserializes) attachment parts of an optimized message. Deserialization, by default, reassembles the original infoset, which results in either a SOAP document or MIME document depending on whether all attachments were referenced by Include elements. Optionally, you can specify a Content ID to select individual attachment parts to reassemble.

entry.name: mode_mtompolicy_descr_60
entry.text: Selects the MTOM optimization mode.

entry.name: rule_mtompolicy_help_61
entry.text:
Each MTOM rule describes which message elements to optimize. A single XPath expression selects one or more elements for optimization.
The XPath expression property defines which schema element or schema elements are subject to this rule.
The Content Type property overrides the value that is attained from the xmlmime:contentType attribute. If the provided XPath matches more than one element, each corresponding MIME attachment part will contain a content-type header with this value. If different content-type values are required, selective XPath expressions are required.
If not explicitly configured, content IDs are automatically generated. Using this property allows for the explicit configuration of content-id headers and their associated href values. Rules that match multiple data elements result in one attachment part for all matched elements. The resulting attachment part contains data from the last match only.
The following are examples of MTOM rules. rule "myelement" rule "myelement" "my-content-type-value" "my-content-id-value"

entry.name: rule_mtompolicy_descr_61
entry.text: Creates an MTOM policy rule.

entry.name: mq_qm_kglobalconfig_help_62
entry.text:
Enters IBM MQ Queue Manager Configuration Mode and creates a named IBM MQ queue manager. name is the name of the newly-created IBM MQ queue manager. For example:
mq-qm QMan-1 Enters IBM MQ Queue Manager Configuration Mode and creates a queue manager named QMan-1

entry.name: mq_qm_kglobalconfig_descr_62
entry.text: Enters IBM MQ Queue Manager Configuration Mode

entry.name: mq_qm_group_kglobalconfig_help_63
entry.text:
Enters IBM MQ Queue Manager Group Configuration Mode and creates a named IBM MQ queue manager group that provides a redundant failover configuration is the event of Queue Manager loss. groupName is the name of the newly-created IBM MQ queue manager group. For example:
mq-qm-group redundantMQ Enters IBM MQ Queue Manager Group Configuration Mode and creates a queue manager group named redundantMQ

entry.name: mq_qm_group_kglobalconfig_descr_63
entry.text: Enters IBM MQ Queue Manager Group Configuration Mode

entry.name: network_kglobalconfig_help_64
entry.text: Enters Network Settings Configuration Mode.

entry.name: network_kglobalconfig_descr_64
entry.text: Enters Network Settings Configuration Mode

entry.name: nfs_client_kglobalconfig_help_65
entry.text: Enters NFS Client Configuration Mode. Used to enable the NFS client, and configure global settings for NFS in all application domains.

entry.name: nfs_client_kglobalconfig_descr_65
entry.text: Enters NFS Client Configuration Mode

entry.name: nfs_dynamic_mounts_kglobalconfig_help_66
entry.text: Enters NFS Dynamic Mounts Configuration Mode. Used to enable NFS dynamic mounts in an application domain, and to configure the options for such mounts.

entry.name: nfs_dynamic_mounts_kglobalconfig_descr_66
entry.text: Enters NFS Dynamic Mounts Configuration Mode

entry.name: nfs_static_mount_kglobalconfig_help_67
entry.text:
Enters NFS Static Mount Configuration Mode, and creates a named NFS static mount in an application domain. name the name of this NFS static mount. Files exported on this mount may be accessed using URLs of the form dpfns://name/. If filesystem access is allowed, they are also available as the directory nfs-name:. For example:
nfs-static-mount server3 Enters nfs-static-mount configuration mode, and creates a static mount named server3.

entry.name: nfs_static_mount_kglobalconfig_descr_67
entry.text: Enters NFS Static Mount Configuration Mode

entry.name: ntp_service_kglobalconfig_help_68
entry.text: Enters NTP Service Configuration Mode. In this mode, you can configure the DataPower Gateway to function as an NTP client.

entry.name: ntp_service_kglobalconfig_descr_68
entry.text: Enters NTP Service Configuration Mode.

entry.name: peer_group_kglobalconfig_help_69
entry.text:
Creates the specified Peer Group and enters Peer Group Configuration Mode.
peer-group The name of the peer group to create.
For example:
peer-group SLM-Group1 Creates the SLM-Group1 peer group and enters Peer Group Configuration Mode.

entry.name: peer_group_kglobalconfig_descr_69
entry.text: Creates a peer group.

entry.name: radius_kglobalconfig_help_70
entry.text: Enters RADIUS Configuration Mode.

entry.name: radius_kglobalconfig_descr_70
entry.text: Enters RADIUS Configuration Mode

entry.name: password_alias_kglobalconfig_help_71
entry.text:
Do not use the password-alias commands to manage the mapping between passwords and their alias. Use the password-map command to add or delete a mapping. To change the password for an alias, you must delete and re-create the mapping.
For example, assuming Global mode: # crypto # password-map Interactively create mappings.
# crypto # delete password-map myAlias Delete the myAlias map.

entry.name: password_alias_kglobalconfig_descr_71
entry.text: Do not use. Use Crypto password-map

entry.name: raid_activate_kglobalconfig_help_72
entry.text:
Activate a hard disk array volume that is in the inactive state, typically in "foreign volume" state. name The name of the existing hard disk array volume. For devices that have a hard disk array for auxiliary data storage, the name is "raid0". For example:
raid-activate raid0 activate the RAID Volume in the disks as the active RAID Volume.

entry.name: raid_activate_kglobalconfig_descr_72
entry.text: Activate an array volume

entry.name: raid_change_encryption_settings_kglobalconfig_help_73
entry.text:
Changes the encryption settings for the document storage partition on the RAID volume. The initial encryption settings is to encrypt the partition with the internal key of the DataPower Gateway. After changing the encryption setting, the RAID volume is rebuilt.
Attention: If you use a passphrase for encryption and lose this passphrase, the data cannot be recovered after a device failure. If this occurs, you will be required to replace the DataPower Gateway.
Before modifying RAID settings, the RAID volume must be in the "disabled" administrative state.
name The name of the existing hard disk array volume. The name is raid0. encrypt Indicates whether to encrypt the partition. on (Default) Encrypts the partition. off Makes the partition unencrypted. method Indicates the method to encrypt the partition. internal (Default) Uses the internal system key. passphrase Uses the specified passphrase. passphrase The passphrase to encrypt the partition.

entry.name: raid_change_encryption_settings_kglobalconfig_descr_73
entry.text: Changes the encryption settings on the document storage partition

entry.name: raid_delete_kglobalconfig_help_74
entry.text:
Make the disks that are presently a hard disk array Volume on the device no longer an array volume, removing all metadata. This action destroys the content of the array volume. name The name of the existing hard disk array volume. For devices that have a hard disk array for auxiliary data storage, the name is "raid0". For example:
raid-delete raid0 delete the hard disk array volume on the disks.

entry.name: raid_delete_kglobalconfig_descr_74
entry.text: Delete an array volume

entry.name: raid_initialize_kglobalconfig_help_75
entry.text:
Make the two disks into a hard disk array volume. This action destroys any prior content of the array volume. name The name of the existing hard disk array volume. For devices that have a hard disk array for auxiliary data storage, the name is "raid0". For example:
raid-initialize raid0 build a RAID-1 Volume on the disks on the system.

entry.name: raid_initialize_kglobalconfig_descr_75
entry.text: Initialize an array volume

entry.name: raid_reconcile_encryption_settings_kglobalconfig_help_76
entry.text:
Reconciles the encryption settings for the document storage partition on a foreign volume before activating the RAID volume. The initial encryption settings is to encrypt the partition with the internal key of the DataPower Gateway. If you changed encryption settings, use this command to match the settings for the foreign volume to those in the DataPower Gateway configuration.
Before modifying RAID settings, the RAID volume must be in the "disabled" administrative state.
name The name of the existing hard disk array volume. The name is raid0. encrypt Indicates whether to encrypt the partition. on (Default) Encrypts the partition. off Makes the partition unencrypted. method Indicates the method to encrypt the partition. internal (Default) Uses the internal system key. passphrase Uses the specified passphrase. passphrase The passphrase to encrypt the partition.
For example to verify the status of the document storage partition, match the settings, and activate the RAID volume, use the following command sequence. # configure terminal (config)# show raid-partitions ... (config)# raid-volume raid0 Modify RAID Array configuration (config raid-volume raid0)# admin-state disabled (config raid-volume raid0)# exit (config)# raid-reconcile-encryption-settings on internal (config)# raid-activate raid0 (config)# raid-volume raid0 Modify RAID Array configuration (config raid-volume raid0)# admin-state enabled (config raid-volume raid0)# exit

entry.name: raid_reconcile_encryption_settings_kglobalconfig_descr_76
entry.text: Reconciles the encryption settings on a foreign volume before activation

entry.name: raid_rebuild_kglobalconfig_help_77
entry.text:
Force a rebuild of a hard disk array volume. The contents of the primary disk in the array volume will be copied to the secondary disk. name The name of the existing hard disk array volume. For devices that have a hard disk array for auxiliary data storage, the name is "raid0". For example:
raid-rebuild raid0 rebuild the array volume raid0.

entry.name: raid_rebuild_kglobalconfig_descr_77
entry.text: Force a rebuild of an array volume

entry.name: raid_make_hot_spare_kglobalconfig_help_78
entry.text:
Make all disk drives on the system that are not presently part of the RAID volume into global hot spares, so that the RAID controller will use them to replace failed disk drives that have been removed. This is done after you replace a failed disk drive with a blank one. The RAID controller will then automatically use it to replace the missing disk drive, and copy the data onto it. For example:
raid-make-hot-spare raid0 make hot spare disks and rebuild the array volume raid0.

entry.name: raid_make_hot_spare_kglobalconfig_descr_78
entry.text: Make hot spare disks for an array volume

entry.name: raid_learn_battery_kglobalconfig_help_79
entry.text:
Perform the battery learning cycle. The RAID controller has a Battery Backup Unit for write cache. The learning cycle is a battery calibration operation and the build in battery has to pass through it to determine the condition of the battery. The RAID controller will perform this automatically, but you can use this command to manually execute this process. For example:
raid-learn-battery Request to start the battery learning cycle of the RAID card.

entry.name: raid_learn_battery_kglobalconfig_descr_79
entry.text: Perform the battery learning cycle of the RAID card

entry.name: raid_volume_kglobalconfig_help_80
entry.text:
Enters RAID Array mode for the RAID volume.
name The name of the RAID volume. The name is "raid0".

entry.name: raid_volume_kglobalconfig_descr_80
entry.text: Enters RAID Array mode

entry.name: directory_raidvolume_help_81
entry.text:
Specifies the directory under which to make the files on the hard disk array available in the local: and logstore: directories in each application domain. name The name of the subdirectory. For example:
directory disk make the files on the hard disk array accessible in local:///disk/ and logstore:///disk/ directories.

entry.name: directory_raidvolume_descr_81
entry.text: Specifies the name of the directory

entry.name: read_only_raidvolume_help_82
entry.text:
Indicates whether access to the RAID volume is read-only or read/write. With the B2B feature, this value must be set to "off". Although this value is ignored, the "on" value generates a warning. B2B storage requires write access to the RAID volume.
on Access to the RAID volume is read-only. off Access to the RAID volume is read/write.

entry.name: read_only_raidvolume_descr_82
entry.text: Sets access permission for the RAID volume.

entry.name: raid_volume_initialize_filesystem_kglobalconfig_help_83
entry.text:
Initializes the file system on the RAID volume to allow it to be made active. This action destroys the existing contents of the hard disk array.
- Unencrypted: raid-volume-initialize-filesystem <name> off - Encrypted: raid-volume-initialize-filesystem <name> on passphrase <passphrase>
name The name of the existing RAID volume. The name is "raid0". encrypt Whether to encrypt the RAID volume. There is no default value. on - Encrypts the RAID volume. off - Does not encrypt the RAID volume. mechanism The keyword "passphrase" that identifies the encryption mechanism. passphrase The passphrase to use to encrypt the RAID volume.
For example: - Makes a new, unencrypted file system on the raid0 RAID volume. raid-volume-initialize-filesystem raid0 off - Makes a new, encrypted file system on the raid0 RAID volume using p2ssphAs3 as the encryption value. raid-volume-initialize-filesystem raid0 on passphrase p2ssphAs3

entry.name: raid_volume_initialize_filesystem_kglobalconfig_descr_83
entry.text: Initialize the file system on a RAID volume.

entry.name: raid_volume_repair_filesystem_kglobalconfig_help_84
entry.text:
Repairs the file system on a hard disk array volume in case it was corrupted by an abnormal shutdown of the device or other error. name The name of the existing hard disk array volume. For devices that have a hard disk array for auxiliary data storage, the name is "raid0". For example:
raid-volume-repair-filesystem raid0 repairs the file system on the hard disk array volume raid0.

entry.name: raid_volume_repair_filesystem_kglobalconfig_descr_84
entry.text: Repair filesystem on a RAID Volume

entry.name: rbm_kglobalconfig_help_85
entry.text: Enters RBM Settings Configuration Mode.

entry.name: rbm_kglobalconfig_descr_85
entry.text: Enters RBM (Role Based Management) Settings Configuration Mode

entry.name: refresh_tam_certs_kglobalconfig_help_86
entry.text:
Refreshes an IBM Security Access Manager client certificate and refreshes the password of the keystore containing the certificate. Note that all IBM Security Access Manager objects which use the same keystore will be restarted during the operation.
tam-object the name of an IBM Security Access Manager object defined in the current domain. The keystore configured in this object contains the client certificate which is refreshed. The keystore password is also refreshed.
admin The IBM Security Access Manager server administrator identifier. password The administrator's password

entry.name: refresh_tam_certs_kglobalconfig_descr_86
entry.text: Refresh IBM Security Access Manager Client Certificate

entry.name: refresh_tam_keystore_pwd_kglobalconfig_help_87
entry.text:
Refreshes an IBM Security Access Manager keystore password. Note: All IBM Security Access Manager objects that use the same keystore will be restarted during the operation.
tam-object The name of an IBM Security Access Manager object. The keystore in this object uses the password that is being refreshed.

entry.name: refresh_tam_keystore_pwd_kglobalconfig_descr_87
entry.text: Refresh IBM Security Access Manager Keystore Password

entry.name: request_rule_stylepolicy_help_88
entry.text:
Enters Stylesheet Rule Configuration Mode, and creates a request rule. match-template The name of a match template that defines candidate documents. For example:
request-rule Star Enters Stylesheet Rule Configuration Mode, and creates a request rule. This rules uses the Star match template as the source of match patterns.

entry.name: request_rule_stylepolicy_descr_88
entry.text: Enters Stylesheet Rule Configuration Mode

entry.name: reset_analytics_endpoint_kglobalconfig_help_89
entry.text: Resets the counters for an analytics endpoint.

entry.name: reset_analytics_endpoint_kglobalconfig_descr_89
entry.text: Resets the counters for an analytics endpoint

entry.name: reset_websocket_connections_counters_kglobalconfig_help_90
entry.text:
Resets the WebSocket connection counters for a specific assembly action. To identify the handler, action class, and action name for an assembly action, use the "show websocket-connections" command.
handler Specifies the HTTP or HTTPS handler. action_class Specifies the class for the assembly action. action_name Specifies the name of the assembly action.

entry.name: reset_websocket_connections_counters_kglobalconfig_descr_90
entry.text: Resets the WebSocket connection counters for a specific assembly action

entry.name: reset_websocket_connections_all_counters_kglobalconfig_help_91
entry.text: Resets the WebSocket connection counters for all assembly actions.

entry.name: reset_websocket_connections_all_counters_kglobalconfig_descr_91
entry.text: Resets the WebSocket connection counters for all assembly actions

entry.name: reset_domain_kglobalconfig_help_92
entry.text:
Reset of the default domain is deprecated. Use the "shutdown reload" command for the default domain. Deletes the configuration for a domain. In the absence of an explicit domain, deletes the configuration for the current domain.
The primary difference between the no domain command and this command is that with the reset domain command you do not need to redefine the configuration for the affected domain.
domainName specifies the name of the domain to reset.
For example:
reset domain Test resets the Test domain (from the default domain).

entry.name: reset_domain_kglobalconfig_descr_92
entry.text: Deletes the configuration for a domain.

entry.name: reset_ssh_keys_kglobalconfig_help_93
entry.text:
Deletes and re-creates SSH host keys. Previously created keys are removed and replaced with new keys. - Without the "include-dsa" parameter, only RSA keys are re-created. DSA keys are not re-created. - With the "include-dsa" parameters, both DSA and RSA keys are re-created.
This action does not impact host keys that you added to the known hosts table through the crypto tools.
Active DataPower SSH sessions might be terminated when you reset host keys. Because private and public portions of the host key change, previously distributed public keys will no longer work. SSH clients will encounter errors when they attempt to reconnect and must delete the public keys from their known hosts collection and accept new keys when attempting to reconnect.
include-dsa Indicates to include DSA keys.
For example:
reset-ssh-keys Deletes all keys and re-creates only RSA keys. reset-ssh-keys include-dsa Deletes all keys and re-creates both DSA and RSA keys.

entry.name: reset_ssh_keys_kglobalconfig_descr_93
entry.text: Deletes and re-creates SSH host keys.

entry.name: response_rule_stylepolicy_help_94
entry.text:
Enters Stylesheet Rule Configuration Mode, and creates a response-rule (a rule that is applied only to server- originated documents) that is added to the current Stylesheet Policy. match-template The name of a match template that defines a set of URLs and/or HTTP match conditions. Candidate documents belonging to the defined set are subject to this response-rule. For example:
response-rule Star Enters Stylesheet Rule Configuration Mode, and creates a response-rule in the current Stylesheet Policy -- the response-rule uses the Star match template as the source of match patterns

entry.name: response_rule_stylepolicy_descr_94
entry.text: Enters Stylesheet Rule Configuration Mode

entry.name: restart_domain_kglobalconfig_help_95
entry.text:
Restart of the default domain is deprecated. Use the "shutdown reload" command for the default domain. Restores a domain to the state defined by its startup configuration. In the absence of an explicit domain, restarts the current domain.
domainName is the name of the domain to restart.
For example:
restart domain AcceptanceCriteria restarts the AcceptanceCriteria domain.

entry.name: restart_domain_kglobalconfig_descr_95
entry.text: Restores a domain.

entry.name: rule_kglobalconfig_help_96
entry.text:
Enters Stylesheet Policy Rule Configuration Mode, and creates a named processing rule. Once in Stylesheet Policy Rule Configuration Mode, you add specific processing instructions to the rule. name The unique name for the processing rule. The optional request and response keywords specify the rule's "direction." A request rule is applied only to client-originated documents. A response rule is applied only to server-originated documents. If no keyword is provided, the rule is "bi-directional"-- that is applied to both client-originated and server-originated documents. For example:
rule validateClient request Enters Stylesheet Policy Rule Configuration Mode, and creates a processing rule, named validateClient, that is applied to client-originated documents

entry.name: rule_kglobalconfig_descr_96
entry.text: Enters Stylesheet Policy Rule Configuration Mode

entry.name: rule_stylepolicy_help_97
entry.text:
Enters Stylesheet Policy Rule Configuration Mode, and creates a bidirectional rule (a rule that is applied to both client-originated and server-originated documents) that is added to the current Stylesheet Policy. match-template The name of a match template that defines a set of URLs and/or HTTP match conditions. Candidate documents belonging to the defined set are subject to this rule. For example:
rule Star Enters Stylesheet Policy Rule Configuration Mode, and creates a bidirectional rule. The rule uses the Star match template as the source of match patterns.

entry.name: rule_stylepolicy_descr_97
entry.text: Enters Stylesheet Policy Rule Configuration Mode

entry.name: schema_exception_map_kglobalconfig_help_98
entry.text:
Enters Schema Exception Map Configuration Mode and creates a named schema Exception Map. name The name of the Schema Exception Map. For example:
schema-exception-map SEM-1 Enters Schema Exception Map Configuration Mode and creates a Schema Exception Map named SEM-1

entry.name: schema_exception_map_kglobalconfig_descr_98
entry.text: Enters Schema Exception Map Configuration Mode

entry.name: service_monitor_kglobalconfig_help_99
entry.text:
Creates the specified Web Service Monitor and enters Web Service Monitor Configuration Mode, or enters Web Service Monitor Configuration Mode and accesses the specified Web Service Monitor.
When in Web Service Monitor Configuration Mode, you can configure the target Web Service Monitor to perform WSDL-aware monitoring.
name The name of the Web Service Monitor.
For example:
service-monitor WSMonitor-2 enters Web Service Monitor Configuration Mode and creates the WSMonitor-2 Web Service Monitor.

entry.name: service_monitor_kglobalconfig_descr_99
entry.text: Creates a new Web Service Monitor.

entry.name: simple_rate_limiter_kglobalconfig_help_100
entry.text:
Enters Simple Rate Limiter Configuration Mode and creates a new Simple Rate Limiter Policy named name. For example:
simple-rate-limiter portal-limit-policy Enters Simple Rate Limiter Configuration Mode and creates a Policy named portal-limit-policy. This new Policy may then be used in a Web Request Profile.

entry.name: simple_rate_limiter_kglobalconfig_descr_100
entry.text: Enters Simple Rate Limiter Configuration Mode

entry.name: slm_action_kglobalconfig_help_101
entry.text:
Creates the specified Service Level Monitor (SLM) Action and enters SLM Action Configuration Mode.
When in SLM Action Configuration Mode, you can define the administrative response by defining the action type (log, reject, or shape traffic) and specify a log priority.
name The name of the SLM Action.
For example:
slm-action MinorPenalty enters SLM Action Configuration Mode and creates the MinorPenalty SLM Action.

entry.name: slm_action_kglobalconfig_descr_101
entry.text: Creates a Service Level Monitor Action.

entry.name: slm_cred_kglobalconfig_help_102
entry.text:
Creates the specified Service Level Monitor (SLM) Credential Class and enters SLM Credential Class Configuration Mode.
When in SLM Credential Class Configuration Mode, you can define a group of credential that are subject to an SLM policy and the optional match conditions to be used in conjunction with the defined credential group.
slmCredName The name of the SLM Credential Class.
For example:
slm-cred ExtranetPartner enters SLM Credential Class Configuration Mode and creates the ExtranetPartner SLM Credential Class.

entry.name: slm_cred_kglobalconfig_descr_102
entry.text: Creates a Service Level Monitor Credential Class.

entry.name: slm_policy_kglobalconfig_help_103
entry.text:
Creates the specified Service Level Monitor (SLM) Policy and enters SLM Policy Configuration Mode.
When in SLM Policy Configuration Mode, you define a policy by specifying an evaluation method, noting peer groups, and assigning statement to the policy.
slmPolicyName is the name of the SLM Policy.
For example:
slm-policy SLM-Policy-1 Enters SLM Policy Configuration Mode and creates the SLM-Policy-1 SLM Policy.

entry.name: slm_policy_kglobalconfig_descr_103
entry.text: Creates a Service Level Monitor Policy.

entry.name: slm_rsrc_kglobalconfig_help_104
entry.text:
Creates the specified Service Level Monitor (SLM) Resource Class and enters SLM Resource Class Configuration Mode.
When in SLM Resource Class Configuration Mode, you define a set of resources that are subject to an SLM Policy.
slmResourceName The name of the SLM Resource Class.
For example:
slm-rsrc ProfitLossStatements enters SLM Resource Class Configuration Mode and creates the ProfitLossStatements SLM Resource Class.

entry.name: slm_rsrc_kglobalconfig_descr_104
entry.text: Creates a Service Level Monitor Resource Class.

entry.name: slm_sched_kglobalconfig_help_105
entry.text:
Creates the specified Service Level Monitor (SLM) Schedule and enters SLM Schedule Configuration Mode.
When in SLM Schedule Configuration Mode, you define an SLM Schedule by specifying the days and hours when the schedule is in effect.
slmScheduleName The name of the SLM Schedule.
For example:
slm-sched WeekEnds enters SLM Schedule Configuration Mode and creates the WeekEnds SLM Schedule.

entry.name: slm_sched_kglobalconfig_descr_105
entry.text: Creates a Service Level Monitor Schedule.

entry.name: snmp_kglobalconfig_help_106
entry.text: Enters SNMP Configuration Mode.

entry.name: snmp_kglobalconfig_descr_106
entry.text: Enters SNMP Configuration Mode

entry.name: source_ssh_server_kglobalconfig_help_107
entry.text:
Enters SFTP Server Handler Configuration Mode, and creates a named SFTP Server. sshServerName identifies the newly created SFTP Server. For example:
source-ssh-server sftpServer-1 Enters SFTP Server Handler Configuration Mode, creates the named handler, sftpServer-1

entry.name: source_ssh_server_kglobalconfig_descr_107
entry.text: Enters SFTP Server Handler Configuration Mode

entry.name: source_mq_kglobalconfig_help_108
entry.text:
Enters IBM MQ Handler Handler Configuration Mode, and creates a named IBM MQ Client Handler. mqHandlerName identifies the newly created IBM MQ Client Handler. For example:
source-mq webSphereHandler-1 Enters IBM MQ Handler Configuration Mode, creates the named handler, webSphereHandler-1

entry.name: source_mq_kglobalconfig_descr_108
entry.text: Enters IBM MQ Handler Configuration Mode

entry.name: source_raw_kglobalconfig_help_109
entry.text:
Enters Stateless Raw XML Handler Configuration Mode, and creates the named stateless TCP handler.
name The name of the stateless handler.
For example:
source-raw SansTCPHandler Enters Stateless Raw XML Handler Configuration Mode, and creates the "SansTCPHandler" handler.

entry.name: source_raw_kglobalconfig_descr_109
entry.text: Enters Stateless Raw XML Handler Configuration Mode

entry.name: source_stateful_tcp_kglobalconfig_help_110
entry.text:
Enters Stateful Raw XML Handler Handler Configuration Mode, and creates the named stateful TCP handler. name The name of the stateful handler. For example:
source-stateful-tcp AvecTCPHandler Enters Stateful Raw XML Handler Configuration Mode, and creates the "AvecTCPHandler" handler.

entry.name: source_stateful_tcp_kglobalconfig_descr_110
entry.text: Enters Stateful Raw XML Handler Configuration Mode

entry.name: source_tibems_kglobalconfig_help_111
entry.text:
Creates the specified TIBCO EMS handler and enters TIBCO EMS Front Side Handler Configuration Mode.
name The name of the TIBCO EMS handler.
For example:
source-tibems TibcoHandler-1 Enters TIBCO EMS Handler Configuration Mode and creates the TibcoHandler-1 TIBCO EMS handler.

entry.name: source_tibems_kglobalconfig_descr_111
entry.text: Creates a TIBCO EMS handler.

entry.name: source_wasjms_kglobalconfig_help_112
entry.text:
Creates the specified WebSphere JMS handler and enters WebSphere JMS Handler Configuration Mode.
name The name of the WebSphere JMS handler.
For example:
source-wasjms JmsHandler-1 Enters WebSphere JMS Handler Configuration Mode and creates the JmsHandler-1 WebSphere JMS handler.

entry.name: source_wasjms_kglobalconfig_descr_112
entry.text: Creates a WebSphere JMS handler.

entry.name: stylepolicy_kglobalconfig_help_113
entry.text:
Enters Stylesheet Policy Configuration, and creates a Stylesheet Policy. name is the name of newly-created Stylesheet Policy. xsldefault is an optional keyword, used in conjunction with stylesheet-url, that identifies a default XSL stylesheet used for document transformation. This default stylesheet default stylesheet performs transformations only if a candidate XML document fails to match any of the transformation rules defined within the named Stylesheet Policy, and if the candidate document does NOT contain internal processing instructions. stylesheet-url is used only in conjunction with the xsldefault keyword, and specifies the location of the default XSL stylesheet. filter is an optional keyword, used in conjunction with the filter-url argument, that identifies a default stylesheet used for document filtering. This default stylesheet performs XML filtering only if a candidate XML document fails to match any of the filter rules defined within the named Stylesheet Policy. filter-url is used only in conjunction with the filter keyword, and specifies the location of the default filtering stylesheet. For example:
stylepolicy FW-1 filter store:///validate.xsl Enters Stylesheet Policy Configuration Mode and creates a Stylesheet Policy named FW-1, which uses the specified default filtering stylesheet

entry.name: stylepolicy_kglobalconfig_descr_113
entry.text: Enters Stylesheet Policy Configuration Mode

entry.name: system_kglobalconfig_help_114
entry.text: Enters System Settings Configuration Mode.

entry.name: system_kglobalconfig_descr_114
entry.text: Enters System Settings Configuration Mode

entry.name: tam_kglobalconfig_help_115
entry.text: Enters ISAM (IBM Security Access Manager) configuration mode.

entry.name: tam_kglobalconfig_descr_115
entry.text: Enters IBM Security Access Manager Configuration Mode

entry.name: tfim_kglobalconfig_help_116
entry.text: Enters TFIM (Tivoli Federated Identity Manager) Configuration Mode.

entry.name: tfim_kglobalconfig_descr_116
entry.text: Enters Tivoli Federated Identity Manager Configuration Mode

entry.name: tibems_server_kglobalconfig_help_117
entry.text:
Creates the specified TIBCO EMS server and enters TIBCO EMS Server Configuration Mode.
name The name of the TIBCO EMS server.
For example:
source-server TibcoServer-1 Enters TIBCO EMS Server Configuration Mode and creates the TibcoServer-1 TIBCO server.

entry.name: tibems_server_kglobalconfig_descr_117
entry.text: Creates a TIBCO EMS server.

entry.name: tracing_target_kglobalconfig_help_118
entry.text:
Creates the specified trace target object and enters Trace Target Configuration Mode.
name The name of the trace target object.
For example:
tracing target TraceTarget-1 enters Trace Target Configuration Mode and creates the TraceTarget-1 trace target object.

entry.name: tracing_target_kglobalconfig_descr_118
entry.text: Creates a trace target.

entry.name: uddi_registry_kglobalconfig_help_119
entry.text:
The UDDI Registry is deprecated. Instead, use WebSphere Service Registry and Repository (WSRR) server.
Creates the specified UDDI registry object and enters UDDI Registry Configuration Mode.
For example:
uddi-registry Registry-1 enters UDDI Registry Configuration Mode and creates the Registry-1 UDDI registry object.

entry.name: uddi_registry_kglobalconfig_descr_119
entry.text: Creates a UDDI registry.

entry.name: uddi_subscription_kglobalconfig_help_120
entry.text:
The UDDI Subscription is deprecated. Instead, use WebSphere Service Registry and Repository (WSRR) subscription.
Creates the specified UDDI Subscription object if it does not exist and enters UDDI Subscription Configuration Mode.
UDDI Subscription objects provide a means to retrieve Web Services endpoint data stored in a UDDI Registry. This endpoint information can then be used by the device for proxying services.
For example:
uddi-subscription ActiveEndpoint1 enters UDDI Subscription Configuration Mode and creates the ActiveEndpoint1 UDDI Subscription object.

entry.name: uddi_subscription_kglobalconfig_descr_120
entry.text: Creates or edits a UDDI Subscription object.

entry.name: urlmap_kglobalconfig_help_121
entry.text:
Enters URL Map Mode and creates the named URL map. A URL map contains a list of match patterns (or rules) that determine whether or not a specific URL belongs in the mapping. URL maps are used in the implementation of a Stylesheet-Refresh Policy. For example:
urlmap URLmap-1 Enters URL Map Mode and creates a URL map named URLmap-1

entry.name: urlmap_kglobalconfig_descr_121
entry.text: Enters URL Map Mode

entry.name: urlrefresh_kglobalconfig_help_122
entry.text:
Enters URL Refresh Mode and creates the named URL Refresh Policy, which is used in the implementation of a Stylesheet-Refresh Policy. For example:
urlrefresh 2aday Enters URL Refresh Mode and creates a URL Refresh Policy named 2aday.

entry.name: urlrefresh_kglobalconfig_descr_122
entry.text: Enters URL Refresh Mode

entry.name: urlrewrite_kglobalconfig_help_123
entry.text:
Enters URL Rewrite Mode and creates a named URL Rewrite Policy. For example:
urlrewrite RewriteContentType Enters URL Rewrite Mode and creates a URL Rewrite Policy named RewriteContentType

entry.name: urlrewrite_kglobalconfig_descr_123
entry.text: Enters URL Rewrite Mode

entry.name: undo_kglobalconfig_help_124
entry.text:
Reverts the specified object to its last persisted state. On success, you receive the message, "Configuration reverted."
type identifies the type of object. For a complete list of object types, use the show command. name identifies the name of the target object.

entry.name: undo_kglobalconfig_descr_124
entry.text: Reverts an unpersisted object.

entry.name: user_expire_password_kglobalconfig_help_125
entry.text:
Forces the specified user to change the account password at the next log in.
accountName identifies the name of the target user account.
For example:
user-expire-password 007 Expires the password for the 007 account. The next time that 007 logs in, this user must change the account password.

entry.name: user_expire_password_kglobalconfig_descr_125
entry.text: Expires the password for a user.

entry.name: usergroup_kglobalconfig_help_126
entry.text:
Enters User Group Configuration Mode and creates a named user group -- a set of CLI access privileges that can be assigned to individual user accounts. For example:
usergroup CryptoBoys Enters User Group Configuration Mode and creates a user group called CryptBoys

entry.name: usergroup_kglobalconfig_descr_126
entry.text: Enters User Group Configuration Mode

entry.name: valcred_kconfigcrypto_help_127
entry.text:
Enters Validation Credentials Configuration Mode. Validation credentials contains aliases for locally stored certificates. Validation credentials are used to authenticate certificates from TLS peers. name The name of the validation credentials. For example:
valcred Trusted-1s Enters Validation Credentials Configuration Mode and creates the Trusted-ls validation credentials.

entry.name: valcred_kconfigcrypto_descr_127
entry.text: Enters Validation Credentials Configuration Mode

entry.name: wasjms_server_kglobalconfig_help_128
entry.text:
Enters WebSphere JMS Configuration Mode and creates a named WebSphere JMS object. While in WebSphere JMS Configuration Mode, you define the parameters needed to locate and access a version 6.x WebSphere Application Server (WAS) JMS provider, running IBM JFAP (JetStream Formats and Protocols). A JMS provider enables messaging based on the Java Messaging Service (JMS). jmsObjectName The name of the newly-created WebSphere JMS object.
For example:
wasjms-server jetStream-1 Enters WebSphere JMS Configuration Mode and creates a WebSphere JMS object named jetStream-1

entry.name: wasjms_server_kglobalconfig_descr_128
entry.text: Enters WebSphere JMS Configuration Mode.

entry.name: web_application_firewall_kglobalconfig_help_129
entry.text:
Enters Web Application Firewall Configuration Mode and creates a new Web Application Firewall. named name For example:
web-application-firewall portalfw Enters Web Application Firewall Configuration Mode and creates a Web Application Firewall named portalfw

entry.name: web_application_firewall_kglobalconfig_descr_129
entry.text: Enters Web Application Firewall Configuration Mode

entry.name: webapp_error_handling_kglobalconfig_help_130
entry.text:
Enters Web Application Error Handling Configuration Mode and creates a new Web Application Error Handling Policy named name. For example:
webapp-error-handling portal-err-policy Enters Web Application Error Handling Policy Configuration Mode and creates a Policy named portal-err-policy. This new policy may then be used in an Application Security Policy or in a Web Request Profile.

entry.name: webapp_error_handling_kglobalconfig_descr_130
entry.text: Enters Web Application Error Handling Configuration Mode

entry.name: webapp_gnvc_kglobalconfig_help_131
entry.text:
Enters Web Application Name Value Profile Configuration Mode and creates a new Web Application Name Value Profile named name. For example:
webapp-gnvc portal-nvp Enters Web Application Name Value Profile Configuration Mode and creates a Profile named portal-nvp. This new profile may then be used in a Web Request or Response Policy.

entry.name: webapp_gnvc_kglobalconfig_descr_131
entry.text: Enters Web Application Name-Value Profile Configuration Mode

entry.name: webapp_request_profile_kglobalconfig_help_132
entry.text:
Enters Web Application Web Request Profile Configuration Mode and creates a new Web Application Web Request Profile named name. For example:
webapp-request-profile portal-request Enters Web Application Web Request Profile Configuration Mode and creates a Profile named portal-request. This new profile may then be used in an Application Security Policy.

entry.name: webapp_request_profile_kglobalconfig_descr_132
entry.text: Enters Web Application Web Request Profile Configuration Mode

entry.name: webapp_response_profile_kglobalconfig_help_133
entry.text:
Enters Web Application Web Response Profile Configuration Mode and creates a new Web Application Web Response Profile named name. For example:
webapp-response-profile portal-response Enters Web Application Web Response Profile Configuration Mode and creates a Profile named portal-response. This new profile may then be used in an Application Security Policy.

entry.name: webapp_response_profile_kglobalconfig_descr_133
entry.text: Enters Web Application Web Response Profile Configuration Mode

entry.name: webapp_session_management_kglobalconfig_help_134
entry.text:
Enters Web Application Session Management Policy Configuration Mode and creates a new Web Application Session Management Policy named name. For example:
webapp-session-management portal-session Enters Web Application Session Management Policy Configuration Mode and creates a Policy named portal-session. This new policy may then be used in a Web Request Profile.

entry.name: webapp_session_management_kglobalconfig_descr_134
entry.text: Enters Web Application Session Management Policy Configuration Mode

entry.name: wsgw_kglobalconfig_help_135
entry.text:
Enters Web Service Gateway Configuration Mode and creates a named Web Service gateway. webServiceGatewayName is the name of the newly created web Service gateway. For example:
wsgw fromWSDL-10 Enters Web Service Gateway Configuration Mode and creates a Web Service Gateway named fromWSDL-10

entry.name: wsgw_kglobalconfig_descr_135
entry.text: Enters Web Service Gateway Configuration Mode

entry.name: wsm_agent_kglobalconfig_help_136
entry.text: Enters Web Services Management Agent Configuration Mode. The Web Services Management Agent provides manageability for Web Services through status, metrics, and transaction history to external management stations.

entry.name: wsm_agent_kglobalconfig_descr_136
entry.text: Enters Web Services Management Agent Configuration Mode.

entry.name: wsm_endpointrewrite_kglobalconfig_help_137
entry.text: Enters WS Proxy EndPoint Rewrite Policy Configuration Mode.

entry.name: wsm_endpointrewrite_kglobalconfig_descr_137
entry.text: Enters Endpoint Rewrite Policy Configuration Mode

entry.name: wsm_rule_kglobalconfig_help_138
entry.text: Enters WS Proxy Rule Configuration Mode.

entry.name: wsm_rule_kglobalconfig_descr_138
entry.text: Enters WS Proxy Rule Configuration Mode

entry.name: wsm_stylepolicy_kglobalconfig_help_139
entry.text:
Enters WS-Proxy Policy configuration mode and creates a named processing policy. If the named policy already exists, enters WS-Proxy Policy configuration mode for the specified policy. wsPolicyName is the name of the newly created or existing processing policy.
For example:
wsm-stylepolicy wsPolicy-1 Enters WS-Proxy Policy configuration mode and creates a processing policy named wsPolicy-1.

entry.name: wsm_stylepolicy_kglobalconfig_descr_139
entry.text: Enters WS-Proxy Policy configuration mode

entry.name: wsrr_server_kglobalconfig_help_140
entry.text:
Enters WSRR Server Configuration Mode and creates a named WSRR server object. If the named WSRR server already exists, enters WSRR Server Configuration Mode for the specified server. name The name of the newly created or existing WSRR server object.
For example:
wsrr-server businessRegistry-1 Enters WSRR Server Configuration Mode and creates a WSRR server object named businessRegistry-1.

entry.name: wsrr_server_kglobalconfig_descr_140
entry.text: Enters WSRR Server Configuration Mode

entry.name: wsrr_subscription_kglobalconfig_help_141
entry.text:
Enters WSRR Subscription Mode and creates a named WSRR subscription object. If the named WSRR subscription already exists, enters WSRR Subscription Configuration Mode for the specified subscription. As used in conjunction with a Web Service Proxy, a WSRR subscription is a regularly scheduled WSRR query that ensures the Web Service Proxy configuration is derived from the latest version of the normative source, for example a single WSDL file, or a collection of WSDL files and associated documents (schema or XML documents).
name The name of the WSRR subscription object.
For example:
wsrr-subscription updateWS-Proxy-1 Enters WSRR Subscription Configuration Mode and creates a WSRR subscription object named updateWS-Proxy-1.

entry.name: wsrr_subscription_kglobalconfig_descr_141
entry.text: Enters WSRR Subscription Configuration Mode

entry.name: wsrr_saved_search_subscription_kglobalconfig_help_142
entry.text:
Enters WSRR Saved Search Subscription Mode and creates a named WSRR saved search subscription object. If the named WSRR saved search subscription already exists, enters WSRR Subscription Saved Search Configuration Mode for the specified subscription.
The WSRR Saved Search Subscription is useful when you want to deploy Web services with an indirect reference to a set of WSDL files required for Web Service Proxy operations. The configuration requires a reference to a WSRR server and the name of an existing saved search from the WSRR server. The management of the service documents is controlled from the WSRR server.
Web Service Proxy services associated with the saved search subscription are updated based on the synchronization method specified in the subscription. A Web Service Proxy virtualizes the Web service endpoints based on the WSDL files returned by executing the configured saved search.
The Saved Search Subscription requires a configured WSRR version 6.2 or later.
name The name of the WSRR saved search subscription object.
For example:
wsrr-saved-search wsProxy-product-wsdls Enters WSRR Saved Search Subscription Configuration Mode and creates a WSRR saved search subscription object named wsProxy-product-wsdls.

entry.name: wsrr_saved_search_subscription_kglobalconfig_descr_142
entry.text: Enters WSRR Saved Search Configuration Mode

entry.name: wsrr_synchronize_kglobalconfig_help_143
entry.text:
Performs an immediate, unscheduled synchronization of previously retrieved subscription content with the WSRR server.
subscriptionName The name of an existing WSRR subscription or WSRR Saved Search subscription.

entry.name: wsrr_synchronize_kglobalconfig_descr_143
entry.text: Synchronizes subscription content with the server.

entry.name: wsdl_refresh_kglobalconfig_help_144
entry.text:
Retrieve and recompile the WSDL.
WSGateway The name of an existing Web Service Proxy Gateway. WSDL The location of a WSDL in the Web Service Proxy Gateway.

entry.name: wsdl_refresh_kglobalconfig_descr_144
entry.text: Refreshes the WSDL for the specified Web Service Proxy Gateway.

entry.name: xacml_pdp_kglobalconfig_help_145
entry.text:
Create the specified XACML (extensible access control markup language) PDP (policy decision point) object and enters XACML Policy Decision Point Configuration Mode.
When in this mode, you can define the properties to configure an XACML PDP that is internal.
name The name of the internal XACML PDP object.
For example:
xacml-pdp PDP-OrderEntry Enters XACML Policy Decision Point Configuration Mode and creates the internal PDP-OrderEntry XACML PDP object.

entry.name: xacml_pdp_kglobalconfig_descr_145
entry.text: Creates an XACML PDP.

entry.name: xml_manager_kglobalconfig_help_146
entry.text:
Create the specified XML manager and enters XML Manager Configuration Mode, or enters XML Manager Configuration Mode and accesses the configuration of the specified XML manager.
When in this mode, you can configure the XML manager to perform a rule-based action.
name The name of the XML manager.
For example:
xml-manager mgr1 Enters XML Manager Configuration Mode and creates the mgr1 XML manager.

entry.name: xml_manager_kglobalconfig_descr_146
entry.text: Creates an new XML manager or accesses an existing XML manager.

entry.name: xml_parser_limits_kglobalconfig_help_147
entry.text:
Enters XML Parser Limits configuration mode for a named XML manager. While in XML Parser Limits Configuration Mode, you can define manager-specific limits on XML document size and complexity. xmlmgr The target XML manager. For example:
xml parser limits mgr1 Enters XML Parser Limits Configuration Mode for mgr1

entry.name: xml_parser_limits_kglobalconfig_descr_147
entry.text: Enters XML Parser Limits Configuration Mode.

entry.name: xmlfirewall_kglobalconfig_help_148
entry.text:
Enters XML Firewall Configuration Mode and creates a named firewall. In the absence of the optional name argument, the system software generates a unique firewall name. For example:
xmlfirewall FW-1 Enters XML Firewall Configuration Mode and creates the XML Firewall, FW-1

entry.name: xmlfirewall_kglobalconfig_descr_148
entry.text: Creates an XML Firewall

entry.name: xpath_routing_kglobalconfig_help_149
entry.text:
Enters XPath Routing Map Mode and creates the named XPath Routing map. An XPath Routing map contains a list of XPath expressions. Each expression is associated with an IP address and port number that identify a destination and a logical switch specifying the connection type (secure or non-secure) to that destination. For example:
xpath-routing ROUTINGmap-1 Enters XPath Routing Map Mode and creates an XPath Routing map, ROUTINGmap-1

entry.name: xpath_routing_kglobalconfig_descr_149
entry.text: Enters XPath Routing Map Mode

entry.name: exit_kall_help_150
entry.text: Applies properties and returns to Global Configuration Mode.

entry.name: exit_kall_descr_150
entry.text: Applies properties and exits

entry.name: exit_kuser_help_151
entry.text: Exits User Mode and terminates the CLI connection.

entry.name: exit_kuser_descr_151
entry.text: Terminates the CLI connection

entry.name: exit_kprivileged_help_152
entry.text: Exits Privileged Mode and terminates the CLI connection.

entry.name: exit_kprivileged_descr_152
entry.text: Terminates the CLI connection

entry.name: exit_kglobalconfig_help_153
entry.text: Exits Global Configuration Mode and enters Privileged Mode.

entry.name: exit_kglobalconfig_descr_153
entry.text: Enters Privileged Mode

entry.name: admin_state_kall_descr_154
entry.text: Administratively enables or disables the object.

entry.name: cancel_kall_help_155
entry.text: Exits the current configuration mode, after discarding any property changes (leaving the configuration object unchanged upon exit).

entry.name: cancel_kall_descr_155
entry.text: Exits the current mode (no changes applied)

entry.name: echo_kall_help_156
entry.text: Echoes text to the console.

entry.name: echo_kall_descr_156
entry.text: Echoes text to the console

entry.name: exec_kall_help_157
entry.text:
Calls and executes a target configuration script from within another configuration script. Upon execution of the target script, returns control to the original script. local-url locates the target script on the device flash, and takes the form config:///filename or temporary:///filename. For example:
exec config:///interfaces.cfg executes the specified configuration script and returns control to the calling script

entry.name: exec_kall_descr_157
entry.text: Executes a configuration script

entry.name: disconnect_kall_help_158
entry.text: Terminates a user session. Requires session id as a parameter. Active user sessions and their session ids are displayed by the 'show users' command.

entry.name: disconnect_kall_descr_158
entry.text: Terminates a user session

entry.name: help_kall_help_159
entry.text: If a command argument is used, displays usage information and help for that command. Otherwise, displays a list of all commands available in the current mode, and a brief description of each command.

entry.name: help_kall_descr_159
entry.text: Displays general or command-specific help

entry.name: help2_kall_help_160
entry.text: If a command argument is used, displays usage information and help for that command. Otherwise, displays a list of all commands available in the current mode, and a brief description of each command.

entry.name: help2_kall_descr_160
entry.text: Displays general or command-specific help

entry.name: ping_kall_help_161
entry.text:
Determines whether the network can reach a remote target. When invoked, 6 ICMP echo-request messages are sent to the specified host with a one second interval between each message and reports the results.
