remote-host Specifies the host name of the target. remote-address Specifies the IP address of the target. IP-version Optional: Identifies the IP version to use when resolving an ambiguous host name to an IP address. Ambiguity occurs when the DNS publishes an IPv4 address and an IPv6 address. If not specified, resolves to the preferred IP version as defined by the "ip-preference" command in DNS Settings mode. -4 Identifies the target as an IPv4 host. -6 Identifies the target as an IPv6 host. This parameter applies to only ambiguous host names. Although you specify -6, output shows the IPv4 address when the DNS publishes only an IPv4 address. Conversely, when you Specify -4 and the DNS publishes only an IPv6 address, the output shows the IPv6 address. local-address Optional: Identifies the IP address or host alias of a local interface to use for the connection test.
For example:
ping example.com Sends 6 ICMP echo request to example.com using the preferred IP version. ping example.com -4 Sends 6 ICMP echo-request messages to example.com using its IPv4 address. ping example.com 1.2.3.4 Sends 6 ICMP echo-request messages from 1.2.3.4 to example.com using the preferred IP version.

entry.name: ping_kall_descr_161
entry.text: Determines whether the network can reach a remote target.

entry.name: test_tcp_connection_kall_help_162
entry.text:
Verifies TCP connectivity to a specific port on a remote target.
remote-host Specifies the host name of the target. remote-address Specifies the IP address of the target. remote-port Specifies the listening port on the target. timeout Specifies the number of seconds to wait for a response. The default value is 10. IP-version Optional: Identifies the IP version to use when resolving an ambiguous host name to an IP address. Ambiguity occurs when the DNS publishes an IPv4 address and an IPv6 address. If not specified, resolves to the preferred IP version as defined by the "ip-preference" command in DNS Settings mode. -4 Identifies the target as an IPv4 host. -6 Identifies the target as an IPv6 host. This parameter applies to only ambiguous host names. Although you specify -6, output shows the IPv4 address when the DNS publishes only an IPv4 address. Conversely, when you Specify -4 and the DNS publishes only an IPv6 address, the output shows the IPv6 address. local-address Optional: Identifies the IP address or host alias of a local interface to use for the connection test.
For example:
test tcp-connection example.com 80 Tests connectivity to port 80 on example.com using the preferred IP version. Times out if no response received in 10 seconds. test tcp-connection example.com 80 -4 Tests connectivity to port 80 on example.com using its IPv4 address. Times out if no response received in 10 seconds. test tcp-connection example.com 80 30 Tests connectivity to port 80 on example.com using the preferred IP version. Times out if no response received in 30 seconds. test tcp-connection example.com 80 1.2.3.4 Test connectivity from 1.2.3.4 to port 80 on example.com using the preferred IP version. Times out if no response received in 10 seconds.

entry.name: test_tcp_connection_kall_descr_162
entry.text: Verifies TCP connectivity to a specific port on a remote target.

entry.name: reset_kall_help_163
entry.text: Exits the current configuration mode, after applying default property values (potentially changing the configuration object upon exit).

entry.name: reset_kall_descr_163
entry.text: Exits the current mode (default values applied)

entry.name: summary_kall_help_164
entry.text:
Adds an object-specific comment. Use double quotes (" ") to bracket the string. string The object description For example:
summary "Gateway-1 intended for extranet usage" Adds object-specific descriptive text

entry.name: summary_kall_descr_164
entry.text: Adds a descriptive string to a configuration object

entry.name: history_kall_descr_165
entry.text: Display recent commands

entry.name: configure_terminal_kuser_descr_166
entry.text: Global configuration mode

entry.name: top_kall_help_167
entry.text: For admin and privileged accounts returns to Privileged Mode. For custom accounts, returns to the account-specific login mode.

entry.name: top_kall_descr_167
entry.text: Returns to initial login mode

entry.name: traceroute_kall_help_168
entry.text:
Traces the network path to a remote target. The output shows the IP address of the hops and the round trip time.
remote-host Specifies the host name of the target. remote-address Specifies the IP address of the target. IP-version Optional: Identifies the IP version to use when resolving an ambiguous host name to an IP address. Ambiguity occurs when the DNS publishes an IPv4 address and an IPv6 address. If not specified, resolves to the preferred IP version as defined by the "ip-preference" command in DNS Settings mode. -4 Identifies the target as an IPv4 host. -6 Identifies the target as an IPv6 host. This parameter applies to only ambiguous host names. Although you specify -6, output shows the IPv4 address when the DNS publishes only an IPv4 address. Conversely, when you Specify -4 and the DNS publishes only an IPv6 address, the output shows the IPv6 address. local-address Optional: Identifies the IP address or host alias of a local interface to use for the connection test.
For example:
traceroute example.com Displays the route to example.com using the preferred IP version. traceroute example.com -4 Displays the route to example.com using its IPv4 address, if published. If not published, uses its IPv6 address, if published. traceroute example.com 1.2.3.4 Displays the route from 1.2.3.4 to example.com using the preferred IP version.

entry.name: traceroute_kall_descr_168
entry.text: Traces the network path to a remote target.

entry.name: show_kall_help_169
entry.text: Displays configuration or status information relevant to the provided argument. If no argument is provided, displays a list of available options.

entry.name: show_kall_descr_169
entry.text: Displays status or configuration data

entry.name: allow_accesscontrollist_help_170
entry.text:
Specifies an IP address or range of IP addresses granted access to a service provider.
ip-address is a dotted decimal IP address. any is a keyword signifying all IP addresses. network-mask is required with a dotted decimal IP address (and otherwise not used) specifies the range of IP addresses granted access to the service provider. network-mask can be express in either "CIDR" or dotted decimal format.
For example:
allow 10.10.10.3/32 allow 10.0.0.0/8 provides access to 10.10.10.3 and 10.0.0.0 through 10.255.255.255 while denying access to all other addresses.

entry.name: allow_accesscontrollist_descr_170
entry.text: Adds an allow clause to an ACL

entry.name: deny_accesscontrollist_help_171
entry.text:
Specifies an IP address or range of IP addresses denied access to a service provider.
ip-address A dotted decimal IP address. any A keyword signifying all IP addresses. network-mask Required with a dotted decimal IP address (and otherwise not used) specifies the range of IP addresses denied access to the service provider. network-mask can be express in either "CIDR" or dotted decimal format. For example:
deny 10.10.10.0/27 allow 10.10.10.0/24 provides access to addresses in the range 10.10.10.32 - 10.10.10.255 while denying access to all other addresses.

entry.name: deny_accesscontrollist_descr_171
entry.text: Adds a deny clause to an ACL

entry.name: error_match_appsecuritypolicy_help_172
entry.text:
An Error Map uses a Matching Rule to select error conditions, which are then handled by the corresponding Processing Rule. An Application Security Policy may have none or many Error Maps.
MatchRuleName specifies the Matching Rule used to select error conditions. Match Rule must already exist. Use Global Configuration Mode command matching to create a new rule. ProcessingRuleName specifies the Processing Rule executed on the error condition. Processing Rule must already exist. Use Global Configuration Mode command rule to create a new rule.
For example:
error-match policy-rejects wafw-error-rule creates a new Error Map that uses the Matching Rule policy-rejects and applies the wafw-error-rule to all matching errors.

entry.name: error_match_appsecuritypolicy_descr_172
entry.text: Creates or edits an Error Map

entry.name: request_match_appsecuritypolicy_help_173
entry.text:
A Request Map uses a Matching Rule to select web requests, which are then processed by the corresponding Web Request Profile. The Profile must pass the request or the request is rejected. A Security Policy must have one and may have many Request Maps.
MatchRuleName specifies the Matching Rule used to select web requests. Match Rule must already exist. Use Global Configuration Mode command matching to create a new rule. WebRequestProfileName specifies the Web Request Profile applied to the request. Web Request Profile must already exist. Use Global Configuration Mode command webapp-request to create a new Profile.
For example:
request-match match-portal-app portal-req-profile creates a new Map that uses the Matching Rule match-portal-app and applies the portal-req-profile to all matching requests.

entry.name: request_match_appsecuritypolicy_descr_173
entry.text: Creates or edits a Request Map

entry.name: response_match_appsecuritypolicy_help_174
entry.text:
A Response Map uses a Matching Rule to select web responses, which are then processed by the corresponding Web Response Profile. The Profile must pass the response or the transaction is rejected. A Security Policy must have one and may have many Response Maps.
MatchRuleName specifies the Matching Rule used to select web requests. Match Rule must already exist. Use Global Configuration Mode command matching to create a new rule. WebResponseProfileName specifies the Web Response Profile applied to the request. Web Response Profile must already exist. Use Global Configuration Mode command webapp-response to create a new profile.
For example:
request-match match-portal-ret portal-resp-profile Creates a new map that uses the match-portal-ret matching rule. and applies the portal-resp-profile to all matching responses.

entry.name: response_match_appsecuritypolicy_descr_174
entry.text: Creates or edits a Response Map

entry.name: disable_expired_certs_certmonitor_help_175
entry.text:
"on" Indicates that when a certificate expires, all objects that use the expired certificate (either directly or through inheritance) are disabled and are no longer in service. For example, certificate expiration triggers the disable of the associated certificate objects. Disable of the certificate object triggers the disable of all identification credentials, and validation credentials that use the expired certificate. In turn, crypto profiles that use disabled identification credentials and validation credentials are disabled, leading to the disable of TLS proxy profiles dependent on the disabled crypto profiles. Ultimately, the DataPower service might be disabled as the result of certificate expiration. "off" (default) Indicates that the certificate object and objects using the expired certificate are not disabled on certificate expiration. For example:
disable-expired-certs on Expired certificates are disabled along with all objects that use the expired certificates.

entry.name: disable_expired_certs_certmonitor_descr_175
entry.text: Indicates the state of expired certificates

entry.name: log_level_certmonitor_help_176
entry.text:
Specifies the priority level of certificate expiration messages logged by the Certificate Monitor. Use of the following keywords (listed in descending order of criticality) to assign the log priority: emergency alert critical error warning notice info debug For example:
log-level error certificate expiration messages are logged with a priority of error

entry.name: log_level_certmonitor_descr_176
entry.text: Specifies the priority of certificate alerts

entry.name: poll_certmonitor_help_177
entry.text:
Specifies the frequency with which the Certificate Monitor scans certificate objects looking for expired or soon-to-expire objects. By default, the Certificate Monitor scans certificate objects on a daily basis. pollingInterval is an integer (within the range 1 through 65535) that specifies the polling interval in days. For example:
poll 3 the Certificate Monitor scans certificate objects every 3 days

entry.name: poll_certmonitor_descr_177
entry.text: Specifies the polling interval

entry.name: reminder_certmonitor_help_178
entry.text:
Specifies the certificate expiration window, that is the number of days prior to certificate expiration that the Certificate Monitor begins to generate certificate expiration log messages. certExpirationWindow is an integer (within the range 1 through 65535) that specifies the certificate expiration window in days. For example:
reminder 30 the Certificate Monitor begins to log certificate expiration messages 30 days prior to certificate expiration

entry.name: reminder_certmonitor_descr_178
entry.text: Specifies the certificate expiration window

entry.name: allow_soap_enc_array_compileoptionspolicy_help_179
entry.text: Designates a set of schemas that will accept most uses of elements with xsi:type='SOAP-ENC:Array' consistent with SOAP 1.1 Section 5, even when these attributes violate the XML Schema specification. Normally the xsi:type attribute must name a type equal to or derived from the actual type of the element. For schemas compiled with this option, xsi:type is accepted specifically for the SOAP 1.1 Encoding 'Array' complex type if the element type is derived from SOAP-ENC:Array; this is the opposite of the normal allowable case.

entry.name: allow_soap_enc_array_compileoptionspolicy_descr_179
entry.text: Specifically Allow xsi:type=SOAP-ENC:Array Rule

entry.name: allow_xop_include_compileoptionspolicy_help_180
entry.text:
Specifies a set of schemas or WSDL documents that accept messages in which base64-encoded binary content was optimized according to the MTOM/XOP specifications. XOP binary-optimization replaces base64-encoded binary data with an xop:Include reference element that references the unencoded binary data located in an attachment.
When this option is disabled, such optimized messages are rejected by the validation of the unoptimized form. Rejection occurs because the schema specifies a simple type that accepts base64-encoded data, such as xs:base64Binary or xs:string, but the message contains an xop:Include element instead.
When this option is enabled, an xop:Include element can optionally appear in place of content for any XML Schema simple type that validates base64-encoded binary data. The xop:Include element itself is validated according to the built-in schema in store:///schemas/xop.xsd.

entry.name: allow_xop_include_compileoptionspolicy_descr_180
entry.text: Accept MTOM/XOP optimized messages.

entry.name: debug_compileoptionspolicy_help_181
entry.text:
Defines a set of URLs that are profiled in debug mode. match-pattern A shell-style regular expression that defines the target URL set.
For example:
debug http://www.amajoraccount.com/Zeus/*xsl defines a URL set to be profiled in debug mode

entry.name: debug_compileoptionspolicy_descr_181
entry.text: Defines a profiled URL set

entry.name: disallow_xg4_compileoptionspolicy_help_182
entry.text:
Defines a set of URLs that are never to be executed on the XML Hardware Accelerator. match-pattern A shell-style regular expression that defines the target URL set.
For example:
disallow-xg4 http://www.amajoraccount.com/Zeus/*xsl Defines a URL set that will never be executed on the XML Hardware Accelerator.

entry.name: disallow_xg4_compileoptionspolicy_descr_182
entry.text: Defines a URL set never executed on the XML Hardware Accelerator

entry.name: minesc_compileoptionspolicy_help_183
entry.text:
Output produced from stylesheets meeting the URL map criteria will not be escaped during processing (escaping is On by default). Minimal escaping is particularly useful when handling non-English character sets. match-pattern A shell-style regular expression that defines the target URL set.
For example:
minesc http://www.amajoraccount.com/International/*xsl Defines a URL set that will be minimally escaped.

entry.name: minesc_compileoptionspolicy_descr_183
entry.text: Sets Minimum Escaping on a defined URL set

entry.name: prefer_xg4_compileoptionspolicy_help_184
entry.text:
Defines a set of URLs that will be executed on the XML Hardware Accelerator if at all possible. This results in greater speed. match-pattern A shell-style regular expression that defines the target URL set.
For example:
prefer-xg4 http://www.amajoraccount.com/Alpha/*xsl Defines a URL set that will be executed on the XML Hardware Accelerator.

entry.name: prefer_xg4_compileoptionspolicy_descr_184
entry.text: Defines a URL set never executed on the XML Hardware Accelerator

entry.name: profile_compileoptionspolicy_help_185
entry.text:
Defines a set of URLs that are profiled. match-pattern A shell-style regular expression that defines the target URL set.
For example:
profile http://www.amajoraccount.com/Zeus/*xsl Defines a URL set to be profiled. All stylesheets that match the regular expression "http://www.amajoraccount.com/Zeus/*xsl" will be profiled.

entry.name: profile_compileoptionspolicy_descr_185
entry.text: Defines a profiled URL set

entry.name: stack_size_compileoptionspolicy_help_186
entry.text:
Indicates the maximum number of bytes the stack is allowed to use while executing a stylesheet or other compiled content. This blocks infinite recursion. The minimum value is 10 kilobytes, or 10,240 bytes. The default is half a megabyte, or 524,288 bytes. bytes The maximum stack size in bytes. For example:
stack-size 256000 Limits the maximum stack size to 256K bytes.

entry.name: stack_size_compileoptionspolicy_descr_186
entry.text: Defines the maximum stack size for execution

entry.name: stream_compileoptionspolicy_help_187
entry.text:
Designates a set of stylesheets which must be run in streaming mode. Transformation of the document begins before the input is fully parsed. Not all stylesheets can be streamed; if a stylesheet cannot be streamed, an error will be issued and the input will not be processed. See the DataPower manual for suggestions on producing streamable stylesheets. match-pattern A shell-style regular expression that defines the target URL set.
For example:
stream book*xsl Defines a set of stylesheets to execute in streaming mode.

entry.name: stream_compileoptionspolicy_descr_187
entry.text: Define stylesheet set to execute in streaming mode

entry.name: strict_compileoptionspolicy_help_188
entry.text:
Enable strict XSLT error checking; non-strict operation attempts to recover from certain errors such as use of undeclared variables, calling undeclared templates, etc. Non-strict is the default. Use the no form of the command to disable strict error-checking.
For example:
strict Enables strict XSLT error checking. no strict Disables strict XSLT error checking.

entry.name: strict_compileoptionspolicy_descr_188
entry.text: Enable strict XSLT error checking

entry.name: try_stream_compileoptionspolicy_help_189
entry.text:
Designates a set of stylesheets which should be run in streaming mode, if possible. Transformation of the document begins before the input is fully parsed. Not all stylesheets can be streamed. If a stylesheet cannot be streamed, it is processed in non-streaming mode.
match-pattern A shell-style regular expression that defines the target URL set. For example:
try-stream magazine*xsl Defines a set of stylesheets to attempt to process in streaming mode.

entry.name: try_stream_compileoptionspolicy_descr_189
entry.text: Define stylesheet set to execute in streaming mode

entry.name: validate_soap_enc_array_compileoptionspolicy_help_190
entry.text: Designates a set of schemas that will do extra validation following the encoding rules in SOAP 1.1 Section 5. This validates members of SOAP arrays, allows attributes such as @id and @href even if not allowed by the schema, and checks that @href values have a corresponding @id element.

entry.name: validate_soap_enc_array_compileoptionspolicy_descr_190
entry.text: Validate SOAP 1.1 Encoding Rule

entry.name: wildcards_ignore_xsi_type_compileoptionspolicy_help_191
entry.text: Designates a set of schemas where wildcards (xs:any elements) only validate children by element name. The XML Schema specification requires that, if a wildcard matches an element but that element does not have an element declaration, the element is instead validated according to an xsi:type attribute on it. This option ignores those xsi:type attributes. It should be used for cases such as SOAP envelope validation where a further validation step will validate the contents matching the wildcard, possibly using the SOAP 1.1 encoding rules.

entry.name: wildcards_ignore_xsi_type_compileoptionspolicy_descr_191
entry.text: Wildcards Ignore xsi:type Rule

entry.name: wsdl_strict_soap_version_compileoptionspolicy_help_192
entry.text:
Determine whether to strictly follow the SOAP binding in the WSDL.
on Follows the version of the SOAP binding in the WSDL. Allows only messages that are bound to SOAP 1.2 to appear in SOAP 1.2 envelopes, and allows only messages that are bound to SOAP 1.1 to appear in SOAP 1.1 envelopes. off (Default) Does not follow the version of the SOAP binding in the WSDL.

entry.name: wsdl_strict_soap_version_compileoptionspolicy_descr_192
entry.text: Determine whether to strictly follow the SOAP binding in the WSDL

entry.name: wsdl_validate_body_compileoptionspolicy_help_193
entry.text:
Sets the level of validation performed on the SOAP Body of a message. Defaults to strict. lax Validate Body contents against WSDL when the first child of SOAP Body matches the WSDL; otherwise do not validate and allow. skip Skip validation and allow. strict Validate all Body contents against WSDL
For example:
wsdl-validate-body lax changes the validation of SOAP Body elements to lax.

entry.name: wsdl_validate_body_compileoptionspolicy_descr_193
entry.text: Defines the level of validation against the WSDL

entry.name: wsdl_validate_faults_compileoptionspolicy_help_194
entry.text:
Sets the level of validation performed on the SOAP Fault messages. Defaults to strict. lax Validate Fault contents against WSDL when the Fault matches the WSDL; otherwise do not validate and allow. skip Skip validation and allow. strict Validate all Fault contents against WSDL
For example:
wsdl-validate-fault lax changes the validation of SOAP Fault elements to lax.

entry.name: wsdl_validate_faults_compileoptionspolicy_descr_194
entry.text: Defines the level of validation against the WSDL

entry.name: wsdl_validate_headers_compileoptionspolicy_help_195
entry.text:
Sets the level of validation performed on the SOAP Headers contained in messages. Defaults to lax. lax Validate Fault contents against WSDL when the Fault matches the WSDL; otherwise do not validate and allow. skip Skip validation and allow. strict Validate all Header contents against WSDL
For example:
wsdl-validate-headers strict changes the validation of SOAP Header elements to strict.

entry.name: wsdl_validate_headers_compileoptionspolicy_descr_195
entry.text: Defines the level of validation against the WSDL

entry.name: wsdl_wrapped_faults_compileoptionspolicy_help_196
entry.text:
For compatibility, require a RPC-style wrapper around fault details that are specified by type. Use the no form of the command to disable this requirement.
For example:
wsdl-wrapped-faults Requires the RPC wrapper around faults specified by type. no wsdl-wrapped-faults disables this requirement.

entry.name: wsdl_wrapped_faults_compileoptionspolicy_descr_196
entry.text: Require RPC wrapper around faults

entry.name: wsi_validate_compileoptionspolicy_help_197
entry.text:
Set level of validation of WSDL files against section 5 of WS-I Basic Profile. fail Reject message and generate error when Profile conformance checking fails. ignore Disable this checking. warn Generate log message when Profile conformance checking fails.
For example:
wsi-validate warn changes the validation to warn.

entry.name: wsi_validate_compileoptionspolicy_descr_197
entry.text: Defines the level of validation against the WSDL

entry.name: xacml_debug_compileoptionspolicy_help_198
entry.text:
Indicates whether to compile XACML policy with debug information.
Note: XACML debugging messages are also controlled by log events in the XACML category. Use the "debug" log level to view the full XACML debugging messages.
on Makes the compiler add more debugging information when evaluating a XACML policy. off (Default) Does not compile the XACML policy with debugging information.

entry.name: xacml_debug_compileoptionspolicy_descr_198
entry.text: Indicates whether to compile XACML policy with debug information

entry.name: xslt_version_compileoptionspolicy_help_199
entry.text:
Set XSLT Specification version used for XSLT error checking. Defaults to 1.0. XSLT10 Sets the XSLT version to 1.0. XSLT20 Sets he XSLT version to 2.0. StylesheetSpecified Uses the version specified in the stylesheet itself.
For example:
xsdlt-version StylesheetSpecified changes the XSLT version to that specified in the stylesheet used.

entry.name: xslt_version_compileoptionspolicy_descr_199
entry.text: Defines the XSLT Version used for error checking

entry.name: bind_dn_kconfigcrl_help_200
entry.text:
Required when defining an LDAP-enabled CRL Update Policy, specifies a login (account) name used to access an LDAP server. dn specifies the account name used to access the LDAP server. For example:
bind-dn datapower specifies the account name (datapower) used to login to an LDAP server

entry.name: bind_dn_kconfigcrl_descr_200
entry.text: Provides a login (account) name

entry.name: bind_pass_kconfigcrl_help_201
entry.text:
Required when defining an LDAP-enabled CRL Update Policy, specifies a password used to access an LDAP server. This property is deprecated and replaced with bind-pass-alias.
password is the password associated with the login account. For example:
bind-pass YeTAnotheRPassWorD specifies the password (YeTAnotheRPassWorD) used to access an LDAP server

entry.name: bind_pass_kconfigcrl_descr_201
entry.text: Provides a password (deprecated)

entry.name: bind_pass_alias_kconfigcrl_help_202
entry.text:
Required when defining an LDAP-enabled CRL Update Policy, specifies a password alias of a password used to access an LDAP server.
password-alias is the password alias of the password associated with the login account. For example:
bind-pass-alias YeTAnotheRPassWorDAliaS specifies the password alias (YeTAnotheRPassWorDAliaS) used to fetch the password to an LDAP server

entry.name: bind_pass_alias_kconfigcrl_descr_202
entry.text: Provides a password alias

entry.name: ldap_readtimeout_kconfigcrl_help_203
entry.text:
Required when defining an LDAP-enabled CRL Update Policy, specifies the number of seconds that the DataPower Gateway should wait for a response from the LDAP server before terminating a connection. For example:
ldap-readtimeout 40 specifies a timeout of 40 seconds after which DataPower will terminate a connection to LDAP server if there is no response from it.

entry.name: ldap_readtimeout_kconfigcrl_descr_203
entry.text: Provides a timeout to terminate hanging LDAP connections

entry.name: ldap_version_kconfigcrl_help_204
entry.text:
Required when defining an LDAP-enabled CRL Update Policy, specifies the LDAP version to be used to access an LDAP server. For example:
ldap-version v3 specifies LDAP version 3 to be used to access an LDAP server

entry.name: ldap_version_kconfigcrl_descr_204
entry.text: Provides LDAP version

entry.name: default_status_kconfigcrl_help_205
entry.text:
Specifies the certificate status in the absence of an updated CRL.
ok (defautl) Certificates are considered valid in the absence of a CRL. revoked Certificates are considered invalid in the absence of a CRL. For example:
default-status revoked specifies that certificates are considered invalid in the absence of a CRL

entry.name: default_status_kconfigcrl_descr_205
entry.text: Specifies certificate status

entry.name: fetch_url_kconfigcrl_help_206
entry.text:
Required when defining an HTTP-enabled Update Policy, specifies the location of the target CRL as a URL. url specifies the location of the target CRL. For example:
fetch-url http://crl.verisign.com/ATTClass1Individual.crl specifies the location of the target CRL

entry.name: fetch_url_kconfigcrl_descr_206
entry.text: Specifies the CRL location as a URL

entry.name: issuer_kconfigcrl_help_207
entry.text:
Specifies a validation Credentials used to validate the credentials of the CRL issuer. Before running this command, you need to enter CRL Mode with an enabled CRL Update Policy.
name identifies the Validation Credentials Set used to authenticate the CRL issuer.
For example:
crl HTTP30 http issuer crfValidate enters CRL Mode, creates the http HTTP-enabled CRL Update Policy, and specifies that validation of the CRL issuer uses the crfValidate Validation Credentials.

entry.name: issuer_kconfigcrl_descr_207
entry.text: Specifies a validation credentials of the CRL issuer.

entry.name: read_dn_kconfigcrl_help_208
entry.text:
Required when defining an LDAP-enabled CRL Update Policy, specifies the distinguished name of the Certificate Authority that issued the target CRL. Use double-quotes around the distinguished name. dn identifies the certificate issuer. For example:
read-dn "C=AU, ST=Victoria, L=South Melbourne, O=VeriSign Australia Limited, OU=IT Department, CN=www.verisign.com.au" The CA that issued the target CRL

entry.name: read_dn_kconfigcrl_descr_208
entry.text: Identifies a CRL issuer

entry.name: refresh_kconfigcrl_help_209
entry.text:
Required when defining either an HTTP-enabled or an LDAP-enabled CRL Update Policy, specifies the interval (in minutes) between CRL updates. update-interval specifies the frequency of updates in seconds. For example:
refresh 1440 specifies daily updates (1440 minutes)

entry.name: refresh_kconfigcrl_descr_209
entry.text: Specifies the CRL update interval

entry.name: remote_address_kconfigcrl_help_210
entry.text:
Identifies the target LDAP server. name The LDAP server by IP address or host name. port The target port. If not specified, uses the default value of 389. For example:
remote address ragnarok Identifies the ragnarok as the host name of the LDAP server and uses the default port of 389.

entry.name: remote_address_kconfigcrl_descr_210
entry.text: Provides an LDAP server address

entry.name: ssl_profile_kconfigcrl_help_211
entry.text:
The TLS proxy profile is deprecated. Use an TLS client profile. Assigns a forward (or client) TLS Proxy profile to the current CRL Update policy. The TLS Proxy profile facilitates the establishment of a secure connection to the remote CRL server name The TLS Proxy forward profile to assign. For example:
ssl TLS-CRLAccess Assigns the TLS-CRLAccess TLS Proxy forward profile.

entry.name: ssl_profile_kconfigcrl_descr_211
entry.text: Deprecated - Assigns an TLS Proxy profile to a CRL Policy

entry.name: ssl_client_type_kconfigcrl_help_212
entry.text:
Specify the type of TLS profile to use. Use "proxy" for TLS proxy profile, and use "client" for TLS client profile. The default value is "proxy". For example:
ssl-client-type client Specifies the use of a TLS client profile

entry.name: ssl_client_type_kconfigcrl_descr_212
entry.text: Specify the type of TLS profile to use.

entry.name: ssl_client_kconfigcrl_help_213
entry.text:
Assigns a TLS client profile to the current CRL Update policy. The TLS client profile establishes a secure connection to the remote CRL server.
name The TLS client profile to assign. For example:
ssl-client TLS-CRLAccess Assigns the TLS-CRLAccess TLS client profile.

entry.name: ssl_client_kconfigcrl_descr_213
entry.text: Assigns a TLS client profile to a CRL Policy

entry.name: certificate_kconfigcrypto_help_214
entry.text:
Creates a certificate alias. cert-alias The alias name. url The location of certificate file. - When stored in the pubcert: directory, takes the following form. pubcert:///filename - When stored cert: directory, takes the following form. cert:///filename When retrieved from z/OS, takes the following form. saf-cert://nssclient/filename password An optional keyword that along with plaintext-password specifies the password or passphrase to access the certificate file. This argument is deprecated and replaced by password-alias. password-alias An optional keyword that along with alias specifies the alias for the encrypted password or passphrase to access the certificate file. The alias must be previously created with the password-map command. ignore-expiration An optional keyword to allow the creation of a certificate prior to its activation date (the NotBefore value in the certificate) or after its expiration date (the NotAfter value in the certificate). Although the certificate is in the up state, objects that reference the certificate use the internal expiration values.
In other words, the certificate itself is in the up state, but validation credentials, firewall credentials, or identification credentials that references the certificate adhere to the internal expiration values. If the certificate is used for a certificate chain validation from a validation credentials and the certificate is not valid, validation fails. Similarly, if the certificate is used from an identification credentials, the DataPower Gateway sends the certificate to the TLS peer for a TLS connection, but the peer can reject the certificate as invalid.
For example:
certificate Alice-1 pubcert:///alice.pem password-alias alexandria Creates the Alice-1 certificate alias for the alice.pem certificate in the pubcert: directory. The certificate is protected by alexandria alias in the password map.

entry.name: certificate_kconfigcrypto_descr_214
entry.text: Creates a certificate alias

entry.name: convert_key_kconfigcrypto_help_215
entry.text:
Converts a private key object to a specific output format and writes it to a file. If the output format includes private fields of the key, the file must be in the same directory as the private key object's configured file.
key The key object to convert. outputfile The name of the output file. format A format (openssh-pubkey). openssh-pubkey format can be used in OpenSSH authorized_keys files and does not contain any private fields of the key (only public ones).

entry.name: convert_key_kconfigcrypto_descr_215
entry.text: Writes a private key object to a file in a specific format

entry.name: convert_certificate_kconfigcrypto_help_216
entry.text:
Converts a certificate object to a specific output format and writes it to a file.
certname specifies the certificate object to be converted. outputfile specifies the name of the output file. format specifies a format (openssh-pubkey). openssh-pubkey format can be used in OpenSSH authorized_keys files.

entry.name: convert_certificate_kconfigcrypto_descr_216
entry.text: Writes a certificate object to a file in a specific format

entry.name: create_luna_clientcert_kconfigcrypto_help_217
entry.text:
Create the Luna client certificate and key pair for DataPower Gateway to establish network trust link (NTL) connection to the Luna HSM.
CN <client hostname> The common name for the certificate. The value must be a fully qualified hostname or IP address of the DataPower Gateway. The Luna HSM registers the DataPower Gateway by the common name. The NTL connection breaks when the provided common name is incorrect. The value is limited to 64 characters. C <country> Optionally specifies the ISO two-character country code. L <locality> Optionally specifies the city or town. The value is limited to 64 characters. ST <state> Optionally specifies an unabbreviated state or province name. The value is limited to 64 characters. O <organization name> Optionally specifies the organization name. The value is limited to 64 characters. OU <organization unit name> Optionally specifies the organizational unit name. The value is limited to 64 characters. Email <email address> Optionally specifies the email address. key-name <private key filename> Optionally specifies the private key file name. Do not specify a directory or a file extension. If not specified, the file name is the common name with a "Key" suffix. cert-name <certificate filename> Optionally specifies the certificate file name. Do not specify a directory or a file extension. If not specified,the common name is used. export-key Optionally creates a copy of the private key in the temporary: directory in addition to one in the cert: directory.
For example:
create-luna-clientcert CN example.com C US O "IBM DataPower" OU "Customer Support" Generates a private key and certificate. The private key file name is "example.comKey.pem" and certificate file name is "example.com.pem".

entry.name: create_luna_clientcert_kconfigcrypto_descr_217
entry.text: Generates a public-private key pair for a Luna HSM client.

entry.name: import_luna_clientcert_kconfigcrypto_help_218
entry.text:
Import the private key and certificate pair to establish the NTL connection to the remote Luna HSM.
key <private key file location> The location of the private key file. The key must be in the cert: directory. cert <certificate file location> The location of the certificate file. The certificate must be in the cert: directory.
For example:
import-luna-clientcert key cert:///key.pem cert cert:///cert.pem imports the "key.pem" as the private key and "cert.pem" as the certificate for the DataPower Gateway to establish the NTL connection to the Luna HSM.

entry.name: import_luna_clientcert_kconfigcrypto_descr_218
entry.text: Import the private key and certificate pair to establish the NTL.

entry.name: kerberos_ticket_delete_kconfigcrypto_help_219
entry.text:
Deletes the specified Kerberos service tickets from the ticket cache.
realm Specifies the Kerberos realm. owner Optionally specifies the owner of the cached Kerberos ticket. client Optionally specifies the Kerberos client principal. server Optionally specifies the Kerberos server principal.

entry.name: kerberos_ticket_delete_kconfigcrypto_descr_219
entry.text: Deletes cached Kerberos tickets

entry.name: oauth_cache_delete_kconfigcrypto_help_220
entry.text:
Deletes cached data for a specific OAuth client from the OAuth cache.
client-id Specifies the OAuth client ID. type Specifies the cache type, which is one of the following values. - dpstate Indicates authorization form states - azcode Indicats authorization codes - access Indicates access tokens - refresh Indicates refresh tokens

entry.name: oauth_cache_delete_kconfigcrypto_descr_220
entry.text: Deletes data for an OAuth client from the cache

entry.name: api_oauth_cache_delete_kconfigcrypto_help_221
entry.text:
Deletes cached responses for a specific OAuth provider from the OAuth cache.
provider Specifies the OAuth provider. type Specifies the cache type, which must be the following value. - 3rdparty Indicates the cache for a third-party provider

entry.name: api_oauth_cache_delete_kconfigcrypto_descr_221
entry.text: Deletes responses for an OAuth provider from the cache

entry.name: crypto_export_kconfigcrypto_help_222
entry.text:
Exports a private key or certificate object (using a variety of encryption mechanisms).
key | cert Specifies the key or certificate object to be exported. output Specifies the name of the local output file. mechanism Specifies an encryption mechanism (hsmkwk). The hsmkwk mechanism is only available on machines with HSMs. No mechanism should be specified when exporting certificates.

entry.name: crypto_export_kconfigcrypto_descr_222
entry.text: Exports a private key or certificate object

entry.name: crypto_import_kconfigcrypto_help_223
entry.text:
Imports a private key or certificate object (using a variety of encryption mechanisms).
key | cert Specifies the key or certificate object to be created by the import. input Specifies the name of the local input file. output Optionally specifies the name of the local output file. password An optional keyword used in conjunction with the following string argument that specifies the password used to encrypt the input file. password-alias An optional keyword used in conjunction with the following string argument that specifies a password alias used to encrypt. the input file.

entry.name: crypto_import_kconfigcrypto_descr_223
entry.text: Imports a private key or certificate, creating a new object of that type

entry.name: hsm_clone_kwk_kconfigcrypto_help_224
entry.text:
Use this command when two HSM-equipped systems have the same key sharing domain and when both systems are at the same FIPS security level. This command copies the key-wrapping key from the source HSM system to the destination HSM system. You must run this command four times.
1. On the source HSM system, create an output file that contains the key material. After you validate that the command created the file, copy it to the destination HSM system. 2. On the destination HSM system, create an output file that uses the copied file as the input file. After you validate that the command created the file, copy it to the source HSM system. 3. On the source HSM system, create an output file that uses the copied file as the input file. After you validate that the command created the file, copy it to the destination HSM system. 4. On the destination HSM system, use the copied file as the input file.
The first run does not require an input and the last run does not require an output. The input to a run must always be the output of the previous run. All file names must use absolute paths.
input Indicates the name of the local file to use as input to the cloning action. During the first part of this four-part task, do not specify this parameter. During the other parts of this task, this parameter is required. output Indicates the name of the local file that the cloning action creates. During the last part of this four-part task, do not specify this parameter. During the other parts of this task, this parameter is required.

entry.name: hsm_clone_kwk_kconfigcrypto_descr_224
entry.text: Clones a key wrapping key between HSM-equipped appliances.

entry.name: hsm_delete_key_kconfigcrypto_help_225
entry.text:
When the HSM is present, deletes the specified key from the HSM.
keyHandle A 64-bit hex key handle that identifies the key stored on the HSM .
For example:
hsm-delete-key 000000000000000a Deletes the specified key from the HSM.

entry.name: hsm_delete_key_kconfigcrypto_descr_225
entry.text: Deletes the specified key.

entry.name: hsm_set_role_kconfigcrypto_help_226
entry.text:
When the HSM is present, this command is used to switch roles from CU to CO and back. The command takes effect at the next appliance start. The specified role remains in effect until the command is called with a different role and the appliance is rebooted again.
Use the CU role for normal operations. Use the CO role only to run the "hsm-clone-kwk" command. The CO role does not support a superset of capabilities. The CO role is not intended for and does not support normal HSM operations that are allowed by the CU role. These CU roles include "show hsm-keys" and "keygen" operations for keys on the HSM, or import or export from the HSM.
Use the "show crypto-engine" command to display the active role.
user Specifies the role as "user" for normal operations such as generation of keys, use of keys, listing of keys, deletion of keys, and import or export of keys. officer Specifies the role as "officer" to clone keys with the "hsm-clone-kwk" command.

entry.name: hsm_set_role_kconfigcrypto_descr_226
entry.text: Schedules the switching of the FIPS 140-2 role for the next restart.

entry.name: hsm_reinit_kconfigcrypto_help_227
entry.text:
This command schedules an HSM reinitialization for the next restart. When you initialize the HSM, it implements FIPS 140-2 Security Level 3. An HSM-equipped appliance does not use a PIN Entry Device (PED). After you initialize the HSM, the next firmware reload deletes all private keys in the HSM.
Instead of using randomly generated credentials for the Cryptographic Office (CO) and Cryptographic User (CU) roles, you can set the names and passwords for these roles. These credentials are used by the DataPower Gateway to authenticate itself in the assigned role to its HSM. Independent of whether these credentials are randomly generated or explicitly defined, you cannot access these credentials. For all other HSM operations, you never need to provide these credentials.
After running this command, immediate restart the DataPower Gateway with the Flash "shutdown reboot" command.
hsm-domain Sets the name of the key-sharing domain. A key-sharing domain is a group of HSM-equipped appliances that support the import and export of keys. Always change the name of the key-sharing domain, never use the default of "datapower" as the name of the key-sharing domain. For improved security, secure the name of the key-sharing domain as part of the protection against key theft.
For HSM-equipped appliances to import and export private keys, you must initialize the appliances with the same name for the key-sharing domain. so-name Optionally specifies the name of the Crypto Officer (CO), which is also known as the Security Officer. On Type 8441 appliances, the name can use all alphanumeric characters and the _ special character. The default behavior is to randomly generate the name. so-password Optionally specifies the password of the CO. The default behavior is to randomly generate the password. user-name Optionally specifies the name of the Crypto User (CU). On Type 8441 appliances, the name can use all alphanumeric characters and the _ special character. The default behavior is to randomly generate the name. user-password Optionally specifies the password of the CU. The default behavior is to randomly generate the password.
Examples: - hsm-reinit hsm-domain domain_5 Reinitialize the HSM with the "domain_5" key-sharing domain and randomly generated credentials for the CO and CU roles. - hsm-reinit hsm-domain domain_5 so-name officer_5 user-name user_5 Reinitialize the HSM with the "domain_5" key-sharing domain, with the "officer_5" CO name and randomly generated password, and with the "user_5" CU name and randomly generated password.

entry.name: hsm_reinit_kconfigcrypto_descr_227
entry.text: Schedules an HSM reinitialization for the next restart.

entry.name: idcred_kconfigcrypto_help_228
entry.text:
Creates an Identification Credentials consisting of a certificate (which contains a public key) and and the corresponding private key. The Identification Credentials Set authenticates a TLS proxy instance. idcred-alias The name the Identification Credentials. key-alias The previously created alias for a locally stored private key. cert-alias The previously created alias for a locally stored certificate. ca The optional keyword that in conjunction with the following cert-alias arguments, identifies the intermediate certificates to establish a "chain-of-trust" that starts with the certificate that is referenced by cert-alias and ends with a CA trusted by the remote TLS peer. cert-alias The previously created alias for an intermediate certificate. You can list up to 10 intermediate certificates.
For example:
idcred ID-bob bob bob Creates the ID-bob Identification Credentials. Theses credentials consists of the bob private key and the bob public key.

entry.name: idcred_kconfigcrypto_descr_228
entry.text: Creates an Identification Credentials

entry.name: kerberos_kdc_kconfigcrypto_help_229
entry.text:
Creates the specified Kerberos Key Distribution Center (KDC) Server object and enters Kerberos KDC Server Configuration Mode.
A Kerberos KDC Server issues Kerberos tickets. Essentially a KDC is a database of all users within the Kerberos realm (or administrative domain). Each user entry in the database is called a principal and includes an associated encryption key that is derived from the user password.
name The name of the Kerberos KDC.
For example:
kerberos-kdc Hades Enters Kerberos KDC Server Configuration Mode and creates the Hades KDC Server object.

entry.name: kerberos_kdc_kconfigcrypto_descr_229
entry.text: Creates the Kerberos KDC Server object.

entry.name: kerberos_keytab_kconfigcrypto_help_230
entry.text:
Creates the specified Kerberos key table (keytab) object and enters Kerberos Keytab Configuration Mode.
A Kerberos keytab (or key table) is an unencrypted file that contains a list of Kerberos principals and their passwords.
name The name of the Kerberos keytab
For example:
kerberos-keytab Inferno Enters Kerberos Keytab Configuration Mode and creates the Inferno keytab object.

entry.name: kerberos_keytab_kconfigcrypto_descr_230
entry.text: Creates the Kerberos keytab object.

entry.name: key_kconfigcrypto_help_231
entry.text:
Creates an alias for a private key. key-alias is the alias name and must be unique within the key alias name-space. url The target file that contains the key. If the key is stored within the private cryptographic area (as recommended by DataPower), the URL takes the form:
file-name
If the key is stored within the public cryptographic area, the URL takes the form:
pubcert:///file-name If the key is retrieved from z/OS, the URL takes the form:
saf-key://nssclient/file-name The file-name identifies a SAF key that is not stored in ICSF.
If the remote key is accessed on z/OS, the URL takes the form:
saf-remote-key://nssclient/file-name The file-name identifies a SAF key that is stored in ICSF.
password is an optional keyword that along with plaintext-password specifies the plaintext password or passphrase that protects the target key file. This argument is deprecated and replaced with password-alias. password-alias is an optional keyword that along with alias specifies the alias for the encrypted password or passphrase that protects the target key file. The alias must have been previously created with the password-map command. For example:
key dpPrivate K2.pem password-alias baltimore creates an alias, dpPrivate, for the key, K2.pem, stored in the private cryptographic storage area. The key is protected by an encrypted password or passphrase aliased by baltimore.

entry.name: key_kconfigcrypto_descr_231
entry.text: Creates a private key alias

entry.name: keygen_kconfigcrypto_help_232
entry.text:
Generates a public-private key pair, a Certificate Signing Request (CSR), and optionally a self-signed certificate for a server.
C | countryName <iso-code> Optionally, the ISO two-character country code for the CSR. L | localityName <locality> Optionally, the city or town for the CSR. Specify a text string up to 64 characters. If the string contains spaces, enclose in double quotation marks. ST | stateOrProvinceName <state> Optionally, an unabbreviated state or province name for the CSR. Specify a text string up to 64 characters. If the string contains spaces, enclose in double quotation marks. O | organizationName <org> Optionally, the organization name for the CSR. Specify a text string up to 64 characters. If the string contains spaces, enclose in double quotation marks. OU | organizationalUnitName <unit-name> Optionally, the organizational unit name for the CSR. Specify a text string up to 64 characters. If the string contains spaces, enclose in double quotation marks. CN | commonName <server-name> The fully qualified domain name of the server for the CSR. Specify a text string up to 64 characters. key-type [RSA | ECDSA] The type of key to generate. The default is RSA. rsa [1024 | 2048 | 4096] The length of the generated RSA key. The default is 2048-bit. The generation of a 4096-bit key can take up to 30 seconds. digest [sha1 | sha256] The hash algorithm of the generated RSA keys. The default value is sha256. This keyword is required only when the key type is RSA and the gen-sscert keyword is set to on. ecdsa-curve <curve-name> The elliptic curve for the generated ECDSA key. The default value is secp521r1 (NIST/SECG curve over a 521 bit prime field). gen-object Creates a crypto key object. To create a crypto certificate object, use the gen-sscert property. object-name <name> Optionally, the object names that are created by the gen-object property. If not specified, the value for the commonName property is used. gen-sscert Optionally creates a self-signed certificate in addition to the private key and CSR. days <number-days> The validity period in days for the self-signed certificate. The default is 365. file-name <name> Optionally, a common prefix for the generated private key, CSR, and self-signed certificate. If not specified, the value for the object-name property is used. export-key Optionally creates a copy of the private key in the temporary: directory in addition to one in the cert: directory. export-sscert Optionally creates a copy of the self-signed certificate in the temporary: directory in addition to the one in the cert: directory. password <plaintext> Optionally, the password to use to encrypt the private key when it is saved to a file and to decrypt the password to access the file. The use of a password is deprecated. Instead, use a password alias. password-alias <alias> Optionally, the password alias map that defines the alias that maps to the cleartext password. The password in the map encrypts the files, and the alias in the map decrypts the passwords to access the file. hsm On HSM-ready appliances, optionally creates the private key on the HSM instead of in memory. hsm-name <name> On HSM-ready appliances, optionally specifies a label for the key created on the HSM. If not specified, the value of the object-name property is used. using-key <name> Optionally, the existing crypto key object to use to sign the CSR and any certificate that is generated. config-file <name> Optionally, when generating a CSR or self-signed certificate, specifies the configuration file to read the DN and OIDs from. The configuration file must be in the OpenSSL CNF format. You must upload the configuration file to the temporary: directory. When you specify the config-file parameter, you must specify the commonName, file-name, or object-name parameter.
For example:
keygen C au L "South Melbourne" ST Victoria O "Example Australia, Ltd." OU "Customer Support" CN www.bob.example.com.au gen-sscert file-name bob Generates a private key, CSR, and self-signed certificate for the specified server. Default conditions apply as follows. - The private key (2048-bits in length) is saved as cert:bob-privkey.pem. - The CSR is saved as temporary:bob.csr. - The self-signed certificate is saved as cert:bob-sscert.pem. - The private key file is not password protected.

entry.name: keygen_kconfigcrypto_descr_232
entry.text: Generates a key pair, a CSR, and a self-signed certificate

entry.name: password_map_kconfigcrypto_help_233
entry.text: Interactively solicits alias names and plaintext passwords. Plaintext passwords are encrypted, associated with the alias, and stored in the password map. Enter a blank alias-name to signal completion.

entry.name: password_map_kconfigcrypto_descr_233
entry.text: Accesses the Password map

entry.name: delete_password_map_kconfigcrypto_help_234
entry.text: Deletes a single alias from the password map. Deleting an alias has no immediate effect on certificates and keys that are already loaded in memory. However, certificates and keys that are related to the deleted alias might become unusable after a restart, unless the password map was refreshed with new data.

entry.name: delete_password_map_kconfigcrypto_descr_234
entry.text: Deletes a password map alias

entry.name: profile_kconfigcrypto_help_235
entry.text:
Creates a crypto profile that defines a level of TLS service. The crypto profile can contain an Identification Credentials that authenticates a TLS proxy, a validation list, a list of supported ciphers, and whether to enable or disable various OpenSSL options. name The name of the crypto profile. idcred The alias for an Identification Credentials that was previously created with the idcred command. Assigning Identification Credentials to a crypto profile is required when the profile is for a TLS server. Assigning Identification Credentials is optional when the crypto profile is for a TLS client. %%none%% The keyword that specifies no Identification Credentials. ssl <valcred> The optional keyword that is used in conjunction with the valcred argument to assign Validation Credentials. When assigned, Validation Credentials must be used during the TLS handshake to authenticate TLS peer certificates. ciphers <list> The optional keyword that is used in conjunction with the cipher-list identifies the symmetric key-encryption algorithms. options <mask> Which TLS options to support. Specify the string or its hex representation. clientcalist Whether to enable "on" or disable "off" the transmission of a client CA list during the TLS handshake.
For example:
profile Low SSL-1 options Disable-SSLv2+Disable-TLSv1 Creates the Low crypto profile that uses TLS-1 Identification Credentials to identify the TLS proxy. The crypto profile specifies no peer validation, disables SSL Version 2 and TLS Version 1.0, and supports the default cipher list.

entry.name: profile_kconfigcrypto_descr_235
entry.text: Creates a crypto profile

entry.name: sskey_kconfigcrypto_help_236
entry.text:
Creates an alias for a shared secret key. key-alias The alias name. local-url The locally stored file that contains the shared secret key.
For example:
sskey alice cert:///alicekey Creates the alice shared secret key that is stored in the "cert:" directory.

entry.name: sskey_kconfigcrypto_descr_236
entry.text: Creates a shared secret key alias

entry.name: test_password_map_kconfigcrypto_help_237
entry.text:
Verifies if the named encrypted password alias opens a specified file. alias-name The alias for the encrypted password. cert Indicates a certificate file. key Indicates a private key file. local-url The location of the locally stored cryptographic file.
For example:
test password-map towson cert pubcert:///dpsupplied.pem Alias towson with file pubcert:dpsupplied.pem --> FAIL The encrypted password aliased by towson is not the one that can open the dpsupplied.pem certificate file.

entry.name: test_password_map_kconfigcrypto_descr_237
entry.text: Tests an alias against the password map

entry.name: undo_kconfigcrypto_help_238
entry.text:
Reverts the specified object to its last persisted state. On success, the message, "Configuration reverted." is displayed.
type The type of object. For a complete list, use the "show" command. name The name of the target object.

entry.name: undo_kconfigcrypto_descr_238
entry.text: Reverts an unpersisted object.

entry.name: port_cryptokerberoskdc_help_239
entry.text:
Specifies the UDP or TCP port monitored by the target Kerberos KDC Server.
portNumber is an integer within the range 1 through 65535, with a default of 88, that identifies the Kerberos server port.
For example:
port 8888 specifies port 8888 as the monitored port.

entry.name: port_cryptokerberoskdc_descr_239
entry.text: Specifies the listening port.

entry.name: realm_cryptokerberoskdc_help_240
entry.text:
Specifies the realm (administrative domain) supported by the target Kerberos KCD Server. You must specify a Kerberos realm to complete KDC configuration.
realmName provides the name of the Kerberos realm.
For example:
realm us.ibm.com provides us.ibm.com as the Kerberos realm.

entry.name: realm_cryptokerberoskdc_descr_240
entry.text: Specifies the supported realm.

entry.name: server_cryptokerberoskdc_help_241
entry.text:
Identifies the Kerberos KDC Server by domain name or IP address. You must specify a Kerberos KDC Server to complete KDC configuration.
kdcServer identifies the Kerberos KDC Server by name or IP address.
For example:
server Furio identifies the Kerberos KDC Server by the Furio domain name.
server 192.168.12.12 identifies the Kerberos KDC Server by IP address.

entry.name: server_cryptokerberoskdc_descr_241
entry.text: Identifies the KDC server.

entry.name: tcp_cryptokerberoskdc_help_242
entry.text:
Enables TCP as the transport layer protocol when contacting the Kerberos KDC Server.
For example:
tcp on specifies TCP as the transport layer protocol.
tcp off restores UDP, the default, as the transport layer protocol.

entry.name: tcp_cryptokerberoskdc_descr_242
entry.text: Sets TCP or UDP as the transport layer.

entry.name: udp_timeout_cryptokerberoskdc_help_243
entry.text:
When using UDP as the transport protocol, specifies the number of seconds to wait for a server response. This command is meaningful only when the default UDP protocol is used to access the Kerberos KDC Server.
timeValue is an interval within the range 1 through 60, with a default value of 5, that specifies the maximum time to wait for a Kerberos KDC Server response.
For example:
udp-timeout 7 specifies 7 seconds as the timeout value.

entry.name: udp_timeout_cryptokerberoskdc_descr_243
entry.text: Specifies the time to wait for a response.

entry.name: cache_tickets_cryptokerberoskdc_help_244
entry.text:
Specifies whether to cache Kerberos service tickets when generating AP-REQ tokens in this realm. The default value is on.
For example:
cache-tickets off disables Kerberos service ticket caching in the realm.

entry.name: cache_tickets_cryptokerberoskdc_descr_244
entry.text: Specifies whether to cache Kerberos service tickets.

entry.name: max_cached_tickets_cryptokerberoskdc_help_245
entry.text:
When ticket caching is enabled, specifies the maximum number of Kerberos service tickets per owner principal to cache in this realm.
For example:
max-cached-tickets 7 specifies that the ticket cache should only hold up to 7 tickets per owner principal in this realm.

entry.name: max_cached_tickets_cryptokerberoskdc_descr_245
entry.text: Specifies the maximum number of tickets per owner to cache.

entry.name: min_cached_ticket_validity_cryptokerberoskdc_help_246
entry.text:
When ticket caching is enabled, specifies the minimum amount of validity time in seconds that must remain on a Kerberos service ticket for it to be reused from the ticket cache during AP-REQ token generation.
For example:
min-cached-ticket-validity 7 specifies that service tickets in the cache with less than 7 seconds of validity on them will not be reused during AP-REQ token generation.

entry.name: min_cached_ticket_validity_cryptokerberoskdc_descr_246
entry.text: Specifies the minimum amount of time that must remain on a ticket for it to be reused.

entry.name: file_name_cryptokerberoskeytab_help_247
entry.text:
Specifies the file that contains the Kerberos keytab. This file contains keys used to decrypt Kerberos tickets.
The keytab file is Kerberos generated and must have previously been downloaded to the device cert: directory.
fileURL identities the name of the keytab file, and takes the form: cert:<fileName>.
For example:
filename cert:KKTab identifies the keytab file.

entry.name: file_name_cryptokerberoskeytab_descr_247
entry.text: Specifies the file that contains the Kerberos keytab.

entry.name: use_replay_cache_cryptokerberoskeytab_help_248
entry.text: Whether to cache Kerberos authenticators on tickets that are destined for Kerberos principals in this keytab in order to prevent replay attacks. The default is on.

entry.name: use_replay_cache_cryptokerberoskeytab_descr_248
entry.text: Use Replay Cache

entry.name: generate_gss_checksum_cryptokerberoskeytab_help_249
entry.text: Whether to generate a GSS-API checksum when generating AP-REQ tokens with this keytab.

entry.name: generate_gss_checksum_cryptokerberoskeytab_descr_249
entry.text: Generate GSS-API Checksum in AP-REQ

entry.name: gss_checksum_flags_cryptokerberoskeytab_help_250
entry.text: Which flags to set in GSS-API checksums when generating AP-REQ tokens with this keytab.

entry.name: gss_checksum_flags_cryptokerberoskeytab_descr_250
entry.text: GSS-API Checksum Flags

entry.name: name_server_dnsnameservice_help_251
entry.text:
Identifies a local DNS provider.
ip-address is the IP address of the DNS server.
For example:
name-server 10.10.10.240 identifies a DNS server at 10.10.10.240.

entry.name: name_server_dnsnameservice_descr_251
entry.text: Identifies a local DNS provider.

entry.name: search_domain_dnsnameservice_help_252
entry.text:
Adds an entry to the IP domain-suffix search table, thus enabling the usage of non-fully qualified domain names. The search-domain and ip domain CLI commands both enable the usage on non-fully qualified domain names (host names) by specifying a list of one or more domain names that can be appended to a host name.
Use multiple search domain or ip domain commands to add more than one entry to the IP domain name table.
The device attempts to resolve a host name in conjunction with any of the domains that are identified by the search domain or ip domain command. The host name is resolved as soon as a match is found.
domain name is a base domain name to which a host name can be prefixed.
For example:
search-domain datapower.com search-domain somewhereelse.com search-domain endoftheearth.com adds three IP domains (datapower.com, somewhereelse.com, and endoftheearth.com) to the IP domain table. The device attempts to resolve the host name loki in three ways: loki.datapower.com loki.somewhereelse.com loki.endoftheearth.com

entry.name: search_domain_dnsnameservice_descr_252
entry.text: Adds an entry to the IP domain-suffix search table.

entry.name: static_host_dnsnameservice_help_253
entry.text:
Maps a specified host name to a specified IP address.
hostName is the name of the host.
ipAddress is the IP address of the host.
For example:
static-host loki 10.10.10.168 maps IP address 10.10.10.168 to the host loki.

entry.name: static_host_dnsnameservice_descr_253
entry.text: Maps a host name to an IP address.

entry.name: ip_preference_dnsnameservice_help_254
entry.text: When a hostname resolves to both v4 and v6 IP addresses, this option determines which version to use.

entry.name: ip_preference_dnsnameservice_descr_254
entry.text: Specifies the preferred IP version when resolving hostnames.

entry.name: force_ip_preference_dnsnameservice_help_255
entry.text:
Specifies whether to restrict DNS queries to the preferred IP version. You want to force the IP preference except when both IPv4 and IPv6 addresses are in use. When not forced, the DataPower Gateway resolves each host name by querying A and AAAA records and waiting for both responses or a timeout. Waiting for the response or timeout for both records can introduce unnecessary latency in DNS resolution.
To set the preferred IP version, use the ip-preference command.
on Sends DNS queries to only the preferred IP version: A (IPv4) or AAAA (IPv6) record. This setting avoids latency with unneeded IPv6 queries in IPv4-only environments and vice versa. off Sends DNS queries for both A and AAAA records. This setting is the default setting.

entry.name: force_ip_preference_dnsnameservice_descr_255
entry.text: Specifies whether to restrict DNS queries to the preferred IP version.

entry.name: load_balance_dnsnameservice_help_256
entry.text:
If multiple name servers are specified in the DNS Settings object, specifies how DNS lookups are distributed to configured name servers. The default is first-alive.
For example: load-balance round-robin distributes the DNS lookups in a round-robin fashion amongst the configured name servers. load-balance first-alive distributes all DNS lookups to the first available name server in the list of configured name servers.

entry.name: load_balance_dnsnameservice_descr_256
entry.text: Specifies the load balancing algorithm to use when resolving hostnames.

entry.name: retries_dnsnameservice_help_257
entry.text:
If the first attempt to resolve a hostname is not acknowledged, specifies how many additional times the DataPower Gateway attempts to resolve the hostname to different DNS servers according to the load balancing algorithm specified. The default is 2.
Any value specified for the retries is ignored when the load balancing algorithm is round robin.
For example:
retries 2 sets the number of retries to 2.

entry.name: retries_dnsnameservice_descr_257
entry.text: Specifies the maximum number of resolution request retries.

entry.name: timeout_dnsnameservice_help_258
entry.text:
Specifies how many seconds can elapse before the DataPower Gateway attempts to retry the query with a different name-server according to the load balancing algorithm specified. The default is 5.
Any value specified for the timeout is ignored when the load balancing algorithm is round robin.
For example:
timeout 5 sets the timeout to 5 seconds.

entry.name: timeout_dnsnameservice_descr_258
entry.text: Specifies the maximum to wait for a response to a DNS query before sending the request to a different server.

entry.name: clear_kconfigdocumentcache_help_259
entry.text:
Deletes or marks as expired all or specified documents from the document cache. When specified without arguments, all documents are deleted.
url-match The optional shell-style regular expression that identifies which documents to delete or to mark as expired. "on" Matching documents are marked as expired. "off" Matching documents are deleted, which is the default behavior. key-match The optional cache key to restrict the URL match to only documents with this cache key. This parameter is valid only when you include the "url-match" parameter.
For example:
clear *.gif Deletes all GIF documents. clear *.gif on Marks all GIF documents as expired. clear *.gif off key1 Deletes only GIF documents with the key1 cache key.

entry.name: clear_kconfigdocumentcache_descr_259
entry.text: Deletes documents from the document cache

entry.name: maxdocs_kconfigdocumentcache_help_260
entry.text:
Specifies the maximum number of documents that can be cached.
documents The maximum number of document that can be cached. Enter a value in the range 1 - 250000. The default value is 5000.
For example:
max-docs 4000 Sets the cache to contain a maximum number of 4000 documents.

entry.name: maxdocs_kconfigdocumentcache_descr_260
entry.text: Sizes the cache in terms of documents

entry.name: max_writes_kconfigdocumentcache_help_261
entry.text:
Specifies the maximum number of concurrent writes to create documents or refresh expired documents in the cache
writes Specify an integer within the range 1 to 32768. The default value is 32768. When the maximum number is reached, requests are forwarded to the target server and the response is not written to the cache. For example:
max-writes 1000 Sets a maximum number of outstanding requests of 1000.

entry.name: max_writes_kconfigdocumentcache_descr_261
entry.text: Maximum number of concurrent writes to create documents in the cache

entry.name: policy_kconfigdocumentcache_help_262
entry.text:
Defines a document caching policy, consisting of match conditions, a document priority, and a document lifetime.
match-pattern The shell-style regular expression that identifies documents to store in the document cache. priority Specifies the priority of the document in the cache. Enter a value in the range 1 - 255. The greater the value, the higher the priority. Without a defined priority, the default value of 128 is used. TTL Specifies the maximum time in seconds that a document is retained in the cache. Enter a value in the range 5 - 31708800. When no cache-lifetime is provided, HTTP-based caching rules are applied. protocol Indicates HTTP-based caching rules are applied. nocache Indicates that documents that match the pattern are not cached. data-grid Specifies the eXtreme Scale grid to use for caching. Use "" to disable caching. cache-responses Indicates whether to cache the response to an HTTP GET request. The default value is "off". "on" Caches server responses. "off" Does not cache server responses. cache-validation Indicates whether the document cache operates on HTTP cache validation requests from the client. The default value is "off". "on" Operates on HTTP cache validation requests, which include any of the following request-header fields. - "If-Modified-Since" - "If-Unmodified-Since" - "If-Match" - "If-None-Match" "off" Does not operate on HTTP cache validation requests that include the request-header fields. return-expired Indicates whether to return expired, or stale, content. The default value is "off". "on" To return expired content, the client request must indicate that it is acceptable to receive a stale resource by using the Cache-Control max-stale directive as defined in RFC 7234 section 5.2.1.2. In the following situations, the expired content is returned. - The DataPower Gateway cannot establish a connection with the origin server. - Another request is actively fetching a fresh version from the origin server. "off" Does not return expired content. REST-invalidation Indicates whether to invalidate the document cache entry when a PUT, POST, or DELETE request matches the entry. The default value is "off". "on" Invalidates the document cache entry on PUT, POST, or DELETE requests. "off" Does not invalidate the document cache entry on PUT, POST, or DELETE requests. cache-response-PUT-POST-request Indicates whether to cache the response to POST and PUT requests. To cache responses to POST and PUT requests, in addition to requests in a processing policy, enable the "cache-response-PUT-POST-request" and "cache-responses" parameters. The default value is "off". "on" Caches responses to POST and PUT requests. "off" Does not cache responses to POST and PUT requests.
Examples
- Cache all XML schemas with the default priority and TTL. policy *xsd - Cache all XML schemas with a priority of 210 and the default TTL. policy *xsd 210 - Cache all stylesheets and schemas with a priority of 255 and the default TTL. Cache all XML files with the default priority and TTL. Cache all GIF files with a priority of 1 and the default TTL. policy *xs[dl] 255 policy *xml policy *gif 1 Cache responses whose URL contains datapower.com. Specify that the policy has a priority of 200, a lifetime of 1 hour, and the wxs-cache grid. The policy includes any server responses and operates on HTTP cache validation requests on a cache match. If the request fails to reach the origin server, the last cached version of a stale document is returned if the client requests stale content. The policy does not use RESTful invalidation. The policy caches responses to POST and PUT requests. policy *datapower.com* 200 3600 wxs-cache on on on off on

entry.name: policy_kconfigdocumentcache_descr_262
entry.text: Defines a cache policy

entry.name: size_kconfigdocumentcache_help_263
entry.text:
Specifies the maximum number of bytes to be cached. By default, the document cache size is disabled. You must size the cache to enable caching.
bytes Specifies the maximum capacity of the cache.

entry.name: size_kconfigdocumentcache_descr_263
entry.text: Sizes the cache in bytes.

entry.name: static_document_calls_kconfigdocumentcache_help_264
entry.text:
By default, static document calls are enabled (on).
For example:
static-document-calls off Treats all document calls as independent of each other.

entry.name: static_document_calls_kconfigdocumentcache_descr_264
entry.text: Enables/disables static document calls

entry.name: namespace_mapping_documentcryptomap_help_265
entry.text:
Adds xmlns data to the current Document Crypto map. prefix is the namespace prefix. uri specifies the namespace location. For example:
namespace-mapping SOAP http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/ specifies the schema for SOAP/1.1 envelope

entry.name: namespace_mapping_documentcryptomap_descr_265
entry.text: Adds xmlns data to a Document Crypto map

entry.name: operation_documentcryptomap_help_266
entry.text:
Specifies the crypto operation (encryption or decryption) to be performed on the document nodes identified by the select command. In the absence of this argument, the default operation (encryption) is performed. encryption specifies node encryption (the default). decryption specifies node decryption. For example:
operation decryption specifies that selected nodes will be decrypted

entry.name: operation_documentcryptomap_descr_266
entry.text: Identifies the required crypto operation

entry.name: select_documentcryptomap_help_267
entry.text:
Specifies the document nodes that will be encrypted or decrypted. xpath-expression An XPath expression. Document nodes matching this expression will be encrypted or decrypted (depending on the value of the operation argument. For example:
select //SSN specifies that SSN nodes will be encrypted or decrypted

entry.name: select_documentcryptomap_descr_267
entry.text: Selects document nodes for crypto operations

entry.name: type_webapperrorhandlingpolicy_help_268
entry.text:
An Error Handling Policy may operate in one of four modes:
standard uses the Error Map specified for active Application Security Policy. This is the default. redirect redirects the client to the URL specified by error-url. proxy fetches and returns to the client to the content found at the URL specified by the error-url command. error-rule executes the Processing Rule identified by error-rule command. the URL specified by the error-url command.
For example:
type proxy sets the operation mode to proxy. You must then use error-url to set a URL from which to fetch content.

entry.name: type_webapperrorhandlingpolicy_descr_268
entry.text: Determines the Mode of operation

entry.name: error_url_webapperrorhandlingpolicy_help_269
entry.text:
Use this command to set the URL used by either the proxy or redirect modes.
URL A complete URL to the content returned when an error is encountered.
For example:
error-url http://host.domain.com/errors/webappfw.html The client will either be redirected to this URL or this content will be fetched and returned to the client.

entry.name: error_url_webapperrorhandlingpolicy_descr_269
entry.text: Sets the URL for both proxy and redirect modes.

entry.name: error_monitor_webapperrorhandlingpolicy_help_270
entry.text:
Use this command to set the Count Monitor used to track error transactions.
CountMonitorName specifies the Count Monitor incremented in the event of an error. Count Monitor must already exist. Use Global Configuration Mode command monitor-count to create a new monitor.
For example:
error-monitor wafw-error-count increments the wafw-error-count monitor.

entry.name: error_monitor_webapperrorhandlingpolicy_descr_270
entry.text: Identifies a Count Monitor to use with this policy

entry.name: error_rule_webapperrorhandlingpolicy_help_271
entry.text:
Sets the Processing Rule that is used in error-rule mode.
ProcessingRuleName Specifies the Processing Rule executed on the error condition.Processing Rule must already exist. Use the rule Global Configuration command to create a new rule.
For example:
error-rule wafw-error-rule Applies the wafw-error-rule to all matching errors.

entry.name: error_rule_webapperrorhandlingpolicy_descr_271
entry.text: Identifies an Error Rule to execute on errors.

entry.name: always_on_startup_errorreportsettings_help_272
entry.text:
When enabled (on) generates a report on every DataPower Gateway startup; when disabled (off, the default) notification is not generated unless an error occurred. It is recommended to disable this option during development but to enable it in production.
For example:
always-on-startup on generates a notification report on every DataPower Gateway startup.

entry.name: always_on_startup_errorreportsettings_descr_272
