entry.text: Determines whether to automatically generate an error report on reboot or reload.

entry.name: always_on_shutdown_errorreportsettings_help_273
entry.text:
When enabled (on, the default) generates a report on every DataPower Gateway shutdown; when disabled (off) notification is not generated on DataPower Gateway shutdown. It is recommended to disable this option during development but to enable it in production.
For example:
always-on-shutdown on generates a notification report on every DataPower Gateway shutdown.

entry.name: always_on_shutdown_errorreportsettings_descr_273
entry.text: Determines whether to automatically generate an error report on shutdown.

entry.name: email_address_errorreportsettings_help_274
entry.text: Specifies the e-mail address to which the error report will be sent.

entry.name: email_address_errorreportsettings_descr_274
entry.text: Specify the e-mail address to which to send the error report.

entry.name: email_sender_address_errorreportsettings_help_275
entry.text: Specifies the e-mail address that will be used in the 'from' line of the error report email. If not specified, the configuration uses the e-mail address of the recipient.

entry.name: email_sender_address_errorreportsettings_descr_275
entry.text: Specify the e-mail address from which the error report will be sent.

entry.name: internal_state_errorreportsettings_help_276
entry.text:
When enabled (on) the generated error notification contains internal state of the machine; when disabled (off, the default) this data is not contained in the generated report. The internal state can be useful in diagnosing the cause of the error.
For example:
internal-state on Includes internal state of the machine in the generated failure notification.

entry.name: internal_state_errorreportsettings_descr_276
entry.text: Include internal snapshot in the error report.

entry.name: location_id_errorreportsettings_help_277
entry.text:
Provides a text string that can be used by the message recipient to identify the device that issued the failure report. string Identifies the message source. Use double quotes (") to bracket a string that contains spaces. For example:
location-id "DP at South Campus Building 9" Identifies the message originator.

entry.name: location_id_errorreportsettings_descr_277
entry.text: String to identify the issuing device

entry.name: mode_errorreportsettings_help_278
entry.text:
Enables/disables failure notification.
on Enables error notification. off Disables error notification. For example:
mode on Enables error notification

entry.name: mode_errorreportsettings_descr_278
entry.text: Enables/disables failure notification

entry.name: remote_address_errorreportsettings_help_279
entry.text:
Provides the address of a remote server that provides SMTP service to the message recipient. smtp-server-address The target remote SMTP server by IP address or by host name. For example:
remote-address smtp.customer.com The remote SMTP server.

entry.name: remote_address_errorreportsettings_descr_279
entry.text: Provides the remote SMTP server address

entry.name: upload_report_errorreportsettings_help_280
entry.text: Determine whether to upload the error report to a specified destination either on or off the DataPower Gateway.

entry.name: upload_report_errorreportsettings_descr_280
entry.text: Indicates whether to upload the error report.

entry.name: protocol_errorreportsettings_help_281
entry.text: Specify the protocol for uploading the error report. The error report can be loaded using FTP, SMTP, RAID, iSCSI (deprecated), NFS or to temporary storage.

entry.name: protocol_errorreportsettings_descr_281
entry.text: Indicates the protocol to be used for uploading the error report.

entry.name: protocol_errorreportsettings_help_282
entry.text: Specify the protocol for uploading the error report. The error report can be uploaded using SMTP, or output to either mqdiag: or temporary storage.

entry.name: protocol_errorreportsettings_descr_282
entry.text: Indicates the protocol to be used for uploading the error report.

entry.name: ftp_server_errorreportsettings_help_283
entry.text: Specify the host name or IP address of the FTP server to be used when sending the error report.

entry.name: ftp_server_errorreportsettings_descr_283
entry.text: Indicates the remote FTP server to which to upload the error report.

entry.name: ftp_path_errorreportsettings_help_284
entry.text: Specify the path to be used when uploading the error report with FTP. Use '%%2F' to specify an absolute path.

entry.name: ftp_path_errorreportsettings_descr_284
entry.text: Indicates the path on the FTP server for uploading the report.

entry.name: ftp_user_agent_errorreportsettings_help_285
entry.text: Specify the User Agent that describes how to connect to remote FTP servers. In addition to the FTP Policy to define the connection, ensure that this User Agent defines the basic authentication policy (user name and password) to connect to the FTP server.

entry.name: ftp_user_agent_errorreportsettings_descr_285
entry.text: Indicates the FTP user agent to be used

entry.name: nfs_mount_errorreportsettings_help_286
entry.text: Specifies the NFS mount point where the error report will be uploaded.

entry.name: nfs_mount_errorreportsettings_descr_286
entry.text: Specify the NFS mount point to which to upload the error report.

entry.name: nfs_path_errorreportsettings_help_287
entry.text: Specifies the NFS path location where the error report will be uploaded.

entry.name: nfs_path_errorreportsettings_descr_287
entry.text: Specify the NFS path location to upload the error report.

entry.name: raid_volume_errorreportsettings_help_288
entry.text: Specifies the RAID volume on the array where the error report will be uploaded.

entry.name: raid_volume_errorreportsettings_descr_288
entry.text: Specify the RAID volume on the hard disk array to which to upload the error report.

entry.name: raid_path_errorreportsettings_help_289
entry.text: Specifies the directory on the RAID volume where the error report will be uploaded.

entry.name: raid_path_errorreportsettings_descr_289
entry.text: Specify the directory on the RAID volume to which to upload the error report.

entry.name: use_smtp_errorreportsettings_help_290
entry.text: Specify whether to send an e-mail that contains the error report. If you want to receive e-mail notification, use the upload error report property instead of this property.

entry.name: use_smtp_errorreportsettings_descr_290
entry.text: Specify whether to send an e-mail that contains the error report.

entry.name: summary_errorreportsettings_help_291
entry.text: Brief summary for user annotation.

entry.name: summary_errorreportsettings_descr_291
entry.text: Brief summary for user annotation.

entry.name: ffdc_packet_capture_errorreportsettings_help_292
entry.text:
This feature enables network packet capture for all interfaces including the internal loopback interface. When enabled, this feature runs continuously.
If the DataPower Gateway encounters a problem or a user triggers the generation of an error report, the error report includes the data from this packet capture data. This data helps to determine the messages that the DataPower Gateway was processing when it encountered the problem.

entry.name: ffdc_packet_capture_errorreportsettings_descr_292
entry.text: Specify whether to use a background packet capture.

entry.name: ffdc_event_log_errorreportsettings_help_293
entry.text:
This feature enables the capture of all log and trace points with minimal overhead. When enabled, this feature runs continuously.
If the DataPower Gateway encounters a problem or a user triggers the generation of an error report, the error report includes data from this log capture. This data can help IBM Support identify the problem.
These messages are independent of messages written to log and trace targets.

entry.name: ffdc_event_log_errorreportsettings_descr_293
entry.text: Specify whether to use a background log capture.

entry.name: ffdc_memory_trace_errorreportsettings_help_294
entry.text:
Specify whether to enable automatic leak detection. This feature finds gradual memory leaks that occur steadily over time. This feature does not help in situations where messages are larger than the DataPower Gateway can parse.
When enabled and if memory falls below an internal threshold, the DataPower Gateway tracks all memory allocations. When the DataPower Gateway reaches a critical condition that will lead to a crash, it generates an error report that contains information about memory allocation.
The configuration of the Throttle Settings affects this feature. The throttle settings can prevent the DataPower Gateway from reaching the internal threshold.

entry.name: ffdc_memory_trace_errorreportsettings_descr_294
entry.text: Specify whether to enable automatic leak detection.

entry.name: report_history_errorreportsettings_help_295
entry.text:
Specifies the maximum number of error reports to be maintained when using the upload error report feature. After reaching this limit, the next error report overwrites the oldest error report. Use any value from 1 - 10. The default value is 5.
If the reports are being stored remotely, this setting does not overwrite older error reports. You must manage these remote reports manually.
Regardless of where error reports are uploaded, this setting configures the number of error reports reported in the Failure Notification status provider.

entry.name: report_history_errorreportsettings_descr_295
entry.text: Specify the maximum number of local error reports to maintain.

entry.name: quoted_command_ftpquotecommands_help_296
entry.text:
Adds a command to the end of the list of commands to be sent by the FTP User Agent to a server before a file transfer. Generally used to send "SITE" commands. ftp-command is the FTP command to send. For example:
quoted-command "SITE REFCM=FB" adds the command "SITE RECFM=FB" to the commands sent

entry.name: quoted_command_ftpquotecommands_descr_296
entry.text: Adds an entry to this list of quoted FTP commands

entry.name: certificate_cryptofwcred_help_297
entry.text:
Adds an aliased certificate to the firewall credentials list. cert-alias Identifies the target certificate alias. For example:
certificate bob Adds the certificate aliased by bob.

entry.name: certificate_cryptofwcred_descr_297
entry.text: Adds an entry to a firewall credentials list

entry.name: key_cryptofwcred_help_298
entry.text:
Adds an aliased private key to the firewall credentials list. key-alias Identifies the target key alias. For example:
key bob Adds the key aliased by bob.

entry.name: key_cryptofwcred_descr_298
entry.text: Adds an entry to a firewall credentials list

entry.name: sskey_cryptofwcred_help_299
entry.text: Adds the aliased shared secret key to the firewall credentials list. sskey-alias The target shared secret key.

entry.name: sskey_cryptofwcred_descr_299
entry.text: Adds an entry to a firewall credentials list

entry.name: boot_config_kconfigflash_help_300
entry.text:
Designates the named file as the boot or startup configuration, the configuration that will be invoked when the device next reboots or restarts. filename The target configuration. For example:
boot config config-1.cfg designates config-1.cfg as the startup configuration

entry.name: boot_config_kconfigflash_descr_300
entry.text: Identifies the boot configuration

entry.name: tenant_install_kconfigflash_help_301
entry.text:
Creates a tenant and installs its initial firmware image. Before you can use the tenant, you must acknowledge the acceptance of the terms of the license agreements.
accept-license Optionally indicates the acceptance of the terms of the license agreements. When you do not specify this parameter, you must configure and access the web management interface to accept the terms of the license agreements. name Specifies the name of the tenant to create. file Specifies the name of the file that contains the initial firmware image to install. The file must be in the "image:" directory.
For example:
tenant-install accept-license tenant01 v760 Create the "tenant01" tenant with the "v760" file in the "image:" directory and acknowledges acceptance of the term of the license agreements.

entry.name: tenant_install_kconfigflash_descr_301
entry.text: Creates a tenant and installs its initial firmware image.

entry.name: tenant_restore_kconfigflash_help_302
entry.text: Restores or reconciles tenant(s) configuration. Compares tenant config object properties with actual tenant configuration as stored in the tenant itself. If tenant configuration object is lost for whatever reason (e.g. forgotten write memory after successful tenant installation and configuration), this command recreates the tenant configuration object in the landlord.

entry.name: tenant_restore_kconfigflash_descr_302
entry.text: Restores tenant configuration

entry.name: boot_image_kconfigflash_help_303
entry.text:
Manages the installed firmware and features by processing the instructions in the file that contains the management tool. This command processes the following firmware management actions. - Install a firmware image, and restart the DataPower Gateway. - Activate, disable, or re-enable features in add-on modules. - Run the integrity verifier tool.
Note: You can obtain all files at no cost from IBM Fix Central, except the files to activate features in add-on modules. For files that activate features in add-on modules, you must purchase the tool from IBM Passport Advantage.
When you use this command, you must acknowledge the acceptance of the terms of the license agreements in one of the ways. If you do not accept the license agreements, processing fails. - Include the "accept-license" keyword. - Have the empty "temporary:///license.accepted" file. Use this approach to automate firmware management processes.
When you install a firmware image, it can contain different versions of component firmware. Examples of component firmware include, but is not limited to, the BIOS, BMC, and RAID controller for the DataPower Gateway. When the firmware image contains different versions of component firmware, the installation can take approximately 20 minutes. During this process, do not power off or restart the DataPower Gateway.
When you purchase and active features in add-on modules, you must restart the DataPower Gateway or install your current firmware image again. For only the following features and modules, you must install your current firmware image again to install their libraries. - Extended Oracle support for the Database Connectivity feature - TIBCO EMS module When you run the integrity verifier tool, it verifies the integrity of files that are part of the currently installed firmware. When files are different from the currently installed firmware image, this tool creates the "temporary:///log/SysCheck.txt" file. This file lists the files that are different. This tool is similar to running the "verify-firmware" command.
accept-license Indicates acceptance of the terms of the license agreements. filename Specifies the name of the file that contains the management tool. The file must be in the "image:" directory.
For example:
boot image accept-license V750 Restarts the DataPower Gateway with the "V7500" file in the "image:" directory and acknowledges acceptance of the license agreements with the "accept-license" keyword.

entry.name: boot_image_kconfigflash_descr_303
entry.text: Manages the installed firmware and features.

entry.name: boot_switch_kconfigflash_help_304
entry.text:
Roll-back (switch) to the previously-installed firmware revision (if available). Upgrading a devices firmware using the "boot image" command will always preserve the current running install plus configuration data allowing the user to roll-back to a known, tested operational state.
You can use the "boot-switch" command to toggle between the newly-installed and previously-installed firmware versions.
Configuration edits made to a selected install are local and do not transition during roll-back. It is possible to issue the "boot switch" command twice, returning the system to the newly-installed version. Firmware roll-back is not available after executing "boot delete", see command help for more details.

entry.name: boot_switch_kconfigflash_descr_304
entry.text: Roll-back to previous firmware install

entry.name: boot_reflash_kconfigflash_help_305
entry.text:
DELETES ALL USER DATA FROM THE DEVICE FLASH!
Deletes user modified or added configuration including local flash data (stylesheets, configurations, keys, certificates, etc), returning a system to the manufactured state. Deletes the previous firmware install (see boot delete).
Use with extreme caution as files are not recoverable once they have been deleted.
Example: boot reflash firmware.scrypt2

entry.name: boot_reflash_kconfigflash_descr_305
entry.text: Reinitializes the device flash

entry.name: boot_delete_kconfigflash_help_306
entry.text:
Delete the previous firmware image.
A firmware upgrade performed with the "boot image" command retains current configuration data, allowing the device to be restored to a known, stable state if necessary. The previous firmware image and associated configuration data is referred to as the "secondary install."
While, you can use the "boot delete" command to delete the secondary install, note that its deletion will prevent firmware roll-back as provided by the "boot switch" command and is not recommended.

entry.name: boot_delete_kconfigflash_descr_306
entry.text: Delete the previous firmware install

entry.name: boot_update_kconfigflash_help_307
entry.text:
Creates a new configuration, or opens an existing configuration for edits that are appended to the end of the configuration. Specific behavior is determined by the keyword choice.
write Creates and opens a new configuration, or "erases" and then opens an existing configuration. append Opens an existing configuration to which you can append CLI commands. filename Identifies the configuration to be created or opened. For example:
boot update write config-1.cfg If the specified configuration (config-1.cfg) does not exist, creates the configuration and prompts for command input. If the specified configuration does exist, opens the configuration in write mode (meaning that its contents will be overwritten) and prompts for command input. boot update append config-1.cfg Opens the existing specified configuration (config-1.cfg) in append mode and prompts for command input

entry.name: boot_update_kconfigflash_descr_307
entry.text: Creates or updates a configuration

entry.name: copy_kconfigflash_help_308
entry.text:
This command transfers files to or from the DataPower Gateway. You must issue this command from the DataPower Gateway.
-f Overwrites an existing file when one with the same name exists. When omitted, an attempt to save a file with the same name as an existing file results in a confirmation prompt. source destination Specifies the locations as a URL that identifies the source file and target destination. - When the source or destination is a local URL, the URL take the directory:///file format. - When the source file or destination is remote, only HTTP, HTTPS, SCP, and SFTP protocols are supported. When SCP or SFTP, use a format that is RFC 1738 compliant.
The following restrictions apply. - Cannot copy files from the cert: directory - Cannot copy files to the audit:, logstore:, or logtemp: directories manager Specifies the name of an XML manager that defines the user agent for basic authentication. When omitted, uses the basic authentication settings for the "default" XML manager.
For example:
copy http://host/image.crypt image:///image.crypt Use HTTP to copy a file from the specified location to the image: directory. copy https://host/image.crypt image:///image.crypt Use HTTPS to copy a file from the specified location to the image: directory. copy logstore:///Week1.log scp://jrb@ragnarok.example.com//LOGS/Week1.log Use SCP to copy a file from the logstore: directory to the specified remote target. copy logstore:///Week1.log sftp://jrb@10.10.1.159//LOGS/x/Week1.log Use SFTP to copy a file from the logstore: directory to the specified remote target. copy config:///startup-config local:///startup-config Copy the startup-config file from the config: directory to the local: directory.

entry.name: copy_kconfigflash_descr_308
entry.text: Copies a file to or from the DataPower Gateway

entry.name: copy_kconfigflash_help_309
entry.text:
This command transfers files to or from the device. You must issue this command from the device.
-f Overwrites an existing file when one with the same name exists. When omitted, an attempt to save a file with the same name as an existing file results in a confirmation prompt. source destination Specifies the locations as a URL that identifies the source file and target destination. - When the source or destination is a local URL, the URL take the directory:///file format. - When the source file or destination is remote, only HTTP, HTTPS, SCP, and SFTP protocols are supported. When SCP or SFTP, use a format that is RFC 1738 compliant.
The following restrictions apply. - Cannot copy files from the cert: directory - Cannot copy files to the audit:, logstore:, logtemp:, mqdiag:, mqerr:, or mqtrace: directories manager Specifies the name of an XML manager that defines the user agent for basic authentication. When omitted, uses the basic authentication settings for the "default" XML manager.
For example:
copy http://host/image.crypt image:///image.crypt Use HTTP to copy a file from the specified location to the image: directory. copy https://host/image.crypt image:///image.crypt Use HTTPS to copy a file from the specified location to the image: directory. copy logstore:///Week1.log scp://jrb@ragnarok.example.com//LOGS/Week1.log Use SCP to copy a file from the logstore: directory to the specified remote target. copy logstore:///Week1.log sftp://jrb@10.10.1.159//LOGS/x/Week1.log Use SFTP to copy a file from the logstore: directory to the specified remote target. copy config:///startup-config local:///startup-config Copy the startup-config file from the config: directory to the local: directory.

entry.name: copy_kconfigflash_descr_309
entry.text: Copies a file to or from the device

entry.name: delete_kconfigflash_help_310
entry.text:
Permanently deletes the specified file from the DataPower Gateway.
For example:
delete config:///test-script.cfg Deletes the specified file from the config: directory.

entry.name: delete_kconfigflash_descr_310
entry.text: Deletes a file from the DataPower Gateway

entry.name: dir_kconfigflash_help_311
entry.text:
The "directory" parameter can take the following keywords: audit: - Lists the audit logs. cert: - Lists the private key and certificate files that services use. chkpoints: - Lists the configuration checkpoint files. config: - Lists the configuration files. dpcert: - Lists the files that the DataPower Gateway itself uses. Available in only the "default" domain. export: - Lists the exported configurations that are created with the Export Configuration utility. image: - Lists the firmware images. Available in only the "default" domain. local: - Lists the miscellaneous files that are used by the services in the domain, such as XSL, XSD, and WSDL files. logstore: - Lists the log files that are stored for future reference. logtemp: - Lists the temporary log files. pubcert: - Lists the security certificates that are used commonly by web browsers. sharedcert: - Lists the security certificates that are shared with partners. store: - Lists the contents of the general storage directory for the DataPower Gateway. tasktemplates: - Lists the XSL files that define the display of specialized WebGUI screens. temporary: - Lists the temporary files that the DataPower Gateway creates and uses.
For example:
dir pubcert: Lists the contents of the public cryptographic directory.

entry.name: dir_kconfigflash_descr_311
entry.text: Displays the contents of a specific directory

entry.name: dir_kconfigflash_help_312
entry.text:
The "directory" parameter can take the following keywords: audit: - Lists the audit logs. cert: - Lists the private key and certificate files that services use. chkpoints: - Lists the configuration checkpoint files. config: - Lists the configuration files. dpcert: - Lists the files that the DataPower Gateway itself uses. Available in only the "default" domain. export: - Lists the exported configurations that are created with the Export Configuration utility. image: - Lists the firmware images. Available in only the "default" domain. local: - Lists the miscellaneous files that are used by the services in the domain, such as XSL, XSD, and WSDL files. logstore: - Lists the log files that are stored for future reference. logtemp: - Lists the temporary log files. mqbackup: - Lists files generated when backing up messaging configuration. mqdiag: - Lists queue manager diagnostic files. mqerr: - Lists queue manager error logs and failure reports. mqpubcert: - Lists queue manager certificate and certificate request files. mqtemporary: - Lists temporary files created by queue managers. mqtrace: - Lists queue manager and MQ Console trace files. mqwebui: - Lists files containing MQ Console user profile data. pubcert: - Lists the security certificates that are used commonly by web browsers. sharedcert: - Lists the security certificates that are shared with partners. store: - Lists the contents of the general storage directory for the DataPower Gateway. tasktemplates: - Lists the XSL files that define the display of specialized WebGUI screens. temporary: - Lists the temporary files that the DataPower Gateway creates and uses.
For example:
dir pubcert: Lists the contents of the public cryptographic directory.

entry.name: dir_kconfigflash_descr_312
entry.text: Displays the contents of a specific directory

entry.name: move_kconfigflash_help_313
entry.text:
Renames a local file in place, or moves it from one directory to another.
-f Overwrites an existing file when one with the same name exists. When omitted, an attempt to save a file with the same name as an existing file results in a confirmation prompt. source destination Specifies the locations as a URL that identifies the source file and target destination in the directory:///file format. You cannot use this command to copy a file from the private crypto area, such as the cert: directory.
For example:
move config:///startup-config store:///archiveConfig-10 Move a file from the config: directory to the store: directory. move config:///startup-config config:///archiveConfig-10 Rename a file in place.

entry.name: move_kconfigflash_descr_313
entry.text: Moves/renames a local file

entry.name: reinitialize_kconfigflash_help_314
entry.text:
DELETES ALL USER DATA FROM THE DEVICE FLASH!
Deletes user modified or added configuration including local flash data (stylesheets, configurations, keys, certificates, etc), returning a system to the manufactured state. Deletes the previous firmware install (see boot delete).
Use with extreme caution as files are not recoverable once they have been deleted.
Example: reinitialize firmware.scrypt2

entry.name: reinitialize_kconfigflash_descr_314
entry.text: Reinitializes the device flash

entry.name: shutdown_kconfigflash_help_315
entry.text:
Reloads the firmware, restarts the DataPower Gateway, or shuts down the DataPower Gateway. Without parameters, it restarts the DataPower Gateway.
The 'shutdown' command is unavailable on Docker.
reload Reloads the firmware. reboot Restarts the DataPower Gateway. halt Stops the DataPower Gateway, but power remains on. This mode is deprecated. Use "poweroff" instead. poweroff Stops the DataPower Gateway and turns off the power. seconds The number of seconds before the shutdown operation starts. Use any value in the range 0 - 65535. The default value is 10.
For example: shutdown reload 0 Specify an immediate reload of the configuration. shutdown reboot Wait 10 seconds, then shut down and restart the DataPower Gateway. shutdown poweroff 60 Wait 1 minute, then shut down and turn off the DataPower Gateway.

entry.name: shutdown_kconfigflash_descr_315
entry.text: Reloads the firmware, restarts the DataPower Gateway, or shuts down the DataPower Gateway.

entry.name: shutdown_kconfigflash_help_316
entry.text:
Restarts or shuts down the appliance. Without parameters, it restarts the appliance.
The appliance restarts using the startup configuration specified by the boot config command and the startup firmware image specified by the boot image command. Without a designated startup configuration or firmware image, the appliance restarts with the configuration and firmware image that are active when you issue the shutdown command.
reboot Shuts down and restarts the appliance. halt Shuts down the appliance, but power remains on. This mode is deprecated. Use "poweroff" instead. poweroff Shuts down the appliance and turns off the power. seconds Optional: Specifies the number of seconds before the appliance starts the shutdown operation. Use any value of 0 - 65535. The default value is 10.
For example: shutdown reboot Specifies an immediate reboot shutdown halt 60 Specifies a shutdown in 1 minute

entry.name: shutdown_kconfigflash_descr_316
entry.text: Restarts or shuts down the appliance.

entry.name: alias_kglobalconfig_help_317
entry.text:
This command is deprecated. Creates a command macro, providing ready access to a specific sequence of CLI commands. command-sequence is the sequence of CLI commands executed by the command macro. Use a backslashed semicolon (\;) to separate multiple commands if the command-sequence is not quoted. For example:
alias break "exit; exit" or alias break exit\; exit creates an alias named break. When executed from Global Configuration Mode breaks the CLI connection.

entry.name: alias_kglobalconfig_descr_317
entry.text: Deprecated - Creates a command macro

entry.name: cache_stylesheet_kglobalconfig_help_318
entry.text:
Adds a specified stylesheet to the stylesheet cache maintained by a named XML manager. xmlmgr The target XML manager url is a URL that specifies the location of the target stylesheet mode specialized output mode to compile in, one of 'stream' or 'general' (the default). Leave this unspecified if in doubt.
For example:
cache stylesheet mgr1 http://www.mycompany.com/XSL/ProcessHeaders.xsl fetches and caches the specified stylesheet in the stylesheet cache maintained by mgr1

entry.name: cache_stylesheet_kglobalconfig_descr_318
entry.text: Caches a specified stylesheet

entry.name: flush_apigw_stylesheet_kglobalconfig_help_319
entry.text: Removes the identified stylesheets for the stylesheet cache. apiGateway The target API Gateway. pattern identifies the stylesheets to remove from the stylesheet cache.

entry.name: flush_apigw_stylesheet_kglobalconfig_descr_319
entry.text: Removes the identified stylesheets for the stylesheet cache of an API Gateway.

entry.name: flush_apigw_document_kglobalconfig_help_320
entry.text: Removes the identified documents for the document cache. apiGateway The target API Gateway. pattern identifies the documents to remove from the document cache.

entry.name: flush_apigw_document_kglobalconfig_descr_320
entry.text: Removes the identified documents for the document cache of an API Gateway.

entry.name: api_application_add_kglobalconfig_help_321
entry.text: Adds an application to an API collection. apiCollectionName The target API collection. appID specifies the application ID. The maximum length of the string is 48 characters. appName specifies the application Name. appEnabled specifies the availability of the application. The value can be "enabled" or "disabled". appLifecycleState specifies the application lifecycle state. The value can be "development" or "production". appType specifies the application type. orgId specifies the developer organization ID. orgName specifies the developer organization name. orgTitle specifies the developer organization title. redirectURLs specifies the the redirect URI of the OAuth client to register with the authorization server. This value is used when the client needs to pass an OAuth security check. certificates Specifies the certificate that verifies the identification of the client that accesses the application. Metadata Specifies the application metadata. Concatenate multiple data with the (,) character.

entry.name: api_application_add_kglobalconfig_descr_321
entry.text: Add an API application entry in an API collection.

entry.name: api_application_update_kglobalconfig_help_322
entry.text: Updates application in API collection. apiCollectionName The target API collection. appID specifies the application ID. The maximum length of the string is 48 characters. appName specifies the application Name. appEnabled specifies the availability of the application. The value can be "enabled" or "disabled". appLifecycleState specifies the application lifecycle state. The value can be "development" or "production". appType specifies the application type. orgId specifies the developer organization ID. orgName specifies the developer organization name. orgTitle specifies the developer organization title. redirectURLs specifies the the redirect URI of the OAuth client to register with the authorization server. This value is used when the client needs to pass an OAuth security check. certificates Specifies the certificate that verifies the identification of the client that accesses the application. Metadata Specifies the application metadata. Concatenate multiple data with the (,) character.

entry.name: api_application_update_kglobalconfig_descr_322
entry.text: Update an API application entry in an API collection.

entry.name: api_application_delete_kglobalconfig_help_323
entry.text: Deletes application in API collection. apiCollectionName The target API collection. appID specifies the application ID. The maximum length of the string is 48 characters.

entry.name: api_application_delete_kglobalconfig_descr_323
entry.text: Delete an API application entry in an API collection.

entry.name: api_subscription_update_kglobalconfig_help_324
entry.text: Updates subscription to an application. apiCollectionName The target API collection. appID specifies the application ID for the subscriber. The maximum length of the string is 48 characters. plans associates a list of plans that the client subscribes to. status specifies the status of plans under the application. The status can be "enabled" or "disabled".

entry.name: api_subscription_update_kglobalconfig_descr_324
entry.text: Update an API subscription entry in an API collection.

entry.name: api_subscription_delete_kglobalconfig_help_325
entry.text: Deletes subscription from an application. apiCollectionName The target API collection. appID specifies the application ID for the subscriber. The maximum length of the string is 48 characters. plan associates the plan that the client subscribes to.

entry.name: api_subscription_delete_kglobalconfig_descr_325
entry.text: Delete an API subscription entry in an API collection.

entry.name: api_client_add_kglobalconfig_help_326
entry.text: Adds a client to an application. apiCollectionName The target API collection. clientId specifies the client ID that uniquely identifies the subscriber. clientSecret specifies the client secret for the subscriber. title specifies the title for the subscriber. appID specifies the application ID for the subscriber. The maximum length of the string is 48 characters.

entry.name: api_client_add_kglobalconfig_descr_326
entry.text: Add an API client entry in an API collection.

entry.name: api_client_update_kglobalconfig_help_327
entry.text: Updates a client in a application. apiCollectionName The target API collection. clientId specifies the client ID that uniquely identifies the subscriber. clientSecret specifies the client secret for the subscriber. title specifies the title for the subscriber. appID specifies the application ID for the subscriber. The maximum length of the string is 48 characters.

entry.name: api_client_update_kglobalconfig_descr_327
entry.text: Update an API client entry in an API collection.

entry.name: api_client_delete_kglobalconfig_help_328
entry.text: Deletes a subscriber to an API collection. apiCollectionName The target API collection. clientId specifies the client ID that uniquely identifies the subscriber.

entry.name: api_client_delete_kglobalconfig_descr_328
entry.text: Delete an API client entry in an API collection.

entry.name: clear_subscriber_cache_kglobalconfig_help_329
entry.text:
Clears the API subscriber caches for a specified API collection. apiCollectionName The target API collection. For example:
clear subscriber cache myCollection clears the API subscriber caches maintained by the API collection 'myCollection'.

entry.name: clear_subscriber_cache_kglobalconfig_descr_329
entry.text: Clears API subscriber caches

entry.name: clear_aaa_cache_kglobalconfig_help_330
entry.text:
Clears the authentication information and authorization information caches maintained by a specified AAA Policy. aaaPolicyName The target AAA Policy. For example:
clear aaa cache Policy-1 clears the authentication and authorization caches maintained by AAA Policy, Policy-1

entry.name: clear_aaa_cache_kglobalconfig_descr_330
entry.text: Clears AAA caches

entry.name: clear_arp_kglobalconfig_help_331
entry.text: Resets the Address Resolution Protocol (ARP) table.

entry.name: clear_arp_kglobalconfig_descr_331
entry.text: Resets the ARP table

entry.name: clear_ndcache_kglobalconfig_help_332
entry.text: Resets the IPv6 Neighbor Discovery cache.

entry.name: clear_ndcache_kglobalconfig_descr_332
entry.text: Resets the IPv6 Neighbor Discovery cache

entry.name: clear_rbm_cache_kglobalconfig_help_333
entry.text:
Purges all cached RBM authentication data. For example:
clear rbm cache clears the RBM authentication cache.

entry.name: clear_rbm_cache_kglobalconfig_descr_333
entry.text: Clears all cached RBM authentication data

entry.name: clear_dns_cache_kglobalconfig_help_334
entry.text:
Purges all cached DNS data.
clear dns-cache Clears data from the DNS cache.

entry.name: clear_dns_cache_kglobalconfig_descr_334
entry.text: Clears the DNS cache

entry.name: clear_xsl_cache_kglobalconfig_help_335
entry.text:
Purges all stylesheets from the XSL stylesheet cache associated with the specified xml manager. xmlmgr The target XML manager. For example:
clear xsl cache mgr1 clears the stylesheet cache maintained by XML Manager, mgr1

entry.name: clear_xsl_cache_kglobalconfig_descr_335
entry.text: Clears all stylesheets from a cache

entry.name: clear_ldap_cache_kglobalconfig_help_336
entry.text:
Purges all LDAP Pool entries from the LDAP Pool associated with the specified xml manager. xmlmgr The target XML manager. For example:
clear ldap cache mgr1 clears the LDAP Pool entries from the LDAP Pool of XML Mgr, mgr1

entry.name: clear_ldap_cache_kglobalconfig_descr_336
entry.text: Clears all entries from a LDAP Pool

entry.name: clear_pdp_cache_kglobalconfig_help_337
entry.text:
Purges all the compiled XACML policy files from cache associated with the specified XACML PDP object. The xacml policy files will be recompiled next time when the specified PDP is being requested. xacml-pdp-name The target XACML PDP object. For example:
clear pdp cache pdp1 clears the xacml policy cache maintained by xacml pdp, pdp1

entry.name: clear_pdp_cache_kglobalconfig_descr_337
entry.text: Clears all cached policies for a PDP.

entry.name: cli_remote_open_kglobalconfig_help_338
entry.text:
Opens a customer-initiated connection to the specified host. (identified by ip-address and port-number) providing a CLI shell for remote administration. This command allows remote DataPower technicians to service a unit that would otherwise be protected by a firewall. ip-address is the remote host address. port-number is an integer (within the range 0 to 65535) that specifies the remote port. For example:
cli remote open 192.168.32.101 2300 provides a customer-initiated CLI shell to the specified IP address:port

entry.name: cli_remote_open_kglobalconfig_descr_338
entry.text: Establishes an customer-initiated CLI shell

entry.name: clear_gatewayscript_cache_kglobalconfig_help_339
entry.text:
Clears the GatewayScript cache data.
path specifies the data in the GatewayScript path cache. For example:
clear gatewayscript cache path Clears the data from the GatewayScript path cache.

entry.name: clear_gatewayscript_cache_kglobalconfig_descr_339
entry.text: Clears the GatewayScript cache

entry.name: cli_serial_kglobalconfig_help_340
entry.text: Creates a CLI shell accessible via the serial port. The optional port-number argument specifies a specific Layer 4 port. This command is executed by the factory default device configuration script, and should rarely be needed during field operation.

entry.name: cli_serial_kglobalconfig_descr_340
entry.text: Enables a CLI shell on the serial port.

entry.name: cli_telnet_kglobalconfig_help_341
entry.text:
Enters Telnet Service configuration mode to create or edit an instance of the Telnet Service object. An instance of this object is a Telnet handler. A Telnet handler supports client-initiated access to the command line interface.
name The name of the Telnet handler.

entry.name: cli_telnet_kglobalconfig_descr_341
entry.text: Enter Telnet Server configuration mode.

entry.name: copy_kglobalconfig_help_342
entry.text:
This command transfers files to or from the DataPower Gateway. You must issue this command from the DataPower Gateway.
-f Overwrites an existing file when one with the same name exists. When omitted, an attempt to save a file with the same name as an existing file results in a confirmation prompt. source destination Specifies the locations as a URL that identifies the source file and target destination. - When the source or destination is a local URL, the URL take the directory:///file format. - When the source file or destination is remote, only HTTP, HTTPS, SCP, and SFTP protocols are supported. When SCP or SFTP, use a format that is RFC 1738 compliant.
The following restrictions apply. - Cannot copy files from the cert: directory - Cannot copy files to the audit:, logstore:, or logtemp: directories manager Specifies the name of an XML manager that defines the user agent for basic authentication. When omitted, uses the basic authentication settings for the "default" XML manager.
For example:
copy http://host/image.crypt image:///image.crypt Use HTTP to copy a file from the specified location to the image: directory. copy https://host/image.crypt image:///image.crypt Use HTTPS to copy a file from the specified location to the image: directory. copy logstore:///Week1.log scp://jrb@ragnarok.example.com//LOGS/Week1.log Use SCP to copy a file from the logstore: directory to the specified remote target. copy logstore:///Week1.log sftp://jrb@10.10.1.159//LOGS/x/Week1.log Use SFTP to copy a file from the logstore: directory to the specified remote target. copy config:///startup-config local:///startup-config Copy the startup-config file from the config: directory to the local: directory.

entry.name: copy_kglobalconfig_descr_342
entry.text: Copies a file to or from the DataPower Gateway

entry.name: copy_kglobalconfig_help_343
entry.text:
This command transfers files to or from the device. You must issue this command from the device.
-f Overwrites an existing file when one with the same name exists. When omitted, an attempt to save a file with the same name as an existing file results in a confirmation prompt. source destination Specifies the locations as a URL that identifies the source file and target destination. - When the source or destination is a local URL, the URL take the directory:///file format. - When the source file or destination is remote, only HTTP, HTTPS, SCP, and SFTP protocols are supported. When SCP or SFTP, use a format that is RFC 1738 compliant.
The following restrictions apply. - Cannot copy files from the cert: directory - Cannot copy files to the audit:, logstore:, logtemp:, mqdiag:, mqerr:, or mqtrace: directories manager Specifies the name of an XML manager that defines the user agent for basic authentication. When omitted, uses the basic authentication settings for the "default" XML manager.
For example:
copy http://host/image.crypt image:///image.crypt Use HTTP to copy a file from the specified location to the image: directory. copy https://host/image.crypt image:///image.crypt Use HTTPS to copy a file from the specified location to the image: directory. copy logstore:///Week1.log scp://jrb@ragnarok.example.com//LOGS/Week1.log Use SCP to copy a file from the logstore: directory to the specified remote target. copy logstore:///Week1.log sftp://jrb@10.10.1.159//LOGS/x/Week1.log Use SFTP to copy a file from the logstore: directory to the specified remote target. copy config:///startup-config local:///startup-config Copy the startup-config file from the config: directory to the local: directory.

entry.name: copy_kglobalconfig_descr_343
entry.text: Copies a file to or from the device

entry.name: delete_kglobalconfig_help_344
entry.text:
Permanently deletes the specified file from the device flash.
NOTE THAT THE FILE IS NOT RECOVERABLE!
Use a local URL to identify the target file. Local URLs take the form
directory:///filename,
where directory can be cert:, config:, dp:, dpcert:, image:, logstore:, logtemp:, pubcert:, store:, temporary:, or webgui:. For example:
delete config:///test-script.cfg Deletes the specified file from the config: directory

entry.name: delete_kglobalconfig_descr_344
entry.text: Deletes a file from the device flash

entry.name: dir_kglobalconfig_help_345
entry.text:
The "directory" parameter can take the following keywords. audit: - Lists the audit logs. cert: - Lists the private key and certificate files that services use. chkpoints - Lists the configuration checkpoint files. config: - Lists the configuration files. dpcert: - Lists the files that the DataPower Gateway itself uses. Available in only the "default" domain. export: - Lists the exported configurations that are created with the Export Configuration utility. image: - Lists the firmware images. Available in only the "default" domain. local: - Lists the miscellaneous files that are used by the services in the domain, such as XSL, XSD, and WSDL files. logstore: - Lists the log files that are stored for future reference. logtemp: - Lists the temporary log files. pubcert: - Lists the security certificates that are used commonly by web browsers. sharedcert: - Lists the security certificates that are shared with partners. store: - Lists the contents of the general storage directory for the DataPower Gateway. tasktemplates: - Lists the XSL files that define the display of specialized GUI screens. temporary: - Lists the temporary files that the DataPower Gateway creates and uses.
For example:
dir pubcert: Lists the contents of the public cryptographic directory.

entry.name: dir_kglobalconfig_descr_345
entry.text: Displays the contents of a specific directory

entry.name: dir_kglobalconfig_help_346
entry.text:
The "directory" parameter can take the following keywords: audit: - Lists the audit logs. cert: - Lists the private key and certificate files that services use. chkpoints - Lists the configuration checkpoint files. config: - Lists the configuration files. dpcert: - Lists the files that the appliance itself uses. Available in only the "default" domain. export: - Lists the exported configurations that are created with the Export Configuration utility. image: - Lists the firmware images. Available in only the "default" domain. local: - Lists the miscellaneous files that are used by the services in the domain, such as XSL, XSD, and WSDL files. logstore: - Lists the log files that are stored for future reference. logtemp: - Lists the temporary log files. mqbackup: - Lists files generated when backing up messaging configuration. mqdiag: - Lists queue manager diagnostic files. mqerr: - Lists queue manager error logs and failure reports. mqpubcert: - Lists queue manager certificate and certificate request files. mqtemporary: - Lists temporary files created by queue managers. mqtrace: - Lists queue manager and MQ Console trace files. mqwebui: - Lists files containing MQ Console user profile data. pubcert: - Lists the security certificates that are used commonly by web browsers. sharedcert: - Lists the security certificates that are shared with partners. store: - Lists the contents of the general storage directory for the appliance. tasktemplates: - Lists the XSL files that define the display of specialized WebGUI screens. temporary: - Lists the temporary files that the appliance creates and uses.
For example:
dir pubcert: Lists the contents of the public cryptographic directory.

entry.name: dir_kglobalconfig_descr_346
entry.text: Displays the contents of a specific directory

entry.name: file_capture_kglobalconfig_help_347
entry.text:
Enables or disables the file capture utility intended to support debug activities in non-production environments. always enables the file capture trace utility and provides a trace of all device traffic. errors enables the file capture trace utility and provides a trace for failed transformations only. off disables the file capture trace utility (the default state). For example:
file-capture errors enables the file capture trace utility, specifying that only failed transformations be traced. file-capture off disables the file capture trace utility, thus restoring the default state

entry.name: file_capture_kglobalconfig_descr_347
entry.text: Enables/disables the file capture utility

entry.name: set_system_var_kglobalconfig_help_348
entry.text:
Allows you to write a text string into the global whiteboard. These variables may be accessed via the var://system/ prefix in action descriptions or within a stylesheet by using the dp:variable() function.
Only system variables within a specified context are acceptable. For example var://system/Notes/jim is fine as it sets the variable jim in the context Notes within the global system scope. However var://system/Notes and var://system/Notes/ are not allowed as they specify only a scope and context, but not a variable.

entry.name: set_system_var_kglobalconfig_descr_348
entry.text: Set a variable in global context

entry.name: ip_domain_kglobalconfig_help_349
entry.text:
Adds the specified domain to the IP domain table. domain-name is a string containing the name of the target domain. For example:
ip domain datapower.com adds datapower.com to the IP domain table.

entry.name: ip_domain_kglobalconfig_descr_349
entry.text: Adds an entry to the IP domain table

entry.name: ip_host_kglobalconfig_help_350
entry.text:
Maps a host name to an IP address. host-name The host. ip-address associates an IP address with the target host. For example:
ip host loki 10.10.10.168 maps the host named loki to the specified IP address.

entry.name: ip_host_kglobalconfig_descr_350
entry.text: Defines a host-name to IP-address mapping

entry.name: ip_name_server_kglobalconfig_help_351
entry.text:
Identifies a DNS server by IP address. ip-address is the required IP address of the DNS server. For example:
ip name-server 10.10.2.250 identifies a DNS server at the specified IP address.

entry.name: ip_name_server_kglobalconfig_descr_351
entry.text: Identifies a DNS server

entry.name: language_kglobalconfig_help_352
entry.text:
Enters the Language mode for the specified language so that you can set the administrative state of the language. Enable a language that you want to be the operating language of the DataPower Gateway. The operating language is set with the 'locale' command in System Settings mode. Also, you can enable a language to support native languages for browsers that connect to the DataPower Gateway with a web management interface.
While in this mode, use the admin-state command to enable or disable the language.
name The language. The following languages are available: de German en English es Spanish fr French it Italian ja Japanese ko Korean pt_BR Brazilian Portuguese zh_CN Simplified Chinese zh_TW Traditional Chinese ru Russian
For example:
language fr admin-state enabled enables French

entry.name: language_kglobalconfig_descr_352
entry.text: Enters the Language mode.

entry.name: ldap_search_parameters_kglobalconfig_help_353
entry.text:
Enters LDAP Search Parameters configuration mode to create a named LDAP Search Parameters object. In this configuration mode, you can create an LDAP Search Parameters object. This object is a container for the parameters to perform an LDAP search to retrieve the distinguished name (DN) or group of the user.
name is the name of the new LDAP Search Parameters object.

entry.name: ldap_search_parameters_kglobalconfig_descr_353
entry.text: Enters LDAP Search Parameters configuration mode

entry.name: load_interval_kglobalconfig_help_354
entry.text:
Specifies a measurement interval during which the internal system load is estimated as a percentage of maximum utilization. measurement-interval is an integer (within the range 500 through 5000, with a default of 1000) that specifies the interval duration in milliseconds. For example:
load-interval 2500 specifies a measurement interval of 2.5 seconds

entry.name: load_interval_kglobalconfig_descr_354
entry.text: Specifies a measurement interval

entry.name: logging_event_kglobalconfig_help_355
entry.text:
Adds an event class (a set of related events) and a minimal priority level to an existing log. name The target log. event-class The event class to be added to the log. Use the show logging event command to display a list of all event classes. priority is a string that specifies the minimal event priority required for inclusion in the target log. Use the show logging priority command to display a list of all event priorities. For example:
logging event Alarms all critic logs all events of critical or higher priority to the existing log named Alarms

entry.name: logging_event_kglobalconfig_descr_355
entry.text: Adds an event class to a log

entry.name: logging_eventcode_kglobalconfig_help_356
entry.text:
Adds an event code to the subscription list for the specified log target. This command is equivalent to using the event-code command in Log Target configuration mode.
target The name of an existing log target. event-code The hex value of the event code.

entry.name: logging_eventcode_kglobalconfig_descr_356
entry.text: Adds an event code to the subscription list for a specific log

entry.name: logging_eventfilter_kglobalconfig_help_357
entry.text:
Adds an event code to the suppression list for the specified log target. This command is equivalent to using the event-filter command in Log Target configuration mode.
target The name of an existing log target. event-code The hex value of the event code.

entry.name: logging_eventfilter_kglobalconfig_descr_357
entry.text: Adds an event code to the suppression list for a specific log

entry.name: logging_ipfilter_kglobalconfig_help_358
entry.text:
Adds an IP address to the IP filter list for the specified log target. This command is equivalent to using the ip-filter command in Log Target configuration mode.
target The name of an existing log target. ip-filter The value of the IP address.

entry.name: logging_ipfilter_kglobalconfig_descr_358
entry.text: Adds an IP address to the filter list for a specific log

entry.name: logging_object_kglobalconfig_help_359
entry.text: Adds an object filter to a target log. name The target log. filter-type The filter type for the log target. Use the show logging object command to display a list of all filter types. object-name A specific instance of the filter-type.

entry.name: logging_object_kglobalconfig_descr_359
entry.text: Adds an object filter to a log

entry.name: logging_trigger_kglobalconfig_help_360
entry.text:
Adds an event trigger to perform an action when the specified trigger conditions are met. When triggered, the output of the command will be displayed in the log prefaced with the words 'Event trigger command'.
target The name of an existing log target. msgid The msgid to trigger the command. regexp Specifies an optional regular expression that if supplied must match the message body in order to trigger the command. only-once Indicates whether to execute the command only once or each time the trigger conditions are met. only-this-trigger Indicates whether to stop processing other event triggers that would be triggered by the same msgid after the first match. command The command to execute if trigger conditions are met. For example:
logging trigger targ1 "0x99999" "" on on "interface eth0; packet-capture temporary:///capture -1 250"
logging trigger targ1 "0x99999" "" on on "interface eth0; no packet-capture temporary:///capture"
The first event trigger initiates a packet capture when the specified message is logged. The only-once option is set to on so that multiple packet captures are not commenced. The second command stops the packet capture, and is triggered by the same message. The only-this-trigger option is set to on for the first event trigger so that a second instance of the message is required to stop the packet capture.

entry.name: logging_trigger_kglobalconfig_descr_360
entry.text: Adds an event trigger to a log target.

entry.name: globallogipfilter_kglobalconfig_help_361
entry.text:
Sets the Global Log IP Filter to the specified IP address which must be specified in the form: a.b.c.d.
Once the Global Log IP Filter is set, any event with the specified IP address is eligible to be written to a log. If the IP address of the event does not match the specified Global Log IP Filter value, the event will not be logged on any log target on the system. ip the IP address to filter against.

entry.name: globallogipfilter_kglobalconfig_descr_361
entry.text: Sets the Global IP Filter

entry.name: loglevel_kglobalconfig_help_362
entry.text:
Sets the log level to the specified priority which may be specified as a number or string. Available levels (from most to least critical) are:
0 - emergency 1 - alert 2 - critical 3 - error 4 - warning 5 - notice 6 - info 7 - debug
Once the log level is set, any event with an numeric value less than or equal to the specified priority is written to the log. For example:
loglevel 7 or loglevel debug both specify that all events (debug, info, notice, warning, error, critical, alert, and emergency) are logged

entry.name: loglevel_kglobalconfig_descr_362
entry.text: Sets the log level to a specified priority

entry.name: logsize_kglobalconfig_help_363
entry.text:
Sets the length (in KB) of the log buffer. For example:
logsize 250 specifies a log length of 250 KB

entry.name: logsize_kglobalconfig_descr_363
entry.text: Sets the log size to the specified length

entry.name: mkdir_kglobalconfig_help_364
entry.text:
Creates a named subdirectory in the local: file system. subDirectoryName The subdirectory. For example:
mkdir local:///testConfigs creates the testConfig subdirectory in local:

entry.name: mkdir_kglobalconfig_descr_364
entry.text: Creates a directory in local:

entry.name: move_kglobalconfig_help_365
entry.text:
Renames a local file in place, or moves it from one directory to another.
-f Overwrites an existing file when one with the same name exists. When omitted, an attempt to save a file with the same name as an existing file results in a confirmation prompt. source destination Specifies the locations as a URL that identifies the source file and target destination in the directory:///file format. You cannot use this command to copy a file from the private crypto area, such as the cert: directory.
For example:
move config:///startup-config store:///archiveConfig-10 Move a file from the config: directory to the store: directory. move config:///startup-config config:///archiveConfig-10 Rename a file in place.

entry.name: move_kglobalconfig_descr_365
entry.text: Moves/renames a local file

entry.name: refresh_stylesheet_kglobalconfig_help_366
entry.text:
Deletes a specified stylesheet or stylesheets from the stylesheet cache maintained by a named XML manager. xml-mgr identifies a specific XML manager. * is a special wild-card character specifying all XML managers. match-pattern A shell-style regular expression that defines the target stylesheet or stylesheets.
For example:
refresh stylesheet mgr1 http://www.a.com/XSL/sheet.xsl deletes the specified stylsheet from the stylesheet cache maintained by XML manager, mgr1 refresh stylesheet * http://www.a.com/XSL/sheet.xsl deletes the specified stylsheet from the stylesheet cache maintained by all XML managers

entry.name: refresh_stylesheet_kglobalconfig_descr_366
entry.text: Forces a stylesheet refresh

entry.name: rmdir_kglobalconfig_help_367
entry.text:
Removes a subdirectory from the local: file system. subDirectoryName The target subdirectory. For example:
rmdir local:///testConfigs deletes the testConfig subdirectory from local:

entry.name: rmdir_kglobalconfig_descr_367
entry.text: Deletes a subdirectory from local:

entry.name: remove_chkpoint_kglobalconfig_help_368
entry.text:
Deletes the named checkpoint configuration file from the domain-specific chkpoint: directory.
name The name of the checkpoint configuration file to remove.

entry.name: remove_chkpoint_kglobalconfig_descr_368
entry.text: Deletes a checkpoint configuration file

entry.name: rollback_chkpoint_kglobalconfig_help_369
entry.text:
The rollback chkpoint command reverts the running configuration to the configuration that is defined in the named checkpoint configuration file.
name The name of the checkpoint configuration file to rollback.

entry.name: rollback_chkpoint_kglobalconfig_descr_369
entry.text: Loads a checkpoint configuration file as the running configuration

entry.name: save_config_overwrite_kglobalconfig_help_370
entry.text: By default, the WebGUI Save Config button and the 'write memory' command write the current running configuration to config:autoconfig.cfg, and designate that file as the start-up configuration. To over-ride the default behavior, place the no form of this command in a start-up configuration script.

entry.name: save_config_overwrite_kglobalconfig_descr_370
entry.text: Specifies 'Save Config' behavior

entry.name: save_chkpoint_kglobalconfig_help_371
entry.text:
Saves the named checkpoint configuration file in the domain-specific chkpoint: directory.
name The name of the checkpoint configuration file.

entry.name: save_chkpoint_kglobalconfig_descr_371
entry.text: Saves a checkpoint configuration file

entry.name: save_internal_state_kglobalconfig_help_372
entry.text: Saves the internal state of the device on the temporary: file system as the internal-state.txt file (temporary:///internal-state.txt). This file includes a dump of the machine. This same data can be included in an error report.

entry.name: save_internal_state_kglobalconfig_descr_372
entry.text: Saves the internal state as a text file

entry.name: tx_warn_kglobalconfig_help_373
entry.text:
Enables IBM Transformation Extender warning support for the specified XML Manager. Warnings are disabled by default.
xml-mgr Indicates the name of the target XML manager.
For example:
tx-warn mgr1 Enables warning support for the mgr1 XML manager.

entry.name: tx_warn_kglobalconfig_descr_373
entry.text: Enables Transformation Extender warning support

entry.name: search_results_kglobalconfig_help_374
entry.text:
Enables XPath optimizations for a specified XML manager. The search results algorithm is enabled by default. xml-mgr is the name of the target XML manager. For example:
search results mgr1 enables XPath optimizations for the XML manager mgr1, -- restoring the default state

entry.name: search_results_kglobalconfig_descr_374
entry.text: Enables XPath optimizations

entry.name: save_error_report_kglobalconfig_descr_375
entry.text: Save error report

entry.name: send_error_report_kglobalconfig_help_376
entry.text:
Enables SMTP-based notification of system re-boot. outgoing-mail-server identifies a local SMTP server by IP address or by host name. subject is a text string that appears in the outgoing message Subject line. email-address is a fully-qualified e-mail addresses that identify the message recipient. email-sender-address is a fully-qualified e-mail addresses that identify the message sender. For example:
send error-report smtp.customer.com Alert! supportteam@customer.com upon system restart, transmits a notification to supportteam@customer.com

entry.name: send_error_report_kglobalconfig_descr_376
entry.text: Enables SMTP notification of system restart.

entry.name: send_file_kglobalconfig_help_377
entry.text:
Enables SMTP-based file transmission. local-url The target file, and takes one of the following forms: audit:///filename logtemp:///filename config:///filemane pubcert:///filename image:///filename store:///filename logstore:///filename temporary:///filename
You cannot send a file from the cert:, dp:, dpcert:, or webgui: directories. outgoing-mail-server identifies a local SMTP server by IP address or by host name. email-address is the fully-qualified e-mail addresses of the file recipient. For example:
send file config:///autoconfig.cfg smtp.customer.com supportteam@customer.com mails autoconfig.cfg to supportteam@customer.com via the specified mail server

entry.name: send_file_kglobalconfig_descr_377
entry.text: Enables SMTP-based file transmission.

entry.name: service_nagle_kglobalconfig_help_378
entry.text: Toggles the nagle slow packet avoidance algorithm.

entry.name: service_nagle_kglobalconfig_descr_378
entry.text: Toggle the nagle slow packet avoidance algorithm

entry.name: service_battery_installed_kglobalconfig_help_379
entry.text: Update the battery installation date.

entry.name: service_battery_installed_kglobalconfig_descr_379
entry.text: Update the battery installation date.

entry.name: ssh_kglobalconfig_help_380
entry.text:
Enables the Secured Shell Protocol on a specified device interface or an all device interfaces. SSH is disabled by default. ip-address optionally identifies a single interface on which SSH is enabled. port-number The port on ip-address monitored by SSH. In the absence of an explicit address assignment, SSH first attempts to bind to the mgt0 interface. If that interface has not been previously configured, SSH binds to all configured interfaces. For example:
ssh 10.10.10.1 2200 enables SSH on the specified IP address:port pair. ssh if the management interface has been configured, enables SSH on port 22 of the management interface. If that interface has not been configured, enables SSH on port 22 of all other interfaces.

entry.name: ssh_kglobalconfig_descr_380
entry.text: Enables SSH

entry.name: sslforwarder_kglobalconfig_help_381
entry.text:
Creates a TLS proxy, or forwarding, service. This service uses a secure connection to relay all traffic received on a local address to a specified remote peer. A common use of this service is to transmit syslog messages a TLS wrapper; for example, the stunnel program.
name Specify the name of the service. local-address Specify the IP address of a local interface. This value can be a host alias, a specific IP address, 0 or 0.0.0.0 to indicate all configured IPv4 addresses, or :: to indicate all configured IPv4 and IPv6 addresses. local-port Specify the local listening port for the service. remote-host Specify the hostname or IP address of remote server. remote-port Specify the listening port on the remote server. ssl-proxy-profile Specify the name of a TLS proxy profile to secure connections when ssl-config-type is set to proxy. priority Specify the service scheduling priority. "normal", "high", and "low" are allowed values. front-timeout Specify the amount of time in seconds a client-side connection can be idle in a transaction before being torn down. Enter a value in the range 0 - 86400. The value of 0 indicates that the timer is disabled. The default value is 0. back-timeout Specify the amount of time in seconds a server-side connection can be idle in a transaction before being torn down. Enter a value in the range 0 - 86400. The value of 0 indicates that the timer is disabled. The default value is 0. connection-timeout Specify the amount of time in seconds a transaction can remain open before being closed. Enter a value in the range 0 - 86400. The value of 0 indicates that the timer is disabled. The default value is 0. maximum-connections Specify the maximum number of concurrent client connections to this service. Enter a value in the range of 0 - 65535. The value of 0 indicates an unlimited number of connections. The default value is 100. summary Specify a brief summary for user annotation. ssl-config-type Specify the TLS profile type. The default value is proxy. Valid values include "proxy", "server", or "sni". ssl-client-profile Specify the name of the TLS client profile to secure connections. ssl-server | sni-server-profile Specify the name of the TLS server or TLS SNI server profile to secure connections. This is dependent on ssl-config-type.
For example:
sslforwarder syslog-1 10.10.13.21 7777 10.10.1.159 1724 sslClient normal 120 120 240 200 Creates the syslog-1 TLS Proxy service. The service listens on 10.10.13.21:7777 and forwards traffic, via a secure connection, to 10.10.1.159:1724. The services uses the sslClient TLS proxy profile to establish the secure connection. The front and back connections time out in 2 minutes of inactivity. If the client connection remains open after 4 minutes, the connection is closed. The service supports only 200 concurrent client connections.

entry.name: sslforwarder_kglobalconfig_descr_381
entry.text: Creates a TLS proxy service.

entry.name: sslproxy_kglobalconfig_help_382
entry.text:
Creates a TLS Proxy Profile that defines a TLS proxy.
name The name of the TLS Proxy Profile.
client (or forward) Indicates that the TLS proxy functions as a TLS client (or functions in the forward direction). In client proxy mode, TLS is used over the device-to-server connection. Client proxy mode requires a client crypto profile. server (or reverse) Indicates that the TLS proxy functions as a TLS server (or functions in the reverse direction). In server proxy mode, TLS is used over the device-to-client connection. Server proxy mode requires a server crypto profile. two-way (or both) Indicates that the TLS proxy functions as both a TLS client and and TLS server (or functions in both directions). In two-way mode, TLS is used over both the device-to-server connection and over the device-to-client connection. Two-way mode requires both a client and server crypto profile. server_profile When the operational mode is either client or two-way, identifies the Crypto Profile that is used by the TLS client to authenticate itself to the TLS server. client_profile When the operational mode is either server or two-way, identifies the Crypto Profile that is used by the TLS server to authenticate itself to TLS clients. sess-timeout <seconds> Sets the session timeout or the server-side session cache in seconds. Enter a value in the range 1 - 86400. The default value is 300. A value of 0 disables server-side caching. cache-size <entries> Optionally sets the maximum size of the server-side session cache in kilo entries (1024 entries). Enter a value in the range 1 - 500. The default value is 20. client-cache {on | off} Optionally disables client-side caching of session state data. - off -- Disables client-side caching. - on (default) -- Enables client-side caching. client-sess-timeout <seconds> Sets the session timeout value for the client-side session cache in seconds, Enter a value in the range 1 - 86400. The default value is 300 seconds. A value of 0 disables client-side caching. client-cache-size <entries> Optionally sets the maximum size of the client-side session cache. Enter a value in the range 1 - 500000. The default value is 100. client-auth-optional {on | off} When acting as a TLS server and performing client authentication, requests, but does not require, TLS client authentication by the application server. This property is meaningful when TLS client authentication is enabled in the server crypto profile. When both properties are enabled, TLS client authentication is optional. The request does not fail when there is no client certificate. When disabled (the default), TLS client authentication is required. client-auth-always-request {on | off} When acting as a TLS server, always request TLS client authentication even when there are no validation credentials defined in the server crypto profile. When disabled (the default), the TLS server only requests TLS client authentication when validation credentials are defined. permit-insecure-servers {on | off} When acting as a TLS client, allow connections to TLS servers that do not support RFC 5746. Such servers are vulnerable to man-in-the-middle attacks as described in CVE-2009-3555. When disabled (the default), the TLS client refuses to connect to such TLS servers.
For example:
sslproxy TLS-1 two-way NoMD High sess-timeout 900 cache-size 50 Creates the TLS-1 TLS proxy that provides a two-way service that uses the NoMD profile on the server side and the High profile on the client side. 50 KB are allocated for the proxy cache, and session-specific cache data is timed out after 15 minutes.

entry.name: sslproxy_kglobalconfig_descr_382
entry.text: Creates a TLS Proxy Profile

entry.name: startup_kglobalconfig_help_383
entry.text:
Prompts for information required to write a basic configuration:
interface IP addresses and masks default gateways interface mode IP name-servers Credentials for account that can reset passwords
After gathering required information, allows for the configuration to be saved to the device flash or discarded.

entry.name: startup_kglobalconfig_descr_383
entry.text: Creates a basic configuration

entry.name: statistics_kglobalconfig_help_384
entry.text: Starts data collection activities on all interfaces. Statistics collection is disabled by default. Use the show statistics command to view aggregated data.

entry.name: statistics_kglobalconfig_descr_384
entry.text: Starts data collection activities

entry.name: switch_domain_kall_help_385
entry.text:
Switches from the current to another application domain. domainName is the name of the destination application domain. For example:
switch domain default switches from the current to the default application domain.

entry.name: switch_domain_kall_descr_385
entry.text: Moves to a different application domain

entry.name: all_domains_kprivileged_help_386
entry.text: Enables or disables all application domains. The default domain is not affected.

entry.name: all_domains_kprivileged_descr_386
entry.text: Enables or disables all application domains.

entry.name: syslog_kglobalconfig_help_387
entry.text:
Identifies a syslog recipient. ip-address is the IP address of the remote syslog daemon. log-level is an integer or string identifying the set of transmitted events. From most to least critical events are characterized as follows:
0 - emergency 1 - alert 2 - critical 3 - error 4 - warning 5 - notice 6 - info
Once the log-level is set, any event with a numeric value less than or equal to the specified loglevel is forwarded to the remote syslog recipient. For example:
syslog 192.168.10.10 2 syslog 192.168.10.10 critical both specify that critical, alert, and emergency events are forwarded to the syslog recipient at the specified IP address

entry.name: syslog_kglobalconfig_descr_387
entry.text: Identifies a syslog recipient

entry.name: tcpproxy_kglobalconfig_help_388
entry.text:
Creates a named TCP packet forwarding proxy that switches incoming packets to a specified remote address. name is the name of the forwarding service. local-ip is the IP address of a local interface. local-port is the local port number. remote-host The recipient by IP address or by host-name. remote-port is the remote port number. timeout is the maximum idle time that is allowed for the front side connection and the server side connection in seconds. After the time is reached, the idle connections are terminated. Enter a value in the range 0 - 86400. The default value is 360. A value of 0 disables the idle timer. priority is the service scheduler priority. "normal", "high", "low" are the allowed values. summary A brief summary for user annotation.
For example:
tcpproxy ForwardHTTP 192.168.14.12 80 10.10.20.100 80 normal Creates a TCP proxy named ForwardHTTP that forwards packets received on 192.168.14.12:80 to 10.10.20.100:80.

entry.name: tcpproxy_kglobalconfig_descr_388
entry.text: Creates a TCP forwarding service

entry.name: template_kall_help_389
entry.text:
Runs an interactive command line script. The script is an XML file that can be local or remote to the DataPower Gateway. The script must conform to the store:///schemas/dp-cli-template.xsd schema.
URL Specifies the fully-qualified location of the interactive command line script.

entry.name: template_kall_descr_389
entry.text: Runs an interactive command line script

entry.name: test_hardware_kglobalconfig_help_390
entry.text: Depending on the state of the hardware, the command produces output that states the status for each component. success warning failure The components are broken down into the following categories. Backtrace availability Interface diagnostics Fan diagnostics Cryptographic card diagnostics

entry.name: test_hardware_kglobalconfig_descr_390
entry.text: Tests the state of the hardware

entry.name: test_logging_kglobalconfig_help_391
entry.text:
Tests the configuration of a Logging Category.
category The name of an existing Logging Category. priority Identifies the event priority. The priority indicates that all events that are greater than or equal to this value are logged. Events use the following priority in descending order: 1) 'emerg' (Emergency), 2) 'alert' (Alert), 3) 'critic' (Critical), 4) 'error' (Error), 5) 'warn' (Warning), 6) 'notice' (Notice), 7) 'info' (Information) and 8) 'debug' (Debug). message The text for the message.

entry.name: test_logging_kglobalconfig_descr_391
entry.text: Tests the configuration of a Logging Category

entry.name: test_urlmap_kglobalconfig_help_392
entry.text:
Tests the candidate URL against the named URL map by scanning the match patterns (rules) contained within the map -- returns "match" if the candidate URL matches any of the map's rules, or "no match" if the URL does not match any of the map's rules. For example:
test urlmap URLmap-1 http://acompany.com/XSL/sheet1.xsl match successfully tests the specified URL against the URL map named URlmap-1

entry.name: test_urlmap_kglobalconfig_descr_392
entry.text: Tests a URL against a URL map

entry.name: test_urlrefresh_kglobalconfig_help_393
entry.text:
Tests the candidate URL against the named URL Refresh Policy by scanning the URL map or maps contained within the policy -- returns "match" if the candidate URL matches any of the policy's patterns (rules), or "no match" if the URL does not match any of the policy's patterns (rules). For example:
test urlrefresh 2aday http://acompany.com/XSL/sheet1.xsl match successfully tests the specified URL against the 2aday URL Refresh Policy

entry.name: test_urlrefresh_kglobalconfig_descr_393
entry.text: Tests a URL against a URL Refresh Policy

entry.name: test_urlrewrite_kglobalconfig_help_394
entry.text:
Tests the candidate URL against the named URL Rewrite Policy by scanning the rewrite rules contained within the policy -- in the event of a match returns the replace URL and the replacement stylesheet generated by the rewrite rule. For example:
