test urlrewrite RW-11 http://mantis:8000/foo/bar/my.cgi?x=y&xsl=style.xsl?/input.xmltest
input replace -> http://mantis:8000/foo/bar/my.cgi?x=y&xsl=ident.xsl?/input.xml
style replace -> http://mantis:8000/style.xsl
successfully tests the candidate URL against the RW1 URL Rewrite Policy

entry.name: test_urlrewrite_kglobalconfig_descr_394
entry.text: Tests a URL against a URL Rewrite Policy

entry.name: throttle_kglobalconfig_help_395
entry.text:
Specifies device behavior when faced with a low memory condition. In such a circumstance, the device implements a memory conservation algorithm by first refusing to accept new connections. If the refusal to accept new connections does not free sufficient memory, the device then restarts.
When free memory falls below the throttle-threshold (expressed as a percentage of total memory), the device refuses to accept new connections. If the amount of free memory does not rise above the throttle-threshold in the specified timeout (expressed in seconds), the device restarts. If free memory falls below the kill-threshold (also expressed as a percentage of total memory), the device restarts immediately. For example: throttle 15 8 10 specifies (1) that the device will stop accepting new connections when the amount of free memory is less than 15 %% of total memory; (2) that the device will restart immediately if the amount of free memory is less than 8%% of total memory; and (3) that the device will restart if the amount of free memory does not exceed 15%% of total memory within 10 seconds of its refusal to accept new connections.

entry.name: throttle_kglobalconfig_descr_395
entry.text: Adjusts throttling parameters for low memory situations

entry.name: user_kglobalconfig_help_396
entry.text: Modifies or creates the specified user-name. Use this command to set the access-level, user-group and annotation for a user. This command may be used to reset a user password. To change the current user's password without allowing access to this administrative command, see the user-password command.

entry.name: user_kglobalconfig_descr_396
entry.text: Modifies or creates a user.

entry.name: user_password_kglobalconfig_help_397
entry.text: Use this command to change your password.

entry.name: user_password_kglobalconfig_descr_397
entry.text: Change the current user's password

entry.name: username_kglobalconfig_help_398
entry.text: The username command has been deprecated and replaced by the user command to create and modify users and the user-password command to change the current user's password.

entry.name: username_kglobalconfig_descr_398
entry.text: Deprecated.

entry.name: watchdog_kglobalconfig_help_399
entry.text:
Watchdog timer values are set to DataPower default values. These default values should rarely, if ever, require change. Timeout values should be a multiple of 20 and the hard timeout should be greater than the soft timeout.
Contact Customer before changing watchdog timer values.

entry.name: watchdog_kglobalconfig_descr_399
entry.text: Sets watchdog timeout values

entry.name: web_mgmt_kglobalconfig_help_400
entry.text:
Creates a specialized HTTP server, supporting GUI access on the specified IP address and port. For example:
web-mgmt 192.168.0.6 9090 Creates an HTTP server that provides GUI access.

entry.name: web_mgmt_kglobalconfig_descr_400
entry.text: Creates a WebGUI HTTP server

entry.name: write_memory_kglobalconfig_help_401
entry.text: Copies the current running configuration to the file config:///autoconfig.cfg. After copying the running configuration to config:///autoconfig.cfg, system software determines if the current start-up configuration script file can be overridden by config:///autoconfig.cfg. If it can be overridden (as determined by the [no] save-config overwrite command), autoconfig.cfg becomes the start-up configuration.

entry.name: write_memory_kglobalconfig_descr_401
entry.text: Copies running configuration to a file

entry.name: xml_validate_kglobalconfig_help_402
entry.text:
Enables schema validation for the named XML manager. Documents matching the patterns contained within matching-template will be validated with the specified schema. If no schema is specified, validation will be performed in accordance with validation processing instructions (if any) contained within the document. Documents that do not contain validation instructions are considered to be validated.
The schema or url-rewrite-policy arguments identify an XML schema. schema identifies a default schema used to validate all matching documents. url-rewrite-policy identifies a URL Rewrite Policy that is applied to the schema identified within a matching document. The re-written URL identifies the actual schema used to validate the document.

entry.name: xml_validate_kglobalconfig_descr_402
entry.text: Enables XML Schema validation

entry.name: xmlmgr_kglobalconfig_help_403
entry.text:
Creates the named XML manager that manages resources. The optional "ssl" keyword and "crypto-profile" arguments assign a TLS helper-agent to access documents over TLS, typically identified by a URL that starts with "https://".
For example:
xmlmgr mgr1 ssl tangClient Creates the mgr1 XML manager and assigns the tangClient crypto-profile as the TLS helper-agent.

entry.name: xmlmgr_kglobalconfig_descr_403
entry.text: Creates an XML manager

entry.name: xml_mgmt_kglobalconfig_help_404
entry.text:
Creates an interface that supports external XML/SOAP-based access to configuration and status data.
ip-address The interface address. port The port monitored for incoming requests. ws-management Enables the WS-Management protocol.
For example: xml-mgmt 10.10.10.23 32000 Creates an XML management interface at the specified interface:port. xml-mgmt 10.10.10.23 32000 on Enables additional WS-Management functionality.

entry.name: xml_mgmt_kglobalconfig_descr_404
entry.text: Creates an XML management interface

entry.name: xsl_cache_size_kglobalconfig_help_405
entry.text:
Sets the maximum number of stylesheets that can be kept by a specified XML manager. Cache size defaults to 256 (stylesheets). The minimum cache size is 5. Maximum cache size is constrained only by memory availability. xmlmgr The target XML manager. size is an integer that specifies the maximum cache size. For example:
xsl cache size mgr1 512 sets a maximum cache size of 512 stylesheets for XML manager, mgr1.

entry.name: xsl_cache_size_kglobalconfig_descr_405
entry.text: Sets the number of stylesheets kept in the cache

entry.name: xsl_checksummed_cache_kglobalconfig_help_406
entry.text:
Enables SHA1-assisted stylesheet caching for the specified XML manager. If enabled, stylesheets are cached by both URL and the SHA1 (Secure Hash Algorithm) signature of their contents. SHA1-assisted stylesheet caching can improve performance in processing environments where the same stylesheet may be obtained from different URLs. xmlmgr The target XML manager. For example:
xsl checksummed cache mgr1 enables SHA1-assisted stylesheet caching for XML manager, mgr1

entry.name: xsl_checksummed_cache_kglobalconfig_descr_406
entry.text: Enables SHA1 caching of stylesheets

entry.name: xslconfig_kglobalconfig_help_407
entry.text:
Assigns a Compile Options Policy to a named XML manager. A Compile Options Policy can be used in non-production debug environments to measure stylesheet performance. xmlMgr The target XML manager. compileOptionsPolicy The assigned Compile Options Policy. For example:
xslconfig mgr1 compilationTest-1 assigns the Compile Options Policy, compilationTest-1, to XML manager, mgr1

entry.name: xslconfig_kglobalconfig_descr_407
entry.text: Assigns a Compile Options Policy to an XML manager

entry.name: xslrefresh_kglobalconfig_help_408
entry.text:
Assigns the specified Stylesheet-Refresh Policy to the named XML manager. For example:
xslrefresh mgr1 2aday assigns the Stylesheet-Refresh Policy named 2aday to XML manager, mgr1.

entry.name: xslrefresh_kglobalconfig_descr_408
entry.text: Sets XSL refresh policy for an XML manager

entry.name: debug_action_kglobalconfig_help_409
entry.text:
Debug a session. For example:
debug-action 99 debug the session with ID 99.

entry.name: debug_action_kglobalconfig_descr_409
entry.text: Debug a session

entry.name: no_debug_action_kglobalconfig_help_410
entry.text:
Cancel a debug session. For example:
no debug-action 99 cancel the debug session with ID 99.

entry.name: no_debug_action_kglobalconfig_descr_410
entry.text: Cancel a debug session

entry.name: pdadmin_kglobalconfig_help_411
entry.text:
Start an administration session which can be used to administer the ISAM security policy. For example:
pdadmin Start a pdadmin administration session.

entry.name: pdadmin_kglobalconfig_descr_411
entry.text: Start a pdadmin administration session.

entry.name: assert_bp10_conformance_conformancepolicy_help_412
entry.text:
Meaningful only when validating messages against WS-I Basic Profile 1.0. The profiles for message validation are defined with the profiles command.
on (Default) Attaches an assertion. off Does not attach an assertion. Use this setting with the filter action.

entry.name: assert_bp10_conformance_conformancepolicy_descr_412
entry.text: Controls the attachment of an assertion to WS-I Basic Profile 1.0 messages.

entry.name: fixup_stylesheets_conformancepolicy_help_413
entry.text:
Defines which style sheets to invoke after conformance analysis. These style sheets can transform the analysis results to repair instances of nonconformance. Corrective style sheets cannot be applied to filter actions.
For each style sheet to include, use this command.
file The name and location of the style sheet.

entry.name: fixup_stylesheets_conformancepolicy_descr_413
entry.text: Identifies which style sheets to invoke after conformance analysis.

entry.name: ignored_requirements_conformancepolicy_help_414
entry.text:
Defines which profile requirements to exclude from validation.
For each requirement to exclude, use this command.
profile The literal representation for the name of the profile. Use one of the following literals: AP1.0 Indicates Web Services Interoperability (WS-I) Attachment Profile, version 1.0. BP1.0 Indicates WS-I Basic Profile, version 1.0. BP1.1 Indicates WS-I Basic Profile, version 1.1. BSP1.0 Indicates WS-I Basic Security Profile, version 1.0. requirement The identifier of the requirement in the profile. The identifier follows the naming convention in the profile documentation.
For example, to exclude requirements R4221 and R4222 in WS-I BSP version 1.0 from validation: ignore-requirements BSP1.0:R4221 ignore-requirements BSP1.0:R4222

entry.name: ignored_requirements_conformancepolicy_descr_414
entry.text: Identifies which profile requires to exclude from validation.

entry.name: profiles_conformancepolicy_help_415
entry.text:
Defines the profiles against which to validate conformance.
profile The literal representation for the name of the profile. To specify multiple profiles, use a + between each profile. Use a combination of the following literals: AP10 Includes Web Services Interoperability (WS-I) Attachment Profile, version 1.0. BP10 Includes WS-I Basic Profile, version 1.0. BP11 Includes WS-I Basic Profile, version 1.1. BSP10 Includes WS-I Basic Security Profile, version 1.0. The default is AP10+BP11+BSP10

entry.name: profiles_conformancepolicy_descr_415
entry.text: Defines the profiles against which to validate conformance.

entry.name: reject_include_summary_conformancepolicy_help_416
entry.text:
Determines whether to include a summary of the conformance analysis in the request rejection message. This command is meaningful only when request messages are rejected. Messages are rejected when the value for the "reject-level" command is set to "failure" or "warning".
on Includes the summary. off (Default) Does not include the summary.

entry.name: reject_include_summary_conformancepolicy_descr_416
entry.text: Controls the inclusion of the summary for rejected requests.

entry.name: reject_level_conformancepolicy_help_417
entry.text:
Defines the degree of nonconformance that causes a request message to be rejected. When a message is rejected, you can use the "reject-include-summary" command to include a summary of the conformance analysis in the rejection message.
failure Rejects messages that are identifies as conformance failures. never (Default) Never rejects messages. warning Rejects messages that are identified as either conformance failures or conformance warnings.

entry.name: reject_level_conformancepolicy_descr_417
entry.text: Identifies when to reject requests.

entry.name: report_level_conformancepolicy_help_418
entry.text:
Defines when to send a conformance report for requests. To send a conformance report, use the "report-target" command to define where to send the report.
always Always records a conformance report. failure Records a conformance report for conformance failures. never (Default) Never records a conformance report. warning Records a conformance report for both conformance failures and conformance warnings.

entry.name: report_level_conformancepolicy_descr_418
entry.text: Identifies when to record a conformance report for requests.

entry.name: report_target_conformancepolicy_help_419
entry.text:
Identifies where to send conformance reports for requests. This command is meaningful only when the value of the "report-level" command is "always", "failure", or "warning".
url Specifies the location to send conformance reports. Use the following URL format: protocol://host/URI

entry.name: report_target_conformancepolicy_descr_419
entry.text: Specifies where to send request conformance reports.

entry.name: response_properties_enabled_conformancepolicy_help_420
entry.text:
Determines whether to enable conformance on response messages.
on Allows the definition of conformance for response messages. off (Default) Does not allow the definition of conformance for response messages.

entry.name: response_properties_enabled_conformancepolicy_descr_420
entry.text: Controls the enablement of conformance for response messages.

entry.name: response_reject_include_summary_conformancepolicy_help_421
entry.text:
Determines whether to include a summary of the conformance analysis in the response rejection message. This command is meaningful only when response messages are rejected. Messages are rejected when the value for the "response-reject-level" command is set to "failure" or "warning".
on Includes the summary. off (Default) Does not include the summary.

entry.name: response_reject_include_summary_conformancepolicy_descr_421
entry.text: Controls the inclusion of the summary for rejected responses.

entry.name: response_reject_level_conformancepolicy_help_422
entry.text:
Defines the degree of nonconformance that causes a response message to be rejected. When a message is rejected, you can use the "response-reject-include-summary" command to include a summary of the conformance analysis in the rejection message.
failure Rejects messages that are identifies as conformance failures. never (Default) Never rejects messages. warning Rejects messages that are identified as either conformance failures or conformance warnings.

entry.name: response_reject_level_conformancepolicy_descr_422
entry.text: Identifies when to reject responses.

entry.name: response_report_level_conformancepolicy_help_423
entry.text:
Defines when to send a conformance report for responses. To send a conformance report, use the "response-report-target" command to define where to send the report.
always Always records a conformance report. failure Records a conformance report for conformance failures. never (Default) Never records a conformance report. warning Records a conformance report for both conformance failures and conformance warnings.

entry.name: response_report_level_conformancepolicy_descr_423
entry.text: Identifies when to record a conformance report for responses.

entry.name: response_report_target_conformancepolicy_help_424
entry.text:
Identifies where to send conformance reports for responses. This command is meaningful only when the value of the "response-report-level" command is "always", "failure", or "warning".
url The location to send conformance reports. Use the following URL format: protocol://host/URI

entry.name: response_report_target_conformancepolicy_descr_424
entry.text: Specifies where to send response conformance reports.

entry.name: result_is_conformance_report_conformancepolicy_help_425
entry.text:
Indicates whether the conformance analysis is delivered as a "results" action or is delivered to the next action in the processing rule. When delivered as a "results" action, the intended purpose is with a loopback XML firewall, which returns the results to the client.
on Delivers a conformance analysis as a "results" action. off (Default) Delivers the original message, possibly modified by one or more style sheets, to the next document processing action.

entry.name: result_is_conformance_report_conformancepolicy_descr_425
entry.text: Determines whether to use conformance analysis as output.

entry.name: cookie_attribute_policy_kconfigcrypto_help_426
entry.text:
Enters Cookie Attribute Policy mode where you can create or modify a cookie attribute policy. A cookie attribute policy defines standard and custom cookie attributes that can be used with HTML Forms Login and LTPA cookies.
name The name for Cookie Attribute Policy object.

entry.name: cookie_attribute_policy_kconfigcrypto_descr_426
entry.text: Enters Cookie Attribute Policy configuration mode.

entry.name: cookie_attribute_cookieattributepolicy_help_427
entry.text:
Identifies which attribute to configure in the policy. Attributes selected here are added to the cookie.
attribute[+attribute]... Identifies the attributes to include in the cookie. Concatenate the attributes with the plus sign (+). The following attributes are available: domain The applicable domain for the cookie. path The path that this cookie is restricted to. secure Indicates that communication should occur on secured channel. httponly Indicates that the cookie is restricted to HTTP or HTTPS protocols. max-age Sets the cookie expiration as relative interval in seconds. expires Sets the cookie expiration using RFC1123 date/time format. custom Includes custom attributes in the cookie.

entry.name: cookie_attribute_cookieattributepolicy_descr_427
entry.text: Specifies the attributes to include in the policy configuration.

entry.name: custom_attribute_cookieattributepolicy_help_428
entry.text:
Specifies the custom attributes to include in the cookie. You can specify the attribute in name-value pair. When you enter multiple pairs, separate the pairs with a semicolon. Instead of name-value pairs, you can also specify only the name of the attribute or specify a context variable to define the attribute.
name The name of the attribute. value The value of the attribute. variable Specifies a context variable.

entry.name: custom_attribute_cookieattributepolicy_descr_428
entry.text: Specifies the custom attributes to include in the cookie.

entry.name: domain_cookieattributepolicy_help_429
entry.text:
Specifies the domain for which the cookie is sent. When the domain is specified, the cookie is accepted by the user agent only if the domain specified here matches the current domain of the resource that is being accessed.
value The domain for which the cookie is sent.

entry.name: domain_cookieattributepolicy_descr_429
entry.text: Specifies the domain for which the cookie is sent.

entry.name: path_cookieattributepolicy_help_430
entry.text:
Specifies the path for which the cookie is sent. When the path is specified, the user agent accepts a cookie only if the path specified here matches the current path of the resource that is being accessed. The default path is the root path (/).
value The path for which the cookie is sent.

entry.name: path_cookieattributepolicy_descr_430
entry.text: Specifies the path for which the cookie is sent.

entry.name: interval_cookieattributepolicy_help_431
entry.text:
Sets the cookie's maximum age and/or the expiration date as an interval of seconds, relative to the current time of the user agent. For example, you have the following configuration: Include the Max-Age and the Expires attributes in the cookie. Set the value of the interval command to 3600. Then, if a transaction that includes a cookie occurred on Feb 10, 2014 12:00:00 GMT, the following rules apply to the cookie: The maximum age of the cookie is 3600 seconds. The expiration date of the cookie is Feb 10, 2014 13:00:00 GMT.
value Sets the time interval in seconds. Enter a value in the range 1 - 2678400. The default value is 3600.

entry.name: interval_cookieattributepolicy_descr_431
entry.text: Sets the time interval in seconds to control when the cookie expires.

entry.name: ip_address_hostalias_help_432
entry.text:
ip-address is the IP address to be mapped to the current host alias. download For example:
ip-address 192.168.1.1 maps the specified IP address with the current host alias

entry.name: ip_address_hostalias_descr_432
entry.text: Maps IP address to host-alias

entry.name: default_encoding_httpinputconversionmap_help_433
entry.text:
Assigns a default conversion for HTTP form values. This is the conversion used if there are no rule entries, or if the form field name does not match any of the PCREs in the rule entries. plain, urlencoded, xml, urlencoded-xml, and base64 are mutually-exclusive keywords selecting the default conversion. plain Synonymous with urlencoded, which is preferred. urlencoded Replace any < >, and & characters with <, >, and & respectively. xml Synonymous with urlencoded-xml, which is preferred. urlencoded-xml Input assumed to be XML fragment. Remove leading <?xml ?> XML declaration, if present, otherwise transparent. base64 The same as urlencoded, except that encoding="base64" attribute is added to the <arg> element. json Converts to XML according to the JSONx XML specification. For example:
default-encoding urlencoded-xml specifies urlencoded-xml as the default encoding.

entry.name: default_encoding_httpinputconversionmap_descr_433
entry.text: Selects the default encoding for HTTP form values

entry.name: rule_httpinputconversionmap_help_434
entry.text:
Adds a pattern match rule to map from form field names to the conversion rule for the value associated with matching fields. NamePCRE The regular expression to match against the name. plain, urlencoded, xml, urlencoded-xml, and base64 are mutually-exclusive keywords selecting the conversion of the associated value. plain Synonymous with urlencoded, which is preferred. urlencoded Replace any < >, and & characters with <, >, and & respectively. xml Synonymous with urlencoded-xml, which is preferred. urlencoded-xml Input assumed to be XML fragment. Remove leading <?xml ?> XML declaration, if present, otherwise transparent. base64 The same as urlencoded, except that encoding="base64" attribute is added to the <arg> element. For example:
rule "^b64" base64 creates a rule that form field names starting with b64 will have their values processed with base64 encoding.

entry.name: rule_httpinputconversionmap_descr_434
entry.text: Map from form field names matching PCRE to encoding of value

entry.name: rewrite_errors_httpproxyservice_help_435
entry.text:
Enables "error message rewriting" -- With error message rewriting enabled (the default state), the XML firewall rewrites errors detected during request processing to avoid padding oracle attacks. For example:
rewrite-errors enables the error message rewrite function

entry.name: rewrite_errors_httpproxyservice_descr_435
entry.text: Enables error message rewrite

entry.name: delay_errors_httpproxyservice_help_436
entry.text:
Enables "delaying error messages" -- With delaying error messages enabled (the default state), the service delays errors for the specified duration to avoid padding oracle attacks. For example:
delay-errors enables the error message delay function

entry.name: delay_errors_httpproxyservice_descr_436
entry.text: Enables delaying error message

entry.name: chunked_uploads_httpproxyservice_help_437
entry.text:
Enables the use of chunked encoding when uploading an HTTP/1.1 request to the server. With chunk coding enabled, the HTTP proxy transfers messages to the server as a series of chunks, with each chunk containing a length value followed by the chunk data. A chunk with a zero length value indicates end-of-message. By default, chunk encoding is disabled. Chunk encoding should be enabled to stream documents to a server. You should, however, ensure that the target server is fully RFC-2616 compliant before enabling chunk encoding. For example:
chunked-uploads enables chunked encoding

entry.name: chunked_uploads_httpproxyservice_descr_437
entry.text: Enables chunked encoding

entry.name: client_address_httpproxyservice_help_438
entry.text:
Restores the default state, and enables the inclusion of the IP address of the requesting client in the HTTP header sent to the web or application server. In the default state the client address is included in a field labeled "X-Client-IP". httpHeaderFieldLabel optionally specifies a new label for the HTTP header field. For example:
client-address X-Forwarded-For includes requesting client addresses in an HTTP header field labeled X-Forwarded-for

entry.name: client_address_httpproxyservice_descr_438
entry.text: Sends client IP address to the HTTP server

entry.name: http_global_tranid_label_httpproxyservice_help_439
entry.text:
Restores the default state, and enables the inclusion of the Global transaction ID in the HTTP header sent to the web or application server. In the default state the global transaction header is included in a field labeled "X-Global-Transaction-ID". httpHeaderFieldLabel optionally specifies a new label for the HTTP header field. For example:
http-global-tranID-label X-MyGlobal-Transaction-ID includes global transaction ID in an HTTP header field labeled X-MyGlobal-Transaction-ID

entry.name: http_global_tranid_label_httpproxyservice_descr_439
entry.text: Global Transaction ID Label

entry.name: compression_httpproxyservice_help_440
entry.text:
Enables GZIP (GNU Zip) compression negotiation with the remote HTTP peer. If enabled, this HTTP proxy responds to compression negotiation initiated by a peer device. By default, compression negotiation is disabled. For example:
compression enables compression negotiation

entry.name: compression_httpproxyservice_descr_440
entry.text: Enables HTTP compression negotiation

entry.name: disallow_empty_reply_httpproxyservice_help_441
entry.text: Rejects server responses containing an empty response body.

entry.name: disallow_empty_reply_httpproxyservice_descr_441
entry.text: Rejects responses containing an empty response body

entry.name: disallow_get_httpproxyservice_help_442
entry.text: Rejects client GET and HEAD requests.

entry.name: disallow_get_httpproxyservice_descr_442
entry.text: Rejects GET and HEAD requests

entry.name: host_rewriting_httpproxyservice_help_443
entry.text:
Enables or disables "host rewrite" -- With host rewrite enabled (the default state), the HTTP proxy rewrites the URL received from the client to reflect the address/method by which the HTTP proxy accesses the back-end web or application server. For example:
host-rewriting yes enables the host rewrite function host-rewriting no disables the host rewrite function

entry.name: host_rewriting_httpproxyservice_descr_443
entry.text: Enables/disables host rewrite

entry.name: http_timeout_httpproxyservice_help_444
entry.text:
Specifies an HTTP timer-interval (expressed in seconds) for the HTTP proxy. timerInterval is an integer (within the range 3 through 7200, with a default value of 120) that specifies the idle timer in seconds. HTTP connections on both the client and server side that are idle for a period in excess of timer-interval are dropped by the HTTP proxy. For example:
http-timeout 30 sets an HTTP idle timer of 30 seconds

entry.name: http_timeout_httpproxyservice_descr_444
entry.text: Sets an HTTP idle timer

entry.name: httpproxy_address_httpproxyservice_help_445
entry.text:
Specifies the IP address or domain name of a remote HTTP Proxy used to access a Web or application server. Used in conjunction with httpproxy-port to provide complete addressing information/ proxyAddress is the IP address or domain name of the remote HTTP proxy. For example:
httpproxy-address 192.168.12.100 specifies the remote HTTP Proxy address

entry.name: httpproxy_address_httpproxyservice_descr_445
entry.text: Identifies a remote HTTP Proxy

entry.name: httpproxy_port_httpproxyservice_help_446
entry.text:
Specifies the port number monitored by a remote HTTP Proxy used to access a Web or application server. Used in conjunction with httpproxy-address to provide complete addressing information/ proxyPort is the port number of the remote HTTP proxy. For example:
httpproxy-port 8888 specifies the remote HTTP Proxy port

entry.name: httpproxy_port_httpproxyservice_descr_446
entry.text: Identifies a remote HTTP Proxy port

entry.name: include_response_type_encoding_httpproxyservice_help_447
entry.text:
Enables the inclusion of character set data in the content-type HTTP header field. By default, character set data is not included within this header field. For example:
include-response-type-encoding enables the inclusion of character set data within the header field. Assuming the transmission of a UTF-8 encoded XML document, the transmitted header contains: content-type=text/xml; charset=UTF-8

entry.name: include_response_type_encoding_httpproxyservice_descr_447
entry.text: Specify content-type header

entry.name: inject_httpproxyservice_help_448
entry.text:
Injects HTTP headers into front (client) or back (server) stream. front The client-side stream. back The server-side stream. headerTag The target HTTP header field. headerValue The contents of the target HTTP header field. For example:
inject front myheadertag myheadervalue injects the header "myheadertag" with a value of "myheadervalue" into the client-side stream

entry.name: inject_httpproxyservice_descr_448
entry.text: Injects HTTP headers into front or back stream

entry.name: persistent_connections_httpproxyservice_help_449
entry.text: With persistent connections enabled, (the default state for both HTTP 1.0 and HTTP 1.1), the device negotiates with the remote HTTP peer and establishes a persistent connection if agreeable to the peer.

entry.name: persistent_connections_httpproxyservice_descr_449
entry.text: Enables persistent connection negotiation

entry.name: persistent_timeout_httpproxyservice_help_450
entry.text:
Specifies an TCP timer-interval (expressed in seconds) for the HTTP proxy. timerInterval is an integer (within the range 0 through 7200) that specifies the TCP idle timer in seconds. TCP connections on both the client and server side that are idle for a period in excess of timer-interval are closed by the HTTP proxy. For example:
http-timeout 120 sets an TCP idle timer of 2 minutes

entry.name: persistent_timeout_httpproxyservice_descr_450
entry.text: Sets a TCP idle timer

entry.name: silence_warning_httpproxyservice_help_451
entry.text: Disables the generation of "Transformation Applied" warning messages. These messages are required by Section 14.46 of RFC 2616 whenever an HTTP proxy performs any transformation that changes either the content-coding or media-type of the response.

entry.name: silence_warning_httpproxyservice_descr_451
entry.text: Disables "Transformation Applied" warnings

entry.name: suppress_httpproxyservice_help_452
entry.text:
Suppresses HTTP headers on front (client) or back (server) stream. front The client-side stream. back The server-side stream. header-tag The target HTTP header field. For example:
suppress back Authorization Removes the Authorization header from the server-side stream

entry.name: suppress_httpproxyservice_descr_452
entry.text: Suppresses HTTP headers on front or back stream

entry.name: version_httpproxyservice_help_453
entry.text:
Specifies the HTTP protocol stack on both the front and back streams. By default, HTTP 1.1 is enabled on both the client and server stream. The first argument identifies the stack version visible to the client and the second argument identifies the version to the back server. For example:
version HTTP/1.0 HTTP/1.1 specifies HTTP Version 1.0 on the client connection HTTP Version 1.1 on the server connection

entry.name: version_httpproxyservice_descr_453
entry.text: Specifies HTTP version information

entry.name: auto_execute_includeconfig_help_454
entry.text: When set to 'on' the include configuration is executed at start-up. The default is on.

entry.name: auto_execute_includeconfig_descr_454
entry.text: Execute the include on start-up

entry.name: config_url_includeconfig_help_455
entry.text:
Specifies the location of a configuration file which may be included in other configuration files. Local configuration files are generally stored in the following directories: config: local: temp
fileURL is a URL that identifies the location of the target configuration file. If the target configuration file resides on the device flash, This argument take the following form: <directory>:///<filename>
where:
directory must be specified by one of the following keywords that identifies specific device directories:
audit: contains the audit log
cert: contains domain-specific private keys and certificates
config: contains configuration scripts
export: contains export packages
image: contains primary and secondary firmware images
local: contains user processing resources such as stylesheets, schemas, document encryption maps, or XML mapping files
logstore: contains logging files
logtemp: contains active and rotated log files
pubcert: contains well-known (for example, Verisign) public certificate files
sharedcert: contains private keys and certificates that are shared across domains
store: contains DataPower-supplied processing resources such as stylesheets, schemas, and authentication and authorization files
tasktemplates: contains Task Template files
temporary: contains temporary files
filename is the name of a file or target destination within the referenced directory.
If the target configuration file is remote from the device and the transport protocol is HTTP, HTTPS, SCP, or SFTP, this argument takes one of the following form, respectively:
http ://userName:passWord@<host>/filePath https://userName:passWord@<host>/filePath scp://userName:passWord@<host>/filePath sftp://userName:passWord@<host>/filePath
where <host> can be specified as an IP address or as a qualified host name (assuming that DNS services were previously enabled).
For example:
include-config standardServiceProxies scp://jrb:passWoRd@baldar.us.ibm.com/configs/standardServiceProxies.cfg specifies the location of a remote configuration file that may be included in other configuration files.
include-config standardServiceProxies local:///standardServiceProxies.cfg specifies the location of a local configuration file that may be included in other configuration files.

entry.name: config_url_includeconfig_descr_455
entry.text: Defines the location of the target configuration file.

entry.name: interface_detection_includeconfig_help_456
entry.text: This setting only affects the execution of configuration files from remote servers. If set to 'on' the remote file is executed asynchronously. It will be executed after the associated IP interface is operational. The default is off.

entry.name: interface_detection_includeconfig_descr_456
entry.text: Wait for an operational interface

entry.name: client_id_prefix_imsconnect_help_457
entry.text:
Sets the two-letter prefix for the generated client ID.
prefix The two-letter prefix for the generated client ID. If not specified, the prefix is set to DP.

entry.name: client_id_prefix_imsconnect_descr_457
entry.text: Sets a prefix for the generated client ID

entry.name: clientid_imsconnect_help_458
entry.text:
Specifies the name of the IMS client identifier.
identifier The name of the IMS client identifier. If not supplied by the client, the user exit must generate it.

entry.name: clientid_imsconnect_descr_458
entry.text: Specifies the name of the IMS client identifier

entry.name: datastore_imsconnect_help_459
entry.text:
Specifies the name of the data store.
name The name of the data store.

entry.name: datastore_imsconnect_descr_459
entry.text: Specifies the name of the data store

entry.name: ebcdic_conversion_imsconnect_help_460
entry.text:
Specifies whether to enable EBCDIC header conversion.
on Enables EBCDIC header conversion. off Disables EBCDIC header conversion.

entry.name: ebcdic_conversion_imsconnect_descr_460
entry.text: Indicates whether to enable EBCDIC header conversion

entry.name: encoding_scheme_imsconnect_help_461
entry.text:
Specifies the Unicode encoding scheme.
NotSet (Default) Uses the encoding that is set by the IMS Connect Handler object or by a transform action in the processing policy. Default Uses the encoding that is set by the message. UCS2 Uses UCS-2 encoding. UTF8 Uses UTF-8 encoding. UTF16 Uses UTF-16 encoding.

entry.name: encoding_scheme_imsconnect_descr_461
entry.text: Sets the Unicode encoding scheme

entry.name: exit_program_imsconnect_help_462
entry.text:
Specifies the exit identifier to use for all IMS connections.
If no exit identifier is specified, *SAMPLE* is used. The DataPower Gateway supports the standard exit identifiers *SAMPLE* and *SAMPL1* and any identifiers that implement exits that conform to these wire protocols. If *SAMPL1*, or an identifier that conforms to *SAMPL1* wire protocol, is specified, set expect-llll to "on". Otherwise, expect-llll must be set to "off". identifier The name of the exit identifier.

entry.name: exit_program_imsconnect_descr_462
entry.text: Specifies the exit identifier to use

entry.name: irm_timer_imsconnect_help_463
entry.text:
Specifies an appropriate wait time for the IMS server to return data to IMS Connect. This value sets the IRM_TIMER. Refer to the IMS Connect documentation for details.
timeout The time to wait. For example,
irm-timer 21 sets the time to wait to 0.21

entry.name: irm_timer_imsconnect_descr_463
entry.text: Specifies the wait time to return data

entry.name: lterm_name_imsconnect_help_464
entry.text:
Specifies the logical terminal (LTERM) name.
name The name of the logical terminal.

entry.name: lterm_name_imsconnect_descr_464
entry.text: Specifies the LTERM name

entry.name: port_imsconnect_help_465
entry.text:
Specifies the port that the target IMS Connect uses for TCP/IP connections.
port The port that IMS Connect uses.

entry.name: port_imsconnect_descr_465
entry.text: Specifies the port on the target IMS Connect

entry.name: tran_code_imsconnect_help_466
entry.text:
Specifies the transaction code to invoke. This value can be overridden by specifying it in the backend URL.
code The transaction code.

entry.name: tran_code_imsconnect_descr_466
entry.text: Specifies the transaction code to invoke

entry.name: segment_size_imsconnect_help_467
entry.text:
Specifies the maximum segment size to split the request into before sending to IMS Connect. A value of '0' means no segmentation will be performed. Any integer value between 1 - 32 represents the segment size in KB.
segment-size The Maximum Segment Size.

entry.name: segment_size_imsconnect_descr_467
entry.text: Specifies the maximum segment size to split the message

entry.name: expect_llll_imsconnect_help_468
entry.text:
Indicates whether the response message includes a 4 byte LLLL header specifying the total response message size back from IMS Connect.
on Indicates a response message with a 4 byte LLLL header field. off (Default) Indicates a response message without the initial LLLL header.

entry.name: expect_llll_imsconnect_descr_468
entry.text: Indicates whether the response message includes a 4 byte LLLL header.

entry.name: sync_level_imsconnect_help_469
entry.text:
Specifies whether the DataPower Gateway sends an acknowledgment (ACK) to the IMS Connect server after receiving the response. The default is 0x00 (NONE).
When communicating with the IMS Connect server on the backend and a transaction is specified with sync-level set to 0x01 (CONFIRM), the client must send an ACK (successful) or a NAK (unsuccessful) after processing the response. The IMS Connect server then sends DEALLOCATE CONFIRM (successful) or DEALLOCATE ABORT (unsuccessful) back to the client.
The DataPower Gateway always sends an ACK upon receiving the response and then checks for the DEALLOCATE CONFIRM.
0x00 (Default) Identifies that the IMS Sync Level is set to NONE. 0x01 Identifies that the IMS Sync Level is set to CONFIRM.

entry.name: sync_level_imsconnect_descr_469
entry.text: Indicates whether the Sync Level is NONE or CONFIRM.

entry.name: acl_imsconnectsourceprotocolhandler_help_470
entry.text:
Specifies an existing Access Control List.
name The name of the Access Control List.

entry.name: acl_imsconnectsourceprotocolhandler_descr_470
entry.text: Specifies an Access Control List (ACL)

entry.name: ebcdic_input_imsconnectsourceprotocolhandler_help_471
entry.text:
Specifies the encoding for input headers as EBCDIC or ASCII. This setting does not affect payload processing. Payload is not automatically processed.
on Indicates the input headers are in EBCDIC encoding. off (Default) Indicates that input headers are in ASCII encoding.

entry.name: ebcdic_input_imsconnectsourceprotocolhandler_descr_471
entry.text: Sets encoding for input headers as EBCDIC or ASCII

entry.name: local_address_imsconnectsourceprotocolhandler_help_472
entry.text:
Specifies the device interface.
address Binds to a single interface on the specified port. Specify the interface by IP address or by host alias. 0 Binds to all enabled interfaces on the specified port.

entry.name: local_address_imsconnectsourceprotocolhandler_descr_472
entry.text: Specifies the device interface

entry.name: persistent_connections_imsconnectsourceprotocolhandler_help_473
entry.text:
When enabled, the IMS Connect Handler negotiates with the remote target to establish a persistent connection, if agreeable with the target.
on (Default) Enables the establishment of persistent connections. off Disables the establishment of persistent connections.

entry.name: persistent_connections_imsconnectsourceprotocolhandler_descr_473
entry.text: Controls the negotiation of persistent connections

entry.name: port_imsconnectsourceprotocolhandler_help_474
entry.text:
Specify the port that the IMS listener monitors.
port The port number. Use an integer in the range of 1 through 65535. The default is 3000.

entry.name: port_imsconnectsourceprotocolhandler_descr_474
entry.text: Specifies the device TCP port

entry.name: segment_size_imsconnectsourceprotocolhandler_help_475
entry.text:
Specifies the maximum segment size to split the response into before sending back to the IMS client. A value of '0' means no segmentation is performed by DataPower. Any integer value between 1 - 32 represents that value in KB.
segment-size The Maximum Segment Size.

entry.name: segment_size_imsconnectsourceprotocolhandler_descr_475
entry.text: Specifies the Maximum Segment Size to split the message into.

entry.name: ssl_imsconnectsourceprotocolhandler_help_476
entry.text:
Specifies an existing TLS Proxy Profile. The TLS proxy profile is deprecated. Use a TLS server profile or an TLS SNI server profile.
name The name of the TLS Proxy Profile Policy.

entry.name: ssl_imsconnectsourceprotocolhandler_descr_476
entry.text: Deprecated - Assigns a TLS Proxy Profile.

entry.name: ssl_config_type_imsconnectsourceprotocolhandler_help_477
entry.text:
Specify the TLS profile type. Valid values include proxy, server, or sni. The default value is proxy, which uses TLS proxy profile. Use server to specify TLS server profile, and use sni to indicate TLS SNI server profile. For example:
ssl-config-type server specifies a TLS server profile for this handler.

entry.name: ssl_config_type_imsconnectsourceprotocolhandler_descr_477
entry.text: Specifies the TLS profile type.

entry.name: ssl_server_imsconnectsourceprotocolhandler_help_478
entry.text:
Assigns a TLS server profile to the IMS Connect handler. The handler uses the resources in this profile to establish a secure connection with clients. sslServerProfileName The TLS server profile assigned to this handler. For example:
ssl-server highSec assigns the TLS server profile named highSec to the handler.

entry.name: ssl_server_imsconnectsourceprotocolhandler_descr_478
entry.text: Assigns a TLS server profile to the handler.

entry.name: ssl_sni_server_imsconnectsourceprotocolhandler_help_479
entry.text:
Assigns a TLS SNI server profile to the IMS Connect handler. The handler uses the resources in this profile to establish a secure connection with clients. name The TLS SNI server profile assigned to this handler. For example:
ssl-sni-server highSec Assigns the highSec TLS SNI server profile.

entry.name: ssl_sni_server_imsconnectsourceprotocolhandler_descr_479
entry.text: Assigns a TLS SNI server profile to the handler.

entry.name: base_dn_ldapsearchparameters_help_480
entry.text:
Specifies the DN relative to which the LDAP search is to be performed.
DN The base DN for the search.

entry.name: base_dn_ldapsearchparameters_descr_480
entry.text: Specifies the base DN to begin the search

entry.name: filter_prefix_ldapsearchparameters_help_481
entry.text:
Specifies the string prefix to construct an LDAP filter expression. This string is added before the user name to construct the LDAP filter to search for the DN of the user. If the prefix is "(&(mail=" and the user name is "bob@example.com" and the suffix is ")(c=US))", the LDAP search filter would be "(&(mail=bob@example.com)(c=US))".
prefix The prefix of the filter expression.

entry.name: filter_prefix_ldapsearchparameters_descr_481
entry.text: Specifies the prefix of the LDAP filter expression

entry.name: filter_suffix_ldapsearchparameters_help_482
entry.text:
Specifies the string suffix to construct an LDAP filter expression. This string is added after the user name to construct the LDAP filter to search for the DN of the user. If the prefix is "(&(mail=" and the user name is "bob@example.com" and the suffix is ")(c=US))", the LDAP search filter would be "(&(mail=bob@example.com)(c=US))".
suffix The suffix of the filter expression.

entry.name: filter_suffix_ldapsearchparameters_descr_482
entry.text: Specifies the suffix of the LDAP filter expression

entry.name: returned_attribute_ldapsearchparameters_help_483
entry.text:
Specifies the attribute to return for each entry that matches the search criteria.
attribute The name of the attribute to return. The default is "dn".

entry.name: returned_attribute_ldapsearchparameters_descr_483
entry.text: Specifies the attribute to return for each match

entry.name: scope_ldapsearchparameters_help_484
entry.text:
Indicates the depth of the LDAP search.
base Searches the input only. one-level Searches the input and any object that is one level below the input. subtree (Default) Searches the input and all of its descendants.

entry.name: scope_ldapsearchparameters_descr_484
entry.text: Indicates the depth of the search

entry.name: idle_timeout_ldapconnectionpool_help_485
entry.text: Specifies how long a LDAP connection could be idle before it is removed from the pool. Enter a value in the range 5 - 360. The default value is 120.

entry.name: idle_timeout_ldapconnectionpool_descr_485
entry.text: Specifies the timeout in seconds for idle connections

entry.name: max_pool_size_ldapconnectionpool_help_486
entry.text: Specifies the maximum connections to a LDAP server:port:BindDN triple in the LDAP pool. Enter a value in the range 1 - 2000. The default value is 35.

entry.name: max_pool_size_ldapconnectionpool_descr_486
entry.text: Specifies the maximum number of connections for a ldap server

entry.name: reject_on_pool_limit_ldapconnectionpool_help_487
entry.text:
Specifies whether to reject any new LDAP connections if pool limit is reached. The default behavior is off which specifies not to reject new LDAP connections when pool limit is reached.
on indicates that new LDAP connections will be rejected on pool limit
off indicates new LDAP connections wont use pool on pool limit

entry.name: reject_on_pool_limit_ldapconnectionpool_descr_487
entry.text: Specifies whether to reject or use non-pool when max-pool-limit reached

entry.name: algorithm_loadbalancergroup_help_488
entry.text:
Specifies a server selection algorithm which determines how incoming client requests are allocated among healthy members of the load balancer group. serverSelectionAlgorithm takes one of the following keyword values: first-alive specifies the first-alive selection algorithm, which is based on the concept of a primary and some number of backup servers. Assuming that the primary server is healthy, all connections are forwarded to this server. Connections are forwarded to backup servers only if the health state of the primary server is down or softdown. hash specifies a SRC hash selection algorithm, which uses the client IP address or the value of an HTTP header. With the hash algorithm, the same client is served by the same server. Use this algorithm only when clients access applications that require the storage of server-side state information, such as cookies. Hashing algorithms cannot ensure even distribution. The HTTP header approach is applicable with only Multi-Protocol Gateway and Web Service Proxy services. least-connections specifies a least-connections selection algorithm, which maintains a record of current active server connections and forwards a new connection to the server with the least number of active connections. round-robin specifies a round-robin selection algorithm, which maintains a simple list of servers and forwards a new connection to the next server on the list. weighted-round-robin specifies a round-robin selection algorithm, which maintains a weighted list of servers and forwards new connections in proportion to the server weight (or preference). weighted-least-connections (requires the AppOpt feature) specifies a least connections algorithm, which maintains a weighted list of servers and forwards new connections in proportion to the server weight (or preference). For example:
algorithm weighted-round-robin designates weighted-round-robin as the server selection policy

entry.name: algorithm_loadbalancergroup_descr_488
entry.text: Specifies a server selection algorithm

entry.name: damp_loadbalancergroup_help_489
entry.text:
Specifies the quarantine period, that is the amount of time that a server is removed from a load balancer group as a consequence of a connection failure during a normal HTTP/TCP transaction. At the expiration of the quarantine period, the failed server is restored to the load balancer group. dampeningInterval is an integer (within the range 1 through 86400) that specifies the number of seconds that a server is removed from a load balancer group. For example:
damp 120 specifies a quarantine period of 2 minutes (120 seconds)

entry.name: damp_loadbalancergroup_descr_489
entry.text: Specifies a quarantine period

entry.name: giveup_when_all_members_down_loadbalancergroup_help_490
entry.text:
Specifies a connection procedure in the event that all members of a load balancer group are in the down state. The default behavior is when all members of a load balancer group are down, an attempt is made to connect to the first member of the group.
on dictates that no attempt is made to connect to the group. off dictates that an attempt is made to connect to the first member of the group.
For example:
giveup-when-all-members-down on giveup-when-all-members-down off disables connection attempts if all members of the load balancer group are in the down state. Subsequently, restores the default behavior.

entry.name: giveup_when_all_members_down_loadbalancergroup_descr_490
entry.text: Specifies procedure when all members are down.

entry.name: health_check_loadbalancergroup_help_491
entry.text:
Defines a periodic health check procedure for members of a load balancer group. admin-state on -- creates the health check object in the enabled state off -- creates the health check object in the disabled state target-uri In conjunction with the target-port specifies the non-server ( filepath) portion of the server URI (that is, the URI that will receive the client request generated by this health-check) target-port In conjunction with target-uri specifies the non-server (filepath) portion of the server URI (that is, the URI that will receive the client request generated by this health-check) type The type of health check operation. Standard -- perform the health check by sending an HTTP request to the member's health port, or if one is not specified, to the remote port IMSConnect -- deprecated - perform the health check with a TCP connection request on the mapped server port LDAP -- deprecated - perform the health check with a TCP connection request on the remote port TCPConnection -- perform the health check by sending a TCP connection request to the member's health port, or if one is not specified, to the remote port use-soap The HTTP method to access the server. on -- POSTs a SOAP message to access the server off -- uses an HTTP GET to access the server send-soap A local URI that identifies the SOAP message POSTed to the server. Use double quotes ("") if using an HTTP GET to access the server. timeout The number of seconds to allow for completion of the health check. Enter a value in the range 2 - 86400. Failure to complete the health check in this interval causes the health check to fail. frequency The interval in seconds between health checks. Enter a value in the range 5 - 86400. xpath An XPath expression contained in a valid response from the server. The health check uses the stylesheet identified by filter to scan the server response for this XPath expression. Upon finding the XPath expression in the response body, the filter accepts the response and deems the server to be healthy. Failure to find the expression causes the filter to reject the response and place the server in the down state. filter The stylesheet to evaluate the server response. The DataPower Gateway provides the default store:///healthcheck.xsl stylesheet. You can create your own stylesheet. tlsproxy The TLS Proxy Profile to enable a secure health check. The TLS proxy profile is deprecated. Use a TLS client profile. enforce-timeout on -- The health check timeout is honored. If a health check times out, the member is immediately marked down. off -- Health checks run until the user agent timeout expires, regardless of the health check timeout value. independent-checks on -- Health checks run independently from one another. off -- Health checks run sequentially. gatewayscript-checks on -- Health check requests and responses can be of any type and the response evaluator must be a GatewayScript file. off -- Health check requests must be SOAP messages, and the response evaluator must be a stylesheet. request-method The HTTP method to use for the health check request. Valid methods are GET, POST, PUT, HEAD, and custom. request-custom-method The HTTP request method. Valid methods are those defined by the 'extension-method' in RFC 2616 Section 5.1.1. request-doc The local URI that identifies the content of the health check request sent to the server. request-content-type The content type of the document sent to the server. response-evaluator-metadata A string that can be used by the response evaluator script to help evaluate the server response. response-evaluator The GatewayScript to evaluate the server response. The DataPower Gateway provides the default store:///healthcheck.js GatewayScript. You can create your own GatewayScript. tcp-conn-type partial -- Perform the TCP connection health check with a half-open connection, without completing the three-way handshake. full -- Perform the TCP connection health check with a three-way handshake to establish a connection and a four-way handshake to close the connection.
For example:
health-check health-check on cgi-bin/x.cgi 80 on on store:///identity.xsl 4 60 / store:///healthcheck.xsl tlsProxy1 Defines a health check.

entry.name: health_check_loadbalancergroup_descr_491
entry.text: Defines a server health check procedure

entry.name: admin_state_upt_dmlbgroupcheck_help_492
entry.text: Enables or disables the health check. The check will not run unless the health check object is enabled.

entry.name: admin_state_upt_dmlbgroupcheck_descr_492
entry.text: Administratively enables or disables the health check

entry.name: enforce_timeout_upt_dmlbgroupcheck_help_493
entry.text: Indicates whether the health check timeout value is used to interrupt and end a health transaction. By default, the health check timeout only compares the actual time that the request took. With the default behavior, the health check timeout is not used to interrupt the transaction.

entry.name: enforce_timeout_upt_dmlbgroupcheck_descr_493
entry.text: Enforce health check timeouts

entry.name: filter_upt_dmlbgroupcheck_help_494
entry.text: Enter the URL of the stylesheet that evaluates the server response using the specified XPath expression.

entry.name: filter_upt_dmlbgroupcheck_descr_494
entry.text: Filter that analyzes a health check response

entry.name: frequency_upt_dmlbgroupcheck_help_495
entry.text: Enter an integer between 5 and 86400 to indicate the number of seconds to wait between health check requests.

entry.name: frequency_upt_dmlbgroupcheck_descr_495

entry.name: gatewayscript_checks_upt_dmlbgroupcheck_help_496
entry.text: Enables or disables GatewayScript health check processing. If enabled, content of health check requests and responses can be of any type and the response evaluator must be a GatewayScript file.

entry.name: gatewayscript_checks_upt_dmlbgroupcheck_descr_496
entry.text: Enable GatewayScript health check processing

entry.name: independent_checks_upt_dmlbgroupcheck_help_497
entry.text: Indicates whether the health checks within a Load Balancer Group run independently of one another. By default, health checks within a Load Balancer Group run sequentially. With the default behavior, if a server hangs, all the other health checks for the other members are delayed.

entry.name: independent_checks_upt_dmlbgroupcheck_descr_497

entry.name: request_content_type_upt_dmlbgroupcheck_help_498
entry.text: Enter the content type of the Request Document.

entry.name: request_content_type_upt_dmlbgroupcheck_descr_498
entry.text: The content type of the Request Document

entry.name: request_custom_method_upt_dmlbgroupcheck_help_499
entry.text: Enter the name of the custom method to use for health check request.

entry.name: request_custom_method_upt_dmlbgroupcheck_descr_499
entry.text: The custom method to use for the request

entry.name: request_doc_upt_dmlbgroupcheck_help_500
entry.text: Enter the URL of the request document. This document can be a file on the local: directory; for example, local:///healthcheck.xml. This document is included in the request to the server if the POST, PUT, or Custom method is selected.

entry.name: request_method_upt_dmlbgroupcheck_help_501

entry.name: request_method_upt_dmlbgroupcheck_descr_501

entry.name: response_evaluator_upt_dmlbgroupcheck_help_502

entry.name: response_evaluator_upt_dmlbgroupcheck_descr_502
entry.text: The GatewayScript file used to evaluate the health check response

entry.name: response_evaluator_metadata_upt_dmlbgroupcheck_help_503

entry.name: send_soap_upt_dmlbgroupcheck_help_504
entry.text: Enter the URL of the SOAP request document. This may be a file on the local flash filesystem (for example, local:///healthcheck.xml). This document is POSTed to the server if use-soap is on.

entry.name: sslproxy_upt_dmlbgroupcheck_help_505

entry.name: sslproxy_upt_dmlbgroupcheck_descr_505
entry.text: Deprecated - An TLS proxy profile if using TLS

entry.name: ssl_client_type_upt_dmlbgroupcheck_help_506
entry.text:
Specify the type of TLS profile to use. Use proxy for TLS proxy profile, and use client for TLS client profile. Default is proxy.
For example:
ssl-client-type client Specifies a TLS client profile will be used.

entry.name: ssl_client_type_upt_dmlbgroupcheck_descr_506
entry.text: Specify the type of TLS profile to use.

entry.name: ssl_client_upt_dmlbgroupcheck_help_507
entry.text: Select the TLS client profile for use with this health check. This is required if the back end server is using TLS communications with the DataPower Gateway.

entry.name: ssl_client_upt_dmlbgroupcheck_descr_507
entry.text: A TLS Client Profile if using TLS

entry.name: target_port_upt_dmlbgroupcheck_help_508
entry.text: Enter the TCP port to test. This port is checked when the health check type is LDAP or Standard.

entry.name: target_port_upt_dmlbgroupcheck_descr_508
entry.text: Port to test

entry.name: target_uri_upt_dmlbgroupcheck_help_509
entry.text: The relative URI to test for each member of the group. XXX in http://www.foobar.com/XXX.

entry.name: target_uri_upt_dmlbgroupcheck_descr_509
entry.text: XXX in http://www.foobar.com/XXX

entry.name: timeout_upt_dmlbgroupcheck_help_510
entry.text: The time in seconds to wait for a response. Enter a value in the range 2 - 86400.

entry.name: timeout_upt_dmlbgroupcheck_descr_510
entry.text: Number of seconds to allocate for a health check

entry.name: type_upt_dmlbgroupcheck_help_511
entry.text: Type of health check to perform. In TCP mode (TCP Connection health check type), a health check is performed with a TCP connection request. In HTTP mode (Standard health check type), a health check is performed with an HTTP GET or HTTP POST.

entry.text: Type of health check operation

entry.name: use_soap_upt_dmlbgroupcheck_help_512
entry.text: When set to on, the SOAP request uses a POST operation. When set to off without a request document, uses a GET operation. The expected response is always valid XML and is analyzed by the XPath expression to verify the health state of the server.

entry.name: use_soap_upt_dmlbgroupcheck_descr_512
entry.text: Send SOAP Request?

entry.name: xpath_upt_dmlbgroupcheck_help_513
entry.text: Enter an XPath Expression that verifies the health of the server. The expression is applied to the server response to the health check POST. If the expression is true, the server is healthy. Otherwise, the server health state is softdown until it passes a health check.

entry.name: xpath_upt_dmlbgroupcheck_descr_513
entry.text: An XPath Expression for a healthy SOAP response

entry.name: tcp_conn_type_upt_dmlbgroupcheck_help_514
entry.text: When set to full, a TCP Connection health check will perform a complete three-way handshake to establish a connection, followed by a four-way handshake to close the connection. When set to partial, a TCP Connection health check will perform a half-open connection to check a member's health. The three-way handshake to establish a connection will not be completed for partial connection types.

entry.name: tcp_conn_type_upt_dmlbgroupcheck_descr_514
entry.text: Type of TCP connection to attempt for health check operations

entry.name: masquerade_loadbalancergroup_help_515
entry.text: If this value is set, the host name presented to the server will be the name of the group instead of the name of the member being used for that specific transaction. The default is off.

entry.name: masquerade_loadbalancergroup_descr_515
entry.text: Masquerade as Group Name

entry.name: server_loadbalancergroup_help_516
entry.text:
Adds a server to a load balancer group. When defining a member, optionally specify the ports to use for sending client requests for a health check.
If the selection algorithm is first-alive, the order is significant. The first server is the primary server, while subsequent entries serve as backup servers. For all other algorithms, the order is not significant.
If the selection algorithm is weighted-round-robin, specify the relative preference of a server. The greater the value, the more likely this is to receive a connection request. For example, there are three member servers (A, B, and C) that have the assigned weights of 100, 60, and 40, respectively. Because of the weighting, A receives 50%% of requests, B receives 30%%, and C receives 20%%.
host The host name or IP address of the server weight For the weighted-round-robin or weighted-least-outstanding-connections algorithms, the relative weight (preference). Use an integer in the range 1 through 65000. The default is 1. mapped-port The port on the real server. If non-zero, the associated real server is contacted on this port. Normally the real server is contacted on the same port as that of the virtual server. However, if the service runs on different ports for different members, you might need to define this value. internal Interval value. Use "". health-port The TCP port to test. admin-state Administratively enables or disables the server.
For example: server 10.10.100.19 5 Adds the designated server to the load balancer group with a relative weight of 5.

entry.name: server_loadbalancergroup_descr_516
entry.text: Adds a server to a load balancer group

entry.name: try_every_server_loadbalancergroup_help_517
entry.text: This property applies only when none of the group members are in the "up" state. If this value is set, every server in the group is tried before failing the connection attempt. This is a "last best-effort" attempt. The default is off.

entry.name: try_every_server_loadbalancergroup_descr_517
entry.text: Try every server in group before failing

entry.name: retrieve_wlm_info_loadbalancergroup_help_518
entry.text: If set to on, attempts to retrieve Work Load Management information. Work Load Management information is used to modify the current members, their weights, and the session affinity information used in load balancing decisions. The default is off.

entry.name: retrieve_wlm_info_loadbalancergroup_descr_518
entry.text: Retrieve Work Load Management information

entry.name: websphere_cell_loadbalancergroup_help_519
entry.text:
This command specifies the WebSphere Cell Service object, previously created with the wcc-service command. The WebSphere Cell service object is the named resource that periodically retrieves Work Load Management information from a WebSphere Cell.
Example:
websphere-cell alpha-cell The WebSphere Cell service object, alpha-cell.

entry.name: websphere_cell_loadbalancergroup_descr_519
entry.text: Reference to an existing WebSphere Cell object

entry.name: wlm_group_loadbalancergroup_help_520
entry.text:
The group name is used to retrieve the Work Load Management information for that specific group. In a WebSphere Cell, the group is the name of a cluster. The name is case sensitive.
Example:
wlm-group cluster-west cluster-west is the name of a cluster in the WebSphere Cell.

entry.name: wlm_group_loadbalancergroup_descr_520
entry.text: Group name of Work Load Management group

entry.name: wlm_type_loadbalancergroup_help_521
entry.text:
The type of Work Load Management information to be retrieved. The options include: use-websphere.
Example:
wlm-retrieval use-websphere specifies that the WebSphere Cell object will be used to retrieve Work Load Management information.

entry.name: wlm_type_loadbalancergroup_descr_521
entry.text: Type of Work Load Management information

entry.name: wlm_transport_loadbalancergroup_help_522
entry.text:
The transport, either http or https, that will be used for back-end connections to the servers in this LBGroup. The options include: http, https.
Example:
wlm-transport http Specifies that the transport used for this load balancer group is http.

entry.name: wlm_transport_loadbalancergroup_descr_522
entry.text: Transport protocol for this Load Balancer Group

entry.name: session_affinity_loadbalancergroup_help_523
entry.text:
Adds session affinity configuration. When using WebSphere Cell configuration information, you do not need to modify this configuration property. However, you may wish to modify the i-cookie-name, i-path, i-domain, and i-cookie-attributes to fit your environment if the configuration that the WebSphere Cell specifies is active or active-conditional.
If you do not have a WebSphere Application Server Network Deployment or Virtual Enterprise backend, you can configure and use active or active-conditional session affinity locally through the DataPower Gateway.
enable-affinity Takes the value "on" or "off" - on -- enables session affinity - off -- disables session affinity i-cookie-name The insertion cookie name to insert into an HTTP Set-Cookie response header when active or active-conditional session affinity is configured. i-path The path attribute value for the insertion cookie. i-domain The domain attribute value for the insertion cookie. override-wlm-affinity Takes the value "on" or "off" - on -- overrides the WebSphere Cell configuration information - off -- uses WebSphere Cell configuration information affinity-mode Takes the value "active" or "activeConditional" - active -- performs active session affinity - activeConditional -- performs active-conditional session affinity i-cookie-attributes Which attributes to insert in the cookie. The following values are supported. Concatenate attributes with the plus sign (+). - secure -- inserts the Secure attribute. - httponly -- inserts the HttpOnly attribute.
For example: session-affinity on DPJESSIONID / datapower.com on active secure+httponly Adds session affinity configuration. - session affinity is enabled - the insertion cookie name is DPJSESSIONID - the insertion path is / - the insertion domain is datapower.com - the WLM WebSphere Cell configuration for session affinity is overridden - the type of affinity will be active - inserts the Secure and HttpOnly attributes in the cookie

entry.name: session_affinity_loadbalancergroup_descr_523
entry.text: Specifies session affinity configuration for this load balancer group

entry.name: monitored_cookie_loadbalancergroup_help_524
entry.text: Adds a cookie name to the list of cookies to be monitored when active-conditional affinity is enabled and the WebSphere Cell override is on. For example: monitored-cookie NEWJSESSIONID Adds the NEWJSESSIONID to the list of monitored cookies.

entry.name: monitored_cookie_loadbalancergroup_descr_524
entry.text: Adds a cookie to be monitored during active-conditional

entry.name: appl_routing_loadbalancergroup_help_525
entry.text:
This command is deprecated. Application routing that is enabled on the load balancer group is deprecated. Instead, use the On Demand Router feature.
Requires the Option for Application Optimization.
Indicates whether the load balancer group attempts to optimally route traffic based on application specific information that is learned from the ODCInfo application.
Enables support for application rollout such that rollout of a new application edition occurs in a seamless way and one edition is replaced by a new edition with little or no traffic lost. When using application rollout, specify subscribe as the update method in the WebSphere cell.
on Indicates that the load balancer group uses application knowledge to route traffic.
off (Default) Indicates the load balancer group does not use application knowledge to route traffic.

entry.name: appl_routing_loadbalancergroup_descr_525
entry.text: Deprecated - Enables routing based on application knowledge

entry.name: ansi_color_logtarget_help_526
entry.text:
Enables use of ANSI X3.64 escape sequences to display log messages in different colors based on the log level. This is relevant only when the logging "type" is "console". This is only useful if the displaying terminal or terminal emulator supports these escape sequences.
on Use ANSI X3.64 escape sequences off Disable escape sequences, the default.
For example:
ansi-color on enables a log color-coded by log level.

entry.name: ansi_color_logtarget_descr_526
entry.text: Enables multicolor logs

entry.name: archive_mode_logtarget_help_527
entry.text:
Specifies the procedure to implement when a file-based log reaches its maximum configured size.
rotate specifies that when a file-based log reaches its maximum size, the log is rotated as specified by the rotate command. upload specifies that when a log file reaches its maximum size, the file is uploaded to a specified site for remote storage. After specifying upload mode, you must use the remote-address, remote-directory, remote-login, and upload-method commands to enable transfer of the file-based log to the remote site.
For example:
archive-mode upload specifies that upon reaching its maximum size a file-based log is uploaded to a remote site

entry.name: archive_mode_logtarget_descr_527
entry.text: Specifies an archiving procedure

entry.name: backup_logtarget_help_528
entry.text:
Specify another logging target to redirect events to in case of an error condition with this log target. targetName The name of another logging target to use as the backup
For example:
backup syslog-server2 Use the logging target syslog-server2 as the backup target for this logging target.

entry.name: backup_logtarget_descr_528
entry.text: Specifies log target to use as backup

entry.name: email_address_logtarget_help_529
entry.text:
When the logging type is SMTP, provides the required destination e-mail address for SMTP logging events. address is the fully-qualified e-mail address of the message recipient.
For example:
email-address tech-support@MegaCorporation.com provides the SMTP e-mail address of the message recipient

entry.name: email_address_logtarget_descr_529
entry.text: Specifies SMTP destination e-mail address

entry.name: event_logtarget_help_530
entry.text:
Subscribes this log target to a particular event category and severity. Any event in the specified category with a severity greater or equal to the specified severity will be captured by this target. event-class The event class to subscribe to. Some examples are mgmt (for configuration), and xslt (for XSLT processing). Additionally, "all" represents all event classes.
"emerg", "alert", "critic", "error", "warn", "notice", "info", and "debug" are mutually-exclusive keywords specifying the minimum severity of event to log, in order from most severe to least severe.
emerg Include events at severity of "system is unusable". alert Include events at severity of "action must be taken immediately" and higher. critic Include events at severity of "critical condition" and higher. error Include events at severity of "error" and higher. warn Include events at severity of "warning condition" and higher. notice Include events at severity of "normal but significant condition" and higher. info Include events at severity of "informational messages" and higher. debug Include events at severity of "debug" or higher (all).
For example:
event mgmt error event xslt warn Subscribe to management events at level error or higher, and XSLT events at level warn or higher.

entry.name: event_logtarget_descr_530
entry.text: Adds an event class to the current log

entry.name: event_code_logtarget_help_531
entry.text:
Adds an event code included in the current log. Event code filters allow only those log messages containing the configured event codes to be written to the current log target. Thus, it is possible to create a log target that only collects log messages for a particular set of event codes; for example, Operational State down.
Use the WebGUI event screen to view all event codes.
eventCodeValue is a a hex event error code which is included in the current log.
For example:
type file event-code 0x00030001 event-code 0x00030002 event-code 0x00030003 event-code 0x00030004 event-code 0x00030005 event-code 0x00030006 event-code 0x00030007 event-code 0x00030008 event-code 0x00030009 event-code 0x0003000a creates a file-based log containing only XML parser events.

entry.name: event_code_logtarget_descr_531
entry.text: Adds an event code match accept filter

entry.name: ip_filter_logtarget_help_532
entry.text:
Adds an IP filter included in the current log. IP address filters allow only those log messages containing the configured IP addresses to be written to the current log target. Thus, it is possible to create a log target that only collects log messages for a particular set of IP addresses.
ipFilterValue is an IP address to be included in the current log.

entry.name: ip_filter_logtarget_descr_532
entry.text: Adds an IP filter match accept filter

entry.name: trigger_logtarget_help_533
entry.text: Add an event trigger to perform the specified action when trigger conditions are met. The output of the triggered command will be logged to this target. msgid The msgid that triggers the command. regexp An optional regular expression that if supplied must match the message body in order to trigger the command. only-once Set to on to trigger the command only the first time the criteria are met. only-this-trigger Set to on to prevent processing other event triggers that would be triggered by the same msgid after the first match. command The command to execute if the trigger conditions are met.

entry.name: trigger_logtarget_descr_533
entry.text: Adds an event trigger to the current log.

entry.name: event_detection_logtarget_help_534
entry.text:
Allows for the suppression of identical log events that are generated by the same configuration object over a configurable time period. When enabled, the Log Target retains a reference to each processed event for a configurable period of time. Until this period expires, the Log Target will not process the same event from the same configuration object.
on Suppresses the writing of identical events to the log for the specified suppression period. off (Default) Identical events are written to the log.

entry.name: event_detection_logtarget_descr_534
entry.text: Suppresses identical events.

entry.name: event_filter_logtarget_help_535
entry.text:
Adds a suppression filter to keep messages from being included in the current log. The suppression filter prevents log messages for specific event codes from being written to the current log target. Therefore, it is possible to create a log target that collects log messages for all but a few event codes.
Use the WebGUI event screen to view all event codes.
eventCodeValue The hex event code to suppress.
For example, to create a file-based log that contains everything but XML parser events. type file event-filter 0x00030001 event-filter 0x00030002 event-filter 0x00030003 event-filter 0x00030004 event-filter 0x00030005 event-filter 0x00030006 event-filter 0x00030007 event-filter 0x00030008 event-filter 0x00030009 event-filter 0x0003000a

entry.name: event_filter_logtarget_descr_535
entry.text: Adds an event code match reject filter

entry.name: facility_logtarget_help_536
entry.text:
Identifies the syslog facility to include in syslog log messages. Only relevant with a syslog-based log target.
user (Default) Use the "user level messages" facility, number 1. security Use the "security/authorization messages" facility, number 4. authpriv Use the "security/authorization messages" facility, number 10. local0 Use the "local use 0" facility, number 16. local1 Use the "local use 0" facility, number 17. local2 Use the "local use 0" facility, number 18. local3 Use the "local use 0" facility, number 19. local4 Use the "local use 0" facility, number 20. local5 Use the "local use 0" facility, number 21. local6 Use the "local use 0" facility, number 22. local7 Use the "local use 0" facility, number 23.
For example:
