type syslog facility local3 Use local use 3 as the facility in syslog messages.

entry.name: facility_logtarget_descr_536
entry.text: Identifies the syslog facility

entry.name: feedback_detection_logtarget_help_537
entry.text:
Controls suppression of log events triggered by the log subsystem itself. They are always suppressed for the current log target, but setting this to "on" disables it for all other log targets.
off Allow other log targets to log, the default. on Disable logging on behalf of any log target.
For example:
feedback-detection on specifies that no logging is to be generated by the log subsystem during logging.

entry.name: feedback_detection_logtarget_descr_537
entry.text: Suppress feedback from log subsystem

entry.name: format_logtarget_help_538
entry.text:
Selects the format in which log entries are generated. Only relevant when the "type" is "smtp", "file", "console", "cache", or "soap".
text Use formatted text. raw Use raw (no formatting applied). xml Use XML. This is the default. cbe Use IBM Common Base Event format. csv Use CSV (comma separated value) format. json-icp Use JSON format compatible with IBM Cloud Private.

entry.name: format_logtarget_descr_538
entry.text: Selects the log format

entry.name: local_address_logtarget_help_539
entry.text:
Configure the IP address used as the local source address when originating logging messages for SMTP and syslog-based log targets. By default, the address is selected based on the interface that is the best route to the remote server. ip-address This must be the IP address of one of the Ethernet interfaces on the system, or "0.0.0.0" to default to any interface.
For example:
type smtp remote-address 10.120.9.9 local-address 10.2.4.1 Use the local interface address of 10.2.4.1 as the source address for opening TCP connections to the SMTP server at 10.120.9.9.

entry.name: local_address_logtarget_descr_539
entry.text: Specifies source IP address

entry.name: connect_timeout_logtarget_help_540
entry.text:
Sets the number of seconds to wait to establish a connection to the server before generating an error message. Enter a value in the range 1 - 90. The default value is 60.
After generating the log message, the DataPower Gateway attempts to establish the connection again.

entry.name: connect_timeout_logtarget_descr_540
entry.text: Sets the timeout for establishing a connection

entry.name: idle_timeout_logtarget_help_541
entry.text: Sets the number of seconds to wait before closing an established, but inactive, connection to the server. Enter a value in the range 1 - 600. The default value is 15. Attention: If multiple log targets have the following configuration, they might share connections. The same local address and port The same remote address and port Because of potential connection-sharing, set the same idle timeout value for these log targets.

entry.name: idle_timeout_logtarget_descr_541
entry.text: Sets the idle timeout

entry.name: active_timeout_logtarget_help_542
entry.text: Sets the number of seconds to wait before closing an established and active connection to the server. Enter a value in the range 0 - 60. The default value of 0 allows the log target to most efficiently send messages to the server by maintaining a healthy connection indefinitely. Attention: If multiple log targets have the following configuration, they might share connections. The same local address and port The same remote address and port Because of potential connection-sharing, set the same active timeout value for these log targets.

entry.name: active_timeout_logtarget_descr_542
entry.text: Sets the active timeout

entry.name: retry_interval_logtarget_help_543
entry.text:
Specify the time interval (in seconds) between attempts to retry the failed connections to a remote host.
intervalSeconds is an integer that specifies the number of seconds to wait before attempting to re-establish a failed connection to the syslog server. Enter a value in the range 1 - 600. The default value is 1.
For example: retry-interval 2 specifies a retry interval of 2 seconds.

entry.name: retry_interval_logtarget_descr_543
entry.text: Specify the number of seconds to wait before attempting to reestablish a failed connection to the syslog server.

entry.name: retry_attempts_logtarget_help_544
entry.text:
The number of attempts to retry the failed connections to the syslog server. After the number of attempts is reached, 'long-retry-interval' will be used instead. When the long interval is disabled, the log target repeatedly attempts to reconnect to the syslog server with the value set by 'retry-interval'.
attempts is an integer that specifies the number of attempts to retry the failed connections. The default value is 0.
0 (zero) would mean the 'long-retry-interval' will not be used and will retry forever using 'retry-interval'.
For example: retry-attempts 10 set the number of retry attempt to 10

entry.name: retry_attempts_logtarget_descr_544
entry.text: The number of attempts for a failed connection to the syslog server.

entry.name: long_retry_interval_logtarget_help_545
entry.text:
The time to wait before attempting to reestablish a failed connection to the syslog server after the number of attempts is reached.
The 'long-retry-interval' must be greater than the 'retry-interval' or it will take no effect.
intervalSeconds is an integer that specifies the number of seconds to wait before attempting to re-establish a failed connection. Enter an integer of 0 - 600 seconds. The default value is 20.
For example: long-retry-interval 50 Specifies a long retry interval of 50 seconds.

entry.name: long_retry_interval_logtarget_descr_545
entry.text: The time to wait before attempting to reestablish a failed connection to the syslog server after the number of failed attempts is reached.

entry.name: priority_logtarget_help_546
entry.text: Indicates the assigned priority for log target event flushing. When resources are in high demand, specifying "high" as the priority increases the processing capacity of the log target but might negatively effect the throughput of the DataPower Gateway. low -- Receives below normal priority. normal -- (Default) Receives normal priority. high -- Receives above normal priority.

entry.name: priority_logtarget_descr_546
entry.text: Assigns the logging priority

entry.name: local_file_logtarget_help_547
entry.text:
Used only when the logging "type" is "file", identifies the file target for logging events. local-url The target file, in the form "logstore:file-name". Must be in logstore: or logtemp: directory.
For example:
local-file logstore:///CryptoLog specifies the log file as CryptoLog in the logstore folder. local-file logtemp:://subdir/newLog specified the log file newLog in the subdir directory of the logtemp: folder.

entry.name: local_file_logtarget_descr_547
entry.text: Specifies the log file location

entry.name: local_ident_logtarget_help_548
entry.text:
Specifies a descriptive string to include in log messages to the remote target that identifies the source. Relevant only with SMTP or syslog-based target with a format of CBE. In syslog-based messages, this string is sent in the "hostname" header. local-id String to include in the log message. Should not include any spaces for syslog destinations.
For example:
type syslog local-ident server3.BigComanpany.com Includes server3.BigCompany.com as the hostname in syslog messages.

entry.name: local_ident_logtarget_descr_548
entry.text: Specifies local system identifier

entry.name: nfs_file_logtarget_help_549
entry.text:
Specifies the path to the log file on the NFS server, relative to the path of the nfs-static-mount specified by the nfs-static-mount parameter.
For example:
nfs-file logdir/remote.log Use the path logdir/remote.log relative to the NFS mount point as the log file.

entry.name: nfs_file_logtarget_descr_549
entry.text: Specifies NFS log file path

entry.name: nfs_static_mount_logtarget_help_550
entry.text:
Specifies the name of the nfs-static-mount configuration object to write log files to the NFS server.
For example:
nfs-static-mount log Use the nfs-static-mount configuration object named log as the NFS mount to write this log target to.

entry.name: nfs_static_mount_logtarget_descr_550
entry.text: Specifies NFS static mount to use

entry.name: object_logtarget_help_551
entry.text:
Add filter to allow log messages generated by a particular instance of a configuration object to be logged to this target. obj-class The class of configuration object that should be added. obj-name The name of a particular instance of the class of configuration object that should be added. No object-name means all instances.
For example:
object xmlfirewall fw1 object xmlfirewall fw2 Include logging events from the xmlfirewall objects named fw1 and fw2.

entry.name: object_logtarget_descr_551
entry.text: Adds configuration object to the current log

entry.name: rate_limit_logtarget_help_552
entry.text:
Set the maximum number of events to be logged per second. Enter a value in the range 1 - 1000. The default value is 100.
Remote log targets might receive more than this number of events within a second, depending on network latency and buffering. syslog over TCP log targets are exclusive, because only a single TCP connection is made to the server.
Note: In the case of syslog over TCP log targets, the rate limit is the maximum number of events transmitted over the connection within one second. A value of 0 disables rate-limiting by the log target.
events/second The maximum number of events to be logged per second. Enter a value in the range 1 - 1000. The default value is 100.
For example:
rate-limit 10 Specifies a maximum of 10 events per second.

entry.name: rate_limit_logtarget_descr_552
entry.text: Specifies the maximum number of events logged

entry.name: remote_address_logtarget_help_553
entry.text:
Specifies the host name or IP address of a remote host (syslog host, SMTP server, or the host that accepts SCP or SFTP connections). Required when the log type is SMTP or syslog-based or when the log type is file with an archive method of upload.
You can use TLS to establish a secure connection to a remote server by setting the remote-address and remote-port values to the values on which an TLS Proxy service is listening. The TLS Proxy service can then forward the log entries over TLS to the remote server.
host The host name or IP address of the remote server. port The UDP and TCP listening port on the remote server. - For SMTP and syslog over TCP, the default value is 25. - For syslog over UDP, the default value is 514.

entry.name: remote_address_logtarget_descr_553
entry.text: Specifies a remote address

entry.name: remote_directory_logtarget_help_554
entry.text:
Specifies the remote directory where uploaded logs are stored. This command is used only when the log type is "file" and the archive-mode is "upload". If the path is preceded with a forward slash (/ for SCP and SFTP) or an encoded forward slash (%%2F for FTP), an absolute path from the root directory is assumed. If the path does not begin with a forward slash or encoded forward slash, a path that is relative to the user's login directory is assumed. dir-path is a string that identifies the remote directory that stores uploaded log files.
For example:
type file archive-mode upload upload-method ftp remote-address 172.16.100.1 remote-port 2123 remote-directory %%2Flogs/ specifies the recipient address and remote directory for an uploaded log file.

entry.name: remote_directory_logtarget_descr_554
entry.text: Specifies the directory for uploaded logs

entry.name: remote_login_logtarget_help_555
entry.text:
Specifies the user name and password to use when uploading a log file to a remote device. This command is used only when the log type is "file" and the archive-mode is "upload". If a password is not specified, it will be prompted for. username is the username used to access a recipient of uploaded logs.
password is the password associated with the username account.
For example:
type file archive-mode upload upload-method ftp remote-address 172.16.100.1 remote-login jrb brj remote-directory logs specifies the method, recipient address, user name and password, and remote directory for an uploaded log file.

entry.name: remote_login_logtarget_descr_555
entry.text: Specifies the user name to use when uploading files

entry.name: remote_port_logtarget_help_556
entry.text:
Specifies the listening port on the remote server when the log type is SMTP or syslog-based. Used with the remote-address command to define the destination of transmitted log messages.
port Sets the UDP or TCP listening port. The default value is 514.

entry.name: remote_port_logtarget_descr_556
entry.text: Specifies a listening port on a remote server.

entry.name: rotate_logtarget_help_557
entry.text:
Used only when the logging type is file, optionally specifies how many prior copies of the log file are kept when rotating. number-of-rotations Number of prior copies of the log file to keep, in addition to the current one. The default value is 3.
For example:
rotate 2 specifies 2 rotations of the log file. Assuming a file name of CryptoLog, the log may consist of up to 3 files, CryptoLog (the current log file), CryptoLog.1 (the most recent), and CryptoLog.2 (the oldest log file).

entry.name: rotate_logtarget_descr_557
entry.text: Specifies the number of log rotations

entry.name: sender_address_logtarget_help_558
entry.text:
Specifies the "from" e-mail address to use when the log type is "smtp".
string is a string that specifies the local e-mail address.
For example:
sender-address X@company.com assigns a local e-mail address.

entry.name: sender_address_logtarget_descr_558
entry.text: Specifies the e-mail address for sending logs

entry.name: size_logtarget_help_559
entry.text:
Used only when the logging type is file or cache, optionally specifies the maximum size of the log. If the log type is file, size is specified in terms of kBytes If the log type is cache, size is specified in terms of events. log-size maximum log size. Enter a value in the range 100 - 50000.
For example:
size 1000 if the log type is file, specifies a maximum size of 1000 kBytes at which point the log file rotates. if the log type is cache, specifies a maximum size of 1000 events at which point the log cache overwrites on a FIFO basis.

entry.name: size_logtarget_descr_559
entry.text: Specifies the log's maximum size

entry.name: smtp_domain_logtarget_help_560
entry.text:
Specifies the fully qualified domain name of the SMTP client. This command is used only if the log type is SMTP, or if the log type is "file" and the archive method is "smtp".
The information provided by smtp-domain is included in the SMTP HELO message.
domainName identifies the fully qualified domain name for the SMTP client.
For example:
type smtp smtp-domain testXA.datapower.com specifies the SMTP domain.

entry.name: smtp_domain_logtarget_descr_560
entry.text: Specifies the domain for the SMTP client

entry.name: soap_version_logtarget_help_561
entry.text:
When the log type is "soap", specifies the version of SOAP for use by SOAP log targets.
soap11 (Default) SOAP targets use SOAP 1.1. soap12 SOAP targets use SOAP 1.2.

entry.name: soap_version_logtarget_descr_561
entry.text: Specifies the version of SOAP to use.

entry.name: suppression_period_logtarget_help_562
entry.text:
Specifies the interval to suppress identical events.
interval The interval, in seconds, to suppress identical event. The default is 10.

entry.name: suppression_period_logtarget_descr_562
entry.text: Interval to suppress identical events.

entry.name: ssl_logtarget_help_563
entry.text:
The TLS proxy profile is deprecated. Use a TLS client profile. Specifies the TLS Proxy Profile to use if logging is over SSL. Applies only when "type" is "soap" or "syslog-tcp", and "url" starts with "https://". name The name of the TLS Proxy Profile to assign.
For example:
type soap ssl-client-type proxy url https://ragnarok.datapower.com/logs ssl soap-log-profile Use the soap-log-profile to send SOAP log messages over HTTPS to ragnarok.datapower.com/logs.

entry.name: ssl_logtarget_descr_563
entry.text: Deprecated - Specifies the TLS Proxy Profile.

entry.name: ssl_client_logtarget_help_564
entry.text:
Specifies the TLS client profile if logging is over SSL. Applies only when "type" is "soap" or "syslog-tcp", and "url" starts with "https://". sslClientProfile The name of the ssl-client configuration section giving the TLS Client Profile to use.
For example:
type syslog-tcp ssl-client-type client url https://ragnarok.datapower.com/logs ssl-client tcp-log-profile Use the tcp-log-profile TLS client profile to send TCP log messages over HTTPS to ragnarok.datapower.com/logs.

entry.name: ssl_client_logtarget_descr_564
entry.text: Specifies the TLS client profile.

entry.name: ssl_client_type_logtarget_help_565
entry.text:
Specifies the type of TLS profile to use . Use 'proxy' for TLS proxy profile, and use 'client' for TLS client profile. Default is 'proxy'.
For example:
ssl-client-type client uses a TLS client profile.

entry.name: ssl_client_type_logtarget_descr_565
entry.text: Specifies the TLS profile type.

entry.name: ssl_client_type_logtarget_help_566
entry.text:
Specifies the type of TLS profile to use. Use 'client' for TLS client profile, which is the default value.
For example:
ssl-client-type client uses a TLS client profile.

entry.name: ssl_client_type_logtarget_descr_566
entry.text: Specifies the TLS profile type.

entry.name: timestamp_logtarget_help_567
entry.text:
Sets the timestamp format when "type" is not "snmp" or for a syslog server.
numeric Uses a numeric timestamp. This setting is the default value. syslog Uses the syslog-style timestamp. zulu Milliseconds are used as the timestamp format in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC) in log messages yyyymmddThhmmss+oo:oo.

entry.name: timestamp_logtarget_descr_567
entry.text: Sets the timestamp format

entry.name: type_logtarget_help_568
entry.text:
The model of this logging target.
console events output to screen cache events saved to memory syslog events transmitted to a remote syslog daemon over UDP syslog-tcp events transmitted to a remote syslog daemon over TCP smtp events transmitted to an SMTP recipient file events written to file in local filestore nfs events written to file on remote NFS mount soap events transmitted as SOAP messages to a specified recipient snmp events transmitted as SNMP traps or notifications to all configured SNMP trap and notification destinations
For example:
type syslog Send events to a remote syslog server over UDP.

entry.name: type_logtarget_descr_568
entry.text: Specifies the logging model

entry.name: precision_logtarget_help_569
entry.text:
The precision of the timestamp for this log target.
second Write log entries with one second precision. Fractional seconds are not shown in the timestamp. microsecond Write log entries with microsecond precision. Six digits of subsecond precision are shown in the timestamp.

entry.name: precision_logtarget_descr_569
entry.text: Specifies the precision of the log timestamp

entry.name: upload_method_logtarget_help_570
entry.text:
Specifies the protocol to upload a file-based log. ftp Use File Transfer Protocol (FTP). scp (deprecated) Use the Secure Copy (SSH) protocol. sftp Use the Secure File Transfer (SSH) protocol. smtp Use the Simple Mail Transfer protocol.
Note: If you use SCP to upload multiple log targets at the same time, a system error might occur. The DataPower Gateway supports only one SCP connection at a time. To minimize the risk when using SCP, configure the log targets with different settings, such as different event subscriptions and different log sizes.
For example:
upload-method smtp Specifies that the file-based log is uploaded to a remote storage device over SMTP

entry.name: upload_method_logtarget_descr_570
entry.text: Specifies the upload protocol

entry.name: url_logtarget_help_571
entry.text:
Specifies the URL to which SOAP-based log entries are posted. This command is used only when the log type is "soap".
postURL The destination to which SOAP-based logs entries are sent.
For example:
type soap url http://ragnarok.datapower.com/logs specifies the recipient of SOAP log messages.

entry.name: url_logtarget_descr_571
entry.text: Specifies the URL for SOAP log messages

entry.name: combine_with_or_matching_help_572
entry.text:
When enabled (on), multiple match conditions are ORed together meaning that the match succeeds if any single match condition is true; when disabled (off, the default), multiple match conditions are ANDed together meaning that the match succeeds only if all match conditions are true. For example:
combine-with-or on specifies that only a single match condition need be true for the match to succeed.
combine-with-or off specifies that all match conditions must be true for the match to succeed, thus restoring the default state.
Alternatively
combine-with-or specifies that only a single match condition need be true for the match to succeed.
specifies that all match conditions must be true for the match to succeed, thus restoring the default state.

entry.name: combine_with_or_matching_descr_572
entry.text: OR multiple match conditions.

entry.name: errorcode_matching_help_573
entry.text:
Adds a "shell-style" regular expression to be used to match error codes to a match template
matchPattern A shell-style match pattern that defines the error code set subject to this Matching Rule.
For example:
matching allErrors error-code * enters Matching Rule Configuration Mode, creates the allErrors matching rule, and adds a "universal" error code match pattern to allErrors. The match succeeds for all error codes.

entry.name: errorcode_matching_descr_573
entry.text: Adds an error code match pattern to the template.

entry.name: fullurlmatch_matching_help_574
entry.text:
Adds a URL match that starts with the protocol. The pattern is evaluated against the full URL. Use the match-with-pcre command to indicate whether the pattern is a shell-style expression or a PCRE.
match-pattern The expression that defines the URL to match against.
For example:
fullurlmatch http://www.example.com/products/* Adds an expression to match against documents.

entry.name: fullurlmatch_matching_descr_574
entry.text: Adds a URL match that starts with the protocol.

entry.name: hostmatch_matching_help_575
entry.text: This command is deprecated. Instead, use the httpmatch command with the combine-with-or command. A matching command that matches against the host and port in a URL. The match occurs against the HTTP host header, which is the way that HTTP/1.1 does virtual hosting.

entry.name: hostmatch_matching_descr_575
entry.text: Specifies a match against the URL host and port - Deprecated

entry.name: httpmatch_matching_help_576
entry.text:
Adds a shell-style match pattern to the current match template. The match pattern is used to evaluate the contents of a specific HTTP header field. header-tag identifies a specific HTTP header field, as defined in RFC 2616. match-pattern A regular expression the defines the contents of the target HTTP header field.
For example:
httpmatch User-Agent *Moz* adds an HTTP match pattern to the current match template -- matching Mozilla in the User-Agent field of any HTTP header

entry.name: httpmatch_matching_descr_576
entry.text: Adds an HTTP match pattern to a template

entry.name: no_match_matching_help_577
entry.text: Removes all match patterns from the current match template.

entry.name: no_match_matching_descr_577
entry.text: Clears the current match template

entry.name: match_with_pcre_matching_help_578
entry.text:
When enabled (on) use PCRE to define match conditions. When disabled (off, the default value) use shell-style expressions to define match conditions. This setting does not apply to XPath or HTTP method evaluations.
For example:
match-with-pcre on Use PCRE to define match conditions.
match-with-pcre off Use shell-style expressions to define match conditions.

entry.name: match_with_pcre_matching_descr_578
entry.text: Enable PCRE match expressions.

entry.name: urlmatch_matching_help_579
entry.text:
Adds a URL match for only the path, which excludes the protocol, host, port, user, and password. In other words, only the URI. The pattern is evaluated against only the path of the URL. Use the match-with-pcre command to indicate whether the pattern is a shell-style expression or a PCRE.
match-pattern The expression that defines the URL to match against.
For example:
urlmatch products/* Adds an expression to match against documents.

entry.name: urlmatch_matching_descr_579
entry.text: Adds a URL match for only the path.

entry.name: xpathmatch_matching_help_580
entry.text:
Adds a XPath expression to a match template.
xpathExpression An XPath Expression that defines the document set subject to this Matching Rule.
For example:
matching xpath xpathmatch @destination enters Matching Rule Configuration Mode, creates the xpath Matching Rule, and adds an XPath expression to xpath. The match succeeds for attributes named destination.

entry.name: xpathmatch_matching_descr_580
entry.text: Adds a XPath expression to a match template.

entry.name: methodmatch_matching_help_581
entry.text:
Adds an HTTP method type to a match template.
method is a supported HTTP request method. Valid methods are GET, POST, PUT, DELETE, HEAD, TRACE, OPTIONS, and custom. The method type is added to this Matching Rule.
customMethod is a valid HTTP request method. Valid methods are those defined by the 'extension-method' in RFC 2616 Section 5.1.1. The method type is added to this Matching Rule.
For example:
matching request methodmatch PUT Enters Matching Rule Configuration Mode, creates the 'request' Matching Rule, and adds the PUT method to it. The match succeeds for HTTP PUT requests.

entry.name: methodmatch_matching_descr_581
entry.text: Adds an HTTP method type to a match template.

entry.name: mcfilters_kglobalconfig_help_582
entry.text: Enters Message Content Filter Configuration Mode

entry.name: mcfilters_kglobalconfig_descr_582
entry.text: Enters Message Content Filter Configuration Mode

entry.name: http_mcfilter_messagecontentfilters_help_583
entry.text: Used to specify a message content filter of type HTTP. The filter matches if the HTTP header field of the incoming message has the specified value.

entry.name: http_mcfilter_messagecontentfilters_descr_583
entry.text: Used to specify an http header name and required value.

entry.name: xpath_mcfilter_messagecontentfilters_help_584
entry.text: Used to specify a message content filter of type XPATH. The filter matches if the XPath expression of the incoming message evaluates to the specified value.

entry.name: xpath_mcfilter_messagecontentfilters_descr_584
entry.text: Used to specify an xpath expression and required value.

entry.name: mcfilters_kglobalconfig_help_585
entry.text: Enters Message Content Filter Configuration Mode

entry.name: mcfilters_kglobalconfig_descr_585
entry.text: Enters Message Content Filter Configuration Mode

entry.name: http_mcfilter_messagecontentfilters_help_586
entry.text: Used to specify a message content filter of type HTTP. The filter matches if the HTTP header field of the incoming message has the specified value. This filter type is deprecated. Define a mcf-httpheader object and reference it with the filter command.

entry.name: http_mcfilter_messagecontentfilters_descr_586
entry.text: Used to specify an http header name and required value (deprecated).

entry.name: xpath_mcfilter_messagecontentfilters_help_587
entry.text: Used to specify a message content filter of type XPATH. The filter matches if the XPath expression of the incoming message evaluates to the specified value. This filter type is deprecated. Define a mcf-xpath object and reference it with the filter command.

entry.name: xpath_mcfilter_messagecontentfilters_descr_587
entry.text: Used to specify an XPath expression and required value (deprecated).

entry.name: filter_messagecontentfilters_help_588
entry.text: Specifies the name of an existing message content filter.

entry.name: filter_messagecontentfilters_descr_588
entry.text: Used to specify the name of an existing message content filter.

entry.name: mcf_httpheader_kglobalconfig_help_589
entry.text: Message content filter based on HTTP header.

entry.name: mcf_httpheader_kglobalconfig_descr_589
entry.text: Message content filter based on HTTP header

entry.name: location_mcfhttpheader_help_590
entry.text: The name of the HTTP header field to match.

entry.name: location_mcfhttpheader_descr_590
entry.text: For mcf-httpheader, the name of the HTTP header field.

entry.name: value_mcfhttpheader_help_591
entry.text: The value of the HTTP header field to match.

entry.name: value_mcfhttpheader_descr_591
entry.text: For mcf-httpheader, the value to be matched.

entry.name: mcf_httpmethod_kglobalconfig_help_592
entry.text: Message content filter based on the HTTP method type.

entry.name: mcf_httpmethod_kglobalconfig_descr_592
entry.text: Message content filter based on HTTP method type

entry.name: value_mcfhttpmethod_help_593
entry.text: The HTTP method (GET,PUT,POST) to match.

entry.name: value_mcfhttpmethod_descr_593
entry.text: For mcf-httpmethod, the method name (GET,PUT,POST).

entry.name: mcf_customrule_kglobalconfig_help_594
entry.text: Specify a name for the custom message content filter that invokes a processing rule to retrieve the match value.

entry.name: mcf_customrule_kglobalconfig_descr_594
entry.text: Message content filter that invokes a processing rule

entry.name: value_mcfcustomrule_help_595
entry.text: Specify the value that must match the return value from the processing rule. Specify either a string that must match the outcome of the rule or an asterisk (*) to match any value in the context variable. When the value is a string, an identical, literal string comparison result is a match. When the value is an asterisk, any value other than null or an empty string results in a match.

entry.name: value_mcfcustomrule_descr_595
entry.text: For a mcf-customrule, the value to match

entry.name: rulename_mcfcustomrule_help_596
entry.text: Specify the name of the processing rule to invoke that retrieves the match value.

entry.name: rulename_mcfcustomrule_descr_596
entry.text: For a mcf-customrule, the processing rule

entry.name: mcf_httpurl_kglobalconfig_help_597
entry.text: Message content filter based on the HTTP URL.

entry.name: mcf_httpurl_kglobalconfig_descr_597
entry.text: Message content filter based on HTTP URL content

entry.name: value_mcfhttpurl_help_598
entry.text: The URL value to match.

entry.name: value_mcfhttpurl_descr_598
entry.text: For mcf-httpurl, the URL to match.

entry.name: mcf_xpath_kglobalconfig_help_599
entry.text: Message content filter based on message data identified with an XPath specification.

entry.name: mcf_xpath_kglobalconfig_descr_599
entry.text: Message content filter based on data found in the message

entry.name: location_mcfxpath_help_600
entry.text: The XPATH expression used to specify the data to be matched.

entry.name: location_mcfxpath_descr_600
entry.text: For mcf-xpath, the XPath expression to locate data for matching.

entry.name: value_mcfxpath_help_601
entry.text: The data value to be matched.

entry.name: value_mcfxpath_descr_601
entry.text: For mcf-xpath, the data to match.

entry.name: distinct_sources_countmonitor_help_602
entry.text:
Determines the number of distinct sources, or user identities, tracked by the limiter.
sourceNumber is the number of distinct sources tracked by this limiter. The default value is 10000. For example:
distinct-source 12000 increases the number of distinct source that are tracked to 12000.

entry.name: distinct_sources_countmonitor_descr_602
entry.text: Sets the number of distinct source to track.

entry.name: filter_countmonitor_help_603
entry.text:
Specifies threshold values and a control procedure to implement should the threshold value(s) be exceeded. name is the name of the incremental monitor filter. interval specifies the measurement interval in milliseconds. threshold is an integer that specifies the threshold value, exceeding this value triggers the specified control-procedure.
burst-threshold is an integer that specifies an acceptable traffic burst, and should be set to approximately twice the threshold value. control-procedure is the name of a control procedure previously created with the monitor-action command; this control procedure is triggered if the threshold value(s) is exceeded. For example:
monitor-count Squelch message-type Extranet filter Filter1 1000 50 100 Squelch defines the Squelch incremental monitor. If the Extranet message class exceeds 50 client requests (the default counter) per second, implement the Squelch control procedure.

entry.name: filter_countmonitor_descr_603
entry.text: Associates a threshold with a control procedure

entry.name: header_countmonitor_help_604
entry.text:
Meaningful only if the source command is set to ip-from-header, specifies that the source address monitoring and information gathering is individualized for all IP addresses within the address range. IP addresses are extracted from the HTTP header specified by this command. httpHeaderField is the name of the HTTP header field that contains the IP monitored by this Message-Count monitor.
For example:
header X-Client-IP specifies the IP address source.

entry.name: header_countmonitor_descr_604
entry.text: Assigns a URL map to a URL Refresh Policy

entry.name: measure_countmonitor_help_605
entry.text:
Specifies how the monitor counter is incremented. requests specifies that the monitor counter is incremented by a client request from the target message class. responses specifies that the monitor counter is incremented by a server response from the target message class. xpath specifies that the monitor counter is incremented via XSLT. If incrementing the counter via XSLT, use the DataPower increment-integer( ) extension function to increment monitor counts. By default, the monitor counter is incremented by a client request from the target message class. For example:
monitor-count Squelch message-type Extranet measure responses specifies that the Squelch incremental monitor is incremented by server responses from the Extranet message class.

entry.name: measure_countmonitor_descr_605
entry.text: Specifies how the monitor counter is incremented

entry.name: message_type_countmonitor_help_606
entry.text:
Specifies the target message class for an incremental monitor. name The message class. For example:
monitor-count Squelch message-type Extranet designates the Extranet message class as the target for the Squelch incremental monitor

entry.name: message_type_countmonitor_descr_606
entry.text: Specifies a target message class

entry.name: source_countmonitor_help_607
entry.text:
Enables IP address-specific monitoring and information gathering.
all Specifies that IP source address monitoring and information gathering is aggregated for the address range. This keyword is the default value. ip-each Specifies that IP source address monitoring and information gathering is individualized for all IP addresses in the range. ip-from-header Specifies that IP source address monitoring and information gathering is individualized for all IP addresses in the range. IP addresses are determined by the value of the HTTP header that is defined with the header command.

entry.name: source_countmonitor_descr_607
entry.text: Enables IP address-specific monitoring

entry.name: filter_durationmonitor_help_608
entry.text:
Specifies a threshold value and a control procedure to implement should the threshold value be exceeded. name is the name of the duration monitor filter. average is a required keyword. threshold is an integer that specifies the threshold processing interval in milliseconds; exceeding this value triggers the specified control procedure. control-procedure is the name of a control procedure previously created with the monitor-action command; this control procedure is triggered if the threshold value is exceeded. For example:
monitor-duration RateLimit-1 message-type Extranet measure server filter Filter3 average 500 Yell defines the RateLimit1 duration message monitor. If the average server processing time of the Extranet message class exceeds 500 milliseconds, implement the Yell control procedure.

entry.name: filter_durationmonitor_descr_608
entry.text: Associates a threshold with a control procedure

entry.name: measure_durationmonitor_help_609
entry.text:
Specifies the transaction type of interest to the duration monitor. messages specifies the time interval between the receipt of a client request and the transmission of the associated server response. requests specifies the time spent by the X-Series device in processing a client request, that is the interval between the receipt of a client request and its transmission to the target server. responses specifies the time spent by the X-Series device in processing a server response, that is the interval between the receipt of a server response and its transmission to the target client. server specifies the server processing time, that is the interval between the transmission of a client request to the server and the receipt of the associated server response. For example:
monitor-duration RateLimit1 message-type Extranet measure messages specifies that the RateLimit1 duration monitor gathers data on messages type transactions

entry.name: measure_durationmonitor_descr_609
entry.text: Specifies a transaction type

entry.name: message_type_durationmonitor_help_610
entry.text:
Specifies the target message class for a duration monitor. name The target message class. For example:
monitor-duration RateLimit-1 message-type Extranet designates the Extranet message class as the target for the RateLimit1 duration monitor

entry.name: message_type_durationmonitor_descr_610
entry.text: Specifies a target message class

entry.name: block_interval_filteraction_help_611
entry.text:
Sets the duration in milliseconds during which an over-threshold message is denied service. This command is meaningful only when the message is rejected due to policy or shaping queue overflow.
duration Specifies the duration in milliseconds. The default value is 0, which indicates that over-threshold messages are dropped but no service denial penalty is imposed.
For example:
monitor-action BufferThenReject type buffer log-priority warn block-interval 5000 Create the BufferThenReject control procedure to buffer messages and add a log event at warn priority. When the buffer is full, reject messages for 5 seconds.

entry.name: block_interval_filteraction_descr_611
entry.text: Sets the duration to deny service

entry.name: log_priority_filteraction_help_612
entry.text:
Sets the priority of the log event when a control procedure is triggered. Use one of the keywords to specify the log level.
For example:
monitor-action Log type notify log-priority notice Create the Log control procedure to add a log event at notify priority and take no further action.

entry.name: log_priority_filteraction_descr_612
entry.text: Sets the priority of the log event

entry.name: type_filteraction_help_613
entry.text:
Sets the control procedure to trigger when a monitored message type exceeds its threshold value.
notify Adds a log entry at the specified priority. This setting is the default value. reject Rejects messages for the specified duration and adds a log entry at the specified priority. shape Buffers and processes messages at a rate that is less than the threshold and adds a log entry at the specified priority. When the buffer is full, messages are rejected for the specified duration.
For example:
monitor-action BufferThenReject type buffer log-priority info block-interval 5000 Create the BufferThenReject control procedure to buffer messages and add a log event at warn priority. When the buffer is full, reject messages for 5 seconds.

entry.name: type_filteraction_descr_613
entry.text: Sets the control procedure to trigger

entry.name: address_sshserversourceprotocolhandler_help_614
entry.text:
Assigns an IP address to the SFTP Server. This is the local device address that the server monitors for incoming SFTP connections. ipAddress The local IP address monitored by this SFTP server. The wildcard IP address "0" indicates that the SFTP server monitors all active device addresses. For example:
address 192.168.1.1 specifies a local address of 192.168.1.1

entry.name: address_sshserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_614
entry.text: Assigns an IP address to the SFTP server

entry.name: port_sshserversourceprotocolhandler_help_615
entry.text:
Assigns a port number to the SFTP Server. This port number, in conjunction with the IP address specified by the address command, identifies the address:port monitored by this handler for incoming SFTP connections. portNumber (an integer within the range 1 through 65534, with a default value of 22) identifies the port monitored by this handler. For example:
port 10001 specifies port number 10001

entry.name: port_sshserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_615
entry.text: Assigns a TCP port to the SFTP server

entry.name: acl_sshserversourceprotocolhandler_help_616
entry.text:
Assigns a named Access Control List (ACL) to this SFTP Server. Only those IP addresses explicitly granted access by the assigned ACL are able to access this SFTP Server. aclName The ACL to be assigned to the SFTP Server. For example:
acl restrictiveACL-1 assigns the ACL named restrictiveACL-1 to this SFTP Server

entry.name: acl_sshserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_616
entry.text: Assign an ACL to SFTP Server

entry.name: host_private_key_sshserversourceprotocolhandler_help_617
entry.text:
Specifies a private host key used by the SFTP Server during Host Authentication.
keyName identifies the crypto key object used for SSH keys.
For example:
host-private-keys sshRSAKey associates the sshRSAKey crypto key object with the current SFTP Server.

entry.name: host_private_key_sshserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_617
entry.text: Specifies the key to use for Host Authentication.

entry.name: user_auth_sshserversourceprotocolhandler_help_618
entry.text:
Specifies which SSH user authentication methods are allowed for client authentication. The default is publickey+password. Authentication can be one or more types (multiple types separated by '+' character): publickey - SSH public key user authentication password - SSH password user authentication For example:
user-auth password Allows password authentication and disallows public key authentication

entry.name: user_auth_sshserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_618
entry.text: Specify allowable SSH user authentication methods

entry.name: allow_backend_listings_sshserversourceprotocolhandler_help_619
entry.text:
Determines whether or not backend directory listings are allowed. The default is on. on Allow backend directory listings off Do not allow backend directory listings For example:
allow-backend-listings off Prohibit backend directory listings

entry.name: allow_backend_listings_sshserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_619
entry.text: Indicates whether backend directory listings are allowed

entry.name: allow_backend_delete_sshserversourceprotocolhandler_help_620
entry.text:
Determines whether or not backend delete requests are allowed. The default is off. on Allow backend delete requests off Do not allow backend delete requests For example:
allow-backend-delete on Enables backend delete request processing.

entry.name: allow_backend_delete_sshserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_620
entry.text: Indicates whether requests to delete files are allowed

entry.name: allow_backend_stat_sshserversourceprotocolhandler_help_621
entry.text:
Determines whether or not querying backend file statistics is allowed. The default is off. on Allow querying backend file statistics off Do not allow querying backend file statistics For example:
allow-backend-stat off Prohibit querying backend file statistics

entry.name: allow_backend_stat_sshserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_621
entry.text: Indicates whether requests to query file statistics are allowed

entry.name: allow_backend_read_sshserversourceprotocolhandler_help_622
entry.text:
Determines whether or not backend file reading is allowed. The default is on. on Allow backend file reading off Do not allow backend file reading For example:
allow-backend-read off Prohibit backend file reading

entry.name: allow_backend_read_sshserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_622
entry.text: Indicates whether requests to read files are allowed

entry.name: allow_backend_write_sshserversourceprotocolhandler_help_623
entry.text:
Determines whether or not backend file writing is allowed. The default is on. on Allow backend file writing off Do not allow backend file writing For example:
allow-backend-write off Prohibit backend file writing

entry.name: allow_backend_write_sshserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_623
entry.text: Indicates whether requests to write files are allowed

entry.name: allow_backend_mkdir_sshserversourceprotocolhandler_help_624
entry.text:
Determines whether or not backend directory creations are allowed. The default is off. on Allow backend directory creation off Do not allow backend directory creation For example:
allow-backend-mkdir off Prohibit backend directory creation

entry.name: allow_backend_mkdir_sshserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_624
entry.text: Indicates whether requests to create directories are allowed

entry.name: allow_backend_rmdir_sshserversourceprotocolhandler_help_625
entry.text:
Determines whether or not backend directory deletions are allowed. The default is off. on Allow backend directory deletions off Do not allow backend directory deletions For example:
allow-backend-rmdir off Prohibit backend directory deletions

entry.name: allow_backend_rmdir_sshserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_625
entry.text: Indicates whether requests to delete directories are allowed

entry.name: allow_backend_setstat_sshserversourceprotocolhandler_help_626
entry.text:
Determines whether or not setting statistics for files on the backend system is allowed. The default is off. on Allow setting statistics for files on the backend system off Do not allow setting statistics for files on the backend system For example:
allow-backend-setstat off Prohibit setting statistics for files on the backend system

entry.name: allow_backend_setstat_sshserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_626
entry.text: Indicates whether requests to set file statistics are allowed

entry.name: allow_backend_rename_sshserversourceprotocolhandler_help_627
entry.text:
Determines whether or not backend file renaming is allowed. The default is off. on Allow backend file renaming off Do not allow backend file renaming For example:
allow-backend-rename off Prohibit backend file renaming

entry.name: allow_backend_rename_sshserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_627
entry.text: Indicates whether requests to rename files are allowed

entry.name: allow_backend_symlink_sshserversourceprotocolhandler_help_628
entry.text:
Determines whether or not backend symbolic link creations are allowed. The default is off. on Allow backend symbolic link creations off Do not allow backend symbolic link creations For example:
allow-backend-symlink off Prohibit backend symbolic link creations

entry.name: allow_backend_symlink_sshserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_628
entry.text: Indicates whether requests to create symbolic links are allowed

entry.name: allow_backend_readlink_sshserversourceprotocolhandler_help_629
entry.text:
Determines whether or not reading symbolic links on the backend system is allowed. The default is off. on Allow reading symbolic links on the backend system off Do not allow reading symbolic links on the backend system For example:
allow-backend-readlink off Prohibit reading symbolic links on the backend system

entry.name: allow_backend_readlink_sshserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_629
entry.text: Indicates whether requests to read symbolic links are allowed

entry.name: aaa_policy_sshserversourceprotocolhandler_help_630
entry.text:
Does authentication of the information provided by the SFTP client, to decide whether the client user is who they say the are. policy The AAA Policy to use during SSH user authentication. For example:
aaa-policy sftp-public-key Selects the sftp-public-key AAA Policy to user during SSH user authentication.

entry.name: aaa_policy_sshserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_630
entry.text: AAA policy for SSH user authentication

entry.name: filesystem_sshserversourceprotocolhandler_help_631
entry.text:
Controls whether the SFTP server presents a virtual filestore, configured locally, or transparently shows the filesystem of the back-end of the Multi-Protocol Gateway. virtual-ephemeral A virtual filestore whose contents (other than configured directories) lasts only for the duration of one SFTP connection, and is private to that connection. virtual-persistent A virtual filestore whose contents survive from one SFTP connection to the next (of the same username). The filestore expires if there have been no connections and the persistent-filesystem-timeout expired. The filestore is shared by all SFTP connections to this SFTP server with the same username from SFTP authentication. transparent There is no pre-established filesystem, instead the filesystem of the back-end of the multi-protocol gateway can be seen. There is a default directory, and the working directory can be changed, but such changes are not verified against what is really present on the back end. The DataPower service must be configured with propagate-uri enabled for this to be a useful option. Only the FTP, SFTP, and HTTP back-ends make much sense for this option. For example:
filesystem virtual-persistent specifies a virtual filesystem that is persistent for each user

entry.name: filesystem_sshserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_631
entry.text: Type of filesystem SFTP server will present

entry.name: default_directory_sshserversourceprotocolhandler_help_632
entry.text:
Sets the default directory that will be the Current Working Directory for all users upon authentication at this SFTP server. If the filesystem-type is transparent, this can be any string starting with /. For example:
default-directory /here Establishes /here as the initial current working directory.

entry.name: default_directory_sshserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_632
entry.text: Set the default directory for SFTP clients

entry.name: idle_timeout_sshserversourceprotocolhandler_help_633
entry.text:
The number of seconds that the SFTP connection can be idle (no commands) until it times out and is closed by the server. The timeout does not apply when a data transfer is in progress. The default is 0, which disables the timeout. seconds Idle timeout in seconds. For example:
idle-timeout 120 Two minutes of inactivity will cause the SFTP connection to close.

entry.name: idle_timeout_sshserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_633
entry.text: Idle timeout for control connection

entry.name: persistent_filesystem_timeout_sshserversourceprotocolhandler_help_634
entry.text:
Specifies the duration in seconds that a connection to a virtual file system is retained after all SFTP connections from user identities are disconnected. When the timeout expires, the virtual file system object is destroyed. Enter any value of 1- 43200. The default is 600. For example:
persistent-filesystem-timeout 300 sets the timeout to 5 minutes.

entry.name: persistent_filesystem_timeout_sshserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_634
entry.text: Inactivity duration for a disconnected virtual persistent file system

entry.name: virtual_directory_sshserversourceprotocolhandler_help_635
entry.text:
In virtual mode, create a directory in the virtual file system that is presented by this SFTP server. The SFTP client can use all of these directories to write file to be processed. The root directory (/) is always present and cannot be created.
path The absolute path, starting with a /, and not ending in /, of a directory to place in the virtual filesystem. This path will be part of the URL for files written in this directory. For example:
virtual-directory /here virtual-directory /here/there Creates the virtual directories /here and /here/there.

entry.name: virtual_directory_sshserversourceprotocolhandler_descr_635
entry.text: Create directory in virtual filesystem

entry.name: http_header_messagematching_help_636
entry.text:
Adds an HTTP Header field and associated value to a traffic-flow definition. A traffic-flow definition may contain multiple HTTP header matches. All traffic whose HTTP header meets the match criteria is included in the traffic flow, and a candidate for administrative monitoring and control. http-header-field The target HTTP header field. regexp A shell-style regular expression that defines the contents of the target HTTP header field.
For example:
http-header from *businessParter.com Identifies From request-header fields containing businessPartner.com as part of the target traffic flow

entry.name: http_header_messagematching_descr_636
entry.text: Adds HTTP header match to include in a traffic-flow definition

entry.name: http_header_exclude_messagematching_help_637
entry.text:
Adds an HTTP Header field and associated value to a traffic-flow definition. A traffic-flow definition may contain multiple HTTP header matches. All traffic whose HTTP header meets the match criteria is excluded from the traffic flow, and not a candidate for administrative monitoring and control. http-header-field The target HTTP header field. regexp A shell-style regular expression that defines the contents of the target HTTP header field.
For example:
http-header-exclude from *businessParter.com Identifies From request-header fields containing businessPartner.com as excluded from the target traffic flow

entry.name: http_header_exclude_messagematching_descr_637
entry.text: Adds HTTP header match to exclude from a traffic-flow definition

entry.name: ip_messagematching_help_638
entry.text:
Adds a contiguous range of source IP addresses to a traffic- flow definition. A traffic-flow definition may contain a single included IP address range. All traffic sourced from the defined address range is a candidate for administrative monitoring and control. ip-address is a network IP address. prefix-length specifies the contiguous address range. For example:
ip 10.10.1.0/24 identifies all source IP addresses within the range 10.10.10.0 through 10.10.10.255 as part of the target traffic-flow

entry.name: ip_messagematching_descr_638
entry.text: Adds an IP address range to a traffic-flow definition

entry.name: ip_exclude_messagematching_help_639
entry.text:
Excludes a contiguous range of source IP addresses from a traffic- flow definition. A traffic-flow definition may contain a single excluded IP address range. ip-address is a network IP address. prefix-length specifies the contiguous address range. For example:
ip 10.10.1.0/24 ip-exclude 10.10.1.126/32 identifies all IP addresses within the range 10.10.10.0 through 10.10.10.255, with the exception of the host address 10.10.1.126, as part of the target traffic-flow.

entry.name: ip_exclude_messagematching_descr_639
entry.text: Excludes IP address range from a traffic-flow definition

entry.name: method_messagematching_help_640
entry.text:
Identifies an HTTP method type to be included in a traffic- flow definition. A traffic-flow definition may contain a single HTTP method match. Use one of the required keywords to specify the HTTP method. For example:
ip 10.10.1.0/24 method post identifies HTTP posts originating from the IP address range 10.10.10.0 through 10.10.10.255 as part of the target traffic-flow

entry.name: method_messagematching_descr_640
entry.text: Adds an HTTP method match to a traffic-flow definition

entry.name: request_url_messagematching_help_641
entry.text:
Specifies a requested URL or URL set to be included in the definition of the traffic flow. This definition can contain a single request-url command. In the absence of a request-url command, the target URL is not considered when evaluating an individual message against a traffic flow definition.
pattern A shell-style match pattern that defines the requested URL.
For example:
message-matching TFDef1 ip 10.10.1.0/24 request-url http://www.datapower.com/sub/*.xml Creates the TFDef1 traffic-flow definition, identifies that all requests for XML documents in the specified directory originating from the 10.10.1.0/24 IP address range as part of the target traffic flow.

entry.name: request_url_messagematching_descr_641
entry.text: Specifies a requested URL for the traffic flow.

entry.name: url_messagematching_help_642
entry.text:
Identifies a target URL included in a traffic-flow definition. A traffic-flow definition may contain a single target URL. All traffic whose target URL meets the match criteria is a candidate for administrative monitoring and control.
regexp The shell-style regular expression that defines the target URL(s).
For example:
ip 10.10.1.0/24 request-url http://www.datapower.com/device/*.xml Identifies all requests for XML documents in the specified directory originating from the IP address range 10.10.10.0 through 10.10.10.255 as part of the target traffic-flow

entry.name: url_messagematching_descr_642
entry.text: Adds a target URL to a traffic-flow definition

entry.name: message_matching_messagetype_help_643
entry.text:
Adds a named traffic-flow definition to a message class. A message class contains one or more traffic definitions, and identifies a traffic stream or streams that are subject to common administrative monitoring and control. name Identifies a traffic-flow definition added to the current message class. For example:
message-type Extranet message-matching TFDef1 message-matching TFDef2 Adds the traffic-flow definitions, TFDef1 and TFDef2, to the Extranet message class.

entry.name: message_matching_messagetype_descr_643
entry.text: Adds a traffic-flow definition to a message class

entry.name: ccsi_mqsourceprotocolhandler_help_644
entry.text:
Meaningful only when the IBM MQ Queue Manager object chosen by the queue-manager command has the Convert Input property set to on, the default. With this property on, the remote IBM MQ Queue Manager converts output data to ISO-8859-1 (latin-1), the default conversion. If you want the output data to be something other than latin-1, use this command to identify the output CCSI. ccsiID The default output encoding
For example:
ccsi 1209 specifies UTF-8 as the default output encoding.

entry.name: ccsi_mqsourceprotocolhandler_descr_644
entry.text: Specifies default output encoding

entry.name: concurrent_connections_mqsourceprotocolhandler_help_645
entry.text:
Sets a limit on the number of concurrent IBM MQ connections to allocate.
limit The number of concurrent connections. The minimum is 1. The default is 1.

entry.name: concurrent_connections_mqsourceprotocolhandler_descr_645
entry.text: Sets the number of concurrent IBM MQ connections

entry.name: content_type_header_mqsourceprotocolhandler_help_646
entry.text:
Specifies the header to extract the Content-Type with XPath expression.
None (Default) No header MQRFH The Content-Type of the MQRFH header. MQRFH2 The Content-Type of the MQRFH2 header.

entry.name: content_type_header_mqsourceprotocolhandler_descr_646
entry.text: Selects the header to extract with XPath expression

entry.name: content_type_xpath_mqsourceprotocolhandler_help_647
entry.text:
Specifies the XPath expression to extract the header.
XPath The XPath expression to extract.

entry.name: content_type_xpath_mqsourceprotocolhandler_descr_647
entry.text: Specifies the XPath expression

entry.name: exclude_headers_mqsourceprotocolhandler_help_648
entry.text:
Identifies the IBM MQ headers to remove from the message. When specifying multiple headers to remove, use a plus sign (+) as the separator.
header_value Identifies the headers to remove. Supports the following values: MQCIH CICS Bridge Header MQDLH Dead Letter Header MQIIH IMS Information Header MQRFH Rules and Formatting Header MQRFH2 Rules and Formatting Header MQWIH Working Information Header
For example:
exclude-headers MQRFH identifies that the MQRFH header is removed from the message before processing.
exclude-headers MQRFH+MQRFH2 identifies that the MQRFH and MQRFH2 headers are removed from the message before processing.

entry.name: exclude_headers_mqsourceprotocolhandler_descr_648
entry.text: Identifies the headers to remove.

entry.name: get_queue_mqsourceprotocolhandler_help_649
entry.text:
Specifies the IBM MQ GET queue, the queue used by IBM MQ Client Handler when retrieving messages from the associated IBM MQ manager. queueName The IBM MQ GET queue. For example:
get-queue GETSVCQ identifies GETSVCQ as the IBM MQ GET queue

entry.name: get_queue_mqsourceprotocolhandler_descr_649
entry.text: Specifies the IBM MQ GET queue

entry.name: get_message_options_mqsourceprotocolhandler_help_650
entry.text:
Sets the MQGET options.
MQGMO Is the cumulative value of the MQGET options that are applicable to messages in decimal or hex format. The value is passed directly to the IBM MQ API. The default value is 1, which is the decimal value for the MQGMO_WAIT option.
When a message is too big for a queue, an attempt to put the message on the queue fails. Segmentation is a technique that allows the queue manager or application to split the message into pieces, and place each segment on a queue as a separate physical message. The application that retrieves the message can handle the multiple segments one-by-one or can request that the queue manager reassembles the segments into a single message. The reassembly request is request is achieved by specifying the MQGMO_COMPLETE_MSG option (65536) on the MPQGET call, and by providing a buffer large enough to accommodate the entire message.
Note: Ensure that the associated IBM MQ queue manager supports the MQGMO_COMPLETE_MSG option. On z/OS, IBM MQ queue managers do not support message segmentation. On other operating systems, queue managers might not be configured to support segmentation.

entry.name: get_message_options_mqsourceprotocolhandler_descr_650
entry.text: Sets the MQGET options.

entry.name: selector_mqsourceprotocolhandler_help_651
entry.text:
Specify a selection string to filter the messages delivered to the DataPower Gateway from a queue or a subscription. A selector is a variable-length string, containing a SQL92 query. The selection is based on the message properties but not the payload. For example, a message selector "sport = 'football'" could be used to limit messages to those that have a message property named "sport" and of value "football".
sql-expression A SQL-like expression to filter messages delivered from a queue or a subscription. For example: selector "Qcode = \\"0x23A195\\"" or selector "car.year > 2000 AND car.color = 'RED'"

entry.name: selector_mqsourceprotocolhandler_descr_651
entry.text: Defines the selection string to filter the messages.

entry.name: publish_topic_string_mqsourceprotocolhandler_help_652
entry.text:
Specifies the PUBLISH TOPIC STRING, the topic string is used by IBM MQ Client Handler when passing messages to the subject on associated IBM MQ manager. If a put-queue is specified for the handler, the response is PUT to the put-queue and the publish-topic-string is ignored. publishTopicString The PUBLISH TOPIC STRING. For example:
publish-topic-string sport identifies sport as the PUBLISH TOPIC STRING

entry.name: publish_topic_string_mqsourceprotocolhandler_descr_652
entry.text: A topic string that used to specify the subject to publish to IBM MQ server.

entry.name: subscribe_topic_string_mqsourceprotocolhandler_help_653
entry.text:
Specifies the SUBSCRIBE TOPIC STRING, the topic string is used by IBM MQ Client Handler when retrieving messages from the subject on associated IBM MQ manager. If a get-queue is specified for the handler, the message is GET from the get-queue and the subscribe-topic-string is ignored. sublishTopicString The SUBSCRIBE TOPIC STRING. For example:
subscribe-topic-string sport identifies sport as the SUBSCRIBE TOPIC STRING

entry.name: subscribe_topic_string_mqsourceprotocolhandler_descr_653
entry.text: A topic string that used to specify the subject to subscribe from IBM MQ server.

entry.name: sub_name_mqsourceprotocolhandler_help_654
entry.text:
Specifies the SUBSCRIPTION NAME, the name is used to IBM MQ Client Handler when retrieving messages from the durable subscription on associated IBM MQ manager. subscriptionName The SUBSCRIPTION NAME. For example:
sub-name sport Identifies sport as the SUBSCRIPTION NAME

entry.name: sub_name_mqsourceprotocolhandler_descr_654
entry.text: A subscription name that used to specify the durable subscription on IBM MQ server.

entry.name: parse_properties_mqsourceprotocolhandler_help_655
entry.text:
Specify whether to parse the properties of the incoming messages from a queue or a subscription. When off, the DataPower Gateway does not ask the IBM MQ Server to send the properties along with the message when issuing an MQGET call. Therefore, all the messages are returned without properties. When on, the server returns messages with their properties.
Example: parse-properties on

entry.name: parse_properties_mqsourceprotocolhandler_descr_655
entry.text: Indicates whether to parse the properties of the incoming messages.

entry.name: async_put_mqsourceprotocolhandler_help_656
entry.text:
Asynchronously put a message to a queue without waiting for a response from the queue manager.
Example: async-put on

entry.name: async_put_mqsourceprotocolhandler_descr_656
entry.text: Asynchronously put a message to a queue. By default, it is off.

entry.name: polling_interval_mqsourceprotocolhandler_help_657
entry.text:
Specifies the number of seconds before an MQGET operation returns if no messages are available. The next attempt will be performed immediately. Setting a low value will help to detect quickly network connectivity issues and queue manager power shutdown. At the same time, a low value will increase network traffic.
interval The number of seconds to wait for an MQGET operation. The minimum is 1. The default is 30.

entry.name: polling_interval_mqsourceprotocolhandler_descr_657
entry.text: Specifies the wait interval for an MQGET operation

entry.name: batch_size_mqsourceprotocolhandler_help_658
entry.text: The number of messages to process as a batch. The source protocol handler gets as many messages as specified and processes the messages as a batch. After the batch of messages has been processed, the source protocol handler performs an MQCMIT if all the messages in the batch processed successfully or an MQBACK if any of the messages in the batch failed.

entry.name: batch_size_mqsourceprotocolhandler_descr_658
entry.text: The number of messages to process as a batch.

entry.name: retrieve_backout_settings_mqsourceprotocolhandler_help_659
entry.text:
Controls whether to retrieve backout settings from the server and checks these values. The backout settings for a local queue manager are set with the "backout-queue" and "backout-threshold" commands.
On a reattempt, the IBM MQ handler uses the higher priority backout settings from the server. If the server does not contain backout settings, the handler uses any existing backout values, either empty or populated, from the local queue manager. If there are no backout settings, the backout function is disabled.
When an alias queue is used, its attributes are retrieved, not those of the base queue.

entry.name: retrieve_backout_settings_mqsourceprotocolhandler_descr_659
entry.text: Controls whether to retrieve backout settings from IBM MQ server.

entry.name: ignore_backout_errors_mqftesourceprotocolhandler_help_660
entry.text: Controls whether this IBM MQFTE handler will ignore backout errors When off, the source protocol handler rolls back and retries the transfer. When on, the source protocol handler ignores the error in sending the transfer to the backout queue and commit the transfer from the get queue.

entry.name: ignore_backout_errors_mqftesourceprotocolhandler_descr_660
entry.text: Controls whether to ignore backout errors.

entry.name: use_qm_in_url_mqsourceprotocolhandler_help_661
entry.text: Indicates whether the var://service/URL-in variable returns the name of IBM MQ Queue Manager or the name of the IBM MQ Queue Manager Group when this configuration defines a queue manager group as the queue manager. When on, the variable returns the name of the queue manager. When off, the default, the variable returns the name of the queue manager group.

entry.name: use_qm_in_url_mqsourceprotocolhandler_descr_661
entry.text: Whether to use the QM or the QM Group in the front side URL

entry.name: queue_manager_mqsourceprotocolhandler_help_662
entry.text:
Specifies the IBM MQ Queue Manager with which the IBM MQ Client handler communicates. queueManagerName The IBM MQ Queue Manager. For example:
queue-manager SVCQ identifies SVCQ as the IBM MQ Queue Manager

entry.name: queue_manager_mqsourceprotocolhandler_descr_662
entry.text: Specifies the IBM MQ Queue Manager

entry.name: put_queue_mqsourceprotocolhandler_help_663
entry.text:
Specifies the IBM MQ PUT queue, the queue used by IBM MQ Client Handler when passing messages to the associated IBM MQ manager. queueName The IBM MQ PUT queue. For example:
get-queue PUTSVCQ identifies PUTSVCQ as the IBM MQ PUT queue

entry.name: put_queue_mqsourceprotocolhandler_descr_663
entry.text: Specifies the IBM MQ PUT queue

entry.name: alternate_user_mqqm_help_664
entry.text:
Toggle the MQOO_ALTERNATE_USER_AUTHORITY flag on calls to MQOPEN. By default the user is root. For example:
alternate-user Enables the use of the ALTERNATE_USER_AUTHORITY flag on calls to MQOPEN (the default state)

entry.name: alternate_user_mqqm_descr_664
entry.text: Toggle the MQOO_ALTERNATE_USER_AUTHORITY flag

entry.name: auto_recovery_mqqm_help_665
entry.text:
Enables an automatic retry procedure after a critical error resulting in a broken connection. For example:
auto-recovery Enables automatic retry (the default state)

entry.name: auto_recovery_mqqm_descr_665
entry.text: Enable connection retry

entry.name: auto_retry_mqqm_help_666
entry.text:
Enables an automatic retry procedure after a critical error resulting in a broken connection. For example:
auto-retry Enables automatic retry (the default state)

entry.name: auto_retry_mqqm_descr_666
entry.text: Enable connection retry

entry.name: automatic_backout_mqqm_help_667
entry.text:
Use this command, which is meaningful only units-of-work is set to 1, to enable the automatic backout of poison messages, defined by IBM as any message which the receiving application does not know how to process. Usually an application rolls-back the GET of this message which leaves the message on the input queue. However, the backout count (MQMD.Backoutcount) is incremented. As the IBM MQ Queue Manager object continues to re-get the message, the backout count continues to increase. Once the Backout Count exceeds the Backout Threshold, the IBM MQ Queue Manager moves the message to the Backout Queue. By default, automatic-backout is disabled.
For example:
automatic-backout enables automatic backout (the default state)

entry.name: automatic_backout_mqqm_descr_667
entry.text: Enable automatic backout of poison messages

entry.name: backout_queue_mqqm_help_668
entry.text:
Specifies the queue which contains those messages that have exceeded the backout-threshold. Use this command, which is only meaningful if units-of-work is set to 1 and automatic-backout is enabled, to specify the backout queue (a queue that contains messages that cannot be processed or delivered, typically SYSTEM.DEAD.LETTER.QUEUE) to which messages that have exceeded the Backout Threshold are re-routed. queueName The backout queue.
For example: backout-queue SYSTEM.DEAD.LETTER.QUEUE The backout queue

entry.name: backout_queue_mqqm_descr_668
entry.text: Identifies the backout queue.

entry.name: backout_threshold_mqqm_help_669
entry.text:
Use this command, which is only meaningful if units-of-work is set to 1 and automatic-backout is enabled, to specify the backout count, the maximum number of re-processing attempts that are allowed per message. Logically, the backout count starts at 0, which accounts for the initial reception of a message. Consequently, the default value 1 specifies two attempts, the initial processing attempt and a single attempt to re-process the message. Retain the default value of 1, or enter an integer greater than 1 to specify the maximum number of re-processing attempts per message. reprocessingCounter is an integer, with a default value of 1, that specifies the maximum number of re-processing attempts per message.
For example: backout-threshold 2 sets the backout threshold at 2, specifying a maximum number of 3 attempts to process a message

entry.name: backout_threshold_mqqm_descr_669
entry.text: Set the max re-processing attempts per message.

entry.name: cache_timeout_mqqm_help_670
entry.text:
Specifies the number of seconds that the DataPower device retains (keeps alive) a dynamic connection in the connection cache. Specify a value that is greater than the negotiated heartbeat interval but less than the keep alive interval.
- The negotiated heartbeat interval is between the DataPower device and the backend IBM MQ server. Use the heartbeat command to define the starting value for the negotiation.
- The keep alive (timeout) interval is on the backend IBM MQ server. The KAINT attribute on the IBM MQ server defines the timeout value for a channel. Not all channels have a defined, explicit keep alive interval on the IBM MQ server. Some queue managers use an automatic timeout setting (the KAINT attribute set to AUTO). In these cases, the keep alive interval is the negotiated heartbeat interval plus 60 seconds.
When an inactive connection reaches this threshold, the DataPower device removes that dynamic connection from the cache. When the cache no longer contains dynamic connections, the DataPower device deletes the dynamic queue manager. Without a dynamic queue manager, there is no connection with the backend IBM MQ server.
Note: The timeout value for the cache-timeout command is the only way to configure a timeout value from the DataPower device to the backend IBM MQ server. No other configuration setting on the DataPower device can time out an IBM MQ connection. seconds The number of seconds to retain a dynamic connection in the connection cache. The minimal value is 1. The default is an empty string. This value indicates that connections in the cache do not time out.

entry.name: cache_timeout_mqqm_descr_670
entry.text: Sets the maximum period to retain a dynamic connection in the connection cache.

entry.name: ccsid_mqqm_help_671
entry.text:
Sets the character code set ID (CCSID) to present to the Queue Manager when the DataPower Gateway connects to it. The CCSID is an integer. Setting this value has the same effect as setting the MQCCSID environment variable for an IBM MQ client. Refer to the IBM MQ documentation for more.
Unless necessary, retain the default value of 850.

entry.name: ccsid_mqqm_descr_671
entry.text: Set the character code set ID to present to the Queue Manager.

entry.name: channel_name_mqqm_help_672
entry.text: Optional when configuring an IBM MQ queue manager, identifies a multiplexed logical communications link to the remote IBM MQ server. name specifies the channel name. For example: channel-name CHANNEL-1 specifies a logical link to the remote IBM MQ server.

entry.name: channel_name_mqqm_descr_672
entry.text: Specifies a logical communication link

entry.name: convert_mqqm_help_673
entry.text:
Enables the conversion of the incoming message to the default CCSI (Coded Character Set Identifier). By default, conversion is enabled.
Use the no form of this command to disable conversion.
For example:
no convert Disables conversion of incoming messages to the default CCSI. convert Enables conversion of incoming messages to the default CCSI, thus restoring the default condition.

entry.name: convert_mqqm_descr_673
entry.text: Enables the conversion of the incoming message to the default CCSI.

entry.name: initial_connections_mqqm_help_674
entry.text:
Specifies the number of pre-allocated connections opened upon start of the queue manager object.
connectionCount is an integer (within the range from 0 to 5000, with a default of 1) that specifies the number of pre-allocated channels opened upon the start of the IBM MQ queue manager. For example:
initial-connections 500 specifies 500 pre-allocated queue manager connections

entry.name: initial_connections_mqqm_descr_674
entry.text: Sets number of pre-allocated connections.

entry.name: sharing_conversations_mqqm_help_675
entry.text:
Specifies the maximum number of conversations to share a single TCP/IP connection. You can only use this command when your IBM MQ Queue Manager connects to an IBM MQ server Version 7 or later.
count The maximum number of conversations to share a single TCP/IP connection. To enable conversation sharing, specify a value that is greater than 1. A value of 0 or 1 disables conversation sharing. Enter a value in the range of 0 - 5000. The default value is 0.
For example:
sharing-conversations 10 Indicates that a TCP/IP connection is shared by a maximum of 10 conversations.

entry.name: sharing_conversations_mqqm_descr_675
entry.text: Sets maximum number of conversations to share in a TCP connection.

entry.name: share_single_conversation_mqqm_help_676
entry.text:
Define whether to enable conversation sharing between the DataPower Gateway and the IBM MQ server. You disable conversation sharing by specifying the value of the sharing-conversations command to 1.
By default, share-single-conversation is off. For example:
share-single-conversation on Enables conversation sharing when the number of shared conversations is 1

entry.name: share_single_conversation_mqqm_descr_676
entry.text: Use single sharing conversations.

entry.name: heartbeat_mqqm_help_677
entry.text:
The approximate time, in seconds, between heartbeat flows on a channel when waiting for a message on a queue. Enter an integer between 0 and 999999. If 0, there will not be heartbeat flows exchanged when waiting for a message on the channel. This value does not set the heartbeat on the channel, rather it is used to negotiate the heartbeat value with the channel. The greater of the two values is used. The default is 300.
Example: heartbeat 15

entry.name: heartbeat_mqqm_descr_677
entry.text: Value to use when sending heartbeat flows on the channel.

entry.name: hostname_mqqm_help_678
entry.text:
Required when configuring an IBM MQ queue manager, identifies a remote IBM MQ server by either host-name or IP address. name is the IP address or host-name of a remote IBM MQ server. For example:
hostname 10.10.14.124 identifies an IBM MQ server at 10.10.14.124. hostname qm.datapower.com identifies an IBM MQ server at qm.datapower.com.

entry.name: hostname_mqqm_descr_678
entry.text: Identifies an IBM MQ server

entry.name: local_address_mqqm_help_679
entry.text:
Optional when configuring an IBM MQ queue manager, identifies the local interface and/or or port(s) to bind to with the outbound TCP connection. addressPortInfo provides interface and port information as shown in the syntax examples below.
For example: local-address 192.168.33.33 uses any port on the specified interface to establish an outbound connection
