local-address 192.168.33.33(56400) use port 56400 on the specified interface to establish an outbound connection
local-address 192.168.33.33(56400, 58000) use any port within the range 56400 through 58000 on the specified interface to establish an outbound connection. Note that if a range of ports is specified, the range must be greater than the value specified by the total-connection-limit command.
local-address (56400) use the specified port on any configured interface to establish an outbound connection. Note that if a range of ports is specified, the range must be greater than the value specified by the total-connection-limit command.
local-address (56400, 58000) use any port within the range 56400 through 58000 on any configured interface to establish an outbound connection. Note that if a range of ports is specified, the range must be greater than the value specified by the total-connection-limit command.

entry.name: local_address_mqqm_descr_679
entry.text: Set the local interface to bind

entry.name: maximum_message_size_mqqm_help_680
entry.text:
Specifies the maximum message size for the queue manager. Optionally used when configuring the queue manager.
bytes is the maximum message size in bytes. Allowable values are within the range of 1024 (1KB) through 104857600 (100MB), with a default value of 1048576 (1MB).
For example:
message-size 2048 specifies a maximum message size of 2K bytes for the queue manager.

entry.name: maximum_message_size_mqqm_descr_680
entry.text: Specifies the maximum message size.

entry.name: queue_manager_mqqm_help_681
entry.text:
Optional when configuring an IBM MQ queue manager, identifies a specific server-resident IBM MQ queue manager. name identifies a server-resident queue manager. For example:
queue-manager QMan-1 specifies a server-resident queue manager named QMan-1.

entry.name: queue_manager_mqqm_descr_681
entry.text: Identifies a server-resident queue manager

entry.name: reporting_interval_mqqm_help_682
entry.text:
Optionally use this command to indicate how often to log failed connection attempts. Enter an integer to specify the interval (in seconds) between the generation of identical error messages to IBM MQ logging targets.
intervalSeconds is an integer (with a default of 1) that specifies the number of seconds to wait before writing identical log messages to an IBM MQ logging target.
For example:
reporting-interval 2 specifies to wait 2 seconds between logging of identical failed connection error messages.

entry.name: reporting_interval_mqqm_descr_682
entry.text: Limits identical log entries.

entry.name: retry_interval_mqqm_help_683
entry.text:
Specify the time interval (in seconds) between attempts to retry the failed connections to a remote host.
intervalSeconds is an integer that specifies the number of seconds to wait before attempting to re-establish a failed connection. The default value is 1.
For example: retry-interval 2 specifies a retry interval of 2 seconds.

entry.name: retry_interval_mqqm_descr_683
entry.text: Specify the time interval (in seconds) between attempts to retry the failed connections to a remote host.

entry.name: retry_attempts_mqqm_help_684
entry.text:
The number of attempts to retry the failed connections. After the number of attempts is reached, the 'long-retry-interval' will be used instead.
attempts is an integer that specifies the number of attempts to retry the failed connections. The default value is 0.
0 (zero) would mean the 'long-retry-interval' will not be used.
For example: retry-attempts 10 set the number of retry attempt to 10

entry.name: retry_attempts_mqqm_descr_684
entry.text: The number of attempts to retry the failed connections.

entry.name: long_retry_interval_mqqm_help_685
entry.text:
Long retry interval before retrying the failed connections. This would be the retry interval to use after the number of short retry attempts is reached.
The 'long-retry-interval' should be greater than the 'retry-interval' or it will take no effect.
intervalSeconds is an integer that specifies the number of seconds to wait before attempting to re-establish a failed connection. Enter an integer of 0 - 65535 seconds. The default value is 1800.
For example: long-retry-interval 50 specifies a long retry interval of 50 seconds.

entry.name: long_retry_interval_mqqm_descr_685
entry.text: Long retry interval before retrying the failed connections.

entry.name: ssl_mqqm_help_686
entry.text:
The TLS proxy profile is deprecated. Use a TLS client profile. Specifies an existing TLS Proxy Profile to use when establishing an SSL session with a remote IBM MQ Queue Manager. With TLS sessions that use IBM MQ URL to establish a connection, use the ssl command. With TLS sessions that do not use IBM MQ URL for establishing a connection, use the combination of ssl-key and ssl-cipher commands.
name The name of an existing TLS Proxy Profile.
For example: ssl MQSSLProfile

entry.name: ssl_mqqm_descr_686
entry.text: Deprecated - Specifies the TLS Proxy Profile

entry.name: ssl_cipher_mqqm_help_687
entry.text:
Specifies the cipher suite available to support TLS operations. A cipher suite is required when TLS communication is enabled for the current IBM MQ Queue Manager. Otherwise, the cipher suite is not used.
cipherDescriptor Describes the supported suite of cryptographic protocols. For a list of supported values, see the latest IBM MQ documentation.
For example:
ssl-cipher TRIPLE_DES_SHA_US Identifies supported cryptographic algorithms.

entry.name: ssl_cipher_mqqm_descr_687
entry.text: Specifies the cipher suite available to support TLS operations.

entry.name: ssl_key_mqqm_help_688
entry.text:
Enables TLS on the communications with the current IBM MQ Queue Manager by specifying the location of the IBM MQ key database file in which keys are certificates are stored.
Each key database file has an associated password stash file. The stash file contains encrypted passwords that are used to allow programmatic access to the key database.
The stash file must reside in the same directory as the key database file, must have the same file stem as the key database file, and must end with the suffix ".sth". For example, if the key database file is cert:///MQkeys.pem, the stash file must be cert:///MQkeys.sth.
localURL Specifies the location of the IBM MQ key database file.
For example:
ssl-key cert:///MQKeys.pem Identifies cert:///MQKeys.pem as the IBM MQ key database file.

entry.name: ssl_key_mqqm_descr_688
entry.text: Specifies the location of the IBM MQ key database file.

entry.name: permit_insecure_servers_mqqm_help_689
entry.text: When TLS Key Repository is used, permit connections to IBM MQ servers that do not support RFC 5746. Such servers are vulnerable to man-in-the-middle attacks as described in CVE-2009-3555. For security reasons this toggle is off by default so that these insecure connections are rejected during the TLS handshake.

entry.name: permit_insecure_servers_mqqm_descr_689
entry.text: Specifies whether connections to insecure TLS servers are permitted

entry.name: total_connection_limit_mqqm_help_690
entry.text:
Specifies the maximum number of open connections that is supported by the current IBM MQ Queue Manager.
maxConnections is an integer within the range 1 through 5000 that sets the maximum open connections limit. The default value is 250.
For example:
total-connection-limit 500 specifies a maximum connection limit of 500.

entry.name: total_connection_limit_mqqm_descr_690
entry.text: Specifies the maximum number of open connections.

entry.name: units_of_work_mqqm_help_691
entry.text:
Under certain conditions (for example, when updating a relational database), it may be vital that all updates succeed or fail as a group. A group of contiguous, related messages is referred to as a transactional group or as a unit of work. Optional when configuring an IBM MQ queue manager, identifies a unit of work, and guarantees "reliable" processing for each such unit. units specifies the units=of-work. By default, this value is set to 0, which provides low-overhead "non-reliable" service in which undeliverable messages are silently discarded. For example:
units-of-work 1 specifies a unit of work of 1 message, essentially enabling a reliable IBM MQ services. units-of-work 0 restores the default non-reliable IBM MQ service.

entry.name: units_of_work_mqqm_descr_691
entry.text: Specifies an IBM MQ syncpoint

entry.name: username_mqqm_help_692
entry.text:
Specifies the plain text string sent to the server for identifying the client.
idString identifies the client.
For example:
username mydevice identifies mydevice as the client ID.

entry.name: username_mqqm_descr_692
entry.text: Identifies the client.

entry.name: mqcsp_userid_mqqm_help_693
entry.text:
Specifies the plain text string used as the user ID value of the MQCSP connection security parameter. This value is combined with the password value and sent to the security exit on the IBM MQ server. The MQCSP connection security parameter is valid only when both the user ID and password values are defined.
idString Specifies the user ID value of the MQCSP connection security parameter when MQCSP structure is used for authorization service.
For example:
mqcsp-userid mqm sets mqm as the MQCSP User ID.

entry.name: mqcsp_userid_mqqm_descr_693
entry.text: The user ID value of the MQCSP connection security parameter.

entry.name: mqcsp_password_mqqm_help_694
entry.text:
Specifies the plain text string used as the password value of the MQCSP connect security parameter. This value is combined with the user ID value and sent to the security exit on the IBM MQ server. The MQCSP connection security parameter is valid only when both the user ID and password values are defined. This property is deprecated and replaced with mqcsp-password-alias.
password Specifies the password value of the MQCSP connection security parameter when MQCSP structure is used for authorization service.
For example:
mqcsp-password passwd sets passwd as the MQCSP password.

entry.name: mqcsp_password_mqqm_descr_694
entry.text: The password value of the MQCSP connection security parameter (deprecated).

entry.name: mqcsp_password_alias_mqqm_help_695
entry.text:
Specifies the password alias that maps to a plain text string used as the password value of the MQCSP connect security parameter. This value is combined with the user ID value and sent to the security exit on the IBM MQ server. The MQCSP connection security parameter is valid only when both the user ID and password values are defined.
password-alias Specifies the password alias of the password value of the MQCSP connection security parameter when MQCSP structure is used for authorization service.
For example:
mqcsp-password-alias alias-1 sets alias-1 as the alias to the MQCSP password.

entry.name: mqcsp_password_alias_mqqm_descr_695
entry.text: The password alias of the password value of the MQCSP connection security parameter.

entry.name: xml_manager_mqqm_help_696
entry.text:
Specifies an existing XML Manager that is assigned to this Queue Manager. More than one Queue Manager may use the same XML Manager.
name The name of the XML Manager.

entry.name: xml_manager_mqqm_descr_696
entry.text: Specifies the XML Manager that is assigned to this Queue Manager.

entry.name: polling_tolerance_mqqm_help_697
entry.text:
Adds the additional network tolerance (in seconds) to the polling interval of IBM MQ MQGET call
seconds is an integer that specifies the number of seconds that is added to the polling interval of IBM MQ MQGET call. The default value is 10.
For example: polling-tolerance 30 Adds an additional time of 30 seconds.

entry.name: polling_tolerance_mqqm_descr_697
entry.text: Adds the additional network tolerance time (in seconds) to the polling interval of IBM MQ MQGET call

entry.name: backup_mqqmgroup_help_698
entry.text:
A Queue Manager Group consists of one primary queue manager object and one or more backup queue managers. Status of the primary queue manager is periodically monitored, and, in the event of failure, one of the backup queue managers, each of which is created with a configurable number of pre-cached connections, is selected to assume the primary role. When, and if, the original primary queue manager returns to service, it re-asserts its primary status and resumes its former role.
qmName identifies a queue manager added to the group as a backup member. For example:
backup Beta adds the queue manager named Beta to the current Queue Manager Group as a backup member

entry.name: backup_mqqmgroup_descr_698
entry.text: Adds a backup queue manager to the group.

entry.name: primary_mqqmgroup_help_699
entry.text:
A Queue Manager Group consists of one primary queue manager object and one or more backup queue managers. Status of the primary queue manager is periodically monitored, and, in the event of failure, one of the backup queue managers, each of which is created with a configurable number of pre-cached connections, is selected to assume the primary role. When, and if, the original primary queue manager returns to service, it re-asserts its primary status and resumes its former role.
qmName identifies a queue manager added to the group as the primary member. For example:
primary Alpha adds the queue manager named Alpha to the current Queue Manager Group as the primary member

entry.name: primary_mqqmgroup_descr_699
entry.text: Adds the primary queue manager to the group.

entry.name: mount_refresh_time_nfsclientsettings_help_700
entry.text:
Sets interval between NFS mount maintenance rounds, in seconds. These rounds check all existing NFS mounts, and retry all NFS mounts that are not presently up. Decreasing the interval decreases the chance that a transaction will timeout waiting for an NFS file open to fail, due to a down or unreachable NFS server. Increasing the interval reduces local and NFS server overhead from mount checking. interval How much time to wait after one maintenance round completes until starting the next one. The default delay is 10 seconds. For example:
mount-refresh-time 5 reduces the delay between rounds to 5 seconds.

entry.name: mount_refresh_time_nfsclientsettings_descr_700
entry.text: Interval for checking all NFS mounts

entry.name: remote_nfsstaticmount_help_701
entry.text:
Specifies the NFS server, and its exported directory, to mount for this NFS static mount. export The remote mount point. It is in the canonical form host:/path, where host is the DNS name or IP address of the NFS server, and path is the path exported by the host to mount. As in any NFS mount, the path can be the root of the exported filesystem, or can be a directory within that filesystem. For example:
remote server7:/export/schemas will mount the directory exported as /export/schemas on the NFS file server server7.

entry.name: remote_nfsstaticmount_descr_701
entry.text: Remote NFS export to mount

entry.name: local_filesystem_access_nfsstaticmount_help_702
entry.text:
Enables local filesystem access to this NFS mount through the user interface. In the CLI, this will allow using commands such as dir and copy. If this nfs-static-mount is named peter, then the files will be visible in the folder named nfs-peter:. Note that if the NFS mount goes down, commands manipulating files on that mount will hang. For example:
local-filesystem-access enable local folder access to NFS files
no local-filesystem-access disable local folder access to NFS files

entry.name: local_filesystem_access_nfsstaticmount_descr_702
entry.text: Enable local filesystem access

entry.name: version_nfsstaticmount_help_703
entry.text:
Desired NFS protocol version for this mount. The chosen version will always be preferred, but the client will fall back to Version 2 if Version 3 is configured, based on what the server supports. There is no fall back from Version 4. Version 3 is the default. version If 3, then NFS Version 3 is preferred, but will fallback to NFS Version 2. If 4, will use NFS Version 4. If 2, will use NFS Version 2. For example:
version 2 only use NFS Version 2.

entry.name: version_nfsstaticmount_descr_703
entry.text: NFS protocol version

entry.name: transport_nfsstaticmount_help_704
entry.text:
Selects preferred transport protocol for this mount. tcp and udp are mutually exclusive keywords. If tcp is selected (the default), then the mount will use TCP if the Mount and NFS RPC protocols are available over TCP, otherwise UDP will be used. If udp is selected, UDP will be used if available, else the mount will fail. tcp prefer TCP for this mount udp only use UDP for this mount For example:
transport tcp prefer TCP for this mount transport udp only use UDP for this mount

entry.name: transport_nfsstaticmount_descr_704
entry.text: Preferred transport protocol

entry.name: mount_type_nfsstaticmount_help_705
entry.text:
Selects the type of NFS mount to use. The default behavior is to use hard mounts, which is generally the appropriate behavior. With hard mounts, there is no risk of data corruption. With soft mounts, undetected data corruption is possible, but the DataPower Gateway might be less prone to reboots caused by watchdog timeouts when the NFS server is unavailable.
hard Makes this NFS mount a hard mount. Hard mounts ensure the reliable transfer of data. If the NFS server is unavailable for more than two minutes, the DataPower Gateway might reboot due to a watchdog error. soft Makes this NFS mount a soft mount. Soft mounts can expose the risk of undetected data corruption and the loss of files read or written via NFS. If the NFS server is unavailable and the retransmit timeout and count does not complete in less than two minutes, soft mounts might prevent a reboot due to a watchdog error. Use this behavior only if preventing watchdog errors is more important than data integrity.

entry.name: mount_type_nfsstaticmount_descr_705
entry.text: NFS mount type

entry.name: read_only_nfsstaticmount_help_706
entry.text:
Selects doing a read-only mount of the NFS export, instead of the default of read-write. If a mount is exported read-only, then the mount must be read-only. Files cannot be written to the NFS export if read-only is selected. For example:
read-only make this mount read-only
no read-only make this mount read-write

entry.name: read_only_nfsstaticmount_descr_706
entry.text: Use read-only mount

entry.name: rsize_nfsstaticmount_help_707
entry.text:
Selects the block size (in bytes) of each NFS read operation over NFS. bytes how many bytes to request in each NFS RPC read. Should be a power of two between 1024 and 32768. Larger sizes increase NFS protocol efficiency. Sizes over 8192 should only be used with TCP as a transport protocol. For example:
rsize 32768 increases the read block size to 32768 bytes.

entry.name: rsize_nfsstaticmount_descr_707
entry.text: NFS read block size

entry.name: wsize_nfsstaticmount_help_708
entry.text:
Selects the block size (in bytes) of each NFS write operation over NFS. bytes how many bytes to request in each NFS RPC write. Should be a power of two between 1024 and 32768. Larger sizes increase NFS protocol efficiency. Sizes over 8192 should only be used with TCP as a transport protocol. For example:
rsize 32768 increases the read block size to 32768 bytes.

entry.name: wsize_nfsstaticmount_descr_708
entry.text: NFS write block size

entry.name: timeo_nfsstaticmount_help_709
entry.text:
Sets time until first retransmission on RPC minor timeout for NFS protocol. delay timeout until first retransmission, in tenths of seconds. Default is 7. For example:
timeo 5 reduce timeout to 5 tenths of a second (half a second).

entry.name: timeo_nfsstaticmount_descr_709
entry.text: NFS minor retransmission timeout

entry.name: retrans_nfsstaticmount_help_710
entry.text:
Sets number of minor NFS RPC timeouts and retransmissions until major timeout. count number of minor timeouts, between 1 and 60, default is 3. For example:
retrans 4 allow 4 minor timeouts before major timeout and NFS read/write failure.

entry.name: retrans_nfsstaticmount_descr_710
entry.text: Maximum minor retransmissions

entry.name: version_nfsdynamicmounts_help_711
entry.text:
Preferred NFS protocol version for dynamic mounts. The chosen version will always be preferred, but the client will fall back to lower versions (down to Version 2) based on what the server supports. Version 3 is the default. version If 3, then NFS Version 3 is preferred, but will fallback to NFS Version 2. If 2, will use NFS Version 2. For example:
version 2 only use NFS Version 2.

entry.name: version_nfsdynamicmounts_descr_711
entry.text: Preferred NFS protocol version

entry.name: transport_nfsdynamicmounts_help_712
entry.text:
Selects preferred transport protocol for dynamic mounts. If tcp is selected (the default), then the mount will use TCP if the Mount and NFS RPC protocols are available over TCP, otherwise UDP will be used. If udp is selected, UDP will be used if available, else the mount will fail. tcp prefer TCP for dynamic mounts udp only use UDP for dynamic mounts For example:
transport tcp prefer TCP for this mount
transport udp only use UDP for this mount

entry.name: transport_nfsdynamicmounts_descr_712
entry.text: Preferred transport protocol

entry.name: mount_type_nfsdynamicmounts_help_713
entry.text:
Selects the type of NFS mount to use. The default behavior is to use hard mounts, which is generally the appropriate behavior. With hard mounts, there is no risk of data corruption. With soft mounts, undetected data corruption is possible, but the DataPower Gateway might be less prone to reboots caused by watchdog timeouts when the NFS server is unavailable.
hard Makes this NFS mount a hard mount. Hard mounts ensure the reliable transfer of data. If the NFS server is unavailable for more than two minutes, the DataPower Gateway might reboot due to a watchdog error. soft Makes this NFS mount a soft mount. Soft mounts can expose the risk of undetected data corruption and the loss of files read or written via NFS. If the NFS server is unavailable and the retransmit timeout and count does not complete in less than two minutes, soft mounts might prevent a reboot due to a watchdog error. Use this behavior only if preventing watchdog errors is more important than data integrity.

entry.name: mount_type_nfsdynamicmounts_descr_713
entry.text: The type of NFS mount to use.

entry.name: read_only_nfsdynamicmounts_help_714
entry.text:
Selects doing a read-only mount of the NFS export, instead of the default of read-write. If a mount is exported read-only, then the mount must be read-only. Files cannot be written to the NFS export if read-only is selected. For example:
read-only Makes this mount read-only no read-only Makes this mount read-write

entry.name: read_only_nfsdynamicmounts_descr_714
entry.text: Use read-only mount

entry.name: rsize_nfsdynamicmounts_help_715
entry.text:
Selects the block size (in bytes) of each NFS read operation over NFS. bytes how many bytes to request in each NFS RPC read. Should be a power of two between 1024 and 32768. Larger sizes increase NFS protocol efficiency. Sizes over 8192 should only be used with TCP as a transport protocol. For example:
rsize 32768 increases the read block size to 32768 bytes.

entry.name: rsize_nfsdynamicmounts_descr_715
entry.text: NFS read block size

entry.name: wsize_nfsdynamicmounts_help_716
entry.text:
Selects the block size (in bytes) of each NFS write operation over NFS. bytes how many bytes to request in each NFS RPC write. Should be a power of two between 1024 and 32768. Larger sizes increase NFS protocol efficiency. Sizes over 8192 should only be used with TCP as a transport protocol. For example:
rsize 32768 increases the read block size to 32768 bytes.

entry.name: wsize_nfsdynamicmounts_descr_716
entry.text: NFS write block size

entry.name: timeo_nfsdynamicmounts_help_717
entry.text:
Sets time until first retransmission on RPC minor timeout for NFS protocol. delay timeout until first retransmission, in tenths of seconds. Default is 7. For example:
timeo 5 reduce timeout to 5 tenths of a second (half a second).

entry.name: timeo_nfsdynamicmounts_descr_717
entry.text: NFS minor retransmission timeout

entry.name: retrans_nfsdynamicmounts_help_718
entry.text:
Sets number of minor NFS RPC timeouts and retransmissions until major timeout. count number of minor timeouts, between 1 and 60, default is 3. For example:
retrans 4 allow 4 minor timeouts before major timeout and NFS read/write failure.

entry.name: retrans_nfsdynamicmounts_descr_718
entry.text: Maximum minor retransmissions

entry.name: inactivity_timeout_nfsdynamicmounts_help_719
entry.text:
Controls how long dynamic NFS mounts with no file read/write activity stay mounted. The default is 900 seconds. Setting this to 0 disables automatic unmounting. seconds how many seconds of inactivity until deciding to unmount a dynamic mount For example:
inactivity-timeout 60 times out dynamic mounts after one minute of inactivity.

entry.name: inactivity_timeout_nfsdynamicmounts_descr_719
entry.text: Inactive mount point timeout

entry.name: mount_timeout_nfsdynamicmounts_help_720
entry.text:
Controls how long the system will keep trying to complete a dynamic NFS caused by an transaction that caused the mount process to be started. After this timeout, the transaction fails (file open error), and the NFS mount process is canceled. The default value is 30 seconds, the range is 10 to 240 seconds. Should be longer than the NFS maintenance interval. seconds How many seconds until dynamic NFS mount attempt abandoned
For example:
mount-timeout 15 Shorten the mount timeout to 15 seconds.

entry.name: mount_timeout_nfsdynamicmounts_descr_720
entry.text: Mount attempt timeout

entry.name: refresh_interval_ntpservice_help_721
entry.text:
Defines the interval, in seconds, between clock synchronizations.
syncFrequency is an integer (within the range 60 through 86400, with a default of 900) that specifies the number of seconds between clock synchronizations.
For example:
refresh-interval 300 identifies the NTP server and specifies a clock synchronization interval of 300 seconds (5 minutes).

entry.name: refresh_interval_ntpservice_descr_721
entry.text: Defines the interval between clock synchronizations.

entry.name: remote_server_ntpservice_help_722
entry.text:
Identifies an NTP server by domain name or IP address.
serverName The device supports one NTP server at a time. To designate a new NTP server, use the no ntp-service command to delete the current server. Then, use the remote-server command to designate the new server.
For example:
remote-server Chronos-1 identifies Chronos-1 as the NTP server.

entry.name: remote_server_ntpservice_descr_722
entry.text: Identifies an NTP server.

entry.name: timeout_ntpservice_help_723
entry.text:
Defines the timeout, in milliseconds, for a response from a NTP server.
timeout Specifies the number of milliseconds to wait for a response before moving to the next NTP server in the list. Enter a value in the range 750 - 300. The efault value is 750.
For example:
timeout 1000 Specifies a timeout of 1000 milliseconds.

entry.name: timeout_ntpservice_descr_723
entry.text: Defines the timeout for a response from a NTP server.

entry.name: url_upt_dmdynamicparsesettingsreference_help_724
entry.text: The URL from which to retrieve the serialized XML or JSON properties that are merging into the dynamic object. These properties take precedence over any existing literal or default properties.

entry.name: url_upt_dmdynamicparsesettingsreference_descr_724
entry.text: Specifies the URL of a resource with one or more properties for the dynamic object

entry.name: literal_upt_dmdynamicparsesettingsreference_help_725
entry.text: A literal string as serialized XML or JSON properties that are merging into the dynamic object. These properties take precedence over any existing default properties.

entry.name: literal_upt_dmdynamicparsesettingsreference_descr_725
entry.text: Specifies a literal configuration string with one or more properties for the dynamic object

entry.name: default_upt_dmdynamicparsesettingsreference_help_726
entry.text: A reference to an existing valid object from which to retrieve default property values for the dynamic object.

entry.name: default_upt_dmdynamicparsesettingsreference_descr_726
entry.text: Specifies an existing object with default property values for the dynamic object

entry.name: type_peergroup_help_727
entry.text:
Specifies the peer group type. All members in an SLM peer group must specify the same type.
slm (Default) Specifies that the SLM peer group use unicast packet transmission for data exchange. slm-multicast Specifies that the SLM peer group use multicast packet transmission for data exchange. For example:
peer-group SLM-Group1 type slm-multicast Enters Peer Group configuration mode, creates the SLM-Group1 peer group, and specifies SLM multicast as the data exchange method.

entry.name: type_peergroup_descr_727
entry.text: Specifies the type of data exchange

entry.name: url_peergroup_help_728
entry.text:
Identifies a member of the current peer group. For unicast peering, peers exchange SLM data over the XML management interface as SOAP over HTTPS. Multicast peering shares the initial SLM state using SOAP over HTTPS; the data transfers are done using multicast. When configuring a peer group you must add the local DataPower Gateway to the peer group list; the peer group lists must be identical across all group members. member Identifies a peer group member by IP address or domain name in the "https://IP_address:port" format for an Ethernet interface or a VLAN interface. The default port for the XML Management Interface is 5550. If this port is changed on any peer, the URL must reflect the correct port.
For example:
peer-group SLM-Group1 type slm url https://192.168.12.100:5550 url https://192.168.49.13:5550 url https://192.168.80.126:5550 Enters Peer Group Configuration Mode, creates the SLM-Group-1 Peer Group, specifies the peer group type, and designates three members.

entry.name: url_peergroup_descr_728
entry.text: Identifies a member of the peer group.

entry.name: update_interval_peergroup_help_729
entry.text:
Specifies the length of time to wait between sending updates to peers. The update-interval command is required when the peer group type is slm-multicast.
milliseconds Specifies the length of time in milliseconds to wait between sending updates to peers. Enter a value in the range 1 - 10000. The default value is 10.
For example:
peer-group SLM-Group1 update-interval 2000 Enters Peer Group configuration mode, creates the SLM-Group1 peer group, and specifies an update-interval of 2000 milliseconds.

entry.name: update_interval_peergroup_descr_729
entry.text: Specifies the time between sending updates

entry.name: ip_multicast_peergroup_help_730
entry.text:
Identifies the IP Multicast configuration used to send and receive peering update messages. The ip-multicast command is required when the peer group type is slm-multicast.
name Specifies an existing IP Multicast configuration for handling the data exchange among the peers.
For example:
peer-group SLM-Group1 ip-multicast IPMulticast-3 enters Peer Group configuration mode, creates the SLM-Group1 peer group, and specifies that the peer group use the IPMulticast-3 IP multicast configuration.

entry.name: ip_multicast_peergroup_descr_730
entry.text: Identifies the IP Multicast configuration

entry.name: alias_kprivileged_help_731
entry.text:
This command is deprecated. Creates a command macro, providing ready access to a specific sequence of commands.
name The command alias. command-sequence Defines the sequence of commands that the macro runs. Use a backslash semicolon (\;) to separate multiple commands, if the command sequence is not quoted.

entry.name: alias_kprivileged_descr_731
entry.text: Deprecated - Creates a command macro

entry.name: clock_kprivileged_help_732
entry.text:
Sets the date or time. For example:
clock 2003-12-23 sets the date to December 23, 2003 clock 23:32:00 sets the time to 11:32:00 PM.

entry.name: clock_kprivileged_descr_732
entry.text: Sets the date or time

entry.name: clock_kglobalconfig_help_733
entry.text:
Sets the date or time. For example:
clock 2003-12-23 sets the date to December 23, 2003 clock 23:32:00 sets the time to 11:32:00 PM.

entry.name: clock_kglobalconfig_descr_733
entry.text: Sets the date or time

entry.name: locate_device_kglobalconfig_help_734
entry.text: Illuminate or extinguish the locate LED.

entry.name: locate_device_kglobalconfig_descr_734
entry.text: Illuminate or extinguish the locate LED

entry.name: login_kprivileged_help_735
entry.text:
Logs in as a specific user; the CLI prompts for a user name and password. For example: login
Username: admin Password: YetAnotherPassword logs into the CLI as the admin account

entry.name: login_kprivileged_descr_735
entry.text: Logs in as a specific user

entry.name: shutdown_kprivileged_help_736
entry.text:
Restarts or shuts down the DataPower Gateway. Without parameters, it restarts the DataPower Gateway.
The DataPower Gateway restarts using the startup configuration specified by the boot config command and the startup firmware image specified by the boot image command. Without a designated startup configuration or firmware image, the DataPower Gateway restarts with the configuration and firmware image that were active when you issued the shutdown command.
reload Restarts the DataPower Gateway. reboot Shuts down and restarts the DataPower Gateway. halt Shuts down the DataPower Gateway but does not power it off. The halt mode is deprecated, using poweroff instead. poweroff Power off the DataPower Gateway, you need to press power button to turn it on. seconds Optional: Specifies the number of seconds before the DataPower Gateway starts the shutdown operation. Use any value of 0 - 65535. The default value is 10.
For example:
shutdown reload Specifies an immediate restart shutdown reboot 10 Specifies a reboot in 10 seconds shutdown halt 60 Specifies a shutdown in 1 minute shutdown poweroff 60 Specifies a poweroff in 1 minute

entry.name: shutdown_kprivileged_descr_736
entry.text: Restarts or shuts down the DataPower Gateway.

entry.name: shutdown_kprivileged_help_737
entry.text:
Restarts or shuts down the appliance. Without parameters, it restarts the appliance.
The appliance restarts using the startup configuration specified by the boot config command and the startup firmware image specified by the boot image command. Without a designated startup configuration or firmware image, the appliance restarts with the configuration and firmware image that are active when you issue the shutdown command.
reboot Shuts down and restarts the appliance. halt Shuts down the appliance, but power remains on. This mode is deprecated. Use "poweroff" instead. poweroff Shuts down the appliance and turns off the power. seconds Optional: Specifies the number of seconds before the appliance starts the shutdown operation. Use any value of 0 - 65535. The default value is 10.
For example: shutdown reboot Wait 10 seconds, then shut down and restart the appliance. shutdown poweroff 60 Wait 1 minute, then shut down and turn off the appliance.

entry.name: shutdown_kprivileged_descr_737
entry.text: Restarts or shuts down the appliance.

entry.name: meta_item_processingmetadata_help_738
entry.text:
Specifies an item of metadata information to include in the manifest or list of items returned by the Processing Metadata object. Issue this command as many times as needed to include all desired items.
There are a large number of predefined metaCategory / metaName argument pairs that refer to predefined data sources (such as protocol headers or system variables). When using these predefined pairs, it is not necessary to specify a dataSource.
Use the "no" form of the command to delete the entire list of items configured for the object.
metaCategory may be a predefined name or "header" to create a custom header item or "variable" to create a custom variable item. When using custom items, you must supply the dataSource argument. metaName may be a predefined name matched to the metaCategory name provided or a custom name if the metaCategory was either "header" or "variable". dataSource optionally is the precise protocol header name or system variable containing the custom meta information desired.
For example:
metadata-item http Host metadata-item http Referrer metadata-item header DeptSrc Department adds two predefined items to the manifest and adds one custom item. no metadata-item deletes all items from the manifest list.

entry.name: meta_item_processingmetadata_descr_738
entry.text: Specifies a metadata item to include in the manifest of items returned.

entry.name: summary_processingmetadata_help_739
entry.text:
Adds a descriptive comment to the object for future reference.
comment An alphanumeric string. When the string contains blanks, enclose in double quotes.
For example:
summary "Returns custom department headers"

entry.name: summary_processingmetadata_descr_739
entry.text: Adds a user comment to the object.

entry.name: refine_soapheaderdisposition_help_740
entry.text:
Specifies an item of SOAP header processing instruction to include in the list of items returned by the SOAP Header Disposition Table object. Issue this command as many times as needed to include all desired items.
Use the "no" form of the command to delete the entire list of items configured for the object.
namespace The namespace URI to be used to match a SOAP header element, the default value is a blank string, which indicates no restriction.
headerLocalName A string to be used to match a SOAP header element local name, the default value is a blank string, which indicates no restriction.
childElementLocalName optionally is the string of the child element local name of a SOAP header, the default value is a blank string, which indicates no restriction.
action what action to take for this SOAP header and/or child element.
Here are the possible action argument values: processed The specified element was processed, take default SOAP action unprocessed The specified element was not processed, take default SOAP action keep Keep this SOAP header or child element remove Remove this SOAP header or child element fault Generate a SOAP fault if the element exists
For example:
refine "my-namespace" "Foo" "" "remove" refine "" "Bar" "abc" "keep" refine "some-namespace" "" "" "processed"
adds three SOAP header processing one by one, it remove the "Foo" header if the namespace uri is "my-namespace", and keep the "Bar" SOAP header's child named "abc" regardless of the namespace uri, then use the default processed header rules for all the headers in namespace "some-namespace". no refine deletes all items from the list.

entry.name: refine_soapheaderdisposition_descr_740
entry.text: Define an instruction to process a SOAP header and/or child element.

entry.name: aaaserver_radiussettings_help_741
entry.text:
Identifies a RADIUS AAA server, prompts for the secret that is unique to this device (RADIUS server pair), and adds the server to the list of RADIUS servers for this device.
Use server number to determine the order in which the device contacts RADIUS AAA servers. For example, assume that an device has a list of three RADIUS AAA servers, numbered 10, 20, and 30. RADIUS AAA requests are always sent first to server 10 (the lowest number is the most preferred). Should that authentication request timeout, it is sent to server 20. Should that request timeout, it is sent to server 30 (the highest number is the least preferred).
Use the "no" form of the server command to delete a server from the list of RADIUS servers.
serverNumber is an integer that specifies the relative position of this server on the list of RADIUS AAA servers.
ipAddress is the IP address of a RADIUS AAA server.
portNumber optionally is optional integer within the range 0 to 65535 that identifies the port number on RADIUS AAA server that monitors RADIUS AAA requests. In the absence of a port number, the device uses the default value of 1812.
For example:
aaaserver 20 172.16.1.1 1812 secret: YetAnotherPasswordServer20 identifies a RADIUS server at 172.16.1.1:1812 as server 20.
aaaserver 30 172.16.100.100 1812 secret: YetAnotherPasswordServer20 identifies a RADIUS server at 172.16.100.100:1812 as server 30. The RADIUS servers will be contacted in the following order (because of server number): 172.16.1.1:1812 172.16.100.100:1812

entry.name: aaaserver_radiussettings_descr_741
entry.text: Identifies a RADIUS AAA server.

entry.name: id_radiussettings_help_742
entry.text:
Specifies the NAS-Identifier, a string which may be used in some environments to identify the device in its role as a RADIUS client. nas-id specifies the NAS-Identifier. The fully qualified domain name of the device is often used as a NAS-Identifier. For example:
id ragnarok.datapower.com specifies a NAS-Identifier

entry.name: id_radiussettings_descr_742
entry.text: Specifies the NAS-Identifier

entry.name: retries_radiussettings_help_743
entry.text:
Specifies the number of times the device, when acting as a RADIUS client, will retransmit an unanswered RADIUS request. If a RADIUS request is still outstanding after retry-count retransmissions, the device will attempt to contact the next RADIUS server in its list of RADIUS servers. retry-count specifies the maximum number of retransmissions. For example:
retries 5 specifies a maximum of 5 retransmissions of an outstanding RADIUS request

entry.name: retries_radiussettings_descr_743
entry.text: Specifies the RADIUS retry counter

entry.name: server_radiussettings_help_744
entry.text:
Identifies a RADIUS server and adds that server to the device's list of RADIUS servers. server-number is an integer that specifies the relative position of this server in the list of RADIUS servers. RADIUS servers with lower server-numbers are the most preferred. ip-address is the dotted decimal IP address of the RADIUS server. port-number is an integer within the range 0 through 65535 identifies the port on ip-address that monitors incoming RADIUS client requests. In the absence of a port-number, a default value of 1812 is provided.
After the server has been identified, the CLI prompts for the "shared secret" unique to this device:RADIUS server pair. For example:
server 10 172.16.20.20 secret: identifies a RADIUS server at 172.168.20.20:1812 (with the port-number 1812 provided by default).

entry.name: server_radiussettings_descr_744
entry.text: Identifies a RADIUS server

entry.name: timeout_radiussettings_help_745
entry.text:
Specifies the interval between retransmissions of outstanding RADIUS requests. interval specifies the interval in milliseconds. For example:
timeout 500 specifies a half-second interval between retransmissions of outstanding RADIUS requests

entry.name: timeout_radiussettings_descr_745
entry.text: Specifies the interval between retransmissions

entry.name: apply_cli_rbmsettings_help_746
entry.text:
Controls whether the RBM policy applies to both WebGUI access and command line access or applies to WebGUI access only. When enabled, command groups assignment that is part of the User Group configuration and user access that is part of Application Domain configuration are ignored.
on Applies RBM to the CLI. The access profile applies to both the WebGUI and the CLI. off (Default) Does not apply RBM to the CLI. The access profile applies to the WebGUI only.

entry.name: apply_cli_rbmsettings_descr_746
entry.text: Specifies whether RBM applies to the CLI

entry.name: au_cache_mode_rbmsettings_help_747
entry.text:
cacheMethod must take one of the following values:
absolute specifies that user authentication results are cached for the period of time (the explicit TTL) set by the au-cache-ttl command. disabled specifies that user authentication results are not cached. Consequently, user access requests are always authenticated. maximum specifies that the TTL (if any) contained in an authentication response is compared with the explicit TTL (set by the au-cache-ttl command), and that the larger value is used. minimum specifies that the TTL (if any) contained in an authentication response is compared with the explicit TTL (set by the au-cache-ttl command), and that the smaller value is used. For example:
au-cache-mode absolute specifies that authentication responses are cached for the period of time specified by the au-cache-ttl command.

entry.name: au_cache_mode_rbmsettings_descr_747
entry.text: Specifies the authentication cache mode

entry.name: au_cache_ttl_rbmsettings_help_748
entry.text:
Meaningful when the cache method is absolute, maximum, or minimum; not used when the cache method is disabled. cacheLifetime is an integer, within the range 1 through 86400 (with a default of 600), that sets the explicit cache lifetime in seconds. If the cache method is absolute, this value is used to set the cache lifetime. If the cache method is maximum or minimum, this value is used in conjunction with the ttl (if any) contained in an authentication response to set the cache lifetime. For example:
au-cache-ttl 900 sets a cache lifetime of 15 minutes (900 seconds).

entry.name: au_cache_ttl_rbmsettings_descr_748
entry.text: Specifies the authentication cache lifetime

entry.name: au_custom_url_rbmsettings_help_749
entry.text:
Meaningful only when the authentication method is custom; not used when the authentication method is ldap, local, radius, or xmlfile. stylesheetURL is a URL that identifies the stylesheet used to make authentication decisions. For example:
au-custom-url store:///rbm.xsl identifies rbm.xsl in the store: directory as the stylesheet used to make authentication decisions.

entry.name: au_custom_url_rbmsettings_descr_749
entry.text: Locates the stylesheet used for user authentication

entry.name: au_info_url_rbmsettings_help_750
entry.text:
Meaningful only when the authentication method is xmlfile; not used when the authentication method is custom, ldap, local, or radius. fileURL is a URL that identifies the XML file used to make authentication decisions. For example:
au-custom-url store:///RBMInfo.xsl identifies RBMInfo.xml in the store: directory as the XML file used to make authentication decisions.

entry.name: au_info_url_rbmsettings_descr_750
entry.text: Locates the stylesheet used for user authentication

entry.name: au_ldap_readtimeout_rbmsettings_help_751
entry.text:
Specifies the number of seconds that the DataPower Gateway waits for a response from the LDAP server before terminating a connection.
This command is relevant when the authentication method defined with the au-method command is ldap and when the LDAP search for group name defined with the au-ldap-search command is enabled.
The default value is 60 seconds. For example:
ldap-readtimeout 40 Specifies a timeout of 40 seconds after which DataPower will terminate a connection to LDAP server if there is no response from it.

entry.name: au_ldap_readtimeout_rbmsettings_descr_751
entry.text: Provides a timeout to terminate hanging LDAP connections

entry.name: au_ldap_bind_dn_rbmsettings_help_752
entry.text:
Specifies the login DN to access the LDAP server. This command is relevant when the authentication method defined with the au-method command is ldap and when the LDAP search for group name defined with the au-ldap-search command is enabled.
DN The login DN

entry.name: au_ldap_bind_dn_rbmsettings_descr_752
entry.text: Specifies the DN to access the LDAP server

entry.name: au_ldap_bind_password_rbmsettings_help_753
entry.text:
Specifies the password for the login DN to access the LDAP server. This command is relevant when the authentication method defined with the au-method command is ldap and when the LDAP search for group name defined with the au-ldap-search command is enabled. This property is deprecated and replaced with au-ldap-bind-password-alias.
password The password for the login DN

entry.name: au_ldap_bind_password_rbmsettings_descr_753
entry.text: Specifies the password to access the LDAP server (deprecated)

entry.name: au_ldap_bind_password_alias_rbmsettings_help_754
entry.text:
Specifies the password alias of the password for the login DN to access the LDAP server. This command is relevant when the authentication method defined with the au-method command is ldap and when the LDAP search for group name defined with the au-ldap-search command is enabled.
password-alias The password alias of the password for the login DN

entry.name: au_ldap_bind_password_alias_rbmsettings_descr_754
entry.text: Specifies the password alias of the password to access the LDAP server

entry.name: au_ldap_parameters_rbmsettings_help_755
entry.text:
Assigns the LDAP Search Parameters object to perform an LDAP search. The search retrieves the DN of the user.
This command is relevant when LDAP search is enabled with the au-ldap-search command and when the authentication method defined with the au-method command is ldap.
name The name of an existing LDAP Search Parameters object

entry.name: au_ldap_parameters_rbmsettings_descr_755
entry.text: Assigns an LDAP Search Parameters for an LDAP search

entry.name: au_ldap_search_rbmsettings_help_756
entry.text:
Indicates whether to retrieve the DN with an LDAP search.
on Enables an LDAP search for the group associated with the user. The login name of the user along with the LDAP Search Parameters will be used as part of an LDAP search. off (Default) Disables an LDAP search for the group associated with the user. The login name of the user along with the LDAP prefix and the LDAP suffix will be used to construct the DN for the user.

entry.name: au_ldap_search_rbmsettings_descr_756
entry.text: Indicates whether to retrieve the DN with an LDAP search

entry.name: au_method_rbmsettings_help_757
entry.text:
authenticationMethod must take one of the following values: client-ssl specifies that RBM user authentication services are performed by an TLS certificate from a connection peer. custom specifies that RBM user authentication services are performed by a stylesheet. ldap specifies that RBM user authentication services are performed by an LDAP server. local (the default) specifies that RBM user authentication services are performed by the local device. radius specifies that RBM user authentication services are performed by a RADIUS server. spnego specifies that RBM user authentication services are performed using Windows Integrated Authentication (SPNEGO). xmlfile specifies that RBM user authentication services are performed by an XML file. zosnss specifies that RBM user authentication services are performed by an NSS server. For example:
au-method LDAP specifies that RBM authentication services are performed by an LDAP server.

entry.name: au_method_rbmsettings_descr_757
entry.text: Specifies the authentication method

entry.name: au_server_host_rbmsettings_help_758
entry.text:
Meaningful only when the authentication method is ldap; not used when the authentication method is custom, local, radius, spnego, or xmlfile. Used in conjunction with the au-server-port command to identify the LDAP server that performs RBM authentication services. hostID is an IP address or host name that identifies the LDAP server that performs RBM authentication services. For example:
au-server-host 10.10.10.13 The LDAP server that performs RBM authentication services.

entry.name: au_server_host_rbmsettings_descr_758
entry.text: Identifies an LDAP server used for RBM authentication

entry.name: au_server_port_rbmsettings_help_759
entry.text:
Meaningful only when the authentication method is ldap; not used when the authentication method is custom, local, radius, spnego, or xmlfile. Used in conjunction with the au-server-host command to identify the LDAP server that performs RBM authentication services. hostPort is an integer (within the range 1 through 65535) that identifies a port that processes RBM authentication services. For example:
au-server-port 5445 The LDAP port that processes RBM authentication service requests.

entry.name: au_server_port_rbmsettings_descr_759
entry.text: Identifies an LDAP port used for RBM authentication

entry.name: au_kerberos_keytab_rbmsettings_help_760
entry.text:
Specifies the name and location of the keytab file that the client uses to decrypt the Kerberos ticket for the Kerberos server principal. Meaningful only when the authentication method is spnego; not used with the other authentication methods.
filename is name and location of the keytab file.

entry.name: au_kerberos_keytab_rbmsettings_descr_760
entry.text: Identifies the keytab for the Kerberos server principal

entry.name: au_valcred_rbmsettings_help_761
entry.text:
Assigns a Validation Credentials object to sue for validating the identity presented in a client certificate from a TLS peer. This command is relevant when the authentication defined with the au-method is ldap.
name The name of a Validation Credentials object

entry.name: au_valcred_rbmsettings_descr_761
entry.text: Assigns a Validation Credentials for TLS client certificate authentication

entry.name: fallback_login_rbmsettings_help_762
entry.text:
Indicates whether to use local user accounts as fallback users when the remote authentication method fails. With fallback users, locally-defined users can log in to the DataPower Gateway if the authentication method fails or in the event of a network outage that affects primary authentication.
disabled (Default) Indicates that no locally-defined user can log in. local Indicates that all locally-defined users can log in. restricted Indicates that only specific locally-defined users can log in. In this case, use the fallback-user command to define the specific, locally-defined users to allow as fallback users.

entry.name: fallback_login_rbmsettings_descr_762
entry.text: Specifies whether to use local users when remote authentication fails

entry.name: fallback_user_rbmsettings_help_763
entry.text:
Allows the locally-defined user to be a fallback user. This command is relevant when the fallback-login command is restricted. Invoke this command for each fallback user to allow.
user The name of an existing user.

entry.name: fallback_user_rbmsettings_descr_763
entry.text: Adds a locally-defined user as a fallback user

entry.name: ssl_client_type_rbmsettings_help_764
entry.text: The TLS profile type to secure connections between the DataPower Gateway and its targets.

entry.name: ssl_client_type_rbmsettings_descr_764
entry.text: TLS client type

entry.name: ssl_client_type_rbmsettings_help_765
entry.text: The TLS profile type to secure connections between the MQ Appliance and its targets.

entry.name: ssl_client_type_rbmsettings_descr_765
entry.text: TLS client type

entry.name: ssl_client_rbmsettings_help_766
entry.text:
Assigns the TLS Client Profile to secure communication with the LDAP credentials server. When specified, LDAP communication uses the configuration that is defined in the assigned TLS Client Profile. If not specified, communications do not use TLS and are nonsecure.
name Specifies the name of an existing TLS Client Profile.

entry.name: ssl_client_rbmsettings_descr_766
entry.text: Assigns an TLS Client Profile to access the LDAP server

entry.name: ldap_sslproxy_rbmsettings_help_767
entry.text:
The TLS proxy profile is deprecated. Use a TLS client profile. Meaningful only when the authentication method is ldap; not used when the authentication method is custom, local, radius, spnego, or xmlfile. sslProxyProfileName The TLS Proxy Profile used to establish a secure connection with the LDAP server that performs RBM user authentication services. For example:
ldap-sslproxy RBM-sslProxy The named TLS Proxy Profile as the one used to establish a secure connection with the LDAP server that performs RBM user authentication services.

entry.name: ldap_sslproxy_rbmsettings_descr_767
entry.text: Deprecated - Identifies the TLS Proxy used to access an LDAP server

entry.name: ldap_prefix_rbmsettings_help_768
entry.text:
Meaningful only when the authentication method is ldap; not used when the authentication method is custom, local, radius, spnego, or xmlfile. A typical LDAP authentication database contains a number of base DNs (distinguished names) with some number of users listed under each base DN. Base DNs generally take a format similar to the following:
dc=datapower,dc=com
Given the above example, the username Trudy is prepended with the prefix uid= to form (assuming an LDAP suffix of "dc=datapower,dc=com"):
cn=Trudy,dc=datapower,dc=com
DNprefix The DN prefix which is used in conjunction with a username and an LDAP suffix to access an LDAP database. For example:
ldap-prefix cn= specifies cn= as the LDAP DN prefix.

entry.name: ldap_prefix_rbmsettings_descr_768
entry.text: Specifies the LDAP DN prefix

entry.name: ldap_suffix_rbmsettings_help_769
entry.text:
Meaningful only when the authentication method is ldap; not used when the authentication method is custom, local, radius, spnego, or xmlfile. A typical LDAP authentication database contains a number of base DNs (distinguished names) with some number of users listed under each base DN. Base DNs generally take a format similar to the following:
dc=datapower,dc=com
Given the above example, the username Trudy is mapped (assuming a value of cn= as the LDAP prefix) to:
cn=Trudy,dc=datapower,dc=com
baseDN The base DN which is used in conjunction with a username to access an LDAP database. For example:
ldap-suffix dc=MegaCorp,dc=com specifies MegaCorp.com as the LDAP base DN.

entry.name: ldap_suffix_rbmsettings_descr_769
entry.text: Specifies the LDAP base DN

entry.name: ldap_version_rbmsettings_help_770
entry.text: Meaningful only when the authentication method is ldap; not used when the authentication method is custom, local, radius, spnego, or xmlfile. The default value is v2. Allowable values are v2 and v3.

entry.name: ldap_version_rbmsettings_descr_770
entry.text: Specifies the LDAP protocol version

entry.name: loadbalancer_group_rbmsettings_help_771
entry.text: Meaningful only when the authentication method is ldap; not used when the authentication method is custom, local, radius, spnego, or xmlfile.

entry.name: loadbalancer_group_rbmsettings_descr_771
entry.text: Specifies the LDAP load balancer group

entry.name: log_allowed_rbmsettings_help_772
entry.text:
Enables the generation of a log message that reports successful (authenticated) user log in. off (the default) specifies that successful logins are not recorded in the system log. on specifies that successful logins are recorded in the system log. With logging enabled, use the log-allowed-level command to specify the priority of the log message. For example:
log-allowed on enables the logging of successful logins.

entry.name: log_allowed_rbmsettings_descr_772
entry.text: Enables logging of successful user logins

entry.name: log_allowed_level_rbmsettings_help_773
entry.text:
Specifies the priority level of successful login messages. Use one of the following keywords (listed in descending order of criticality) to assign the message priority: emergency alert critical error warning notice info debug For example:
log-allowed-level notice successful login messages are logged with a priority of notice.

entry.name: log_allowed_level_rbmsettings_descr_773
entry.text: Assigns a priority to login messages

entry.name: log_rejected_rbmsettings_help_774
entry.text:
Enables the generation of a log message that reports unsuccessful (unauthenticated) user log in. off (the default) specifies that unsuccessful logins are not recorded in the system log. on specifies that unsuccessful logins are recorded in the system log. With logging enabled, use the log-rejected-level command to specify the priority of the log message. For example:
log-rejected on enables the logging of unsuccessful logins.

entry.name: log_rejected_rbmsettings_descr_774
entry.text: Enables logging of rejected user logins

entry.name: log_rejected_level_rbmsettings_help_775
entry.text:
Specifies the priority level of unsuccessful login messages. Use one of the following keywords (listed in descending order of criticality) to assign the message priority: emergency alert critical error warning notice info debug For example:
log-rejected-level error unsuccessful login messages are logged with a priority of error.

entry.name: log_rejected_level_rbmsettings_descr_775
entry.text: Assigns a priority to login messages

entry.name: mc_custom_url_rbmsettings_help_776
entry.text:
Meaningful only when the mapping credentials method is custom; not used when the mapping credentials method is local usergroup or xmlfile. stylesheetURL is a URL that identifies the stylesheet used to map authenticated users to an RBM policy that defines access privileges accorded to an authenticated users. For example:
mc-custom-url store:///rbm.xsl identifies rbm.xsl in the store: directory as the stylesheet used to map authenticated users to an RBM access policy.

entry.name: mc_custom_url_rbmsettings_descr_776
entry.text: Locates the stylesheet used for user credentialing

entry.name: mc_info_url_rbmsettings_help_777
entry.text:
Meaningful only when the mapping credentials method is xmlfile; not used when the mapping credentials method is custom or local usergroup. fileURL is a URL that identifies the XML file used to map authenticated users to an RBM policy that defines access privileges accorded to an authenticated users. For example:
mc-info-url store:///rbmPolicy.xml identifies rbmPolicy.xml in the store: directory as the XML file used to map authenticated users to an RBM policy.

entry.name: mc_info_url_rbmsettings_descr_777
entry.text: Locates the XML file used for user credentialing

entry.name: mc_ldap_readtimeout_rbmsettings_help_778
entry.text:
Specifies the number of seconds that the DataPower Gateway waits for a response from the LDAP server before terminating a connection. The default value is 60.
This command is relevant when the credentials mapping method defined with the mc-method command is local or xmlfile and when the LDAP search defined with the mc-ldap-search command is enabled.
For example:
ldap-readtimeout 40 Specifies a timeout of 40 seconds after which DataPower will terminate a connection to LDAP server if there is no response from it.

entry.name: mc_ldap_readtimeout_rbmsettings_descr_778
entry.text: Provides a timeout to terminate hanging LDAP connections

entry.name: mc_ldap_bind_dn_rbmsettings_help_779
entry.text:
Specifies the login DN to access the LDAP server. This command is relevant when the credentials mapping method defined with the mc-method command is local or xmlfile and when the LDAP search defined with the mc-ldap-search command is enabled.
DN The login DN

entry.name: mc_ldap_bind_dn_rbmsettings_descr_779
entry.text: Specifies the DN to access the LDAP server

entry.name: mc_ldap_bind_password_rbmsettings_help_780
entry.text:
Specifies the password for the login DN to access the LDAP server. This command is relevant when the credentials mapping method defined with the mc-method command is local or xmlfile and when the LDAP search defined with the mc-ldap-search command is enabled. This property is deprecated and replaced with mc-ldap-bind-password-alias.
password The password for the login DN

entry.name: mc_ldap_bind_password_rbmsettings_descr_780
entry.text: Specifies the password to access the LDAP server (deprecated)

entry.name: mc_ldap_bind_password_alias_rbmsettings_help_781
entry.text:
Specifies the password alias of the password for the login DN to access the LDAP server. This command is relevant when the credentials mapping method defined with the mc-method command is local or xmlfile and when the LDAP search defined with the mc-ldap-search command is enabled.
password-alias The password alias of the password for the login DN

entry.name: mc_ldap_bind_password_alias_rbmsettings_descr_781
entry.text: Specifies the password alias of the password to access the LDAP server

entry.name: mc_ldap_parameters_rbmsettings_help_782
entry.text:
Assigns the LDAP Search Parameters object to perform an LDAP search. The search retrieves the DN of the user.
This command is relevant when the credentials mapping method defined with the mc-method command is local or xmlfile and when the LDAP search defined with the mc-ldap-search command is enabled.
name The name of an existing LDAP Search Parameters object

entry.name: mc_ldap_parameters_rbmsettings_descr_782
entry.text: Assigns an LDAP Search Parameters for an LDAP search

entry.name: mc_ldap_search_rbmsettings_help_783
entry.text:
Indicate whether to search LDAP to retrieve all user groups that match the query. The default value is "off".
on Enables LDAP search for user groups. When enabled, the authenticated DN of the user and the LDAP search parameters are used as part of the LDAP search to retrieve all user groups that match the query. When a user belongs to multiple groups, the resultant access policy for this user is additive not most restrictive. off Disables LDAP search for user groups. When disabled, the authenticated identity of the user (DN or user group of local user) is used directly as the input credential.

entry.name: mc_ldap_search_rbmsettings_descr_783
entry.text: Whether to search LDAP to retrieve all matching user groups.

entry.text: The TLS profile type to secure connections between the DataPower Gateway and its targets.

entry.text: TLS client type

entry.name: mc_ssl_client_type_rbmsettings_help_785
entry.text: The TLS profile type to secure connections between the MQ Appliance and its targets.

entry.name: mc_ssl_client_type_rbmsettings_descr_785
entry.text: TLS client type

entry.name: mc_ssl_client_rbmsettings_help_786
entry.text:
Assigns the TLS Client Profile to secure communication with the LDAP credentials server. When specified, LDAP communication uses the configuration that is defined in the assigned TLS Client Profile. If not specified, communications do not use TLS and are nonsecure.
name Specifies the name of the TLS Client Profile.

entry.name: mc_ldap_sslproxy_rbmsettings_help_787
entry.text:
Assigns an existing TLS proxy profile to secure communication with the LDAP credentials server. When specified, LDAP communication uses the configuration that is defined in the assigned TLS proxy profile. If not specified, communications do not use TLS and are nonsecure.
name The name of an existing TLS proxy profile.

entry.name: mc_ldap_sslproxy_rbmsettings_descr_787
entry.text: Assigns a TLS proxy profile to access the LDAP server

entry.name: mc_loadbalancer_group_rbmsettings_help_788
entry.text:
Assigns an LDAP load balancer group instead of a single LDAP server for performing an LDAP search to retrieve the DN.
name The name of an existing load balancer group.

entry.name: mc_loadbalancer_group_rbmsettings_descr_788
entry.text: Assigns a load balancer group for credential searching

entry.name: mc_method_rbmsettings_help_789
entry.text:
Specifies the method used to map an authenticated user to an RBM policy that defines access privileges accorded to an authenticated user. mappingCredentialsMethod must take one of the following values,
custom specifies that an authenticated user is mapped to an RBM policy by a stylesheet. local (the default) specifies that an authenticated user is mapped to an RBM policy by assignment to a locally-defined user group. xmlfile specifies that an authenticated user is mapped to an RBM policy by an XML file. For example:
mc-method custom specifies that RBM credentialing services are provided by a stylesheet.

entry.name: mc_method_rbmsettings_descr_789
entry.text: Specifies the credentialing method

entry.name: mc_server_host_rbmsettings_help_790
entry.text:
Specifies the IP address or domain name of the credentials server.
host The IP address or domain name of the server.

entry.name: mc_server_host_rbmsettings_descr_790
entry.text: Identifies the server for credentials mapping

entry.name: mc_server_port_rbmsettings_help_791
entry.text:
Specifies the listening port on the credentials server.
port The port number of the credentials server.

entry.name: mc_server_port_rbmsettings_descr_791
entry.text: Identifies the port on the credentials server

entry.name: pwd_aging_rbmsettings_help_792
entry.text:
Specifies whether or not a user passwords must be periodically changed. If password aging is enabled, use the pwd-max-age command to specify the maximum shelf-life of a user password.
on requires the periodic change of user passwords. off (the default) allows continued use of user passwords.
For example:
pwd-aging on pwd-max-age 15 requires that user passwords must be changed every 15 days.

entry.name: pwd_aging_rbmsettings_descr_792
entry.text: Indicates whether passwords must be changed periodically.

entry.name: pwd_digit_rbmsettings_help_793
entry.text:
Specifies whether or not a user password must contain at least one numeric character.
on specifies that user passwords must contain at least one numeric characters. off (the default) does not require the use of numeric characters in user passwords.
For example:
pwd-digit on requires user passwords contain one or more numeric characters. "p4AssWord" is acceptable, but "password" and "PASSWORD" are not acceptable. pwd-digit off restores the default state. "p4AssWord", "password", and "PASSWORD" are acceptable.

entry.name: pwd_digit_rbmsettings_descr_793
entry.text: Indicates whether passwords must contain a numeric digit.

entry.name: pwd_history_rbmsettings_help_794
entry.text:
Indicates whether to control the reuse of recent passwords. When you prevent the reuse of recent passwords, use the pwd-max-history command to specify the number of recent passwords to retain. Retained passwords are ineligible for reuse.
on Prevents the reuse of recent passwords. off Allows the reuse of recent passwords. This setting is the default value.
For example:
pwd-history on pwd-max-history 3 Indicates that the three most recent passwords cannot be reused.

entry.name: pwd_history_rbmsettings_descr_794
entry.text: Indicates whether to control the reuse of recent passwords.

entry.name: pwd_max_age_rbmsettings_help_795
entry.text:
Specifies the maximum shelf life of a user password. If password aging is enabled, use the pwd-max-age command to specify the maximum shelf life of a user password.
shelfLifeDays is an integer within the range 1 through 65535, with a default value of 300, that specifies the maximum number of days that a password can be used.
For example:
pwd-aging on pwd-max-age 15 requires user passwords to be changed every 15 days.

entry.name: pwd_max_age_rbmsettings_descr_795
entry.text: Specifies the shelf life of a password.

entry.name: pwd_max_history_rbmsettings_help_796
entry.text:
Specifies the number of recent passwords that are retained. If password reuse is enabled, use the pwd-max-history command to specify the number of recent passwords to retain. Retained passwords are not eligible for reuse.
recentPasswordCount is an integer within the range 1 through 65535, with a default value of 5, that specifies the number of recent passwords retained.
For example:
pwd-history on pwd-max-history 3 Indicates that the three most recent passwords cannot be reused.

entry.name: pwd_max_history_rbmsettings_descr_796
entry.text: Indicates the number of recent password to retain.

entry.name: pwd_minimum_length_rbmsettings_help_797
entry.text:
Specifies the minimum number of characters that are required in a user password.
length The minimum password length. Enter a value in the range 1 - 128. The default value is 6.
For example:
pwd-minimum-length 10 Sets a minimum password length of 10 characters.

entry.name: pwd_minimum_length_rbmsettings_descr_797
entry.text: Defines the minimum length of passwords.

entry.name: pwd_mixed_case_rbmsettings_help_798
entry.text:
Specifies whether or not a user password must contain both uppercase and lowercase characters.
on specifies that user passwords must contain both uppercase and lowercase characters.
off (the default) does not require the use of both uppercase and lowercase characters in user passwords.
For example:
pwd-mixed-case on requires user passwords contain both uppercase and lowercase characters. "pAssWord" is acceptable, but "password" and "PASSWORD" are not acceptable.
pwd-mixed-case off restores the default state. "pAssWord", "password", and "PASSWORD" are acceptable.

entry.name: pwd_mixed_case_rbmsettings_descr_798
entry.text: Indicates whether passwords must contain mixed cased characters.

entry.name: pwd_nonalphanumeric_rbmsettings_help_799
entry.text:
Specifies whether or not a user password must contain at least one non-alphanumeric character.
on specifies that user passwords must contain non-alphanumeric characters.
off (the default) does not require the use of non-alphanumeric characters in user passwords.
For example:
pwd-nonalphanumeric on requires user passwords contain non-alphanumeric characters. "pAssWord#" is acceptable, but "password3" is not acceptable.
pwd-nonalphanumeric off restores the default state. "pAssWord#" and "password3" are acceptable.

entry.name: pwd_nonalphanumeric_rbmsettings_descr_799
entry.text: Indicates whether password must contain non-alphanumeric characters.

entry.name: pwd_username_rbmsettings_help_800
entry.text:
Indicates whether a password can contain the user name.
on The password cannot contain the user name. off The password can contain the user name. This setting is the default value.
For example:
pwd-username on Disallow passwords that contain the user name. Assuming the user name "Bob", a password of "Bobs1stpassword" is not acceptable. pwd-username off Restore the default state to allow passwords to contain the user name. Assuming the user name "Bob", a password of "Bobs1stpassword" is acceptable.

entry.name: pwd_username_rbmsettings_descr_800
entry.text: Indicates whether the password can contain the user name.

entry.name: restrict_admin_rbmsettings_help_801
entry.text:
Specifies whether to restrict access by the admin account to the command line on the serial port. When enabled, the access method for the admin account is through the command line when connected to the serial port. When disabled, the default state, the admin account can use all of the available access methods.
on Restricts the admin account to command line access on the serial port. off (Default) Allows the admin account to all access methods.

entry.name: restrict_admin_rbmsettings_descr_801
entry.text: Indicates whether the restrict admin to the CLI on serial port

entry.name: aaa_policy_stylepolicyaction_help_802
entry.text:
Used when the action type is aaa, identifies the specific AAA Policy implemented by this rule. aaaPolicyName The AAA Policy implemented by this action. For example:
type aaa aaa-policy Policy-1 implements the AAA Policy named Policy-1

entry.name: aaa_policy_stylepolicyaction_descr_802
entry.text: Applies a specified AAA Policy

entry.name: async_action_stylepolicyaction_help_803
entry.text:
Includes the named asynchronous action in the list of actions that must complete for an event-sink action to complete. This command is used only when the action type is "event-sink".
action the name of an asynchronous action.
For example:
type event-sink async-action async-fetch-1 async-action async-fetch-2 causes the event-sink to wait until the actions "async-fetch-1" and "async-fetch-2" have completed.

entry.name: async_action_stylepolicyaction_descr_803
entry.text: Includes an async action in the event-sink config.

entry.name: asynchronous_stylepolicyaction_help_804
entry.text:
Marks this action as asynchronous. When run, this action will begin execution and whatever action follows will begin execution immediately without waiting for the asynchronous action to complete. Any data placed in the Output context of an asynchronous action cannot reliably be used by any other action; errors generated by the action will be ignored by the remainder of the processing policy, and the network transaction may complete even if this action is still in progress.
Include this action in a subsequent event-sink action to cause processing to wait for this action to complete. By marking several actions asynchronous and then including these actions in an event-sink it is possible to execute actions in parallel.
For example:
type results input context-to-log destination http://log-server/log-me asynchronous causes the results action to send its input to "log-server", but processing does not wait for an acknowledgment or response.

entry.name: asynchronous_stylepolicyaction_descr_804
entry.text: Marks this action as asynchronous.

entry.name: attachment_uri_stylepolicyaction_help_805
entry.text:
Specifies the URI of an attachment that is to be stripped from a MIME multi-part package by the current strip-attachments action. This command is used only when the action type specified by the type command is "strip-attachments".
attachmentURI identifies a document attachment to be stripped from the MIME multi-part package.
For example:
type strip-attachments attachment-uri https://sona/TestBase/simple.xsl strips the specified document.

entry.name: attachment_uri_stylepolicyaction_descr_805
entry.text: Strips the specified document.

entry.name: condition_stylepolicyaction_help_806
entry.text:
Provides an XPath expression for the conditional action, and the name of the action to run if that XPath expression matches. This command is used only when the action type specified by the type command is "conditional". The action may contain multiple "condition" clauses; the first XPath expression that matches against the named input context causes the corresponding action to be invoked.
xpath gives the XPath expression to test against the input.
action gives the name of the action to run if the XPath expression evaluates true.
For example:
type conditional condition //*[local-name()='Request'] process-request condition . process-any causes the conditional action to run the action "process-request" if the message contains a "Request" element, or the action "process-any" otherwise.

entry.name: condition_stylepolicyaction_descr_806
entry.text: Specifies a condition and action for conditional actions.

entry.name: debug_stylepolicyaction_help_807
entry.text:
Specifies whether GatewayScript debug is enabled for the action. By default, debug is disabled.
Debug is available only for GatewayScript files. Therefore, for actions that support GatewayScript, you can enable debug. If the action calls a script file with a GatewayScript extension function, dp:gatewayscript(), then, you can debug the called script file.
To debug an action, you must add one or more "debugger;" statements at the points in your script where you want to start debugging.
on Enables GatewayScript debug for this action. off (Default) Does not enable GatewayScript debug for this action.

entry.name: debug_stylepolicyaction_descr_807
entry.text: Specifies whether GatewayScript debug is enabled for the action

entry.name: destination_stylepolicyaction_help_808
entry.text:
Used only when the action type is results or fetch. When used with fetch specifies the context in which to store the fetched resource. When used with results specifies the destination of the transmitted context contents. destinationURI can take the form of a DataPower variable, a context name, or a standard URI. For example:
type results destination https://10.10.110.19:9090 sends the input of the results action to the specified URI.
