type results destination var://context/mycontext/urllist sends the input of the results action to the list of URLs specified in the variable given. May be used with the multiple-outs option. type fetch destination tmp1 stores a fetched resource in the context named tmp-1

entry.name: destination_stylepolicyaction_descr_808
entry.text: Set fetch or results destination

entry.name: dynamic_schema_stylepolicyaction_help_809
entry.text:
Specifies a dynamic schema to be used in validation operations by the current "validate" action. This command is used only if the action type as specified by the type command is "validate". It identifies a dynamic schema used to validate incoming documents.
schemaName identifies the dynamic schema used for document validation.
For example:
type validate dynamic-schema https://sona/TestBase/validate.xsd specifies the dynamic schema used for validation.

entry.name: dynamic_schema_stylepolicyaction_descr_809
entry.text: Specifies the dynamic schema used for validation.

entry.name: dynamic_stylesheet_stylepolicyaction_help_810
entry.text:
Specifies a dynamic stylesheet to be used in document routing or transformation. This command is used to either route or transform documents when the action type is: route-action xform xformbin xformpi
stylesheetURL identifies the dynamic stylesheet used for document routing or transformation.
For example:
type xform dynamic-stylesheet https://sona/TestBase/xform.xsl specifies the stylesheet used for document transformations.

entry.name: dynamic_stylesheet_stylepolicyaction_descr_810
entry.text: Specifies the stylesheet for document transformations.

entry.name: error_input_stylepolicyaction_help_811
entry.text:
Specifies the input context for an on-error action. This command is used only if the action type as specified by the type command is "on-error".
errorInputContext identifies the input context for the on-error action. If no context is explicitly identified, the input context of the failed action is used by default.
For example:
type on-error error-input temp1 specifies temp1 as the input context for the on-error action.

entry.name: error_input_stylepolicyaction_descr_811
entry.text: specifies the input context for the on-error action.

entry.name: error_mode_stylepolicyaction_help_812
entry.text:
Specifies the operational response to an error. This command is used only if the action type as specified by the type command is "on-error".
errorMode is the operation mode and takes one of the following forms:
abort (the default) specifies that Processing Rule execution is ceased in the event of an error
continue specifies that Processing Rule execution continues with the next action in the event of an error
alternative specifies that rule processing invokes an alternative rule in the event of an error.
For example:
type on-error error-mode continue specifies continue as the error response mechanism.

entry.name: error_mode_stylepolicyaction_descr_812
entry.text: Specifies the error response mechanism.

entry.name: error_output_stylepolicyaction_help_813
entry.text:
This command is used only if the action type as specified by the type command is "on-error". If no context is explicitly identified, the output context of the failed action is used by default.
errorOutputContext identifies the output context for the on-error rule.
For example:
type on-error error-output trashCan specifies trashCan as the output context.

entry.name: error_output_stylepolicyaction_descr_813
entry.text: Specifies the output context for an on-error action.

entry.name: event_stylepolicyaction_help_814
entry.text:
Specifies the event that triggers a checkpoint. This command is used only if the action type (as specified by the type command) is "checkpoint". checkpointEvent identifies the event that triggers the checkpoint, and takes one of the following values:
AuthComplete (the default) signifies the completion of an authentication process
Fault signifies a fault condition
Request signifies the input of a client-originated document
Response signifies the input of a server-originated document
For example:
type checkpoint event fault specifies fault as the checkpoint trigger.

entry.name: event_stylepolicyaction_descr_814
entry.text: Specifies the checkpoint trigger.

entry.name: gatewayscript_location_stylepolicyaction_help_815
entry.text:
Specifies the location of the GatewayScript program to run.
location Specifies the location of the GatewayScript program with one of the following formats:
A URL. The prefix of the URL can be the local:, store:, or temporary: directory. When specifying the URL, use the absolute path to the file, such as, "temporary:///my_scripts/jsTest.js", or use a relative path, such as, "../my_scripts/jsTest.js".
A context variable that expands to a URL that specifies the file location. Use the "var://context/contextName/varName" format, such as "var://context/myContext/jsLocation".
A context. The context content runs as GatewayScript. Use one of the following formats: "var://context/name" "var://context/name/"
For example:
gatewayscript-location local://sub-dir/testscript.js Specifies that the action runs the script file named "testscript.js" that is in the "local://sub-dir/" directory.
gatewayscript-location var://context/myTestContext Specifies that the action runs a script that is in "var://context/myTestContext" context.

entry.name: gatewayscript_location_stylepolicyaction_descr_815
entry.text: Specifies the location of the GatewayScript file

entry.name: input_stylepolicyaction_help_816
entry.text:
Specifies the input context for the current action.
inputContext identifies the input context for the current action.
For example:
type extract input INPUT identifies INPUT as the input context for an extract action.

entry.name: input_stylepolicyaction_descr_816
entry.text: Specifies the input context.

entry.name: dfdl_settings_reference_stylepolicyaction_help_817
entry.text:
This command is used to specify which DFDL Settings object should be used to control the DFDL Settings for a DFDL schema directed parse or serialize. dfdl-settings The name of a DFDL Settings object. For example:
dfdl-settings-reference myDFDLSettings

entry.name: dfdl_settings_reference_stylepolicyaction_descr_817
entry.text: Specifies a reference to a DFDL Settings object to control the DFDL Settings for a DFDL schema directed parse or serialize.

entry.name: input_conversion_stylepolicyaction_help_818
entry.text:
This command is used only if the action type as specified by the type command is "convert-http" to translate non-XML content.
inputConversionMapName identifies the conversion map to use.
For example:
type convert-http input-conversion httpToXML specifies httpToXML as the conversion map used by the current convert-http action.

entry.name: input_conversion_stylepolicyaction_descr_818
entry.text: specifies the conversion map used by a convert-http action.

entry.name: input_descriptor_stylepolicyaction_help_819
entry.text:
Identifies the descriptor of the input to a Transform action.
descriptorURL A URL to the input descriptor, as understood according to the input-language.
If input-language is xsd, then descriptorURL must be a URL to an XML Schema (XSD) file.
If input-language is xml or json, do not specify an input-descriptor.
For example:
input-language xsd input-descriptor local://schemas/mySchema.xsd

entry.name: input_descriptor_stylepolicyaction_descr_819
entry.text: Specifies the descriptor of the input, understood according to the input-language

entry.name: input_root_name_stylepolicyaction_help_820
entry.text:
Specifies the root element in the DFDL model from which to start a parse. This command is meaningful only in the context of a DFDL parse.
inputName
Specify the root element with one of the following formats:
A namespace URL by prepending the name between braces ({}) before the local part. This syntax is known as an XML Universal Name.
A context variable that resolves to an XML Universal Name. Use the "var://context/contextName/varName" format, such as "var://context/myContext/inputName".
For example, if in the the DFDL schema, the target namespace is "http://example.com/messages" and the local element is <xsd:element name="Message">...</xsd:element>, the name should be {http://example.com/messages}Message.
The schema author might specify the root parse element with the ibmSchExtn:docRoot="true" element within the schema. For instance, <xsd:element ibmSchExtn:docRoot="true" name="Message">...</xsd:element>. However, the use of the DFDL input root name overrides this value.
Example:
input-language dfdl input-root-name {http://example.com/messages}Message

entry.name: input_root_name_stylepolicyaction_descr_820
entry.text: Specifies the root element in the DFDL model from which to start a parse.

entry.name: input_language_stylepolicyaction_help_821
entry.text:
Identifies the input language of a Transform action.
language-name The name of the input language.
xml The input is XML and is not type-assessed.
xsd The input is XML and is type-assessed against the provided schema.
json The input is JSON and is not type-assessed.
For example, to specify that the input is XML which is type-assessed against mySchema.xsd:
input-language xsd input-descriptor local://schemas/mySchema.xsd

entry.name: input_language_stylepolicyaction_descr_821
entry.text: Specifies the input language of a Transform action

entry.name: iterator_count_stylepolicyaction_help_822
entry.text:
Specifies the number of times a loop should run. During the loop, the service variable var://service/multistep/loop-count is set to the current iteration of the loop, starting at 1. This command is used only if the action type as specified by the type command is "for-each", and the loop type as specified by the iterator-type command is "count".
count specifies the number of times the loop action should run.
For example:
type for-each iterator-type count iterator-count 4 loop-action transformer runs the "transformer" action 4 times.

entry.name: iterator_count_stylepolicyaction_descr_822
entry.text: Specifies a fixed count for a loop.

entry.name: iterator_expression_stylepolicyaction_help_823
entry.text:
This XPath expression is applied to the input context of a loop. The loop action runs once for each item in the node set the XPath expression produces, with the service variable var://service/multistep/loop-iterator set to the matching node. This command is used only if the action type as specified by the type command is "for-each", and the loop type as specified by the iterator-type command is "xpath".
xpath specifies the XPath expression the loop should use.
For example:
type for-each input INPUT iterator-type xpath iterator-expression //*[local-name()='item'] loop-action transformer runs the "transformer" action once for each "item" element in the INPUT context.

entry.name: iterator_expression_stylepolicyaction_descr_823
entry.text: Specifies an XPath expression for a loop.

entry.name: iterator_type_stylepolicyaction_help_824
entry.text:
A for-each action can run for a fixed number of iterations, or it may apply an XPath expression to an input context and run an action once for each matching node. This indicates whether the loop runs for a fixed count or using an XPath expression. The iterator-count and iterator-xpath commands give more details on the loop. This command is used only if the action type as specified by the type command is "for-each".
count and xpath are mutually exclusive options indicating whether the loop runs with a fixed count or using an XPath expression.
For example:
type for-each input INPUT iterator-type xpath iterator-expression //*[local-name()='item'] loop-action transformer runs the "transformer" action once for each "item" element in the INPUT context.

entry.name: iterator_type_stylepolicyaction_descr_824
entry.text: Specifies the type of a loop.

entry.name: json_schema_url_stylepolicyaction_help_825
entry.text:
The json-schema-url command identifies a JSON schema used to validate incoming documents. This command is used only if the action type, as specified by the type command, is validate.
jsonSchemaURL Specifies the location of the JSON schema used for document validation with one of the following formats:
A URL. The prefix of the URL can be the local:, store:, or temporary: directory. When specifying the URL, use the absolute path to the file, such as "temporary:///mySchemas/Schema.jsv", or use a relative path, such as "../mySchemas/Schema.jsv".
A context variable that expands to a URL that specifies the file location. Use the "var://context/contextName/varName" format, such as "var://context/myContext/jsvLocation".
A context. The context content runs as JSON schema validation. Use one of the following formats: "var://context/name" "var://context/name/"
For example:
type validate json-schema-url local:///jsvSchema2.jsv uses the jsvSchema2.jsv schema for validation.

entry.name: json_schema_url_stylepolicyaction_descr_825
entry.text: Specifies a JSON schema for validation operations.

entry.name: log_level_stylepolicyaction_help_826
entry.text:
Specifies the priority of the message generated by the current log action. This command is used only if the action type as specified by the type command is "log".
logPriority specifies the message priority, and takes one of the following values: emergency alert critical error warning notice (the default) info debug
For example:
type log log-level warning specifies a log priority of warning.

entry.name: log_level_stylepolicyaction_descr_826
entry.text: Specifies a log priority

entry.name: log_type_stylepolicyaction_help_827
entry.text:
Identifies the message type (a group of related messages) that are transmitted by the current log action. This command is used only if the action type is "log".
msgType specifies the message type, and takes one of the following values: aaa all auth cert-monitor cli crypto file file-capture ftp http kerberos ldap mgmt mime monitor mpgw mq multistep network ocsp odbc schema slm smtp ssl system tam user useragent ws-proxy wsm-agent xmlfilter xmlfirewall xmlparse xmlroute xslt xsltmsg
For example:
type log log-type aaa specifies that the log action sends AAA messages.

entry.name: log_type_stylepolicyaction_descr_827
entry.text: Identifies the message type

entry.name: loop_action_stylepolicyaction_help_828
entry.text:
Specifies the action run in a loop. The named action's output context is replaced with the output context of the for-each action, or, if the multiple-outputs option is set, with a context with the same name and a number appended. This command is used only if the action type as specified by the type command is "for-each".
action gives the name of the action to run inside the loop.
For example:
type for-each input INPUT iterator-type xpath iterator-expression //*[local-name()='item'] loop-action transformer runs the "transformer" action once for each "item" element in the INPUT context.

entry.name: loop_action_stylepolicyaction_descr_828
entry.text: Specifies the action a loop runs.

entry.name: multiple_outputs_stylepolicyaction_help_829
entry.text:
Specifies that loop and results actions should generate multiple output contexts. If this option is set and this action's output is a named context "ctx", then iterations of the loop or individual targets of the results action will generate separate contexts "ctx_1", "ctx_2", and so on. This command is used only if the action type as specified by the type command is "for-each" or "results".
For example:
type for-each output out multiple-outputs iterator-type xpath iterator-expression //*[local-name()='item'] loop-action transformer runs the "transformer" action once for each "item" element in the INPUT context, generating contexts "out_1", etc.

entry.name: multiple_outputs_stylepolicyaction_descr_829
entry.text: Specifies that the action generates multiple outputs.

entry.name: named_inouts_stylepolicyaction_help_830
entry.text:
This command is used only when the action type is xformbin and the tx-map property contains a value. This property determines how to find the location of named inputs and named outputs that the binary transform uses. Valid values are as follows.
default The input and output contexts that are defined for the action. explicit The input contexts that the transform uses are explicitly defined with the named-input command as many times as needed. The output contexts are explicitly defined with the named-output command as many times as needed. dynamic (Deprecated) It is used by IBM Transformation Extender Design Studio to test its generated maps against the DataPower Gateway. This value is not valid for use on the DataPower Gateway during service development.
For example: named-inouts explicit named-input "ContactFileCard" "INPUT" named-input "SecondCard" "custom1" named-output "LabelCard" "OUTPUT" Sets the mode to explicit. The required named-input commands explicitly define the inputs for the transform. The required named-output command explicitly defines the output for the transform.

entry.name: named_inouts_stylepolicyaction_descr_830
entry.text: Identifies how to find the location of named inputs and named outputs

entry.name: named_input_stylepolicyaction_help_831
entry.text:
This command is used only when the action type is xformbin, the tx-map property contains a value and the named-inouts property is set to explicit. This command identifies the processing context containing named input data. Issue this command as many times as needed to identify all inputs. named-input The name of an input expected by the map. This must be the same as a cardname identified in the map file. context The name of the DataPower processing context that contains the input data identified above. You must arrange to fill this context with the expected input data. For example:
named-inouts explicit named-input "ContactFileCard" "INPUT" named-input "SecondCard" "custom1" named-output "LabelCard" "OUTPUT" sets the mode to explicit. The required named-input commands explicitly determine the inputs for the transform. The required named-output command explicitly determines the output for the transform.

entry.name: named_input_stylepolicyaction_descr_831
entry.text: Maps one named input to one processing context

entry.name: named_output_stylepolicyaction_help_832
entry.text:
This command is used only when the action type is xformbin, the tx-map property contains a value and the named-inouts property is set to explicit. This command identifies the processing context containing named output data. Issue this command as many times as needed to identify all outputs. named-output The name of an output expected by the map. This must be the same as a cardname identified in the map file. context The name of the DataPower processing context that contains the output data identified above. For example:
named-inouts explicit named-input "ContactFileCard" "INPUT" named-input "SecondCard" "custom1" named-output "LabelCard" "OUTPUT" sets the mode to explicit. The required named-input commands explicitly determine the inputs for the transform. The required named-output command explicitly determines the output for the transform.

entry.name: named_output_stylepolicyaction_descr_832
entry.text: Maps one named output to one processing context

entry.name: output_stylepolicyaction_help_833
entry.text:
outputContext identifies the output context for the current action.
For example:
type fetch output temp2 specifies the temp2 context as the output context for the current fetch action. For a fetch action, the output context is the context that contains the fetched resource.

entry.name: output_stylepolicyaction_descr_833
entry.text: Specifies the output context.

entry.name: output_type_stylepolicyaction_help_834
entry.text:
dataDescriptordescribes the outgoing data and takes one of the following keywords:
default Data type is determined by reading the content type field of the document; if the content type is XML or undeclared, the data is treated as XML. Otherwise, the data is treated as binary.
xml The data is treated and parsed as XML.
binary The data is treated as binary and unprocessed.
For example:
type fetch output-type binary characterizes the fetched data as binary.

entry.name: output_type_stylepolicyaction_descr_834
entry.text: Characterizes the data output.

entry.name: parameter_stylepolicyaction_help_835
entry.text:
This command is optionally used to specify a parameter-value pair for the current stylesheet.
name is the parameter name. value is the value assigned to the parameter.
For example:
type route-action parameter staticRoute 192.168.12.12 sets the staticRoute parameter to 192.168.12.12 for stylesheets used by the current route-action action.

entry.name: parameter_stylepolicyaction_descr_835
entry.text: Specifies a parameter-value pair.

entry.name: results_mode_stylepolicyaction_help_836
entry.text:
Specifies how the results action handles multiple targets. This command is used only if the action type as specified by the type command is "results".
first-available specifies that targets are dispatched one at a time; the action succeeds when the first target is reached successfully
require-all specifies that targets are dispatched in parallel; the action succeeds only if all targets are reached successfully
attempt-all specifies that targets are dispatched in parallel; the action succeeds if any target is reached successfully
For example:
type results input ctx destination var://context/ctx/urls results-mode first-available looks in the named context variable for a list of URLs to send to, and sends a copy of ctx to each in turn until one is successful.

entry.name: results_mode_stylepolicyaction_descr_836
entry.text: Specifies how the results action handles multiple targets.

entry.name: retry_count_stylepolicyaction_help_837
entry.text:
Specifies how many times a results action will retry when attempting to reach its targets. A count of 0 indicates that no retries will be attempted. This command is used only if the action type as specified by the type command is "results".
count specifies how many times to retry if reaching a target fails
For example:
type results input ctx destination http://log-server/log retry-count 1 indicates that, if the log server is not accepting requests, to retry once.

entry.name: retry_count_stylepolicyaction_descr_837
entry.text: Specifies how many times a results action retries.

entry.name: retry_interval_stylepolicyaction_help_838
entry.text:
Specifies how long a results action will wait before attempting to retry a connection to a target. A retry interval of 0 indicates that failed connections will be retried immediately. This command is used only if the action type as specified by the type command is "results".
ms specifies how long to wait before retrying
For example:
type results input ctx destination http://log-server/log retry-count 10 retry-interval 5000 specifies that 5 seconds should pass before attempting to retry a connection to the log server.

entry.name: retry_interval_stylepolicyaction_descr_838
entry.text: Specifies the delay before a results action retries.

entry.name: rule_stylepolicyaction_help_839
entry.text:
This command is used only if the action type, as specified by the type command, is call. This command identifies the rule invoked by the call action.
ruleName identifies the rule called by the action.
For example:
type call rule validateSOAP defines a call action that invokes the rule named validateSOAP.

entry.name: rule_stylepolicyaction_descr_839
entry.text: Specifies a rule.

entry.name: schema_url_stylepolicyaction_help_840
entry.text:
This command is used only if the action type, as specified by the type command, is validate. This command identifies a schema used to validate incoming documents.
schemaURL Specifies the location of the schema used for document validation with one of the following formats:
A URL. The prefix of the URL can be the local:, store:, or temporary: directory. When specifying the URL, use the absolute path to the file, such as, "temporary:///my_schemas/Schema2.xsd", or use a relative path, such as, "../my_schemas/Schema2.xsd".
A context variable that expands to a URL that specifies the file location. Use the "var://context/contextName/varName" format, such as "var://context/myContext/xsdLocation".
A context. The context content runs as schema validation. Use one of the following formats: "var://context/name" "var://context/name/"
For example:
type validate schema-url local:///soapSchema2.xsd uses the soapSchema2.xsd schema for validation.

entry.name: schema_url_stylepolicyaction_descr_840
entry.text: Specifies a schema for validation operations.

entry.name: slm_stylepolicyaction_help_841
entry.text:
This command s used only if the action type, as specified by the type command, is slm. This command identifies the SLM policy used by the current slm action.
slmPolicy is the name of the SLM policy.
For example:
type slm slm wsMonitor1 assigns the wsMonitor1 SLM policy to the current slm action.

entry.name: slm_stylepolicyaction_descr_841
entry.text: Identifies the SLM policy.

entry.name: soap_validation_stylepolicyaction_help_842
entry.text:
This command is used only if the action type, as specified by the type command, is validate. This command identifies the validation type performed on SOAP messages.
body, body-or-detail, envelope, and ignore-faults are mutually-exclusive key words that specify the validation type.
body validates the contents of the SOAP body element. body-or-detail validates the contents of the detail element for SOAP faults and the contents of the SOAP body element. envelope (the default) validates the entire message to include the contents of the SOAP envelope. ignore-faults performs no validation on SOAP faults; if the message is not a fault message, validates the contents of the SOAP body element.
This setting does not affect validating the INPUT context to ensure that it is a valid document. If you are validating an intermediate context, such as the result of an XSLT transform or an externally fetched document, this will not be implicitly validated as SOAP, and you may want to retain the default value (envelope) here to validate the entire document.
For example:
type validate soap-validation body specifies that only the SOAP body is subject to validation.

entry.name: soap_validation_stylepolicyaction_descr_842
entry.text: Specify SOAP validation type.

entry.name: sql_source_stylepolicyaction_help_843
entry.text:
sql-source is required when the action type is sql, and is otherwise unused. This command identifies the data source object used by the sql action. dataSourceName is the name of a data source object previously created with the sql-source command.
For example:
type sql sql-source db2source identifies db2source as the data source object used the current sql action

entry.name: sql_source_stylepolicyaction_descr_843
entry.text: Identifies the data source object used by an SQL action.

entry.name: sql_source_type_stylepolicyaction_help_844
entry.text:
sql-source-type is required when the action type is sql, and is otherwise unused. This command identifies the source of the SQL statement executed by an sql action. static (the default) identifies the SQL statement as the literal text specified by the sql-text command. stylesheet indicates that the SQL statement is derived by executing the stylesheet specified by the transform command against the contents on the context specified by the input command. variable indicates that the SQL statement is contained within the variable specified by the variable command.
For example:
type sql input initFilter sql-source-type stylesheet transform ODBC.xsl specifies that the SQL statement executed by the sql action is the result of applying the specified stylesheet, ODBC.xsl, to the contents of the initFilter context.

entry.name: sql_source_type_stylepolicyaction_descr_844
entry.text: Identifies the SQL Statement source.

entry.name: sql_text_stylepolicyaction_help_845
entry.text:
sql-text is required when the action type is sql and the sql-source-type is static and is otherwise unused. This command provides the SQL statement executed by an sql action. sqlStatement is a string that provides the literal text of the SQL statement to be executed by an sql action.
For example:
type sql sql-source db2Source sql-text "SELECT SSN BaseSalary FROM EmployeeSALES" provides the SQL statement executed by the sql action.

entry.name: sql_text_stylepolicyaction_descr_845
entry.text: Provides an SQL statement.

entry.name: sslcred_stylepolicyaction_help_846
entry.text:
The TLS proxy profile is deprecated. Use a TLS client profile. This command is used only if the action type, as specified by the type command, is route-set. This command identifies the TLS proxy profile to use to establish a secure (SSL-enabled) connection with the remote destination. For other action types, the command is not used.
sslProxyProfileName identifies the TLS Proxy Profile.
For example:
type route-set sslcred SSLProfile2 uses the SSLProfile2 profile to establish the connection.

entry.name: sslcred_stylepolicyaction_descr_846
entry.text: Deprecated - Identifies the TLS proxy profile.

entry.name: ssl_client_type_stylepolicyaction_help_847
entry.text:
This command specifies the TLS profile type. It is used only when the action type, as specified by the type command, is route-set. The TLS profile is used to establish a secure (SSL-enabled) connection with the remote destination. For other action types, the command is not used.
For example:
type route-set ssl-client-type client specifies that TLS client profile is used to establish the connection.

entry.name: ssl_client_type_stylepolicyaction_descr_847
entry.text: Specifies the TLS profile type.

entry.name: ssl_client_stylepolicyaction_help_848
entry.text:
This command identifies the TLS client profile to use to establish a secure (SSL-enabled) connection with the remote destination. This command is used only if the action type, as specified by the type command, is route-set. For other action types, the command is not used.
sslClientProfileName identifies the TLS client profile.
For example:
type route-set ssl-client-type client ssl-client SSLClientProfile2 uses the SSLClientProfile2 profile to establish the connection.

entry.name: ssl_client_stylepolicyaction_descr_848
entry.text: Identifies the TLS client profile.

entry.name: timeout_stylepolicyaction_help_849
entry.text:
Specifies how an event-sink action will wait for its named actions to finish. A timeout of 0 indicates that the event-sink will wait forever. This command is used only if the action type as specified by the type command is "event-sink".
ms specifies how long to wait for target actions
For example:
type event-sink async-action async-fetch timeout 1000 waits until the async-fetch action finishes, but not longer than 1 second.

entry.name: timeout_stylepolicyaction_descr_849
entry.text: Specifies how long an event-sink waits.

entry.name: transactional_stylepolicyaction_help_850
entry.text:
Enables (on) or disables (off) transaction-based processing in which messages are acknowledged only after the transaction has succeeded.
By default, transaction-based processing is disabled.

entry.name: transactional_stylepolicyaction_descr_850
entry.text: Acknowledges messages only if successful

entry.name: transform_stylepolicyaction_help_851
entry.text:
This command specifies a style sheet or transform file to use for transformation and routing. Specify the style sheet or transform file with a file name and path or as a file that resolves from a context variable or a context.
stylesheetURL Specifies the location of the style sheet with one of the following formats:
A URL. The prefix of the URL can be the local:, store:, or temporary: directory. When specifying the URL, use the absolute path to the file, such as, "temporary:///my_xsl/style2.xsl", or use a relative path, such as, "../my_xsl/style2.xsl".
A context variable that expands to a URL that specifies the file location. Use the "var://context/contextName/varName" format, such as "var://context/myContext/xslLocation".
A context. The context content runs as a style sheet. Use one of the following formats: "var://context/name" "var://context/name/"
For example:
type xform transform local:///processHeader.xsl identifies the processHeader.xsl style sheet for use by the current xform action.

entry.name: transform_stylepolicyaction_descr_851
entry.text: Identifies the style sheet or transform file for transformation and routing.

entry.name: transform_language_stylepolicyaction_help_852
entry.text:
Identifies the transformation language of a Transform action.
language-name The name of the transformation language.
For example:
transform-language xquery

entry.name: transform_language_stylepolicyaction_descr_852
entry.text: Specifies the transformation language of a Transform action

entry.name: tx_map_stylepolicyaction_help_853
entry.text:
Identifies the location of an IBM Transformation Extender map file that was converted for use by the DataPower Gateway. This argument takes the form of a URL. When present, the DataPower Gateway uses this map for a binary transformation.
map-url Identifies the local or remote location of a map file. When the map file is local, use a string in the <directory>:///<file> format such as local:///recipe.dpa. When the map file is remote, use a string in the <protocol>://<host>/<path_qualified_file> format, where the protocol is HTTP or HTTPS.
For example: tx-map local:///itxMap.dpa Locates the itxMap.dpa map file on the local: directory.

entry.name: tx_map_stylepolicyaction_descr_853
entry.text: Specifies the location of an XML Transformation Extender map file

entry.name: tx_mode_stylepolicyaction_help_854
entry.text:
Indicates the map processing mode.
dpa Processes the map in DPA mode. default Processes the map in exported-files mode. (Deprecated) no-map Disables mapping logic. Valid only with maps that have exactly one input card and one output card.

entry.name: tx_mode_stylepolicyaction_descr_854
entry.text: Indicates the map-processing mode

entry.name: tx_audit_log_stylepolicyaction_help_855
entry.text:
Indicates whether to enable generation of the IBM Transformation Extender audit log. When enabled, use the value as the context name to save the audit log. This command is valid in only DPA mode.
ctx-name Sets the context name to save the audit log.
For example: tx-audit-log my-audit-ctx Saves the audit log in the my-audit-ctx context. no tx-audit-log Disables the audit log.

entry.name: tx_audit_log_stylepolicyaction_descr_855
entry.text: Sets the context name to save the Transformation Extender audit log.

entry.name: tx_tlm_stylepolicyaction_help_856
entry.text:
You can use this command to determine which IBM Transformation Extender map to run when the exported map file that is identified by the tx-map command contains more than one map.
map-name Identifies the map to process.
For example: tx-map local:///itx.map.xml tx-tlm Orders Locates the itx.map.xml map file in the local: directory and selects the Orders map for processing.

entry.name: tx_tlm_stylepolicyaction_descr_856
entry.text: Specifies the top level Transformation Extender map to run

entry.name: type_stylepolicyaction_help_857
entry.text:
Specifies the action type. actionType takes one of the following values: aaa implements an AAA Policy call calls another processing rule checkpoint records information about each transaction for reporting via Web Services Management conditional enables if-then-else processing control convert-http converts non-XML input (for example, an HTTP POST or an HTML form) to XML cryptobin signs, verifies, encrypts, or decrypts binary data event-sink waits for asynchronous actions to complete extract applies an XPath expression to a context and stores the result in another context fetch obtains a remote resource and stores it in a specified context filter filters a document set with a specified stylesheet for-each enables processing loops gatewayscript runs the specified GatewayScript file jose-decrypt runs a JOSE decrypt action jose-encrypt runs a JOSE encrypt action jose-sign runs a JOSE sign action jose-verify runs a JOSE verify action log generates a log message and sends it to the specified destination on-error defines custom error-processing parse defines a parse action results transmits the contents of a context to a remote destination results-async asynchronously transmits the contents of a context to a remote destination rewrite implements a URL Rewrite Policy route-action implements a routing action route-set specifies dynamic routing setvar creates a variable slm implements the specified SLM Policy sql runs an SQL statement against a specified data source strip-attachments strips attachments from a MIME multi-part package validate implements schema validation xform performs as XSL transform using a specified stylesheet xformbin performs binary-to-XML transformation xformng performs a transform using a specified transform file xformpi performs as XSL transform using processing instructions internal to candidate documents method-rewrite rewrites the http method
For example:
type xform specifies an action type of stylesheet-based transformation

entry.name: type_stylepolicyaction_descr_857
entry.text: Specifies the action type

entry.name: urlrewrite_policy_stylepolicyaction_help_858
entry.text:
This command is required when the action type, as specified by the type command is "rewrite". This command is optional when the action type is: validate xform xformbin xformng xformpi
urlRewritePolicyName identifies the URL rewrite policy.
For example:
type rewrite urlrewrite-policy rewritePolicy1 identifies rewritePolicy1 as the URL rewrite policy implemented by the current rewrite action.

entry.name: urlrewrite_policy_stylepolicyaction_descr_858
entry.text: Identifies the URL rewrite policy.

entry.name: http_method_stylepolicyaction_help_859
entry.text:
Used only when the type is method-rewrite, assigns the http method value to the http request method line. methodValue is One of the HTTP method types, POST, PUT, DELETE, GET. For example:
type method-rewrite http-method PUT Rewrites the current HTTP method request line to use PUT

entry.name: http_method_stylepolicyaction_descr_859
entry.text: Rewrite the http method to the method value

entry.name: value_stylepolicyaction_help_860
entry.text:
Used only when the type is setvar, assigns a value to a variable. variableValue is the value assigned to the current variable. variableName can be an integer, a string, or a DataPower variable URI. For example:
type setvar variable value creates a variable and sets its value

entry.name: value_stylepolicyaction_descr_860
entry.text: Assigns a variable value

entry.name: variable_stylepolicyaction_help_861
entry.text:
This command is required when the action type, as specified by the type command, is "setvar". Otherwise, it is not used. After specifying the name of the variable, you must define its value using the value command.
variableName is the name of the variable.
For example:
type setvar variable customer value preferredAccount assigns the customer variable the value of preferredAccount for the current setvar action.

entry.name: variable_stylepolicyaction_descr_861
entry.text: Identifies a declared variable.

entry.name: wsdl_url_stylepolicyaction_help_862
entry.text:
The URL of the WSDL file that defines the operations used during the validate action. The WSDL file can reside on the local system or elsewhere on the network.
url Specifies the location of the WSDL file with one of the following formats:
A URL. The prefix of the URL can be the local:, store:, or temporary: directory. When specifying the URL, use the absolute path to the file, such as, "temporary:///mywsdl/mywsdl.wsdl", or use a relative path, such as, "../mywsdl/mywsdl.wsdl".
A context variable that expands to a URL that specifies the file location. Use the "var://context/contextName/varName" format, such as "var://context/myContext/wsldLocation".
A context. The context content runs as a WSDL. Use one of the following formats: "var://context/name" "var://context/name/"

entry.name: wsdl_url_stylepolicyaction_descr_862
entry.text: Specifies the WSDL URL

entry.name: xpath_stylepolicyaction_help_863
entry.text:
This command is required when the action type, as specified by the type command, is "extract". Otherwise, it is not used.
xpathExpression is the XPath expression.
For example:
type extract xpath .//Order_Number specifies the XPath expression for the current extract action.

entry.name: xpath_stylepolicyaction_descr_863
entry.text: Identifies the XPath expression.

entry.name: wsdl_port_stylepolicyaction_help_864
entry.text: The Qname of the WSDL port that defines the service traffic to be validated. The value should be a Qname of the form "{namespace-uri}local-part" or "*" for all ports defined in the WSDL. If specified, and not "*", only messages defined for the named port will be considered valid.

entry.name: wsdl_port_stylepolicyaction_descr_864
entry.text: Specifies the QName of the WSDL port to validate against

entry.name: wsdl_operation_stylepolicyaction_help_865
entry.text: The name of the WSDL operation that defines the service traffic to validated. The value should be the (unqualified) name of the operation or "*" for all operations defined in the WSDL file. If specified, and not "*", only messages defined for operations that match the specified name will be considered valid.

entry.name: wsdl_operation_stylepolicyaction_descr_865
entry.text: Specifies the name of the WSDL operation to validate against

entry.name: wsdl_message_direction_or_name_stylepolicyaction_help_866
entry.text: The name or direction of the WSDL input, output or fault that defines the service traffic to be validated. The value should be the name of one or more wsdl input, output, or fault components, or "#input" or "#output" for the request and response directions respectively, or "*" for all inputs, outputs and faults defined in the WSDL file. If specified, and not "*", only messages defined for inputs, outputs and faults that match the specified name or direction will be considered valid. Faults are considered valid for the response direction.

entry.name: wsdl_message_direction_or_name_stylepolicyaction_descr_866
entry.text: Specifies the name or direction of the WSDL input, output, or fault to validate against

entry.name: wsdl_attachment_part_stylepolicyaction_help_867
entry.text: The name of the WSDL message part that defines the content of a mime attachment. The value should be the (unqualified) name of the message part, which is the same as the part attribute on the corresponding mime:content component in the wsdl. When this property is not defined (or has the special value "*", the root mime part (the one bound to a soap:body) is validated.

entry.name: wsdl_attachment_part_stylepolicyaction_descr_867
entry.text: Specifies the name of the WSDL message part to validate an attachment against

entry.name: policy_key_stylepolicyaction_help_868
entry.text: The key is used to identify the table used to store action results. This table is passed to a remote monitoring service. This is typically read-only and is generated automatically by the DataPower Gateway.

entry.name: policy_key_stylepolicyaction_descr_868
entry.text: Specifies a key to collate action results to a monitoring service

entry.name: serialization_stylepolicyaction_help_869
entry.text:
Specifies the serialization representation of the JOSE action.
compact Compact serialization, URL-safe string. json JSON serialization, representation as a JSON object.
For example:
serialization Compact Specifies a JOSE action with Compact representation.

entry.name: serialization_stylepolicyaction_descr_869
entry.text: Specifies the serialization representation of the JOSE action

entry.name: jwe_enc_stylepolicyaction_help_870
entry.text:
Specifies the encryption algorithm of the jose-encrypt action.
algorithm The encryption algorithms of jose-encrypt action. Check documentation for the supported algorithm list.
For example:
jwe-enc A128CBC-HS256 Specifies A128CBC-HS256 as the encryption algorithm of the jose-encrypt action.

entry.name: jwe_enc_stylepolicyaction_descr_870
entry.text: Specifies the encryption algorithm of the jose-encrypt action

entry.name: jws_signature_stylepolicyaction_help_871
entry.text:
Specifies a jws-signature object of jose-sign action. The jws-signature object is used to generate the JWS object.
jws-signature object The jws-signature object is used in the jose-sign action. Use jws-signature to configure a jws-signature object.

entry.name: jws_signature_stylepolicyaction_descr_871
entry.text: Specifies a jws-signature object of jose-sign action

entry.name: jwe_header_stylepolicyaction_help_872
entry.text:
Specifies a jwe-header object of jose-encrypt action. The jwe-header object is used to generate the JWE object.
jwe-header object The jwe-header object is used in the jose-encrypt action. Use jwe-header to configure a jwe-header object.

entry.name: jwe_header_stylepolicyaction_descr_872
entry.text: Specifies a jwe-header object of jose-encrypt action

entry.name: jose_verify_type_stylepolicyaction_help_873
entry.text:
Specifies the identifier type of the jose-verify action.
type The identifier type of the jose-verify action. Check the documentation for available identifier types.

entry.name: jose_verify_type_stylepolicyaction_descr_873
entry.text: Specifies the identifier type of the jose-verify action

entry.name: jose_decrypt_type_stylepolicyaction_help_874
entry.text:
Specifies the identifier type of the jose-decrypt action.
type The identifier type of the jose-decrypt action. Check the documentation for available identifier types.

entry.name: jose_decrypt_type_stylepolicyaction_descr_874
entry.text: Specifies the identifier type of the jose-decrypt action

entry.name: signature_identifier_stylepolicyaction_help_875
entry.text:
Specifies a jose-signature-identifier of the jose-verify action. The jose-signature-identifier object is used to specify the match condition used to match the JWS signature.
jose-signature-identifier object The jose-signature-identifier object is used in the jose-verify action. Use jose-signature-identifier to configure a jose-signature-identifier object.

entry.name: signature_identifier_stylepolicyaction_descr_875
entry.text: Specifies a jose-signature-identifier object of the jose-verify action

entry.name: recipient_identifier_stylepolicyaction_help_876
entry.text:
Specifies a jose-recipient-identifier object of the jose-decrypt action. The jose-recipient-identifier object is used to specify the match condition that is used to match the JWE recipient.
jose-recipient-identifier object The jose-recipient-identifier object is used in the jose-decrypt action. Use jose-recipient-identifier to configure a jose-recipient-identifier object.

entry.name: recipient_identifier_stylepolicyaction_descr_876
entry.text: Specifies a jose-recipient-identifier object of the jose-decrypt action

entry.name: single_cert_stylepolicyaction_help_877
entry.text:
Specifies a certificate object of the jose-verify action. The certificate object is used to verify all JWS signatures.
certificate The certificate object is used in the jose-verify action. Use certificate to configure a certificate object.

entry.name: single_cert_stylepolicyaction_descr_877
entry.text: Specifies a certificate object of the jose-verify action

entry.name: single_key_stylepolicyaction_help_878
entry.text:
Specifies a private key object of the jose-decrypt action. The private key object is used to verify all JWE recipients.
key The private key object is used in the jose-decrypt action. Use key to configure a private key object.

entry.name: single_key_stylepolicyaction_descr_878
entry.text: Specifies a private key object of the jose-decrypt action

entry.name: single_sskey_stylepolicyaction_help_879
entry.text:
Specifies a shared secret key object of the jose-verify or jose-decrypt action. The shared secret key object is used to verify all JWS signatures or JWE recipients.
sskey The shared secret key object is used in the jose-verify or jose-decrypt action. Use sskey to configure a shared secret key object.

entry.name: single_sskey_stylepolicyaction_descr_879
entry.text: Specifies a shared secret key object of the jose-verify or jose-decrypt action

entry.name: direct_key_stylepolicyaction_help_880
entry.text:
Specifies a shared secret key object of jose-decrypt action. The shared secret key object is used to specify the key object when the JWE algorithm is 'dir'.
sskey The shared secret key object is used in the jose-encrypt action. Use sskey to configure a shared secret key object.

entry.name: direct_key_stylepolicyaction_descr_880
entry.text: Specifies a shared secret key object of jose-decrypt action

entry.name: strip_signature_stylepolicyaction_help_881
entry.text:
Specifies whether to write the payload in the JWS object to the output context.
on (Default) The payload in the JWS object is written to the output context implicitly. off The payload in the JWS object is not written to the output context.

entry.name: strip_signature_stylepolicyaction_descr_881
entry.text: Specifies whether to write the payload in the JWS object to the output context

entry.name: parse_settings_reference_stylepolicyaction_help_882
entry.text:
This command is used only when the action type is parse. A parse settings configuration defines the constraints on the documents to parse. You can configure the constraints by specifying a URL reference from which to retrieve the constraints definition. You can also specify a literal configuration string in XML/SOAP or JSON/RMI format that contains the constraints definition. You can also select a parse settings configuration object from the list in Object reference to retrieve constraints definition.
Precedence rules apply when the constraint for the same aspect of an input document is configured with more than one method.

entry.name: parse_settings_reference_stylepolicyaction_descr_882
entry.text: Enters the submode to configure parse settings

entry.name: parse_settings_result_type_stylepolicyaction_help_883
entry.text: This command is used only when the action type is parse. Specifies the language format to save the parse metrics results. No parse metrics results are saved if the value of the parameter is 'none'.

entry.name: parse_settings_result_type_stylepolicyaction_descr_883
entry.text: Specifies the language format to save the parse metrics results

entry.name: parse_settings_result_location_stylepolicyaction_help_884
entry.text: This command is used only when the action type is parse. Specifies the name of the context to save parse metrics results. When "XML" or "JSON" is specified for parse metrics result type, the parse metrics results are saved in the specified context in the requested language format.

entry.name: parse_settings_result_location_stylepolicyaction_descr_884
entry.text: Specifies the name of the context to save parse metrics results

entry.name: original_schema_schemaexceptionmap_help_885
entry.text:
Identifies the target schema which is subject to the exception rules defined by the current Schema Exception Map. schema-url Identifies the target schema. For example:
original-schema store:///schema-12b.xsd specifies the target schema

entry.name: original_schema_schemaexceptionmap_descr_885
entry.text: Identifies the target schema

entry.name: rule_schemaexceptionmap_help_886
entry.text:
Adds an exception rule to the current Schema Exception Map. xpath is an XPath expression that identifies a schema element or elements subject to this rule allow Elements subject to this rule can be encrypted. require Elements subject to this rule must be encrypted. For example:
rule //SSN requireEncrypted Specifies that SSN schema elements must be encrypted

entry.name: rule_schemaexceptionmap_descr_886
entry.text: Adds an exception rule

entry.name: log_priority_slmaction_help_887
entry.text:
Specifies the log priority of the message that is generated when the current SLM Action is triggered.
Use the "no" form of this command to restore the default setting of "debug".
priority takes one of the following values: - emergency - alert - critical - error - warning - notice - info - debug
For example:
slm-action minorPenalty log-priority info Enters SLM Action Configuration Mode, creates the minorPenalty SLM Action, and raises the priority of action-generated messages to informational.
slm-action minorPenalty log-priority info no log-priority restores the default log priority.

entry.name: log_priority_slmaction_descr_887
entry.text: Specifies the priority of log messages.

entry.name: type_slmaction_help_888
entry.text:
Specifies the administrative procedure followed when the current SLM Action is triggered.
When the SLM Action type is "reject", the device drops all traffic until the monitored entity is within conformance levels.
When the SLM Action type is "shape", the device queues the next 2500 transactions for later transmission when the monitored entity is within conformance levels; after 2500 transactions have been queued, further transactions are rejected.
You must explicitly designate an SLM Action type to complete object configuration. slmActionType identifies the administrative procedure and takes one of the following values
log-only generates a log message when the current action is triggered and continues to process transactions.
reject generates a log message and drops traffic when the current action is triggered.
shape generates a log message and queues traffic when the current action is triggered.
For example:
slm-action minorPenalty log-priority info type shape enters SLM Action Configuration Mode, creates the minorPenalty SLM Action, raises the priority of action-generated messages to informational, and specifies that non-conforming transactions are queued.

entry.name: type_slmaction_descr_888
entry.text: Specifies the administrative procedure for an action.

entry.name: header_slmcredclass_help_889
entry.text: The name of the HTTP header to read to determine the value of the source IP address.

entry.name: header_slmcredclass_descr_889
entry.text: Identifies the header to extract IP address.

entry.name: match_type_slmcredclass_help_890
entry.text:
Identifies the match type, which specifies if all or selected members of the Credential Class provisionally identified by the CLI type command are subject to an SLM Policy.
A Credential Class defines a user group subject to an SLM Policy. It consists of:
- a credential type (defined by the type command), which specifies a method used to obtain credentials
- a match type (defined by this command), which specifies if all or selected members of the group identified by type are subject to the an Policy
- a credential value (defined by the value command), which is used when the match type is exact-match to identify specific members of a Credential Class subject to an SLM Policy
The aaa-mapped-credential and aaa-username types can only be used if the Document Processing that uses Credentials Class (as part of an SLM Policy) has previously implemented an AAA policy which provides the needed credentials.
The match type is ignored when the credential type is custom-stylesheet, and is otherwise required.
exact-match specifies that all members of the group defined by the CLI Type command are subject an SLM Policy.
per-extracted-value specifies that only a subset of the group defined by the CLI Type command is subject an SLM Policy. The subset is defined by one or more entries specified by the CLI Value command. The SLM Policy is enforced only in the event of an exact match.
For example:
slm-cred extranetPartner type client-ip match-type exact-match enters SLM Credential Class Configuration Mode and creates the extranetPartner SLM Credential Class. Specifies that Credential Class membership is based on source IP address, and that only a subset of IP addresses is subject to an SLM policy.

entry.name: match_type_slmcredclass_descr_890
entry.text: Identifies the match type

entry.name: stylesheet_slmcredclass_help_891
entry.text:
This command is meaningful only if the Credential Class type is "custom-stylesheet". In which case specifies the location of the stylesheet used to establish Credential Class membership.
Use the "no" form of this command to remove a custom stylesheet from the Credentials Class. stylesheetURL specifies the stylesheet location.
For example:
slm-cred extranetPartner type custom-stylesheet stylesheet local:///extranetPartner.xsl enters SLM Credential Class Configuration Mode and creates the extranetPartner SLM Credential Class. Specifies that Credential Class membership is determined by the XSLT stylesheet at the specified location.
slm-cred extranetPartner no stylesheet local:///extranetPartner.xsl enters SLM Credential Class Configuration Mode and removes the specified stylesheet from the Credentials Class.

entry.name: stylesheet_slmcredclass_descr_891
entry.text: Specifies the location of the stylesheet.

entry.name: type_slmcredclass_help_892
entry.text:
Specifies the type of group of credentials subject to an SLM Policy.
A Credential Class defines a user group subject to an SLM Policy. It consists of:
- a credential type (defined by the type command), which specifies a method used to obtain credentials
- a match type (defined by this command), which specifies if all or selected members of the group identified by type are subject to the an Policy
- a credential value (defined by the value command), which is used when the match type is exact-match to identify specific members of a Credential Class subject to an SLM Policy
The "aaa-mapped-credential" and "aaa-username" types can only be used if the Document Processing that uses Credentials Class (as part of an SLM Policy) has previously implemented an AAA policy which provides the needed credentials.
In the absence of an explicitly defined Credential Class type, the value "aaa-mapped-credential" is used by default.
slmCredType identifies the group of credentials and takes one of the following values:
aaa-mapped-credential specifies that the credentials returned by an AAA policy mapping credentials operation are members of this Credentials Class
aaa-username specifies that the user identities extracted by an AAA policy are members of this Credentials Class
client-ip specifies that members of this Credentials Class are defined by source IP addresses
custom-stylesheet specifies that members of this Credentials Class are defined by an XSLT stylesheet
mq-application specifies that members of this Credentials Class are defined by IBM MQ application names
For example:
slm-cred extranetPartner type client-ip enters SLM Credential Class Configuration Mode and creates the extranetPartner SLM Credential Class. Specifies that Credential Class membership is based on source IP address.

entry.name: type_slmcredclass_descr_892
entry.text: Specifies the type of the credentials group.

entry.name: value_slmcredclass_help_893
entry.text:
This command is meaningful only if the match type is "exact-match". In this case, defines specific members of a Credential Class as being subject to the provisions of an SLM Policy.
A Credential Class defines a user group subject to an SLM Policy. It consists of:
- a credential type (defined by the type command), which specifies a method used to obtain credentials - a match type (defined by the match-type command), which specifies if all or selected members of the group identified by type are subject to the an Policy - a credential value (defined by this command), which is used when the match type is exact-match to identify specific members of a Credential Class subject to an SLM Policy
You can use the value command one or more times to define any number of exact matches.
Use the "no" form of this command to remove an exact match value.
value The string that specifies the exact match criteria. - If the Credential Class type is "aaa-mapped-credential", provide a string in the format returned by the mapping operation. - If the Credential Class type is "aaa-username", provide a user name in the format extracted by the AAA Policy. - If the Credential Class type is "client-ip", provide an IP address and network-prefix mask. - If the Credential Class type is "mq-application", provide an IBM MQ application name. - If the Credential Class type is "custom-stylesheet", the value command is ignored.
For example:
slm-cred extranetPartner type client-ip match-type exact-match value 10.119.10.3/32 value 192.168.3.012/27 value 192.168.12.0/24 Enters SLM Credential Class Configuration Mode and creates the extranetPartner SLM Credential Class. Specifies that Credential Class membership is based on source IP address, and that only the defined subset of IP addresses is subject to an SLM policy. slm-cred extranetPartner no value 192.168.12.0/24 enters SLM Credential Class Configuration Mode and removes an exact match value from the Credential Class.

entry.name: value_slmcredclass_descr_893
entry.text: defines specific members as being subject to a policy.

entry.name: eval_method_slmpolicy_help_894
entry.text:
Specifies the SLM Policy behavior in the event that an action is triggered. The default behavior is to process all policy statements.
Use the "no" form of this command to delete the current behavior and use the default behavior, execute-all-statements.
policyBehavior takes one of the following values:
execute-all-statements (Default) indicates that policy execution continues until all associated statements have been evaluated.
terminate-at-first-action indicates that policy processing stops any statement after the first control procedure (an SLM reject or notify action).
terminate-at-first-reject indicates that policy processing stops after the triggering of any action that drops traffic by an associated statement.
For example:
slmAction SLM-Policy-1 eval-method terminate-at-first-reject enters SLM Policy Configuration Mode, creates the SLM-Policy-1 SLM Policy, and specifies that Policy processing ceases when a called action drops traffic.
slmAction SLM-Policy-1 no eval-method eval-method execute-all-statements deletes the existing policy behavior and assigns a new behavior (execute-all-statements).

entry.name: eval_method_slmpolicy_descr_894
entry.text: Specifies the behavior of an action.

entry.name: peer_group_slmpolicy_help_895
entry.text:
Associates a named SLM Monitoring Peer Group with the current SLM Policy. Assignment of an SLM Monitoring Peer Group enables SLM date aggregation and sharing across similarly configured DataPower devices.
peerGroupName identifies the associated SLM Monitoring Peer Group.
For example:
slmAction SLM-Policy-1 peer-group SLM-Group-1 enters SLM Policy Configuration Mode and associates the SLM-Group-1 SLM Peer Group with the current SLM Policy.

entry.name: peer_group_slmpolicy_descr_895
entry.text: Associates a peer group.

entry.name: statement_slmpolicy_help_896
entry.text:
Constructs an SLM Statement and adds the statement to the current SLM Policy.
Use the "no" form of this command to delete an SLM Statement from the current SLM Policy.
index Specifies the order in which to execute the statement. Statements are executed in least to greatest value.
Note: Adding a statement with the same index value as an existing statement deletes the existing statement and replaces it with the newer statement.
slmLogString Specifies the identifier for this statement. The identifier appears in log messages.
slmCredentialClass Specifies the name of the SLM Credentials Class to assign to the SLM Policy.
slmResourceClass Specifies the name of the SLM Resource Class to assign to the SLM Policy.
slmSchedule Specifies the name of the SLM Schedule to assign to the SLM Policy.
slmAction Specifies the name of the SLM Action to assign to the SLM Policy.
thresholdIntervalLength Specifies the SLM Policy-specific measurement interval in seconds. When the threshold interval type is "moving", the maximum threshold interval length is 65535 seconds.
thresholdIntervalType Specifies the threshold type. For the token-bucket algorithm, latency and payload threshold types do not apply.
concurrent Specifies that transactions are measured at the time they are received rather than in intervals. The threshold level specifies the number of concurrent transactions that can be processed at a time before the threshold is enforced.
"concurrent" is only valid with the "count-all" threshold type and cannot be used with the "token-bucket" algorithm. The interval length is not relevant when the interval type is "concurrent".
fixed Specifies a discrete time block for the interval length; for example, an interval length of 3600 with an interval type of "fixed" results in hourly measurements.
moving Specifies a sliding time block for the interval length; for example, an interval length of 900 with an interval type of "moving" results in sliding measurements over the last 15 minutes.
thresholdAlgorithm Specifies the threshold methodology.
greater-than Specifies a simple numeric relationship.
high-low-thresholds Specifies a methodology that triggers after the high threshold and continues to trigger until the high-low threshold is achieved.
less-than Specifies a simple numeric relationship.
token-bucket Specifies a rate-based methodology and allows bursting.
thresholdType Specifies the threshold measurement target.
count-all Specifies that the threshold measures all requests for the resource set identified by SLM Resource Class.
count-errors Specifies that the threshold measures only errors.
latency-backend Specifies that the threshold measures device-to-server latency.
latency-internal Specifies that the threshold measures internal latency (processing time).
latency-total Specifies that the threshold measures both device-to-server latency and internal latency.
payload-request Specifies that the threshold measures the payload for only the request message.
payload-response Specifies that the threshold measures the payload for only the response message.
payload-total Specifies that the threshold measures the payload for both the request message and the response message.
thresholdLevel Specifies the count or value that triggers the control procedure for the SLM Action. If the algorithm is "high-low-thresholds", defines the high threshold.
highLowReleaseLevel If the algorithm is "high-low-thresholds", specifies the low threshold. For all other algorithms, enter 0.
burstLimit If the algorithm is "token-bucket", specifies the maximum burst. Enter a value that is approximately twice the value of the threshold level. For all other algorithms, enter 0.
reportingInterval Specifies the base aggregation level in minutes for reporting of statistics. This value does not affect thresholding intervals.
maxRecords Specifies the maximum records to save per reporting interval.
off Designates a required keyword.
classCombinations Specifies the maximum number of records for the combination of credentials and resources.
For example:
slmAction SLM-Policy-1 statement 1 slmCred-1 slmRsrc-1 skedPeak minorPenalty 600 moving greater-than count-errors 3 0 0 5000 enters SLM Policy mode and creates a statement with the index value of 1.
slmAction SLM-Policy-1 no statement 1 enters SLM Policy Mode and deletes the statement with the index value of 1.

entry.name: statement_slmpolicy_descr_896
entry.text: Creates a statement for the policy.

entry.name: match_type_slmrsrcclass_help_897
entry.text:
Used when the Resource Method that is one of the following types defined by the type command to specify match criteria: - "aaa-mapped-resource" - "destination-URL" - "error-code" - "front-URL" - "reply-mq-qname" - "request-mq-qname" - "wsdl" - "wsdl-operation" - "wsdl-port" - "wsdl-service"
Not used when Resource Method is one of the following types, because these types test for existence only: - "concurrent-connections" - "custom-stylesheet" - "request-message" - "response-message" - "soap-fault" - "xpath-filter"
matchMethodology identifies the match procedure and takes one of the following values:
exact-match (the default), specifies that only a subset of the group defined by the CLI type command is covered this SLM Resource Class. The subset is defined by one or more entries specified by the CLI value command.
per-extracted-value specifies that all members of the group defined by CLI type command are covered by this SLM Resource Class.
For example:
slm-rsrc profitLossStatements type destination-url exact-match enters SLM Resource Class Configuration Mode and creates the profitLossStatements SLM Resource Class. Specifies that membership in the credentials class is defined by the destination URL, which is the URL sent to the target server. Coverage by the credentials class is restricted to a specific subset of destination URLs.

entry.name: match_type_slmrsrcclass_descr_897
entry.text: Specifies match criteria.

entry.name: stylesheet_slmrsrcclass_help_898
entry.text:
Used only when the Resource Method that is defined by the type command is "custom-stylesheet" to specify the stylesheet used to produce resource identification.
Use the "no" form of this command to delete a stylesheet-based credential-source. stylesheetURL identifies the stylesheet location.
For example: slm-rsrc profitLossStatements type custom-stylesheet stylesheet local:///extractResourceID.xsl identifies the extractResourceID.xsl local stylesheet as the source of resource identification data.
slm-rsrc profitLossStatements type custom-stylesheet no stylesheet local:///extractResourceID.xsl removes the extractResourceID.xsl local stylesheet as the source of resource identification data. Note that this command has no impact on the referenced stylesheet. The referenced stylesheet is not deleted by this command.

entry.name: stylesheet_slmrsrcclass_descr_898
entry.text: Specifies the stylesheet for resource identification.

entry.name: type_slmrsrcclass_help_899
entry.text:
Specifies the method that is used to obtain a resource value.
resourceIdMethod identifies the method used to identify the requested resource and takes one of the following values:
aaa-mapped-resource (the default), specifies that resource identities returned by an AAA map resource operation are members of the current SLM Resource Class.
Note: The aaa-mapped-resource method can only be used if the Document Processing that used this SLM Policy has previously implemented an AAA policy which provides the needed resource mapping.
concurrent-connections specifies that membership in this SLM Resource Class is defined by the presence of concurrent connections.
For this parameter, the threshold type must be count all and the algorithm type cannot be token-bucket.
concurrent-transactions All other active transactions.
For this parameter, the threshold type must be count all and the algorithm type cannot be token-bucket.
custom-stylesheet specifies that membership in this SLM Resource Class is defined by an XSLT stylesheet.
destination-URL specifies that membership in this Resource Class is defined by the destination URL (the URL output to the destination server, which may not be identical to the URL requested by the client device).
error-code specifies that membership in this SLM Resource Class is defined by error-code values.
front-URL specifies that membership in this SLM Resource Class is defined by the URL requested by the client, or by a rewritten client-requested URL.
reply-mq-qname specifies that membership in this SLM Resource Class is defined by the IBM MQ reply queue.
request-message specifies that membership in this SLM Resource Class is restricted to all client requests.
request-mq-qname specifies that membership in this SLM Resource Class is defined by the IBM MQ request queue.
response-message specifies that membership in this SLM Resource Class is restricted to all server requests.
soap-fault specifies that membership in this SLM Resource Class is restricted to SOAP fault messages.
uddi-subscription (deprecated) specifies that membership in this SLM Resource Class is defined by a UDDI Subscription key.
wsdl specifies that membership in this SLM Resource Class is defined by a WSDL file.
wsdl-operation specifies that membership in this SLM Resource Class is defined by WSDL operation names.
wsdl-port specifies that membership in this SLM Resource Class is defined by WSDL port names.
wsdl-service specifies that membership in this SLM Resource Class is defined by WSDL service names.
xpath-filter specifies that membership in this SLM Resource Class is defined by an XPath expression.
For example:
slm-rsrc profitLossStatements type destination-url enters SLM Resource Class Configuration Mode and creates the profitLossStatements SLM Resource Class. Specifies that membership in the credentials class is by the destination URL, which is the URL sent to the target server.

entry.name: type_slmrsrcclass_descr_899
entry.text: Specifies the method to obtain a resource value.

entry.name: subscription_slmrsrcclass_help_900
entry.text: When the resource type is UDDI Subscription, specify the subscription key.

entry.name: subscription_slmrsrcclass_descr_900
entry.text: Identifies the subscription key

entry.name: value_slmrsrcclass_help_901
entry.text:
Used when the Resource Method, which is defined by the type command, is one of the following types and when the Match Type is "exact-match" to specify which specific members of an SLM Resource Class are subject to coverage by the current resource class: - aaa-mapped-resource - destination-URL - error-code - front-URL - reply-mq-qname - request-mq-qname - wsdl - wsdl-operation - wsdl-port - wsdl-service
Not used when the Resource Method is one of the following types, because these types test for existence only: - concurrent-connections - custom-stylesheet - request-message - response-message - soap-fault - xpath-filter
Use this command as often as necessary to define all resource subsets covered by the current SLM Resource Class.
Use the "no" form of this command to delete a class member.
valueString is a string that identifies a specific resource subject to coverage by the current SLM Resource Class.
For example:
slm-rsrc profitLossStatements type destination-url exact-match value *www.datapower.com* enters SLM Resource Class Configuration Mode and creates the profitLossStatements SLM Resource Class. Specifies that membership in the credentials class is defined by the destination URL, which is the URL sent to the target server. Coverage by the credentials class is restricted to a specific subset of destination URLs that contain www.datapower.com.

entry.name: value_slmrsrcclass_descr_901
entry.text: Specifies member subject to coverage.

entry.name: wsrr_subscription_slmrsrcclass_help_902
entry.text: When the resource type is WSRR Subscription, specify the subscription that defines the membership.

entry.name: wsrr_subscription_slmrsrcclass_descr_902
entry.text: Identifies the subscription

entry.name: xpath_filter_slmrsrcclass_help_903
entry.text:
Used only when the Resource Method, which is defined by the type command, is "xpath-filter" to specify the XPath expression used to produce resource identification.
Use the "no" form of this command to delete an XPath-based credential source.
xpathExpression is the operative XPath Expression.
For example:
slm-rsrc profitLossStatements type xpath-filter xpath-filter @destination identifies the @destination XPath Expression as the resource identification tool.
slm-rsrc profitLossStatements type xpath-filter no xpath-filter @destination removes the @destination XPath Expression as the resource identification tool.

entry.name: xpath_filter_slmrsrcclass_descr_903
entry.text: Specifies the XPath expression for resource identification.

entry.name: days_slmschedule_help_904
entry.text:
Specifies a day of the week during which the schedule is operational. Use this command as often as necessary to specify all days during which the schedule is operational.
dayOfWeek takes one of the following values: - Sunday - Monday - Tuesday - Wednesday - Thursday - Friday - Saturday
For example:
sched weekEnds days Saturday days Sunday enters SLM Schedule Configuration Mode, creates the weekEnds SLM Schedule, and specifies Saturday and Sunday operation.

entry.name: days_slmschedule_descr_904
entry.text: Specifies the days that the schedule is operational.

entry.name: duration_slmschedule_help_905
entry.text:
Specifies the number of minutes per day that the current SLM Schedule is operational.
Use the command in conjunction with the start command to define specific time blocks during which this SLM Schedule is operational. minutes is an integer within the range 1 through 1440, with a default of 1440, that specifies the number of minutes that the current SLM Schedule is operational.
For example:
sched weekEnds days Saturday days Sunday duration 1080 start 24:00:00 enters SLM Schedule Configuration Mode, creates the weekEnds SLM Schedule that is active on Saturdays and Sundays from midnight to 6:00 PM (1080 minutes from midnight).

entry.name: duration_slmschedule_descr_905
entry.text: Specifies the duration of the schedule.

entry.name: start_slmschedule_help_906
entry.text:
Specifies the time-of-day at which the current SLM Schedule becomes operational.
Use the command in conjunction with the duration command to define specific time blocks during which this SLM Schedule is operational.
startTime specifies the time-of-day (expressed in hh:mm:ss format) at which the schedule becomes operational.
For example:
sched weekEnds days Saturday days Sunday duration 1080 start 24:00:00 enters SLM Schedule Configuration Mode, creates the weekEnds SLM Schedule that is active on Saturdays and Sundays from midnight to 6:00 PM (1080 minutes from midnight).

entry.name: start_slmschedule_descr_906
entry.text: Specifies the start time for the schedule.

entry.name: timezone_slmschedule_help_907
entry.text:
Specifies the time zone in which the schedule is operational. The default is the local time zone of the DataPower Gateway.
tzName One of the following values: - LOCAL - Pacific/Honolulu - America/Anchorage - America/Los_Angeles - America/Denver - America/Chicago - America/New_York - America/Halifax - America/Sao_Paulo - America/Noronha - Atlantic/Azores - Europe/London - Europe/Paris - Europe/Athens - Asia/Riyadh - Europe/Moscow - Asia/Karachi - Asia/Kolkata - Asia/Dhaka - Asia/Novosibirsk - Asia/Shanghai - Australia/Perth - Asia/Tokyo - Australia/Adelaide - Australia/Sydney - Asia/Vladivostok - Pacific/Auckland
For example:
sched weekEnds days Saturday+Sunday timezone Asia/Tokyo Enters SLM Schedule Configuration Mode, creates the weekEnds SLM Schedule, and specifies Saturday and Sunday operation in Japan.

entry.name: timezone_slmschedule_descr_907
entry.text: Specifies the time zone in which the schedule is operational.

entry.name: access_snmpsettings_help_908
entry.text:
This command is deprecated! Identifies an SNMP manager community granted access to the local SNMP agent, and specifies the access level accorded to the community.
community-name The name of the SNMP manager community. read-only Read-only access to the local SNMP agent. read-write Read-write access to the local SNMP agent. ip-address The optional IP address of a specific SNMP manager. In the absence of an IP address, access is granted to all community members.
For example:
