access public read-only grants read-only access to all SNMP managers using the community name, public. access private read-write 10.10.100.19 access private read-write 192.168.1.1 grants read-write access to two specific SNMP managers, using the community name, private. All other managers are denied access.

entry.name: access_snmpsettings_descr_908
entry.text: DEPRECATED -- use community

entry.name: community_snmpsettings_help_909
entry.text:
Identifies an SNMP Version 1 and Version 2c community (a group of SNMP managers) granted access to the local SNMP agent, the application domain to which access is granted, the access level accorded to the community, and optionally the set of IP addresses which may use this community. If there is no community configuration, access via SNMP Versions 1 and 2c is disabled. communityName The SNMP community string. applicationDomain The specific application domain visible to the SNMP community. read-only Allows read-only access to the MIB objects in the specified domain. read-write Allows read-write access to the MIB objects in the specified domain. none Denies MIB access to the specified domain and provides a method to temporarily disable SNMPv1/v2c access to this community. ipAddress An optional IP address and prefix length identifying the range of IP addresses from which SNMP requests for this community will be honored. In the absence of an IP address, access is granted for requests from any IP address.
For example:
community NOC application-1 read-write grants read-write access to the application-1 domain to all members of the NOC community. community NOC application-1 read-only 192.168.5.0/27 grants read-only access to the application-1 domain to all members of the NOC community whose IP address is between 192.168.5.0 and 192.168.5.31. All other community members are denied access.

entry.name: community_snmpsettings_descr_909
entry.text: Grants/defines access to a specified SNMPv1/v2c community

entry.name: snmp_community_snmpsettings_help_910
entry.text:
Identifies an SNMP Version 1 and Version 2c community (a group of SNMP managers) granted access to the local SNMP agent, the access level accorded to the community, and optionally the set of IP addresses which may use this community. If there is no community configuration, access via SNMP Versions 1 and 2c is disabled. community The SNMP community string. read-only Allows read-only access to the MIB objects. read-write Allows read-write access to the MIB objects. none Denies MIB access and provides a method to temporarily disable SNMPv1/v2c access to this community. ipAddress An optional IP address and prefix length identifying the range of IP addresses from which SNMP requests for this community will be honored. In the absence of an IP address, access is granted for requests from any IP address. For example:
community NOC read-write Grants read-write access to all members of the NOC community. community NOC read-only 192.168.5.0/27 Grants read-only access to all members of the NOC community whose IP address is between 192.168.5.0 and 192.168.5.31. All other community members are denied access.

entry.name: snmp_community_snmpsettings_descr_910
entry.text: Grants/defines access to a specified SNMPv1/v2c community

entry.name: port_snmpsettings_help_911
entry.text:
Specifies the UDP port monitored by the local SNMP agent for SNMP requests. By default, the agent monitors port 161. ip-address optionally identifies a specific device interface as the recipient of SNMP requests. In the absence of a specific IP address, SNMP requests will be handled on all interfaces. port-number The recipient UDP port. For example:
port 65161 designates port 65161 (on all interfaces) as the UDP SNMP port port 10.10.10.1 161 designates port 161 on interface 10.10.10.1 as the sole recipient of SNMP requests

entry.name: port_snmpsettings_descr_911
entry.text: Specifies the IP address and UDP port for the SNMP service

entry.name: ip_address_snmpsettings_help_912
entry.text:
Specifies the IP address monitored by the local SNMP agent for SNMP requests. By default, the agent monitors all local interface addresses. local-address identifies a specific device interface as the recipient of SNMP requests. In the absence of a specific IP address, or address 0.0.0.0, SNMP requests will be handled on all interfaces. For example:
ip-address 10.10.10.1 designates interface 10.10.10.1 as the sole recipient of SNMP requests

entry.name: ip_address_snmpsettings_descr_912
entry.text: Specifies the IP address for the SNMP service

entry.name: trap_target_snmpsettings_help_913
entry.text:
Specifies a recipient of SNMP traps and notifications generated by the local SNMP agent. ip-address is the IP address of the trap recipient. This address is unique for each recipient. port-number is the UDP port number that receives SNMP traps. If no port-number is provided, a default port number of 162 is used. community-name is the optional community-name used in the SNMP trap or notification message. If no community-name is provided, a default value of public is used. If Version 3 notifications are being sent to this destination, this argument is ignored. 1 SNMP Version 1 traps are sent to this ip-address. (This is the default if not specified.) 2c SNMP Version 2c notifications are sent to this ip-address. 3 SNMP Version 3 notifications are sent to this ip-address. user is the local SNMP Version 3 user to use when notifications are sent to this ip-address. Ignored for Versions 1 and 2c. Required for Version 3. noAuthNoPriv, authNoPriv, and authPriv are mutually-exclusive keywords that set the security level used for SNMP Version 3 notifications to this ip-address. The default (when this argument is not included) is authPriv. noAuthNoPriv No authentication or encryption of notifications. authNoPriv Authentication is included in notifications, but encryption is not. authPriv Authentication and encryption of the notifications is enabled. For example:
trap-target 192.168.1.1 OpenView specifies 192.168.1.1 (UDP port 162) as a recipient of SNMP Version 1 traps issued by the local SNMP agent. The trap recipient is accessed using a community name of OpenView.
trap-target 192.168.9.10 162 public 2c specifies 192.168.9.10 (UDP port 162) as a recipient of SNMP Version 2c notifications issued by the local SNMP agent. The community name in the notification is public. trap-target 192.168.9.11 162 ignore 3 trapUser authNoPriv specifies 192.168.9.11 (UDP port 162) as a recipient of SNMP Version 3 notifications issued by the local SNMP agent. They will be sent using the authentication parameters of trapUser, with no encryption (privacy).

entry.name: trap_target_snmpsettings_descr_913
entry.text: Specifies a recipient of SNMP traps

entry.name: version_snmpsettings_help_914
entry.text:
DEPRECATED. Specified the SNMP version number used by the local SNMP agent. Has no real effect. Select 1 (SNMP Version 1), 2c (SNMP Version 2x) or 3 (SNMP Version 3). By default, the SNMP agent uses SNMP Version 2c. For example:
version 3 switches to SNMP Version 3. version 2c reverts to SNMP Version 2c, the default version.

entry.name: version_snmpsettings_descr_914
entry.text: Identifies the SNMP version number

entry.name: user_snmpsettings_help_915
entry.text:
Defines an SNMP V3 user. The user must have been previously defined using the top-level user command, with the snmp-cred property. If that user has an snmp-cred with the local SNMP V3 engineID (or 0), that user will be granted SNMP V3 access to the local SNMP V3 agent. The SNMP V3 authentication and privacy configuration for the user are also part of the snmp-cred property. userName is the user name of the user. For example:
user alice password dontcare snmp-cred 0 sha password maplesyrup des password maplesyrup exit snmp user alice exit
Creates a user alice, who can access the SNMP agent using SNMPv3.

entry.name: user_snmpsettings_descr_915
entry.text: Defines an SNMP V3 user

entry.name: context_snmpsettings_help_916
entry.text:
Maps an SNMPv3 context to a particular application domain. The default SNMPv3 context (empty string) is always present, and accesses the IETF MIBs, and the Enterprise MIB objects for the 'default' application domain. Additional SNMPv3 contexts may be added, they only see the Enterprise MIB objects, for the specified application domain. context The string that is the SNMPv3 context to create. applicationDomain The name of the application domain whose Enterprise MIB objects will be visible in this context. For example:
context trial testing Creates an SNMPv3 context named trial, which accesses the Enterprise MIB object instances related to the application domain testing.

entry.name: context_snmpsettings_descr_916
entry.text: Maps an SNMPv3 context to an application domain

entry.name: security_level_snmpsettings_help_917
entry.text:
Sets the minimum security level required for SNMPv3 access to the MIB using the SNMPv3 protocol. Access may be at a higher security level than specified here, but not lower. noAuthNoPriv, authNoPriv, and authPriv are mutually-exclusive keywords that set the minimum security level. The default (when this command is not used) is authPriv. noAuthNoPriv No authentication or encryption of the messages is required. authNoPriv Authentication of the messages is required, but encryption is not. authPriv Authentication and encryption of the messages is required. For example:
security-level authNoPriv SNMPv3 requests with valid authentication digests, and with or without encryption of their contents, are accepted and processed.

entry.name: security_level_snmpsettings_descr_917
entry.text: Selects minimum SNMPv3 security level

entry.name: access_level_snmpsettings_help_918
entry.text:
Selects what level of access to MIB objects is allowed for requests using the SNMPv3 protocol. read-only and read-write are mutually-exclusive keywords that control access. The default (if this command is not used) is read-only. read-only MIB objects may only be read (get, get-next, and get-bulk) using SNMPv3. read-write MIB objects may be read (get, get-next, and get-bulk) or written (set, if the object allows it) using SNMPv3. For example:
access-level read-write overrides the default access level of read-only for SNMPv3 requests, and allows setting those MIB objects that allow sets.

entry.name: access_level_snmpsettings_descr_918
entry.text: Selects SNMPv3 MIB object access level

entry.name: sql_source_kglobalconfig_help_919
entry.text:
Enters SQL Data Source Configuration Mode and creates a named data source. For example:
sql-source source-1 Enters SQL Data Source Configuration Mode and creates the SQL Data Source source-1

entry.name: sql_source_kglobalconfig_descr_919
entry.text: Enters SQL Data Source configuration mode

entry.name: username_sqldatasource_help_920
entry.text:
Assigns the username for the database connection. The account must have the necessary permissions to execute the relevant SQL statements.
Example: username dbuser1 Sets the username for the database connection to dbuser1.

entry.name: username_sqldatasource_descr_920
entry.text: Configure the username credential for the DB connection

entry.name: password_sqldatasource_help_921
entry.text:
Assigns the password for the database connection; used in conjunction with the username parameter. This property is deprecated and replaced with password-alias.
Example: password JHNddHFG1 Sets the password for the database connection to JHNddHFG1.

entry.name: password_sqldatasource_descr_921
entry.text: Configure the password credential for the DB connection (deprecated)

entry.name: password_alias_sqldatasource_help_922
entry.text:
Assigns the password alias for the password for the database connection; used in conjunction with the username parameter.
Example: password-alias sql-alias-2 Sets the password alias for the password for the database connection to sql-alias-2.

entry.name: password_alias_sqldatasource_descr_922
entry.text: Configure the password alias of the password credential for the DB connection

entry.name: id_sqldatasource_help_923
entry.text:
The data source ID is used to identify the target data source. This may be vendor-specific (e.g., an Oracle SID would be a valid identifier for an Oracle database).
Example: id Routing Sets the data source ID to Routing, the name of a database on the source host.

entry.name: id_sqldatasource_descr_923
entry.text: Configure the target SQL data source name

entry.name: oracle_objects_sqldatasource_help_924
entry.text: Enable this property to define additional Oracle support. When enabled, the DataPower Gateway runs the SQL configuration hosted in a runtime environment. To define these requirements, configure the SQL data source runtime settings in the default domain.

entry.name: oracle_objects_sqldatasource_descr_924
entry.text: Enables Oracle object support

entry.name: oracle_datasource_type_sqldatasource_help_925
entry.text:
When the database type is Oracle, indicates the type of identifier that the id command defines.
SID (Default) Indicates that the identifier is an Oracle system identifier (SID). The SID is a unique name for an Oracle database instance. ServiceName Indicates that the identifier is an Oracle service name. The service name is a domain-qualified database name. This global database name is defined during installation or database creation.

entry.name: oracle_datasource_type_sqldatasource_descr_925
entry.text: Sets the type of identifier for an Oracle data source.

entry.name: host_sqldatasource_help_926
entry.text:
The hostname where the SQL data source resides. This can be either the IP address or a host name. When load-balancing is enabled for a DB2 data source on z/OS, enter the Sysplex DVIPA.
Example: host 10.10.1.200 Identifies a SQL data source on 10.10.1.200 host db.datapower.com Identifies a SQL data source on db.datapower.com.

entry.name: host_sqldatasource_descr_926
entry.text: The host for the target SQL data source

entry.name: port_sqldatasource_help_927
entry.text:
The port on the host for the target SQL data source.
Example: port 10000 identifies a port value of 10000.

entry.name: port_sqldatasource_descr_927
entry.text: The port on the target SQL data source host

entry.name: limit_sqldatasource_help_928
entry.text:
Toggling this parameter will enable a limit to be specified on the amount of data returned from executing a single SQL statement. Used in conjunction with the "limit-size" command.
Example: limit on enables the limiting of the size of data returned from a single command. The size is set by the limit-size command.

entry.name: limit_sqldatasource_descr_928
entry.text: Set a limit on data returned from the SQL data source

entry.name: limit_size_sqldatasource_help_929
entry.text:
If the "limit" parameter has been set to yes, the value of limit-size indicates the maximum size (in kilobytes) of data that will be returned from a single SQL statement. When this limit is exceeded, the returned data may be truncated.
Example: limit-size 512 Limits the size of returned data to 512K bytes.

entry.name: limit_size_sqldatasource_descr_929
entry.text: The maximum size of data returned from a SQL statement

entry.name: db_sqldatasource_help_930
entry.text:
Identifies the type of database accessed by a Data Source object. DB2 -- identifies an IBM DB2 database IMS -- identifies an IBM IMS database MSSQLServer -- identifies a Microsoft SQL Server Database Oracle -- identifies an Oracle database Sybase -- identifies a Sybase database
Example: db Sybase Sets the type of database to Sybase.

entry.name: db_sqldatasource_descr_930
entry.text: Identifies the database type (vendor).

entry.name: sql_config_param_sqldatasource_help_931
entry.text:
Define optional but valid ODBC (or CLI) configuration parameters for your data server connection. Configuration parameters modify the behavior of the services that run with a data server. Some configuration parameters in the configuration file are informational and define characteristics about the environment. These configuration parameters cannot be modified.
name The name of the configuration parameter.
value The value for the configuration parameter.

entry.name: sql_config_param_sqldatasource_descr_931
entry.text: Defines configuration parameters.

entry.name: read_only_sqldatasource_help_932
entry.text:
All access can be restricted to read-only by enabling this property.
Example: read-only on allows only read-only access to the data source.

entry.name: read_only_sqldatasource_descr_932
entry.text: Disables any non-read operation

entry.name: maximum_connections_sqldatasource_help_933
entry.text:
Specifies the maximum number of concurrent connections that will be used to a database. Increasing this number may result in higher database throughput.
Example: maximum-connections 20 Specifies that at most 20 connections will be used to the database

entry.name: maximum_connections_sqldatasource_descr_933
entry.text: The maximum number of connections to the database

entry.name: connect_timeout_sqldatasource_help_934
entry.text: A connection timeout indicates the length of time in seconds that the DataPower Gateway waits to establish a new connection to the remote data server. The minimum value is 0, which will disable the timeout. The default value is 15. The connect-timeout should be less than the query-timeout. With this configuration, the initial query has time to establish the connection to the remote data.

entry.name: connect_timeout_sqldatasource_descr_934
entry.text: The length of time to wait to establish a new connection

entry.name: query_timeout_sqldatasource_help_935
entry.text: A query timeout indicates the length of time in seconds that the DataPower Gateway waits for an SQL request to complete. The measured duration is from when the service sends the request to and receives the results from the SQL data server. The minimum and default value is 0. A value of 0 uses the standard timeout in the user agent. The query-timeout should be greater than the connect-timeout. With this configuration, the initial query has time to establish the connection to the remote data.

entry.name: query_timeout_sqldatasource_descr_935
entry.text: The length of time to wait for an SQL request to complete

entry.name: idle_timeout_sqldatasource_help_936
entry.text: Specifies duration in seconds that a connection from the connection pool can remain idle before the DataPower Gateway might release it. The minimum value is 0, which will disable the timeout. The default value is 180.

entry.name: idle_timeout_sqldatasource_descr_936
entry.text: The length of time that a connection can remain idle before it is released

entry.name: load_balancing_sqldatasource_help_937
entry.text:
For only DB2 on z/OS, enables DB2 workload balancing and DB2 automatic client reroute. When enabled, use the host command to specify the sysplex DVIPA as the data source host. The default value is 'off'.
Example: load-balancing on enables load balancing for the DB2 data source on z/OS.

entry.name: load_balancing_sqldatasource_descr_937
entry.text: Enables DB2 load balancing on z/OS

entry.name: acl_xtcprotocolhandler_help_938
entry.text:
Assigns a named Access Control List (ACL) to this stateful TCP Client Handler. Only those IP addresses explicitly granted access by the assigned ACL are able to access the stateful TCP Client Handler. aclName The ACL to be assigned to the handler. For example:
acl restrictiveACL-1 assigns the ACL named restrictiveACL-1 to the stateful TCP-1 Client Handler

entry.name: acl_xtcprotocolhandler_descr_938
entry.text: Assigns an ACL to the handler

entry.name: close_on_fault_xtcprotocolhandler_help_939
entry.text:
Specifies the stateful TCP Client Handler's response to a detected fault. With default settings is place, only connection termination, connection timeout, or a connection error closes the connection. close-on-fault changes this behavior and specifies that a connection is closed with the detection of any fault. For example:
close-on-fault specifies that both client and server connections are torn down when a fault is detected

entry.name: close_on_fault_xtcprotocolhandler_descr_939
entry.text: Tear down connections on any fault

entry.name: local_address_xtcprotocolhandler_help_940
entry.text:
Assigns an IP address to the Stateful TCP Client Handler. This is the local device address that the handler monitors for incoming client requests. After assigning an IP address, use the port command to identify the specific port to monitor. ipAddress is the local IP address monitored by this handler. The wildcard IP address "0" indicates that the handler monitors all active device addresses. For example:
local-address 192.168.1.1 specifies a local address of 192.168.1.1

entry.name: local_address_xtcprotocolhandler_descr_940
entry.text: Assigns an IP address to the handler

entry.name: port_xtcprotocolhandler_help_941
entry.text:
Assigns a port number to the stateful TCP Client Handler. This port number, in conjunction with the IP address specified by the local-address command, identifies the address:port monitored by this handler for incoming client requests. portNumber (an integer within the range 1 through 65535, with a default value of 80) identifies the port monitored by this handler. For example:
port 10001 specifies port number 10001

entry.name: port_xtcprotocolhandler_descr_941
entry.text: Assigns a port number to the handler

entry.name: remote_address_xtcprotocolhandler_help_942
entry.text:
Specifies the address of the stateful TCP server. After providing the server address, use the port command to identify the specific port to which the stateful TCP Handler relays traffic. ipAddress is the remote server address that receives stateful TCP traffic. For example:
remote-address 10.10.1.1 specifies a remote server address of 10.10.1.1

entry.name: remote_address_xtcprotocolhandler_descr_942
entry.text: Identifies the server address

entry.name: remote_port_xtcprotocolhandler_help_943
entry.text:
Specifies the stateful TCP server port. This port number, in conjunction with the IP address specified by the by the remote-address command, identifies the address:port monitored by the remote stateful TCP server. portNumber (an integer within the range 1 through 65535, with a default value of 80) identifies the server port. For example:
remote-port 10001 specifies remote port number 10001

entry.name: remote_port_xtcprotocolhandler_descr_943
entry.text: Identifies the server port

entry.name: ssl_xtcprotocolhandler_help_944
entry.text:
The TLS proxy is deprecated. Use a TLS client profile and a TLS server profile or TLS SNI server profile. Assigns a TLS Proxy Profile to the stateful TCP Client Handler. The handler uses the resources afforded by this proxy to establish a secure connection with client devices. sslProxyProfileName The TLS Proxy Profile assigned to this handler. For example:
ssl highSec assigns the TLS Proxy Profile named highSec to the handler.

entry.name: ssl_xtcprotocolhandler_descr_944
entry.text: Deprecated - Assigns a TLS Proxy Profile to the handler

entry.name: ssl_config_type_xtcprotocolhandler_help_945
entry.text:
Specifies the TLS profile type for the handler. Use proxy to specify TLS proxy profile, use server to specify TLS server profile, and use sni to specify TLS SNI server profile. For server and sni, TLS client profile can be optionally specified.
For example:
ssl-config-type server specifies that TLS server profile is used.

entry.name: ssl_config_type_xtcprotocolhandler_descr_945
entry.text: Specifies the TLS profile type for the handler.

entry.name: ssl_server_xtcprotocolhandler_help_946
entry.text:
Assigns a TLS Server Profile to the stateful TCP Client Handler. The handler uses the resources afforded by this proxy to establish a secure connection with client devices. sslServerProfileName The TLS Server Profile assigned to this handler. For example:
ssl-server high assigns the TLS Server Profile named high to the handler

entry.name: ssl_server_xtcprotocolhandler_descr_946
entry.text: Assigns a TLS Server Profile to the handler

entry.name: ssl_sni_server_xtcprotocolhandler_help_947
entry.text:
Assigns a TLS SNI server profile to the stateful TCP Client Handler. The handler uses the resources afforded by this proxy to establish a secure connection with client devices. sslSNIProfileName The TLS SNI Server Profile assigned to this handler. For example:
ssl-sni-server highSec assigns the TLS SNI Server Profile named highSec to the handler

entry.name: ssl_sni_server_xtcprotocolhandler_descr_947
entry.text: Assigns a TLS SNI server profile to the handler.

entry.name: ssl_client_xtcprotocolhandler_help_948
entry.text:
Assigns a TLS Client Profile to the stateful TCP Client Handler. The handler uses the resources afforded by this proxy to establish a secure connection with backend. sslClientProfileName The TLS Client Profile assigned to this handler. For example:
ssl-client highSec assigns the TLS Client Profile named highSec to the handler

entry.name: ssl_client_xtcprotocolhandler_descr_948
entry.text: Assigns a TLS Client Profile to the handler

entry.name: acl_statelesstcpsourceprotocolhandler_help_949
entry.text:
Assigns an Access Control List (ACL) to the current Stateless Raw XML Handler.
Only those IP addresses explicitly granted access by the assigned ACL are able to access the Stateless Raw XML Handler.
Use the "no" form of this command to remove an ACL from a Stateless Raw XML Handler.
aclName identifies the ACL to be assigned to the Stateless Raw XML Handler.
For example:
source-raw sansTCPHandler acl aclRestrictive-1 creates the sansTCPHandler Stateless Raw XML Handler and assigns the designated ACL to the handler.
no acl aclRestrictive-1 removes the aclRestrictive-1 ACL from the current Stateless Raw XML Handler.

entry.name: acl_statelesstcpsourceprotocolhandler_descr_949
entry.text: Assigns an ACL.

entry.name: local_address_statelesstcpsourceprotocolhandler_help_950
entry.text:
Specifies the device interface monitored by the current Stateless Raw XML Handler for client requests.
This command only sets the IP address for the Stateless Raw XML Handler. Use the port command to set the TCP port on which the Stateless Raw XML Handler listens.
ipAddress binds the Stateless Raw XML Handler to a single, specific interface:port pair. 0 binds the Stateless Raw XML Handler to portNumber on all enabled interfaces.
For example:
source-raw sansTCPHandler local-address 192.168.1.10 binds the current Stateless Raw XML Handler to the specified IP address.
source-raw sansTCPHandler local-address 0 binds the current Stateless Raw XML Handler to all enabled interfaces. This configuration is strongly discouraged for production environments.

entry.name: local_address_statelesstcpsourceprotocolhandler_descr_950
entry.text: Specifies the device interface monitored for client requests.

entry.name: persistent_connections_statelesstcpsourceprotocolhandler_help_951
entry.text:
With persistent connections enabled, the default state for both HTTP 1.0 and HTTP 1.1, the Stateless Raw XML Handler negotiates with the remote HTTP peer and establishes a persistent connection if agreeable to the peer.
With persistent connections disabled, the Stateless Raw XML Handler refuses to negotiate the establishment of persistent connections.
Alternatively, use the "no" form of the command to disable persistent connections.
on | off are mutually exclusive keywords that enable ("on") or disable ("off") the establishment of persistent connections.
For example:
source-raw sansTCPHandler persistent-connections off . . . persistent-connections on creates the sansTCPHandler Stateless Raw XML Handler and disables persistent connection negotiation. Subsequently, enables persistent connection negotiation, thus restoring the default state.
source-raw sansTCPHandler no persistent-connections . . . persistent-connections Same as the previous example.

entry.name: persistent_connections_statelesstcpsourceprotocolhandler_descr_951
entry.text: Enables or disables persistent connections.

entry.name: port_statelesstcpsourceprotocolhandler_help_952
entry.text:
Specifies the TCP port monitored by the current Stateless Raw XML Handler for client requests.
This command only sets the TCP port for the Stateless Raw XML Handler. This port applies to all configured local addresses. Use the local-address command to set the IP address on which the handler listens.
portNumber binds the Stateless Raw XML Handler to a specific port.
For example:
source-raw sansTCPHandler port 16000 binds the sansTCPHandler handler to port 16000.

entry.name: port_statelesstcpsourceprotocolhandler_descr_952
entry.text: Specifies the TCP port monitored for client requests.

entry.name: ssl_config_type_statelesstcpsourceprotocolhandler_help_953
entry.text:
Specifies the TLS profile type.
proxy (Default) Uses a TLS proxy profile to secure connections. server Uses a TLS server profile to secure connections. sni Uses a TLS SNI server profile to secure connections.

entry.name: ssl_config_type_statelesstcpsourceprotocolhandler_descr_953
entry.text: Specifies the TLS profile type.

entry.name: ssl_server_statelesstcpsourceprotocolhandler_help_954
entry.text:
Assigns a TLS server profile to the stateless raw XML handler.
sslServerProfileName is the name of the TLS server profile that is assigned to the stateless raw XML handler.
For example:
ssl-server serverprofile1 assigns the TLS server profile serverprofile1 to the stateless raw XML handler.

entry.name: ssl_server_statelesstcpsourceprotocolhandler_descr_954
entry.text: Assigns a TLS server profile.

entry.name: ssl_sni_server_statelesstcpsourceprotocolhandler_help_955
entry.text:
Assigns a TLS SNI server profile to the stateless raw XML handler.
sslSNIServerProfileName is the name of the TLS SNI server profile that is assigned to the stateless raw XML handler.
For example:
ssl-sni-server sniprofile1 assigns the TLS SNI server profile sniprofile1 to the stateless raw XML handler.

entry.name: ssl_sni_server_statelesstcpsourceprotocolhandler_descr_955
entry.text: Assigns a TLS SNI server profile.

entry.name: ssl_statelesstcpsourceprotocolhandler_help_956
entry.text:
The TLS proxy profile is deprecated. Use a TLS server profile or TLS SNI server profile. Assigns a TLS Proxy Profile to the current Stateless Raw XML Handler. Assignment of a TLS Proxy Profile is optional.
The TLS Proxy Profile identified here must already exist in the current application domain. Use the Global Configuration Mode sslproxy command to create a new TLS Proxy Profile.
sslProxyProfileName is the name of the existing TLS Proxy Profile assigned to the Stateless Raw XML Handler.
For example:
source-raw sansTCPHandler ssl SSL-1 assigns the TLS Proxy named SSL-1 to the current Stateless Raw XML Handler.

entry.name: ssl_statelesstcpsourceprotocolhandler_descr_956
entry.text: Deprecated - Assigns a TLS proxy profile.

entry.name: filter_stylepolicy_help_957
entry.text:
Identifies a default style sheet used for document filtering. This default style sheet performs XML filtering only if a candidate XML document fails to match any of the filter rules defined within the named processing policy. filter-url specifies the location of the default filtering style sheet. For example:
filter store:///validate.xsl identifies validate.xsl as the default filtering style sheet

entry.name: filter_stylepolicy_descr_957
entry.text: Identifies the default filtering style sheet

entry.name: xsldefault_stylepolicy_help_958
entry.text:
Identifies a default style sheet used for document transformation. This default style sheet performs transformation only if a candidate XML document fails to match any of the transformation rules defined within the named processing policy and if the document contains no internal processing instructions. stylesheet-url specifies the location of the default transformation style sheet. For example:
filter store:///identity.xsl identifies identity.xsl as the default filtering style sheet

entry.name: xsldefault_stylepolicy_descr_958
entry.text: Identifies the default transformation style sheet

entry.name: xquerydefault_stylepolicy_help_959
entry.text:
Identifies a default style sheet used for JSON document transformation. This default style sheet performs transformation only if a candidate JSON document fails to match any of the transformation rules defined within the named processing policy and if the document contains no internal processing instructions. stylesheet-url specifies the location of the default XQuery style sheet. For example:
xquerydefault store:///identity-json.xq identifies identity-json.xq as the default filtering style sheet

entry.name: xquerydefault_stylepolicy_descr_959
entry.text: Identifies the default XQuery style sheet for JSON

entry.name: error_rule_stylepolicy_help_960
entry.text: Assigns an error processing rule to the current Document Processing Policy. errorRuleName The error processing rule to assign to the object.

entry.name: error_rule_stylepolicy_descr_960
entry.text: Assigns an error processing rule.

entry.name: match_stylepolicy_help_961
entry.text:
Associates a named transformation or filtering rule with a matching rule and adds the rule-template pair to the current Style Policy.
Use the "no" form of this command to reset a Processing Policy, that is clear all rules from the policy.
matchingRule is the name of a matching rule that was previously created with the matching command and populated with the httpmatch or urlmatch command that serves as a source of URL or HTTP templates. Candidate documents that match any of the templates that are contained in the rule might be processed in accordance with the associated rule.
globalRule is the name of a transformation or filtering rule that was previously created with the rule command. This rule defines the processing procedures for documents that perform both of the following:
- Match any of the expressions that are contained in the associated matching rule
- Match the direction of the rule. A "request-rule" applies only to client-originated documents. A "response-rule" applies only to server-originated documents. While a "bi-directional" rule applies to all documents regardless of source.

entry.name: match_stylepolicy_descr_961
entry.text: Associates a transformation or filtering rule with a matching rule.

entry.name: action_stylepolicyrule_help_962
entry.text:
Adds a Processing Action object to the list of actions performed by the rule. The action must be configured using Processing Action configuration mode prior to running this command.
action_name specifies the name of the action to add to the rule. The action is appended to the end of the list of configured actions. For example:
action validate-it adds the existing action named validate-it to the rule.

entry.name: action_stylepolicyrule_descr_962
entry.text: Adds a configured action to a Processing Rule

entry.name: checkpoint_stylepolicyrule_help_963
entry.text: Adds an information collection checkpoint in the transaction which is used for Web Services Management. These actions are inserted automatically by the Web Services Gateway when for managed Web Services.

entry.name: checkpoint_stylepolicyrule_descr_963
entry.text: Adds a checkpoint for Web Services Management

entry.name: convert_http_stylepolicyrule_help_964
entry.text:
Defines an XML conversion rule, a rule that converts non-XML input (for example, an HTTP GET or POST or an HTML form) into XML, and adds the conversion rule to a processing policy.
INPUT specifies the original input to the Stylesheet Policy Rule. context The output of a prior transformation or filter operation within a multi-step rule. OUTPUT and context are mutually exclusive and identify the destination of the XML content. OUTPUT specifies the final output of the Stylesheet Policy Rule, which, depending on the rule's direction, is sent to a requesting client or responding server. context The context that receives the XML contents. input-conversion-map optionally identifies an input conversion map that specifies document encoding. In the absence a map designation, all input is treated as URLescaped. For example:
convert-http INPUT tempParams ICM-normal converts the original input to the rule to XML and puts the XML content in the tempParams context. The Input Conversion Map, ICM-normal, which specifies the encoding of the non-XML input.

entry.name: convert_http_stylepolicyrule_descr_964
entry.text: Adds as HTTP conversion rule to a processing policy

entry.name: extract_stylepolicyrule_help_965
entry.text:
Applies an XPath expression to a context and stores the result in a specified context. source-context The context the XPath expression is applied to. destination-context The context that stores the result of the XPath expression application. xpath-exp specifies the XPath expression, and may be expressed as in XPath format or as a var:// URL that expands to an XPath expression. variable optionally specifies a variable name (within destination- context) in which to store the result of the XPath expression. For example:
extract INPUT three //games/url var://local/urls applies the XPath expression //games/url to the rule input and stores the result in the variable urls within the three context

entry.name: extract_stylepolicyrule_descr_965
entry.text: Applies an XPath expression to a context

entry.name: fetch_stylepolicyrule_help_966
entry.text:
Uses HTTP to obtain a resource for use within a Stylesheet Policy Rule. url The target resource. destination-context The context in which to store the parsed resource. input-context The context in which to retrieve the content body http-method The HTTP method to use in for the request For example:
fetch var://local/doc TestIt fetches the resource named doc from within the default context stores it within the TestIt context fetch store:///count.xsl count fetches the stylesheet from the local store: directory and stores it in the count context. fetch https://sona/TestBase/simple.xsl tmp1 fetches the specified XSL stylesheet and store it in the tmp1 context

entry.name: fetch_stylepolicyrule_descr_966
entry.text: Fetches a resource for use within a rule

entry.name: filter_stylepolicyrule_help_967
entry.text:
Adds a filtering rule, which results in an accept or reject decision, to the current processing policy.
INPUT specifies the original input to the Stylesheet Policy Rule. context The output of a prior transformation or filter operation within a multi-step rule. dynamic-stylesheet is an optional keyword that identifies the filter stylesheet as being dynamically created. stylesheet The filter stylesheet. For example:
filter INPUT store:///filter-1.xsl uses the specified stylesheet to filter the original input to the Stylesheet Policy filter INPUT var://context/filter/filter uses the stylesheet addressed by the filter variable in the filter context to filter the original input to the Stylesheet Policy

entry.name: filter_stylepolicyrule_descr_967
entry.text: Adds a filtering rule to a processing policy

entry.name: non_xml_processing_stylepolicyrule_help_968
entry.text: Enables processing of non-XML INPUT or OUTPUT within a Stylesheet Policy. Non-XML OUTPUT is passed through to the target destination.

entry.name: non_xml_processing_stylepolicyrule_descr_968
entry.text: Enables non-XML processing

entry.name: results_stylepolicyrule_help_969
entry.text:
Transmits the contents of a context to a specified destination. send-context The target context. destination optionally identifies the destination of the transmitted context. In the absence of this argument, the target context is transmitted to the rule's OUTPUT. response-context is required only when a response is expected from the destination and is otherwise unused. response-context The target context that stores the parsed reply. http-method specifies the http method to use e.g. POST, PUT, DELETE.
For example:
results INPUT sends the contents of the INPUT context to the rule's destination results INPUT var://local/dest sends the contents of the INPUT context to the destination referenced by the local VAR URL, var://local/dest results INPUT http://127.0.0.1:9000/ apple sends the contents of the INPUT context to the to loop-back server for processing. Returned processing results are stored in the apple context.

entry.name: results_stylepolicyrule_descr_969
entry.text: Outputs the contents of a context

entry.name: rewrite_stylepolicyrule_help_970
entry.text:
Adds a URL rewrite instruction to the current processing rule. name is the name of the URL Rewrite Policy used to rewrite the input URL. For example:
rewrite RW-1 invokes the RW-1 URL Rewrite Policy to rewrite the input URL

entry.name: rewrite_stylepolicyrule_descr_970
entry.text: Adds a rewrite instruction to a processing rule

entry.name: route_action_stylepolicyrule_descr_971
entry.text: Not used during CLI configuration

entry.name: route_set_stylepolicyrule_help_972
entry.text:
Enables dynamic routing with a stylesheet by identifying the destination and optional TLS credentials.
destination A URL that identifies the document destination. Destinations can be expressed as a protocol-specific URL or a variable that expands to a transport URL. tlsProxy The name of a TLS proxy profile. proxy | client Whether the profile type is for a TLS proxy profile or a TLS client profile. The default value is "proxy". tlsClient The name of a TLS client profile. For example:
route-set var://context/destination/dest-1 dynTLSProxy-1 Specifies a dynamic route expanded from the dest-1 variable in the destination context. The dynTLSProxy TLS proxy profile provides the credentials to establish a secure connection. route-set var://context/destination/dest-1 "" client dynTLSClient Same as the previous example, but uses the dynTLSClient TLS client profile.

entry.name: route_set_stylepolicyrule_descr_972
entry.text: Enables dynamic routing with a stylesheet

entry.name: strip_attachments_stylepolicyrule_descr_973
entry.text: Strip attachments from the input context

entry.name: setvar_stylepolicyrule_help_974
entry.text:
Assigns a value to a variable. context The context in which the variable is set. variable specifies the variable name and takes the form of a var:// URL. Note that if the var:// URL is not of the local type, this argument overrides the context specified by the previous argument. value specifies the value assigned to the variable, and may be expanded from the value of an existing variable. For example:
setvar INPUT var://local/dest http://ragnarok:9010/ sets a variable in the INPUT context, with a variable name of dest and a value of "http://ragnarok:9010/" setvar INPUT var://context/routing/dest http://ragnarok:9010/ sets a variable in the "routing" context, with a variable name of dest and a value of "http://ragnarok:9010/"

entry.name: setvar_stylepolicyrule_descr_974
entry.text: Sets the value of a variable

entry.name: type_stylepolicyrule_help_975
entry.text:
Enables the dynamic re-typing of a rule. request-rule, response-rule, and rule are mutually exclusive and specify the rule type, or direction. request-rule specifies a rule applied to client-originated traffic. response-rule specifies a rule applied to server-originated traffic. rule specifies a bi-directional rule, a rule applied to both client and server documents. For example:
type rule recasts the rule as bi-directional.

entry.name: type_stylepolicyrule_descr_975
entry.text: Specifies the direction of a rule

entry.name: xform_stylepolicyrule_help_976
entry.text: Define a transform using a specific stylesheet.

entry.name: xform_stylepolicyrule_descr_976
entry.text: Define a transform using a specific stylesheet

entry.name: validate_stylepolicyrule_help_977
entry.text:
INPUT and source-context are mutually exclusive and identify the target document, the document to be validated.
INPUT The original input to this rule as the target document
source-context The output of a prior transformation or filter as the target document
attribute-rewrite, dynamic-schema, json-schema, schema, and wsdl are mutually exclusive keywords that optionally identify the validation methodology and the schema used for validation. If no methodology is identified, documents are validated in accordance with xsi:schemaLocation attributes in the specified context. Documents that contain no such attributes are considered valid.
attribute-rewrite in conjunction with rewrite-policy, rewrites the schema reference contained in an xsi:schemaLocation attribute within the XML document. The re-written schema reference usually specifies the location of a local trusted copy of the schema that is used for document validation.
rewrite-policy is the name of the URL rewrite policy used to rewrite the schema reference.
dynamic-schema in conjunction with dynamic-schema-url, specifies the use of a dynamically-generated schema, regardless of any xsi:schemaLocation attributes contained with the document to be validated.
dynamic-schema-url The dynamic schema used for document validation.
json-schema in conjunction with json-schema-url, specifies the use of a JSON schema for validation.
json-schema-url The JSON schema used for document validation. Identify the schema with a URL or with a variable in the form var://context/name that evaluates to a URL.
schema in conjunction with schema-url, specifies the use of a specific schema, ignoring any xsi:schemaLocation attributes contained within the document to be validated.
schema-url The schema used for document validation.
wsdl in conjunction with wsdl-url, specifies the use of a specific WSDL file, ignoring any xsi:schemaLocation attributes contained within the document to be validated.
destination-context optionally identifies an output context where the document produced by the validation process is stored. For example:
validate INPUT attribute-rewrite URL-RW1 adds a validation rule. Internal validation instructions are rewritten with the URL Rewrite Policy named URL-RW1. The resulting URL locates the schema used for document validation.

entry.name: validate_stylepolicyrule_descr_977
entry.text: Adds a schema validation rule

entry.name: xformbin_stylepolicyrule_help_978
entry.text:
Adds an xformbin action to the current Web Services Processing Rule. An xformbin action defines a policy-based XSL transformation that converts INPUT binary data to XML.
inputContext identifies the context that contains the document transformed by this rule. Use "INPUT" to specify the initial policy input, that is the original client request or server response.
<stylesheetURL> and dynamic-stylesheet <objectName> are mutually exclusive.
stylesheetURL identifies the stylesheet used to transform documents. This argument can take the form of a local or remote URL or a var:// URL that expands to a stylesheet location.
dynamic-stylesheet objectName identifies the object (for example, an XPath Routing Map) from which the dynamic stylesheet is generated.
outputContext identifies the context that receives the transformed document. Use "OUTPUT" to specify the final policy output, that is the transformed client request or transformed server response.
For example:
xformbin INPUT store:///binToXML.xsl OUTPUT adds a transformation rule. Transforms the original binary input to XML (using the local binToXML.xsl stylesheet), and sends the XML to the final output of the rule.
xformbin INPUT var://stylesheets/bin-xform FromBin adds a transformation rule. Transforms the original binary input to XML (using the stylesheet referenced by the var://stylesheets/bin-xform variable, and sends the transformed document to the FromBin context.

entry.name: xformbin_stylepolicyrule_descr_978
entry.text: Adds an xformbin action.

entry.name: xformpi_stylepolicyrule_help_979
entry.text:
Define an XSL transformation rule that uses processing instructions contained within the XML document, or (if the document does not contain processing instructions) a specified default stylesheet. Transformation rules are used in the implementation of a Style Policy. The syntax takes the form:
source stylesheet destination
Source identifies the source of the XML document that will be transformed. Valid inputs are the keywords SERVER or CLIENT, a URL, or a local (device-resident) variable name.
Stylesheet identifies the stylesheet that will be used to transform the XML document if the document does not contain processing instructions. Valid inputs are a URL, or a local (device-resident) variable name.
Destination identifies the destination of the transformed XML document. Valid inputs are the keywords SERVER or CLIENT, a URL, or a local (device-resident) variable name.
Implementation of a Style Policy is enabled by the following commands:
matching httpmatch urlmatch stylepolicy rule xform xformpi
For example:
xformpi SERVER http://mycompany.com/central/ default.xsl CLIENT specifies an XSL transformation rule -- take the input server-originated XML document, and use its contained processing instructions to perform XSL transformation, then send result to the client -- if the document lacks processing instructions, use the specified default stylesheet, and send result to the client

entry.name: xformpi_stylepolicyrule_descr_979
entry.text: Define a processing instruction transform with a default stylesheet

entry.name: aaa_stylepolicyrule_help_980
entry.text:
Adds an AAA action (implementing an AAA Policy) to the current Web Services Processing Rule.
inputContext identifies the context that contains the document that is authenticated or authorized or both by the AAA policy implemented by this rule. Specify the initial policy input, that is the original client request or the original server response.
aaaPolicy is the name of an AAA Policy.
outputContext optionally identifies the context where any post-processing output is stored. Specify the final policy output, that is the transformed client request or transformed server response.
For example:
aaa INPUT AAA-Policy1 applies the AAA-Policy1 AAA Policy to the original input to the Web Services Processing Rule.

entry.name: aaa_stylepolicyrule_descr_980
entry.text: Adds an AAA action to a processing rule.

entry.name: call_stylepolicyrule_help_981
entry.text:
Adds a call action to the current Web Services Processing Rule. A call action invokes another named rule.
inputContext identifies the context that contains the document in which the specified rule is called. Specify the initial policy input, that is the original client request or the original server response.
aaaPolicy is the name of the rule to be invoked.
outputContext identifies the context where results are stores. Specify the final policy output, that is the transformed client request or transformed server response.
For example:
call temp1 processRequest temp2 applies the processRequest call rule to the document in the temp1 context and moves the results to the temp2 context.

entry.name: call_stylepolicyrule_descr_981
entry.text: Adds an call action to a processing rule.

entry.name: input_filter_stylepolicyrule_help_982
entry.text:
Adds an input-filter action to the current Web Services Processing Rule. An input-filter action specifies a decompression algorithm to be applied to all incoming traffic before any other processing occurs. decompressionAlgorithm identifies one of the following decompression methods (keywords) to use for incoming messages:
zip decompresses with the ZIP algorithm.
pkzip decompresses with the PKZIP algorithm.
none the default, performs no decompression.
For example:
input-filter pkzip decompresses all incoming traffic using PKZIP.
input-filter none restores the default state, incoming traffic is not decompressed.

entry.name: input_filter_stylepolicyrule_descr_982
entry.text: Adds an input-filter action to the processing rule.

entry.name: log_stylepolicyrule_help_983
entry.text:
Adds a log action to the current Web Services Processing Rule. A log action generates a log message containing the contents of a specified context and sends the message to a target location.
inputContext identifies the context whose contents are to be sent to a target location. Specify the initial policy input, that is the original client request or the original server response.
aaaPolicy is a URL that specifies the log message recipient.
outputContext optionally identifies the output context.
http-method specifies the http method to use e.g. POST, PUT, DELETE.
For example:
log INPUT http://www.us.ibm/ragnarok/log sends the contents of the INPUT context to the specified target URL.

entry.name: log_stylepolicyrule_descr_983
entry.text: Adds a log action to the processing rule.

entry.name: on_error_stylepolicyrule_help_984
entry.text:
Adds an on-error action to the current Web Services Processing Rule. An on-error action provides user-defined error-handling procedures.
errorMode specifies the operational response to an error and takes one of the following forms (keywords):
abort specifies that rule processing ceases in the event of an error.
continue specifies that rule processing continues with the next action in the event of an error.
alternative specifies that rule processing invokes an alternative rule in the event of an error.
errorRule optionally specifies an error rule that is executed in the event of an error condition.
errorInputContext optionally identifies the input context for the error rule. If no context is explicitly identified, the input context of the failed action is used by default.
errorOutputContext optionally identifies the output context for the error rule. If no context is explicitly identified, the output context of the failed action is used by default.
For example:
on-error abort faultProcessing specifies that rule processing ceases in the event of an error and calls the faultProcessing rule as an error handler.

entry.name: on_error_stylepolicyrule_descr_984
entry.text: Adds an on-error action to the processing rule.

entry.name: output_filter_stylepolicyrule_help_985
entry.text:
Adds an output-filter action to the current Web Services Processing Rule. An output-filter action specifies a compression algorithm to be applied to all outgoing traffic after all other processing occurs.
compressionAlgorithm identifies the method used to compress outgoing messages and takes one of the following keywords:
zip compresses traffic with the ZIP algorithm.
pkzip compresses traffic with the PKZIP algorithm.
none the default, performs no compression.
For example:
output-filter pkzip compresses all outgoing traffic using PKZIP.
output-filter none restores the default state, outgoing traffic is not compressed.

entry.name: output_filter_stylepolicyrule_descr_985
entry.text: Adds an output-filter action to the processing rule.

entry.name: results_async_stylepolicyrule_help_986
entry.text:
Adds a results-async action to the current Web Services Processing Rule. A results-async action transmits the contents of a context to a specified destination.
context identifies the target context, that is the target whose contents are transmitted.
destination specifies the destination.
http-method specifies the http method to use e.g. POST, PUT, DELETE.
For example:
results INPUT sends the contents of the INPUT context to the currently defined destination.
results INPUT var://local/dest sends the contents of the INPUT context to the destination referenced by the local VAR URL, var://local/dest.
results INPUT http://127.0.0.1:9000/ apple sends the contents of the INPUT context to the loop-back server for processing. Returned processing results are stored in the apple context.

entry.name: results_async_stylepolicyrule_descr_986
entry.text: Adds a results-async action to the processing rule.

entry.name: slm_stylepolicyrule_help_987
entry.text:
Adds an slm action (implementing an SLM policy) to the current Web Services Processing Policy Rule. inputContext identifies the context monitored by the specified SLM policy. Specify the initial policy input, that is the original client request or server response.
slmPolicyName is the name of an SLM policy.
For example:
slm INPUT SLM-1 assigns the SLM-1 SLM policy with the INPUT context.

entry.name: slm_stylepolicyrule_descr_987
entry.text: Adds an SLM action to the processing rule.

entry.name: unprocessed_stylepolicyrule_help_988
entry.text:
Enables data to pass-through subsequent actions of the current Web Services Processing Rule in an unprocessed state.
Use the "no" form to disable unprocessed mode.
unprocessed enables unprocessed mode. no unprocessed disabled unprocessed mode.

entry.name: unprocessed_stylepolicyrule_descr_988
entry.text: Enabled or disabled unprocessed mode.

entry.name: entitlement_systemsettings_help_989
entry.text: Specify the serial number of the original device after receiving a replacement device. Without the serial number of the original device, IBM cannot entitle the replacement device for future maintenance or warranty service.

entry.name: entitlement_systemsettings_descr_989
entry.text: Specifies the original serial number

entry.name: contact_systemsettings_help_990
entry.text:
Identifies the individual or function responsible for device administration and/or maintenance. Use double quotes (") to bracket a contact string that contains spaces. For example:
contact"Tector Gorch at 555.555.5555" The system contact

entry.name: contact_systemsettings_descr_990
entry.text: Specifies the system contact

entry.name: custom_ui_file_systemsettings_help_991
entry.text:
Specifies the location of the custom user interface file. This XML contains custom user interface messages to display in the WebGUI or from the command line. The file also defines the custom prompt for the command line. After creating the custom user interface file, use the "test schema" command to validate that the file conforms with the "dp-user-interface.xsd" schema.
For information about creating a custom user interface file, refer to the "WebGUI Guide".
Use the "no custom-ui-file" command to remove the use of custom messages and the command line prompt that are defined in the custom user interface file.
URL The location of the custom user interface file. The location must be local file (in the local: or store: directory), not a file on a mounted file system.
For example: custom-ui-file store:///xyzbanner.xml Specifies "store:///xyzbanner.xml" as the custom user interface file.

entry.name: custom_ui_file_systemsettings_descr_991
entry.text: Specifies the URL of the custom user interface file.

entry.name: locale_systemsettings_help_992
entry.text:
Specifies the locale, or the operating language, of the DataPower Gateway. This setting manages locale-specific conventions, such as date and time formats, and controls the language of log messages.
Before you select a locale, you must enable the administrative state of the language with the 'language' command.
locale-name Specifies the language. The following languages are available. - de -- German - en-- English - es -- Spanish - fr -- French - it -- Italian - ja -- Japanese - ko -- Korean - pt_BR -- Brazilian Portuguese - ru -- Russian - zh_CN -- Simplified Chinese - zh_TW -- Traditional Chinese

entry.name: locale_systemsettings_descr_992
entry.text: Specifies the operating locale of the DataPower Gateway.

entry.name: location_systemsettings_help_993
entry.text: Specifies the device location. Use double quotes (") to bracket a string that contains spaces. For example: location "West Campus, Building 3, 3rd floor, RM208"

entry.name: location_systemsettings_descr_993
entry.text: Specifies the device location

entry.name: login_message_systemsettings_help_994
entry.text:
This command is deprecated. If you used this command to define a message with a previous firmware release, the message will be rewritten to the "store:///login-message.xml" file the first time that you access the configuration for System Settings.
This functionality is replaced by the contents of the XML file that is specified with the "custom-ui-file" command.

entry.name: login_message_systemsettings_descr_994
entry.text: Deprecated - use custom-ui-file.

entry.name: name_systemsettings_help_995
entry.text: Provides a device-specific name or description. Use double quotes (") to bracket a name that contains spaces. For example: name "XML Device"

entry.name: name_systemsettings_descr_995
entry.text: Names of the device

entry.name: xml_accelerator_systemsettings_help_996
entry.text:
Attention: Use this command only at the direction of IBM Support. Controls whether to enable or disable the XML hardware accelerator. After changing the state, reboot the appliance to remove any items from the cache. When you reboot, the specified state is in effect. When you disable the XML hardware accelerator, the stylesheets defined by the disallow-xg4 and the prefer-xg4 commands in Compile Options Policy mode are ignored.
The "show firmware-version" and the "show version" monitoring commands show whether the appliance has the XML hardware accelerator. The "show memory" command shows the percentage of memory offloaded in the XML hardware accelerator or shows 0%% if the XML hardware accelerator is disabled. on (Default) Enables the XML hardware accelerator. off Disables the XML hardware accelerator.
For example:
xml-accelerator off Specifies that the XML hardware accelerator is disabled on the next reboot.

entry.name: xml_accelerator_systemsettings_descr_996
entry.text: Controls whether to use the XML hardware accelerator

entry.name: ad_use_ad_tam_help_997
entry.text:
Indicates if Active Directory registry configuration is required. Note: This will be confirmed from the configuration file entered.
yes | no

entry.name: ad_use_ad_tam_descr_997
entry.text: Indicates if Active Directory registry configuration is required.

entry.name: tam_version_tam_help_998
entry.text:
Select the IBM Security Access Manager version to upgrade to if required, else leave as 'Default'.
Note: This will be confirmed from the configuration file entered.
Default The version obtained from the configuration file will be used. v70 (deprecated) v801 v901 (deprecated) v903 The version will be used if it is the same or later than the version of the configuration file.

entry.name: tam_version_tam_descr_998
entry.text: Determine the version that the Security Access Manager client is to run as

entry.name: file_tam_help_999
entry.text:
Specifies the name and location of the IBM Security Access Manager configuration file.
filename Specifies the name and location of the IBM Security Access Manager configuration files. The name of the file should end with .conf or .cfg.
The file CLI specifies the name and location of the existing ISAM client configuration files. There are two versions of each ISAM configuration file: plain text and obfuscated. The plain text version contains all configuration details except security-sensitive details (such as passwords). The obfuscated version contains only the security-sensitive details. The obfuscated versions need to be on the device, but you do not need to explicitly use this CLI to specify the obfuscated version.
Note: Files stored in either the cert: or sharedcert: directory can be read by the system but cannot be viewed.

entry.name: file_tam_descr_999
entry.text: Specifies the name and location of the ISAM configuration file.

entry.name: reg_file_tam_help_1000
entry.text:
Specifies the name and location of the IBM Security Access Manager Active Directory configuration file.
filename Specifies the name and location of the ISAM Active Directory configuration file. The name of the file should end with .conf or .cfg.
The reg-file CLI specifies the name and location of the existing ISAM client Active Directory registry configuration file. The file is only required when the Active Directory registry is being configured. The file contains parameters specific to the Active Directory configuration. Note: Files stored in either the cert: or sharedcert: directory can be read by the system but cannot be viewed.

entry.name: reg_file_tam_descr_1000
entry.text: Specifies the name and location of the ISAM Active Directory configuration file.

entry.name: use_ldap_ssl_tam_help_1001
entry.text: Indicates whether communication with the LDAP/AD server is secured by SSL. yes | no

entry.name: use_ldap_ssl_tam_descr_1001
entry.text: Indicates if communication with the LDAP/AD server is secured by SSL.

entry.name: ldap_ssl_port_tam_help_1002
entry.text: Specifies the value of the LDAP TLS port. The default port for LDAP over TLS is 636.

entry.name: ldap_ssl_port_tam_descr_1002
entry.text: Specifies LDAP TLS port.

entry.name: ldap_ssl_key_file_tam_help_1003
entry.text:
Specifies the name and location of the IBM Security Access Manager TLS key file that contain the certificate used for LDAP access. The TLS key file handles the certificates that are used in LDAP communication. The location of this key file is either the cert: or sharedcert: directory.
The ISAM configuration file must contain the ssl-keyfile-pwd in the [ldap] stanza to access this file, or configure the ldap-ssl-key-file-password parameter for this ISAM configuration object.
file The name of the LDAP TLS key file.

entry.name: ldap_ssl_key_file_tam_descr_1003
entry.text: Specifies the name of the LDAP TLS key file.

entry.name: ldap_ssl_key_file_password_tam_help_1004
entry.text:
Specifies the LDAP TLS key file password. This property is deprecated and replaced with ldap-ssl-key-file-password-alias.
password Specifies the LDAP TLS key file password.
The ldap-ssl-key-file-password CLI specifies the password used to access the LDAP TLS key file, as specified by the ldap-ssl-key-file configuration parameter.

entry.name: ldap_ssl_key_file_password_tam_descr_1004
entry.text: Specifies the LDAP TLS key file password (deprecated).

entry.name: ldap_ssl_key_file_password_alias_tam_help_1005
entry.text:
Specifies the password alias of the LDAP TLS key file password.
password-alias Specifies the password alias of the LDAP TLS key file password.
The ldap-ssl-key-file-password-alias CLI specifies the password alias of the password used to access the LDAP TLS key file, as specified by the ldap-ssl-key-file configuration parameter.

entry.name: ldap_ssl_key_file_password_alias_tam_descr_1005
entry.text: Specifies the password alias of the LDAP TLS key file password.

entry.name: ldap_ssl_key_file_dn_tam_help_1006
entry.text:
Specifies the name used to refer to the correct LDAP TLS client certificate in the LDAP TLS key file. This parameter is relevant for only mutually-authenticated TLS.
dn-label The name of the LDAP TLS key certificate.

entry.name: ldap_ssl_key_file_dn_tam_descr_1006
entry.text: Specifies the label of the LDAP TLS client certificate.

entry.name: use_fips_tam_help_1007
entry.text: Configures the IBM Security Access Manager to run in FIPS mode, for TLS network communication.

entry.name: use_fips_tam_descr_1007
entry.text: Select to run in FIPS mode.

entry.name: choose_nist_tam_help_1008
entry.text:
Sets the NIST mode for FIPS compliance. The selected mode must be compatible with the corresponding Security Access Manager servers and registry servers. The following modes are are available.
fips Enable FIPS 140-2 compliance. This is a legacy compliance mode and is deprecated. sp800-131-transition Enable NIST SP 800-131ai compliance at a transitional level. This mode is valid until 2014. sp800-131-strict Enable strict NIST SP 800-131a compliance. This mode is mandatory from 2014. suite-b-128 Enable NSA Suite B compliance at the 128 bit level. suite-b-192 Enable NSA Suite B compliance at the 192 bit level.

entry.name: choose_nist_tam_descr_1008
entry.text: Sets the NIST mode for FIPS compliance

entry.name: use_local_mode_tam_help_1009
entry.text:
Indicates if the local policy cache is required. Note: This option must match the mode selected at configuration file creation.
yes | no

entry.name: use_local_mode_tam_descr_1009
entry.text: Indicates if local policy cache is used.

entry.name: cache_refresh_interval_tam_help_1010
entry.text:
Specifies the value of the interval (seconds) between polling of the policy server to check for policy updates. If set to 'disable' then polling will not take place.i If set to 'default' then a default value, currently 600 seconds is used.
refresh-interval

entry.name: cache_refresh_interval_tam_descr_1010
entry.text: Poll interval between checks for updates to the local policy cache.

entry.name: listen_mode_tam_help_1011
entry.text: Indicates if the policy server is to send notifications of policy updates for the policy cache. If this is true then a valid network address to receive the notifications must have been supplied at ISAM configuration file creation. yes | no

entry.name: listen_mode_tam_descr_1011
entry.text: Indicates if the policy cache is to be updated via notifications from the policy server.

entry.name: listen_port_tam_help_1012
entry.text:
Specifies the value of the port to which the policy server sends policy update notifications. This port is used with the local host name to identify where the policy server sends updates. This value if it is provided will override the port value provided during ISAM configuration file creation. The local host name must have been provided during ISAM configuration file creation.
listen-port

entry.name: listen_port_tam_descr_1012
entry.text: Specifies the port to which the policy server sends policy update notifications

entry.name: replica_tam_help_1013
entry.text:
Adds a ISAM authorization server replica to the configuration file.
The replica command defines one replica. Replicas indicate the network location of the remote server. Additional replicas can be configured for failover purposes, but you cannot define more than one replica on a single host. When the environment contains multiple replicas, replicas can have the same weight.
Invoke this command to add each needed replica.
Note: When using an existing ISAM client configuration file, the file must contain at least one replica.
host Specifies the TCP host name of the authorization server replica. For example: libra libra.dallas.ibm.com. port Sets the listening port of the replica. During configuration, this parameter is required. The default is 7136. weight Specifies the order of preference among replicas. Replicas with higher ranks are used preferentially. For example, the DataPower Gateway contacts a replica with a weight of 10 before contacting a replica with a weight of 9. Use an integer in the range of 1 through 10. The default is 10.

entry.name: replica_tam_descr_1013
entry.text: Adds an authorization server replica.

entry.name: tam_ras_trace_tam_help_1014
entry.text:
Enable IBM Security Access Manager trace Turns on trace in the ISAM libraries. the default is 'off' ISAM trace file The base filename for the ISAM trace file. The actual file will be stored as 'temporary:/<ISAM object name>/<filename>.<n>' where n is 1 or 2. ISAM trace size The number of entries to store in the trace file. Each entry is about 500 characters if XML type is selected otherwise it is 200 characters. ISAM trace type The format of the trace file -one of textfile, utf8file or xmlfile. ISAM trace component A list of triples consisting of comma separated <component>.<sub-component>.<level> entries. The value of '*.*.9' logs all entries. Enable LDAP trace Turns on trace in the LDAP libraries used by the ISAM client. LDAP trace file The base filename for the ISAM trace file. The actual file will be stored as 'temporary:/<ISAM object name>/<filename>.<n>'
where n is 1 or 2. LDAP trace size The number of characters stored in the trace file. LDAP trace level The level of LDAP trace required represented as a 16 position bitmap. A value of 65535 generates all available logging, a value of 1 generates function entry/exit logging. enable GSKit trace Turns on trace in the GSKit libraries. GSKit trace file The base filename for the ISAM trace file. The actual file will be stored as 'temporary:/<ISAM object name>/<filename>.<n>'
where n is 1 or 2. The size of the trace file is fixed at 25Mb. The file is in a compressed format that requires GSKit L2/L3 to decode. GSKit trace flushing Enabling trace flushing disables buffering of trace output. This means that if GSKit crashes the logs will be closer to the crash point than if they were buffered. It does generate a performance degradation however.

entry.name: tam_ras_trace_tam_descr_1014
entry.text: Allows enabling of trace in ISAM and related libraries.

entry.name: return_attributes_tam_help_1015
entry.text:
Indicates whether ISAM returns user attributes.
The return-attributes CLI indicates whether ISAM returns user attributes to the DataPower Gateway. When ISAM returns user attributes, you can use these attributes within authorization requests.
on Indicates that ISAM returns user attributes. off (Default) Indicates that ISAM does not return user attributes.

entry.name: return_attributes_tam_descr_1015
entry.text: Indicates whether ISAM returns user attributes.

entry.name: ssl_key_tam_help_1016

Specifies the name of the ISAM TLS key file.
file The name and location of the ISAM TLS key file. This file must be in either the cert: or sharedcert: directory.

entry.text: Specifies the name of the ISAM TLS stash file.

entry.name: acl_telnetservice_help_1018
entry.text:
Assigns an Access Control List (ACL) to the current Telnet Service. Assignment of an ACL to a Telnet Service is optional. If an ACL is assigned to the service, only those IP addresses specifically allowed by the ACL can initiate telnet access to the device; if an ACL is not assigned, Telnet access to the device is unrestricted.
aclName Identifies the ACL assigned to the current Telnet Service.
For example:
cli telnet telnet-1 acl aclTelnet assigns the aclTelnet ACL to the telnet-1 Telnet Service.

entry.name: acl_telnetservice_descr_1018
entry.text: Assigns an ACL.

entry.name: local_address_telnetservice_help_1019
entry.text:
Specifies the local IP address and port monitored by the current Telnet Service for incoming CLI traffic.
telnetServerIP and 0 are mutually-exclusive arguments.
telnetServerIP The IP address, either primary or secondary, of the interface incoming Telnet requests. With the port, identifies the IP address and port that is monitored by the Telnet service. 0 Indicates a wildcard value for all IP addresses. telnetServerPort is an integer within the range 0 to 65535 that identifies a port on one or all IP interfaces. In conjunction with IP address, this value identifies the device IP addresses and port monitored by the telnet service.
For example:
cli telnet telnet-1 local-address 10.10.13.35 23000 specifies 10.10.13.35:23000 as the local IP address:port monitored by the telnet-1 Telnet service.

entry.name: local_address_telnetservice_descr_1019
entry.text: Specifies the IP address for incoming CLI traffic.

entry.name: tfim_60_req_tokenformat_tfimendpoint_help_1020
entry.text:
Specifies the format of the TFIM 6.0 request token.
tokenFormat Specifies the format of the token. Only the following values are supported: WSTokenType (Default) Indicates a WS-Security Username TokenType. SAML1.0 Indicates a SAML Assertion 1.0. SAML1.1 Indicates a SAML Assertion 1.1. Custom Indicates a custom token. When specified, requires the use of the tfim-custom-req-url CLI.
This CLI is required when tfim-compatible is v6.0 and tfim-endpoint-type is tokenmapping; otherwise, it is ignored.

entry.name: tfim_60_req_tokenformat_tfimendpoint_descr_1020
entry.text: Specifies the format of the TFIM 6.0 request token.

entry.name: tfim_61_req_tokenformat_tfimendpoint_help_1021
entry.text:
Specifies the format of the TFIM 6.1 request token.
tokenFormat Specifies the format of the token. Only the following values are supported: WSTokenType (Default) Indicates a WS-Security Username TokenType. SAML1.0 Indicates a SAML Assertion 1.0. SAML1.1 Indicates a SAML Assertion 1.1 SAML2.0 Indicates a SAML Assertion 2.0 WSKerberosToken Indicates a WS-Security Kerberos Token. WSX509Token Indicates a WS-Security X.509 Token BinarySecurityToken Indicates a WS-Security BinarySecurityToken CustomToken Indicates a Custom Token Custom Indicates a custom token. When specified, requires the use of the tfim-custom-req-url CLI.
This CLI is required when tfim-compatible is v6.1 and tfim-endpoint-type is tokenmapping; otherwise, it is ignored.

entry.name: tfim_61_req_tokenformat_tfimendpoint_descr_1021
entry.text: Specifies the format of the TFIM 6.1 request token.

Specifies the format of the TFIM 6.2 request token.
tokenFormat Specifies the format of the token. Only the following values are supported: WSTokenType (Default) Indicates a WS-Security Username TokenType. SAML1.0 Indicates a SAML Assertion 1.0. SAML1.1 Indicates a SAML Assertion 1.1 SAML2.0 Indicates a SAML Assertion 2.0 WSKerberosToken Indicates a WS-Security Kerberos Token. WSX509Token Indicates a WS-Security X.509 Token BinarySecurityToken Indicates a WS-Security BinarySecurityToken CustomToken Indicates a Custom Token Custom Indicates a custom token. When specified, requires the use of the tfim-custom-req-url CLI.
This CLI is required when tfim-compatible is v6.2 and tfim-endpoint-type is tokenmapping; otherwise, it is ignored.
