entry.name: tfim_compatible_tfimendpoint_help_1024
entry.text:
Indicates the version of Tivoli Federated Identity Manager.
version Indicates the currently configured version of TFIM. Only the following values are supported: v6.0 Indicates Tivoli Federated Identity Manager, version 6.0. v6.1 Indicates Tivoli Federated Identity Manager, version 6.1. v6.2 Indicates Tivoli Federated Identity Manager, version 6.2.
The tfim-compatible CLI indicates the currently configured version of IBM Federated Identity Manager. The specified value determines the details for the namespace and WS-Trust messages.

entry.name: tfim_compatible_tfimendpoint_descr_1024
entry.text: Indicates the version of TFIM.

entry.name: tfim_custom_req_url_tfimendpoint_help_1025
entry.text:
The tfim-custom-req-url CLI specifies the location of the custom stylesheet or GatewayScript file that is used for Tivoli Federated Identity Manager requests. This CLI is required when the request token type is Custom; otherwise, it is ignored.
stylesheet Specifies the location of the custom stylesheet or GatewayScript file.

entry.name: tfim_custom_req_url_tfimendpoint_descr_1025
entry.text: Specifies the location of the custom stylesheet.

entry.name: tfim_issuer_tfimendpoint_help_1026
entry.text:
Specifies the identity that issued the request.
issuer Specifies the identity that issued the request in the following format: urn:itfim:wssm:tokenconsumer
The tfim-issuer CLI specifies the issuer of the request. Within the WSDL document, this party equates to the Issuer field. In the WS-Security Management (WSSM) component, the issuer is either the WSSM token generator or the WSSM token consumer. To determine the correct value, consult either the WSDL document or your Tivoli Federated Identity Manager administrator.
This CLI is required for all TFIM request tokens (v6.0, v6.1 and v6.2) except Custom when tfim-endpoint-type is tokenmapping; otherwise, it is ignored.

entry.name: tfim_issuer_tfimendpoint_descr_1026
entry.text: Specifies the identity that issued the request.

entry.name: tfim_operation_tfimendpoint_help_1027
entry.text:
Specifies the name of the Web services operation.
operation Specifies name of the Web services operation. For example 'echo' or 'whoami'. The tfim-operation CLI specifies the name of the Web services operation as defined in the WSDL document. To determine the correct value, consult either the WSDL document or your Tivoli Federated Identity Manager administrator.
This CLI is required for all Tivoli Federated Identity Manager request tokens (v6.1 and v6.2) except Custom when tfim-endpoint-type is tokenmapping; otherwise, it is ignored.

entry.name: tfim_operation_tfimendpoint_descr_1027
entry.text: Specifies the name of the Web services operation.

entry.name: tfim_pathaddr_tfimendpoint_help_1028
entry.text:
Specifies the scope for the security token.
destination Specifies the scope for the security token. For example: http://itfim.ibm.com:9080/EchoApplication/services/EchoServiceUsername http://9.33.97.251:9080/EchoApplication/services/EchoServiceUsername
The tfim-pathaddr CLI specifies the scope for this security token. Within the Tivoli Federated Identity Manager service, this information specifies the destination of the request. The TFIM trust service uses this information to determine which partner is being accessed. To determine the correct value, consult either the WSDL document or your TFIM administrator. Within the WSDL document, this destination equates to the AppliesTo field. This CLI is required for all TFIM request tokens (v6.0, v6.1 and v6.2) except Custom; otherwise, it is ignored.

entry.name: tfim_pathaddr_tfimendpoint_descr_1028
entry.text: Specifies the scope for the security token.

entry.text:
Specifies the port number of the Tivoli Federated Identity Manager server.
port specifies the port number of the TFIM server. The default is port 9080.

entry.name: tfim_port_tfimendpoint_descr_1029

entry.name: tfim_porttype_tfimendpoint_help_1030
entry.text:
Specifies the Web services port type.
portType Specifies the Web services port type. For example, 'EchoService'.
The tfim-porttype CLI specifies the Web services port type to use. A port type is a group of Web services operations.
To determine the correct value, consult either the WSDL document or your Tivoli Federated Identity Manager administrator. Within the WSDL document, this destination equates to the PortType field. This CLI is required for all TFIM request tokens (v6.1 and v6.2) except Custom when tfim-endpoint-type is tokenmapping; otherwise, it is ignored.

entry.name: tfim_porttype_tfimendpoint_descr_1030
entry.text: Specifies the Web services port type.

on Indicates that responses are schema-validated. off (Default) Indicates that responses are not schema-validated. The tfim-schema-validate CLI indicates whether TFIM responses are schema-validated. When validating TFIM responses, the response is validated against the WS-Trust version indicated by the tfim-compatible CLI.

entry.name: backlog_size_throttler_help_1040
entry.text:
Specifies the number of connection requests that the DataPower Gateway routes to the backlog queue. Enter a value in the range 0 - 500. The default value is 0.
If the amount of free memory falls below the configured memory-throttle threshold, the DataPower Gateway delays processing the specified number of requests. Processing is delayed until sufficient memory is available or until the configured backlog-timeout elapses. When sufficient memory is free, the DataPower Gateway processes all requests in the backlog queue. When the backlog queue reaches the configured size, new requests replace previously received requests. If backlog-size is set to 0, the DataPower Gateway does not route requests to the backlog queue.
A request is immediately rejected if the DataPower Gateway does not allocate sufficient resources to route the request to the backlog queue. If such an event occurs and the request arrives over a new connection, an interface rejection error is logged. If the request arrives over an existing connection, a handler rejection error is logged

entry.name: backlog_size_throttler_descr_1040
entry.text: Specifies the size of the backlog queue.

entry.name: backlog_timeout_throttler_help_1041
entry.text:
Specifies the duration in seconds that a connection request remains in the backlog queue. The default is 30.
The DataPower Gateway delays processing requests in the backlog queue until sufficient memory is free or until the specified time elapses. When a request is routed to the backlog queue, the backlog time begins for that request. When the backlog time elapses, the DataPower Gateway rejects the request.

entry.name: backlog_timeout_throttler_descr_1041
entry.text: Specifies the duration that requests remain in the backlog queue.

entry.name: memory_terminate_throttler_help_1042
entry.text:
Specifies the memory reboot threshold, the minimal free memory required for operations. After reaching this threshold, the DataPower Gateway reboots.
percent Specifies the percentage of minimum free memory. Enter a value in the range 0 - 100. The default value is 5.
For example:
memory-terminate 10 Reboots when free memory drops to 10 percent of total memory.

entry.name: memory_terminate_throttler_descr_1042
entry.text: Specifies the memory reboot threshold.

entry.name: memory_throttle_throttler_help_1043
entry.text:
Specifies the memory throttle threshold, the minimal free memory required for unimpeded traffic flow. After reaching this threshold, queues traffic for the duration defined by the "timeout" command.
percent Specifies the minimum percentage of free temporary file space. Enter a value in the range 0 - 100. The default value is 2.
For example:
memory-throttle 25 timeout 15 Queues traffic for 15 seconds when free memory drop to 25 percent of total memory.

entry.name: memory_throttle_throttler_descr_1043
entry.text: Specifies the memory throttle threshold.

entry.name: qcode_warn_throttler_help_1044
entry.text:
Specifies the warn threshold for the number of available XML names and JSON keys in any of the XML names or JSON keys pools. This threshold is the point at which the number of available XML names or JSON keys in any of the pools falls below the warn threshold. This threshold is a measure of free XML names and JSON keys that is expressed as a percentage of the total XML names and JSON keys in a pool.
When this threshold is reached, the DataPower Gateway writes an alert to the log. This message indicates the detection of a shortage of free XML names or JSON keys in a pool.
When you receive this alert, the percentage of available XML names or JSON keys is below the defined threshold. After you receive this alert, schedule a system reload as soon as possible to prevent an unscheduled restart. If the available XML names or JSON keys in any pool is less than 5 percent available, the system reloads.
percent Specifies the percentage of available XML names and JSON keys. Enter a value in the range 5 - 65. The default value is 10.

entry.name: qcode_warn_throttler_descr_1044
entry.text: Specifies the XML names and JSON keys threshold.

entry.name: sensors_log_throttler_help_1045
entry.text:
Indicates whether the monitoring of system fan speeds and power supply status should generate log messages when a failure event occurs.
on Generates the message. This setting is the default value. off Does not generate the message.

entry.name: sensors_log_throttler_descr_1045
entry.text: Manages the monitoring of environmental sensors.

entry.name: status_log_throttler_help_1046
entry.text:
Enables or disables the generation of throttle setting log messages.
on Enables throttle settings log messages. off Disables throttle settings log messages. This setting is the default value.

entry.name: status_log_throttler_descr_1046
entry.text: Manages the generation of throttle setting log messages.

entry.name: status_loglevel_throttler_help_1047
entry.text:
Specifies the level of throttle settings log messages. This command is meaningful only when "status-log" is set to "on".
priority Specifies the message priority. The priority can be expressed as either a keyword or integer. The default value is "debug" or 7. "emerg" | 0 "alert" | 1 "critic" | 2 "error" | 3 "warn" | 4 "notice" | 5 "info" | 6 "debug" | 7

entry.name: status_loglevel_throttler_descr_1047
entry.text: Sets the level of messages that throttle settings generate.

entry.name: temp_fs_terminate_throttler_help_1048
entry.text:
Specifies the temporary file space reboot threshold, the minimal free temporary file space required for operations. After reaching this threshold, the DataPower Gateway reboots.
percent Specifies the percentage of minimum free temporary file space. Enter a value in the range 0 - 100. The default value is 2.
For example:
temp-fs-terminate 4 Reboots when free temporary file space drops to 4 percent of total temporary file space.

entry.name: temp_fs_terminate_throttler_descr_1048
entry.text: Sets the temporary file space reboot threshold.

entry.name: temp_fs_throttle_throttler_help_1049
entry.text:
Specifies the temporary file space throttle threshold, the minimal free temporary file space required for unimpeded traffic flow. After reaching this threshold, queues traffic for the duration defined by the "timeout" command.
percent Specifies the minimum percentage of free temporary file space. Enter a value in the range 0 - 100. The default value is 5.
For example:
temp-fs-throttle 10 timeout 15 Queues traffic for 15 seconds when free temporary file space drop to 15 percent of total temporary file space.

entry.name: temp_fs_throttle_throttler_descr_1049
entry.text: Sets the temporary file space throttle threshold.

entry.name: timeout_throttler_help_1050
entry.text:
Specifies the duration to reject new connection after reaching a throttle threshold. This command is used in conjunction with the "memory-throttle" and "temp-fs-throttle" commands.
seconds Specifies the duration in seconds. The default value is 30.
For example:
memory-throttle 25 timeout 15 Queues traffic for 15 seconds when free memory drop to 25 percent of total memory.

entry.name: timeout_throttler_descr_1050
entry.text: Sets the duration to reject new connection after reaching a throttle threshold.

entry.name: auto_retry_tibcoemsserver_help_1051
entry.text:
Enables an automatic critical error-recovery procedure that attempts to re-establish a connection that has been broken in response to an error condition. Error recovery is enabled by default. on and off Mutually exclusive key words that enable (on) or disable (off) the automatic error recovery procedure.
For example:
error recovery off Disables automatic error recovery attempts

entry.name: auto_retry_tibcoemsserver_descr_1051
entry.text: Enable or disable error recovery procedure.

entry.name: connection_client_id_tibcoemsserver_help_1052
entry.text:
Specifies the string to set as the TIBCO EMS Connection clientID.
string The value for clientID.

entry.name: connection_client_id_tibcoemsserver_descr_1052
entry.text: Specifies the connection client ID.

entry.name: default_message_type_tibcoemsserver_help_1053
entry.text:
Use this command to specify the default TIBCO EMS message type, which is provided by this TIBCO JMS object only if the message type cannot be determined from the EMS message headers. byte and text are mutually exclusive key words that specify the message type. byte (the default) Specifies that the message payload is accessed as a Java byte array. text Specifies that the message payload is accessed as a Java string value.
For example:
default-message-type text Specifies the default message type as text, suitable for XML and SOAP input

entry.name: default_message_type_tibcoemsserver_descr_1053
entry.text: Specify default TIBCO EMS message type.

entry.name: enable_logging_tibcoemsserver_help_1054
entry.text:
Enables/disables an expanded TIBCO EMS logging facility. on and off are mutually exclusive key words that enable (on) or disable (off -- the default state) expanded TIBCO EMS logging.
For example:
enable-logging on enables expanded logging

entry.name: enable_logging_tibcoemsserver_descr_1054
entry.text: Enable/disable an expanded TIBCO logging facility.

entry.name: hostname_tibcoemsserver_help_1055
entry.text:
Identifies the remote TIBCO EMS Server by IP Address or host. TibcoEMSServerName specifies the IP Address or host name of the remote TIBCO EMS server.
For example:
hostname 192.168.45.32 The remote TIBCO EMS Server by IP address

entry.name: hostname_tibcoemsserver_descr_1055
entry.text: Identifies the Remote TIBCO EMS Server.

entry.name: load_balancing_algorithm_tibcoemsserver_help_1056
entry.text:
Specifies a server selection algorithm which determines how incoming client requests are allocated among healthy members of the load balancer group. serverSelectionAlgorithm takes one of the following keyword values: none specifies that load balancing not enabled. least-connections specifies a least-connections selection algorithm, which creates a connection to the server with the least number of active connections. byte-rate specifies a byte-rate selection algorithm, which creates a connection to the server with the lowest total byte rate (input and output).
For example:
load-balancing-algorithm least-connections designates least-connections as the server selection policy

entry.name: load_balancing_algorithm_tibcoemsserver_descr_1056
entry.text: Identifies the TIBCO EMS Load Balancing Algorithm to use.

entry.name: loadbalance_faulttolerance_tibcoemsserver_help_1057
entry.text:
TIBCO EMS supports the idea of fault-tolerant servers. According to the TIBCO documentation, fault-tolerant TIBCO EMS servers are actually a pair of servers whereby one server is the active server that clients connect to and, the other server is on standby (a “passive” server) to take over in the case of a failure of the active server. Another feature TIBCO EMS supports to maximize the up-time of servers is load balancing. By load balancing, one particular server is not overloaded with majority of the connections. Instead, the TIBCO EMS clients choose a load balanced server to create a connection to based on a load balancing algorithm option (e.g. the server with the fewest connections).
To utilize fault-tolerance, specify both a primary and backup TIBCO EMS Server hostname.
To utilize load balancing, call this command multiple times specifying a different primary TIBCO EMS Server hostname each time.
To utilize both fault-tolerance and load balancing, call this command multiple times specifying a different primary and backup TIBCO EMS Server hostname each time.
TibcoEMSServerName specifies the IP Address or host name of a remote TIBCO EMS server TibcoEMSBackupServerName specifies the IP Address or host name of a remote TIBCO EMS backup server
For example:
loadbalance-faulttolerance 192.168.45.32 192.168.45.33 identifies a fault-tolerant pair of a remote TIBCO EMS Server and Backup Server by IP address

entry.name: loadbalance_faulttolerance_tibcoemsserver_descr_1057
entry.text: Identify a fault-tolerant server pair and/or servers to load balance to.

entry.name: maximum_message_size_tibcoemsserver_help_1058
entry.text:
Specifies the maximum message size supported by the current TIBCO EMS object. maxMsgSize is an integer (with the range 0 through 1073741824, with a default of 1048576) that specifies the maximum message size in bytes.
For example:
maximum-message-size 2097152 sets a maximum message size of 2MB

entry.name: maximum_message_size_tibcoemsserver_descr_1058
entry.text: Set the maximum message size.

entry.name: memory_threshold_tibcoemsserver_help_1059
entry.text:
Specifies the maximum memory allocation for pending messages.
bytes Specifies the maximum memory to allocate in bytes for pending messages. Enter a value in the range 1048576 - 1073741824. The default value is 268435456.
For example:
memory-threshold 20971520 Sets a maximum memory allocation to 2MB.

entry.name: memory_threshold_tibcoemsserver_descr_1059
entry.text: Set the maximum memory allocation for pending messages.

entry.name: password_tibcoemsserver_help_1060
entry.text:
Specifies the password to access the TIBCO EMS server. This property is deprecated. Use the password-alias command.
plaintextString Is the password to access the TIBCO EMS server.
For example:
username Dante password Alighieri Specifies the user and password to access the server.

entry.name: password_tibcoemsserver_descr_1060
entry.text: Identify the TIBCO EMS Server password (deprecated).

entry.name: password_alias_tibcoemsserver_help_1061
entry.text:
Specifies the password alias of the password to access the TIBCO EMS server.
password-alias Is the password alias of the password to access the TIBCO EMS server.
For example:
username Dante password-alias Alighieri-alias Specifies the user and password alias to access the server.

entry.name: password_alias_tibcoemsserver_descr_1061
entry.text: Identify the password alias of the TIBCO EMS Server password.

entry.name: retry_interval_tibcoemsserver_help_1062
entry.text:
Meaningful only if auto-retry is enabled, specifies the interval between automatic re-connection attempts. In the absence of an explicit assignment, a default value of 1 is used. intervalSeconds is an integer that specifies the interval (in seconds) between attempts to re-establish a downed connection to the TIBCO EMS Server.
For example:
retry-interval 2 specifies a 2 second pause between reconnection attempts

entry.name: retry_interval_tibcoemsserver_descr_1062
entry.text: Specify frequency of re-connection attempts.

entry.name: sessions_per_connection_tibcoemsserver_help_1063
entry.text:
Specifies the maximum number of concurrent multiplexed sessions supported by a single connection to the current TIBCO EMS Server. Session requests in excess of the value set by the sessions-per-connection command trigger the establishment of a new connection to the TIBCO EMS Server, assuming that the number of current connections is less than the value specified by total-connection-limit command. For example, assuming default values (20 for sessions-per-connection, and 5 for total-connection-limit) and 3 active fully-subscribed connections, a new session request generates the establishment of a 4th connection. maxSessions is an integer (greater than 4, and with a default value of 20) that specifies the maximum concurrent sessions supported by a single connection to the TIBCO EMS Server.
For example:
total-connection-limit 4 sessions-per-connection 15 specifies the connection limit and per-connection session limit for the TIBCO EMS Server

entry.name: sessions_per_connection_tibcoemsserver_descr_1063
entry.text: Set per-connection session limit.

entry.name: ssl_client_type_tibcoemsserver_help_1064
entry.text:
Specify the type of TLS profile to use. Use proxy for TLS proxy (deprecated) profile, and use client for SSL client profile. Default is proxy. For example:
ssl-client-type client specifies TLS client profile will be used.

entry.name: ssl_client_type_tibcoemsserver_descr_1064
entry.text: Specify the type of TLS profile to use.

entry.name: ssl_client_tibcoemsserver_help_1065
entry.text:
Identifies the TLS Client Profile to establish a secure connection to the TIBCO EMS server. In the absence of an explicitly assigned TLS Client Profile, the DataPower Gateway establishes a nonsecure connection to the TIBCO EMS server.
name Identifies the TLS Client Profile to assign.
For example:
ssl emsTLSClient Assigns the emsTLSClient TLS Client Profile.

entry.name: ssl_client_tibcoemsserver_descr_1065
entry.text: Assigns a TLS Client Profile.

entry.name: ssl_tibcoemsserver_help_1066
entry.text:
Identifies the TLS Proxy Profile to establish a secure connection to the TIBCO EMS Server. The TLS proxy profile is deprecated. In the absence of
an explicitly assigned TLS Proxy Profile, the DataPower Gateway establishes a nonsecure connection to the TIBCO EMS server. name The TLS Proxy Profile to assign.
For example:
ssl emsTLSProxy Assigns the emsTLSProxy TLS Proxy Profile.

entry.name: ssl_tibcoemsserver_descr_1066
entry.text: Deprecated - Assigns a TLS Proxy Profile.

entry.name: total_connection_limit_tibcoemsserver_help_1067
entry.text:
Specifies the maximum number of open connections to the TIBCO EMS Server. Session requests in excess of the value set by the sessions-per-connection command trigger the establishment of a new connection to the TIBCO EMS Server, assuming that the number of current connections is less than the value specified by total-connection-limit command. For example, assuming default values (20 for sessions-per-connection, and 5 for total-connection-limit) and 3 active fully-subscribed connections, a new session request generates the establishment of a 4th connection. maxSessions is an integer (greater than 4, and with a default value of 20) that specifies the maximum concurrent sessions supported by a single connection to the TIBCO EMS Server.
For example:
total-connection-limit 4 sessions-per-connection 15 specifies the connection limit and per-connection session limit for the TIBCO EMS Server.

entry.name: total_connection_limit_tibcoemsserver_descr_1067
entry.text: Set per-connection session limit.

entry.name: transactional_tibcoemsserver_help_1068
entry.text:
Enables/disables transaction-based processing in which messages are acknowledged only after the transaction has succeeded. on and off are mutually exclusive key words that enable (on) or disable (off -- the default state) transaction-based processing.
For example:
transactional on enables transaction-based processing

entry.name: transactional_tibcoemsserver_descr_1068
entry.text: Enable/disable transaction-based processing.

entry.name: username_tibcoemsserver_help_1069
entry.text:
Specifies the account, or user name, to access the TIBCO EMS server.
plaintextString Is the account to access the TIBCO EMS server.
For example:
username Dante password-alias Alighieri-alias Specifies the user and password alias to access the server.

entry.name: username_tibcoemsserver_descr_1069
entry.text: Identify the TIBCO EMS Server account.

entry.name: get_queue_tibcoemssourceprotocolhandler_help_1070
entry.text:
Specifies the name of the queue that contains client-originated TIBCO EMS request messages. The TIBCO EMS Handler monitors the GET queue for incoming client requests. Upon message receipt, the handler forwards the extracted message to the a local TIBCO EMS object that will gateway the message to a remote TIBCO EMS server. Identification of a GET queue is required. queueName is the name of the queue that contains TIBCO EMS request messages. For example:
get-queue emsSecure identifies hiPriority as the TIBCO EMS GET queue

entry.name: get_queue_tibcoemssourceprotocolhandler_descr_1070
entry.text: Specifies the TIBCO EMS GET queue

entry.name: put_queue_tibcoemssourceprotocolhandler_help_1071
entry.text:
Specifies the name of the queue that contains server-originated TIBCO EMS reply messages. Such messages are originated by a remote TIBCO EMS server and put into this queue by a local TIBCO EMS object. Identification of a PUT queue is optional. A PUT queue should be configured if server replies are expected; if reply messages are not expected, a PUT queue need not be configured. In the absence of a PUT queue, any received replies are dropped. queueName is the name of the queue that contains TIBCO EMS reply messages. For example:
put-queue tibcoEmsResponse identifies tibcoEmsResponse as the TIBCO EMS PUT queue

entry.name: put_queue_tibcoemssourceprotocolhandler_descr_1071
entry.text: Specifies the TIBCO EMS PUT queue

entry.name: selector_tibcoemssourceprotocolhandler_help_1072
entry.text:
The message selector is a conditional expression based on a subset of SQL92 conditional expression syntax. The conditional expression enables the TIBCO EMS Handler to identify messages of interest. The conditional expression does not operate on the body of the EMS message, rather it examines EMS message headers and properties (proprietary user-created headers that might appear between the required headers and the message body). The required EMS headers are as follows:
Destination contains the destination (queue) to which the message is being sent DeliveryMode contains the delivery mode (PERSISTENT or NON_PERSISTENT) Expiration contains a message TTL or a value of 0 indicating an unlimited TTL Priority contains the message priority expressed as a digit from 0 (lowest priority) to 9 (highest priority) MessageID contains a unique message identifier starting with the prefix ID:, or a null value, effectively disabling message ID Timestamp contains the time the message was handed off for transmission, not the time it was actually sent CorrelationID contains a means of associating one message (for example, a response) with another message (for example, the original request) ReplyTo contains the destination (queue or topic) to which a reply to this message should be sent Type contains a message identifier provided by the application Redelivered contains a boolean indicating that the message has been delivered in the past, but not yet acknowledged
Configuration of a message selector is optional. If a message selector is not specified, all incoming client request messages are transferred by the TIBCO EMS Handler to the TIBCO EMS object for processing. If a message selector is specified, only those client requests that match the criteria specified by the SQL expression are forwarded to the TIBCO EMS object for processing. All other messages are dropped from the GET queue. sqlExpression is the SQL-like expression to filter messages from the GET queue. For example:
selector selector "DeliveryMode LIKE PERSISTENT" indicates that only client requests that have a DeliveryMode of PERSISTENT are forwarded to the TIBCOMS object for processing; all other messages are dropped from the GET queue.

entry.name: selector_tibcoemssourceprotocolhandler_descr_1072
entry.text: Describe messages of interest.

entry.name: server_tibcoemssourceprotocolhandler_help_1073
entry.text:
Specifies the TIBCO EMS Server object supported by this protocol handler. tibcoEMSName is the name of the TIBCO EMS object supported by this TIBCO EMS Protocol handler. For example:
server emsServer-1 identifies emsServer-1 as the supported TIBCO EMS object

entry.name: server_tibcoemssourceprotocolhandler_descr_1073
entry.text: identifies the supported TIBCO EMS object

entry.name: hostname_uddiregistry_help_1074
entry.text:
Establishes the IP address or hostname of the remote UDDI registry host. hostname Address of registry. For example:
hostname 192.168.1.20 sets the IP address of the registry to 192.168.1.20

entry.name: hostname_uddiregistry_descr_1074
entry.text: Establishes the IP address or hostname of registry.

entry.name: inquiry_url_uddiregistry_help_1075
entry.text:
The local path (URI) portion of the URL used to query the Registry. UDDI inquiry requests will be sent to http(s)://hostname:port/inquiry-url. A typical default looks like https://192.18.1.120:443/uddi/inquiry. URI The URI for querying For example:
inquiry-url "/uddi/web/inquiry"

entry.name: inquiry_url_uddiregistry_descr_1075
entry.text: The local path (URI) portion of the URL used to query the Registry.

entry.name: port_uddiregistry_help_1076
entry.text:
The port number of the registry's SOAP over HTTP interface. See ssl-port command to set the port for HTTPS communications. port The port number of the registry. For example:
port 8080 sets the port number on which the Registry listens to 8080.

entry.name: port_uddiregistry_descr_1076
entry.text: The port number of the registry's SOAP over HTTP interface.

entry.name: publish_url_uddiregistry_help_1077
entry.text:
The local path (URI) portion of the URL used to publish to the Registry. UDDI publish requests will be sent to http(s)://hostname:port/inquiry-url. A typical default looks like https://192.18.1.120:443/uddi/publishing. URI The URI for publishing. For example:
publish-url "/uddi/web/publish"

entry.name: publish_url_uddiregistry_descr_1077
entry.text: The local path (URI) portion of the URL used to publish to the Registry.

entry.name: security_url_uddiregistry_help_1078
entry.text:
The local path (URI) portion of the URL used to issue security requests to the Registry. The Registry may impose security, such as requiring username and passwords, on any data maintained in the registry. UDDI subscription requests will be sent to http(s)://hostname:port/security-url. A typical default looks like https://192.18.1.120:443/uddi/security.
For example:
security-url "/uddi/web/security"

entry.name: security_url_uddiregistry_descr_1078
entry.text: The local path (URI) portion of the URL used for security requests.

entry.name: ssl_uddiregistry_help_1079
entry.text:
The TLS proxy profile is deprecated. Use a TLS client profile. Sets an existing TLS proxy profile for TLS communications with the remote registry. The TLS proxy profile determines the keys and certificates for secure connections. This does not turn on, or enable TLS connections to the registry. Use the use-ssl command to enable TLS connections.
name The TLS proxy profile to assign.
For example:
ssl registryTLS Assigns the registryTLS TLS proxy profile.

entry.name: ssl_uddiregistry_descr_1079
entry.text: Deprecated - Sets the TLS proxy profile in effect for TLS connections to the Registry.

entry.name: ssl_port_uddiregistry_help_1080
entry.text:
The port number of the registry's SOAP over HTTPS interface.
port The HTTP port. The default is 443.
For example:
port 9091 Sets the port number on which the registry listens to 9091.

entry.name: ssl_port_uddiregistry_descr_1080
entry.text: The port number of the registry's SOAP over HTTPS interface.

entry.name: subscription_url_uddiregistry_help_1081
entry.text:
The local path (URI) portion of the URL used to subscribe to the Registry. UDDI subscription requests will be sent to http(s)://hostname:port/subscription-url. A typical default looks like https://192.18.1.120:443/uddi/subscription. URI The URI for subscriptions. For example:
subscription-url "/uddi/web/subscribe"

entry.name: subscription_url_uddiregistry_descr_1081
entry.text: The local path (URI) portion of the URL used for subscription data requests.

entry.name: use_ssl_uddiregistry_help_1082
entry.text:
Determines when to use TLS connections to the registry. always Require TLS for all connections to the registry. publish Require TLS only when publishing information to the registry.
For example:
use-ssl always Requires TLS connections for all communications with the registry.

entry.name: use_ssl_uddiregistry_descr_1082
entry.text: Determines when to use TLS connections to the registry.

entry.name: version_uddiregistry_help_1083
entry.text:
Determines the UDDI specification version employed. This must agree with what is supported by the remote registry. UDDIv2 Use UDDI version 2. The default. UDDIv3 Use UDDI version 3.
For example:
version UDDIv3 sets the UDDI specification employed to UDDI version 3.

entry.name: version_uddiregistry_descr_1083
entry.text: Determines the UDDI specification version employed.

entry.name: key_uddisubscription_help_1084
entry.text:
This is a subscriptionKey for the subscription, which must already exist in the registry. In order to track services that are modeled in UDDI using both services and tModels (e.g. when following UDDI Best Practices), several subscriptions will be required in order to receive updates for both the service and tModel components. All of these subscriptions must use the same Username and Password. Issue the key command as many times as needed to include all desired keys in this object. Use the no form of the command to remove keys.
key A valid subscription key, as defined on the registry configured for this object.
For example:
key uddi:4f0d7450-a578-11d8-91cd-5c1d367091cd key uddi:4f0d7450-a578-11d8-91cd-5c1d367092cd adds two subscription keys to this object.

entry.name: key_uddisubscription_descr_1084
entry.text: Includes a Registry subscription key in this object.

entry.name: password_uddisubscription_help_1085
entry.text:
Sets the password for the subscription connection. This property is deprecated and replaced with password-alias.
password the password to use for connecting to the registry.
For example:
password jhfhvhy333 sets the password for the subscription connection.

entry.name: password_uddisubscription_descr_1085
entry.text: Sets the password for the subscription connection (deprecated).

entry.name: password_alias_uddisubscription_help_1086
entry.text:
Sets the password alias of the password for the subscription connection.
password-alias the password alias of the password to use for connecting to the registry.
For example:
password-alias jhfhvhy333 sets the password alias for the subscription connection.

entry.name: password_alias_uddisubscription_descr_1086
entry.text: Sets the password alias of the password for the subscription connection.

entry.name: registry_uddisubscription_help_1087
entry.text:
The UDDI Registry object identifying a UDDI Registry offering the subscriptions desired.
registryName The name of an existing UDDI Registry object. To create a new Registry object, use the uddi-registry Global Configuration command.
For example:
registry WebServiceRegistry establishes the Registry used for these subscriptions.

entry.name: registry_uddisubscription_descr_1087
entry.text: Determines the UDDI Registry for these subscriptions.

entry.name: username_uddisubscription_help_1088
entry.text:
Sets the username for the subscription connection. username the username to use for connecting to the registry.
For example:
username proxydevice sets the username for the subscription connection.

entry.name: username_uddisubscription_descr_1088
entry.text: Sets the username for the subscription connection.

entry.name: match_urlmap_help_1089
entry.text:
Adds the specified URL match pattern (or rule) to the current URL map. The patterns contained within the map determine whether or not a specific URL belongs to the mapping. URL maps are used to implement a Stylesheet-Refresh Policy.
match The match pattern, per the rules above. For example:
match http://www.datapower.com/stylesheets/routine.xsl adds an exact match -- matching the specified stylesheet match http://www.datapower.com/stylesheets/* adds a wildcard match -- matching any file in the stylesheets directory

entry.name: match_urlmap_descr_1089
entry.text: Adds a match pattern to a URL map

entry.name: disable_cache_urlrefreshpolicy_help_1090
entry.text:
Assigns a named URL map to the current URL Refresh Policy; candidate stylesheets matching the rules contained within this URL map are not cached by an XML manager. url-map is the name of the assigned URL map. For example:
disable cache URLmap-1 assigns URLmap-1 to the current URL Refresh Policy. Stylesheets matching rules contained within URLmap-1 are not cached by an XML manager.

entry.name: disable_cache_urlrefreshpolicy_descr_1090
entry.text: Defines the URL map of style sheets to never cache.

entry.name: disable_flush_urlrefreshpolicy_help_1091
entry.text:
Assigns a named URL map to the current URL Refresh Policy; candidate stylesheets matching the rules contained within this URL map are preferentially cached by an XML manager. url-map is the name of the assigned URL map. refresh-interval is an integer that specifies the frequency (expressed in seconds) at which stylesheets obtained via url-map are refreshed. For example:
disable flush URLmap-2 3600 assigns URLmap-2 to the current URL Refresh Policy. Stylesheets matching rules contained within URLmap-2 are preferentially cached by an XML manager for one hour (3600 seconds).

entry.name: disable_flush_urlrefreshpolicy_descr_1091
entry.text: Defines the URL map of style sheet to cache preferentially.

entry.name: interval_urlmap_urlrefreshpolicy_help_1092
entry.text:
Assigns a named URL map to the current URL Refresh Policy; candidate stylesheets matching the rules contained within this URL map are cached by an XML manager. url-map is the name of the assigned URL map. refresh-interval is an integer that specifies the frequency (expressed in seconds) at which stylesheets obtained via url-map are refreshed. For example:
interval urlmap URLmap-3 43200 assigns URLmap-3 to the current URL Refresh Policy. Stylesheets matching rules contained within URLmap-3 are cached by an XML manager for twelve hours (43200 seconds).

entry.name: interval_urlmap_urlrefreshpolicy_descr_1092
entry.text: Defines the URL map of style sheets to cache.

entry.name: protocol_specified_urlrefreshpolicy_help_1093
entry.text:
Assigns a named URL map to the current URL Refresh Policy; candidate stylesheets matching the rules contained within this URL map are cached using expiration semantics provided by the transport protocol, such as http. urlMap is the name of the assigned URL map. refreshInterval is an integer that specifies the frequency (expressed in seconds) at which stylesheets obtained via urlMap are refreshed. For example:
protocol-specific httpMap 3600 assigns httpMap to the current URL Refresh Policy. Stylesheets matching rules contained within httpMap are preferentially cached by an XML manager for one hour (3600 seconds).

entry.name: protocol_specified_urlrefreshpolicy_descr_1093
entry.text: Defines the URL map of style sheets to cache with protocol semantics.

entry.name: direction_urlrewritepolicy_help_1094
entry.text: URLRewrite policy by default is applied in both directions when initiated from a service object.) Use this option to add directionality to the policy restricting it to either request or response processing when invoked from a service level object. Direction has no meaning when invoked from a urlrewrite action.

entry.name: direction_urlrewritepolicy_descr_1094
entry.text: Adds a processing direction to this policy

entry.name: rewrite_urlrewritepolicy_help_1095
entry.text:
This command is deprecated. Use absolute-rewrite instead. Matches against the filename portion of a requested URL and constructs a new request URL and stylesheet URL from it. regexp-pattern specifies a regular expression that the filename portion of an requested URL is matched against, e.g., if the requested URL is "http://myhost.com/myfile.xml", this pattern matches against the "/myfile.xml" portion.
url-replace is the replacement URL (which may contain regular expression syntax) that is forwarded to the web or application server. If this argument is not present, the original URL is forwarded unmodified. If a replacement URL begins with a hostname or port different from the remote-address configured on the service using this rule, the hostname and port portion of the URL is ignored.
style-replace (which may contain regular express syntax) identifies the stylesheet used to transform the XML document. If this argument is not present, the default stylesheet specified in the proxy configuration is used.
url-unescape is a boolean value (true | false) that specifies whether the replacement URL is url-decoded. Default: false.
stylesheet-url-unescape is a boolean value (true | false) that specifies whether the stylesheet URL is url-decoded. Default: true.

entry.name: rewrite_urlrewritepolicy_descr_1095
entry.text: Adds a URL rewrite rule to a URL Rewrite Policy

entry.name: absolute_rewrite_urlrewritepolicy_help_1096
entry.text:
Adds a URL rewrite rule to the current URL Rewrite Policy. regexp is a Perl compatible regular expression defining a match condition that triggers this URL rewrite rule. Candidate URLs matching the regular expression trigger the rewrite rule. input-replace is an optional Perl compatible regular expression that defines the rewritten URL (which will be passed to the Web or Application server. style-replace is an optional Perl compatible regular expression that defines the stylesheet used to filter or transform the XML document referenced by the rewritten URL. input-url-unescape is a boolean value (true | false) that specifies whether URL-encoded characters (for example, %%2F) occurring in the rewritten URL are replaced with literal character equivalents. true replaces escape sequences with literal characters. false retains escape sequences. stylesheet-url-unescape is a boolean value (true | false) that specifies whether URL-encoded characters (for example, %%2F) occurring in the rewritten stylesheet URL are replaced with literal character equivalents. true replaces escape sequences with literal characters. false retains escape sequences. For example:
absolute-rewrite (.*)xsl=(.*)\?(.*) $1xsl=ident.xsl?$3 http://mantis:8000/$2 adds a URL rewrite rule to the current URL Rewrite Policy

entry.name: absolute_rewrite_urlrewritepolicy_descr_1096
entry.text: Adds a URL rewrite rule to a URL Rewrite Policy

entry.name: content_type_urlrewritepolicy_help_1097
entry.text:
Adds a content-type rewrite rule to the current URL Rewrite Policy. regexp is a Perl compatible regular expression defining a match condition that triggers this content-type rewrite rule. Candidate URLs matching the regular expression trigger the rewrite rule. input-replace is a literal string or Perl compatible regular expression that specifies rewritten contents of the Content-Type header field. For example:
content-type /web/Server.* text/xml adds a content-type rewrite rule to the current URL Rewrite Policy

entry.name: content_type_urlrewritepolicy_descr_1097
entry.text: Adds a Content-Type rewrite rule to a URL Rewrite Policy

entry.name: header_rewrite_urlrewritepolicy_help_1098
entry.text:
Adds an HTTP header field rewrite rule (a rule that rewrites the contents of a specified HTTP header field) to the current URL Rewrite Policy. http-header-field The target HTTP header field as defined in sections 4.5, 5.3, 6.2, and 7.1 of RFC 2616. regexp is a Perl compatible regular expression defining a match condition that triggers this HTTP header field rewrite rule. Candidate HTTP header fields matching the regular expression trigger the rewrite rule. input-replace is a Perl compatible regular expression that defines the rewritten contents of the specified HTTP header field. For example:
header-rewrite Age *.* 1 adds an HTTP header field rewrite rule to the current URL Rewrite Policy

entry.name: header_rewrite_urlrewritepolicy_descr_1098
entry.text: Adds an HTTP header rewrite rule to a URL Rewrite Policy

entry.name: post_body_urlrewritepolicy_help_1099
entry.text: Adds a POST-body rewrite rule to the current URL Rewrite Policy. url-regexp is a PCRE (Perl compatible regular expression) that defines a URL set. This argument, although not used with the current release, is required to maintain compatibility with prior releases. Users are encouraged to use a "universal" regexp such as *.* post-body-regexp is a PCRE defining a match condition that triggers this POST-bocy rewrite rule. Candidate POSTs matching the regular expression trigger the rewrite rule. body-replace is an optional Perl compatible regular expression that defines the rewritten POST (which will be passed to the Web or Application server. style-replace is an optional PCRE that defines the stylesheet used to filter or transform the rewritten POST. input-url-unescape is a boolean value (true | false) that specifies whether URL-encoded characters (for example, %%2F) occurring in the rewritten POST are replaced with literal character equivalents. true replaces escape sequences with literal characters. false retains escape sequences. stylesheet-url-unescape is a boolean value (true | false) that specifies whether URL-encoded characters (for example, %%2F) occurring in the rewritten stylesheet URL are replaced with literal character equivalents. true replaces escape sequences with literal characters. false retains escape sequences.

entry.name: post_body_urlrewritepolicy_descr_1099
entry.text: Adds a POST body rewrite rule to a URL Rewrite Policy

entry.name: access_level_user_help_1100
entry.text:
Assigns user privileges to the account being defined. group-defined and privileged are mutually exclusive keywords that specify access privileges granted to the user. group-defined indicates that the user is granted access privileges as defined by a specific User Group. The user must later be assigned to this group with the group command. privileged indicates that the user is granted the same read-write access as the admin account; a privileged used differs from the admin account only in that a privileged user cannot delete the admin account. For example:
access-level privileged this user is granted the same read-write access as the admin account access-level group-defined this user will be accorded access privileges inherited from an assigned User Group

entry.name: access_level_user_descr_1100
entry.text: Assigns user account privileges

entry.name: group_user_help_1101
entry.text:
Assigns a user to a User Group. The user derives his/her access privileges from the assigned group. groupName The User Group to which the user is assigned. For example:
access-level group-defined group developer this user will be accorded access privileges inherited from the assigned developer group

entry.name: group_user_descr_1101
entry.text: Assigns a user to a User Group

entry.name: password_user_help_1102
entry.text:
Assigns a temporary password or changes a password. For example:
password Enter new password: ****** Re-enter new password: ******
password mypass Re-enter new password: ******

entry.name: password_user_descr_1102
entry.text: Assigns/changes a password

entry.name: snmp_cred_user_help_1103
entry.text:
Adds SNMP V3 credentials for this user. Each user can have multiple SNMP V3 credentials, one for each SNMP V3 engine identified by an engineID value. The secrets for authentication can be entered either as passphrases, which will be hashed and localized using the engineID, or can be entered as localized hex keys. engineID The engineID of the SNMP V3 engine that this user is being defined for. 0 is a shorthand for the engineID of the local SNMP V3 engine on this system. For other engineID values, they are a hex string representing a 5 to 32 byte value. none, md5, and sha are mutually-exclusive keywords specifying what authentication protocol this user will use. none This user has no authentication key. md5 This user uses HMAC-MD5-96 as the authentication protocol. sha This user uses HMAC-SHA-96 as the authentication protocol. password and key are mutually-exclusive keywords that specify whether a secret (auth-secret or priv-secret) is a password or is a fully localized key. password The following secret is a password, which will be converted to an intermediate key with a standardized algorithm and then localized against the engineID value. key The following secret is a fully localized key. auth-secret The secret, or key, for authentication for this user. If a password, this is a plaintext password, which must be at least 8 characters long. If a key, and HMAC-MD5 is the authentication protocol, it is the hex representation of a 16 byte key. If HMAC-SHA-96 is the authentication protocol, it is the hex representation of a 20 byte key. Colons (:) can be optionally used between each two hex characters. none, des, and aes are mutually-exclusive keywords specifying what privacy (encryption) protocol this user will use. none This user has no privacy key. des This user uses CBC-DES as the privacy protocol. aes This user uses CFB128-AES-128 as the privacy protocol. priv-secret The secret, or key, for privacy (encryption) for this user. If a password, this is a plaintext password, which must be at least 8 characters long. If a key, and HMAC-MD5 is the authentication protocol, it is the hex representation of a 16 byte key. If HMAC-SHA-1 is the authentication protocol, it is the hex representation of a 20 byte key. Colons (:) can be optionally used between each two hex characters. For example:
snmp-cred 0 md5 password aBigSecret des password aDifferentSecret Creates SNMP V3 credentials for this user on the local machine with HMAC-MD5-96 as the authentication algorithm, and DES-CBC as the privacy algorithm. The password aBigSecret will be converted to a localized authentication key, and the password aDifferentSecret will be converted to a localized encryption key.
snmp-cred 000000000000000000000002 md5 password maplesyrup none password "" Creates SNMP V3 credentials for this user on the remote machine with the engineID 000000000000000000000002. The authentication algorithm is HMAC-MD5-96, and there is no privacy algorithm. The password is maplesyrup, which will be converted to a localized key for engineID 000000000000000000000002.
snmp-cred 000000000000000000000002 md5 key 52:6f:5e:ed:9f:cc:e2:6f:89:64:c2:93:07:87:d8:2b none password "" This does the same thing as the previous example, except that the fully localized key has been entered directly. This is useful when the key was initially created on another system, and it (properly) will only display the localized key.

entry.name: snmp_cred_user_descr_1103
entry.text: Add SNMP V3 credentials to this user

entry.name: access_policy_usergroup_help_1104
entry.text:
Assigns an access policy to the current User Group. The access policy provides user accounts that are subsequently assigned to the User Group with the access privileges granted by this access policy.
It is possible to assign more than one access policy to a user group. If there are more than one statement, the statements are cumulative. If more than one statement applies to the same resource, the most specific statement will apply. For example, given the following statements:
*/*/*?Access=r */*/services/wsgateway?Access=r+w+a
Any member of the user group being configured can read all objects and modify and add wsgateway objects.
To remove an access policy, it is necessary to remove all policies with the no access-policy command and then recreate the desired policies.
statement The policy statement added to the user group. An access policy statement takes the following forms:
<address>/<domain>/<type>?[Name=<resource>]&Access=<permission>
where:
address An IP address. This policy will apply only to clients with IP addresses that match this value. PCRE expressions are allowed. A value of * matches all possible addresses.
domain The name of an application domain. This policy will apply only to resources within the given domain. A value of * matches all possible domains.
type The resource type to which this policy applies. To obtain a list of resource types, type access-policy help at the configuration prompt.
resource Optional. The name of a resource of the type specified. PCRE expressions can be used (for example "foo*").
permissions The permission string assigns permissions. The string is cumulative and connected by + signs. For example "r+w+a+d" r Read w Write (modify) a Add a new object d Delete existing object x Execute For example:
usergroup appdev access-policy "*/*/*?Access=r+w+a+d" access-policy "*/*/login/?Access=r" access-policy "*/*/network/*?Access=r" Enters User Group Configuration Mode, creates a appdev User Group, and provides full access to all resources but read only access for login and network resources for members of the appdev User Group.

entry.name: access_policy_usergroup_descr_1104
entry.text: Assigns an access policy.

entry.name: add_usergroup_help_1105
entry.text:
Adds a command group (a set of associated CLI commands) to the current User Group, thus providing that User Group with access to the command set. command-group identifies the command group. To display a list or command groups, use the add command, with no arguments, at the CLI prompt. For example:
add stylesheetpolicy adds the Stylesheet Policy command group to the current User Group

entry.name: add_usergroup_descr_1105
entry.text: Adds a command group to a User Group

entry.name: delete_usergroup_help_1106
entry.text:
Removes a command group (a set of associated CLI commands) from the current User Group, thus denying that User Group access to the command set. command-group identifies the command group. To display a list or command groups, use the delete command, with no arguments, at the CLI prompt. For example:
delete stylesheetpolicy removes the Stylesheet Policy command group from the current User Group

entry.name: delete_usergroup_descr_1106
entry.text: Removes a command group from a User Group

entry.name: cert_validation_mode_cryptovalcred_help_1107
entry.text:
Specifies the method by which received certificates are validated.
legacy (the default) A received certificate is deemed valid if the current Validation Credentials list contains either the exact received certificate, or the immediate issuer's certificate, which may be an intermediate or root certificate. pkix A received certificate is deemed valid only if the complete certificate chain (from received certificate to root CA) ends in a trusted CA. This technique requires that the remote peer provide all intermediate certificates during TLS negotiation. Note that with this method, an exact match of the received certificate is possible only if that certificate is a self-signed root certificate. exact-match A received certificate is deemed valid if the current Validation Credentials list contains the exact received certificate.
For example:
cert-validation-mode pkix Requires validation of the complete certificate chain.

entry.name: cert_validation_mode_cryptovalcred_descr_1107
entry.text: Specifies the validation technique

entry.name: certificate_cryptovalcred_help_1108
entry.text:
Adds the specified certificate to the current Validation Credentials list. certObjectName The target certificate. For example:
certificate bob adds the certificate object bob to the current Validation Credentials list.

entry.name: certificate_cryptovalcred_descr_1108
entry.text: Adds an entry to a validation list

entry.name: crldp_cryptovalcred_help_1109
entry.text:
Enables or disables support for the X.509 Certificate Distribution Point certificate extension.
"ignore" and "require" are mutually exclusive tokens that enable or disable support for the X.509 Certificate Distribution Point certificate extension.
ignore (the default) ignores the certificate extension, if present.
require checks the certificate extension. This method is used when the current Validation Credentials List is used for TLS peer validation. In this case, the candidate certificate is deemed to be valid when the presented certificate chain is terminated by a trust anchor.
For example:
valcred ValCred-1 crldp require enters Validation Credentials Mode, creates the ValCred-1 Validation Credentials List, and enables support for the Certificate Distribution Point certificate extension.
crldp ignore restores the default state.

entry.name: crldp_cryptovalcred_descr_1109
entry.text: Enables or disables support for X.509 extensions.

entry.name: explicit_policy_cryptovalcred_help_1110
entry.text:
Disables or enables support for the initial-explicit-policy variable as defined in RFC 3280 "Internet X.509 Public Key Infrastructure Certificate and Certificate Revocation List (CRL) Profile".
This command is meaningful only when cert-validation mode is "pkix"; otherwise, it is not used.
If enabled, the chain validation algorithm must end with a non-empty policy tree. If disabled, the algorithm can end with an empty policy tree unless Policy Constraints extensions in the chain require an explicit policy.
on | off are mutually exclusive keywords that enables ("on") or disables ("off") the initial-explicit-policy variable. The default is off. Alternatively, use the "no" form of the command to disable support for the initial-explicit-policy variable.
For example:
explicit-policy . . . explicit-policy off specifies the chain validation algorithm must end with an empty tree. Subsequently, restores the default state.
explicit-policy . . . no explicit-policy same as the previous example.

entry.name: initial_policy_set_cryptovalcred_help_1111
entry.text:
Identifies a Certificate Policy used by the current Validation Credentials List. The certificate policies extension contains a sequence of one or more policy information terms, each of which consists of an object identifier (OID) and optional qualifiers.
Notes:
The current release does not support qualifiers. If present, they will be ignored.
This command is meaningful only when cert-validation mode is "pkix"; otherwise, it is not used.
In a host certificate, policy information terms indicate the policy under which the certificate was issued and the purposes for which the certificate can be used.
In a CA certificate, policy information terms limit the set of policies for certification paths that include this certificate. When a CA does not wish to limit the set of policies for certification paths that include this certificate, it can assert the "anyPolicy" special policy with an OID of 2.5.29.32.0.
Use this command as often as needed to construct a set of Certificate Policy identifiers. By default, the initial Certificate Policy Set consists of the single OID 2.5.29.32.0, that identifies anyPolicy. All members of the constructed set are used in certificate chain processing as described in Section 6.1.1 of RFC 3280.
Use the "no" form of this command to remove a Certificate Policy from the Validation Credentials List.
policyOID is the unique object identifier for the certificate policy that is associated with the current Validation Credentials List.
For example:
initial-policy-set 1.3.6.1.4.1.14248.1.1 adds the 1.3.6.1.4.1.14248.1.1 OID to the set of Certificate Policy identifiers that associated with the current Validation Credentials List.
no initial-policy-set 1.3.6.1.4.1.14248.1.1 removes the 1.3.6.1.4.1.14248.1.1 OID from the set of Certificate Policy identifiers.

entry.name: initial_policy_set_cryptovalcred_descr_1111
entry.text: Identifies a Certificate Policy.

entry.name: require_crl_cryptovalcred_help_1112
entry.text:
Meaningful only if CRL (Certificate Revocation List) usage is enabled, the default state. If CRL usage has been enabled, requires the use of a CRL during the certificate validation process. In the absence of a CRL, for any reason, certificate validation fails. By default, CRL usage is not required. For example:
require-crl specifies that certificate validation requires a CRL.

entry.name: require_crl_cryptovalcred_descr_1112
entry.text: Require CRL usage

entry.name: use_crl_cryptovalcred_help_1113
entry.text:
Enables the use of CRLs (certificate Revocation Lists) while verifying received certificates. By default, CRL usage is enabled. Use crl (Crypto Configuration Mode) and related commands to define a CRL Update Policy. For example:
use-crl enables CRL usage when verifying received certificates, thus restoring the default state.

entry.name: use_crl_cryptovalcred_descr_1113
entry.text: Enables CRL usage

entry.name: check_dates_cryptovalcred_help_1114
entry.text:
Specifies whether to check the current date and time against the notBefore and notAfter fields in certificates and CRLs during certificate validation. If enabled, date fields are checked and expired certificates will cause validation to fail. If disabled, date fields are ignored and the fact that a certificate is expired will not cause validation to fail. For example:
check-dates off specifies that dates are not checked during certificate validation.

entry.name: check_dates_cryptovalcred_descr_1114
entry.text: Check dates

entry.name: priority_webappfw_help_1115
entry.text: Assigns a priority for scheduling or for resource allocation. When system resources are in high demand, higher priority services will be favored over lower priority services. low Receives below normal priority. normal (Default) Receives normal priority. high Receives above normal priority.

entry.name: priority_webappfw_descr_1115
entry.text: Assigns a service-level scheduling priority

entry.name: allow_cache_control_webappfw_help_1116
entry.text:
Specifies whether the Cache-Control header passes from the client to the back end. on Specifies that the HTTP GET method passes the Cache-Control header through to the back end. If the client request does not specify the header, a "Cache-Control:no-transform" header is passed to the back end. off (Default) A "Cache-Control:no-transform" header is passed to the back end. For example:
allow-cache-control on enables the client to specify the Cache-Control header with the HTTP GET method.

entry.name: allow_cache_control_webappfw_descr_1116
entry.text: Specifies handling of the Cache-Control header

entry.name: summary_webappfw_help_1117
entry.text:
Enter an alphanumeric string for user annotation.
Summary Any alphanumeric string in quotation marks. For example:
summary "Web App FW fronting internal portal application."

entry.name: summary_webappfw_descr_1117
entry.text: Comment for user annotation

entry.name: listen_on_webappfw_help_1118
entry.text:
Establishes IP Address, TCP Port on which service listens. Optionally, requires TLS connections. Optionally, specifies the character encoding of the original basic authentication values.
LocalAddress An IP address in dot notation (10.10.1.23) or an existing host alias. LocalPort An available TCP port. UseTLS Can be "on" or "off" to control TLS connections. Defaults to off. If turned on, assign a TLS profile to establish secure connections. CredentialCharset Specifies the character encoding of the original basic authentication values. Basic authentication credentials are combined and base64 encoded in the authorization header of the request. The DataPower Gateway transcodes the contents of the authorization header to UTF-8. The default value is "protocol", which is ISO-8859-1. - protocol - ascii - big5 - cp1250 - cp1251 - cp1252 - cp1253 - cp1254 - cp1255 - cp1256 - cp1257 - cp1258 - euc_jp - euc_kr - gb18030 - gb2312 - iso2022_jp - iso2022_kr - iso8859_1 - iso8859_2 - iso8859_4 - iso8859_5 - iso8859_6 - iso8859_7 - iso8859_8 - iso8859_9 - iso8859_15 - sjis - tis620 - unicode_le - utf8
For example:
listen-on 10.10.13.23 3000 Causes the firewall to listen to IP address 10.10.13.23 for client requests on port 3000.
listen-on 10.10.13.23 3000 off utf8 Causes the firewall to listen to IP address 10.10.13.23 for client requests on port 3000. Does not use TLS. Specifies UTF-8 for the character set encoding.

entry.name: listen_on_webappfw_descr_1118
entry.text: Establishes IP Address, TCP Port, TLS, and credential encoding

entry.name: remote_address_webappfw_help_1119
entry.text:
Establishes IP Address of remote (back end) application server.
RemoteAddress Remote IP address of back end application server.
For example:
remote-address 10.10.103.2 Causes the Firewall to forward all requests to IP address 10.10.103.23.

entry.name: remote_address_webappfw_descr_1119
entry.text: Establishes remote (back end server) address.

entry.name: remote_port_webappfw_help_1120
entry.text:
Establishes TCP port of remote (back end) application server.
RemotePort Remote port number. Defaults to 80.
For example:
remote-port 8080 Causes the Firewall to forward all requests to port 8080.

entry.name: remote_port_webappfw_descr_1120
entry.text: Establishes remote (back end server) port.

entry.name: ssl_client_webappfw_help_1121
entry.text:
Assigns a TLS client profile to the current Web Application Firewall. The client profile secures connections between the DataPower Gateway and the remote server.
This command is used only when the value set by the ssl-config-type is either "server" or "sni". If the value is "proxy", a TLS proxy profile must be used with forward crypto profile instead.
name The TLS client profile to assign.
For example:
ssl-client tlsClientProfile Assigns the tlsClientProfile TLS client profile.

entry.name: ssl_client_webappfw_descr_1121
entry.text: Assigns a TLS client profile to Web Application Firewall.

entry.name: ssl_config_type_webappfw_help_1122
entry.text:
Specifies the TLS profile type. Valid values include proxy, server, or sni. Default is proxy, which uses TLS proxy profile. Use server to specify TLS server profile, and use sni to indicate TLS SNI server profile. For example:
ssl-config-type server specify that TLS server profile is used to secure connections.

entry.name: ssl_config_type_webappfw_descr_1122
entry.text: Specifies the TLS profile type.

entry.name: ssl_profile_webappfw_help_1123
entry.text:
The TLS proxy profile is deprecated. Use a TLS client profile and a TLS server profile or TLS SNI server profile.
Establishes TLS proxy profile to control TLS connections. May be required if firewall listens with TLS on, or if communications with servers require TLS.
name The name of an existing TLS proxy profile.
For example:
ssl-profile wasTLS Assigns the wasTLS TLS proxy profile.

entry.name: ssl_profile_webappfw_descr_1123
entry.text: Deprecated - Select TLS proxy profile to control TLS connections.

entry.name: ssl_server_webappfw_help_1124
entry.text:
Assigns a TLS server profile to the Web Application Firewall. The Web Application Firewall uses this profile to establish a secure connection with clients. name The TLS server profile to assign. For example:
ssl-server highSec Assigns the highSec TLS server profile.

entry.name: ssl_server_webappfw_descr_1124
entry.text: Assigns a TLS server profile to the Web Application Firewall.

entry.name: ssl_sni_server_webappfw_help_1125
entry.text:
Assigns a TLS SNI server profile to the Web Application Firewall. The Web Application Firewall uses this profile to establish a secure connection with clients. sslSNIProfileName The TLS SNI server profile. For example:
ssl-sni-server highSec assigns the TLS SNI server profile, highSec, to the Web Application Firewall.

entry.name: ssl_sni_server_webappfw_descr_1125
entry.text: Assigns a TLS SNI server profile to the Web Application Firewall.

entry.name: security_policy_webappfw_help_1126
entry.text:
Establishes the required Security Policy for this Firewall.
SecurityPolicyName The name of an existing Security Policy. Use the Global command application-security-policy to create a new policy.
For example:
security-policy portal-sec-policy Sets the security policy to portal-sec-policy.

entry.name: security_policy_webappfw_descr_1126
entry.text: Selects the required Security Policy for this Firewall.

entry.name: error_policy_webappfw_help_1127
entry.text:
Establishes an optional Error Policy for this Firewall.
ErrorPolicyName The name of an existing Error Policy. Use the Global command webapp-error-handling to create a new policy.
For example:
error-policy portal-err-policy Sets the error policy to portal-err-policy.

entry.name: error_policy_webappfw_descr_1127
entry.text: Selects an Error Policy for this Firewall.

entry.name: uri_normalization_webappfw_help_1128
entry.text:
If this property is enabled the URI is rewritten to make sure the URI is RFC-compliant by escaping certain characters. Additionally, characters that are escaped that do not need to be are unescaped. This makes checking for attack sequences such as .. more reliable. on|off Enable (on, the default) or disable (off) URI normalization.
For example:
uri-normalization on Normalizes URIs.

entry.name: uri_normalization_webappfw_descr_1128
entry.text: Controls URI normalization.

entry.name: stream_output_to_back_webappfw_help_1129
entry.text:
Specifies if the current firewall begins sending output to the server before completing the processing of a client request.
buffer-until-verification indicates that the firewall disables streaming. With streaming disabled, the firewall buffers a client request until all processing is complete, and only then sends the request to the server.
stream-until-infraction indicates that the firewall enables streaming. With streaming enabled (which may result in faster response times) the firewall begins sending the request to the server prior to the completion of processing. If a processing error occurs, the firewall reverts to the buffering model.
For example:
stream-output-to-front stream-until-infraction enables back-end streaming

entry.name: stream_output_to_back_webappfw_descr_1129
entry.text: Enables/Disables back-end streaming

entry.name: stream_output_to_front_webappfw_help_1130
entry.text:
Specifies if the current firewall begins sending output to the client before completing the processing of a server response.
buffer-until-verification indicates that the firewall disables streaming. With streaming disabled, the firewall buffers a server response until all processing is complete, and only then sends the response to the client.
stream-until-infraction indicates that the firewall enables streaming. With streaming enabled (which may result in faster response times) the firewall begins sending the response to the client prior to the completion of processing. If a processing error occurs, the firewall reverts to the buffering model.
For example:
stream-output-to-front stream-until-infraction enables front-end streaming

entry.name: stream_output_to_front_webappfw_descr_1130
entry.text: Enables/Disables front-end streaming

entry.name: front_timeout_webappfw_help_1131
entry.text:
Specifies the number of seconds that an idle client connection is maintained before being terminated.
idleTimeout specifies the number of seconds that an idle client connection is maintained. Allowable values are within the range 10 through 86400 seconds, with a default value of 120.
For example:
front-timeout 60 specifies a front-side idle timeout of 1 minute

entry.name: front_timeout_webappfw_descr_1131
entry.text: Specifies a client-side idle timeout

entry.name: front_persistent_timeout_webappfw_help_1132
entry.text:
Specifies the number of seconds that an idle client persistent connection is maintained before being terminated.
persistentTimeout specifies the number of seconds that an idle client persistent connection is maintained. Allowable values are within the range 10 through 86400 seconds, with a default value of 180.
For example:
front-persistent-timeout 150 specifies a back-side idle timeout of two-and-a-half minutes

entry.name: front_persistent_timeout_webappfw_descr_1132
entry.text: Specifies a client-side persistent timeout

entry.name: back_persistent_timeout_webappfw_help_1133
entry.text:
Specifies the number of seconds that an idle server persistent connection is maintained before being terminated.
persistentTimeout specifies the number of seconds that an idle server persistent connection is maintained. Allowable values are within the range 10 through 86400 seconds, with a default value of 180.
For example:
back-persistent-timeout 300 specifies a back-side idle timeout of 5 minutes

entry.name: back_persistent_timeout_webappfw_descr_1133
entry.text: Specifies a server-side persistent timeout

entry.name: back_timeout_webappfw_help_1134
entry.text:
Specifies the number of seconds that an idle server connection is maintained before being terminated.
idleTimeout specifies the number of seconds that an idle server connection is maintained. Allowable values are within the range 10 through 86400 seconds, with a default value of 120.
For example:
back-timeout 60 specifies a back-side idle timeout of 1 minute

entry.name: back_timeout_webappfw_descr_1134
entry.text: Specifies a server-side idle timeout

entry.name: http_back_version_webappfw_help_1135
entry.text:
Specifies the version of HTTP used to connect to the back-end server(s). HTTP/1.0 and HTTP/1.1 are mutually exclusive keywords that identify the HTTP protocol version.
HTTP/1.0 specifies the earlier HTTP 1.0. HTTP/1.1 specifies the more recent HTTP 1.1 (the default).
For example:
http-server-version HTTP/1.0 specifies HTTP 1.0

entry.name: http_back_version_webappfw_descr_1135
entry.text: Specifies an HTTP version

entry.name: http_front_version_webappfw_help_1136
entry.text:
Specifies the version of HTTP used to connect to the clients making requests. HTTP/1.0 and HTTP/1.1 are mutually exclusive keywords that identify the HTTP protocol version.
HTTP/1.0 specifies the earlier HTTP 1.0. HTTP/1.1 specifies the more recent HTTP 1.1 (the default).
For example:
http-front-version HTTP/1.0 specifies HTTP 1.0

entry.name: http_front_version_webappfw_descr_1136
entry.text: Specifies an HTTP version

entry.name: chunked_uploads_webappfw_help_1137
entry.text:
Enables the use of chunked encoding when uploading an HTTP/1.1 request to the server. With chunk coding enabled, the gateway transfers messages to the server as a series of chunks, with each chunk containing a length value followed by the chunk data. A chunk with a zero length value indicates end-of-message. By default, chunk encoding is disabled. Chunk encoding should be enabled to stream documents to a server. You should, however, ensure that the target server is fully RFC-2616 compliant before enabling chunk encoding.
For example:
chunked-uploads enables chunked encoding

entry.name: chunked_uploads_webappfw_descr_1137
entry.text: Enables chunked encoding

entry.name: request_security_webappfw_help_1138
entry.text:
If this property is disabled, no request side security policies will be enforced and all requests will be allowed through. on|off Enable (on, the default) or disable (off) Request Security.
For example:
request-security on resumes normal Request Security processing.

entry.name: request_security_webappfw_descr_1138
entry.text: Controls Request Security execution.

entry.name: response_security_webappfw_help_1139
entry.text:
If this property is disabled, no response side security policies will be enforced and all responses will be allowed through. on|off Enable (on, the default) or disable (off) Response Security.
For example:
response-security on resumes normal Response Security processing.

entry.name: response_security_webappfw_descr_1139
entry.text: Controls Response Security execution.

entry.name: follow_redirects_webappfw_help_1140
entry.text:
Some protocols generate redirects as part of the protocol - for example HTTP response code 302. If this property is enabled the firewall will try and transparently resolve those redirects. on|off Enable (on, the default) or disable (off) Follow Redirects.
For example:
follow-redirects on resumes normal Redirect processing.

entry.name: follow_redirects_webappfw_descr_1140
entry.text: Enables HTTP Redirect processing.

entry.name: http_client_ip_label_webappfw_help_1141
entry.text:
Retain the default value (X-Client-IP) or provide an other value (for example, X-Forwarded-For).
HTTPClientIPLabel Enter a string to set the client IP label.
For example:
http-client-ip-label X-Forwarded-For sets the label to X-Forwarded-For.

entry.name: http_client_ip_label_webappfw_descr_1141
entry.text: Sets the HTTP Client IP label

entry.name: http_global_tranid_label_webappfw_help_1142
entry.text:
Restores the default state, and enables the inclusion of the Global transaction ID in the HTTP header sent to the web or application server. In the default state the global transaction header is included in a field labeled "X-Global-Transaction-ID". httpHeaderFieldLabel optionally specifies a new label for the HTTP header field. For example:
http-global-tranID-label X-MyGlobal-Transaction-ID includes global transaction ID in an HTTP header field labeled X-MyGlobal-Transaction-ID

entry.name: http_global_tranid_label_webappfw_descr_1142
entry.text: Global Transaction ID Label

entry.name: debug_mode_webappfw_help_1143
entry.text:
Enables diagnostic mode. Transaction diagnostic mode is not intended for use in a production environment. Transaction diagnostic mode consumes significant resources that can slow down transaction processing.
on Enables diagnostic mode. The probe contains the number of transactions that is defined by the debug history. off (Default) Disables diagnostic mode. Alternatively, use the 'no' form of the command to disable diagnostic mode.
unbounded Enables diagnostic mode. The probe history contains 250 transactions. This mode consumes significant resources and slows down transaction processing.

entry.name: debug_mode_webappfw_descr_1143
entry.text: Enables diagnostic mode

entry.name: debug_history_webappfw_help_1144
entry.text: Controls the number of transactions that are saved when in diagnostic mode. This value limits the number of concurrent XML sessions. Valid values are in the range from 10 through 250. The default value is 25.

entry.name: debug_history_webappfw_descr_1144
entry.text: Sets limit for transaction history

entry.name: debug_trigger_webappfw_help_1145
entry.text:
Optionally use the following criteria to define one or more triggers. The Probe becomes active only for traffic that meets the criteria for one of the defined triggers.
PCRE to match client IP addresses Specify a PCRE-match to the client IP address. Requests from clients with matching IP addresses trigger debugging. To match any number of any character, specify ".*" (without quotes) instead of "*" (without quotes). PCRE to match inbound URL requests Specify a PCRE-match to an inbound URL. Requests from clients that match this expression trigger debugging. To match any number of any character, specify ".*" (without quotes) instead of "*" (without quotes). PCRE to match outbound URL responses Specify a PCRE-match for an outbound URL. Outbound requests that match this expression trigger debugging. To match any number of any character, specify ".*" (without quotes) instead of "*" (without quotes). Processing rule Specify one of the following values, based on direction, to trigger debugging: "Request" "Response" "Both" "Error" The value "Both" includes both requests and responses.
