PCRE to match names of rules Specify a PCRE match for the name of a processing rule. Names that match this expression trigger debugging. To match any number of any character, specify ".*" (without quotes) instead of "*" (without quotes). XPath expression Specify an XPath expression. Messages that have an element that match this expression trigger debugging.

entry.name: debug_trigger_webappfw_descr_1145
entry.text: Defines triggers

entry.name: urlrewrite_policy_webappfw_help_1146
entry.text: Assigns a URL Rewrite Policy to the current service. urlRewritePolicyName The URL Rewrite Policy to assign.

entry.name: urlrewrite_policy_webappfw_descr_1146
entry.text: Assigns a URL Rewrite Policy to the service

entry.name: xml_manager_webappfw_help_1147
entry.text:
An XML Manager manages XML documents for the service (for example, caching documents).
XMLManagerName The name of an existing XML Manager object.
For example:
xml-manager WebXMLMgr sets the XML Manager to WebXMLMgr.

entry.name: xml_manager_webappfw_descr_1147
entry.text: Sets the XML Manager

entry.name: max_attributes_namevalueprofile_help_1148
entry.text:
Enter an integer to determine the maximum number of name value pairs allowed in a single entity (header, cookie set, Post body, or Query String). Defaults to 256.
AttributeNumber An integer determining the allowed pair limit per entity.
For example:
max-attributes 64 sets the number of allowed name-value pairs to 64.

entry.name: max_attributes_namevalueprofile_descr_1148
entry.text: Sets Name Value Pair limit

entry.name: max_aggregate_size_namevalueprofile_help_1149
entry.text:
Enter an integer to determine the maximum size, in bytes, of the aggregated names and values in a single entity. Defaults to 128000.
SizeInBytes An integer determining the allowed aggregated size per entity.
For example:
max-aggregate-size 64000 sets the aggregated size of all pairs to 64K bytes.

entry.name: max_aggregate_size_namevalueprofile_descr_1149
entry.text: Sets Max Aggregate Size of Name Value Pairs

entry.name: max_name_size_namevalueprofile_help_1150
entry.text:
Enter an integer to determine the maximum size, in bytes, of any single Name attribute in an entity. Defaults to 512.
SizeInBytes An integer determining the allowed Name attribute size.
For example:
max-name-size 1024 sets the allowed size of any Name to 1K bytes.

entry.name: max_name_size_namevalueprofile_descr_1150
entry.text: Sets Max Size of Name Attribute

entry.name: max_value_size_namevalueprofile_help_1151
entry.text:
Enter an integer to determine the maximum size, in bytes, of any single Value attribute in an entity. Defaults to 1024.
SizeInBytes An integer determining the allowed Value attribute size.
For example:
max-value-size 2056 sets the allowed size of any Name to 2K bytes.

entry.name: max_value_size_namevalueprofile_descr_1151
entry.text: Sets Max Size of Value Attribute

entry.name: validation_namevalueprofile_help_1152
entry.text:
The Name Value Profile works by comparing each name of a Name Value Pair to the Name Expressions on the Validation List. If no match is found, the No Match Policy (discussed above) is executed. When a match is found, the corresponding value is compared to the corresponding Value Constraint in the Validation List. If a match is found, the Name Value Pair passes. If no match is found, the Failure Policy is executed. In addition, unmatched values may also be checked for Cross-Site Scripting.
NamePCRE A PCRE expression used to match Name attributes. When Name matches this expression, ValuePCRE is applied. ValuePCRE A PCRE expression used to match Value attributes. When Value matches this expression, the pair passes the validation filter. FailurePolicy When a value constraint fails to validate an input, the failure policy dictates what action should be taken. Valid values are: error The Profile validation fails and an error is generated. This is the default. passthru The given Name Value pair is passed through to the next step in processing. set The given Value is replaced with a default value, given by the MapValue argument. strip The Name Value pair is removed from the entity (headers, Post body, Query String or cookie) and processing continues. MapValue The Value will be replaced with this constant value when the Failure Policy is "set". CheckXSS When set to on, the values that do not match the ValuePCRE expression are checked for Cross Site Scripting (XSS) signatures. XSSPatternsFile Specifies custom XML file containing XSS (Cross Site Scripting) patterns to be used with XSS filtering. The default patterns file, store:///XSS-Patterns.xml, checks for invalid characters and various forms of the term <script. Specify a custom XML patterns file with PCRE patterns to be used by the XSS filter.
For example:
validation hdr "^PRE[012345678]*" strip "" "off" matches any Name attribute containing the string "hdr". When a match is made, the Value must start with "PRE" followed by any numeric character 0-8, followed by anything. if the validation fails, the Name Value Pair is stripped from the entity containing it. XSS checking is off. validation hdr "^PRE[012345678]*" set "BogieAlert" "on" "store:///XSSPatterns.xml" matches any Name attribute containing the string "hdr". When a match is made, the Value must start with "PRE" followed by any numeric character 0-8, followed by anything. if the validation fails, the Value Pair is set to the string "BogieAlert". XSS checking is turned on.

entry.name: validation_namevalueprofile_descr_1152
entry.text: Validation List for Name Value Pairs

entry.name: unvalidated_fixup_policy_namevalueprofile_help_1153
entry.text:
Determine the action taken when a given Name attribute does not match a Name Matching expression in the configured Validation List (see validation command). error The Profile validation fails and an error is generated. This is the default. passthru The given Name Value pair is passed through to the next step in processing. set The given Value is replaced with a default value, given by the unvalidated-fixup-map command. strip The Name Value pair is removed from the entity (headers, Post body, Query String or cookie) and processing continues.
For example:
unvalidated-fixup-policy strip removes the unvalidated Name Value Pair from the entity.

entry.name: unvalidated_fixup_policy_namevalueprofile_descr_1153
entry.text: Sets Unvalidated Pair Policy

entry.name: unvalidated_fixup_map_namevalueprofile_help_1154
entry.text:
The Value of a pair will be set to this value when the corresponding Name attribute does not match a Name Matching expression in the configured Validation List (see validation command). MapValue Any alphanumeric string.
For example:
unvalidated-fixup-map BogieAt5 sets the unvalidated value to BogieAt5.

entry.name: unvalidated_fixup_map_namevalueprofile_descr_1154
entry.text: Unvalidated Map Value Replacement

entry.name: unvalidated_xss_check_namevalueprofile_help_1155
entry.text:
This property allows the value to be checked for Cross Site Scripting (XSS) signatures. Cross Site Scripting signatures are malicious attempts to input client-side script as the input to a web application. If this client-side script is later displayed in a browser, the script executes and can perform malicious activities.
Enable this feature to filter input for malicious content that might get stored and displayed again later, such as the contents of a comment form. The check looks for invalid characters and various forms of the term <script that is often used to engage JavaScript on a browser without the user knowing.
For example:
unvalidated-xss-check on turns on Cross Site Scripting.

entry.name: unvalidated_xss_check_namevalueprofile_descr_1155
entry.text: Unvalidated XSS Check

entry.name: unvalidated_xss_patternsfile_namevalueprofile_help_1156
entry.text: NoMatchXSSPatternsFile Specifies an XML file containing custom XSS (Cross Site Scripting) patterns to be used with XSS filtering. The default patterns file, store:///XSS-Patterns.xml, checks for invalid characters and various forms of the term <script. Specify a custom XML patterns file with PCRE patterns to be used by the XSS filter.

entry.name: unvalidated_xss_patternsfile_namevalueprofile_descr_1156
entry.text: Unvalidated XSS Check Patterns File

entry.name: tps_simplecountmonitor_help_1157
entry.text:
The rate of acceptable traffic, per user, expressed in transactions per second. Defaults to 500.
TPS An integer determining the allowed rate limit per user.
For example:
tps 1000 increases the allowed transactions per second to 1000.

entry.name: tps_simplecountmonitor_descr_1157
entry.text: Sets Transactions Per Second limit

entry.name: action_simplecountmonitor_help_1158
entry.text:
Select the action taken when the rate limit (tps) is exceeded. Defaults to reject.
notify Generate log message in the appropriate application domain. Log targets must subscribe to this event to capture message. reject Requests are rejected until transaction rate drops below the configured limit. shape Delay requests as much as possible to lower the transaction rate to the configured limit. Once too many messages are buffered, creating a low memory state, transactions are rejected until rate drops. The ability to shape transactions is limited when concurrent connections are high.
For example:
action notify sets the rate limiter to generate log messages only.

entry.name: action_simplecountmonitor_descr_1158
entry.text: Sets Transactions Per Second limit

entry.name: distinct_sources_simplecountmonitor_help_1159
entry.text:
The system organizes the counts user by the identity most recently used. When too many distinct counts have been observed, the users not seen in the longest time are discarded. This parameter specifies how many distinct users are tracked before discard. Defaults to 10000.
SourceNumber An integer determining how many unique identities are tracked before least recently seen identity is discarded.
For example:
distinct-sources 8000 sets the number of distinct identities tracked to 8000.

entry.name: distinct_sources_simplecountmonitor_descr_1159
entry.text: Limits number of distinct user identities tracked

entry.name: concurrent_connection_limit_simplecountmonitor_help_1160
entry.text:
An integer setting the number of concurrent (simultaneous) connections allowed per user. Set this to zero (the default) to disable this enforcement.
ConnLimit An integer determining how many concurrent connections allowed per user.
For example:
concurrent-connection-limit 20 limits any one user to 20 concurrent connections.

entry.name: concurrent_connection_limit_simplecountmonitor_descr_1160
entry.text: Limits number of concurrent connections per user

entry.name: policy_type_webappresponse_help_1161
entry.text:
Set one of the following styles, or modes, of operation:
admission If a response passes the criteria set forth in this profile, the response is immediately forwarded to the client. No other matching profile is run. This is the default. pre-requisite If a response passes the criteria set forth in this profile, any other profiles that match the request may now run. The request is not necessarily forwarded to the back end service. However, if there are no other matching profiles and the request passes this profile, the request will then be passed to the back end service.
For example:
policy-type admission sets the Profile mode to admission. If a response passes this profile, the response is forwarded to the client.

entry.name: policy_type_webappresponse_descr_1161
entry.text: Determines the Mode of operation

entry.name: response_codes_webappresponse_help_1162
entry.text:
Use this command to adjust the defaults. The default values are shown in this list. Issue a +-separated list of methods. Possible values: HTTP-100 100 Continue (default) HTTP-101 101 Switching Protocols HTTP-200 200 OK (default) HTTP-201 201 Created (default) HTTP-202 202 Accepted (default) HTTP-203 203 Informative HTTP-204 204 No Content (default) HTTP-205 205 Reset HTTP-206 206 Partial Content (default) HTTP-300 300 Multiple Choices HTTP-301 Moved (default) HTTP-302 Found (default) HTTP-303 See Other HTTP-304 Not Modified (default) HTTP-305 Use Proxy HTTP-307 Moved Temporarily (default) HTTP-400 Bad Request HTTP-401 Unauthorized HTTP-402 Payment Required HTTP-403 Forbidden HTTP-404 Not Found HTTP-405 Method Not Allowed HTTP-406 Not Acceptable HTTP-407 Proxy Authentication Required HTTP-408 Request Timeout HTTP-409 Conflict HTTP-410 Gone HTTP-411 Length required HTTP-412 Precondition Failed HTTP-413 Request Entity Too Large HTTP-500 Server Error HTTP-503 Service Unavailable
For example: response-methods HTTP-100+HTTP-200 resets the HTTP methods allowed by the current Web Response Profile.

entry.name: response_codes_webappresponse_descr_1162
entry.text: Determines the HTTP Methods allowed by this Profile.

entry.name: response_versions_webappresponse_help_1163
entry.text:
By default, both HTTP/1.0 and HTTP/1.1 are allowed. Use this command to alter these defaults. Issue a +-separated list of methods.
For example: response-versions HTTP/1.1 resets the HTTP methods allowed by the current Web Response Profile to only HTTP/1.1.

entry.name: response_versions_webappresponse_descr_1163
entry.text: Determines the HTTP Versions allowed by this Profile.

entry.name: response_body_min_webappresponse_help_1164
entry.text:
Minimum response body size in bytes. The default value is 0.
For example: response-body-min 100 Set the minimum body size to 100 bytes.

entry.name: response_body_min_webappresponse_descr_1164
entry.text: Sets the minimum size of the response body

entry.name: response_body_max_webappresponse_help_1165
entry.text:
Maximum response body size in bytes. The default value is 128000000.
For example: response-body-max 1000000 Set the maximum body size to 1000000 bytes.

entry.name: response_body_max_webappresponse_descr_1165
entry.text: Sets the maximum size of the response body

entry.name: response_header_profile_webappresponse_help_1166
entry.text:
Each HTTP header name/value pair will be subjected to the rules set forth in the selected Profile. If no profile is specified, any header is allowed.
NameValueProfileName The name of an existing Name Value Profile. Profile must already exist. Use Global Configuration Mode command webapp-gnvc to create a new profile.
For example:
response-header-profile portal-response-hdrs applies the portal-response-hdrs NameValue Profile to all HTTP response headers.

entry.name: response_header_profile_webappresponse_descr_1166
entry.text: Sets the Name Value Profile for the HTTP Response headers

entry.name: response_content_type_webappresponse_help_1167
entry.text:
Creates a list of HTTP Content Types allowed by this Response Profile. Responses not containing these Types cause an error. An empty list (the default) allows all types.
TypeString A Content Type specification string to add to allowed list.
For example:
response-content-type application/www-url-encoded response-content-type text/xml adds two content types to the list and restricts accepted types to these.

entry.name: response_content_type_webappresponse_descr_1167
entry.text: Controls HTTP Content Types allowed

entry.name: response_xml_policy_webappresponse_help_1168
entry.text:
Select an action to take when responses contain an XML MIME type in the HTTP header Content-type: field (text/xml, for example). nothing No action taken (the default)
xml The device parses the response to validate that the response is well-formed XML. The XML Transformation Rule specified then runs on the response and the result is used as the response content. soap The device parses the response to validate that the response adheres to the SOAP specifications. The XML Transformation Rule specified then runs on the response and the result is used as the response content.
For example: response-xml-policy soap validates the response as SOAP and runs the Transformation Rule.

entry.name: response_xml_policy_webappresponse_descr_1168
entry.text: Determines action taken on responses containing XML

entry.name: response_xml_rule_webappresponse_help_1169
entry.text:
Use this command to set the Processing Rule used on XML or SOAP content.
ProcessingRuleName specifies the Processing Rule executed on the content. Processing Rule must already exist. Use Global Configuration Mode command rule to create a new rule.
For example:
response-xml-rule portal-xml-rule applies the portal-xml-rule to all SOAP content.

entry.name: response_xml_rule_webappresponse_descr_1169
entry.text: Sets the XML Transformation Rule.

entry.name: response_nonxml_policy_webappresponse_help_1170
entry.text:
Select an action to take when responses do not contain an XML MIME type in the HTTP header Content-type: field (text/plain, for example).
nothing No action taken (the default) side The device executes the Non-XML Processing Rule specified. This rule cannot alter the content of the response (cannot access the INPUT and OUTPUT processing contexts). The Rule can perform such actions as authenticate and authorize, or send a copy of the response content to a third destination. binary The device executes the Non-XML Processing Rule specified. The response payload is submitted as an unparsed binary object. This rule can alter the content of the response. The Rule can perform such actions as authenticate and authorize, convert to XML, repackage with additional information retrieved from elsewhere and/or send a copy of the response content to a third destination. The result of this rule is then used as the response payload for further processing.
For example: response-nonxml-policy side runs the NonXML Transformation Rule on nonXML responses.

entry.name: response_nonxml_policy_webappresponse_descr_1170
entry.text: Determines action taken on responses not XML

entry.name: response_nonxml_rule_webappresponse_help_1171
entry.text:
Use this command to set the Processing Rule used on non-XML content.
ProcessingRuleName specifies the Processing Rule executed on the content. Processing Rule must already exist. Use Global Configuration Mode command rule to create a new rule.
For example:
response-nonxml-rule portal-nonxml-rule applies the portal-nonxml-rule to all non-XML content.

entry.name: response_nonxml_rule_webappresponse_descr_1171
entry.text: Sets the non-XML Transformation Rule.

entry.name: error_policy_override_webappresponse_help_1172
entry.text:
This Error Policy will run when any client response violates this Web Response Profile. The Error Policy selected will also override any Error Policy selected at the Web Application Firewall level.
ErrorPolicyName The name of an existing ErrorHandling Policy. Policy must already exist. Use Global Configuration Mode command webapp-error-handling to create a new policy.
For example:
error-policy-override portal-req-err-policy applies the portal-req-err-policy to all errors.

entry.name: error_policy_override_webappresponse_descr_1172
entry.text: Sets the Error Handling Policy for the Profile

entry.name: policy_type_webapprequest_help_1173
entry.text:
Set one of the following styles, or modes, of operation, admission (default) If a request passes the criteria set forth in this profile, the client request is immediately forwarded to the server. No other matching profile is run.
pre-requisite If a request passes the criteria set forth in this profile, any other profiles that match the request may now run. The request is not necessarily forwarded to the server. However, if there are no other matching profiles and the request passes this profile, the request is passed to the server.
For example:
policy-type admission Sets the Profile mode to admission. If a request passes this profile, the request is forwarded to the server.

entry.name: policy_type_webapprequest_descr_1173
entry.text: Determines the mode of operation

entry.name: request_ssl_policy_webapprequest_help_1174
entry.text:
Determines TLS communications policy for this Request Profile. This defaults to allow.
allow Allows TLS connections. The TLS proxy profile assigned to the firewall may apply. deny Disallows TLS connections. Such connections are refused. require Requires TLS connections. The TLS proxy profile assigned to the firewall applies. Profile must already exist. The TLS proxy profile must use Crypto Profile configured for server (reverse) direction or client cannot use HTTPS to connect.
For example:
request-ssl-policy deny Refuses all TLS connections.

entry.name: request_ssl_policy_webapprequest_descr_1174
entry.text: Controls TLS communications for this profile.

entry.name: aaa_policy_webapprequest_help_1175
entry.text:
Assigns an AAA Policy to the current Web Request Profile. When assigned, this Profile will authenticate and authorize all requests with this AAA Policy. Defaults to none (no AAA).
aaaPolicyName specifies the AAA Policy assigned to the gateway. Policy must exist.
For example:
aaa-policy webFWAccess-1 assigns the AAA Policy named webFWAccess-1 to the current Web Request Profile.

entry.name: aaa_policy_webapprequest_descr_1175
entry.text: Assigns an AAA Policy to the Profile.

entry.name: ss_key_webapprequest_help_1176
entry.text: Shared Secret Key for signing and encrypting

entry.name: ss_key_webapprequest_descr_1176
entry.text: Shared Secret Key

entry.name: ratelimiter_policy_webapprequest_help_1177
entry.text:
When assigned, traffic will be limited in accordance with the designated policy. Defaults to none (no rate limiting).
RateLimitPolicyName specifies the Rate Limit Policy assigned to the Profile. Policy must exist. Use simple-rate-limit global command to create.
For example:
ratelimiter-policy portal-limiter assigns the Rate Limit Policy named portal-limiter to the current Web Request Profile. Traffic may now be limited.

entry.name: ratelimiter_policy_webapprequest_descr_1177
entry.text: Assigns a Rate Limit Policy to the Profile.

entry.name: acl_webapprequest_help_1178
entry.text:
When assigned, access will be granted in accordance with the designated access control list. Defaults to none (no control).
aclName specifies the Access Control List assigned to the Profile. Policy must exist. Use acl global command to create.
For example:
acl portal-acl assigns the Access Control List named portal-acl to the current Web Request Profile. Access is now restricted by the list.

entry.name: acl_webapprequest_descr_1178
entry.text: Assigns an Access Control List to the Profile.

entry.name: request_methods_webapprequest_help_1179
entry.text:
By default, only POST, GET and HEAD are allowed. Use this command to alter these defaults. Issue a +-separated list of methods.
For example: request-methods POST+GET+PUT+HEAD+OPTIONS+TRACE resets the HTTP methods allowed by the current Web Request Profile.

entry.name: request_methods_webapprequest_descr_1179
entry.text: Determines the HTTP Methods allowed by this Profile.

entry.name: request_versions_webapprequest_help_1180
entry.text:
By default, both HTTP/1.0 and HTTP/1.1 are allowed. Use this command to alter these defaults. Issue a +-separated list of methods.
For example: request-versions HTTP/1.1 resets the HTTP methods allowed by the current Web Request Profile to only HTTP/1.1.

entry.name: request_versions_webapprequest_descr_1180
entry.text: Determines the HTTP Versions allowed by this Profile.

entry.name: request_body_min_webapprequest_help_1181
entry.text:
Minimum request body size in bytes. The default value is 0.
For example: request-body-min 100 Set the minimum body size to 100 bytes.

entry.name: request_body_min_webapprequest_descr_1181
entry.text: Sets the minimum size of the request body.

entry.name: request_body_max_webapprequest_help_1182
entry.text:
Maximum request body size in bytes. The default value is 128000000.
For example: request-body-max 1000000 Set the maximum body size to 1000000 bytes.

entry.name: request_body_max_webapprequest_descr_1182
entry.text: Sets the maximum size of the request body.

entry.name: request_xml_policy_webapprequest_help_1183
entry.text:
Select an action to take when requests contain an XML MIME type in the HTTP header Content-type: field (text/xml, for example).
nothing No action taken (the default) xml The device parses the request to validate that the request is well-formed XML. The XML Transformation Rule specified then runs on the request and the result is used as the request content. soap The device parses the request to validate that the request adheres to the SOAP specifications. The XML Transformation Rule specified then runs on the request and the result is used as the request content.
For example: request-xml-policy soap validates the request as SOAP and runs the Transformation Rule.

entry.name: request_xml_policy_webapprequest_descr_1183
entry.text: Determines action taken on XML MIME type.

entry.name: request_xml_rule_webapprequest_help_1184
entry.text:
Use this command to set the Processing Rule used on XML or SOAP content.
ProcessingRuleName specifies the Processing Rule executed on the content. Processing Rule must already exist. Use Global Configuration Mode command rule to create a new rule.
For example:
request-xml-rule portal-xml-rule applies the portal-xml-rule to all SOAP content.

entry.name: request_xml_rule_webapprequest_descr_1184
entry.text: Sets the XML Transformation Rule.

entry.name: request_nonxml_policy_webapprequest_help_1185
entry.text:
Select an action to take when requests do not contain an XML MIME type in the HTTP header Content-type: field (text/plain, for example).
nothing No action taken (the default) side The device executes the Non-XML Processing Rule specified. This rule cannot alter the content of the request (cannot access the INPUT and OUTPUT processing contexts). The Rule can perform such actions as authenticate and authorize, or send a copy of the request content to a third destination. binary The device executes the Non-XML Processing Rule specified. The request payload is submitted as an unparsed binary object. This rule can alter the content of the request. The Rule can perform such actions as authenticate and authorize, convert to XML, repackage with additional information retrieved from elsewhere and/or send a copy of the request content to a third destination. The result of this rule is then used as the request payload for further processing.
For example: request-nonxml-policy side runs the NonXML Transformation Rule on nonXML requests.

entry.name: request_nonxml_policy_webapprequest_descr_1185
entry.text: Determines action taken on requests not XML

entry.name: request_nonxml_rule_webapprequest_help_1186
entry.text:
Use this command to set the Processing Rule used on non-XML content.
ProcessingRuleName specifies the Processing Rule executed on the content. Processing Rule must already exist. Use Global Configuration Mode command rule to create a new rule.
For example:
request-nonxml-rule portal-nonxml-rule applies the portal-nonxml-rule to all non-XML content.

entry.name: request_nonxml_rule_webapprequest_descr_1186
entry.text: Sets the non-XML Transformation Rule.

entry.name: error_policy_override_webapprequest_help_1187
entry.text:
This Error Policy will run when any client request violates this Web Request Profile. The Error Policy selected will also override any Error Policy selected at the Web Application Firewall level.
ErrorPolicyName The name of an existing ErrorHandling Policy. Policy must already exist. Use Global Configuration Mode command webapp-error-handling to create a new policy.
For example:
error-policy-override portal-req-err-policy applies the portal-req-err-policy to all errors.

entry.name: error_policy_override_webapprequest_descr_1187
entry.text: Sets the Error Handling Policy for the Profile

entry.name: session_policy_webapprequest_help_1188
entry.text:
A Session Policy establishes the URLs that are acceptable starting points (start pages) for a web application session. In addition, a Session Policy limits the duration of any session. Leave the default (none) to enforce no Session Policy.
SessionPolicyName The name of an existing Session Policy. Policy must already exist. Use Global Configuration Mode command webapp-session-management to create a new policy.
For example:
session-policy portal-session-policy applies the portal-session-policy to all requests.

entry.name: session_policy_webapprequest_descr_1188
entry.text: Sets the Session Policy for the Profile

entry.name: request_header_profile_webapprequest_help_1189
entry.text:
Each HTTP header name/value pair will be subjected to the rules set forth in the selected Profile. If no profile is specified, any header is allowed.
NameValueProfileName The name of an existing Name Value Profile. Profile must already exist. Use Global Configuration Mode command webapp-gnvc to create a new profile.
For example:
request-header-profile portal-request-hdrs applies the portal-request-hdrs NameValue Profile to all HTTP request headers.

entry.name: request_header_profile_webapprequest_descr_1189
entry.text: Sets the Name Value Profile for the HTTP Request headers

entry.name: request_body_profile_webapprequest_help_1190
entry.text:
Each element in the HTTP Post body will be subjected to the rules set forth in the selected Profile. If no profile is specified, any element is allowed.
NameValueProfileName The name of an existing Name Value Profile. Profile must already exist. Use Global Configuration Mode command webapp-gnvc to create a new profile.
For example:
request-body-profile portal-request-hdrs applies the portal-request-body NameValue Profile to all HTTP body content.

entry.name: request_body_profile_webapprequest_descr_1190
entry.text: Sets the Name Value Profile for the HTTP body content

entry.name: request_qs_policy_webapprequest_help_1191
entry.text:
Determines policy regarding query strings in the request.
allow allows query strings. The Query String Profile may apply. deny disallows query strings. Such connections will result in an error. require requires query strings. Connections without Query Strings will result in an error. The Query String Profile may apply.
For example:
request-qs-policy require requires query strings in HTTP requests.

entry.name: request_qs_policy_webapprequest_descr_1191
entry.text: Allow, deny or require Query Strings in Request

entry.name: request_qs_profile_webapprequest_help_1192
entry.text:
Each element in the HTTP Query String will be subjected to the rules set forth in the selected Profile. If no profile is specified, any element is allowed.
NameValueProfileName The name of an existing Name Value Profile. Profile must already exist. Use Global Configuration Mode command webapp-gnvc to create a new profile.
For example:
request-qs-profile portal-request-qs applies the portal-request-body NameValue Profile to all HTTP query strings.

entry.name: request_qs_profile_webapprequest_descr_1192
entry.text: Sets the Name Value Profile for the HTTP Query Strings

entry.name: request_sql_policy_webapprequest_help_1193
entry.text:
Enables (on) or disables (off) automatic SQL Injection Attack filtering.
on Turns on filtering (the default). off Turns off filtering.
For example:
request-sql-policy off turns off Injection Attack filtering.

entry.name: request_sql_policy_webapprequest_descr_1193
entry.text: Controls SQL Injection attack filtering

entry.name: sql_injection_patterns_file_webapprequest_help_1194
entry.text:
Specify an XML file that contains patterns to be used with SQL Injection Attack filtering. For example:
sql-injection-patterns-file local:///mySQLInjectionPatterns.xml

entry.name: sql_injection_patterns_file_webapprequest_descr_1194
entry.text: Specifies custom SQL Injection patterns file

entry.name: request_uri_max_webapprequest_help_1195
entry.text:
Enter an integer to determine the maximum URI length, in characters. This defaults to 1024.
For example: request-uri-max 512 set the maximum URI size allowed by the current Web Request Profile to 512 bytes .

entry.name: request_uri_max_webapprequest_descr_1195
entry.text: Determines the maximum URI size allowed

entry.name: request_uri_filter_unicode_webapprequest_help_1196
entry.text:
Reject (on) or allow (off) requests if Unicode is detected in the URI. The default is on. on Turns on filtering (the default). off Turns off filtering.
For example:
request-uri-filter-unicode on turns on Unicode filtering.

entry.name: request_uri_filter_unicode_webapprequest_descr_1196
entry.text: Controls Unicode filtering

entry.name: request_uri_filter_dotdot_webapprequest_help_1197
entry.text:
Reject (on) or allow (off) requests if ".." is detected in the URI. The default is on. on Turns on filtering (the default). off Turns off filtering.
For example:
request-uri-filter-dotdot on turns on Dot Dot filtering.

entry.name: request_uri_filter_dotdot_webapprequest_descr_1197
entry.text: Controls Dot Dot filtering

entry.name: request_uri_filter_exe_webapprequest_help_1198
entry.text:
Reject (on) or allow (off) requests if "exe" is detected in the URI. The default is on. on Turns on filtering (the default). off Turns off filtering.
For example:
request-uri-filter-exe on turns on Executable filtering.

entry.name: request_uri_filter_exe_webapprequest_descr_1198
entry.text: Controls Executable filtering

entry.name: request_uri_filter_fragment_webapprequest_help_1199
entry.text:
Controls handling of URI fragments (everything after "#" in the request URL. The default is allow.
allow Allows requests containing URI fragments (the default). reject Rejects requests containing URI fragments. truncate Removes URI fragments from request.
For example:
request-uri-filter-fragment truncate removes URI fragments from the request.

entry.name: request_uri_filter_fragment_webapprequest_descr_1199
entry.text: Controls URI Fragment filtering

entry.name: request_content_type_webapprequest_help_1200
entry.text:
Creates a list of HTTP Content Types allowed by this Request Profile. Requests not containing these Types cause an error. An empty list (the default) allows all types.
TypeString A Content Type specification string to add to allowed list.
For example:
request-content-type application/www-url-encoded request-content-type text/xml adds two content types to the list and restricts accepted types to these.

entry.name: request_content_type_webapprequest_descr_1200
entry.text: Controls HTTP Content Types allowed

entry.name: multipart_form_data_webapprequest_help_1201
entry.text:
Sets the multi-part request processing policy for this Request Profile. Requests violating these limits cause an error. The defaults are enforced automatically. Use this command to change the values.
MaxParts Maximum number of parts allowed. Defaults to 4. MaxSizePerPart Maximum size of any one part allowed. Defaults to 5000000. MaxSize Maximum size of all parts combined allowed. Defaults to 5000000. ContentTypeRestricted If set, this forces the individual form-data content types to be matched against the general list of request acceptable content-type expressions. Defaults to off.
For example:
multipart-form-data 12 50000 250000 on expands allowed parts to 12, makes sizes smaller and enforces content-type restriction.

entry.name: multipart_form_data_webapprequest_descr_1201
entry.text: Controls multi-part form submissions

entry.name: cookie_policy_webapprequest_help_1202
entry.text:
Sets the Cookie processing policy for this Request Profile. Requests violating these limits cause an error. By default, cookies are allowed and they are not encrypted or signed.
CookiePolicy May be "allow", "deny" or "require". Defaults to allow. If set to "deny" or "require", may cause an error if request does not conform. Type May be "none", "encrypt" or "sign". Defaults to none. If set to encrypt, cookie contents are encrypted using Key. If set to sign, a digital signature is appended to cookie using Key. Must specify Key for either type. Key Enter a string to use as a secret passphrase. Signing and/or Encrypting cookies requires a secret passphrase or a shared secret key for the cryptographic operation. If this key is the same on multiple devices, then each device verify or decrypt a cookie generated by another device without maintaining state. IPinWatermark Normally the signed/encrypted cookie contains the client IP address and this prevents the client from using this cookie from any other host. Some proxy server environments may make this undesirable. Turning this property off will make the generated cookies address independent. CookieGNVC The name of a Name Value Pair Profile applied to cookie contents. If not present, no profile is applied. The profile must already exist. UseSharedSecretObject Allow a shared secret key, instead of a secret passphrase, to be used for signing and encrypting the cookie.
For example:
cookie-policy require sign mysecretkey on requires cookies, signs them using "mysecretkey" as the passphrase and does not use the IP address in the cookie.

entry.name: cookie_policy_webapprequest_descr_1202
entry.text: Controls Cookie Processing

entry.name: process_all_cookie_webapprequest_help_1203
entry.text: Protect All Cookies

entry.name: process_all_cookie_webapprequest_descr_1203
entry.text: Protect All Cookies

entry.name: cookie_namelist_webapprequest_help_1204
entry.text: Protect the cookie with the given name

entry.name: cookie_namelist_webapprequest_descr_1204
entry.text: Name of Cookie

entry.name: auto_renew_webappsessionpolicy_help_1205
entry.text:
If this property is enabled (on), the session lifetime is renewed on each use of the session (click, etc). Session lifetime then measures idle time. If this property is disabled (off) Otherwise the session lifetime is the total amount of time allowed before returning to the login pages. on|off Enable (on, the default) or disable (off) automatic session renewal.
For example:
auto-renew on enables automatic session renewal. auto-renew off disables automatic session renewal.

entry.name: auto_renew_webappsessionpolicy_descr_1205
entry.text: Enables Automatic Session Renewal

entry.name: lifetime_webappsessionpolicy_help_1206
entry.text:
Enter an integer to determine the length, in seconds, of a session before renewal is required. Use the auto-renew command to determine how sessions may be renewed. Defaults to 3600.
seconds An integer setting the lifetime (length), in seconds, of a session.
For example:
lifetime 3000 sets the lifetime to 3000 seconds (5 minutes).

entry.name: lifetime_webappsessionpolicy_descr_1206
entry.text: Sets length (lifetime) of session in seconds

entry.name: allow_cookie_sharing_webappsessionpolicy_help_1207
entry.text:
Normally the session cookie contains the client IP address and this prevents using the session on any other host. Some proxy server environments may not function correctly as a result. Turning this property on will make the session cookie address-independent. Defaults to off (IP address is contained in cookie). on|off Enable (on) or disable (off, the default) use of cookie from different IP addresses. For example:
allow-cookie-sharing on removes the IP address from the cookie. allow-cookie-sharing off returns setting to the default.

entry.name: allow_cookie_sharing_webappsessionpolicy_descr_1207
entry.text: Enable Address-Independent Sessions

entry.name: matching_policy_webappsessionpolicy_help_1208
entry.text:
Select the matching rule that is used to identify start pages. Start pages are pages that can be accessed without a session cookie and if their security policy passes will issue a session cookie. This parameter is required.
MatchingRuleName The name of an existing Matching Rule. Rule must already exist. Use Global Configuration Mode command matching to create a new rule.
For example:
matching-policy portal-start-match sets the Matching Rule used to identify session start pages.

entry.name: matching_policy_webappsessionpolicy_descr_1208
entry.text: Matching Rule used to identify start pages

entry.name: idle_timeout_webgui_help_1209
entry.text:
Specifies the idle session logout timer, which is the amount of idle time before a Web Management Service login is shut down for inactivity. timerValue is an integer within the range 0 to 65535 that specifies the value in seconds for the idle-session logout timer.
For example:
web-mgmt idle-timeout 300 enter Web Management Service Configuration Mode and specifies an idle session logout timer of 5 minutes (300 seconds).

entry.name: idle_timeout_webgui_descr_1209
entry.text: Specifies the idle session logout timer

entry.name: local_address_webgui_help_1210
entry.text:
Identifies the local device address monitored for Web Management Service requests. You can use the special IP address 0.0.0.0 to specify all device addresses.
ipAddress:portNumber specifies the IP address and port number monitored for incoming Web Management Service requests.
For example:
web-mgmt local-address 0.0.0.0:8090 enter Web Management Service Configuration Mode and specifies that port 8090 on all interfaces is monitored for incoming Web Management Service requests.

entry.name: local_address_webgui_descr_1210
entry.text: Specifies the local address.

entry.name: port_webgui_help_1211
entry.text:
Specifies the port portion of the IP Address:Port pair monitored by the Web Management Service for incoming requests. portNumber is a integer that identifies the monitored port.
Note that the IP Address:Port pair is initially set with the local-address command. You can use the port command at a subsequent time to change the port portion of the
IP Address: Port pair. For example:
local-address 192.168.45.122 46000 ... ... ... port 46501 changes the monitored port from 46000 to 46501.

entry.name: port_webgui_descr_1211
entry.text: Identifies the monitored port number.

entry.name: save_config_overwrite_webgui_help_1212
entry.text:
Specifies system behavior after a running configuration was saved through the Web Management Service.
By default, clicking Save Config (from the Web Management Interface) and running the write memory command to save the current running configuration to config:///autoconfig.cfg and designate this file as the start-up configuration. To override the default behavior, place the "no" form of this command in a start-up configuration script.
For example: no save-config overwrite Assuming that this file is the start-up configuration, clicking Save Config: - writes the running configuration to: config:///autoconfig.cfg - retains the file designated by the boot config command as the start-up configuration.
save-config overwrite Assuming that this file is the start-up configuration, clicking Save Config: - writes the running configuration to: config:///autoconfig.cfg - designates config:///autoconfig.cfg as the start-up configuration.

entry.name: save_config_overwrite_webgui_descr_1212
entry.text: Specifies system behavior for saving a configuration.

entry.name: ssl_webgui_help_1213
entry.text:
The TLS proxy profile is deprecated. Use a TLS server profile or TLS SNI server profile. Assigns a TLS Proxy Profile to the web management service.
name The TLS proxy profile to assign.
For example:
web-mgmt ssl webMgmtTLS Enters Web Management Service Configuration Mode and assigns the webMgmtTLS TLS proxy profile.

entry.name: ssl_webgui_descr_1213
entry.text: Deprecated - Assigns a TLS proxy profile.

entry.name: ssl_config_type_webgui_help_1214
entry.text:
Sets the type of the TLS profile for the Web Management Service. Default is proxy. For example:
web-mgmt ssl-config-type server enter Web Management Service Configuration Mode and assigns TLS Server Profile to support the Web Management Service operations.

entry.name: ssl_config_type_webgui_descr_1214
entry.text: Sets the TLS profile type.

entry.name: ssl_server_webgui_help_1215
entry.text:
Assigns a TLS server profile to the web management service.
name The TLS server profile to assign.
For example:
web-mgmt ssl-config-type server ssl-server webMgmtTLS Enters Web Management Service Configuration Mode and assigns the webMgmtTLS TLS server profile.

entry.name: ssl_server_webgui_descr_1215
entry.text: Assigns a TLS server profile.

entry.name: ssl_sni_server_webgui_help_1216
entry.text:
Assigns a TLS SNI server profile to the web management service.
name The TLS SNI server profile to assign.
For example:
web-mgmt ssl-config-type sni ssl-sni-server webMgmtTLS Enters Web Management Service Configuration Mode and assigns the webMgmtTLS TLS SNI server profile.

entry.name: ssl_sni_server_webgui_descr_1216
entry.text: Assigns a TLS SNI server profile.

entry.name: user_agent_webgui_help_1217
entry.text:
Optionally assigns an HTTP user agent to the web management service. By default, no user agent is assigned.
name The HTTP user agent to assign.
For example:
user-agent restrictedAccess Assigns the restrictedAccess HTTP user agent.

entry.name: user_agent_webgui_descr_1217
entry.text: Assigns an HTTP user agent.

entry.name: ssl_config_type_webgui_help_1218
entry.text:
Specifies which TLS profile to use to secure connections.
proxy (Default) Uses a TLS proxy profile. server Uses a TLS server profile. sni Uses a TLS SNI server profile.

entry.name: ssl_config_type_webgui_descr_1218
entry.text: Sets the TLS profile type.

entry.name: ssl_server_webgui_help_1219
entry.text:
Assigns a TLS server profile to the web management service.
name The TLS Server Profile to assign.
For example:
web-mgmt ssl-server webMgmtTLS Enter Web Management Service Configuration Mode and assigns the webMgmtTLS TLS Server Profile.

entry.name: ssl_server_webgui_descr_1219
entry.text: Assigns a TLS server profile.

entry.name: ssl_sni_server_webgui_help_1220
entry.text:
Assigns a TLS SNI server profile to the web management service.
name The TLS SNI server profile to assign.
For example:
web-mgmt ssl-sni-server webMgmtTLS Enter Web Management Service Configuration Mode and assigns the webMgmtTLS TLS SNI server profile.

entry.name: ssl_sni_server_webgui_descr_1220
entry.text: Assigns a TLS SNI Server Profile.

entry.name: enable_sts_webgui_help_1221
entry.text: Controls whether to inject HTTP Strict Transport Security (STS) headers in responses from the web management service. The default value is "on". on Injects STS headers. off Does not inject STS headers.

entry.name: enable_sts_webgui_descr_1221
entry.text: Whether to inject Strict Transport Security headers.

entry.name: disable_csrf_webgui_help_1222
entry.text:
Controls CSRF protection. The default value is "off".
on Disables CSRF protection. off Enables CSRF protection.

entry.name: disable_csrf_webgui_descr_1222
entry.text: Controls CSRF protection.

entry.name: priority_wsgateway_help_1223
entry.text: Assigns a priority for scheduling or for resource allocation. When system resources are in high demand, higher priority services will be favored over lower priority services. low Receives below normal priority. normal (Default) Receives normal priority. high Receives above normal priority.

entry.name: priority_wsgateway_descr_1223
entry.text: Assigns a service-level scheduling priority

entry.name: operation_priority_wsgateway_help_1224
entry.text:
Controls the scheduling priority and resource allocation for a specified web service operation.
priority Assigns a priority for scheduling or for resource allocation. Use one of the following values: low Receives below normal priority. normal (Default) Receives normal priority. high Receives above normal priority. wsdlComponentType The type of the WSDL component to match. Use one of the following values: all (Default) Matches all input. Includes all component types. operation Matches when the identified operation is requested in the current transaction.
Matches wsdl:binding/operation/@name when formatted as {bindingNamespace}name, or matches wsdl:service/wsdl:port when formatted as {serviceNamespace}port-name/operation-name port Matches when the operation requested in the current transaction is included in the identified WSDL port.
Matches wsdl:service/wsdl:port/@name when formatted as {serviceNamespace}port-name service Matches when the operation requested in the current transaction is included in the identified WSDL service.
Matches wsdl:service/@name when formatted as {serviceNamespace}name subscription Matches an identified subscription key. wsdl Matches when the operation requested in the current transaction is defined in the identified WSDL file. wsdlComponentValue Identifies the name of the WSDL-defined component. The value to specify depends on the identified WSDL component type. all
operation Specify double quotation marks (""). This combination eliminates the WSDL component from consideration. port The name of the WSDL operation. port The name of the WSDL port. service The name of the WSDL service. subscription Specify double quotation marks (""). Any specified value is ignored. wsdl The name of the WSDL file. subscription The name of an existing Subscription object. Required when the value specified by the component type is subscription.

entry.name: operation_priority_wsgateway_descr_1224
entry.text: Defines the priority for a web service operation

entry.name: aaa_policy_wsgateway_help_1225
entry.text:
Assigns an AAA Policy to the current Web Service Gateway. aaaPolicyName specifies the AAA Policy assigned to the gateway. For example:
aaa-policy webAccess-1 assigns the AAA Policy named webAccess-1 to the current Web Service Gateway

entry.name: aaa_policy_wsgateway_descr_1225
entry.text: Assigns an AAA Policy to the gateway

entry.name: kerberos_keytab_wsgateway_help_1226
entry.text:
Specifies the name and location of the keytab file that is used by the client to decrypt the Kerberos ticket for the Kerberos server principal.
filename is name and location of the keytab file.

entry.name: kerberos_keytab_wsgateway_descr_1226
entry.text: Identifies the keytab for the Kerberos server principal

entry.name: client_principal_wsgateway_help_1227
entry.text: Principal name that must appear as the client name in the Kerberos ticket. This must be a full principal name, including the Kerberos realm.

entry.name: client_principal_wsgateway_descr_1227
entry.text: Identifies the client principal name

entry.name: server_principal_wsgateway_help_1228
entry.text: Principal name that must appear as the server name in the Kerberos ticket. This must be a full principal name, including the Kerberos realm.

entry.name: server_principal_wsgateway_descr_1228
entry.text: Identifies the server principal name

entry.name: wssec11_enckey_cache_wsgateway_help_1229
entry.text: This is the Cache Lifetime for the decrypted generated key. Setting the value to 0 means the decrypted generated key will not be cached.

entry.name: wssec11_enckey_cache_wsgateway_descr_1229
entry.text: Identifies the EncryptedKeySHA1 Cache Lifetime

entry.name: preserve_key_chain_wsgateway_help_1230
entry.text: This controls whether the xenc:EncryptedKey will be removed after the decrypt action.

entry.name: preserve_key_chain_wsgateway_descr_1230
entry.text: Control the output of xenc:EncryptedKey after the decrypt action

entry.name: attachment_byte_count_wsgateway_help_1231
entry.text:
Specifies the maximum size (in bytes) of an attached document passing through the current Web Services Gateway. maxBytes specifies the maximum attachment size in bytes. In the absence of a specified value, this property defaults to 2000000000 bytes. The special value 0 indicates that all attachments are processed, regardless of size. For example:
attachment-byte-count 1000000000 specifies a maximum attachment size of 1000000000 bytes

entry.name: attachment_byte_count_wsgateway_descr_1231
entry.text: Specifies maximum attachment size

entry.name: attachment_package_byte_count_wsgateway_help_1232
entry.text:
Specifies the maximum size (in bytes) of an attached package, including the root part, passing through the current Web Services Gateway. maxBytes specifies the maximum attachment package size in bytes. In the absence of a specified value, this property defaults to 0 bytes. The special value 0 indicates that all attachments are processed, regardless of size. For example:
attachment-package-byte-count 1000000000 specifies a maximum attachment package size of 1000000000 bytes

entry.name: attachment_package_byte_count_wsgateway_descr_1232
entry.text: Specifies maximum attachment package size

entry.name: attribute_count_wsgateway_help_1233
entry.text:
Specifies the maximum number of attributes assigned to any XML element processed by the current Web Services Gateway. maxAttributes specifies the maximum number of attributes. In the absence of a specified value, this property defaults to 128 attributes. If set, this property overrides any parser limits assigned to the gateway by the XML manager. For example:
attribute-count 64 specifies a maximum number of 64 attributes per XML element

entry.name: attribute_count_wsgateway_descr_1233
entry.text: Specifies maximum attribute count

entry.name: autocreate_sources_wsgateway_help_1234
entry.text:
Enables or disables a default HTTP Handler. If front side traffic is conveyed by standard HTTP protocol, you can use this command to enable a default traffic handler. Otherwise, you must use the front-protocol command to assign a protocol-specific traffic handler or handlers to the Web Service Gateway. off the default, disables the default traffic handler; an explicit handler or handlers must be assigned with the front-protocol command. on enables the default traffic handler, which supports HTTP traffic only. For example:
autocreate-sources on enables the default traffic handler.

entry.name: autocreate_sources_wsgateway_descr_1234
entry.text: Enables/disables default Protocol Handler

entry.name: back_attachment_format_wsgateway_help_1235
entry.text:
Specifies the attachment output format to back-end servers. dime, dynamic, and mime are mutually exclusive keywords that specify the attachment format type. dime specifies that server attachments are DIME-encapsulated documents. dynamic specifies that the format of server attachments is deduced from the front side content. Mime specifies that server attachments are MIME-encapsulated documents. For example:
back-attachment-format dime specifies server attachments are DIME-encapsulated

entry.name: back_attachment_format_wsgateway_descr_1235
entry.text: Characterizes server attachment formats

entry.name: back_persistent_timeout_wsgateway_help_1236
entry.text:
Sets the inter-transaction timeout value, the maximum idle time allowed between the completion of a TCP transaction and the initiation of a new TCP transaction on the Web-Service-Gateway- to-server connection. If the specified idle timeout is exceeded, the connection is torn down. persistentTimeout specifies the number of seconds that an idle server persistent connection is maintained. Allowable values are within the range 10 through 86400 seconds, with a default value of 180. For example:
back-persistent-timeout 300 specifies a back-side idle timeout of 5 minutes

entry.name: back_persistent_timeout_wsgateway_descr_1236
entry.text: Specifies a server-side persistent timeout

entry.name: back_timeout_wsgateway_help_1237
entry.text:
Sets the intra-transaction timeout value, the maximum idle time allowed within a transaction on the Web-Service-Gateway-to-server connection. This timer, for example, monitors the interval between sending the client request and receiving the server response, and idle time within the data transfer process. If the specified idle time is exceeded, the connection is torn down. idleTimeout specifies the number of seconds that an idle transaction is maintained. Allowable values are within the range 10 through 86400 seconds, with a default value of 120. For example:
front-timeout 90 specifies a front-side idle timeout of 1 and a half minutes

entry.name: back_timeout_wsgateway_descr_1237
entry.text: Specifies a server-side idle timeout

entry.name: backend_url_wsgateway_help_1238
entry.text:
Identifies the target server; used only when the gateway type is static-backend. serverURL The server address to which all processed client requests are passed. serverURL can take the following forms depending on the transport protocol:
http:\server-name | ip-address:port-number:URI https:\server-name | ip-address:port-number:URI dpmq://QM/URI?RequestQueue=PUTQ;ReplyQueue=GETQ;UserName=name; TimeOut= milliseconds;Size=bytes
For example:
backend-url 192.168.100.12:8080 The target server

entry.name: backend_url_wsgateway_descr_1238
entry.text: Specifies the target server

entry.name: backside_port_rewrite_wsgateway_help_1239
entry.text:
Specifies a URL Rewrite Policy used to modify the wsdl:port address specified in the source WSDL when the service is loaded. If no URL Rewrite Policy is specified, the default local address is the IP address of the device and the relative URI and the original port number from the wsdl:port address specified in the source WSDL. urlRewritePolicyName The URL Rewrite Policy used to rewrite the frontside wsdl:port address. For example:
backside-port-rewrite amendBackPort The URL Rewrite Policy used to rewrite the port address.

entry.name: backside_port_rewrite_wsgateway_descr_1239
entry.text: Specifies a URL Rewrite Policy

entry.name: chunked_uploads_wsgateway_help_1240
entry.text:
Enables the use of chunked encoding when uploading an HTTP/1.1 request to the server. With chunk coding enabled, the WEb Service Gateway transfers messages to the server as a series of chunks, with each chunk containing a length value followed by the chunk data. A chunk with a zero length value indicates end-of-message. By default, chunk encoding is disabled. Chunk encoding should be enabled to stream documents to a server. You should, however, ensure that the target server is fully RFC-2616 compliant before enabling chunk encoding. For example:
chunked-uploads enables chunked encoding

entry.name: chunked_uploads_wsgateway_descr_1240
entry.text: Enables chunked encoding

entry.name: allow_cache_control_wsgateway_help_1241
entry.text:
Specifies whether the Cache-Control header passes from the client to the back end. on Specifies that the HTTP GET method passes the Cache-Control header through to the back end. If the client request does not specify the header, a "Cache-Control:no-transform" header is passed to the back end. off (Default) A "Cache-Control:no-transform" header is passed to the back end. For example:
allow-cache-control on enables the client to specify the Cache-Control header with the HTTP GET method.

entry.name: allow_cache_control_wsgateway_descr_1241
entry.text: Specifies handling of the Cache-Control header

entry.name: compression_wsgateway_help_1242
entry.text:
Enables GZIP compression negotiation. If enabled, the Web Service Gateway responds to compression negotiation initiated by a server device. By default, compression negotiation is disabled. For example:
compression enables compression negotiation

entry.name: compression_wsgateway_descr_1242
entry.text: Enables compression negotiation

entry.name: debug_mode_wsgateway_help_1243
entry.text:
Enables diagnostic mode. Transaction diagnostic mode is not intended for use in a production environment. Transaction diagnostic mode consumes significant resources that can slow down transaction processing.
on Enables diagnostic mode. The probe contains the number of transactions that is defined by the debug history. off (Default) Disables diagnostic mode. Alternatively, use the 'no' form of the command to disable diagnostic mode.
unbounded Enables diagnostic mode. The probe history contains 250 transactions. This mode consumes significant resources and slows down transaction processing.

entry.name: debug_mode_wsgateway_descr_1243
entry.text: Enables diagnostic mode

entry.name: debug_history_wsgateway_help_1244
entry.text: Controls the number of transactions that are saved when in diagnostic mode. This value limits the number of concurrent XML sessions. Valid values are in the range from 10 through 250. The default value is 25.

entry.name: debug_history_wsgateway_descr_1244
entry.text: Sets limit for transaction history

entry.name: debug_trigger_wsgateway_help_1245
entry.text:
Optionally use the following criteria to define one or more triggers. The Probe becomes active only for traffic that meets the criteria for one of the defined triggers.
PCRE to match client IP addresses Specify a PCRE-match to the client IP address. Requests from clients with matching IP addresses trigger debugging. To match any number of any character, specify ".*" (without quotes) instead of "*" (without quotes). PCRE to match inbound URL requests Specify a PCRE-match to an inbound URL. Requests from clients that match this expression trigger debugging. To match any number of any character, specify ".*" (without quotes) instead of "*" (without quotes). PCRE to match outbound URL responses Specify a PCRE-match for an outbound URL. Outbound requests that match this expression trigger debugging. To match any number of any character, specify ".*" (without quotes) instead of "*" (without quotes). Processing rule Specify one of the following values, based on direction, to trigger debugging: "Request" "Response" "Both" "Error" The value "Both" includes both requests and responses. PCRE to match names of rules Specify a PCRE match for the name of a processing rule. Names that match this expression trigger debugging. To match any number of any character, specify ".*" (without quotes) instead of "*" (without quotes). XPath expression Specify an XPath expression. Messages that have an element that match this expression trigger debugging.

entry.name: debug_trigger_wsgateway_descr_1245
entry.text: Defines triggers

entry.name: debugger_type_wsgateway_help_1246
entry.text: Indicates whether the probe operates in internal mode (the default) or operates in external mode. Always specify "internal".

entry.name: debugger_type_wsgateway_descr_1246
entry.text: Sets the probe mode

entry.name: debugger_url_wsgateway_help_1247
entry.text: Configures the URL for the probe when it operates in external mode.

entry.name: debugger_url_wsgateway_descr_1247
entry.text: Defines the external server URL

entry.name: decrypt_key_wsgateway_help_1248
entry.text: The Web Service Proxy automatically decrypts encrypted requests. Configure the decrypt key to explicitly select the private key to be used in the decryption.

entry.name: decrypt_key_wsgateway_descr_1248
entry.text: Crypto key to decrypt encrypted operations

entry.name: default_param_namespace_wsgateway_help_1249
entry.text:
Specifies a default namespace for stylesheet parameters defined without an explicit namespace declaration. By default, such parameters are assigned to the
http://www.datapower.com/param/config
namespace. defaultNamespace The default namespace. For example:
default-namespace http://megaCorp.com/XML/NS/external specifies the default namespace for stylesheet parameters

entry.name: default_param_namespace_wsgateway_descr_1249
entry.text: Specifies the default namespace

entry.name: element_depth_wsgateway_help_1250
entry.text:
Specifies the maximum depth of nested elements supported by this Web Services Gateway. maxNestingLevel specifies the maximum depth of nested elements. In the absence of a specified value, this property defaults to 512 levels. If set, this property overrides any parser limits inherited by the gateway from the assigned XML manager. For example:
element-depth 32 specifies a maximum element nesting of 32 levels

entry.name: element_depth_wsgateway_descr_1250
entry.text: Specifies maximum element nesting

entry.name: endpoint_rewrite_policy_wsgateway_help_1251
entry.text:
Assigns an Endpoint Rewrite Policy to the current WS Proxy. The Policy determines the Local, Remote and Published Endpoints used by the Proxy. If not present, the Proxy will use Local and Remote Endpoint Rewrite Rules, in conjunction with the auto-create-sources toggle to generate endpoints. PolicyName the name of an existing Endpoint Rewrite Policy. Use the wsm-endpointrewrite Global Config command to create such a policy.
For example:
endpoint-rewrite-policy Searcher assigns the policy named Searcher to the proxy.

entry.name: endpoint_rewrite_policy_wsgateway_descr_1251
entry.text: Assigns an EndPoint Rewrite Policy to the Proxy.

entry.name: follow_redirects_wsgateway_help_1252
entry.text:
Enables redirection on the current Web Service Gateway. Some protocols, HTTP for example, may generate redirect messages. With redirection enabled (the default state), the gateway attempts to resolve redirection instructions. For example:
follow-redirects enables redirection, thus restoring the default state

entry.name: follow_redirects_wsgateway_descr_1252
entry.text: Enables redirect resolution

entry.name: external_references_wsgateway_help_1253
entry.text:
Defines the handling mode for input documents that contain external references. External references can be external entities or external DTD definitions. This setting overrides the value that is set by the XML Parser Limits command.
allow Allows and resolves external references. This is a security risk. forbid Forbids external references. An external reference causes the XML parser to stop. This setting is the default value. ignore Accesses and resolves external references, but replaces each for further processing with an empty string. This can be a security risk.

entry.name: external_references_wsgateway_descr_1253
entry.text: Handling mode for input documents that contain external references.

entry.name: front_attachment_format_wsgateway_help_1254
entry.text:
Characterizes client attachment formats received by the current Web Service Gateway. dime, dynamic, and mime are mutually exclusive keywords that specify the attachment format type. dime specifies that client attachments are DIME-encapsulated documents. dynamic specifies that the format of client attachments is deduced from the document content. Mime specifies that client attachments are MIME-encapsulated documents. For example:
front-attachment-format dime specifies client attachments are DIME-encapsulated

entry.name: front_attachment_format_wsgateway_descr_1254
entry.text: Characterizes client attachment formats

entry.name: front_persistent_timeout_wsgateway_help_1255
entry.text:
Sets the inter-transaction timeout value, the maximum idle time allowed between the completion of a TCP transaction and the initiation of a new TCP transaction on the Web-Service-Gateway- to-client connection. If the specified idle timeout is exceeded, the connection is torn down. persistentTimeout specifies the number of seconds that an idle client persistent connection is maintained. Allowable values are within the range 10 through 86400 seconds, with a default value of 180. For example:
front-persistent-timeout 150 specifies a front-side idle timeout of two-and-a-half minutes

entry.name: front_persistent_timeout_wsgateway_descr_1255
entry.text: Specifies a client-side persistent timeout

entry.name: front_protocol_wsgateway_help_1256
entry.text:
Assigns a protocol-specific Protocol Handler to the Web Service Gateway. If the incoming front-side traffic is HTTP, you can use the autocreate-sources command to enable a default traffic handler which services HTTP traffic only. Otherwise, use this command to one or more protocol-specific handlers to the gateway. protocolHandlerName The Protocol Handler assigned to the gateway. For example:
front-protocol httpsHandler front-protocol mqHandler assigns two protocol-specific handlers to the current gateway

entry.name: front_protocol_wsgateway_descr_1256
entry.text: Assigns a Protocol Handler

entry.name: frontside_port_rewrite_wsgateway_help_1257
entry.text:
Specifies a URL Rewrite Policy used to modify the wsdl:port address specified in the source WSDL when the service is loaded. If no URL Rewrite Policy is specified, the default local address is the IP address of the device and the relative URI and the original port number from the wsdl:port address specified in the source WSDL. urlRewritePolicyName The URL Rewrite Policy used to rewrite the frontside wsdl:port address. For example:
frontside-port-rewrite amendFrontPort The URL Rewrite Policy used to rewrite the port address.

entry.name: frontside_port_rewrite_wsgateway_descr_1257
entry.text: Specifies a URL Rewrite Policy

entry.name: front_timeout_wsgateway_help_1258
entry.text:
Sets the intra-transaction timeout value, the maximum idle time allowed within a transaction on the Web-Service-Gateway-to-client connection. This timer, for example, monitors idle time within the data transfer process. If the specified idle time is exceeded, the connection is torn down. idleTimeout specifies the number of seconds that an idle transaction is maintained. Allowable values are within the range 10 through 86400 seconds, with a default value of 120. For example:
front-timeout 60 specifies a front-side idle timeout of 1 minute

entry.name: front_timeout_wsgateway_descr_1258
entry.text: Specifies a client-side idle timeout

entry.name: fwcred_wsgateway_help_1259
entry.text:
Assigns a Firewall Credentials List, a list of certificates and keys, to the current Web Service Gateway. A Firewall Credentials list specifies which keys and certificates are available to support Web Service Gateway processing. In the absence of an identified Firewall Credentials list, all locally-stored keys and certificates are available to the gateway. firewallCredentialsName is the name of the Firewall Credentials List. For example:
fwcred fwCreds-1 assigns the Firewall Credentials List, fwCreds-1, to the gateway

entry.name: fwcred_wsgateway_descr_1259
entry.text: Assigns a Firewall Credentials List to the gateway

entry.name: gateway_parser_limits_wsgateway_help_1260
entry.text:
Enables gateway-specific parsing limits. If enabled, the Web Service Gateway uses the values (if any) set by the attribute-count, element-depth, max-message-size, and max-node-size CLI commands to govern XML parsing. If values have not been explicitly set by these commands, the gateway uses the XML parsing limits inherited from the XML manager assigned to the gateway. For example:
gateway-parser-limits enables Web Service gateway-specific parsing limits

entry.name: gateway_parser_limits_wsgateway_descr_1260
entry.text: Enables gateway-specific parsing limits

entry.name: host_rewriting_wsgateway_help_1261
entry.text:
Enables "host rewrite" -- with host rewrite enabled (the default state), the Web Service Gateway rewrites the URL received from the client to reflect the address/method used by the gateway to access the back-end web or application server. For example:
host-rewriting enables the host rewrite function

entry.name: host_rewriting_wsgateway_descr_1261
entry.text: Enables Host Rewrite

entry.name: http_client_ip_label_wsgateway_help_1262
entry.text:
When set, the IP address of the calling client will be read from the HTTP Header identified here. This IP address will then be used for monitoring and logging. Defaults to X-Client-IP. For example:
http-client-ip-label X-Forwarded-For The HTTP Header containing the client IP address as X-Forwarded-For.

entry.name: http_client_ip_label_wsgateway_descr_1262
entry.text: Identifies an HTTP Header containing the Client IP

entry.name: http_global_tranid_label_wsgateway_help_1263
entry.text:
Restores the default state, and enables the inclusion of the Global transaction ID in the HTTP header sent to the web or application server. In the default state the global transaction header is included in a field labeled "X-Global-Transaction-ID". httpHeaderFieldLabel optionally specifies a new label for the HTTP header field. For example:
http-global-tranID-label X-MyGlobal-Transaction-ID includes global transaction ID in an HTTP header field labeled X-MyGlobal-Transaction-ID

entry.name: http_global_tranid_label_wsgateway_descr_1263
entry.text: Global Transaction ID Label

entry.name: http_server_version_wsgateway_help_1264
entry.text:
Specifies the version of HTTP used by the Web Service Gateway to connect to the back-end server(s). HTTP/1.0 and HTTP/1.1 are mutually exclusive keywords that identify the HTTP protocol version. HTTP/1.0 specifies the earlier HTTP 1.0. HTTP/1.1 the default, specifies the more recent HTTP 1.1. For example:
http-server-version HTTP/1.0 specifies HTTP 1.0

entry.name: http_server_version_wsgateway_descr_1264
entry.text: Specifies an HTTP version

entry.name: include_content_type_encoding_wsgateway_help_1265
entry.text:
Specifies that character set encoding data is contained in content-type headers generated by the Web Service Gateway. Assume a UFT-8 encoded XML document. With this property enabled, the content-type header contains a value of "text/xml; charset=UTF-8". With this property disabled, the content-type header reads "text/xml". By default, character set inclusion is disabled. For example:
include-content-type-encoding enables character set inclusion

entry.name: include_content_type_encoding_wsgateway_descr_1265
entry.text: Include character set encoding

entry.name: inject_wsgateway_help_1266
entry.text:
Injects (adds) a specified HTTP header field into the Web-Service-Gateway-to-client or gateway-to-server packet stream. back and front are mutually exclusive keywords that identify the target stream. back The Web-Service-Gateway-to-server stream. front The Web-Service-Gateway-to-client stream. httpHeaderFieldName The HTTP header field to be added to the specified stream. httpHeaderFieldValue specifies the value contained in httpHeaderFieldName. stream. For example:
inject back myHeader myValue add the header field myHeader, containing the value myValue, into the gateway-to-server stream

entry.name: inject_wsgateway_descr_1266
entry.text: Injects a named HTTP header field

entry.name: inorder_mode_wsgateway_help_1267
entry.text:
Enables in-order (serial) processing of queue-based messages during different parts of transactions through the service. When enabled the service respects the sequential order of the messages when writing them to queues.
When using this command, use a plus (+) character as a separator.
The following processing modes are supported: Backend Enforces serial transmission of messages to the backend request queue. Request Enforces serial processing of the actions defined for request processing, excluding serial transmission of messages to the backend request queue. Response Enforces serial processing of the actions defined for response processing, including serial transmission of messages to the front-side reply queue.
For example to process both request and response messages in order: inorder-mode Request+Response

entry.name: inorder_mode_wsgateway_descr_1267
entry.text: Controls serial processing of queue-based messages processing

entry.name: load_balancer_hash_header_wsgateway_help_1268
entry.text:
The name of an HTTP Header to use rather than a Client IP address when load balancing traffic to the back end servers using a hash algorithm. The value of the header identified here will be used to calculate a hash rather than the IP address. If this is blank, then the client IP address will be used for hash calculation. For example:
load-balancer-hash-header X-Forwarded-For The HTTP Header value to use for load balancing.

entry.name: load_balancer_hash_header_wsgateway_descr_1268
entry.text: Identifies an HTTP Header to use for Load Balancing

entry.name: loop_detection_wsgateway_help_1269
entry.text:
Enables a loop-detection algorithm on the Web Service Gateway. By default, loop-detection is disabled. For example:
loop-detection enables the loop-detection algorithm

entry.name: loop_detection_wsgateway_descr_1269
entry.text: Enables a loop-detection algorithm

entry.name: max_message_size_wsgateway_help_1270
entry.text:
Specifies the maximum size (in kilobytes) of an XML or SOAP message passing through the current Web Service Gateway. maxKiloBytes specifies the maximum XML or SOAP document size in kilobytes. In the absence of a specified value, this property defaults to 0, indicating that all documents are accepted, regardless of size. If set, this property overrides any parser limits inherited by the gateway from the assigned XML manager. For example:
max-message-size 1000 specifies a maximum document size of 1000 kilobytes

entry.name: max_message_size_wsgateway_descr_1270
entry.text: Specifies maximum message size

entry.name: max_node_size_wsgateway_help_1271
entry.text:
Sets the maximum size of any XML node within an XML document processed by the current Web Service Gateway. maxBytes specifies the maximum node size. By default, the maximum node size is is set to 33554432 (32MB). Allowable values are within the range 1024 through 4294967295. If set, this property overrides any parser limits inherited by the gateway from the assigned XML manager. For example:
max-node-size 671080864 limits the per-node size to 64 MB.

entry.name: max_node_size_wsgateway_descr_1271
entry.text: Limits the maximum size of an XML node

entry.name: max_prefixes_wsgateway_help_1272
entry.text:
Specifies the maximum number of distinct XML namespace prefixes in a document. This limit counts multiple prefixes that are defined for the same namespace. This limit does not count multiple namespaces that are defined in different parts of the input document under a single prefix.
number Specifies the maximum number of distinct XML namespace prefixes in a document. Enter a value in the range 0 - 262143. The default value is 1024. A value of 0 indicates that the limit is 1024.
For example: max-prefixes 40 Set the maximum number of distinct XML namespace prefixes to 40.

entry.name: max_prefixes_wsgateway_descr_1272
entry.text: Specifies the maximum number of distinct XML namespace prefixes in a document

entry.name: max_namespaces_wsgateway_help_1273
entry.text:
Specifies the maximum number of distinct XML namespace URIs in a document. This limit counts all XML namespaces, regardless of how many prefixes are used to declare them.
number Specifies the maximum number of distinct XML namespace URIs in a document. Enter a value in the range 0 - 65535. The default value is 1024. A value of 0 indicates that the limit is 1024.
For example: max-namespaces 40 Set the maximum number of distinct XML namespace URIs to 40.

entry.name: max_namespaces_wsgateway_descr_1273
entry.text: Specifies the maximum number of distinct XML namespace URIs in a document

entry.name: max_local_names_wsgateway_help_1274
entry.text:
This limit counts all local names, independent of the namespaces they are associated with.
number Specifies the maximum number of distinct XML local names in a document. Enter a value in the range 0 - 1048575. The default value is 60000. A value of 0 indicates that the limit is 60000.
For example: max-local-names 100 Set the maximum number of distinct XML local names to 100.

entry.name: max_local_names_wsgateway_descr_1274
entry.text: Specifies the maximum number of distinct XML local names in a document

entry.name: mime_back_headers_wsgateway_help_1275
entry.text:
Enables processing support (on the Web-Service-Gateway-to-server stream) for MIME package headers within MIME multi-part messages transmitted over HTTP. By default, processing support is enabled. For example:
mime-back-headers enables MIME package header support, thus restoring the default state

entry.name: mime_back_headers_wsgateway_descr_1275
entry.text: Processes MIME package headers

entry.name: mime_front_headers_wsgateway_help_1276
entry.text:
Enables processing support (on the Web-Service-Gateway-to-client stream) for MIME package headers within MIME multi-part messages transmitted over HTTP. By default, processing support is enabled. For example:
