mime-front-headers enables MIME package header support, thus restoring the default state

entry.name: mime_front_headers_wsgateway_descr_1276
entry.text: Processes MIME package headers

entry.name: monitor_count_wsgateway_help_1277
entry.text:
Assigns a count monitor to the current Web Service Gateway. countMonitorName The count monitor assigned to the gateway For example:
monitor-count CMonitor-1 assigns count monitor CMonitor-1 to the gateway

entry.name: monitor_count_wsgateway_descr_1277
entry.text: Assigns a count monitor to the gateway

entry.name: monitor_duration_wsgateway_help_1278
entry.text:
Assigns a duration monitor to the current Web Service Gateway. durationMonitorName The duration monitor assigned to the gateway. For example:
monitor-duration DMonitor-11 assigns duration monitor DMonitor-11 to the gateway

entry.name: monitor_duration_wsgateway_descr_1278
entry.text: Assigns a duration monitor to the gateway

entry.name: monitor_processing_policy_wsgateway_help_1279
entry.text:
Set the monitor processing policy to one of the following options to determine how the system behaves when more than one monitor is attached to the service. May be either of: terminate-at-first-throttle: (the default) Monitors will execute in the order in which they are listed. After any monitor either shapes (buffers to delay) or rejects a message, no further monitors will execute. terminate-at-first-match Monitors will execute in the order in which they are listed. After any monitor matches a message and takes any action at all, no further monitors will execute. For example:
monitor-processing-policy terminate-at-first-match allows only the first matching monitor to execute.

entry.name: monitor_processing_policy_wsgateway_descr_1279
entry.text: Sets the behavior of multiple monitors

entry.name: monitor_service_wsgateway_help_1280
entry.text:
Assigns a service monitor to the current Web Service Gateway. serviceMonitorName The service monitor assigned to the gateway. For example:
monitor-service SMonitor-21 assigns service monitor SMonitor-21 to the gateway

entry.name: monitor_service_wsgateway_descr_1280
entry.text: Assigns a service monitor to the gateway

entry.name: parameter_wsgateway_help_1281
entry.text:
Assigns a parameter/value pair to the current Web Service Gateway; the pair is available to any stylesheet used by the gateway. parameterName specifies the parameter's name. parameterValue specifies the parameter's value. For example:
parameter defaultTee 10.10.4.4:8080 assigns the parameter defaultTee, with a value of 10.10.4.4:8080, to the gateway

entry.name: parameter_wsgateway_descr_1281
entry.text: Assigns a parameter/value pair to the gateway

entry.name: persistent_connections_wsgateway_help_1282
entry.text:
Enables HTTP/1.1 persistent connections on the Web-Service-Gateway-to-server connection. By default, persistent connections are enabled. For example:
persistent-connections enables persistent connections on the gateway-to-server connection thus restoring the default state

entry.name: persistent_connections_wsgateway_descr_1282
entry.text: Enables persistent connections

entry.name: process_http_errors_wsgateway_help_1283
entry.text:
Most successful HTTP transactions return a 200 level response code. However, it is possible, and in some environments common, for errors to return codes such as 404 or 500 with an XML response body. process-http-errors specifies that such a response body should be processed as would the body of the "normal" (200 level) response. For example:
process-http-errors enables processing of non-200 response bodies, restoring the default state

entry.name: process_http_errors_wsgateway_descr_1283
entry.text: Processing for error responses

entry.name: propagate_uri_wsgateway_help_1284
entry.text:
Specifies that the local portion of a URI is passed from the front (client) to the back (server). Propagation of the local portion of the URI is enabled by default. For example:
propagate-uri enables propagation of the local portion of the URI, restoring the default state

entry.name: propagate_uri_wsgateway_descr_1284
entry.text: Propagates local portion of URI

entry.name: query_param_namespace_wsgateway_help_1285
entry.text:
Specifies a default namespace for parameters contained within a URL query string. By default, such parameters are assigned to the
http://www.datapower.com/param/query
namespace. defaultNamespace The default namespace. For example:
default-namespace http://megaCorp.com/XML/NS/query specifies the default namespace for URL query parameters

entry.name: query_param_namespace_wsgateway_descr_1285
entry.text: Specifies the default namespace

entry.name: request_attachments_wsgateway_help_1286
entry.text:
Specifies how to handle messages with attachments.
allow Allows messages with attachments, and processes needed attachments. reject Rejects messages with attachments. strip Removes attachments from messages before processing. streaming Allows messages with attachments, but provides limited processing. unprocessed Allows messages with attachments, but does not process them.

entry.name: request_attachments_wsgateway_descr_1286
entry.text: Specify client attachment processing

entry.name: request_type_wsgateway_help_1287
entry.text:
Specifies client input to the current Web Service Gateway by traffic type. Preprocessed, SOAP, Unprocessed, and XML are mutually exclusive keywords that identify client traffic type. Preprocessed The client input as flat file text or another binary format. The gateway passes the contents of the message unaltered to the destination server. The gateway can take such action as authenticate and authorize access, set a target destination or attach variables to the context for tracking. SOAP (the default) The client input as XML formatted in accordance with the SOAP schema standards. The gateway validates the message against a default or user-designated SOAP schema, performs other user-designated document processing and forwards the resulting material to the server. Unprocessed The client input as uncharacterized. The gateway relays the input to the server, with no processing of any sort. XML The client input as formatted XML that is passed to the server after user-designated document processing. For example:
request-type XML characterizes incoming client traffic as XML

entry.name: request_type_wsgateway_descr_1287
entry.text: Characterizes client input

entry.name: response_attachments_wsgateway_help_1288
entry.text:
Specifies how to handle messages with attachments.
allow Allows messages with attachments, and processes needed attachments. reject Rejects messages with attachments. strip Removes attachments from messages before processing. streaming Allows messages with attachments, but provides limited processing. unprocessed Allows messages with attachments, but does not process them.

entry.name: response_attachments_wsgateway_descr_1288
entry.text: Specify server attachment processing

entry.name: response_type_wsgateway_help_1289
entry.text:
Specifies server input to the current Web Service Gateway by traffic type. Preprocessed, SOAP, Unprocessed, and XML are mutually exclusive keywords that identify server traffic type. Preprocessed The server input as flat file text or another binary format. The gateway passes the contents of the message unaltered to the destination client. The gateway can take such action as authenticate and authorize access, set a target destination or attach variables to the context for tracking. SOAP (the default) The server input as XML formatted in accordance with the SOAP schema standards. The gateway validates the message against a default or user-designated SOAP schema, performs other user-designated document processing and forwards the resulting material to the client. Unprocessed The server input as uncharacterized. The gateway relays the input to the client, with no processing of any sort. XML The server input as formatted XML that is passed to the client after user-designated document processing. For example:
response-type XML characterizes incoming server traffic as XML

entry.name: response_type_wsgateway_descr_1289
entry.text: Characterizes server input

entry.name: soap_action_policy_wsgateway_help_1290
entry.text:
Use one of the following Policy argument values to determine the handling of the SOAPAction HTTP header. lax (default) An empty header or a header containing the empty string from the client is considered a match. The client's soap action header may be quoted. For example, SOAPAction: "" is treated as a match. strict The client must provide exactly the header specified in the WSDL. The client may quote the SOAP action header. off The header is ignored when issued by clients and is never compared to the WSDL. For example:
soap-action-policy strict sets a strict policy for handling the SOAP Action header value.

entry.name: soap_action_policy_wsgateway_descr_1290
entry.text: Sets the SOAP Action Header Policy

entry.name: soap_schema_url_wsgateway_help_1291
entry.text:
Assigns a SOAP schema to the current Web Service Gateway. In the absence of an explicit schema assignment, the gateway uses the DataPower-supplied schema,
store:///schemas/soap-envelope.xsd.
schemaURL The SOAP schema used to validate incoming client or server SOAP messages. For example:
soap-schema-url store:///schemas/newSOAP.xsd assigns the specified schema to the gateway

entry.name: soap_schema_url_wsgateway_descr_1291
entry.text: Assigns a SOAP schema to the gateway

entry.name: ssl_wsgateway_help_1292
entry.text:
The TLS proxy profile is deprecated. Use a TLS server profile or TLS SNI server profile. Assigns a TLS Proxy Profile to the current Web Service Gateway. xxlProxyProfileName The TLS Proxy Profile assigned to the gateway. For example:
ssl sslProxyProfile-1 assigns TLS Proxy Profile sslProxyProfile-1 to the gateway

entry.name: ssl_wsgateway_descr_1292
entry.text: Deprecated - Assigns a TLS Proxy Profile to the gateway

entry.name: ssl_client_type_wsgateway_help_1293
entry.text:
Sets the type of the TLS profile for the current Web Service Gateway. For example:
ssl-client-type client uses a TLS client profile to secure connections.

entry.name: ssl_client_type_wsgateway_descr_1293
entry.text: Sets the TLS profile type to secure connections.

entry.name: ssl_client_wsgateway_help_1294
entry.text:
Assigns a TLS Client Profile to the current Web Service Gateway. sslClientProfileName The TLS Client Profile assigned to the gateway. For example:
ssl-client-type client ssl-client sslClientProfile-1 assigns TLS Client Profile sslClientProfile-1 to the gateway.

entry.name: ssl_client_wsgateway_descr_1294
entry.text: Assigns a TLS Client Profile to the gateway

entry.name: ssl_config_type_wsgateway_help_1295
entry.text:
Sets the type of TLS profile for the current Web Service Gateway. For example:
ssl-config-type server uses a TLS Server Profile to secure connections.

entry.name: ssl_config_type_wsgateway_descr_1295
entry.text: Sets the type of TLS profile for the gateway.

entry.name: ssl_server_wsgateway_help_1296
entry.text:
Assigns a TLS Server Profile to the current Web Service Gateway. sslServerProfileName The TLS Server Profile assigned to the gateway. For example:
ssl-config-type server ssl-server sslServerProfile-1 assigns TLS Server Profile sslServerProfile-1 to the gateway.

entry.name: ssl_server_wsgateway_descr_1296
entry.text: Assigns a TLS Server Profile to the gateway.

entry.name: ssl_sni_server_wsgateway_help_1297
entry.text:
Assigns a TLS SNI Server Profile to the current Web Service Gateway. sslSNIProfileName The TLS SNI Server Profile assigned to the gateway. For example:
ssl-config-type sni ssl-sni-server sslSNIProfile-1 assigns TLS SNI Profile sslSNIProfile-1 to the gateway.

entry.name: ssl_sni_server_wsgateway_descr_1297
entry.text: Assigns a TLS SNI Server Profile to the gateway.

entry.name: stream_output_to_back_wsgateway_help_1298
entry.text:
Specifies if the current Web Service Gateway begins sending output to the server before completing the processing of a client request.
buffer-until-verification indicates that the gateway disables streaming. With streaming disabled, the gateway buffers a client request until all processing is complete, and only then sends the request to the server. stream-until-infraction indicates that the gateway enables streaming. With streaming enabled (which may result in faster response times) the gateway begins sending the request to the server prior to the completion of processing. If a processing error occurs, the gateway reverts to the buffering model. If the XML Manager selected for this Gateway has streaming enabled, use the stream-until-infraction command to ensure that the DataPower device will stream messages end to end. Use this option if streaming of attachments is enabled. For example:
stream-output-to-back stream-until-infraction enables back-end streaming

entry.name: stream_output_to_back_wsgateway_descr_1298
entry.text: Enables/Disables back-end streaming

entry.name: stream_output_to_front_wsgateway_help_1299
entry.text:
Specifies if the current Web Service Gateway begins sending output to the client before completing the processing of a server response.
buffer-until-verification indicates that the gateway disables streaming. With streaming disabled, the gateway buffers a server response until all processing is complete, and only then sends the response to the client. stream-until-infraction indicates that the gateway enables streaming. With streaming enabled (which may result in faster response times) the gateway begins sending the response to the client prior to the completion of processing. If a processing error occurs, the gateway reverts to the buffering model. If the XML Manager selected for this Gateway has streaming enabled, use the stream-until-infraction command to ensure that the DataPower device will stream messages end to end. Use this option if streaming of attachments is enabled. For example:
stream-output-to-front stream-until-infraction enables front-end streaming

entry.name: stream_output_to_front_wsgateway_descr_1299
entry.text: Enables/Disables front-end streaming

entry.name: stylepolicy_wsgateway_help_1300
entry.text:
Assigns a Document Processing Policy to the current Web Service Gateway. Note that this policy must be created using the wsm-stylepolicy command. documentProcessingPolicyName The Document Processing Policy assigned to the gateway. For example:
stylepolicy schemaValidate-1 assigns Document Processing Policy schemaValidate-1 to the gateway

entry.name: stylepolicy_wsgateway_descr_1300
entry.text: Assigns a Document Processing Policy to the gateway

entry.name: suppress_wsgateway_help_1301
entry.text:
Suppresses (deletes) a specified HTTP header field from the Web-Service-Gateway-to-client or gateway-to-server packet stream. back and front are mutually exclusive keywords that identify the target stream. back The gateway-to-server stream. front The gateway-to-client stream. httpHeaderFieldName The HTTP header field to be deleted from the specified stream. HTTP header fields are defined in Sections 4.5, 5.3, 6.2 and 7.1 of RFC 2616. For example:
suppress back Authorization deletes the Authorization header field from the gateway-to-server stream

entry.name: suppress_wsgateway_descr_1301
entry.text: Suppresses a named HTTP header field

entry.name: type_wsgateway_help_1302
entry.text:
Specifies the type of connection between the current Web Service Gateway and back-end servers. dynamic-backend and static-backend are mutually exclusive keywords that identify the gateway type.
dynamic-backend indicates that the address of the target server is programmatically extracted from the client request with either the set-target or xset-target extension element. static-backend (the default value) indicates that all client requests are sent to a single server identified by the backend-url command. For example:
type dynamic-backend specifies the use of extension elements to programmatically extract the address a of back-end server

entry.name: type_wsgateway_descr_1302
entry.text: Specifies the gateway type

entry.name: uddi_subscription_wsgateway_help_1303
entry.text:
The UDDI Subscription is deprecated. Instead, use WebSphere Service Registry and Repository (WSRR) subscription.
The Web Service Proxy will load and proxy services that are obtained through the specified existing UDDI Subscription.

entry.name: uddi_subscription_wsgateway_descr_1303
entry.text: Obtain web services through a UDDI subscription

entry.name: urlrewrite_policy_wsgateway_help_1304
entry.text:
Assigns a URL Rewrite Policy to the current Web Service Gateway. urlRewritePolicyName The URL Rewrite Policy assigned to the gateway. For example:
urlrewrite-policy urlRewrite-1 assigns URL Rewrite Policy urlRewrite-1 to the gateway

entry.name: urlrewrite_policy_wsgateway_descr_1304
entry.text: Assigns a URL Rewrite Policy to the gateway

entry.name: user_policy_wsgateway_help_1305
entry.text: Each WSDL operation of the web service proxied by a Web Services Gateway may have a user policy defined for that component. Specific WSDL components are specified by the combination of Target Namespace, WSDL file name, Service, PortType, Binding and Operation. For example, to specify all operations in the target namespace MySvc, assign a value of "MySvc" to the targeNamespace argument and set all other arguments to *. To specify only one particular operation, named GetLottoPick for example, assign the value "wsdl:definitions//wsdl:operation/@GetLottoPick" to the wsdlOperation argument and set all other arguments to *. The user-designed policy applied to the specified component consists of three options: enable, publish and Validatefaults. targetNamespace specifies namespace criteria for policy selection. The target namespace is found in the WSDL definitions element. Enter the target namespace or * to match any namespace. wsdlFile specifies a specific WSDL file. Use the local name as identified by the wsdl CLI command, or use * to identify all associated WSDL files. wsdlService specifies WSDL service criteria for policy selection. Specify a particular service with the form wsdl:definitions/wsdl:service/@name or use * for any service. wsdlPortType specifies WSDL port criteria for policy selection. Specify a particular port with the form wsdl:definitions/wsdl:portType/@name or use * for any PortType. wsdlBinding specifies WSDL binding criteria for policy selection. Specify a particular binding with the form wsdl:definitions/wsdl:binding/@name or use * for any Binding. wsdlOperation specifies WSDL operation criteria for policy selection. Specify a particular operation with the form wsdl:definitions//wsdl:operation/@name or use * for any operation. You can use the portType and wsdlBinding arguments to limit the operations selected for this policy. enable, publish, and validatefaults are non-mutually exclusive keywords that specify policy operations. enable enables the policy. publish specifies that the user policy is included in any published description (WSDL) of the gateway service. validatefaults specifies that any generated fault messages are schema validated.

entry.name: user_policy_wsgateway_descr_1305
entry.text: Assigns a user-designed policy to a WSDL component

entry.name: wsdl_wsgateway_help_1306
entry.text:
Associates a WSDL file with the Web Service Proxy. The WSDL file defines the Web services that the Web Service Proxy supports.
Use the no wsdl command to remove a WSDL file from the Web Service Proxy.
wsdlLocation The exact location (URL) of the WSDL file. The file can be stored on the device or on a remote server (for example, local:///searchservice.wsdl). localName Specifies a mnemonic for the WSDL file. The mnemonic can be the file name (for example, searchservice.wsdl) or an alias (for example, search). The value for the parameter should be the name of the WSDL-file parameter as identified by the user-policy command. policyAttachment The name of an existing Policy Attachment object. Policy attachments associate WS-Policy with the different types of policy subjects (service, endpoint, operation, message) in the WSDL file.
For example:
wsdl local:///accountquery.wsdl CheckBalanceWSDL associates the specified WSDL file with the current Web Service Proxy

entry.name: wsdl_wsgateway_descr_1306
entry.text: Assigns or removes a source WSDL file

entry.name: wsdl_cache_policy_wsgateway_help_1307
entry.text:
The Proxy can automatically refresh one or more of the WSDL files on which the Proxy is based. WSDL files matching the urlMatch argument will automatically be refreshed after the TTL expires. This may cause the Proxy to reconfigure itself in accordance with the new state of the WSDL. urlMatch A URL Match expression matching the location of one or more WSDL files used by the Proxy. TTL An integer representing the number of seconds that will elapse before the Proxy automatically refreshes the matching WSDL files. For example:
wsdl-cache-policy http://server/banking/* 86400 caches all WSDL files located in at the URL http://server/banking/* every 24 hours.

entry.name: wsdl_cache_policy_wsgateway_descr_1307
entry.text: Establishes a WSDL Caching Policy

entry.name: wsmagent_monitor_wsgateway_help_1308
entry.text:
Controls whether the Web Services Management Agent collects Web Services Management (WS-Management) data for the service.
on Collects WS-Management records. (Default) off Does not collect WS-Management records.

entry.name: wsmagent_monitor_wsgateway_descr_1308
entry.text: Whether to collect Web Services Management records

entry.name: wsmagent_monitor_capture_mode_wsgateway_help_1309
entry.text:
WSM Agent monitor payload capture mode in Web Service Proxy identifies messages that are captured and forwarded to a Web Services Manager for analysis.
By default, all messages are captured, but you can choose not to capture messages or capture messages on error or fault.
Full message capture incurs a performance penalty.
Not all Web Service Management protocols accommodate full message capture, so it should only be configured if the spooler is capable of forwarding full messages.
none Captures no messages. all-messages Captures all messages. (Default) on-error Captures messages on error or fault.

entry.name: wsmagent_monitor_capture_mode_wsgateway_descr_1309
entry.text: Captures the message for monitoring records with Web Services Management agent

entry.name: wsrm_wsgateway_help_1310
entry.text:
WS-ReliableMessaging is deprecated. Specifies whether to enable or disable WS-ReliableMessaging 1.1 support.
on Enables Reliable Messaging. off Disables Reliable Messaging.

entry.name: wsrm_wsgateway_descr_1310
entry.text: Specifies WS-ReliableMessaging - Deprecated

entry.name: wsrm_aaa_policy_wsgateway_help_1311
entry.text:
WS-ReliableMessaging is deprecated. Specifies the name of an existing AAA Policy object for authentication of incoming Reliable Messaging control messages. This AAA Policy would normally be the same one that is used in later processing by the request or response rule. The results are cached so it is not evaluated again.
name The name of the AAA Policy.

entry.name: wsrm_aaa_policy_wsgateway_descr_1311
entry.text: Specifies AAA Policy for WS-ReliableMessaging - Deprecated

entry.name: wsrm_destination_accept_create_sequence_wsgateway_help_1312
entry.text:
WS-ReliableMessaging is deprecated. Specifies whether to accept or reject incoming Reliable Messaging CreateSequence SOAP requests, which create a RM Destination when accepted. The default is on.
on Accepts incoming CreateSequence SOAP requests. off Rejects incoming CreateSequence SOAP requests.

entry.name: wsrm_destination_accept_create_sequence_wsgateway_descr_1312
entry.text: Specifies accepting CreateSequence - Deprecated

entry.name: wsrm_destination_accept_offers_wsgateway_help_1313
entry.text:
WS-ReliableMessaging is deprecated. Specifies whether to accept or reject Offers for two-way Reliable Messaging in CreateSequence SOAP requests. If enabled, Offers will be accepted from either the client or server, creating a RM Source to send messages reliably to the client or server.
on Accepts offers for two-way Reliable Messaging. off Rejects offers for two-way Reliable Messaging.

entry.name: wsrm_destination_accept_offers_wsgateway_descr_1313
entry.text: Specifies accepting offers for two-way - Deprecated

entry.name: wsrm_destination_inorder_wsgateway_help_1314
entry.text:
WS-ReliableMessaging is deprecated. Specifies if RM Destinations will provide the InOrder delivery assurance, in addition to the ExactlyOnce delivery assurance that is always provided. If this is enabled, no sequenced message will be processed until all messages with lower MessageNumbers have already been processed. If this is disabled, messages will be processed in the order that they are received, so long as their message number has not been received before.
Specifies whether to accept InOrder and ExactlyOnce destination assurance, or whether to accept ExactlyOnce delivery assurance only.
on Provide InOrder and ExactlyOnce delivery assurance. off Provide ExactlyOnce delivery assurance only.

entry.name: wsrm_destination_inorder_wsgateway_descr_1314
entry.text: Specifies InOrder delivery assurance - Deprecated

entry.name: wsrm_destination_maximum_inorder_queue_length_wsgateway_help_1315
entry.text:
WS-ReliableMessaging is deprecated. Specifies the maximum number of messages held in a RM Destination's InOrder queue beyond a gap in the received MessageNumbers.
numberOfMessages The number of messages held in the queue. Use an integer in the range of 1 through 256. The default is 10.

entry.name: wsrm_destination_maximum_inorder_queue_length_wsgateway_descr_1315
entry.text: Limits maximum length of InOrder queue - Deprecated

entry.name: wsrm_destination_maximum_sequences_wsgateway_help_1316
entry.text:
WS-ReliableMessaging is deprecated. Sets a limit on the maximum number of simultaneously active RM Destination sequences of this DataPower service.
maximumSequences The number of active sequences. The default is 400.

entry.name: wsrm_destination_maximum_sequences_wsgateway_descr_1316
entry.text: Limits maximum RM Destination sequences - Deprecated

entry.name: wsrm_request_force_wsgateway_help_1317
entry.text:
WS-ReliableMessaging is deprecated. Specifies whether to require the use of WS-ReliableMessaging (inclusion of Sequence SOAP header) for all SOAP request messages from the client that request rules process. If on, the failure to include a Sequence header will result in a SOAP fault.
on Requires WS-ReliableMessaging for all requests. off WS-ReliableMessaging is optional for requests.

entry.name: wsrm_request_force_wsgateway_descr_1317
entry.text: Specifies requiring WS-ReliableMessaging on requests - Deprecated

entry.name: wsrm_response_force_wsgateway_help_1318
entry.text:
WS-ReliableMessaging is deprecated. Specifies whether to require the use of WS-ReliableMessaging (inclusion of Sequence SOAP header) for all SOAP response messages from the server that response rules process. The failure to include the Sequence header will cause the transaction to fail.
on Requires WS-ReliableMessaging for all responses. off WS-ReliableMessaging is optional for responses.

entry.name: wsrm_response_force_wsgateway_descr_1318
entry.text: Specifies requiring WS-ReliableMessaging on responses - Deprecated

entry.name: wsrm_sequence_expiration_wsgateway_help_1319
entry.text:
WS-ReliableMessaging is deprecated. Sets the target expiration lifetime in seconds for all Reliable Messaging sequences, both RM Sources and RM Destinations. A sequence (RM Source or RM Destination) will be destroyed this many seconds after creation if not previously closed or terminated by protocol activity. This is the Expires time that will be included in all CreateSequence requests. When an incoming CreateSequence is processed, if there is no expiration, or it is longer than this, this is the value that will be placed in the response.
lifetime The expiration lifetime in seconds. The default is 3600.

entry.name: wsrm_sequence_expiration_wsgateway_descr_1319
entry.text: Specifies the target sequence lifetime - Deprecated

entry.name: wsrm_source_sequence_ssl_wsgateway_help_1320
entry.text:
WS-ReliableMessaging is deprecated. Enables having RM Sources use TLS session binding to protect sequence lifecycle messages. The UsesSequenceSSL WS-ReliableMessaging SOAP header will be included in outgoing CreateSequence requests, and all control and data messages will use the same TLS Session ID. Requires that TLS be configured for this DataPower service.
on Enables using TLS session binding. off Disables using TLS session binding.

entry.name: wsrm_source_sequence_ssl_wsgateway_descr_1320
entry.text: Specifies TLS session binding - Deprecated

entry.name: wsrm_source_back_acks_to_wsgateway_help_1321
entry.text:
WS-ReliableMessaging is deprecated. Selects the Protocol Handler to receive the asynchronous RM SequenceAcknowledgement SOAP responses from the server. The Front Side Protocol Handler must be associated with the same DataPower service where the corresponding RM sequence is occurring.
handler The name of an existing Protocol Handler object.

entry.name: wsrm_source_back_acks_to_wsgateway_descr_1321
entry.text: Specifies Protocol Handler for Acks from server - Deprecated

entry.name: wsrm_source_exponential_backoff_wsgateway_help_1322
entry.text:
WS-ReliableMessaging is deprecated. Enables using the exponential back off to increase the interval between retransmissions on unacknowledged control or data messages by RM Sources.
on Enables using the exponential back off off Disables using the exponential back off.

entry.name: wsrm_source_exponential_backoff_wsgateway_descr_1322
entry.text: Specifies exponential backoff of retransmissions - Deprecated

entry.name: wsrm_source_front_acks_to_wsgateway_help_1323
entry.text:
WS-ReliableMessaging is deprecated. Identifies the Protocol Handler to receive the asynchronous RM SequenceAcknowledgement SOAP responses from the client. The Front Side Protocol Handler must be associated with the same DataPower service where the corresponding RM sequence is occurring.
handler The name of an existing Protocol Handler object.

entry.name: wsrm_source_front_acks_to_wsgateway_descr_1323
entry.text: Specifies Protocol Handler for Acks from client - Deprecated

entry.name: wsrm_source_inactivity_close_interval_wsgateway_help_1324
entry.text:
WS-ReliableMessaging is deprecated. Specifies the duration in seconds that RM Sources wait for another message to be sent before closing the sequence by sending a CloseSequence or TerminateSequence SOAP message.
duration The length of time in seconds. Use any value of 10 - 360. The default is 360.

entry.name: wsrm_source_inactivity_close_interval_wsgateway_descr_1324
entry.text: Specifies how long a RM Source remains idle - Deprecated

entry.name: wsrm_source_make_offer_wsgateway_help_1325
entry.text:
WS-ReliableMessaging is deprecated. Specifies whether to include an Offer for two-way Reliable Messaging in CreateSequence SOAP requests that are made to the server as the result of request processing. This Offer allows creating a RM Destination for the response channel at the same time the RM Source for the request channel is created.
on Includes an Offer for two-way Reliable Messaging in CreateSequence to server. off Do not include Offer for two-way Reliable Messaging.

entry.name: wsrm_source_make_offer_wsgateway_descr_1325
entry.text: Specifies offers in CreateSequence requests to server - Deprecated

entry.name: wsrm_source_maximum_queue_length_wsgateway_help_1326
entry.text:
WS-ReliableMessaging is deprecated. Specifies the maximum number of messages a RM Source sequence will hold in the retransmit queue awaiting SequenceAcknowledgement from the peer RM Destination. If the queue gets longer, messages will be dropped.
numberOfMessages The number of messages. The default is 30.

entry.name: wsrm_source_maximum_queue_length_wsgateway_descr_1326
entry.text: Limits length of retransmit queue - Deprecated

entry.name: wsrm_source_maximum_sequences_wsgateway_help_1327
entry.text:
WS-ReliableMessaging is deprecated. Sets a limit on the maximum number of simultaneously active RM Source sequences on this DataPower server.
limit The number of sequences. The default is 400.

entry.name: wsrm_source_maximum_sequences_wsgateway_descr_1327
entry.text: Limits number of RM Source sequences - Deprecated

entry.name: wsrm_source_request_ack_count_wsgateway_help_1328
entry.text:
WS-ReliableMessaging is deprecated. Specifies the number of sequenced messages that the a RM Source sends before including the AckRequested SOAP header to request an acknowledgment. The AckRequested SOAP header is always included in retransmitted messages.
numberOfMessages The number of messages. The default is 1.

entry.name: wsrm_source_request_ack_count_wsgateway_descr_1328
entry.text: Specifies interval between acknowledgment requests - Deprecated

entry.name: wsrm_source_request_create_sequence_wsgateway_help_1329
entry.text:
WS-ReliableMessaging is deprecated. Enable the automatic use of WS-ReliableMessaging on requests to the back side server. Enabling this causes CreateSequence SOAP messages to be sent to create a RM Source in this service connected to a RM Destination on the server. If disabled, the only way such a RM Source code can be created would be by accepting an Offer when the server sends this service a CreateSequence SOAP message.
on Creates a RM Source for requests to the server. off Does not create a RM Source.

entry.name: wsrm_source_request_create_sequence_wsgateway_descr_1329
entry.text: Specifies automatic reliable transmission of requests to server - Deprecated

entry.name: wsrm_source_response_create_sequence_wsgateway_help_1330
entry.text:
WS-ReliableMessaging is deprecated. Enable the automatic use of WS-ReliableMessaging on responses to the front side client. Enabling this causes CreateSequence SOAP messages to be sent to create a RM Source in this service connected to a RM Destination on the client. If disabled, the only way such a RM Source code can be created would be by accepting an Offer when the client sends this service a CreateSequence SOAP message. Enabling this requires Web Services Addressing to be enabled on the front side of this service.
on Creates a RM Source for requests to the server. off Does not create a RM Source.

entry.name: wsrm_source_response_create_sequence_wsgateway_descr_1330
entry.text: Specifies automatic reliable transmission of responses to the client - Deprecated

entry.name: wsrm_source_retransmission_interval_wsgateway_help_1331
entry.text:
WS-ReliableMessaging is deprecated. Specifies how many seconds RM Source sequences wait after sending a sequenced message or a control message before retransmitting it. This is the initial timeout, if wsrm-source-exponential-backoff is enabled, the interval will increase each time there is a retransmission. The default is 10 seconds.
interval The time to wait in seconds.

entry.name: wsrm_source_retransmission_interval_wsgateway_descr_1331
entry.text: Specifies initial retransmission interval - Deprecated

entry.name: wsrm_source_retransmit_count_wsgateway_help_1332
entry.text:
WS-ReliableMessaging is deprecated. Specifies the number of times a RM Source retransmits a control or data message before declaring a failure.
count The number of times a source retransmits. The default is 4.

entry.name: wsrm_source_retransmit_count_wsgateway_descr_1332
entry.text: Specifies how many retransmissions before failure - Deprecated

entry.name: operation_conformance_wsgateway_help_1333
entry.text:
Defines the conformance policy to apply to a specific WSDL component level.
policy The name of an existing Conformance Policy. wsdlComponentType The type of the WSDL component to match. Use one of the following values: "" Disables all WSDL-based matching criteria. Disabling the matching criteria effectively creates a document-based Processing Policy. all (Default) Matches all inputs, which includes or excludes all WSDL component types (operation, port, service) to and from the match criteria. operation Matches when the identified operation is requested in the current transaction. Matches wsdl:binding/operation/@name when formatted as {bindingNamespace}name, or matches wsdl:service/wsdl:port when formatted as {serviceNamespace}port-name/operation-name. port Matches when the operation requested in the current transaction is included in the identified WSDL port. Matches wsdl:service/wsdl:port/@name when formatted as {serviceNamespace}port-name. service Matches when the operation requested in the current transaction is included in the identified WSDL service. Matches wsdl:service/@name when formatted as {serviceNamespace}name. subscription Matches an identified subscription key. wsdl Matches when the operation requested in the current transaction is defined in the identified WSDL file. wsdlComponentValue Identifies the value of the WSDL-defined component.The value to specify depends on the identified WSDL component type. all as WSDL component type If all, specify double quotation marks (""). This combination eliminates the WSDL component from consideration. operation as WSDL component type If operation, specifies the name of the WSDL operation. Use the wildcard character (*) to specify all operations. port as WSDL component type If port, specifies the name of the WSDL port. Use the wildcard character (*) to specify all ports. service as WSDL component type If service, specifies the name of the WSDL service. Use the wildcard character (*) to specify all services. subscription as WSDL component type If subscription, specify double quotation marks (""). Any specified value is ignored. wsdl as WSDL component type If wsdl, specifies either a URL or the "local name" mnemonic that is assigned to the WSDL file. subscription The name of an existing Subscription object.The property is meaningful only when the value of the component type is subscription.

entry.name: operation_conformance_wsgateway_descr_1333
entry.text: Defines the operational conformance policy

entry.name: operation_policy_opt_out_wsgateway_help_1334
entry.text:
Sets the WS-Policy subjects to ignore.
subjects Identifies which policy subjects should ignore any defined WS-Policy. Use any combination of the following keywords. To specify multiple keywords, enclose the entire selection in double quotation marks ("") characters and separate each keyword with the plus sign (+) character. Service Ignores the policy defined for the service policy subject. Endpoint Ignores the policy defined for the endpoint policy subject. Operation Ignores the policy defined for the operation policy subject. MessageIn Ignores the policy defined for the message policy subject for input messages. MessageOut Ignores the policy defined for the message policy subject for output messages. wsdlComponentType The type of the WSDL component to match. Use one of the following values: "" Disables all WSDL-based matching criteria. Disabling the matching criteria effectively creates a document-based Processing Policy. all (Default) Matches all inputs, which includes or excludes all WSDL component types (operation, port, service) to and from the match criteria. operation Matches when the identified operation is requested in the current transaction. Matches wsdl:binding/operation/@name when formatted as {bindingNamespace}name, or matches wsdl:service/wsdl:port when formatted as {serviceNamespace}port-name/operation-name. port Matches when the operation requested in the current transaction is included in the identified WSDL port. Matches wsdl:service/wsdl:port/@name when formatted as {serviceNamespace}port-name. service Matches when the operation requested in the current transaction is included in the identified WSDL service. Matches wsdl:service/@name when formatted as {serviceNamespace}name. subscription Matches an identified subscription key. wsdl Matches when the operation requested in the current transaction is defined in the identified WSDL file. wsdlComponentValue Identifies the value of the WSDL-defined component.The value to specify depends on the identified WSDL component type. all as WSDL component type If all, specify double quotation marks (""). This combination eliminates the WSDL component from consideration. operation as WSDL component type If operation, specifies the name of the WSDL operation. Use the wildcard character (*) to specify all operations. port as WSDL component type If port, specifies the name of the WSDL port. Use the wildcard character (*) to specify all ports. service as WSDL component type If service, specifies the name of the WSDL service. Use the wildcard character (*) to specify all services. subscription as WSDL component type If subscription, specify double quotation marks (""). Any specified value is ignored. wsdl as WSDL component type If wsdl, specifies either a URL or the "local name" mnemonic that is assigned to the WSDL file. subscription The name of an existing Subscription object.The property is meaningful only when the value of the component type is subscription.

entry.name: operation_policy_opt_out_wsgateway_descr_1334
entry.text: Specifies the WS-Policy subjects to ignore

entry.name: policy_parameters_wsgateway_help_1335
entry.text:
Defines a sets of WS-Policy parameters for use by attached policy.
parameterSet The name of an existing Policy Parameter object. wsdlComponentType The type of the WSDL component to match. Use one of the following values: "" Disables all WSDL-based matching criteria. Disabling the matching criteria effectively creates a document-based Processing Policy. all (Default) Matches all inputs, which includes or excludes all WSDL component types (operation, port, service) to and from the match criteria. operation Matches when the identified operation is requested in the current transaction. Matches wsdl:binding/operation/@name when formatted as {bindingNamespace}name, or matches wsdl:service/wsdl:port when formatted as {serviceNamespace}port-name/operation-name. port Matches when the operation requested in the current transaction is included in the identified WSDL port. Matches wsdl:service/wsdl:port/@name when formatted as {serviceNamespace}port-name. service Matches when the operation requested in the current transaction is included in the identified WSDL service. Matches wsdl:service/@name when formatted as {serviceNamespace}name. subscription Matches an identified subscription key. wsdl Matches when the operation requested in the current transaction is defined in the identified WSDL file. wsdlComponentValue Identifies the value of the WSDL-defined component.The value to specify depends on the identified WSDL component type. all as WSDL component type If all, specify double quotation marks (""). This combination eliminates the WSDL component from consideration. operation as WSDL component type If operation, specifies the name of the WSDL operation. Use the wildcard character (*) to specify all operations. port as WSDL component type If port, specifies the name of the WSDL port. Use the wildcard character (*) to specify all ports. service as WSDL component type If service, specifies the name of the WSDL service. Use the wildcard character (*) to specify all services. subscription as WSDL component type If subscription, specify double quotation marks (""). Any specified value is ignored. wsdl as WSDL component type If wsdl, specifies either a URL or the "local name" mnemonic that is assigned to the WSDL file. subscription The name of an existing Subscription object.The property is meaningful only when the value of the component type is subscription.

entry.name: policy_parameters_wsgateway_descr_1335
entry.text: Specifies a sets of WS-Policy parameters for use by attached policy

entry.name: reliable_messaging_wsgateway_help_1336
entry.text:
Controls reliable messaging properties.
options Identifies the options for reliable messaging. Use any combination of the following keywords. To specify multiple keywords, enclose the entire selection in double quotation marks ("") characters and separate each keyword with the plus sign (+) character. Optional Reliable Messaging is optional. SequenceTransportSecurity Reliable Messaging Sequence must be bound to underlying transport-level protocol. InOrder Reliable Messaging messages must be delivered in the same sequence as sent by the source. deliveryAssuranceType Identifies the assurance type. Use the following keyword: exactly-once Messages must be delivered exactly one time. wsdlComponentType The type of the WSDL component to match. Use one of the following values: "" Disables all WSDL-based matching criteria. Disabling the matching criteria effectively creates a document-based Processing Policy. all (Default) Matches all inputs, which includes or excludes all WSDL component types (operation, port, service) to and from the match criteria. operation Matches when the identified operation is requested in the current transaction. Matches wsdl:binding/operation/@name when formatted as {bindingNamespace}name, or matches wsdl:service/wsdl:port when formatted as {serviceNamespace}port-name/operation-name. port Matches when the operation requested in the current transaction is included in the identified WSDL port. Matches wsdl:service/wsdl:port/@name when formatted as {serviceNamespace}port-name. service Matches when the operation requested in the current transaction is included in the identified WSDL service. Matches wsdl:service/@name when formatted as {serviceNamespace}name. subscription Matches an identified subscription key. wsdl Matches when the operation requested in the current transaction is defined in the identified WSDL file. wsdlComponentValue Identifies the value of the WSDL-defined component.The value to specify depends on the identified WSDL component type. all as WSDL component type If all, specify double quotation marks (""). This combination eliminates the WSDL component from consideration. operation as WSDL component type If operation, specifies the name of the WSDL operation. Use the wildcard character (*) to specify all operations. port as WSDL component type If port, specifies the name of the WSDL port. Use the wildcard character (*) to specify all ports. service as WSDL component type If service, specifies the name of the WSDL service. Use the wildcard character (*) to specify all services. subscription as WSDL component type If subscription, specify double quotation marks (""). Any specified value is ignored. wsdl as WSDL component type If wsdl, specifies either a URL or the "local name" mnemonic that is assigned to the WSDL file. subscription The name of an existing Subscription object.The property is meaningful only when the value of the component type is subscription.

entry.name: reliable_messaging_wsgateway_descr_1336
entry.text: Controls reliable messaging properties

entry.name: remote_retry_wsgateway_help_1337
entry.text:
Enables or disables the recovery policy for failed network connections.
on Enables the recovery policy for failed network connections. retry-interval The number of seconds to wait after a failed connection attempt before performing another connection attempt. The minimum and default is 1. reporting-interval The number of seconds after a failed attempt to log a message at the error level instead of the default debug level. The minimum and default is 1. total-retries The total number of connection attempts to perform after the initial failed attempt. The minimum and default is 1. off Disables the recovery policy for failed network connections.

entry.name: remote_retry_wsgateway_descr_1337
entry.text: Specifies the recovery policy for failed network connections

entry.name: root_part_not_first_action_wsgateway_help_1338
entry.text:
Defines the action to take when the MIME message root part is not first.
abort Stops the transaction and return an error. buffer Buffers attachments before the root part into memory. Then processes the root part, buffered attachments, and subsequent attachments. process-in-order (Default) Processes the attachments and root part in the order that they appear in the original message. All parts are still processed in streaming mode even though only attachments after the root will be streamed from the network. This command is meaningful only when the value of either the request-attachments or response-attachments command is streaming.

entry.name: root_part_not_first_action_wsgateway_descr_1338
entry.text: Defines the action when the MIME message root part is not first

entry.name: wsrr_subscription_wsgateway_help_1339
entry.text: The Web Service Proxy will load and proxy services that are obtained through the specified subscription.

entry.name: wsrr_subscription_wsgateway_descr_1339
entry.text: Obtain web services through a WSRR subscription

entry.name: xml_manager_wsgateway_help_1340
entry.text:
Assigns an XML manager to the current Web Service Gateway. xmlManagerName The XML manager assigned to the gateway. For example:
xml-manager mgr-1 assigns XML manager mgr-1 to the gateway

entry.name: xml_manager_wsgateway_descr_1340
entry.text: Assigns an XML manager to the gateway

entry.name: wsa_back_protocol_wsgateway_help_1341
entry.text:
Relevant when the WS-Proxy is providing asynchronous service; that is when the Web Service Addressing message generation pattern, as specified by the wsa-genstyle command, is async. In these topologies, use the wsa-back-protocol command to specify the Protocol Handler that will receive the asynchronous response, and then forward the response to the original client.
Note the Protocol Handler specified by this command can be programmatically overridden by the
var://context/__WSA_REQUEST/replyto variable. frontSideProtocolHandler The name of the Protocol Handler that receives asynchronous server responses for transmission to the original client. For example:
wsa-back-protocol asyncHandler specifies the Protocol Handler that will receive asynchronous server responses.

entry.name: wsa_back_protocol_wsgateway_descr_1341
entry.text: Specifies a Protocol Handler

entry.name: wsa_default_faultto_wsgateway_help_1342
entry.text:
Relevant when the Web Service Proxy is providing service for Web Service Addressing client users; that is when the Web Service Addressing mode, as specified by the wsa-mode command, is wsa2sync or wsa2wsa. In these topologies, you can use the wsa-default-faultto command to ensure that all messages contain the optional Web Service Addressing FaultTo element that identifies the recipient endpoint of fault messages.
Because the Web Service Addressing specifications do not require the inclusion of the FaultTo element, the Web Service Proxy may receive Web Service Addressing messages that do not contain a FaultTo element, or that contain the element with no value. When this happens, the Web Service Proxy will modify the Web Service Addressing message to include a FaultTo element that contains the value specified by the faultURL argument. If a default recipient endpoint of fault messages is not explicitly identified by this command, the Proxy provides a default value of
http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2004/08/addressing/role/anonymous
faultURL is the value of the FaultTo element, a URL that The recipient endpoint to which fault messages are sent. For example:
wsa-default-faultto http://www.datapower.com/cs/internal/hdesk/
specifies the recipient of fault messages.

entry.name: wsa_default_faultto_wsgateway_descr_1342
entry.text: Forces the inclusion of a FaultTo header

entry.name: wsa_default_replyto_wsgateway_help_1343
entry.text:
Relevant when the Web Service Proxy is providing service for Web Service Addressing client users; that is when the Web Service Addressing mode, as specified by the wsa-mode command, is wsa2sync or wsa2wsa. In these topologies, you can use the wsa-default-replyto command to ensure that all messages contain the optional Web Service Addressing ReplyTo element that identifies the recipient endpoint of a response message.
Because the Web Service Addressing specifications do not require the inclusion of the ReplyTo element, the Web Service Proxy may receive Web Service Addressing messages that do not contain a ReplyTo element, or that contain the element with no value. When this happens, the Web Service Proxy will modify the Web Service Addressing message to include a ReplyTo element that contains the value specified by the replyURL argument. If a default recipient endpoint of response messages is not explicitly identified by this command, the Proxy provides a default value of
http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2004/08/addressing/role/anonymous
replyURL is a URL that identifies the recipient endpoint to which response messages are sent. For example:
wsa-default-replyto http://www.customer.com/PO/inventoryReq/
specifies the default message recipient.

entry.name: wsa_default_replyto_wsgateway_descr_1343
entry.text: Forces the inclusion of a ReplyTo header

entry.name: wsa_faultto_rewrite_wsgateway_help_1344
entry.text:
Relevant when the Web Service Proxy is providing service for Web Service Addressing client users; that is when the Web Service Addressing mode, as specified by the wsa-mode command, is wsa2sync or wsa2wsa. In these topologies, you can use the wsa-faultto-rewrite command to modify the contents of an incoming FaultTo element that identifies the recipient endpoint of fault messages.
urlRewritePolicy is the name of the URL Rewrite Policy used to modify the contents or the original FaultTo element. For example:
wsa-faultto-rewrite wsaErrorHandler
identifies wsaErrorHandler as the URL Rewrite Policy used modify the contents of the FaultTo element.

entry.name: wsa_faultto_rewrite_wsgateway_descr_1344
entry.text: Rewrites contents of the FaultTo element

entry.name: wsa_force_wsgateway_help_1345
entry.text:
Relevant when the Web Service Proxy is providing service for Web Service Addressing users; that is when the Web Service Addressing mode, as specified by the wsa-mode command, is wsa2wsa, wsa2sync, or sync2wsa. In these topologies, the Web Service Proxy generally handles a mix of Web Service addressed and traditionally addressed messages. You can use the wsa-force command to ensure that all messages use Web Service Addressing.
By default, wsa-force is disabled (off), meaning that the Proxy supports of mix of addressing styles. When enabled (on), the Proxy converts traditionally addressed messages to Web Service Addressing format through the addition of reply-to and fault-to Web Service Addressing headers to the traditionally addressed message. The reply-to header will contain the default value
http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2004/08/addressing/role/anonymous
The fault-to header will contain the default value
http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2004/08/addressing/role/anonymous
These default values can be overridden with the wsa-default-replyto and wsa-default-faultto CLI commands.
on | off are mutually exclusive keywords that enable (on) or disable (off) the addition of Web Service Addressing headers to a traditionally addressed incoming message. For example:
wsa-force on
changes the default state; adds Web Service Addressing headers to traditionally addressed messages.
wsa-force off
or
no wsa-force restores the default state; traditionally addressed message headers are untouched.

entry.name: wsa_force_wsgateway_descr_1345
entry.text: Forces the inclusion of WS addressing headers

entry.name: wsa_genstyle_wsgateway_help_1346
entry.text:
Specifies the request/response transmission model between the Web Service Proxy and the target server.
async, oob, and sync are mutually exclusive keywords that identify the transmission model.
async identifies an asynchronous exchange pattern in which the server response is received over a different channel than the one used by the proxy to convey the client request.
If the request/response transmission model is async, you must use the wsa-back-protocol command to identify the Protocol Handler that will convey asynchronous server responses to the original requesting clients.
For the async model, you can also use the wsa-timeout command to specify the maximum time to suspend a transaction while waiting for an asynchronous server response. oob identifies an out-of-band exchange pattern in which the routing of the response to the original client is handled by the target server and does not pass through the Proxy.
If the request/response transmission model is oob, you must ensure that explicit (non-anonymous) client-originated ReplyTo and FaultTo element values are preserved by the Proxy and passed intact to the server. sync (the default) identifies a synchronous exchange pattern in which the server response is received over the same channel used by the Proxy to convey the client request. For example:
wsa-genstyle oob
specifies an out-of-band request/response transmission model in which server responses to not pass through the Web Service Proxy.

entry.name: wsa_genstyle_wsgateway_descr_1346
entry.text: Specifies the request/response transmission model

entry.name: wsa_http_async_response_code_wsgateway_help_1347
entry.text:
If the server response to an HTTP client request is asynchronous, the Web Service Proxy must close the original HTTP channel with a valid response code. After the channel is closed, the Proxy forwards the server-generated response or fault message to the client over a new channel. In the absence of an explicit assignment, the Proxy provides a default value of 204.
responseCodeValue is an integer (within the range 200 through 599, with a default value of 204) that specifies the HTTP response code used to close the original client channel. For example:
wsa-http-response-code 210
specifies an HTTP Response Code of 210 is used to close an open HTTP client channel.

entry.name: wsa_http_async_response_code_wsgateway_descr_1347
entry.text: Specifies the HTTP response code sent to client

entry.name: wsa_mode_wsgateway_help_1348
entry.text:
Specifies the Web Service Addressing support provided by the DataPower service. The level of support is determined by the WS-Addressing capabilities of the associated client and server devices. Support for any particular level of WS-Addressing does not preclude simultaneous support for traditional addressing formats.
sync2sync Disables Web Service Addressing support. Both hosts (clients and servers) that access the DataPower service use traditional addressing. This setting is the default value.
sync2wsa Specifies that the DataPower service is mediating between hosts that employ traditional addressing and servers that support WS-Addressing. In sync2wsa mode, the DataPower service, under user control, can do the following actions.
Insert WS-Addressing headers into the traditionally addressed original client request. The default behavior is to retain the original addressing format.
Strip WS-Addressing headers from any server-generated response before the response is forwarded to the original client. The default behavior is to strip WS-Addressing headers.
Process synchronous or asynchronous sever responses of either the ReplyTo (a standard response to a client request) or FaultTo (reporting an error condition) variety.
A synchronous response is received over the same connection that carried the client request to the server.
An asynchronous response is received over a different connection that carried the client request to the server. The DataPower service must maintain state information that associates the received response with an outstanding request.
wsa2sync When operating in wsa2sync mode, the DataPower service, under user control, can do the following actions.
Insert WS-Addressing headers into the traditionally addressed original client request. The default behavior is to retain the original addressing format.
Strip WS-Addressing headers from any server-generated response before the response is forwarded to the original client. The default behavior is to strip WS-Addressing headers.
Rewrite the contents of, or supply default values for, client-generated ReplyTo and FaultTo elements to specify the destinations of these response types.
Rewrite the contents of the client-generated To element to specify where the client request is routed.
Process synchronous or asynchronous sever responses of either the ReplyTo (a standard response to a client request) or FaultTo (reporting an error condition) variety.
A synchronous response is received over the same connection that carried the client request to the server.
An asynchronous response is received over a different connection that carried the client request to the server. The DataPower service must maintain state information that associates the received response with an outstanding request.
wsa2wsa When operating in wsa2wsa mode, the DataPower service, under user control, can do the following actions.
Insert WS-Addressing headers into the traditionally addressed original client request. The default behavior is to retain the original addressing format.
Strip WS-Addressing headers from any server-generated response before the response is forwarded to the original client. The default behavior is to strip WS-Addressing headers.
Rewrite the contents of, or supply default values for, client-generated ReplyTo and FaultTo elements to specify the destinations of these response types.
Rewrite the contents of the client-generated To element to specify where the client request is routed.
Support three response modes for either the ReplyTo (a standard response to a client request) or FaultTo (reporting an error condition) variety.
A synchronous response is received over the same connection that carried the client request to the server.
An asynchronous response is received over a different connection that carried the client request to the server. The DataPower service must maintain state information that associates the received response with an outstanding request.
An out-of-band response is handled by the target server and does not pass through the DataPower service. An out-of-band response requires explicit (non-anonymous) client-originated ReplyTo and FaultTo element values that are preserved by the DataPower service and passed to the server.
For example:
wsa-mode sync2wsa
Specifies sync2wsa mode, which indicates that the DataPower service is mediating between hosts that employ traditional addressing and servers that that support WS-Addressing.

entry.name: wsa_mode_wsgateway_descr_1348
entry.text: Specifies Web Service Addressing operational mode

entry.name: wsa_replyto_rewrite_wsgateway_help_1349
entry.text:
Relevant when the Web Service Proxy is providing service for Web Service Addressing client users; that is when the Web Service Addressing mode, as specified by the wsa-mode command, is wsa2sync or wsa2wsa. In these topologies, you can use the wsa-replyto-rewrite command to modify the contents of an incoming ReplyTo element that identifies the recipient endpoint of response messages.
urlRewritePolicy is the name of the URL Rewrite Policy used to modify the contents or the original ReplyTo element. For example:
wsa-replyto-rewrite wsaResponseHandler
identifies wsaResponseHandler as the URL Rewrite Policy used modify the contents of the ReplyTo element.

entry.name: wsa_replyto_rewrite_wsgateway_descr_1349
entry.text: Rewrites contents of the ReplyTo element

entry.name: wsa_require_aaa_wsgateway_help_1350
entry.text:
When enabled (the default state), mandates the use of a AAA policy before establishing new channels required for message processing.
on requires AAA Policy usage. off AAA Policy usage is optional. For example:
wsa-require-aaa off or no wsa-require-aaa change the default state, making the execution of an AAA Policy prior to establishing a new channel optional.
wsa-require-aaa on restores the default state.

entry.name: wsa_require_aaa_wsgateway_descr_1350
entry.text: Mandate AAA Policy usage

entry.name: wsa_strip_headers_wsgateway_help_1351
entry.text:
Relevant when the Web Service Proxy is positioned between a user of Web Service Addressing and a non-user; that is when the Web Service Addressing mode, as specified by the wsa-mode command, is wsa2sync or sync2wsa.
By default, wsa-strip-headers is on.
on | off are mutually exclusive keywords that enable (on) or disable (off) the deletion of Web Service Addressing headers from an incoming message. For example:
wsa-strip-headers off
or
no wsa-strip-headers changes the default state; retains all Web Service Addressing headers contained in incoming messages.
wsa-strip-headers on
or
wsa-strip-headers restores the default state; deletes all Web Service Addressing headers contained in incoming messages.

entry.name: wsa_strip_headers_wsgateway_descr_1351
entry.text: Includes or excludes WS addressing headers

entry.name: wsa_to_rewrite_wsgateway_help_1352
entry.text:
Relevant when the Web Service Proxy is providing service for Web Service Addressing client users; that is when the Web Service Addressing mode, as specified by the wsa-mode command, is wsa2sync or wsa2wsa. In these topologies, you can use the wsa-to-rewrite command to modify the contents of an incoming To element that identifies the message destination.
urlRewritePolicy is the name of the URL Rewrite Policy used to modify the contents or the original To element. For example:
wsa-to-rewrite wsaRoute2Handler
identifies wsaRoute2Handler as the URL Rewrite Policy used modify the contents of the To element.

entry.name: wsa_to_rewrite_wsgateway_descr_1352
entry.text: Rewrites contents of the ReplyTo element

entry.name: wsa_timeout_wsgateway_help_1353
entry.text:
specifies the maximum period of time to wait for an asynchronous response, before abandoning the transaction. timerValue Specifies the maximum wait period in seconds. Enter a value in the range 1 - 4000000. The default value is 120. Note that the timer value specified by this command can be programmatically overridden by the var://service/wsa/timeout variable.
For example:
no wsa-timeout 60 Specifies a maximum pause of 1 minute while waiting for an asynchronous response.

entry.name: wsa_timeout_wsgateway_descr_1353
entry.text: Specifies the asynchronous timeout value

entry.name: backend_rule_wsendpointrewritepolicy_help_1354
entry.text:
A Remote Endpoint specifies the location to which requests are sent by a WS Proxy after processing the request. This is the back end, or application endpoint, of the transaction. It is possible to direct traffic to an endpoint other than that specified in the underlying WSDL by rewriting the endpoint.
Note: All arguments to this command must be specified in the documented order.
servicePortMatch is a Perl-style regular expression to specify web services port to rewrite endpoint for. There is no default value for this argument.
remoteEndpointProtocol is the part of the URL from web service binding that specifies the protocol. This defaults to the protocol found in the WSDL file. The remoteEndpointProtocol takes one of the following values:
default http https dpmq mq dptibems tibems dpwasjms
remoteEndpointHostname is the part of the URL from web service binding that specifies the host name or IP address. If not specified, the value from the WSDL will be used. If the protocol is dpmq, dptibems, or dpwasjms, use two double quotation mark ("") characters without any intervening space.
remoteEndpointPort is the part of the URL from web service binding that specifies the port. A value of 0 will use the port specified in the WSDL. The default value is 0. If the protocol is dpmq, dptibems, or dpwasjms, use two double quotation mark characters enclosing a zero character ("0").
remoteEndpointURI is the part of the URL from web service binding that specifies the remote path. If no string is configured, the value from the WSDL will be used.
MQQM is the URL portion of the rewritten web service binding that specifies the IBM MQ Queue Manager. Required when the protocol is dpmq.
TIBCO is the URL portion of the rewritten web service binding that specifies the TIBCO EMS object. Required when the protocol is dptibems.
WASJMS is the URL portion of the rewritten web service binding that specifies the WebSphere JMS object. Required when the protocol is dpwasjms.
For example:
wsm-endpointrewrite someBanking backend-rule "{http://somebank.com}SomeBankPort" "http" "10.10.13.35" "2068" "/SomeBankService/services/SomeBankPort" creates an Endpoint Rewrite Policy named someBanking, moves to WS-Proxy Endpoint Rewrite Policy Configuration Mode, and defines a remote endpoint rewrite rule with the following properties:
- A Perl-style regular expression of {http://somebank.com}SomeBankPort to match the web service port
- A protocol of http
- An IP address for the remote endpoint of 10.10.13.35
- A port of 2068
- A local path of /SomeBankService/services/SomeBankPort

entry.name: backend_rule_wsendpointrewritepolicy_descr_1354
entry.text: Adds, edits, or deletes a remote endpoint rewrite rule.

entry.name: listener_rule_wsendpointrewritepolicy_help_1355
entry.text:
The Local Endpoint defines the IP address, TCP port and URI offered by the Proxy to clients making a request for service as described in the published WSDL. The Proxy listens for requests at the Local Endpoint URL.
Note: All arguments to this command must be specified in the documented order.
servicePortMatch is a Perl-style regular expression to specify web services port to rewrite endpoint for.
localEndpointProtocol is the part of the URL from web service binding that specifies the protocol.This argument is relevant when useFrontProtocol is off. This argument is ignored when useFrontProtocol is on. The default is default.
localEndpointHostname is the part of the URL from web service binding that specifies the host name or IP address.This argument is relevant when useFrontProtocol is off. This argument is ignored when useFrontProtocol is on. The default is 0.0.0.0.
localEndpointPort is the part of the URL from web service binding that specifies the port. A value of 0 will use the port specified in the WSDL. This argument is relevant when useFrontProtocol is off. This argument is ignored when useFrontProtocol is on. The default is 0.
localEndpointURI is the part of the URL from web service binding that specifies the local path. If no string is configured, the value from the WSDL will be used.
frontProtocol is the protocol handler that is used for matching web service ports.This argument is relevant when useFrontProtocol is on. This argument is ignored when useFrontProtocol is off.
useFrontProtocol is a keyword (on or off) that indicates whether the protocol handler determines the protocol, interface, and port of the local address for any matched WSDL service port. Specifying on overrides the values specified for localEndpointProtocol, localEndpointHostname, and localEndpointPort in this rewrite rule. The default is off.
wsdlBindingProtocol takes one of the following values:
default (the default) uses the binding protocol that the WSDL specifies.
soap-11 uses the SOAP 1.1 binding for WSDL 1.1 http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/wsdl/soap/
soap-12 uses the SOAP 1.2 binding for WSDL 1.1 http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/wsdl/soap12/
http-get uses the HTTP binding for WSDL 1.1 using the GET verb http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/wsdl/http/
wsdlPortNameSuffix Specify the a suffix to add to the name of the WSDL port that will be used to represent this service endpoint in the rewritten Web service. If empty, rewrite the original port. The original port can only be rewritten once.
For example:
wsm-endpointrewrite testing listener-rule ".*" "default" "0.0.0.0" "0" "/search/beta2" "Searcher" "on" creates an Endpoint Rewrite Policy named testing, moves to WS-Proxy Endpoint Rewrite Policy Configuration Mode, and defines a local endpoint rewrite rule with the following properties:
- A Perl-style regular expression of .* to match the web service port.
- Use the handler Searcher for matching web service ports.
- Because the handler Searcher is used and is in use, the properties for the default protocol, the 0.0.0.0 IP address, and the 0 port are ignored (useFrontProtocol is on).

entry.name: listener_rule_wsendpointrewritepolicy_descr_1355
entry.text: Adds, edits, or deletes a local endpoint rewrite rule.

entry.name: publisher_rule_wsendpointrewritepolicy_help_1356
entry.text:
This rule rewrites the endpoint published to UDDI registries (deprecated) or included in the WSDL supplied by the Proxy in response to a request for a WSDL describing the services offered by the Proxy.
All of the arguments for the publisher-rule command must be specified in the documented order.
servicePortMatch is a Perl-style regular expression to specify web services port to rewrite endpoint for.
publishedEndpointProtocol is the part of the URL from web service binding that specifies the protocol.
publishedEndpointHostname is the part of the URL from web service binding that specifies the host name or IP address.
publishedEndpointPort is the part of the URL from web service binding that specifies the port. A value of 0 will use the port specified in the WSDL. The default is 0.
publishedEndpointURI is the part of the URL from web service binding that specifies the local path. If no string is configured, the value from the WSDL will be used.
For example:
wsm-endpointrewrite someBanking publisher-rule "{http://somebank.com}SomeBankPort" "http" "10.10.13.35" "2068" "/SomeBankService/services/SomeBankPort" creates an Endpoint Rewrite Policy named someBanking, moves to WS-Proxy Endpoint Rewrite Policy Configuration Mode, and defines a publish endpoint rewrite rule with the following properties:
- A Perl-style regular expression of {http://somebank.com}SomeBankPort to match the web service port.
- A protocol of http. - An IP address for the remote endpoint of 10.10.13.35. - A port of 2068. - A local path of /SomeBankService/services/SomeBankPort.

entry.name: publisher_rule_wsendpointrewritepolicy_descr_1356
entry.text: Adds, edits, or deletes a publish endpoint rewrite rule

entry.name: subscription_backend_rule_wsendpointrewritepolicy_help_1357
entry.text:
Subscription Remote Rewrite rules determine the destination to which the Proxy forwards requests. By default, the Proxy uses the remote endpoints defined in the underlying WSDL files. By rewriting these endpoint definitions, it is possible to route requests to another application server without changing the underlying WSDL file.
Note: All arguments to this command must be specified in the documented order.
uddiSubscription Specifies the name of an existing UDDI Subscription to match against a subscription that is in use by the Proxy that is employing this rewrite rule.
remoteEndpointProtocol Specify the part of the URL from the web service binding that specifies the protocol. The remoteEndpointProtocol takes one of the following values:
default http https dpmq mq dptibems tibems dpwasjms
remoteEndpointHostname Specifies the part of the URL from web service binding that specifies the host name or IP address. If not specified, the value from the WSDL will be used. If the protocol is dpmq, dptibems, or dpwasjms, use two double quotation mark ("") characters without any intervening space.
remoteEndpointPort Specifies the part of the URL from web service binding that specifies the port. A value of 0 will use the port specified in the WSDL. The default value is 0. If the protocol is dpmq, dptibems, or dpwasjms, use two double quotation mark characters enclosing a zero character ("0").
remoteEndpointURI Specifies the part of the URL from the web service binding that specifies remote path. If no string is configured, the value from the WSDL will be used.
MQQM is the URL portion of the rewritten web service binding that specifies the IBM MQ Queue Manager. Required when the protocol is dpmq.
TIBCO is the URL portion of the rewritten web service binding that specifies the TIBCO EMS object. Required when the protocol is dptibems.
WASJMS is the URL portion of the rewritten web service binding that specifies the WebSphere JMS object. Required when the protocol is dpwasjms.
For example:
wsm-endpointrewrite someBanking subscription-backend-rule "uddiSubscriber-SomeBankPort" "http" "10.10.13.35" "2068" "/SomeBankService/services/SomeBankPort" creates an Endpoint Rewrite Policy named someBanking, moves to WS-Proxy Endpoint Rewrite Policy Configuration Mode, and defines a remote, subscription-based endpoint rewrite rule with the following properties: - The uddiSubscriber-SomeBankPort UDDI subscriber to match - A protocol of http - An IP address for the remote endpoint of 10.10.13.35 - A port of 2068 - A local path of /SomeBankService/services/SomeBankPort

entry.name: subscription_backend_rule_wsendpointrewritepolicy_descr_1357
entry.text: Adds, edits, or deletes a subscription remote rewrite rule

entry.name: subscription_listener_rule_wsendpointrewritepolicy_help_1358
entry.text:
Subscription Local Rewrite rules determine the address, port, and URI that are used by clients to request services through a Proxy instead of directly from the application endpoint that is defined in the Subscription.
Note: All arguments to this command must be specified in the documented order.
uddiSubscription Specifies the name of an existing UDDI Subscription to match against a subscription that is in use by the Proxy that is employing this rewrite rule.
localEndpointProtocol is the part of the URL from web service binding that specifies the protocol.This argument is relevant when useFrontProtocol is off. This argument is ignored when useFrontProtocol is on. The default is default.
localEndpointHostname is the part of the URL from web service binding that specifies the host name or IP address.This argument is relevant when useFrontProtocol is off. This argument is ignored when useFrontProtocol is on. The default is 0.0.0.0.
localEndpointPort is the part of the URL from web service binding that specifies the port. A value of 0 will use the port specified in the WSDL. This argument is relevant when useFrontProtocol is off. This argument is ignored when useFrontProtocol is on. The default is 0.
localEndpointURI is the part of the URL from web service binding that specifies the local path. If no string is configured, the value from the WSDL will be used.
frontProtocol is the protocol handler that is used for matching web service ports.This argument is relevant when useFrontProtocol is on. This argument is ignored when useFrontProtocol is off.
useFrontProtocol is a keyword (on or off) that indicates whether the protocol handler determines the protocol, interface, and port of the local address for any matched WSDL service port. Specifying on overrides the values specified for localEndpointProtocol, localEndpointHostname, and localEndpointPort in this rewrite rule. The default is off.
wsdlBindingProtocol takes one of the following values:
default (the default) uses the binding protocol that the WSDL specifies.
soap-11 uses the SOAP 1.1 binding for WSDL 1.1 http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/wsdl/soap/
soap-12 uses the SOAP 1.2 binding for WSDL 1.1 http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/wsdl/soap12/
http-get uses the HTTP binding for WSDL 1.1 using the GET verb http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/wsdl/http/
wsdlPortNameSuffix Specify the a suffix to add to the name of the WSDL port that will be used to represent this service endpoint in the rewritten Web service. If empty, rewrite the original port. The original port can only be rewritten once.
For example:
