wsm-endpointrewrite testing subscription-listener-rule "uddiSubscriber-SomeBankPort" "default" "0.0.0.0" "0" "/search/beta2" "Searcher" "on" creates an Endpoint Rewrite Policy named testing, moves to WS-Proxy Endpoint Rewrite Policy Configuration Mode, and defines a local subscriber rewrite rule with the following properties: - The uddiSubscriber-SomeBankPort UDDI subscriber to match - Use the handler Searcher for matching UDDI subscribers. - Because the handler Searcher is used and is in use, the properties for the default protocol, the 0.0.0.0 IP address, and the 0 port are ignored (useFrontProtocol is on).

entry.name: subscription_listener_rule_wsendpointrewritepolicy_descr_1358
entry.text: Adds, edits, or deletes a subscription local rewrite rule

entry.name: subscription_publisher_rule_wsendpointrewritepolicy_help_1359
entry.text:
Subscription Publish Rewrite rules rewrite the endpoint definitions that are published to UDDI directories. If a publish rule does not match an endpoint, the rewritten local endpoint is used. If no Local Endpoint Rewrite rule matches, the values in the original WSDL file are used.
All of the arguments for the publisher-rule command must be specified in the documented order.
uddiSubscription Specifies the name of an existing UDDI Subscription to match against a subscription that is in use by the Proxy that is employing this rewrite rule.
publishedEndpointProtocol is the part of the URL from web service binding that specifies the protocol.
publishedEndpointHostname is the part of the URL from web service binding that specifies the host name or IP address.
publishedEndpointPort is the part of the URL from web service binding that specifies the port. A value of 0 will use the port specified in the WSDL. The default is 0.
publishedEndpointURI is the part of the URL from web service binding that specifies the local path. If no string is configured, the value from the WSDL will be used.
For example:
wsm-endpointrewrite someBanking subscription-publisher-rule "uddiSubscriber-SomeBankPort" "http" "10.10.13.35" "2068" "/SomeBankService/services/SomeBankPort" creates an Endpoint Rewrite Policy named someBanking, moves to WS-Proxy Endpoint Rewrite Policy Configuration Mode, and defines a publish subscriber rewrite rule with the following properties: - The uddiSubscriber-SomeBankPort UDDI subscriber to match - A protocol of http. - An IP address for the remote endpoint of 10.10.13.35 - A port of 2068 - A local path of /SomeBankService/services/SomeBankPort.

entry.name: subscription_publisher_rule_wsendpointrewritepolicy_descr_1359
entry.text: Adds, edits, or deletes a subscription publish rewrite rule.

entry.name: buffer_mode_webservicesagent_help_1360
entry.text: Deprecated command, has no effect.

entry.name: buffer_mode_webservicesagent_descr_1360
entry.text: Deprecated command

entry.name: capture_mode_webservicesagent_help_1361
entry.text:
Capture mode identifies messages that are captured and forwarded to a Web Services Manager for further analysis.
By default, no messages are captured.
Full message capture incurs a performance penalty, so keep this in mind while performing load testing of the managed service.
Not all Web Service Management protocols accommodate full message capture, so it should only be configured if the spooler is capable of forwarding full messages.
all-messages | faults | none are mutually exclusive keywords that specify the capture strategy as previously described. The faults keyword is deprecated. For example:
wsm-agent capture-mode none enters Web Services Management Agent Configuration Mode and specifies that no messages are captured.

entry.name: capture_mode_webservicesagent_descr_1361
entry.text: Identifies messages to capture and forward.

entry.name: max_memory_webservicesagent_help_1362
entry.text:
Specifies the maximum size of the buffer when there are no registered consumers of transaction events.
If buffer mode is set to "discard", transaction information for the current domain is discarded.
If buffer mode is set to "buffer", transaction information for the current domain is held in the expectation that a manager will connect. Buffering reduces the loss of transaction accounting information, but at the cost of more memory consumed.
Records are accumulated until the configured size limits (max-records and max-memory) are reached. After maximum configured values are reached, new records will be dropped.
maxKBytes is an integer that specifies the maximum buffer usage in kilobytes.
For example:
wsm-agent max-memory 128 enters Web Services Management Agent Configuration Mode and specifies maximum buffer usage of 128 kilobytes.

entry.name: max_memory_webservicesagent_descr_1362
entry.text: Specifies the maximum buffer usage in kilobytes.

entry.name: max_records_webservicesagent_help_1363
entry.text:
Specifies the maximum number of buffered transactions when there are no registered consumers of transaction events.
If buffer mode is set to "discard", transaction information for the current domain is discarded.
If buffer mode is set to "buffer", transaction information for the current domain is held in the expectation that a manager will connect. Buffering reduces the loss of transaction accounting information, but at the cost of more memory consumed.
Records are accumulated until the configured size limits (max-records and max-memory) are reached. After maximum configured values are reached, new records will be dropped.
maxRecordsCount is an integer that specifies the maximum number of buffered transactions.
For example:
wsm-agent max-records 3500 enters Web Services Management Agent Configuration Mode and enables a maximum count of 3500 buffered transactions.

entry.name: max_records_webservicesagent_descr_1363
entry.text: Specifies the maximum number of buffered transactions.

entry.name: mediation_enforcement_metrics_webservicesagent_help_1364
entry.text:
Enables the collection of Mediation Enforcement Policy metrics. No collection of metrics is the default. For example:
mediation-enforcement-metrics on enable collection of Mediation Enforcement Policy metrics. mediation-enforcement-metrics off disable collection of Mediation Enforcement Policy metrics.

entry.name: mediation_enforcement_metrics_webservicesagent_descr_1364
entry.text: Enables the collection of Mediation Enforcement Policy metrics.

entry.name: endpoint_name_webservicemonitor_help_1365
entry.text:
Specifies the WSDL-defined endpoint that is monitored by the current Web Services Monitor. Use the endpoint name exactly as it is defined in the WSDL file.
wsdlEndpoint identifies the target WSDL endpoint.
For example:
endpoint-name GoogleSearchService specifies GoogleSearchService as the endpoint name.

entry.name: endpoint_name_webservicemonitor_descr_1365
entry.text: Specifies the endpoint that is monitored.

entry.name: endpoint_url_webservicemonitor_help_1366
entry.text:
Specifies the URL of the WSDL endpoint that is monitored by the current Web Services Monitor. Use the URL exactly as it is defined in the WSDL file.
wsdlURL identifies the URL of the target endpoint.
For example:
endpoint-url http://api.google.com/search/beta2/ specifies the endpoint URL.

entry.name: endpoint_url_webservicemonitor_descr_1366
entry.text: Specifies the URL of the endpoint that is monitored.

entry.name: frontend_url_webservicemonitor_help_1367
entry.text:
Specifies the URL used by the client to access the WSDL endpoint that is monitored by the current Web Services Monitor. This URL may or may not be identical to the one that was specified by the endpoint-url command.
clientOriginatedURL The URL sent by the client to access the monitored endpoint. You can use wildcard characters when defining a client URL.
For example:
frontend-url http://api.google.com/search/beta2/ Specifies the front end URL.

entry.name: frontend_url_webservicemonitor_descr_1367
entry.text: Specifies the URL that the client uses to access the endpoint.

entry.name: operation_webservicemonitor_help_1368
entry.text:
Specifies the administrative operations of the current Web Services Monitor.
operationType specifies the operations that are monitored. Currently, the only keyword that is supported is "all". This keyword indicates that all WSDL-defined operations are monitored.
monitorTarget specifies whether the current Web Services Monitor monitors errors or transactions, and takes one of the following values: front Monitors front end errors.
rate Monitors the transaction rate.
thresholdLevel specifies the threshold level, and takes on of the following values: low high
There are two threshold levels available, low and high For example, as transaction rates rise, the low limit might be reached at 30 transactions per second. At this point, some action (for example, logging) might be taken. The high limit might be reached at 50 transactions per second. At this point, some (potentially different) action, such as throttling, might be taken.
thresholdValue is an integer that specifies the point, expressed in instances per second, at which the associated trigger (first limit or second limit) is fired.
action specifies the administrative response to the trigger, and takes one of the following values: log Generates a log message.
throttle Queues out-of-limits traffic.
For example:
operation all rate low 30 log operation all rate high 50 throttle specifies monitor operation, generate log entries in response to more that 30 transactions per second; throttle excessive transactions (more that 50 transactions per second.

entry.name: operation_webservicemonitor_descr_1368
entry.text: Specifies the administrative operation.

entry.name: transport_webservicemonitor_help_1369
entry.text:
Specifies the transport type used by the monitored endpoint.
transportType identifies the transport type, and takes one of the following values: - HTTP-GET - HTTP-SOAP - SOAP-document - SOAP-RPC
For example:
transport HTTP-SOAP specifies the transport as HTTP over SOAP.

entry.name: transport_webservicemonitor_descr_1369
entry.text: Specifies the transport type.

entry.name: wsdl_webservicemonitor_help_1370
entry.text:
Specifies the location of the WSDL file that defines the endpoints, transport type, and operations watched by this monitor. The WSDL file can reside on the local system or elsewhere on the network.
wsdlURL specifies the location of the target WSDL file.
For example:
wsdl local:///checkQuery.wsdl locates the target WSDL file.

entry.name: wsdl_webservicemonitor_descr_1370
entry.text: Specifies the location of the WSDL file.

entry.name: filter_wsstylepolicy_help_1371
entry.text:
Identifies a default stylesheet used by the current Web Services Processing Policy for document filtering. The assigned default stylesheet performs XML filtering only if a candidate XML document fails to match any of the filter rules defined within the Web Services Processing Policy.
filterURL specifies the location of the default filtering stylesheet.
For example:
filter store:///validate.xsl identifies validate.xsl as the default filtering stylesheet

entry.name: filter_wsstylepolicy_descr_1371
entry.text: Identifies the default stylesheet for filtering.

entry.name: match_wsstylepolicy_help_1372
entry.text:
Associates a named transformation or filtering rule with a matching rule and adds the rule-template pair to the current Style Policy.
Use the "no" form of this command to reset a Web Services Processing Policy, that is clear all rules from the policy.
matchingRule is the name of a matching rule that was previously created with the matching command and populated with the httpmatch or urlmatch command that serves as a source of URL or HTTP templates. Candidate documents that match any of the templates that are contained in the rule might be processed in accordance with the associated transformation or filtering rule.
globalRule is the name of a transformation or filtering rule that was previously created with the rule command. This rule defines the processing procedures for documents that perform both of the following:
- Match any of the expressions that are contained in the associated matching rule
- Match the direction of the rule. A "request-rule" applies only to client-originated documents. A "response-rule" applies only to server-originated documents. While a "bi-directional" rule applies to all documents regardless of source.
For example:
match star valClientServer adds the associated matching rule and global rule to the current Web Services Processing Policy.
no match remove all rules from the current Web Services Processing Policy.

entry.name: match_wsstylepolicy_descr_1372
entry.text: Associates a transformation or filtering rule with a matching rule.

entry.name: xsldefault_wsstylepolicy_help_1373
entry.text:
Identifies a default style sheet used by the current Web Services Processing Policy for document transformation. The assigned default style sheet performs XML transforms only if a candidate XML document fails to match any of the transformation rules that are defined in the Web Services Processing Policy.
transformURL specifies the location of the default transformation style sheet.
For example:
xsldefault store:///validate.xsl identifies validate.xsl as the default transformation style sheet

entry.name: xsldefault_wsstylepolicy_descr_1373
entry.text: Identifies a default style sheet for transformation.

entry.name: aaa_wsstylepolicyrule_help_1374
entry.text:
Adds an aaa action (implementing an AAA Policy) to the current Web Services Processing Rule.
inputContext identifies the context that contains the document authenticated or authorized by the AAA policy implemented by this rule. Use "INPUT" to specify the initial policy input, that is the original client request or server response.
aaaPolicy is the name of an AAA Policy.
outputContext optionally identifies the context where any post-processing output is stored. Use "OUTPUT" to specify the final policy output, that is the transformed client request or transformed server response.
For example:
aaa INPUT AAA-Policy1 applies the AAA-Policy1 AAA Policy to the original input to the Web Services Processing Rule.

entry.name: aaa_wsstylepolicyrule_descr_1374
entry.text: Adds an aaa action.

entry.name: action_wsstylepolicyrule_help_1375
entry.text:
Adds a named action to the current Web Services Processing Rule.
Use the "no" form of the command to delete a named action or to delete all actions from the current Web Services Processing Rule. To delete all action, do not specify an action.
actionName identifies the action to be added to or to be removed from the current Web Services Processing Rule.
For example:
action checkError applies the checkError action to the current processing rule.
no action checkError deletes the checkError action from the current processing rule.
no action deletes all actions from the current processing rule.

entry.name: action_wsstylepolicyrule_descr_1375
entry.text: Adds an action.

entry.name: call_wsstylepolicyrule_help_1376
entry.text:
Adds a call action to the current Web Services Processing Rule. A call action invokes another named rule.
inputContext identifies the context that contains in which the specified rule is called. Use "INPUT" to specify the initial policy input, that is the original client request or server response.
rule is the name of the rule to be invoked.
outputContext identifies the context where any results are stores. Use "OUTPUT" to specify the final policy output, that is the transformed client request or transformed server response.
For example:
call temp1 processRequest temp2 applies the processRequest call rule to the document in the temp1 context and moves the results of the rule to the temp2 context.

entry.name: call_wsstylepolicyrule_descr_1376
entry.text: Adds a call action.

entry.name: checkpoint_wsstylepolicyrule_help_1377
entry.text:
Applies a checkpoint action to the current Web Services Processing Rule.
checkpointEvent identifies the event that triggers the checkpoint, and takes one of the following keywords:
AuthComplete Signifies the completion of the authentication process.
Fault Signifies a fault condition.
Request Signifies the input of a client-originated document.
Response Signifies the input of a server-originated document. inputContext optionally identifies the context in which the checkpoint is triggered. In the absence of an explicit context assignment, the "INPUT" context is used by default.
For example:
checkpoint fault temp1 adds a checkpoint that is triggered by a fault condition in the temp1 context.

entry.name: checkpoint_wsstylepolicyrule_descr_1377
entry.text: Adds a checkpoint action.

entry.name: convert_http_wsstylepolicyrule_help_1378
entry.text:
Defines an XML conversion rule, which is a rule that converts non-XML input (for example, an HTTP GET or POST or an HTML form) into XML, and adds the conversion rule to a processing policy.
inputContext identifies the context that contains the non-XML source. Use "INPUT" to specify the initial policy input, which is either the original client request or the original server response.
outputContext identifies an output context where the converted document is stored. Use "OUTPUT" to specify the final policy output, which is the transformed client request or the transformed server response.
httpInputConvertMap optionally identifies an input conversion map that specifies the document encoding. In the absence of a map designation, all input is treated as URL-escaped.
For example:
convert-http INPUT tempParams ICM-normal converts the original input to the rule to XML and puts the XML content in the tempParams context. The ICM-normal input conversion map specifies the encoding of the non-XML input.

entry.name: convert_http_wsstylepolicyrule_descr_1378
entry.text: Adds a convert-http action.

entry.name: extract_wsstylepolicyrule_help_1379
entry.text:
Adds an extract action to the current Web Services Process Rule. An extract action applies an XPath expression to a context and stores the result in another context.
inputContext identifies the context to which the XPath expression is applied. Use "INPUT" to specify the initial policy input, that is the original client request or server response.
outputContext identifies the context that stores the result of the XPath expression. Use "OUTPUT" to specify the final policy output, that is the transformed client request or transformed server response.
xpathExp specifies the XPath expression that is applied. This argument can be expressed in standard XPath format or as a var:// URL that expands to an XPath expression.
variable optionally specifies a variable, within the output context, in which to store the result of the XPath expression. In the absence this argument, the results of the XPath expression are stored as the default contents (tree) of the destination context.
For example:
extract INPUT three //games/url applies the //games/url XPath expression to the INPUT context and stores the result in the three context.
extract INPUT three //games/url var://local/url applies the //games/url XPath expression to the INPUT context and stores the result in the url variable within the three context.
extract INPUT three var://local/xpath var://local/url applies the XPath expression that is referenced by the local xpath variable and stores the result in the url variable within the three context.
extract INPUT three var://local/xpath var://three/url same as the previous example. Note the explicit addressing of the optional variable argument.

entry.name: extract_wsstylepolicyrule_descr_1379
entry.text: Adds an extract action.

entry.name: fetch_wsstylepolicyrule_help_1380
entry.text:
Adds a fetch action to the current Web Services Processing Rule. A fetch action performs an HTTP fetch of a resource for use with a Web Services Processing Rule. You can use any protocol-specific URL when addressing the target resource.
resourceURL identifies the resource to be fetched. This argument can be expressed as a URL or as a var:// URL that expands to a URL.
outputContext identifies the context in which to store the fetched resource.
For example:
fetch var://local/doc Testit fetches the resource that is referenced by the doc variable from within the default context and stores it within the Testit context.
fetch store:///count.xsl count fetches the stylesheet from the store: directory and stores it in the count context.
fetch https://sona/TestBase/simple.xsl tmp1 fetches the stylesheet and stores it in the tmp1 context.

entry.name: fetch_wsstylepolicyrule_descr_1380
entry.text: Adds a fetch action.

entry.name: filter_wsstylepolicyrule_help_1381
entry.text:
Adds a filter action to the current Web Services Processing Rule. A filter action accepts or rejects a document.
Filters differ from XSL transformations in that filters produce no output. Filters are generally used to propose conditions against which a candidate document is evaluated. They result in an accept or reject decision.
Filters are implemented by style policies. A style policy enables a Web Services Proxy to select an appropriate stylesheet with which to filter or transform an input document. The selected stylesheet can be used in conjunction with, or instead of, processing instructions that are contained within the input document.
inputContext identifies the context that contains the document to be filtered. Use "INPUT" to specify the initial policy input, that is the original client request or server response.
stylesheet identifies the XSL stylesheet that is used to filter the source document. This argument can take the form of a URL or of a var:// URL that expands to a URL.
For example:
filter INPUT store:///filter-1.xsl uses the filter-1.xsl stylesheet to filter the original input to the style policy.
filter INPUT var://context/tools/filter uses the stylesheet that is referenced by the filter variable in the tools context to filter the original input to the style policy.

entry.name: filter_wsstylepolicyrule_descr_1381
entry.text: Adds a filter action.

entry.name: input_filter_wsstylepolicyrule_help_1382
entry.text:
Adds an input-filter action to the current Web Services Processing Rule. An input-filter action specifies a decompression algorithm to be applied to all incoming traffic before any other processing occurs.
Use this command only when you are certain that all incoming traffic was compressed with the selected algorithm. Attempts to decompress uncompressed data will result in data corruption.
decompressionAlgorithm identifies the method used to decompress incoming messages and takes one of the following values:
zip Decompresses all incoming traffic with the ZIP algorithm.
pkzip Decompresses all incoming traffic with the PKZIP algorithm.
none (the default) Performs no decompression on incoming traffic.
For example:
input-filter pkzip decompresses all incoming traffic using PKZIP.
input-filter none restores the default state. Incoming traffic is not decompressed.

entry.name: input_filter_wsstylepolicyrule_descr_1382
entry.text: Adds an input-filter action.

entry.name: log_wsstylepolicyrule_help_1383
entry.text:
Adds a log action to the current Web Services Processing Rule. A log action generates a log message that contains the contents of a specified context and sends the message to a target location.
inputContext identifies the context whose contents are to be sent to a target location. Use "INPUT" to specify the initial policy input, that is the original client request or server response. destination is a URL that specifies the log message recipient.
outputContext optionally identifies an output context. http-method specifies the http method to use e.g. POST, PUT, DELETE.
For example:
log INPUT http://www.us.ibm./ragnarok/log sends the contents of the INPUT context to the specified target URL.

entry.name: log_wsstylepolicyrule_descr_1383
entry.text: Adds a log action.

entry.name: non_xml_processing_wsstylepolicyrule_help_1384
entry.text:
Enables or disables processing of non-XML INPUT or OUTPUT within a Web Services Processing Rule.
Use the "no" form of this command to disable non-XML processing.
For example:
non-xml-processing enables non-XML processing within the current Web Services Processing Rule.
no non-xml-processing disables non-XML processing.

entry.name: non_xml_processing_wsstylepolicyrule_descr_1384
entry.text: Enables or disables processing on non-XML.

entry.name: on_error_wsstylepolicyrule_help_1385
entry.text:
Adds an on-error action to the current Web Services Processing Rule. An on-error action provides user-defined error-handling procedures.
mode specifies the operational response to an error, and takes one of the following keywords:
abort specifies that Web Services Processing Rule execution is ceased in the event of an error.
continue specifies that Web Services Processing Rule execution continues with the next action in the event of an error.
alternative specifies that rule processing invokes an alternative rule in the event of an error.
rule optionally specifies an error rule that is executed in the event of an error condition.
inputContext optionally identifies the input context for the error rule. If no context is explicitly identified, the input context of the failed action is used by default.
outputContext optionally identifies the output context for the error rule. If no context is explicitly identified, the output context of the failed action is used by default.
For example:
on-error abort faultProcessing specifies that rule processing ceases in the event of an error and calls the faultProcessing rule as an error handler.

entry.name: on_error_wsstylepolicyrule_descr_1385
entry.text: Adds an on-error action.

entry.name: output_filter_wsstylepolicyrule_help_1386
entry.text:
Adds an output-filter action to the current Web Services Processing Rule. An output-filter action specifies a compression algorithm to be applied to all outbound traffic after all other processing occurs.
compressionAlgorithm identifies the method used to compress outgoing messages and takes one of the following values:
zip Compresses all outgoing traffic with the ZIP algorithm.
pkzip Compresses all outgoing traffic with the PKZIP algorithm.
none (the default) Performs no compression on outgoing traffic.
For example:
output-filter pkzip compresses all outgoing traffic using PKZIP.
output-filter none restores the default state. Outgoing traffic is not compressed.

entry.name: results_wsstylepolicyrule_help_1387
entry.text:
Adds a results action to the current Web Services Processing Rule. A results action transmits the contents of a context to a specified destination.
context identifies the target context, which is the target whose contents are transmitted.
destination optionally specifies the destination. In the absence of this argument, the contents of the target context are transmitted to the "OUTPUT" of the Web Services Processing Rule.
response is required only when a response is expected from the destination. Otherwise, it is not used. This argument identifies the target context that stores the parsed reply.
For example:
results INPUT sends the contents of the INPUT context to the destination of the rule.
results INPUT var://local/dest sends the contents of the INPUT context to the destination that is reference by the local URL variable (var://local/dest).
results INPUT http://127.0.0.1:9000/ apple sends the contents of the INPUT context to the loopback server for processing. Returned processing results are stored in the apple context.

entry.name: results_wsstylepolicyrule_descr_1387
entry.text: Adds a results action.

entry.name: results_async_wsstylepolicyrule_help_1388
entry.text:
Adds a results-async action to the current Web Services Processing Rule. A results-async action transmits the contents of a context to a specified destination.
A results-async action differs from a results action. A results-async action transmits the contents message asynchronously. The results-async action never expects a response from the target destination.
context identifies the target context, that is the target whose contents are transmitted.
destination specifies the destination.
results-async INPUT sends the contents of the INPUT context to the destination of the rule.
results-async INPUT var://local/dest sends the contents of the INPUT context to the destination that is reference by the local URL variable (var://local/dest).

entry.name: results_async_wsstylepolicyrule_descr_1388
entry.text: Adds a results-async action.

entry.name: rewrite_wsstylepolicyrule_help_1389
entry.text:
Adds a rewrite action (implementing a URL Rewrite Policy) to the current Processing Policy Rule.
policyName is the name of the URL Rewrite Policy implemented by this action.
For example:
rewrite URLRewrite-1 rewrites the input URL with the URLRewrite-1 policy.

entry.name: rewrite_wsstylepolicyrule_descr_1389
entry.text: Adds a rewrite action.

entry.name: route_action_wsstylepolicyrule_help_1390
entry.text:
Adds a route-action action to the current Processing Policy Rule. A route-action action enables stylesheet-based routing. Note that there are two syntaxes for this command: route-action <inputContext> <stylesheetURL> route-action <inputContext> dynamic-stylesheet <stylesheetName>
inputContext identifies the context whose contents are to be routed by the specified stylesheet. Use "INPUT" to specify the initial policy input, that is the original client request or server response.
stylesheetURL identifies the local stylesheet used to route the contents of input context.
dynamic-stylesheet is a required token that is used in conjunction with stylesheet name to identify the dynamic stylesheet to use to route the contents of the input context.
stylesheetName identifies the dynamic stylesheet used for routing.
For example:
route-action temp1 local:///route.xsl specifies stylesheet-based routing of the contents of the temp1 context using the route.xsl stylesheet.

entry.name: route_action_wsstylepolicyrule_descr_1390
entry.text: Adds a route-action action.

entry.name: route_set_wsstylepolicyrule_help_1391
entry.text:
Adds a route-set action to the current Processing Policy Rule. A route-set action enables dynamic routing within a Web Services Processing Rule by identifying the document destination and providing optional TLS credentials.
destination is a URL that identifies the document destination. This argument can be expressed as a protocol-specific URL or as a var:// URL that expands to a transport URL.
sslProxyProfile is the optional name of as TLS Proxy Profile used to establish a secure connection with the destination URL. The TLS proxy profile is deprecated. Use a TLS client profile.
For example:
route-set var://context/destinations/dest-1 DySSL-1 specifies a dynamic route expanded from the dest-1 variable in the destinations context. The DySSL-1 TLS Proxy Profile provides the credentials needed for establishment of a secure connection to the destination.

entry.name: route_set_wsstylepolicyrule_descr_1391
entry.text: Adds a route-set action.

entry.name: setvar_wsstylepolicyrule_help_1392
entry.text:
Sets the value of a variable within a context. If the var:// URL is not of the local type, this value overrides the context specified by the context argument.
context identifies the context in which the variable is set.
variable is the variable name and takes the form of a var:// URL.
value is the value assigned to the variable
For example:
setvar INPUT var://local/dest http://ragnarok:9010/ ssets a variable in the INPUT context, with a variable name of dest and a value of http://ragnarok:9010/.
setvar INPUT var://context/routing/dest http://ragnarok:9010/ sets a variable in the routing context, with a variable name of dest and a value of http://ragnarok:9010/.

entry.name: setvar_wsstylepolicyrule_descr_1392
entry.text: Defines a variable.

entry.name: slm_wsstylepolicyrule_help_1393
entry.text:
Adds an slm action (implementing an SLM Policy) to the current Processing Policy Rule.
inputContext identifies the context monitored by the specified SLM Policy. Use "INPUT" to specify the initial policy input, that is the original client request or server response.
policyName is the name of an SLM Policy.
For example:
slm INPUT SLM-1 assigns the SLM-1 SLM policy within the INPUT context.

entry.name: slm_wsstylepolicyrule_descr_1393
entry.text: Adds an slm action.

entry.name: strip_attachments_wsstylepolicyrule_help_1394
entry.text:
Adds a strip-attachments action to the current Processing Policy Rule. A strip-attachments action removes all or specified attachments from a target context.
context identifies the context from which attachments are stripped.
attachmentURI identifies a document attachment to be stripped from context. In the absence of a specified attachment, all attachments are stripped from the target context.
For example:
strip-attachments temp1 strips all attachments from the temp1 context.

entry.name: strip_attachments_wsstylepolicyrule_descr_1394
entry.text: Adds a strip-attachments action.

entry.name: type_wsstylepolicyrule_help_1395
entry.text:
Enables the dynamic retyping of the current Web Services Processing Rule.
ruleType specifies the rule type or direction, and takes one of the following keywords:
error-rule identifies the rule as an error rule, a rule invoked in response to a fault condition.
request-rule identifies the rule as a request rule, a rule applied only to client requests.
response-rule identifies the rule as a response rule, a rule applied only to server responses.
rule identifies the rule as a bi-directional rule, a rule applied both to client requests and server responses.
For example:
type request-rule retypes the current Web Services Processing Rule as a request rule.

entry.name: type_wsstylepolicyrule_descr_1395
entry.text: Enables dynamic retyping.

entry.name: unprocessed_wsstylepolicyrule_help_1396
entry.text:
Enables data to pass-through subsequent actions of the current Web Services Processing Rule in an unprocessed state.
For example:
unprocessed enabled unprocessed mode. no unprocessed disables unprocessed mode.

entry.name: unprocessed_wsstylepolicyrule_descr_1396
entry.text: Enables or disables data passthrough.

entry.name: validate_wsstylepolicyrule_help_1397
entry.text:
Adds a validate action to the current Web Services Processing Rule. A validate action defines a policy-based XML schema validation filter.
"attribute-rewrite", "dynamic-schema", "json-schema", "schema", "schema-rewrite", and "wsdl" are mutually exclusive, but optional, keywords that, in conjunction with their associated arguments, identify the schema or WSDL file to use for document validation.
attribute-rewrite rewrites the schema reference (if any) contained within the XML document. The re-written schema reference usually specifies the location of a local "trusted" copy of the schema that is used for document validation.
dynamic-schema specifies the use of a dynamically-generated schema regardless of any xsi:schemaLocation attributes that are contained within the XML document.
json-schema specifies the use of a JSON schema for validation.
schema specifies the use of a specific schema regardless of any xsi:schemaLocation attributes that are contained within the XML document.
schema-rewrite specifies the use of a specific schema regardless of any xsi:schemaLocation attributes that are contained within the XML document.
wsdl specifies the use of a specific WSDL file regardless of any xsi:schemaLocation attributes that are contained within the XML document.
In the absence of keywords, validation is performed according to xsi:schemaLocation attributes, if any, that are contained within the XML document. Documents that contain no such attributes are considered to be validated.
If an XML schema is specified, all XML documents that are subject to this validation rule are validated against that schema, regardless of any of the validation attributes that are contained within the XML document. If an XML schema is not specified, the document is validated according to any of the validation attributes that are contained within the document.
inputContext identifies the context whose contents are to be validated.
policyName identifies the URL Rewrite Policy that is applied to the schema reference contained with the body of the XML document. This argument can be expressed as the name of a URL Rewrite Policy, or as a var:// URL.
schemaName identifies the dynamic schema used for document validation. This argument can be expressed as a local URL, or as a var:// URL.
jsonschemaURL identifies the JSON schema used for document validation. This argument can be expressed as a URL, or as a var:// URL.
schemaURL identifies the schema used for document validation. This argument can be expressed as a URL, or as a var:// URL.
wsdlURL identifies the WSDL file used for document validation. This argument can be specified as a URL, or as a var:// URL.
outputContext optionally specifies an output context where the (possibly modified) input document is stored.
For example:
validate INPUT attribute-rewrite URL-RW-1 adds a validation action. The xsi:schemaLocation attributes that are contained in XML documents in the INPUT context are rewritten in accordance with the URL-RW-1 URL Rewrite Policy. The rewritten schema reference is used to validate the document.
validate INPUT schema var://context/schemas/1 adds a validation action. XML documents in the INPUT context are validated with the schema referenced by the var://context/schemas/1 variable.
validate INPUT schema store:///SchemaOne.xsd Post-Validation adds a validation action. XML documents in the INPUT context are validated with the local SchemaOne.xsd schema. The possibly transformed document is stored in the Post-Validation context.

entry.name: validate_wsstylepolicyrule_descr_1397
entry.text: Adds a validate action.

entry.name: xform_wsstylepolicyrule_help_1398
entry.text:
Adds an xform action to the current rule. This action defines a policy-based XSL transformation using a specified stylesheet.
XSL transformations are performed by the DataPower service. The selected stylesheet can be used in conjunction with, or instead of, processing instructions within the input document.
inputContext identifies the context that contains the document transformed by this rule. Use "INPUT" to specify the initial policy input, that is the original client request or server response.
<stylesheetURL> and dynamic-stylesheet <objectName> are mutually exclusive.
stylesheetURL identifies the stylesheet used to transform documents. This argument can take the form of a local or remote URL or a var:// URL that expands to a stylesheet location.
dynamic-stylesheet objectName identifies the object (for example, an XPath Routing Map) from which the dynamic stylesheet is generated.
outputContext identifies the context that receives the transformed document. Use "OUTPUT" to specify the final policy output, that is the transformed client request or transformed server response.
For example:
xform INPUT store:///xform-1.xsl OUTPUT Adds a transformation rule. Transform the original input to the Processing Policy Rule with the xform-1.xsl stylesheet and send the transformed document to the final output of the rule.
xform INPUT var://stylesheets/1 Step2 Adds a transformation rule. Transform the original input to the Processing Policy Rule with the stylesheet referenced by the var://stylesheets/1 variable, and send the transformed document to the Step2 context.
xform Step2 var://stylesheets/5 OUTPUT Adds a transformation rule. Transform the document in the Step2 context with the stylesheet referenced by the var://stylesheets/5 variable, and send the transformed document to final output of the rule.

entry.name: xform_wsstylepolicyrule_descr_1398
entry.text: Adds an xform action.

entry.name: xformbin_wsstylepolicyrule_help_1399
entry.text:
Adds an xformbin action to the current Web Services Processing Rule. This action defines a policy-based XSL transformation that converts INPUT binary data to XML.
inputContext identifies the context that contains the document transformed by this rule. Use "INPUT" to specify the initial policy input, that is the original client request or server response.
<stylesheetURL> and dynamic-stylesheet <objectName> are mutually exclusive.
stylesheetURL identifies the stylesheet used to transform documents. This argument can take the form of a local or remote URL or a var:// URL that expands to a stylesheet location.
dynamic-stylesheet objectName identifies the object (for example, an XPath Routing Map) from which the dynamic stylesheet is generated.
outputContext identifies the context that receives the transformed document. Use "OUTPUT" to specify the final policy output, that is the transformed client request or transformed server response.
For example:
xformbin INPUT store:///binToXML.xsl OUTPUT Adds a transformation rule. Transforms the original binary input to XML (using the local binToXML.xsl stylesheet), and sends the XML to the final output of the rule.
xformbin INPUT var://stylesheets/bin-xform FromBin adds a transformation rule. Transforms the original binary input to XML (using the stylesheet referenced by the var://stylesheets/bin-xform variable, and sends the transformed document to the FromBin context.

entry.name: xformbin_wsstylepolicyrule_descr_1399
entry.text: Adds an xformbin action.

entry.name: xformpi_wsstylepolicyrule_help_1400
entry.text:
Adds an xformpi action to the current rule. This action defines a policy-based XSL transformation that is performed according to processing instructions within the candidate XML document.
An optional stylesheet can be identified to transform documents that lack internal processing instructions.
inputContext identifies the context that contains the document transformed by this rule. Use "INPUT" to specify the initial policy input, that is the original client request or server response.
<stylesheetURL> and dynamic-stylesheet <objectName> are mutually exclusive.
stylesheetURL identifies the stylesheet used to transform documents. This argument can take the form of a local or remote URL or a var:// URL that expands to a stylesheet location.
dynamic-stylesheet objectName identifies the object (for example, an XPath Routing Map) from which the dynamic stylesheet is generated.
outputContext identifies the context that receives the transformed document. Use "OUTPUT" to specify the final policy output, that is the transformed client request or transformed server response.
For example:
xformpi INPUT store:///identity.xsl OUTPUT adds a transformation rule. Transforms the original input to the Processing Policy Rule with internal processing instructions contained with XML document and send the transformed document to the final output of the rule. Uses identity.xsl to perform document transformation if the document does not contain processing instructions.

entry.name: xformpi_wsstylepolicyrule_descr_1400
entry.text: Adds an xformpi action.

entry.name: auto_retry_webspherejmsserver_help_1401
entry.text:
Enables an automatic critical error-recovery procedure that attempts to re-establish a connection that has been broken in response to an error condition. Error recovery is enabled by default. on and off are mutually exclusive key words that enable (on) or disable (off) the automatic error recovery procedure.
For example:
error recovery off disables automatic error recovery attempts

entry.name: auto_retry_webspherejmsserver_descr_1401
entry.text: Enable/disable error recovery procedure.

entry.name: default_message_type_webspherejmsserver_help_1402
entry.text:
Use this command to specify the default JMS message type, which is provided by this WebSphere JMS object only if the message type cannot be determined from the JMS message headers. byte and text are mutually exclusive key words that specify the message type. byte (the default) specifies that the message payload is accessed as a Java byte array text specifies that the message payload is accessed as a Java string value
For example:
default-message-type text specifies the default message type as text, suitable for XML and SOAP input

entry.name: default_message_type_webspherejmsserver_descr_1402
entry.text: Specify default JMS message type.

entry.name: enable_logging_webspherejmsserver_help_1403
entry.text:
Enables/disables an expanded JMS logging facility. on and off are mutually exclusive key words that enable (on) or disable (off -- the default state) expanded JMS logging.
For example:
enable-logging on enables expanded logging

entry.name: enable_logging_webspherejmsserver_descr_1403
entry.text: Enable/disable an expanded JMS logging facility.

entry.name: endpoint_webspherejmsserver_help_1404
entry.text:
A service integration bus (SIB) supports applications using message-based and service-oriented architectures. A bus is a group of interconnected servers and clusters that have been added as members of the bus. Applications connect to a bus at one of the messaging engines associated with its bus members.
A messaging engine is a component, running inside a server, that manages messaging resources for a bus member. Applications are connected to a messaging engine when accessing a SIB. Applications (such as the WebSphere JMS object) running outside the WAS environment cannot locate directly a suitable messaging engine to connect to the target bus. In such cases the remote clients or servers must access the bus through a bootstrap server that is a member of the target bus. A bootstrap server is an application server running the SIB process, but need not be running any message engines. Rather the bootstrap server selects a messaging engine that is running in an application server that supports the bootstrap protocol requested by the remote device.
To connect to a messaging engine the remote application first connects to a bootstrap server; the bootstrap server selects a messaging engine and then tells the client application to connect to that message engine in order to gain bus access.
A bootstrap server uses a host name or IP address, in conjunction with a port number and a bootstrap transport chain (identifying the protocol stack offered by the bootstrap server) to define an endpoint address.
The protocol stack used to access the bootstrap server need not be the same protocol stack used for actual message transfer via the bus.
You can use the endpoint command multiple times to identify more than one non-default bootstrap server. For failover capability, the endpoints must be members of the same WebSphere Application Server cluster.
bootstrapHost The host name or IP address of a bootstrap server. bootstrapPort The port monitored by the bootstrap server for incoming requests. bootstrapProtocol The predefined transport chain provided by the bootstrap server. HTTP The predefined BootstrapTunneledMessaging transport chain (tunnels JFAP using HTTP wrappers) HTTPS The predefined BootstrapTunneledSecureMessaging transport chain (tunnels JFAP using HTTPS wrappers) SSL The predefined BootstrapSecureMessaging transport chain (JFAP-SSL-TCP/IP) TCP (default) The predefined BootstrapBasicMessaging transport chain (JFAP-TCP/IP)
For example:
endpoint 192.168.34.87 4500 SSL Identifies a bootstrap server at the specified address:port pair; the BootstrapSecureMessaging transport chain

entry.name: endpoint_webspherejmsserver_descr_1404
entry.text: Identify a bootstrap server endpoint.

entry.name: maximum_message_size_webspherejmsserver_help_1405
entry.text:
Specifies the maximum message size supported by the current WebSphere JMS object. maxMsgSize is an integer (with the range 0 through 1073741824, with a default of 1048576) that specifies the maximum message size in bytes. n For example:
maximum-message-size 2097152 sets a maximum message size of 2MB

entry.name: maximum_message_size_webspherejmsserver_descr_1405
entry.text: Set the maximum message size.

entry.name: memory_threshold_webspherejmsserver_help_1406
entry.text:
Specifies the maximum memory allocation for pending messages.
bytes Specifies the maximum memory to allocate in bytes for pending messages. Enter a value in the range 1048576 - 1073741824. The default value is 268435456.
For example:
memory-threshold 20971520 Sets a maximum memory allocation to 2MB.

entry.name: memory_threshold_webspherejmsserver_descr_1406
entry.text: Set the maximum memory allocation for pending messages.

entry.name: messaging_bus_webspherejmsserver_help_1407
entry.text:
Specifies the Service Integration Bus (SIB) used to access the remote WebSphere Application Server. A service integration bus (SIB), or bus, supports applications using message-based and service-oriented architectures. A bus is a group of interconnected servers and clusters that have been added as members of the bus. Applications connect to a bus at one of the messaging engines associated with its bus members. If you have access to the WebSphere Administrative Console, you can view bus information, to include bus members and messaging engines, queues and topics, and the bus-specific default topic space through the Service integration|Buses menu. busName is the name of the Service Integration Bus.
For example:
messaging-bus Firenze identifies Firenze as the bus used to access the WebSphere Application server

entry.name: messaging_bus_webspherejmsserver_descr_1407
entry.text: Identify the Service Integration Bus (SIB).

entry.name: password_webspherejmsserver_help_1408
entry.text:
Specifies the password to access the WebSphere Application Server. This property is deprecated. Use the password-alias command.
plaintextString Is the password to access the WebSphere Application Server.
For example:
username Dante password Alighieri Specifies the user and password to access the server.

entry.name: password_webspherejmsserver_descr_1408
entry.text: Identify the WebSphere Application Server password (deprecated).

entry.name: password_alias_webspherejmsserver_help_1409
entry.text:
Specifies the password alias of the password to access the WebSphere Application Server.
password-alias Is the password alias to access the WebSphere Application Server.
For example:
username Dante password-alias Alighieri-alias Specifies the user and password alias to access the server.

entry.name: password_alias_webspherejmsserver_descr_1409
entry.text: Identify the password alias of the WebSphere Application Server password.

entry.name: retry_interval_webspherejmsserver_help_1410
entry.text:
Meaningful only if auto-retry is enabled, specifies the interval between automatic re-connection attempts. In the absence of an explicit assignment, a default value of 1 is used. intervalSeconds is an integer that specifies the interval (in seconds) between attempts to re-establish a downed connection to the WebSphere Application Server.
For example:
retry-interval 2 specifies a 2 second pause between reconnection attempts

entry.name: retry_interval_webspherejmsserver_descr_1410
entry.text: Specify frequency of re-connection attempts.

entry.name: sessions_per_connection_webspherejmsserver_help_1411
entry.text:
Specifies the maximum number of concurrent multiplexed sessions supported by a single connection to the current WebSphere Application Server. Session requests in excess of the value set by the sessions-per-connection command trigger the establishment of a new connection to the WebSphere Application Server, assuming that the number of current connections is less than the value specified by total-connection-limit command. For example, assuming default values (20 for sessions-per-connection, and 5 for total-connection-limit) and 3 active fully-subscribed connections, a new session request generates the establishment of a 4th connection. maxSessions is an integer (greater than 4, and with a default value of 20) that specifies the maximum concurrent sessions supported by a single connection to the WebSphere Application Server.
For example:
total-connection-limit 4 sessions-per-connection 15 Specifies the connection limit and per-connection session limit for the WebSphere Application Server

entry.name: sessions_per_connection_webspherejmsserver_descr_1411
entry.text: Set per-connection session limit.

entry.name: ssl_client_type_webspherejmsserver_help_1412
entry.text:
Provides a choice between "proxy" (deprecated) or "client" to establish secure connection from the DataPower Gateway to WebSphere Application Server.
For example:
ssl-client-type client

entry.name: ssl_client_type_webspherejmsserver_descr_1412
entry.text: Set the TLS profile type to secure connections to targets

entry.name: ssl_client_webspherejmsserver_help_1413
entry.text:
Identifies the TLS Client Profile used to establish a secure connection from the DataPower Gateway to WebSphere Application Server. In the absence of an explicitly assigned TLS Client Profile, the DataPower Gateway establishes a nonsecure connection.
If you specify a TLS client profile, the associated cipher specification is replaced by an IBM default cipher specification (SSL_RSS_WITH_NULL_MD5). You can use the ssl-cipher and ssl-fips commands to tailor TLS operations. name The TLS Client Profile to assign.
For example:
ssl-client jmsClientProfile Assigns the jmsClientProfile TLS Client Profile

entry.name: ssl_client_webspherejmsserver_descr_1413
entry.text: Assign a TLS Client Profile.

entry.name: ssl_webspherejmsserver_help_1414
entry.text:
The TLS proxy profile is deprecated. Use a TLS client profile. Identifies the TLS Proxy Profile to establish a secure connection from the DataPower Gateway to WebSphere Application Server. In the absence of an explicitly assigned TLS Proxy Profile, the DataPower Gateway establishes a nonsecure connection.
If you specify a TLS Proxy, the associated cipher specification is replaced by the IBM default cipher specification (SSL_RSS_WITH_NULL_MD5). You can use the ssl-cipher and ssl-fips commands to tailor TLS operations. name The TLS Proxy Profile to assign.
For example:
ssl jmsProxy Assigns the jmsProxy TLS Proxy Profile

entry.name: ssl_webspherejmsserver_descr_1414
entry.text: Deprecated - Assign a TLS Proxy Profile.

entry.name: ssl_cipher_webspherejmsserver_help_1415
entry.text:
Identifies the IBM cipher specification used by the assigned TLS Proxy Profile when establishing a secure connection to the WebSphere Application Server. If you specify a TLS Proxy, the cipher specification associated with the proxy is replaced by an IBM default cipher specification (SSL_RSS_WITH_NULL_MD5). You can use this command to change that default assignment. cipherSpecificationID The cipher specification and takes one of the following values:
SSL_RSA_WITH_NULL_MD5 (the default) SSL_RSA_EXPORT_WITH_RC2_CBC_40_MD5 SSL_RSA_EXPORT_WITH_RC4_40_MD5 SSL_RSA_WITH_RC4_128_MD5 SSL_RSA_WITH_NULL_SHA SSL_RSA_EXPORT1024_WITH_RC4_56_SHA SSL_RSA_WITH_RC4_128_SHA SSL_RSA_WITH_DES_CBC_SHA SSL_RSA_EXPORT1024_WITH_DES_CBC_SHA SSL_RSA_FIPS_WITH_DES_CBC_SHA SSL_RSA_WITH_3DES_EDE_CBC_SHA SSL_RSA_FIPS_WITH_3DES_EDE_CBC_SHA TLS_RSA_WITH_DES_CBC_SHA TLS_RSA_WITH_3DES_EDE_CBC_SHA TLS_RSA_WITH_AES_128_CBC_SHA TLS_RSA_WITH_AES_256_CBC_SHA TLS_RSA_WITH_AES_128_CBC_SHA256 TLS_RSA_WITH_AES_256_CBC_SHA256 TLS_RSA_WITH_NULL_SHA256
For example:
ssl-cipher SSL_RSA_FIPS_WITH_3DES_EDE_CBC_SHA assigns a non-default cipher specification

entry.name: ssl_cipher_webspherejmsserver_descr_1415
entry.text: Assign an IBM cipher specification.

entry.name: ssl_fips_webspherejmsserver_help_1416
entry.text:
Forces the use of an IBM FIPS (Federal Information Processing Standard)-compliant cipher specification. on and off are mutually exclusive key words that enable (on) or disable (off -- the default state) use of a FIPS-compliant cipher specification.
For example:
ssl-fips on requires the use of a FIPS-compliant cipher

entry.name: ssl_fips_webspherejmsserver_descr_1416
entry.text: Force use of a FIPS-compliant cipher specification.

entry.name: target_transport_chain_webspherejmsserver_help_1417
entry.text:
Identifies the predefined transport chain provided by the WebSphere Application Server, and used for message exchange between the application server and the WebSphere JMS object. If you have access to the WebSphere Administrative Console, you can view transport chain information through the Application Servers|serverName|Transport Chain menu. The transport chain used for message exchange need not match the chain used for bootstrap access. msgXferProtocol The predefined transport chain provided by the WebSphere Application Server and takes one of the following values: InboundBasicMessaging (the default) specifies the predefined InboundBasicMessaging transport chain (JFAP-TCP/IP) InboundHTTPMessaging specifies the predefined InboundHTTPMessaging transport chain (tunnels JFAP using HTTP wrappers) InboundHTTPSMessaging specifies the predefined InboundHTTPSMessaging transport chain (tunnels JFAP using HTTPS wrappers) InboundSecureMessaging specifies the predefined InboundSecureMessaging transport chain (JFAP-SSL-TCP/IP)
For example:
target-transport-chain InboundSecureMessaging identifies the transport chain used for message exchange

entry.name: target_transport_chain_webspherejmsserver_descr_1417
entry.text: Identify the message exchange transport chain.

entry.name: total_connection_limit_webspherejmsserver_help_1418
entry.text:
Specifies the maximum number of open connections to the WebSphere Application Server. Session requests in excess of the value set by the sessions-per-connection command trigger the establishment of a new connection to the WebSphere Application Server, assuming that the number of current connections is less than the value specified by total-connection-limit command. For example, assuming default values (20 for sessions-per-connection, and 5 for total-connection-limit) and 3 active fully-subscribed connections, a new session request generates the establishment of a 4th connection. maxSessions is an integer (greater than 4, and with a default value of 20) that specifies the maximum concurrent sessions supported by a single connection to the WebSphere Application Server.
For example:
total-connection-limit 4 sessions-per-connection 15 specifies the connection limit and per-connection session limit for the WebSphere Application Server.

entry.name: total_connection_limit_webspherejmsserver_descr_1418
entry.text: Set per-connection session limit.

entry.name: transactional_webspherejmsserver_help_1419
entry.text:
Enables/disables transaction-based processing in which messages are acknowledged only after the transaction has succeeded. on and off are mutually exclusive key words that enable (on) or disable (off -- the default state) transaction-based processing.
For example:
transactional on enables transaction-based processing

entry.name: transactional_webspherejmsserver_descr_1419
entry.text: Enable/disable transaction-based processing.

entry.name: username_webspherejmsserver_help_1420
entry.text:
Specifies the account, or user name, to access the WebSphere Application Server.
plaintextString Is the account to access the WebSphere Application Server.
For example:
username Dante password-alias Alighieri-alias Specifies the user and password alias to access the server.

entry.name: username_webspherejmsserver_descr_1420
entry.text: Identify the WebSphere Application Server account.

entry.name: get_queue_webspherejmssourceprotocolhandler_help_1421
entry.text:
Specifies the name of the queue that contains client-originated WebSphere Application Server (WAS) Java Message Service (JMS) request messages. The WebSphere JMS Handler monitors the GET queue for incoming client requests. Upon message receipt, the handler forwards the extracted message to the a local WebSphere JMS object that will gateway the message to a remote WebSphere JMS default message provider. Identification of a GET queue is required. queueName is the name of the queue that contains WAS JMS request messages. For example:
get-queue hiPriority identifies hiPriority as the WebSphere JMS GET queue

entry.name: get_queue_webspherejmssourceprotocolhandler_descr_1421
entry.text: Specifies the WebSphere JMS GET queue

entry.name: put_queue_webspherejmssourceprotocolhandler_help_1422
entry.text:
Specifies the name of the queue that contains server-originated WebSphere Application Server (WAS) Java Message Service (JMS) reply messages. Such messages are originated by a remote WAS JMS default message provider and put into this queue by a local WebSphere JMS object. Identification of a PUT queue is optional. A PUT queue should be configured if server replies are expected; if reply messages are not expected, a PUT queue need not be configured. In the absence of a PUT queue, any received replies are dropped. queueName is the name of the queue that contains WAS JMS reply messages. For example:
put-queue JmsResponse identifies JmsResponse as the WebSphere JMS PUT queue

entry.name: put_queue_webspherejmssourceprotocolhandler_descr_1422
entry.text: Specifies the WebSphere JMS PUT queue

entry.name: reply_topic_space_webspherejmssourceprotocolhandler_help_1423
entry.text:
A topic space is a hierarchy of topics used for publish/subscribe messaging. Topics with the same name can exist in multiple topic spaces, but there can be only one topic space with a given name in a service integration bus. For example, consider a topic hierarchy split into the following topic spaces: library - Topics for document management sales - Topics for marketing and sales tracking engineering - Topics for engineering and technology
The topic volumes can appear in all three topic spaces, and have a very different meaning in each. Use this command to disambiguate a topic if the response destination is a topic whose name appears in multiple topic spaces. topicSpaceName is the name of a non-default topic space. For example:
reply-topic-space sales identifies sales as a non-default reply topic space

entry.name: reply_topic_space_webspherejmssourceprotocolhandler_descr_1423
entry.text: Specifies a non-default topic space.

entry.name: request_topic_space_webspherejmssourceprotocolhandler_help_1424
entry.text:
A topic space is a hierarchy of topics used for publish/subscribe messaging. Topics with the same name can exist in multiple topic spaces, but there can be only one topic space with a given name in a service integration bus. For example, consider a topic hierarchy split into the following topic spaces: library - Topics for document management sales - Topics for marketing and sales tracking engineering - Topics for engineering and technology
The topic volumes can appear in all three topic spaces, and have a very different meaning in each. Use this command to disambiguate a topic if the request destination is a topic whose name appears in multiple topic spaces. topicSpaceName is the name of a non-default topic space. For example:
request-topic-space engineering identifies engineering as a non-default request topic space

entry.name: request_topic_space_webspherejmssourceprotocolhandler_descr_1424
entry.text: Specifies a non-default topic space.

entry.name: selector_webspherejmssourceprotocolhandler_help_1425
entry.text:
The message selector is a conditional expression based on a subset of SQL92 conditional expression syntax. The conditional expression enables the WebSphere JMS Handler to identify messages of interest. The conditional expression does not operate on the body of the JMS message, rather it examines JMS message headers and properties (proprietary user-created headers that might appear between the required headers and the message body). The required JMS headers are as follows:
Destination contains the destination (queue) to which the message is being sent DeliveryMode contains the delivery mode (PERSISTENT or NON_PERSISTENT) Expiration contains a message TTL or a value of 0 indicating an unlimited TTL Priority contains the message priority expressed as a digit from 0 (lowest priority) to 9 (highest priority) MessageID contains a unique message identifier starting with the prefix ID:, or a null value, effectively disabling message ID Timestamp contains the time the message was handed off for transmission, not the time it was actually sent CorrelationID contains a means of associating one message (for example, a response) with another message (for example, the original request) ReplyTo contains the destination (queue or topic) to which a reply to this message should be sent Type contains a message identifier provided by the application Redelivered contains a boolean indicating that the message has been delivered in the past, but not yet acknowledged
Configuration of a message selector is optional. If a message selector is not specified, all incoming client request messages are transferred by the WebSphere JMS Handler to the WebSphere JMS object for processing. If a message selector is specified, only those client requests that match the criteria specified by the SQL expression are forwarded to the WebSphere JMS object for processing. All other messages are dropped from the GET queue. sqlExpression is the SQL-like expression to filter messages from the GET queue. For example:
selector selector "DeliveryMode LIKE PERSISTENT" indicates that only client requests that have a DeliveryMode of PERSISTENT are forwarded to the WebSphere JMS object for processing; all other messages are dropped from the GET queue.

entry.name: selector_webspherejmssourceprotocolhandler_descr_1425
entry.text: Describe messages of interest.

entry.name: server_webspherejmssourceprotocolhandler_help_1426
entry.text:
Specifies the WebSphere JMS Server object supported by this protocol handler. wasJMSName is the name of the WebSphere JMS object supported by this. WebSphere JMS Protocol handler. For example:
server jetStream-1 identifies jetStream-1 as the supported WebSphere JMS object

entry.name: server_webspherejmssourceprotocolhandler_descr_1426
entry.text: identifies the supported WAS JMS object

entry.name: method_wsrrsubscription_help_1427
entry.text:
Specifies the method to synchronize the "local" copy of the subscribed object with the version stored on the remote WSRR server.
automatic Synchronization is automatic. The subscription is automatically updated when there is a change to a subscribed resource on the WSRR server. manual Synchronization is achieved by a direct action, specifically with the wsrr-synchronize command. poll (Default) Synchronization is an automatic and periodic refresh of the subscription by regularly scheduled WSRR queries that request the latest version of the resource.

entry.name: method_wsrrsubscription_descr_1427
entry.text: Specifies the synchronization method.

entry.name: namespace_wsrrsubscription_help_1428
entry.text:
Used in conjunction with the object-name command, namespace unambiguously identifies a subscribed-to WSRR resource. Both the resource namespace and name are assigned when a resource, such as a WSDL file, is first loaded to a WSRR, or when a collection of resources is aggregated as a "concept". The identification of the resource namespace is required. resourceNamespace is a string that identifies the namespace of the resource to be subscribed to.
For example:
namespace http://tonawanda.sr.ibm.com/ValidateInsurance specifies the resource namespace.

entry.name: namespace_wsrrsubscription_descr_1428
entry.text: Used with object-name to identify a resource.

entry.name: object_name_wsrrsubscription_help_1429
entry.text:
Used in conjunction with the namespace command, object-name unambiguously identifies a subscribed-to WSRR resource. Both the resource name and namespace are assigned when a resource, such as a WSDL file, is first loaded to the WSRR, or when a collection of resources is aggregated as a "concept". The identification of the resource name is required. resourceName is the name of the resource to be subscribed to.
For example:
name ValidateInsurancePolicyTestService.wsdl specifies the resource name.

entry.name: object_name_wsrrsubscription_descr_1429
entry.text: Used with namespace to identify a resource.

entry.name: object_type_wsrrsubscription_help_1430
entry.text:
This required command identifies a resource type. wsdl (the default) is a keyword that identifies the resource subscribed to as a single WSDL file. concept is a keyword that identifies the resource subscribed to as a "concept". A concept, which is created and maintained by the WSRR administrator, is simply a package for metadata, and can contain one or more WSDL files possibly along with a number of associated files to include XSD schemas and XML files such as AAA info files.
For example:
object-type wsdl specifies the resource type.

entry.name: object_type_wsrrsubscription_descr_1430
entry.text: Identifies a resource type.

entry.name: refresh_interval_wsrrsubscription_help_1431
entry.text:
Specifies the synchronization frequency in seconds. Meaningful only when the synchronization method is set to "poll". refreshFrequency is an integer that specifies the interval in seconds between the regularly-scheduled WSRR queries used to synchronize the local copy of the subscribed resource with the WSRR-resident version. In the absence of an explicitly-assigned interval, a default
value of 86400 (24 hours) is used.
For example:
refresh-interval 28800 specifies a refresh interval of 8 hours.

entry.name: refresh_interval_wsrrsubscription_descr_1431
entry.text: Specifies the synchronization frequency.

entry.name: server_wsrrsubscription_help_1432
entry.text:
This required command specifies the WSRR server object, previously created with the wsrr-server command that identifies the WSRR Server that stores the subscribed-to resource. wsrrServerObjectName is a string that provides the name of the WSRR server object.
For example:
server businessRegistry-1 The WSRR server object, businessRegistry-1.

entry.name: server_wsrrsubscription_descr_1432
entry.text: Identifies the target WSRR Server.

entry.name: use_version_wsrrsubscription_help_1433
entry.text: If enabled, the subscription will query the registry for wsdl document version specified in the version field. Otherwise, it will not use the version field

entry.name: use_version_wsrrsubscription_descr_1433
entry.text: Use the WSDL version field provided byWSRR Server.

entry.name: version_wsrrsubscription_help_1434
entry.text: If use-version is on, the subscription will query the registry for wsdl document version specified in the version field. Otherwise, it will not use the version field

entry.name: version_wsrrsubscription_descr_1434
entry.text: The WSDL version

entry.name: fetch_policy_attachments_wsrrsubscription_help_1435
entry.text: If fetch-policy-attachments is on, the subscription will query the registry for policy attachment Otherwise, it will not query the registry for policy attachment.

entry.name: fetch_policy_attachments_wsrrsubscription_descr_1435
entry.text: Fetch the PolicyAttachment for WSDL Document

entry.name: method_wsrrsavedsearchsubscription_help_1436
entry.text:
Specifies the method to synchronize the "local" copy of the wsdl objects with the version stored on the remote WSRR server.
automatic Synchronization is automatic. The subscription is automatically updated when there is a change to a subscribed resource on the WSRR server. manual Synchronization is achieved by a direct action, specifically with the wsrr-synchronize command. poll (Default) Synchronization is an automatic and periodic refresh of the subscription by regularly scheduled WSRR queries that request the latest version of the resource.

entry.name: method_wsrrsavedsearchsubscription_descr_1436
entry.text: Specifies the synchronization method.

entry.name: saved_search_name_wsrrsavedsearchsubscription_help_1437
entry.text:
This is the name of the Saved Search query that is submitted to the WSRR Server. The resulting resources are then used as the subscription objects for the WS Proxy. savedSearchName is the name of the WSRR Saved Search to be subscribed to.
For example:
saved-search-name ProductionWSDLsQuery specifies to use the resources from the execution of the of the saved search called ProductionWSDLsQuery in the WSRR server.

entry.name: saved_search_name_wsrrsavedsearchsubscription_descr_1437
entry.text: Name of the WSRR Saved Search.

entry.name: refresh_interval_wsrrsavedsearchsubscription_help_1438
entry.text:
Specifies the synchronization frequency in seconds. Meaningful only when the synchronization method is set to "poll". refreshFrequency is an integer that specifies the interval in seconds between the regularly-scheduled WSRR queries used to synchronize the local copy of the subscribed resource with the WSRR-resident version. In the absence of an explicitly-assigned interval, a default value of 86400 (24 hours) is used.
For example:
refresh-interval 28800 specifies a refresh interval of 8 hours.

entry.name: refresh_interval_wsrrsavedsearchsubscription_descr_1438
entry.text: Specifies the synchronization frequency.

entry.name: server_wsrrsavedsearchsubscription_help_1439
entry.text:
This required command specifies the WSRR server object, previously created with the wsrr-server command that identifies the WSRR Server that stores the subscribed-to resource. wsrrServerObjectName is a string that provides the name of the WSRR server object.
For example:
server businessRegistry-1 The WSRR server object, businessRegistry-1.

entry.name: server_wsrrsavedsearchsubscription_descr_1439
entry.text: Identifies the target WSRR Server.

entry.name: fetch_policy_attachments_wsrrsavedsearchsubscription_help_1440
entry.text: If fetch-policy-attachments is on, the subscription will query the registry for policy attachments Otherwise, it will not query the registry for policy attachments.

entry.name: fetch_policy_attachments_wsrrsavedsearchsubscription_descr_1440
entry.text: Fetch the PolicyAttachment for WSDL Document

entry.name: params_wsrrsavedsearchsubscription_help_1441
entry.text: Define the parameters for a saved-search that requires parameters. The parameters are used in the query that is sent to the WSRR server. A parameter can be up to 255 characters in length. Define a maximum of 9 parameters for a query. It is an error to define parameters for a saved search that does not require parameters.

entry.name: params_wsrrsavedsearchsubscription_descr_1441
entry.text: Specifies the parameters for the saved search

entry.name: password_wsrrserver_help_1442
entry.text:
Use in conjunction with "username" command to provide the credentials used to access the WSRR Server. Required when the WSRR Server enforces authentication. This property is deprecated and replaced with password-alias.
passPhrase is a string that provides the user password. For example:
username admin password yetAnotherPassword! specifies the user name and password.

entry.name: password_wsrrserver_descr_1442
entry.text: Provides WSRR Server credentials password (deprecated).

entry.name: password_alias_wsrrserver_help_1443
entry.text:
Use in conjunction with "username" command to provide the credentials used to access the WSRR Server. Required when the WSRR Server enforces authentication. This is the password alias of the password.
passPhrase-alias is a string that provides the password alias to the user password. For example:
username admin password-alias alias-2 specifies the user name and password alias.

entry.name: password_alias_wsrrserver_descr_1443
entry.text: Provides the password alias for the WSRR Server credentials password.

entry.name: soap_url_wsrrserver_help_1444
entry.text:
soapAPIURL is string that provides the URL used to access the SOAP API provided by WSRR V6.0. soapAPIURL takes the following format:
http://hostname:port/URI
For example, https://192.168.1.120:9443/WSRRCoreSDO/services/WSRRCoreSDOPort
For example:
soap-url http://192.168.1.120:9080/WSRRCoreSDO/services/WSRRCoreSDOPort accesses the application server default internal HTTP transport port.
soap-url https://192.168.1.120:9443/WSRRCoreSDO/services/WSRRCoreSDOPort accesses the application server default HTTPS transport port

entry.name: soap_url_wsrrserver_descr_1444
entry.text: Locates the WSRR SOAP API interface.

entry.name: ssl_wsrrserver_help_1445
entry.text:
The TLS proxy profile is deprecated. Use a TLS client profile. Assigns a TLS Proxy Profile to support secure communications between the DataPower Gateway and a remote WSRR Server. Meaningful only when the SOAP API URL starts with "https:".
name The TLS Proxy Profile to assign. For example:
ssl TLS-1 Assigns the TLS-1 TLS Proxy Profile.

entry.name: ssl_wsrrserver_descr_1445
entry.text: Deprecated - Assigns a TLS proxy.

entry.name: ssl_client_type_wsrrserver_help_1446
entry.text: Specify the type of TLS profile to use. "proxy" (default) Uses an TLS proxy profile. "client" Uses a TLS client profile.

entry.name: ssl_client_type_wsrrserver_descr_1446
entry.text: Specifies the type of TLS profile.

entry.name: ssl_client_wsrrserver_help_1447
entry.text:
Assigns a TLS client profile to support secure communications between the DataPower Gateway and a remote WSRR Server. Meaningful only when the SOAP API URL starts with "https:". name The name of the TLS client profile to assign. For example:
ssl-client TLS-1 Assigns the TLS-1 TLS client profile.

entry.name: ssl_client_wsrrserver_descr_1447
entry.text: Assigns a TLS client profile.

entry.name: username_wsrrserver_help_1448
entry.text:
Use in conjunction with "password" command to provide the credentials used to access the WSRR Server. Required when the WSRR Server enforces authentication. accountName is a string that provides the user name. For example:
username admin password yetAnotherPassword! specifies the user name and password.

entry.name: username_wsrrserver_descr_1448
entry.text: Provides WSRR Server credentials.

entry.name: server_prefix_wsrrserver_descr_1449
entry.text: The WSRR Instance Prefix for a specific instance of a multi-cell deployment.

entry.name: cache_ttl_xacmlpdp_help_1450
entry.text:
Assigns a Policy Decision Point (PDP) cache lifetime.
ttlValue is an integer (in the range from 0 to 2,678,400, with a default of 0) that specifies the time, in seconds, that compiled XACML policies are maintained in the PDP cache.

entry.name: cache_ttl_xacmlpdp_descr_1450
entry.text: Assigns a PDP cache lifetime.

entry.name: combining_alg_xacmlpdp_help_1451
entry.text:
A policy-combining algorithm defines a procedure for arriving at an authorization decision given the individual results of evaluation of a set of policies. Meaningful only when equal-policies is on.
deny-overrides This algorithm evaluates each policy in the order that it appears in the XACML Policy Set. If any policy in the set evaluates to deny, the policy combination evaluates immediately to deny.
first-applicable This algorithm evaluates each policy in the order that it appears in the XACML Policy Set. For an individual policy, if the target (resource) evaluates to TRUE and the policy conditions evaluate unambiguously to permit or deny, evaluation is immediately halted, and the policy combination evaluates to the effect of that individual policy. If the individual policy evaluates the target as FALSE or the policy conditions as NotApplicable, then the next policy in the order is evaluated; if no further policy exists in the order, the policy combination evaluates to NotApplicable.
only-on-applicable This algorithm evaluates each policy in the order that it appears in the XACML Policy Set. Unlike the other algorithms, only-one-applicable must evaluate all policies to render a final evaluation.
