If after evaluating all policies, no policy is considered applicable by virtue of its target (the requested resource), the policy combination evaluates to NotApplicable. If after evaluating all policies, more than one policy is considered applicable by virtue of its target, the policy combination evaluates to Indeterminate. If after evaluating all policies, only one single policy is considered applicable by virtue of its target, the policy combination evaluates to the result of evaluating that single policy.
permit-overrides This algorithm evaluates each policy in the order that it appears in the XACML Policy Set. If any policy in the set evaluates to permit, the policy combination evaluates immediately to permit.

entry.name: combining_alg_xacmlpdp_descr_1451
entry.text: Selects a policy-combining algorithm.

entry.name: dependent_policy_xacmlpdp_help_1452
entry.text:
Identifies a dependent file could be required by the PDP to evaluate submitted policies.
fileURL Specifies the file location.

entry.name: dependent_policy_xacmlpdp_descr_1452
entry.text: Identifies a dependent file.

entry.name: directory_xacmlpdp_help_1453
entry.text:
Identifies a specific local directory as a source of dependent files. All files in this directory with an .xml or .xacml extension are identified as dependent policy files.
directoryName Specifies the local directory or sub-directory.

entry.name: directory_xacmlpdp_descr_1453
entry.text: Identifies the directory for dependent files.

entry.name: equal_policies_xacmlpdp_help_1454
entry.text:
Indicates whether a single, top-level, comprehensive XACML policy file is in use or multiple XACML policy files are in use.
on Comprehensive file in use. off Multiple files in use.

entry.name: equal_policies_xacmlpdp_descr_1454
entry.text: Indicates a comprehensive XACML policy file.

entry.name: general_policy_xacmlpdp_help_1455
entry.text:
Identifies the location of the comprehensive XACML policy file.
fileURL Specifies the file location.

entry.name: general_policy_xacmlpdp_descr_1455
entry.text: Identifies the comprehensive XACML policy file.

entry.name: priority_xmlfirewallservice_help_1456
entry.text: Assigns a priority for scheduling or for resource allocation. When system resources are in high demand, higher priority services will be favored over lower priority services. low Receives below normal priority. normal (Default) Receives normal priority. high Receives above normal priority.

entry.name: priority_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1456
entry.text: Assigns a service-level scheduling priority

entry.name: acl_xmlfirewallservice_help_1457
entry.text:
Assigns a previously configured Access Control List, a list of IP address ranges that are allowed or denied service access, to the XML firewall. aclName The ACL assigned to the current firewall. For example:
acl ACL-1 assigns the ACL named ACL-1 to the current firewall.

entry.name: acl_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1457
entry.text: Assigns an ACL to an XML firewall

entry.name: attachment_byte_count_xmlfirewallservice_help_1458
entry.text:
Specifies the XML Firewall-specific maximum size in bytes for an attached document. Attachments that exceed this size will result in a failure of the entire transaction.
bytes is an integer that sets the maximum number of bytes allowed in any attachment. A value of 0, specifies that size limitations are not enforced by this XML Firewall. The default value is 2000000000.
For example:
attachment-byte-count 5000000 sets the maximum attachment size for the current XML Firewall to 5,000,000 bytes.

entry.name: attachment_byte_count_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1458
entry.text: Specifies the maximum size for an attached document.

entry.name: attachment_package_byte_count_xmlfirewallservice_help_1459
entry.text:
Specifies the XML Firewall-specific maximum size in bytes for an attached package, including the root part. Attachment packages that exceed this size will result in a failure of the transaction.
bytes is an integer that sets the maximum number of bytes allowed in any attachment. A value of 0, specifies that size limitations are not enforced by this XML Firewall. The default value is 0.
For example:
attachment-package-byte-count 5000000 sets the maximum attachment package size for the current XML Firewall to 5,000,000 bytes.

entry.name: attachment_package_byte_count_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1459
entry.text: Specifies the maximum size for an attached package.

entry.name: attribute_count_xmlfirewallservice_help_1460
entry.text:
Defines the XML Firewall-specific maximum number of attributes that are associated with a given XML element. If firewall-specific parser limitations are enabled by the firewall-parser-limits command, the maximum attribute count assigned by this command overrides the value that is inherited from the XML Manager assigned to the XML Firewall.
count is an integer that sets the gateway-specific maximum number of attributes associated with an XML element. The default value is 128.
For example:
firewall-parser-limits on attribute-count 512 sets the maximum attribute count for the current XML Firewall to 512.

entry.name: attribute_count_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1460
entry.text: Sets maximum number of attributes per XML element.

entry.name: bytes_scanned_xmlfirewallservice_help_1461
entry.text:
Specifies the XML Firewall-specific maximum scope (bytes) of the XML parser scanning operation. If firewall-specific parser limitations are enabled by the firewall-parser-limits command, the maximum byte count assigned by this command overrides the value which is inherited from the XML Manager assigned to the XML Firewall. The document scan includes the document itself, plus any external DTDs, plus any text produced by expanding entity references.
byteCount is an integer that specifies the maximum scan in bytes. The default value is 4 MB. For example:
firewall-parser-limits on bytes-scanned 2097152 specifies a maximum document scan of 2 MB.

entry.name: bytes_scanned_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1461
entry.text: Specifies the maximum scope parsing.

entry.name: debug_mode_xmlfirewallservice_help_1462
entry.text:
Enables diagnostic mode. Transaction diagnostic mode is not intended for use in a production environment. Transaction diagnostic mode consumes significant resources that can slow down transaction processing.
on Enables diagnostic mode. The probe contains the number of transactions that is defined by the debug history. off (Default) Disables diagnostic mode. Alternatively, use the 'no' form of the command to disable diagnostic mode.
unbounded Enables diagnostic mode. The probe history contains 250 transactions. This mode consumes significant resources and slows down transaction processing.

entry.name: debug_mode_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1462
entry.text: Enables diagnostic mode

entry.name: debug_history_xmlfirewallservice_help_1463
entry.text: Controls the number of transactions that are saved when in diagnostic mode. This value limits the number of concurrent XML sessions. Valid values are in the range from 10 through 250. The default value is 25.

entry.name: debug_history_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1463
entry.text: Sets limit for transaction history

entry.name: debug_trigger_xmlfirewallservice_help_1464
entry.text:
Optionally use the following criteria to define one or more triggers. The Probe becomes active only for traffic that meets the criteria for one of the defined triggers.
PCRE to match client IP addresses Specify a PCRE-match to the client IP address. Requests from clients with matching IP addresses trigger debugging. To match any number of any character, specify ".*" (without quotes) instead of "*" (without quotes). PCRE to match inbound URL requests Specify a PCRE-match to an inbound URL. Requests from clients that match this expression trigger debugging. To match any number of any character, specify ".*" (without quotes) instead of "*" (without quotes). PCRE to match outbound URL responses Specify a PCRE-match for an outbound URL. Outbound requests that match this expression trigger debugging. To match any number of any character, specify ".*" (without quotes) instead of "*" (without quotes). Processing rule Specify one of the following values, based on direction, to trigger debugging: "Request" "Response" "Both" "Error" The value "Both" includes both requests and responses. PCRE to match names of rules Specify a PCRE match for the name of a processing rule. Names that match this expression trigger debugging. To match any number of any character, specify ".*" (without quotes) instead of "*" (without quotes). XPath expression Specify an XPath expression. Messages that have an element that match this expression trigger debugging.

entry.name: debug_trigger_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1464
entry.text: Defines triggers

entry.name: debugger_type_xmlfirewallservice_help_1465
entry.text: Indicates whether the probe operates in internal mode (the default) or operates in external mode. Always specify "internal".

entry.name: debugger_type_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1465
entry.text: Sets the probe mode

entry.name: debugger_url_xmlfirewallservice_help_1466
entry.text: Configures the URL for the probe when it operates in external mode.

entry.name: debugger_url_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1466
entry.text: Defines the external server URL

entry.name: default_param_namespace_xmlfirewallservice_help_1467
entry.text:
Specifies the default namespace for parameters provided via the CLI or WebGUI. name-space, if provided, replaces the system default value, http://www.datapower.com/param/config. Parameters specified with the parameter command, are assumed to belong to the default namespace space unless an explicit namespace is specified as part of the parameter command syntax. name-space is a URL that identifies the namespace to which parameters are assumed to belong. For example:
default-param-namespace http://www.enterprise.com/XML/ns The default namespace for parameters passed via the CLI or GUI

entry.name: default_param_namespace_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1467
entry.text: Specifies namespace for CLI/WebGUI parameters

entry.name: element_depth_xmlfirewallservice_help_1468
entry.text:
Defines the XML-Firewall-specific maximum depth of element nesting in an XML document. If firewall-specific parser limitations are enabled by the firewall-parser-limits command, the nesting limit that is assigned by this command overrides the value which is inherited from the XML Manager assigned to the XML Firewall.
depth is an integer that specifies the gateway-specific maximum depth of element nesting. The default value is 512.
For example:
firewall-parser-limits on element-depth 128 sets the maximum nesting depth for the current XML Firewall to 128.

entry.name: element_depth_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1468
entry.text: Defines the maximum depth of nested elements.

entry.name: firewall_parser_limits_xmlfirewallservice_help_1469
entry.text:
Enables or disables XML-Firewall-specific parser limitations for the current XML Firewall. Parser limitations guard against denial-of-service attacks that use malicious XML documents seeking to exhaust system resources.
With firewall-specific parser limitations enabled, the values specified by the attribute-count, bytes-scanned, and element-depth CLI commands (all available in XML Firewall Configuration Mode) are used to evaluate incoming XML documents.
With firewall-specific parser limitations disabled (the default condition), parser limitations, if any, are inherited from the XML Manager assigned to the XML Firewall.
on | off are mutually exclusive keywords that enable ("on") or disable ("off") XML Firewall-specific parser limitations.
For example:
firewall-parser-limits on enables firewall-specific parser limitations for the current XML firewall.

entry.name: firewall_parser_limits_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1469
entry.text: Enables/disables XML parser limits.

entry.name: external_references_xmlfirewallservice_help_1470
entry.text:
Defines the handling mode for input documents that contain external references. External references can be external entities or external DTD definitions. This setting overrides the value that is set by the XML Parser Limits command.
allow Allows and resolves external references. This is a security risk. forbid Forbids external references. An external reference causes the XML parser to stop. This setting is the default value. ignore Accesses and resolves external references, but replaces each for further processing with an empty string. This can be a security risk.

entry.name: external_references_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1470
entry.text: Handling mode for input documents that contain external references.

entry.name: fwcred_xmlfirewallservice_help_1471
entry.text:
Assigns a Firewall Credentials List, a list of certificates and keys, to the XML Firewall. name is the name of the Firewall Credentials List. For example:
fwcred FW1 assigns the Firewall Credentials List, FW1, to the current XML Firewall.

entry.name: fwcred_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1471
entry.text: Assigns a Firewall Credentials List

entry.name: local_address_xmlfirewallservice_help_1472
entry.text:
Specifies the IP interface address monitored by the XML Firewall for incoming client requests. ip-address is a dotted decimal IP address that designates a specific IP interface. 0 is a "wildcard" value that specifies all enabled IP interfaces. port-number identifies the specific port monitored by the XML Firewall. For example:
local-address 192.168.10.1 45000 binds the XML Firewall to the specified IP address:port

entry.name: local_address_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1472
entry.text: Specifies the XML Firewall local address

entry.name: max_message_size_xmlfirewallservice_help_1473
entry.text:
Specifies the maximum allowable size in kilobytes of a message. Enter a value in the range 0 - 2097151. The maximum message size limit applies to JSON, SOAP, XML, and non-XML messages. If the message type is pass-through, no limit is enforced.
length-in-kilobytes specifies the maximum allowable document size in kilobytes. In the absence of a specified value, this property defaults to 0. The value 0 indicates that all documents are accepted, regardless of size. If set, this property overrides any parser limits inherited by the service from the assigned XML manager. For example:
max-message-size 4 specifies a maximum length of 4,096 bytes

entry.name: max_message_size_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1473
entry.text: Specifies maximum message size

entry.name: max_node_size_xmlfirewallservice_help_1474
entry.text:
Specifies the maximum size of an XML node accepted by the current XML Firewall.
bytes is an integer that specifies the firewall-specific maximum number of bytes allowed in a single parsed XML node before the source XML document is considered malicious and dropped. The default value is 0, indicating that no size limitations are imposed on parsed XML nodes.
For example:
max-node-size 50000 specifies a maximum node size of 50,000 bytes for the current XML Firewall.

entry.name: max_node_size_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1474
entry.text: Specifies the maximum size of an XML node.

entry.name: max_prefixes_xmlfirewallservice_help_1475
entry.text:
Specifies the maximum number of distinct XML namespace prefixes in a document. This limit counts multiple prefixes that are defined for the same namespace. This limit does not count multiple namespaces that are defined in different parts of the input document under a single prefix.
number Specifies the maximum number of distinct XML namespace prefixes in a document. Enter a value in the range 0 - 262143. The default value is 1024. A value of 0 indicates that the limit is 1024.
For example: max-prefixes 40 Set the maximum number of distinct XML namespace prefixes to 40.

entry.name: max_prefixes_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1475
entry.text: Specifies the maximum number of distinct XML namespace prefixes in a document

entry.name: max_namespaces_xmlfirewallservice_help_1476
entry.text:
Specifies the maximum number of distinct XML namespace URIs in a document. This limit counts all XML namespaces, regardless of how many prefixes are used to declare them.
number Specifies the maximum number of distinct XML namespace URIs in a document. Enter a value in the range 0 - 65535. The default value is 1024. A value of 0 indicates that the limit is 1024.
For example: max-namespaces 40 Set the maximum number of distinct XML namespace URIs to 40.

entry.name: max_namespaces_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1476
entry.text: Specifies the maximum number of distinct XML namespace URIs in a document

entry.name: max_local_names_xmlfirewallservice_help_1477
entry.text:
This limit counts all local names, independent of the namespaces they are associated with.
number Specifies the maximum number of distinct XML local names in a document. Enter a value in the range 0 - 1048575. The default value is 60000. A value of 0 indicates that the limit is 60000.
For example: max-local-names 100 Set the maximum number of distinct XML local names to 100.

entry.name: max_local_names_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1477
entry.text: Specifies the maximum number of distinct XML local names in a document

entry.name: monitor_count_xmlfirewallservice_help_1478
entry.text:
Assigns an incremental monitor to the current XML firewall and activates the monitor. name is the name of the incremental monitor. For example:
monitor-count Squelch assigns the incremental monitor, Squelch, to the current XML Firewall

entry.name: monitor_count_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1478
entry.text: Assigns an incremental monitor to an XML Firewall

entry.name: monitor_duration_xmlfirewallservice_help_1479
entry.text:
Assigns a duration monitor to the current XML Firewall and activates the monitor. name is the name of the duration monitor. For example:
monitor-duration RateLimit-1 assigns the duration monitor, RateLimit-1, to the current XML Firewall

entry.name: monitor_duration_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1479
entry.text: Assigns a duration monitor to an XML Firewall

entry.name: monitor_processing_policy_xmlfirewallservice_help_1480
entry.text:
Set the monitor processing policy to one of the following options to determine how the system behaves when more than one monitor is attached to the service. May be either of: terminate-at-first-throttle: (the default) Monitors will execute in the order in which they are listed. After any monitor either shapes (buffers to delay) or rejects a message, no further monitors will execute. terminate-at-first-match Monitors will execute in the order in which they are listed. After any monitor matches a message and takes any action at all, no further monitors will execute. For example:
monitor-processing-policy terminate-at-first-match allows only the first matching monitor to execute.

entry.name: monitor_processing_policy_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1480
entry.text: Sets the behavior of multiple monitors

entry.name: monitor_service_xmlfirewallservice_help_1481
entry.text:
Assigns or removes a Count Monitor to the current XML Firewall. After completing the configuration of a message-count monitor, you can activate the monitor by assigning it to a service.
Use the "no" form of this command to remove the Service Level Monitor (SLM) assignment.
serviceMonitorName is the name of the SLM assigned to the service.
For example:
monitor-service wsdlPortSLM assigns the wsdlPortSLM SLM to the current service.
no monitor-count wsdlPortSLM removes the assignment of the wsdlPortSLM SLM from the current service.

entry.name: monitor_service_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1481
entry.text: Assigns or removes a count monitor

entry.name: parameter_xmlfirewallservice_help_1482
entry.text:
Passes a parameter:value pair to an XML Firewall, making the parameter:value pair available to all stylesheets used by the firewall. name is the name of the parameter, which may identify the namespace (delimited by curly braces) to which the parameter belongs. In the absence of an explicit namespace, the default namespace is assumed. value is the value of the parameter. For example:
parameter recipient ALICE assigns the value ALICE to the parameter recipient and passes the parameter:value pair to the current XML Firewall. The default namespace is used.
parameter {http://www.example.com}recipient BOB assigns the value BOB to the parameter recipient and passes the parameter:value pair to the current XML Firewall. An explicit namespace is identified.

entry.name: parameter_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1482
entry.text: Passes a parameter:value pair to an XML Firewall

entry.name: query_param_namespace_xmlfirewallservice_help_1483
entry.text:
Specifies the default namespace for parameters provided via URL query strings. name-space, if provided, replaces the default value, http://www.datapower.com/param/query. Parameters specified via a URL query string, are assumed to belong to the default namespace unless an explicit namespace is called out by the URL query string. name-space is a URL that identifies the namespace to which parameters are assumed to belong. For example:
query-param-namespace http://www.enterprise.com/XML/ns The default namespace for parameters passed via a URL query string

entry.name: query_param_namespace_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1483
entry.text: Specifies URL query parameter default namespace

entry.name: force_policy_exec_xmlfirewallservice_help_1484
entry.text: Bypasses the one way exchange pattern allowing processing policy rules to be executed even when the request or response body is empty. This feature is useful for RESTful web services when the request and response type are both set to XML, and some request/responses are bodiless depending on the HTTP method.

entry.name: force_policy_exec_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1484
entry.text: Forces processing policy execution

entry.name: raw_mode_xmlfirewallservice_help_1485
entry.text:
Identifies the incoming traffic streams -- both client and server originated as either SOAP (that is, encapsulated within a SOAP envelope), or "raw" XML. yes specifies XML traffic. no specifies SOAP traffic (the default). For example:
raw-mode yes characterizes all incoming traffic (both client and server originated) as unencapsulated XML

entry.name: raw_mode_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1485
entry.text: Characterizes client and server traffic

entry.name: remote_address_xmlfirewallservice_help_1486
entry.text:
Specifies the IP interface address of the web or application server supported by the XML Firewall, and/or specifies the firewall type. ip-address, %%dynamic%%, %%loopback%%, and "*" are mutually exclusive. ip-address is an dotted decimal IP address that, along with port-number, identifies a single, specific server interface:port pair. ip-address sets the XML Firewall type to static-backend, meaning that the firewall is supporting a single, specified server. %%dynamic%% is a keyword signifying all IP addresses. %%dynamic%% sets the XML Firewall type to dynamic-backend, meaning that the address of the target server is dynamically extracted from incoming client requests. %%loopback%% is a keyword that specifies a loopback configuration. %%loopback%% sets the XML Firewall type to loopback. * is synonymous with %%dynamic%%. * sets the XML Firewall type to dynamic-backend. port-number required with ip-address and otherwise not used, is a port number (within the range 0 to 65535) that, along with ip-address, identifies a single, specific server interface:port pair. For example:
remote-address %%dynamic%% specifies a dynamic-backend server that extracts actual server addresses from incoming client requests

entry.name: remote_address_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1486
entry.text: Specifies a server address or firewall type

entry.name: request_type_xmlfirewallservice_help_1487
entry.text:
Identifies the client request as either SOAP (that is, encapsulated within a SOAP envelope), unencapsulated XML, or as unprocessed. soap The client request as SOAP (the default). xml The client request as XML. unprocessed specifies that the client request is passed unchanged to the web/application server. JSON The client input as JavaScript Object Notation (JSON). The service validates the message as well-formed JSON, performs user-designated document processing, and forwards the resulting material to the server. User-designated document processing can be applied on the __JSONASJSONX context that represents the JSON input as JSONx.
For example:
request-type XML characterizes client requests as XML

entry.name: request_type_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1487
entry.text: Characterizes client requests

entry.name: response_type_xmlfirewallservice_help_1488
entry.text:
Identifies the server response as either SOAP (that is, encapsulated within a SOAP envelope), unencapsulated XML, or as unprocessed. soap The server response as SOAP (the default). xml The server response as XML. unprocessed specifies that the server response is passed unchanged to the web/application server. JSON The server input as JavaScript Object Notation (JSON). The service validates the message as well-formed JSON, performs user-designated document processing, and forwards the resulting material to the client. User-designated document processing can be applied on the __JSONASJSONX context that represents the JSON input as JSONx.
For example:
response-type XML characterizes server requests as XML

entry.name: response_type_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1488
entry.text: Characterizes server responses

entry.name: root_part_not_first_action_xmlfirewallservice_help_1489
entry.text:
Defines the action to take when the MIME message root part is not first.
abort Stops the transaction and return an error. buffer Buffers attachments before the root part into memory. Then processes the root part, buffered attachments, and subsequent attachments. process-in-order (Default) Processes the attachments and root part in the order that they appear in the original message. All parts are still processed in streaming mode even though only attachments after the root will be streamed from the network. This command is meaningful only when the value of either the request-attachments or response-attachments command is streaming.

entry.name: root_part_not_first_action_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1489
entry.text: Defines the action when the MIME message root part is not first

entry.name: soap_schema_url_xmlfirewallservice_help_1490
entry.text:
Assigns a schema used to validate incoming SOAP messages to the current XML Firewall. When an XML Firewall is in SOAP mode, either on the request or response side, it validates the incoming messages against a W3C Schema that defines a conforming SOAP message.
It is possible to customize which schema is used on a per-firewall basis by using this command; different schemas can be used to accommodate non-standard configurations or other special cases.
schemaURL the URL of the schema file to use to validate that SOAP messages conform to the SOAP schema. The default value is store:///schemas/soap-envelope.xsd.
For example:
soap-schema-url local://custom-soap-schema.xsd assigns the specified schema to the current XML Firewall.

entry.name: soap_schema_url_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1490
entry.text: Assigns a schema to validate incoming SOAP messages.

entry.name: ssl_xmlfirewallservice_help_1491
entry.text:
The TLS proxy profile is deprecated. Use a TLS client profile and a TLS server profile or TLS SNI server profile. Assigns a TLS Proxy Profile to the current XML Firewall. name The name of the TLS Proxy Profile. For example:
ssl TLS-1 Assigns the TLS-1 TLS Proxy Profile.

entry.name: ssl_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1491
entry.text: Deprecated - Assigns a TLS Proxy to an XML Firewall

entry.name: ssl_client_xmlfirewallservice_help_1492
entry.text:
Assigns a TLS client profile to the current XML Firewall. The TLS client profile secures connections between clients and remote servers. This profile is used only when the value set by the ssl-config-type command is "server" or "sni". If the value is "proxy", a TLS proxy must be used with forward crypto profile instead. sslClientProfile The TLS client profile assigned to the current XML Firewall. For example:
ssl-client sslClientProfile Assigns the sslClientProfile TLS client profile.

entry.name: ssl_client_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1492
entry.text: Assigns a TLS client profile to the XML Firewall.

entry.name: ssl_config_type_xmlfirewallservice_help_1493
entry.text:
Sets the type of TLS profile to use. Valid values include "proxy", "server", or "sni". The default value is "proxy", which uses a TLS proxy profile. Use "server" to specify a TLS server profile, and use "sni" to indicate a TLS SNI server profile.
For example:
ssl-config-type server Uses a TLS server profile.

entry.name: ssl_config_type_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1493
entry.text: Sets the type of TLS profile.

entry.name: ssl_server_xmlfirewallservice_help_1494
entry.text:
Assigns a TLS server profile to the XML Firewall. The XML Firewall uses this profile to establish a secure connection with clients. name The TLS server profile assigned to the XML Firewall. For example:
ssl-server highSec Assigns the highSec TLS server profile.

entry.name: ssl_server_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1494
entry.text: Assigns a TLS server profile to the XML Firewall.

entry.name: ssl_sni_server_xmlfirewallservice_help_1495
entry.text:
Assigns a TLS SNI server profile to the XML Firewall. The XML Firewall uses this profile to establish a secure connection with clients.
name The TLS SNI server profile to assign. For example:
ssl-sni-server highSec Assigns the highSec TLS SNI Server Profile.

entry.name: ssl_sni_server_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1495
entry.text: Assigns a TLS SNI server profile to the XML Firewall.

entry.name: stylesheet_policy_xmlfirewallservice_help_1496
entry.text:
Assigns a stylesheet policy to the current XML Firewall. name is the name of the stylesheet policy. For example:
stylepolicy DecryptInEncryptOut Assigns the DecryptInEncryptOut stylesheet policy.

entry.name: stylesheet_policy_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1496
entry.text: Assigns a stylesheet policy to an XML Firewall

entry.name: type_xmlfirewallservice_help_1497
entry.text:
Changes the XML Firewall type.
Do not use the type command to create a new XML Firewall. Use this command to recast the type of an existing XML Firewall.
dynamic-backend sets the XML Firewall type to dynamic-backend, meaning that the address of the target server is dynamically extracted from the client request using the set-target or xset-target extension element.
loopback-proxy sets the XML Firewall type to loopback.
static-backend sets the XML Firewall type to static-backend, meaning that the address of the target server is identified with the remote-address command.
For example:
type dynamic-backend changes the XML Firewall type to dynamic-backend.

entry.name: type_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1497
entry.text: Changes the XML Firewall type.

entry.name: urlrewrite_policy_xmlfirewallservice_help_1498
entry.text:
Assigns a URL Rewrite Policy to the current XML Firewall. name is the name of the URL Rewrite Policy. For example:
urlrewrite-policy RW-1 assigns the URL Rewrite Policy, RW-1, to the current XML Firewall

entry.name: urlrewrite_policy_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1498
entry.text: Assigns a URL Rewrite Policy to an XML Firewall

entry.name: wsdl_file_location_xmlfirewallservice_help_1499
entry.text:
Used when the WSDL Response Policy is "serve" to designate the local WSDL file to provide in response to .NET WSDL requests received via the http://domain.com/service?wsdl convention.
localWSDLFile specifies the location of the target WSDL file.
For example:
wsdl-response-policy serve wsdl-file-location local;///pseudoProxy.wsdl specifies that .NET WSDL requests are responded to by the current XML Firewall by serving the pseudoProxy.wsdl local file. Such requests are not forwarded to the back-end server.

entry.name: wsdl_file_location_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1499
entry.text: IDs the WSDL file served in response to requests.

entry.name: wsdl_response_policy_xmlfirewallservice_help_1500
entry.text:
Specifies XML Firewall response to receipt of a .NET WSDL request via the http://domain.com/service?wsdl convention.
"intercept and rewrite", "off", and "serve local file" are mutually exclusive keywords that specify the XML Firewall response to receipt of a .NET WSDL request.
intercept and rewrite specifies that the XML Firewall rewrites the wsdl:service/wsdl:port/soap:address field to point to the proxy.
off (the default) specifies that the XML Firewall does not touch .NET requests and responses.
serve local file specifies that the XML Firewall will serves a local WSDL file without forwarding the request to the backside server.
For example:
wsdl-response-policy serve wsdl-file-location local;///pseudoProxy.wsdl specifies that .NET WSDL requests are responded to by the current XML Firewall by serving the pseudoProxy.wsdl local file. Such requests are not forwarded to the back-end server.

entry.name: wsdl_response_policy_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1500
entry.text: Specifies XML Firewall response to requests.

entry.name: xml_manager_xmlfirewallservice_help_1501
entry.text:
Assigns an XML manager to the XML Firewall. xmlmgr. The target XML manager. For example:
xml-manager mgr1 assigns XML manager, mgr1, to the current XML Firewall

entry.name: xml_manager_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1501
entry.text: Assigns an XML manager to an XML Firewall

entry.name: request_attachments_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1502
entry.text: Set attachment processing mode for request

entry.name: response_attachments_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1503
entry.text: Set attachment processing mode for response

entry.name: front_attachment_format_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1504
entry.text: Front-side attachment format

entry.name: back_attachment_format_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1505
entry.text: Back-side attachment format

entry.name: mime_headers_xmlfirewallservice_help_1506
entry.text: Enables processing of MIME headers

entry.name: mime_headers_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1506
entry.text: Enables processing of MIME headers

entry.name: credential_charset_xmlfirewallservice_help_1507
entry.text:
Specifies the character encoding of the original basic authentication values. Basic authentication credentials are combined and base64 encoded in the authorization header of the request. The DataPower Gateway transcodes the contents of the authorization header to UTF-8. The default value is "protocol", which is ISO-8859-1. - protocol - ascii - big5 - cp1250 - cp1251 - cp1252 - cp1253 - cp1254 - cp1255 - cp1256 - cp1257 - cp1258 - euc_jp - euc_kr - gb18030 - gb2312 - iso2022_jp - iso2022_kr - iso8859_1 - iso8859_2 - iso8859_4 - iso8859_5 - iso8859_6 - iso8859_7 - iso8859_8 - iso8859_9 - iso8859_15 - sjis - tis620 - unicode_le - utf8
For example:
credential-charset utf8 Specifies UTF-8 for the character set encoding.

entry.name: credential_charset_xmlfirewallservice_descr_1507
entry.text: Character encoding of the original basic authentication values.

entry.name: local_address_mgmtinterface_help_1508
entry.text:
Identifies the local IP address-port pair that is monitored by the XML Management Interface for incoming management requests.
ipAddress is an IP address that, in conjunction with port number, identifies the XML Management Interface.
port-portNumber is an integer within the range 0 to 65535 that identifies the port number on the local device interface that monitors SOAP/XML management traffic.
For example:
local-address 10.10.13.7 1080 creates the XML Management Interface on the specified interface.

entry.name: local_address_mgmtinterface_descr_1508
entry.text: Specifies the local address.

entry.name: mode_mgmtinterface_help_1509
entry.text:
Use this command to list of management protocol and service endpoints to enabled for the XML Management Interface. Use a plus sign (+) character to combine. amp Enables the Appliance Management Protocol endpoint. Support for amp is enabled by default. any Enables processing of messages received on any URI for legacy applications. Support for "any" is enabled by default. slm Enables a management endpoint supporting the proprietary SLM protocol which provides a mechanism for data exchange and aggregation across multiple DataPower Gateway instances. Support for slm is enabled by default. soma Enables support for SOAP configuration Management. Support for soma is enabled by default. uddi-subscription (deprecated) Enables a UDDI subscription listener web service. This service endpoint must be configured in the UDDI registry as the subscription's service endpoint. Any number of subscriptions may use this endpoint. This endpoint processes subscription updates for all domains. v2004 Enables support for SOAP Management format. Support for v2004 is enabled by default. wsdm Enables a management endpoint supporting the WSDM 1.0 family of protocols. wsm Enables a management endpoint supporting the WS-Management family of protocols. wsrr-subscription Enables a WSRR subscription listener web service. This service endpoint must be configured in the WSRR registry as the subscription's service endpoint. Any number of subscriptions may use this endpoint. This endpoint processes subscription updates for all domains.
For example:
mode soma+any+slm+wsdm Enables access to the SOAP Configuration Management, proprietary, SLM, and WSDM endpoints.

entry.name: mode_mgmtinterface_descr_1509
entry.text: Specifies services granted access to XML Management Interface.

entry.name: port_mgmtinterface_help_1510
entry.text:
Specifies the port portion of the IP Address:Port pair monitored by the XML Management Service for incoming requests. portNumber is a integer that identifies the monitored port.
Note that the IP Address:Port pair is initially set with the local-address command. You can use the port command at a subsequent time to change the port portion of the IP Address: Port pair.
For example:
local-address 192.168.45.122 46000 ... ... ... port 46501 changes the monitored port from 46000 to 46501.

entry.name: port_mgmtinterface_descr_1510
entry.text: Identifies the monitored port number.

entry.name: slm_peering_mgmtinterface_help_1511
entry.text:
Specifies the frequency with which SLM peer group updates are issued through the XML Management Interface.
frequencySeconds is an integer that specifies the number of seconds between SLM peer group updates issued through the XML Management Interface. The default value is 10.
For example:
slm-peering 25 specifies a 25-second interval between the issuing of SLM peer group updates.

entry.name: slm_peering_mgmtinterface_descr_1511
entry.text: Specifies frequency of updates to peers.

entry.name: ssl_mgmtinterface_help_1512
entry.text:
The TLS proxy profile is deprecated. Use an TLS server profile or TLS SNI server profile. Assigns a TLS Proxy Profile to the XML Management Interface. Assignment of an TLS Proxy Profile is optional. The TLS Proxy Profile identified here must already exist in the current application domain.
Use the Global Configuration Mode sslproxy command to create a TLS Proxy Profile.
sslProxyProfileName The name of the existing TLS Proxy Profile assigned to the XML Management Interface.
For example: local-address 10.10.13.7 1080 ssl mgmtProxy Creates the XML Management Interface on the specified interface and assigns the mgmtProxy TLS Proxy Profile to the interface to enable TLS support.

entry.name: ssl_mgmtinterface_descr_1512
entry.text: Deprecated - Assigns an TLS proxy profile.

entry.name: user_agent_mgmtinterface_help_1513
entry.text:
Optionally assigns an HTTP User Agent to the XML Management Interface. By default, no User Agent is assigned to this interface. userAgentName The name of the HTTP User Agent assigned to the XML Management Interface.
For example:
user-agent restrictedAccess assigns the HTTP User Agent named restrictedAccess to the XML Management Interface.

entry.name: user_agent_mgmtinterface_descr_1513
entry.text: Assigns an HTTP User Agent.

entry.name: ws_management_mgmtinterface_help_1514
entry.text:
Enables or disables exposure of the XML Management Interface to the WS-Management protocol suite. If enabled, the device will expose a management endpoint to the WS-Management protocol suite. The exposed endpoint co-exists with the XML Management Interface. By default, this property is "off".
"on" and "off" are mutually exclusive keywords that enable (on) or disable (off) XML Management Interface WS-Management visibility.
For example:
local-address 10.10.13.7 1080 ws-management on ssl mgmtProxy creates the XML Management Interface on the specified interface, enables endpoint exposure to WS-Management protocols.
ws-management off restores the default condition; disables endpoint exposure to WS-Management protocols.

entry.name: loadbalancer_group_xmlmanager_help_1515
entry.text:
Assigns a load balancer group to an XML manager, thus making the load balancer group available to services objects supported by the manager. name The load balancer group assigned to the XML manager For example:
loadbalancer-group LBGroup-1 assigns load balancer group LBGroup-1 to the current XML manager

entry.name: loadbalancer_group_xmlmanager_descr_1515
entry.text: Assigns a load balancer group to an XML manager

entry.name: json_parser_settings_xmlmanager_help_1516
entry.text:
Assigns the specified JSON settings to the current XML manager so that the named JSON settings are applied when processing a JSON to JSONx conversion of the received body.
name The JSON settings that are assigned to the XML manager For example:
json-parser-settings JSONSettings-1 assigns the JSON settings named JSONSettings-1 to the current XML manager

entry.name: json_parser_settings_xmlmanager_descr_1516
entry.text: Assigns JSON settings to an XML manager

entry.name: dfdl_settings_reference_xmlmanager_help_1517
entry.text:
Assigns the specified DFDL settings to the current XML manager so that the named DFDL settings are applied when conducting a DFDL-Schema directed parse or serialize.
name The DFDL settings that are assigned to the XML manager For example:
dfdl-settings-reference DFDLSettings-1 assigns the DFDL settings named DFDLSettings-1 to the current XML manager

entry.name: dfdl_settings_reference_xmlmanager_descr_1517
entry.text: Assigns DFDL Settings to an XML manager

entry.name: ldap_pool_xmlmanager_help_1518
entry.text:
Assigns the specified LDAP Connection Pool to the current XML manager so when a stylesheet uses ldap, the assigned pool is used.
name The LDAP Connection Pool that will be assigned to the XML manager For example:
ldap-pool ldapconnpool-1 assigns the LDAP Connection pool named ldapconnpool-1 to the current XML manager

entry.name: ldap_pool_xmlmanager_descr_1518
entry.text: Assigns LDAP Connection Pool to an XML manager

entry.name: schedule_rule_xmlmanager_help_1519
entry.text:
Assigns a processing rule and optional associated frequency of execution to an XML manager. name The processing rule assigned to the XML manager frequency is an optional integer that specifies (in seconds) the interval between rule executions. If no argument is provided, the rule is executed a single time. For example:
schedule-rule Get-XML 30 assigns the processing rule, Get-XML, to the current XML manager for execution at 30-second intervals

entry.name: schedule_rule_xmlmanager_descr_1519
entry.text: Assigns a processing rule to an XML manager

entry.name: user_agent_xmlmanager_help_1520
entry.text:
Assigns an HTTP User Agent to an XML manager. name The HTTP User Agent assigned to the XML manager For example:
user-agent GetResourcefromSecSer assigns the user-agent, GetResourcefromSecSer, to the current XML manager

entry.name: user_agent_xmlmanager_descr_1520
entry.text: Assigns a User Agent to an XML manager

entry.name: bytes_scanned_kconfigparserlimits_help_1521
entry.text:
Sets a maximum value on the number of bytes to scan while parsing an XML document. The maximum value (which defaults to 4 Megabytes) includes external DTDs, external parsed entities, and input data produced by expanding entity references. A zero value indicates no limit. For example:
bytes-scanned 2097152 limits the XML parser scan to 2 Megabytes

entry.name: bytes_scanned_kconfigparserlimits_descr_1521
entry.text: Limits the number of scanned bytes

entry.name: element_depth_kconfigparserlimits_help_1522
entry.text:
Sets a maximum value on the element nesting depth in an XML document. By default, the maximum nesting depth is set to 512. A zero value indicates no limit. For example:
element-depth 128 limits the element nesting depth to 128.

entry.name: element_depth_kconfigparserlimits_descr_1522
entry.text: Limits the element nesting depth

entry.name: attribute_count_kconfigparserlimits_help_1523
entry.text:
Sets a maximum value on the number of attributes per element in an XML document. By default, the attribute count is set to 128. A zero value indicates no limit. For example:
attribute-count 64 limits the per-element attribute count to 64.

entry.name: attribute_count_kconfigparserlimits_descr_1523
entry.text: Limits the per-element attribute count

entry.name: external_references_kconfigparserlimits_help_1524
entry.text:
Defines the handling mode for input documents that contain external references. External references can be external entities or external DTD definitions.
allow Allows and resolves external references. This is a security risk. forbid Forbids external references. An external reference causes the XML parser to stop. This setting is the default value. ignore Accesses and resolves external references, but replaces each for further processing with an empty string. This can be a security risk.

entry.name: external_references_kconfigparserlimits_descr_1524
entry.text: Handling mode for input documents that contain external references.

entry.name: max_node_size_kconfigparserlimits_help_1525
entry.text:
Sets the maximum size that any XML node may consume in an XML document. By default, the maximum node size is is set to 32MB For example, to allow nodes with up to 64 MB:
max-node-size 64000000 limits the per-node size to 64 MB.

entry.name: max_node_size_kconfigparserlimits_descr_1525
entry.text: Limits the maximum size of any XML node

entry.name: max_prefixes_kconfigparserlimits_help_1526
entry.text:
Specifies the maximum number of distinct XML namespace prefixes in a document. This limit counts multiple prefixes that are defined for the same namespace. This limit does not count multiple namespaces that are defined in different parts of the input document under a single prefix.
number Specifies the maximum number of distinct XML namespace prefixes in a document. Enter a value in the range 0 - 262143. The default value is 1024. A value of 0 indicates that the limit is 1024.
For example: max-prefixes 40 Set the maximum number of distinct XML namespace prefixes to 40.

entry.name: max_prefixes_kconfigparserlimits_descr_1526
entry.text: Specifies the maximum number of distinct XML namespace prefixes in a document

entry.name: max_namespaces_kconfigparserlimits_help_1527
entry.text:
Specifies the maximum number of distinct XML namespace URIs in a document. This limit counts all XML namespaces, regardless of how many prefixes are used to declare them.
number Specifies the maximum number of distinct XML namespace URIs in a document. Enter a value in the range 0 - 65535. The default value is 1024. A value of 0 indicates that the limit is 1024.
For example: max-namespaces 40 Set the maximum number of distinct XML namespace URIs to 40.

entry.name: max_namespaces_kconfigparserlimits_descr_1527
entry.text: Specifies the maximum number of distinct XML namespace URIs in a document

entry.name: max_local_names_kconfigparserlimits_help_1528
entry.text:
This limit counts all local names, independent of the namespaces they are associated with.
number Specifies the maximum number of distinct XML local names in a document. Enter a value in the range 0 - 1048575. The default value is 60000. A value of 0 indicates that the limit is 60000.
For example: max-local-names 100 Set the maximum number of distinct XML local names to 100.

entry.name: max_local_names_kconfigparserlimits_descr_1528
entry.text: Specifies the maximum number of distinct XML local names in a document

entry.name: namespace_mapping_xpathroutingmap_help_1529
entry.text:
Adds xmlns data to the current XPath Routing map. prefix is the namespace prefix. uri specifies the namespace location. For example:
namespace-mapping SOAP http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/ specifies the schema for SOAP/1.1 envelope

entry.name: namespace_mapping_xpathroutingmap_descr_1529
entry.text: Adds xmlns data to an XPath Routing map

entry.name: rule_xpathroutingmap_help_1530
entry.text:
Defines a forwarding rule and adds it to the current XPath Routing Map. xpath-expression An XPath expression. Contents of candidate XML documents are evaluated are evaluated against this expression. Matching documents are forwarded to the destination. host In conjunction with the "port", identifies the destination of matching XML documents. port In conjunction with "host", identifies the destination of matching XML documents. "on" and "off" Mutually-exclusive keywords that specify the connection type to the destination. - "on" specifies a secure connection using TLS. - "off" specifies a non-secure connection. For example:
rule //request[dept='dev'] 127.0.0.1 8001 on rule //request[dept='sales'] 127.0.0.1 8002 on rule //request[dept='admin'] 192.168.1.100 8000 off rule true() 192.168.1.10 8000 on Adds four forwarding rules to the current XPath Routing map. - XML documents with a request element matching the XPath expression //request[dept='dev'] are forwarded to 127.0.0.1:8001 via a secure connection. - XML documents with a request element matching the XPath expression //request[dept='sales'] are forwarded to 127.0.0.1:8002 via a secure connection. - XML documents with a request element matching the XPath expression //request[dept='admin'] are forwarded to 192.168.1.100:8000 via an non-secure connection. - Because the XPath expression true() resolves to TRUE, all other documents are forwarded to 192.168.1.10:8000 via a secure connection.

entry.name: rule_xpathroutingmap_descr_1530
entry.text: Defines a rule for the XPath routing map

entry.text:
Create a named Import Package and enter Import Package Configuration Mode
packageName is the name of the Import Package to create
For example:
import-package Goodies Create import package named Goodies, and enter Import Package Configuration Mode

Perform import of package previously defined in Import Package Configuration mode

For example:

entry.name: destination_domain_importpackage_help_1554
entry.text:
Identify the local domain into which the Import Package is to be imported. In the absence of an explicit destination domain identification, the Import Package is imported into the current domain.
domainName is the name of the local application domain that will receive the current import package
For example:
destination-domain smokeTest identify the destination domain as smokeTest

entry.text: Specify local domain package will be imported into

entry.name: import_format_importpackage_help_1555
entry.text:
Specify the file format of the Import Package In the absence of an explicit format identification, the Import Package is assumed to be in ZIP format.
For example:

entry.name: overwrite_files_importpackage_help_1556
entry.text:
Specify that any files in the Import Package that have the same directory path and filename will overwrite existing files in the destination application domain
For example:
overwrite-files Specify that existing files within the destination domain will be overwritten by imported files of the same name

entry.name: overwrite_objects_importpackage_help_1557
entry.text:
Specify that any objects in the Import Package that have the same object type and object name will overwrite existing objects in the destination application domain
For example:
overwrite-objects Specify that existing objects within the destination domain will be overwritten by imported objects of the same type and name

entry.name: source_url_importpackage_help_1558
entry.text:
Specify the location of the Import Package. The import tool does not support SCP and SFTP URL protocols. All other URL protocols are available; for example, HTTP, HTTPS, or FTP.
For example:
source-url http://192.168.1.32:8088/Imports/Goodies identify the Import Package location

entry.text: Specify the location of the Import Package.

entry.name: backup_kglobalconfig_help_1559
entry.text:
Create a backup of the current domain, or of the domains listed on the command line
filename is the name of the file where the backup will be stored
domain is a list of the target domains to back up. In the absence of this argument, all domains are backed up. This argument is available only from the default domain.
For example:
backup Goodies.zip mydomain hisdomain Create a backup file named Goodies.zip, containing the domains mydomain and hisdomain

entry.name: backup_kglobalconfig_descr_1559
entry.text: Backs up the current domain, or the domains given on the command line

entry.name: secure_backup_kglobalconfig_help_1560
entry.text:
Create a secure backup of the complete configuration of the DataPower Gateway with the following exceptions. Keys on the HSM. The password for IPMI users, which are in the Baseboard Management Controller (BMC).
cert Specifies the certificate to encrypt the secure backup. You cannot use a certificate that contains ECDSA keys because the secure backup does not support ECDSA keys. When the certificate contains ECDSA keys, the system returns an error.
destination Specifies the URL of the target directory for the backup files. When you create the backup files on the DataPower Gateway, securely copy these files to a protected, remote location. The supported file system locations are as follows. "local:" "temporary:" The supported remote location is an FTP server. For the FTP protocol, use the following format. ftp://user:password@host
iscsi The iSCSI protocol is deprecated. Specify "" as the value.
include-raid Specifies whether the RAID device is backed up. The default value is "on". If possible, use another method to back up RAID data. Backing up this data can require a significant amount of time.
Example
Create a secure backup with the following characteristics. - Encrypt with the "myCert" certificate. - Store in the "temporary:///myBackupDir/" directory. - Exclude RAID data. secure-backup myCryptoCert temporary:///myBackupDir/ off

entry.name: secure_backup_kglobalconfig_descr_1560
entry.text: Create a backup to restore the complete configuration to another DataPower Gateway.

entry.name: secure_restore_kglobalconfig_help_1561
entry.text:
Restores a DataPower Gateway from a backup that you created with the "secure-backup" command. You must use the secure backup-restore process among products that are at the same firmware level and features. The following conditions apply. - When the backup image contains RAID data, the target must have equal or greater RAID volume than the source. Otherwise, the RAID data is not restored. - When the backup image contains data related to features, the target must have the same features. Otherwise the restore fails. - You can use a backup image from a Type 8436 to restore a Type 8436, Type 8441, or Type 8496. - You can use a backup image from a Type 8441 to restore a Type 8436, Type 8441, or Type 8496. - You can use a backup image from a Type 8496 to restore a Type 8436, Type 8441, or Type 8496. - You can use a backup image from a nonphysical DataPower Gateway to restore a nonphysical DataPower Gateway. The following cases are supported. - Use a production backup image to restore a production, nonproduction, or developers system. - Use a nonproduction backup image to restore a production, nonproduction, or developers system. - Use a developers backup image to restore a production, nonproduction, or developers system. - You cannot use a backup image from a physical DataPower Gateway to restore a nonphysical DataPower Gateway. - You cannot use a backup image from a nonphysical DataPower Gateway to restore a physical DataPower Gateway.
cred Specifies the identification credentials to decrypt the secure backup.
source Specifies the URL of the source directory to restore the backup files from. The following protocols are supported. "local:" "temporary:" "ftp:" validate Indicates whether to validate the backup files or restore from the backup files. "on" validates the backup but does not restore from the backup files. "off" restores from the backup files. This setting is the default value. backup-machine-type Specifies the machine type model where the backup image was created. Open the manifest of the backup image to find the machine type model. The following list shows the machine type model values for most, if not all, DataPower products.
Product name Machine type model --------------------------------------- ------------------ Type 8436 DataPower Gateway without HSM 843652X Type 8441 DataPower Gateway without HSM 844152X Type 8496 DataPower Gateway without HSM 849652X Type 8436 DataPower Gateway with HSM 843653X Type 8441 DataPower Gateway with HSM 844153X Type 8496 DataPower Gateway with HSM 849653X DataPower Gateway for VMware 5725T09 DataPower Gateway for Linux 5725T09C
Examples Decrypt the backup with the myCred certificate from the temporary:///myBackupDir/ directory, which overwrites the configuration. secure-restore myCred temporary:///myBackupDir Decrypt the backup from a Type 8436 with the myCred credential from the temporary:///myBackupDir/ directory, which overwrites the configuration. secure-restore myCred temporary:///myBackupDir 843652X Decrypt the backup from a Type 8441 with the myCred credential from the temporary:///myBackupDir/ directory, which overwrites the configuration. secure-restore myCred temporary:///myBackupDir 844152X Decrypt the backup from a Type 8496 with the myCred credential from the temporary:///myBackupDir/ directory, which overwrites the configuration. secure-restore myCred temporary:///myBackupDir 849652X

entry.name: secure_restore_kglobalconfig_descr_1561
entry.text: Restores a DataPower Gateway from a secure backup.

entry.name: source_nfs_poller_kglobalconfig_help_1562
entry.text:
Enters NFS File Poller Handler Configuration Mode and creates a named NFS File Poller Handler. nfsFilePollerName identifies the newly created file poller.
Example: source-nfs-poller nfsFilePoller-1

entry.name: source_nfs_poller_kglobalconfig_descr_1562
entry.text: Enters NFS File Poller Handler Configuration Mode

entry.name: target_dir_nfsfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_help_1563
entry.text:
Specifies a directory to poll. The path must end in a slash denoting a directory.
Examples:
target-dir "dpnfs://static-mount-name/path/" target-dir "ftp://user:password@host:port/path/path/" target-dir "ftp://user:password@host:port/%%2Fpath/path/"

entry.name: target_dir_nfsfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_descr_1563
entry.text: Specify the directory to poll.

entry.name: delay_time_nfsfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_help_1564
entry.text: Specifies how many milliseconds to wait after the completion of one polling sequence before starting the next. This is not a polling interval. It is the delay between poll sequences. A polling sequence is defined as the actual polling action plus the time it takes to complete all transactions started by that poll action. The next polling action will take place the specified number of milliseconds after the last transaction that was started by the previous poll action completes.

entry.name: delay_time_nfsfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_descr_1564
entry.text: Specifies the delay between polling sequences.

entry.name: match_pattern_nfsfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_help_1565
entry.text:
Specifies the PCRE to use to match the contents of the directory being polled.
Examples:
match-pattern "(.*)\.input$" match-pattern ".*\.input$"

entry.name: match_pattern_nfsfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_descr_1565
entry.text: Input file match pattern

entry.name: max_transfers_per_poll_nfsfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_descr_1566
entry.text: Specifies the maximum number of files to be transferred per poll cycle.

entry.name: processing_rename_pattern_nfsfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_help_1567
entry.text:
Specifies the PCRE to use to rename an input file that is to be processed. The rename pattern should be configured in conjunction with "match-pattern" if PCRE back references are to be used.
Example: processing-rename-match-pattern "$1.processing"

entry.name: processing_rename_pattern_nfsfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_descr_1567
entry.text: Specifies the processing file renaming pattern.

entry.name: success_delete_nfsfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_help_1568
entry.text: Specifies whether or not to delete the input (or processing renamed) files after successful processing. Default value is off.

entry.name: success_delete_nfsfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_descr_1568
entry.text: Deletes input file on success

entry.name: success_rename_pattern_nfsfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_help_1569
entry.text:
Specifies the PCRE to use to rename an input file that was successful processing. This pattern should be configured in conjunction with "match-pattern" if PCRE back references are to be used.
This option is ignored if success-delete is on.
Example: success-rename-pattern "$1.processed"

entry.name: success_rename_pattern_nfsfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_descr_1569
entry.text: Specifies the success file renaming pattern

entry.name: error_delete_nfsfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_help_1570
entry.text: Specifies whether or not to delete the input (or processing renamed) files after a processing error. Default value is off.

entry.name: error_delete_nfsfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_descr_1570
entry.text: Deletes input file on error

entry.name: error_rename_pattern_nfsfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_help_1571
entry.text:
Specifies the PCRE to use to rename an input file after a processing error. This should be configured in conjunction with "match-pattern" if PCRE back references are to be used.
This option is ignored if error-delete is on.
Example: error-rename-pattern "$1.error"

entry.name: error_rename_pattern_nfsfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_descr_1571
entry.text: Specifies the error file renaming pattern

entry.name: result_nfsfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_help_1572
entry.text: Specifies whether or not to create a result file for transaction. Default value is on.

entry.name: result_nfsfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_descr_1572
entry.text: Creates a result file

entry.name: result_name_pattern_nfsfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_help_1573
entry.text:
Specifies the PCRE to use to name a result file. This pattern should be configured in conjunction with "match-pattern" if PCRE back references are to be used.
This option is ignored if result is off.
Example: result-name-pattern "$1.result"

entry.name: result_name_pattern_nfsfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_descr_1573
entry.text: Specifies the result file renaming pattern

entry.name: processing_seize_timeout_nfsfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_help_1574
entry.text:
This property allows handling the failure of a poller when multiple DataRouters are polling the same target. If another DataRouter renames a file and then does not process within the specified number of seconds, this system will try to take over processing.
If a file matches the processing seize pattern and the timestamp portion of the file is older than "processing-seize-timeout" plus the current time, the file will be claimed by this poller, renamed (in order to give the file a new timestamp), and processed locally (presuming that the rename succeeds.)
Setting the timeout to 0 (the default) disables this behavior.

entry.name: processing_seize_timeout_nfsfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_descr_1574
entry.text: Time to wait to process a file in the processing state

entry.name: processing_seize_pattern_nfsfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_help_1575
entry.text:
Specifies the PCRE to use to find files that were renamed to indicate a "being processed" state but processing never completed.
If the "processing-rename-pattern" is: "$1.processing" the "processing-seize-pattern" should be: "(.*)\.processing\.([^.]*)\.([0-9]*)"
Example: processing-seize-pattern "(.*)\.processing\.([^.]*)\.([0-9]*)"

entry.name: processing_seize_pattern_nfsfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_descr_1575
entry.text: Specifies the name pattern to find files being processed

entry.name: xml_manager_nfsfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_help_1576
entry.text:
Assigns an XML manager to the current NFS Poller. "xmlManagerName" identifies the XML manager assigned to the NFS Poller.
Example: xml-manager mgr-1

entry.name: xml_manager_nfsfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_descr_1576

entry.name: success_rename_pattern_ftpfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_help_1583

entry.name: error_delete_ftpfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_descr_1584
entry.text: Deletes input file on error

entry.name: error_rename_pattern_ftpfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_help_1585
entry.text:
Specifies the PCRE to use to rename an input file after a processing error. This pattern should be configured in conjunction with "match-pattern" if PCRE back references are to be used.
This option is ignored if error-delete is on.
Example: error-rename-pattern "$1.error"

entry.name: error_rename_pattern_ftpfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_descr_1585
entry.text: Specifies the error file renaming pattern

entry.name: result_ftpfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_help_1586
entry.text: Specifies whether or not to create a result file for transaction. Default value is on.

entry.name: result_ftpfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_descr_1586
entry.text: Creates a result file after processing an input file

entry.name: result_name_pattern_ftpfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_help_1587
entry.text:
Specifies the PCRE to use to name a result file. This pattern should be configured in conjunction with "match-pattern" if PCRE back references are to be used.
This option is ignored if result is off.
Example: result-name-pattern "$1.result"

entry.name: result_name_pattern_ftpfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_descr_1587
entry.text: Specifies the result file renaming pattern

entry.name: processing_seize_timeout_ftpfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_help_1588
entry.text:
This property allows for handling the failure of a poller when multiple DataRouters are polling the same target. If another DataRouter renames a file and does not process it within the specified number of seconds, this system will try to take over processing.
If a file matches the processing seize pattern and the timestamp portion of the file is older than "processing-seize-timeout" plus the current time, the file will be claimed by this poller, renamed (in order to give the file a new timestamp), and processed locally (presuming that the rename succeeds.)
Setting the timeout to 0 (the default) disables this behavior.

entry.name: processing_seize_timeout_ftpfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_descr_1588
entry.text: Specifies the time to wait before processing a file in the processing state

entry.name: processing_seize_pattern_ftpfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_help_1589
entry.text:
Specifies the PCRE to use to find files that were renamed to the "being processed" state but processing never completed.
If the "processing-rename-pattern" is: "$1.processing" then the "processing-seize-pattern" should be: "(.*)\.processing\.([^.]*)\.([0-9]*)"
Example: processing-seize-pattern "(.*)\.processing\.([^.]*)\.([0-9]*)"

entry.name: processing_seize_pattern_ftpfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_descr_1589
entry.text: Specifies the file name pattern to find files being processed

entry.name: xml_manager_ftpfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_help_1590
entry.text:
Assigns an XML manager to the current FTP Poller. "xmlManagerName" identifies the XML manager assigned to the FTP Poller.
Example: xml-manager mgr-1

entry.name: xml_manager_ftpfilepollersourceprotocolhandler_descr_1590
entry.text: Assigns an XML manager to the FTP Poller

entry.name: enforcement_mode_policyattachments_help_1596
entry.text:
filter Creates a configuration where the service only checks the syntax of the original message to verify that the message meets security requirements. The service does not alter the original message.
enforce Creates a configuration where the service might alter the original message to meet security requirements.
If a client request or server response does not satisfy policy, the service rejects the message. A rejection triggers error handling. For example, if WS-Policy requires an encrypted response, filter behavior causes the service to reject the response and to trigger error handling for an unencrypted response.
If a client request or server response does not satisfy policy and the configuration defines the required policy parameters, the service modifies the original message to satisfy policy. For example, if WS-Policy requires an encrypted response, enforce behavior causes the service to encrypt the response. If the configuration does not define the required policy parameters to encrypt the response, the mode switches to filter behavior and triggers error handling for an unencrypted response.

entry.name: enforcement_mode_policyattachments_descr_1596
entry.text: Defines how the configuration uses WS-Policy to ensure that messages meet security requirements.

entry.name: sla_enforcement_mode_policyattachments_help_1597
entry.text:
allow-if-no-sla When allow is specified, all transactions are processed and any applicable Service Level Definition policies and Anonymous SLA policies are enforced. This is the default.
reject-if-no-sla When reject is selected, transactions must match at least one SLA policy to be processed. If there are no matches, the transaction is rejected with the message 'Rejected by policy. (from client)'.

entry.name: sla_enforcement_mode_policyattachments_descr_1597
entry.text: Controls the application of SLA Policies to transactions.

entry.name: b2bp_archive_purge_now_kglobalconfig_help_1602
entry.text:
Performs a manual archive operation to archive and purge B2B persistent data. The data is archived or purged according to the archive configuration for each B2B gateway.
archivePurgeAllTransactions Whether to archive all transactions or only completed transactions, which includes AS MDN receipt and ebMS Acknowledgment Messages.
archivePurgeAllGateways Whether to archive for all B2B gateways or a specific one. In the default domain, all B2B gateways on the DataPower Gateway can be archived. In an application domain, all B2B gateways in this domain can be archived. If "off", you must specify the name of the B2B gateway. archivePurgeUnexpiredEBMSTransactions Whether to archive unexpired ebMS transactions. A message is expired if the TimeStamp of receiving or sending plus its PersistDuration (found in the PartnerProfile configuration) is less than the current TimeStamp of archiving action. If "off", unexpired ebMS transactions are not archived. This option does not apply to AS transactions.
Examples:
b2bp-archive-purge-now on on Archives all AS and ebMS transactions in all B2B gateways on the DataPower Gateway when issued from the default domain or all B2B gateways when issued from an application domain. Because archivePurgeUnexpiredEBMSTransactions is "off", unexpired ebMS transactions are not archived. b2bp-archive-purge-now on on "" on Archives all AS and ebMS transactions in all B2B gateways on the DataPower Gateway when issued from the default domain or all B2B gateways when from an application domain. Unexpired ebMS transactions are archived. Note that if archivePurgeAllGateways is "on", the name of the B2B gateway is enclosed in double quotes "" and disregarded. b2bp-archive-purge-now on off gateway-1 Archives all AS transactions and all unexpired ebMS transactions for the gateway-1 B2B gateway. b2bp-archive-purge-now on off gateway-1 on Archives all AS transactions and all ebMS transactions, including expired and unexpired ebMS transactions for the gateway-1 B2B Gateway. b2bp-archive-purge-now off off gateway-1 Archives only completed AS and completed unexpired ebMS transactions for the gateway-1 B2B gateway. b2bp-archive-purge-now off off gateway-1 on Archives only completed AS and completed ebMS transactions, including expired and unexpired ebMS transactions, from the gateway-1 B2B gateway.

entry.name: b2bp_archive_purge_now_kglobalconfig_descr_1602
entry.text: Perform an archive operation to backup B2B persistent data.

entry.name: b2bp_ha_switch_primary_kglobalconfig_help_1603
entry.text: Switches the state of the B2B Persistence Store to Primary. This action should be done on initial configuration of B2B High Availability on the primary DataPower Gateway. It can be done after configuration to manually switch the state of the DataPower Gateway to primary.

entry.name: b2bp_ha_switch_primary_kglobalconfig_descr_1603
entry.text: Switches the state of the B2B Persistence Store to primary.

entry.name: b2bp_initialize_secondary_kglobalconfig_help_1604
entry.text: Initializes the B2B Persistence store for the high availability secondary DataPower Gateway. This command should be run when configuring B2B high availability. During initial setup, the persistence store on the secondary DataPower Gateway must synchronize with the persistence store on the primary DataPower Gateway. To synchronize, the persistence store on the secondary DataPower Gateway must first be initialized.

entry.name: b2bp_initialize_secondary_kglobalconfig_descr_1604
entry.text: Initialize B2B high availability secondary.

entry.name: ebms2_ping_kglobalconfig_help_1605
entry.text:
Send an ebMS2 Ping message to external partner.
FromPartnerId The 'From' PartyId in ebMS2 Ping message. ToPartnerId The 'To' PartyId in the ebMS2 Ping message. CPAId The CPA ID to use in the conversation. ebMS2URL The target URL to send the the ebMS2 Ping message.
Example:
ebms2-ping Alice Bob 12345 ebms2://example.com:58080/pingService Generate an ebMS2 Ping message with CPAId '12345', and send the Ping message to an external partner whose business id is 'Bob'. Notes: The FromPartnerId must belongs to an internal partner profile. The ToPartnerId must belongs to an external partner profile.

entry.name: ebms2_ping_kglobalconfig_descr_1605
entry.text: Send an ebMS2 Ping message to external partner.

entry.name: match_upt_dmconfigmodifytype_help_1606
entry.text:
A match statement takes the following general form: Address / Domain / Resource [?Name=resource-name& Property=property-name&Value=property-value]
Address Device Address. Specifies IP address or host alias. The value (*) matches all IP addresses. Domain Application Domain. The name of the application domain. The value (*) matches all domains. Resource Resource Type. The name of the resource type. The value (*) matches all resource types. Name=resource-name An additional specification field, such as "Name". Limits the match statement to resources of the specified name. Use a PCRE to select groups of resource instances. For example, "Name=foo(*)" would match all resources with names that start with "foo". Property=property-name Property Name. The name of the configuration property. Limits the match statement to resources of the specified property. If change specified, set property-name to null string. Value=property-value Property Value. Specifies the value for the configuration property. This property limits the match statement to resources with the specified property value.

entry.name: match_upt_dmconfigmodifytype_descr_1606
entry.text: Set the match statement

entry.text: Set the property name to modify.

entry.text: Set the modify type. Valid values are add, delete, or change.
