entry.name: service_quiesce_kglobalconfig_help_1610
entry.text:
Transitions the operational state of a service or handler to down in a controlled manner.
If quiescing a service, all handlers associated with the service are also placed in the down operational state. The handlers that are quiesced as a result of the service quiesce are not available for use in other services.
type Specifies the type of the service or protocol handler. Use one of the following types.
- B2BGateway -- Specifies a B2B Gateway - HTTPService -- Specifies an HTTP service - MultiProtocolGateway -- Specifies a Multi-Protocol Gateway - SSLProxyService -- Specifies an TLS Proxy - TCPProxyService -- Specifies a TCP Proxy - WebAppFW -- Specifies a Web Application Firewall - WSGateway -- Specifies a Web Service Proxy - XMLFirewallService -- Specifies an XML Firewall - AS1PollerSourceProtocolHandler -- Specifies an AS1 handler - AS2SourceProtocolHandler -- Specifies an AS2 handler - AS3SourceProtocolHandler -- Specifies an AS3 handler - EBMS2SourceProtocolHandler -- Specifies an ebMS2 handler - FTPFilePollerSourceProtocolHandler -- Specifies an FTP Poller handler - FTPServerSourceProtocolHandler -- Specifies an FTP Server handler - HTTPSourceProtocolHandler -- Specifies an HTTP handler - HTTPSSourceProtocolHandler -- Specifies an HTTPS handler - IMSConnectSourceProtocolHandler -- Specifies an IMS Connect handler - MQSourceProtocolHandler - Specifies an IBM MQ handler - NFSFilePollerSourceProtocolHandler -- Specifies an NFS Poller handler - POPPollerSourceProtocolHandler -- Specifies an POP Poller handler - SFTPFilePollerSourceProtocolHandler -- Specifies an SFTP Poller handler - SSHServerSourceProtocolHandler -- Specifies an SFTP Server handler - XTCProtocolHandler -- Specifies a Stateful Raw XML handler - StatelessTCPSourceProtocolHandler -- Specifies a Stateless Raw XML handler - TibcoEMSSourceProtocolHandler -- Specifies a TIBCO EMS handler - WASJMSSourceProtocolHandler -- Specifies a WebSphere JMS handler name Specifies the name of the service or protocol handler. timeout Specifies the length of time in seconds to wait for all transactions to complete. Specify a long enough timeout value to handle long living transactions. The minimum is 60.
delay Specifies the interval of time in seconds to wait before initiating the quiesce action. This could be used in self-balancing where the intent to quiesce is propagated to the distributor before initiating the quiesce action. This allows new connections to be routed to other nodes before quiesce is initiated. Specify a long enough time to propagate to the distributor. In general a value less than 10 seconds should be sufficient. The minimum is 0 (quiesce immediately).
For example:
Quiesces the HTTP-12 HTTP handler. Waits for at most 90 seconds for all transactions to complete and proceeds to notify quiesce complete.
service-quiesce HTTPSourceProtocolHandler HTTP-12 90

entry.name: service_quiesce_kglobalconfig_descr_1610
entry.text: Quiesces a service or handler

entry.name: domain_quiesce_kglobalconfig_help_1611
entry.text:
Transitions the operational state of a domain and all associated services and handlers to down in a controlled manner. The default domain cannot be quiesced.
name Specifies the name of an existing domain to be quiesced. timeout Specifies the length of time in seconds to wait for all transactions to complete. Specify a long enough timeout value to handle long living transactions. The minimum is 60.
delay Specifies the interval of time in seconds to wait before initiating the quiesce action. This could be used in self-balancing where the intent to quiesce is propagated to the distributor before initiating the quiesce action. This allows new connections to be routed to other nodes before quiesce is initiated. Specify a long enough time to propagate to the distributor. In general a value less than 10 seconds should be sufficient. The minimum is 0 (quiesce immediately).
For example:
Quiesces the abc domain and quiesces all services and handlers in the abc domain. Waits for at most 60 seconds for all transactions to complete and proceeds to notify quiesce complete.
domain-quiesce abc 60

entry.name: domain_quiesce_kglobalconfig_descr_1611
entry.text: Quiesces a domain

entry.name: appliance_quiesce_kglobalconfig_help_1612
entry.text:
Transitions the operational state of all domains, except the default domain, all services, and all handlers to down in a controlled manner. The command does not quiesce the management interfaces such as the Telnet service, the Web Management Interface, the XML Management Interface, and the like.
timeout Specifies the length of time in seconds to wait for all transactions to complete. Specify a long enough timeout value to handle long living transactions. The minimum is 60.
delay Specifies the interval of time in seconds to wait before initiating the quiesce action. This could be used in self-balancing where the intent to quiesce is propagated to the distributor before initiating the quiesce action. This allows new connections to be routed to other nodes before quiesce is initiated. Specify a long enough time to propagate to the distributor. In general a value less than 10 seconds should be sufficient. The minimum is 0 (quiesce immediately).
For example:
appliance-quiesce 60 Quiesces the DataPower Gateway. Waits for at most 60 seconds for all transactions to complete and proceeds to notify quiesce complete.

entry.name: appliance_quiesce_kglobalconfig_descr_1612
entry.text: Quiesces the DataPower Gateway

entry.name: service_unquiesce_kglobalconfig_help_1613
entry.text:
Places the quiesced service or handler in the up operational state.
type Specifies the type of the service or protocol handler. Use one of the following types. - B2BGateway -- Specifies a B2B Gateway - HTTPService -- Specifies an HTTP service - MultiProtocolGateway -- Specifies a Multi-Protocol Gateway - SSLProxyService -- Specifies an TLS Proxy - TCPProxyService -- Specifies a TCP Proxy - WebAppFW -- Specifies a Web Application Firewall - WSGateway -- Specifies a Web Service Proxy - XMLFirewallService -- Specifies an XML Firewall - AS1PollerSourceProtocolHandler -- Specifies an AS1 handler - AS2SourceProtocolHandler -- Specifies an AS2 handler - AS3SourceProtocolHandler -- Specifies an AS3 handler - EBMS2SourceProtocolHandler -- Specifies an ebMS2 handler - FTPFilePollerSourceProtocolHandler -- Specifies an FTP Poller handler - FTPServerSourceProtocolHandler -- Specifies an FTP Server handler - HTTPSourceProtocolHandler -- Specifies an HTTP handler - HTTPSSourceProtocolHandler -- Specifies an HTTPS handler - IMSConnectSourceProtocolHandler -- Specifies an IMS Connect handler - MQSourceProtocolHandler -- Specifies an IBM MQ handler - NFSFilePollerSourceProtocolHandler -- Specifies an NFS Poller handler - POPPollerSourceProtocolHandler -- Specifies an POP Poller handler - SFTPFilePollerSourceProtocolHandler -- Specifies an SFTP Poller handler - SSHServerSourceProtocolHandler -- Specifies an SFTP Server handler - XTCProtocolHandler -- Specifies a Stateful Raw XML handler - StatelessTCPSourceProtocolHandler -- Specifies a Stateless Raw XML handler - TibcoEMSSourceProtocolHandler -- Specifies a TIBCO EMS handler - WSSJMSProtocolHandler -- Specifies a WebSphere JMS handler name Specifies the name of the service or protocol handler.
For example:
Unquiesces the HTTP-12 HTTP handler. service-unquiesce HTTPSourceProtocolHandler HTTP-12

entry.name: service_unquiesce_kglobalconfig_descr_1613
entry.text: Unquiesces the quiesced service or handler

entry.name: domain_unquiesce_kglobalconfig_help_1614
entry.text:
Places the quiesced domain in the up operational state. All quiesced services and handlers associated with the quiesced domain are also placed in the up operational state.
name Specifies the name of a quiesced domain.
For example:
Unquiesces the quiesced abc domain and unquiesces all services and handlers in the abc domain.
domain-unquiesce abc

entry.name: domain_unquiesce_kglobalconfig_descr_1614
entry.text: Unquiesces the quiesced domain

entry.name: appliance_unquiesce_kglobalconfig_help_1615
entry.text:
Places the quiesced domains, services, and handlers in the up operational state. The running configuration reflects any changes that were applied while the DataPower Gateway was in the quiesced state.
For example:
Unquiesces the DataPower Gateway.
appliance-unquiesce

entry.name: appliance_unquiesce_kglobalconfig_descr_1615
entry.text: Unquiesces the DataPower Gateway

entry.name: client_known_host_sshclientprofile_help_1616
entry.text: Defines an SSH peer as an SSH client known host. The host specified and its host key is added to the SSH client known host list. When strict host key checking is on, the SSH client connects only to known hosts with valid SSH host keys that are stored in the known hosts list. Host keys not listed in the known host list are rejected.

entry.name: client_known_host_sshclientprofile_descr_1616
entry.text: Add SSH Known Host

entry.name: packet_capture_advanced_kglobalconfig_help_1617
entry.text:
Initiates a packet-capture session on the specified interface. Packet-capture data is stored in the pcap format.
name Specifies the name of the interface for the packet capture. There are two special keywords. "lo" for the software loopback interface. "all" for all Ethernet interfaces. file Specifies the file name for the packet capture. seconds Specifies the maximum duration of the packet-capture session in seconds. Enter a value in the range 5 - 86400. The special value of -1 indicates that the packet capture is continuous and completes only when the you enter the "no packet-capture-advanced" command. KB Specifies the maximum size of the file in KB. Enter a value in the range 10 - 500000. packet-size Optionally specifies the maximum size of each captured packet of data in bytes. Enter a value in the range 20 - 9000. The special value of -1 sets the length to the default value of 9000 bytes, which is the maximum transmission unit (MTU) for Ethernet interfaces. The default value ensures that the entire packet is captured. expression Optionally specifies the expression that filters the packet capture. Enclose the expression in double quotation marks. ssl-key-log Indicates whether to capture the TLS master secret in the "logtemp:///sslkeyfile.log" file. When you capture the master secret, you can use a network protocol analyzer to decrypt TLS encrypted traffic to help with problem determination. on Captures the master secret. During the packet capture session, all TLS sessions have their master secret logged. off Does not capture the master secret. This setting is the default value.
For example:
packet-capture-advanced eth0 temporary:///Eth0Trace 60 250 1000 Starts a packet-capture session on the "eth0" interface Packet-capture data is written to the "temporary:///Eth0Trace" file. The session stops after 1 minute or when the file contains 250 KB of data, whichever comes first. Only the first 1000 bytes of data from each packet are captured. packet-capture-advanced all temporary:///allTrace -1 250 -1 Starts a continuous advanced packet-capture session on all interfaces. The session stops when the file contains 250 KB of data or when you enter the "no packet-capture-advanced" command ("no packet-capture-advanced all temporary:///allTrace"). The maximum packet size of -1 indicates the default value, so the first 9000 bytes of each packet are captured. packet-capture-advanced eth0 temporary:///Eth0Trace 60 250 -1 "host svr1" on Starts a packet-capture session on the "eth0" interface. Packet-capture data is written to the "temporary:///Eth0Trace" file. The session stops after 1 minute or when the file contains 250 KB of data, whichever comes first. The maximum packet size of -1 indicates the default value, so the first 9000 bytes of each packet are captured. The session only captures packets to or from "svr1" and logs the TLS master secrets in the "logtemp:///sslkeyfile.log" file.

entry.name: packet_capture_advanced_kglobalconfig_descr_1617
entry.text: Start the capture of network packets.

entry.name: sshclientprofile_kglobalconfig_help_1618
entry.text:
An SSH Client Profile is associated with an SSH URLOpener or with a Secure Cloud Connector. A Secure Cloud Connection requires the Application Optimization feature. The remote server's public key must be in the SSH SSH Client Profile known hosts list.
Note: The Secure Cloud Connector is deprecated.

entry.name: sshclientprofile_kglobalconfig_descr_1618
entry.text: Profile describing an SSH client

entry.name: iop_mgmt_kglobalconfig_help_1619
entry.text:
Creates an HTTP or HTTPS server for Interoperability testing on the specified IP address and port number.
Interoperability Test Service is used to test stylesheets or maps. The service is available via HTTP or HTTPS, and it is disabled by default.

entry.name: iop_mgmt_kglobalconfig_descr_1619
entry.text: Interoperability Test Service configuration.

entry.name: http_acl_interopservice_help_1620
entry.text:
Assigns a named Access Control List (ACL) to the HTTP handler.
Access control list is used to allow or deny access to the service based on the IP address of the client.
acl The ACL assigned to the HTTP handler.
For example: http-acl restrictive-acl-1 assigns the ACL 'restrictive-acl-1' to the HTTP handler.

entry.name: http_acl_interopservice_descr_1620
entry.text: Assigns an ACL to the HTTP handler.

entry.name: http_ip_address_interopservice_help_1621
entry.text:
Assigns an IP address to the HTTP Handler. The IP address is the local device address that the handler monitors for incoming client requests.
address is the local IP address monitored by the HTTP handler. The default IP address "0.0.0.0" indicates that the HTTP handler monitors all active device addresses.
For example: http-ip-address 192.168.1.1 assigns the local address 192.168.1.1 to the HTTP handler.

entry.name: http_ip_address_interopservice_descr_1621
entry.text: Assigns an IP address to the HTTP handler.

entry.name: http_port_interopservice_help_1622
entry.text:
Assigns a port number to the HTTP handler. The port number, along with the IP address specified by the http-ip-address command, identifies the address:port to be monitored by the HTTP handler for incoming client requests.
port an integer (from 1 to 65535, with a default value of 9990) identifies the port monitored by the HTTP handler.
For example: port 22222 assigns the port number 22222 to the HTTP handler.

entry.name: http_port_interopservice_descr_1622
entry.text: Assigns a port number to the HTTP handler.

entry.name: http_service_interopservice_help_1623
entry.text:
This command enables the Interoperability Test Service over HTTP.
For example: http-service off disables the Interoperability Test Service over HTTP.

entry.name: http_service_interopservice_descr_1623
entry.text: Enables the Interoperability Test Service via HTTP.

entry.name: https_acl_interopservice_help_1624
entry.text:
Assigns a named Access Control List (ACL) to the HTTPS handler.
Access control list is used to allow or deny access to the service based on the IP address of the client.
acl The ACL assigned to the HTTPS handler.
For example: https-acl restrictive-acl-1 assigns the ACL 'restrictive-acl-1' to the HTTPS handler.

entry.name: https_acl_interopservice_descr_1624
entry.text: Assigns an ACL to the HTTPS handler.

entry.name: https_ip_address_interopservice_help_1625
entry.text:
Assigns an IP address to the HTTPS Handler. The IP address is the local device address that the handler monitors for incoming client requests.
address is the local IP address monitored by the HTTPS handler. The default IP address "0.0.0.0" indicates that the HTTPS handler monitors all active device addresses.
For example: https-ip-address 192.168.1.1 assigns the local address 192.168.1.1 to the HTTPS handler.

entry.name: https_ip_address_interopservice_descr_1625
entry.text: Assigns an IP address to the HTTPS handler.

entry.name: https_port_interopservice_help_1626
entry.text:
Assigns a port number to the HTTPS handler. The port number, along with the IP address specified by the https-ip-address command, identifies the address:port monitored by the HTTPS handler for incoming client requests.
port an integer (within the range 1 to 65535, with a default value of 9991) identifies the port monitored by the HTTPS handler.
For example: port 22223 specifies port number 22223 to the HTTPS handler.

entry.name: https_port_interopservice_descr_1626
entry.text: Assigns a port number to the HTTPS handler.

entry.name: https_service_interopservice_help_1627
entry.text:
This command enables the Interoperability Test Service via HTTPS.
For example: https-service off disables the Interoperability Test Service over HTTPS.

entry.name: https_service_interopservice_descr_1627
entry.text: Enables the Interoperability Test Service via HTTPS.

entry.name: xml_manager_interopservice_help_1628
entry.text:
Assigns a custom XML manager instead of the default one to the Interoperability Test Service.
xmlManagerName The custom XML manager associated with the Interoperability Test Service.
For example: xml-manager iop-mgr assigns the XML manager named 'iop-mgr' to the Interoperability Test Service.

entry.name: xml_manager_interopservice_descr_1628
entry.text: Assigns a custom xml-manager associated with the Interoperability Test Service.

entry.name: oauth_supported_client_group_kglobalconfig_help_1629
entry.text:
Enters OAuth Client Group mode where you can create or modify the configuration of a group of supported OAuth clients. The OAuth client group is part of the AAA policy configuration that supports the OAuth protocol.
name The name of the group of OAuth clients.

entry.name: oauth_supported_client_group_kglobalconfig_descr_1629
entry.text: Enters OAuth Client Group mode.

name The name of the group of OAuth clients.

entry.name: template_process_url_oauthsupportedclientgroup_help_1631
entry.text:
Specifies the location of the stylesheet or GatewayScript file that defines the OAuth client. You can define parts of the configuration parameters in the stylesheet or GatewayScript file and then specify an OAuth client template to derive the parameters that are not specified in the stylesheet or GatewayScript file. Note that the stylesheet or GatewayScript file must provide the "client-id" parameter.
URL The location of the stylesheet or GatewayScript file. The stylesheet or GatewayScript file must be in the "local" or "store" directory.

entry.name: template_process_url_oauthsupportedclientgroup_descr_1631
entry.text: Location of the stylesheet or GatewayScript file that defines the OAuth client.

entry.name: customized_oauthsupportedclientgroup_help_1632
entry.text:
Indicates whether the configuration is for a customized OAuth client group.
on Indicates that the configuration is for a customized OAuth client group. off Indicates that the configuration is not for a customized OAuth client group.

entry.name: customized_oauthsupportedclientgroup_descr_1632
entry.text: Whether the configuration is for a customized group.

entry.name: customized_type_oauthsupportedclientgroup_help_1633
entry.text:
Indicates the method to customize an OAuth client.
custom Indicates that the configuration is for a customized OAuth client group. This method uses a stylesheet or GatewayScript file to define the details of the OAuth client configuration. template Indicates that a combination of a stylesheet or GatewayScript file and a client template is used to define the OAuth client configuration.

entry.name: customized_type_oauthsupportedclientgroup_descr_1633
entry.text: How to customize an OAuth client.

entry.name: oauth_role_oauthsupportedclientgroup_help_1634
entry.text:
Specifies the role for the OAuth client profiles in the group.
azsvr The role is authorization server endpoints: authorization endpoint and token endpoint. rssvr The role is enforcement point for a resource server. azsvr+rssvr (Default) The role is authorization server endpoints and the enforcement point for a resource server.

entry.name: oauth_role_oauthsupportedclientgroup_descr_1634
entry.text: Role of the client profiles in the group.

entry.name: client_oauthsupportedclientgroup_help_1635
entry.text:
Manages the supported OAuth client profiles in the OAuth client group.
name The name of an existing OAuth client profile.
For example: Add two client profiles to the group client profile1 client profile2 Remove a client profile from the group no client profile2

entry.name: client_oauthsupportedclientgroup_descr_1635
entry.text: Client profiles in the group.

entry.name: az_grant_oauthsupportedclient_help_1643
entry.text:
Sets the method to obtain the access token for authorization based on the grant type.

on (Default) Generates the passphrase for the client secret. off Does not generate the passphrase for the client secret. Use the "client-secret" command to define the passphrase.

entry.name: redirect_uri_oauthsupportedclient_help_1655
entry.text:
Defines the set of redirection URIs to exchange tokens for an authorization code. Enter this command for each redirection URI that the authorization process uses.
expression Specifies a redirection URI as a PCRE. The minimum length of the expression is 1 character. The maximum length of the expression is 255 characters.
For example:
redirect-uri http(s)://example.com/redirect specifies the acceptable redirect URI for the OAuth client, in PCRE

entry.name: redirect_uri_oauthsupportedclient_descr_1655
entry.text: Set of redirection URIs for the OAuth client.

on Checks the scope with a custom stylesheet or GatewayScript file. off (Default) Checks the scope as a PCRE.

entry.name: rs_set_header_oauthsupportedclient_help_1671
entry.text:
Identifies which HTTP headers to create and send to the remote resource server. To create and send multiple HTTP headers, separate the keywords with the plus(+) character.
owner Creates the DP-OWNER HTTP header with resource owner information. clientid Creates the DP-CLIENTID HTTP header with client_id information. scope Creates the DP-SCOPE HTTP header with scope information.
miscinfo Creates the DP-MISCINFO HTTP header with customized information.
For example, create and send HTTP headers with resource owner and client_id information. rs-set-header owner+clientid

entry.name: domain_availability_kglobalconfig_help_1680
entry.text:
Enters Domain Availability Configuration Mode. Domain Availability monitors Web Service Proxy and Multi-Protocol Gateway services in the domain. The monitored services control the configuration's operational state: Up or down.
When the operational state of all services is up, the operational state of the domain availability configuration is up. If the operational state of any service is down, the operational state of the domain availability configuration is down. When the operational state of all services and handlers are up after the domain starts, the DataPower Gateway generates a log message to indicate that the domain can process traffic.
When the DataPower Gateway starts, handlers are quiesced to block traffic until all services complete their configuration and essential processing. When these configuration complete, the domain starts to accept and process traffic.
The administrative state of the domain availability configuration does not control the operational state of the domain or its configured services.
All configured Web Service Proxy and Multi-Protocol Gateway services implicitly participate in the Domain Availability.

entry.name: domain_availability_kglobalconfig_descr_1680
entry.text: Enters Domain Availability Configuration Mode

entry.text: Enters API Probe Mode

entry.name: apiprobe_create_capture_setting_kconfigapiprobe_help_1693
entry.text:
Create the capture settings for a specified API Gateway to enable the debugging for API transactions.
apigw Specifies the API gateway that the capture setting will apply to. total Specifies the number of the probe data to be captured. interval The interval in seconds between which two consecutive transactions can be debugged. requireDebugHdr Whether to debug only transactions that have the 'APIm-Debug: true' header. sendTIDInResponse Whether to return the probe ID in the response header, default is 'false'. encryptAlgorithm Algorithm to encrypt the captured probe data. encryptCert Certificate to encrypt the captured probe data for the recipient. logLevel The log level of the capture setting, valid values are 'debug' or 'payload'. apiFilter Specifies the PCRE to filter transactions by the API name. catalogFilter Specifies the PCRE to filter transactions by the API catalog name. ipFilter Specifies the PCRE to filter transactions by the client IP. pathFilter Specifies the PCRE to filter transactions by the request path. clientIdFilter Specifies the PCRE to filter transactions by the client ID.
For example: apiprobe-create-capture-setting apigw-sandbox 100 0 true true '' '' 'petstore.*' debugs the transactions for the API names that start with petstore'.

entry.name: apiprobe_create_capture_setting_kconfigapiprobe_descr_1693
entry.text: Create the capture setting for API Gateway

entry.name: apiprobe_delete_capture_setting_kconfigapiprobe_help_1694
entry.text:
Delete the capture setting for a specified API Gateway to disable the debugging for API transactions.
apigw Specifies the API gateway that the capture setting will apply to. captureId Specifies the ID of the capture setting.
For example: apiprobe-delete-capture-setting apigw-sandbox 2c3b10b3-728a-4923-ae38-40662a92b95a deletes the capture setting 'apigw-sandbox 2c3b10b3-728a-4923-ae38-40662a92b95a'.

entry.name: apiprobe_delete_capture_setting_kconfigapiprobe_descr_1694
entry.text: Delete the capture setting for API Gateway

entry.name: apiprobe_list_capture_settings_kconfigapiprobe_help_1695
entry.text:
List the capture settings of a specified API Gateway
apigw Specifies the API gateway that the capture settings are applied to.
For example: apiprobe-lists-capture-settings apigw-sandbox Lists the capture settings of API Gateway 'apigw-sandbox'.

entry.name: apiprobe_list_capture_settings_kconfigapiprobe_descr_1695
entry.text: List the capture settings of API Gateway

entry.name: apiprobe_get_capture_setting_kconfigapiprobe_help_1696
entry.text:
Get the details of the specified capture setting in an API Gateway
apigw Specifies the API gateway that the capture setting is applied to. captureId Specifies the ID of the capture setting.
For example: apiprobe-get-capture-setting apigw-sandbox 2c3b10b3-728a-4923-ae38-40662a92b95a Gets the details of the capture setting '2c3b10b3-728a-4923-ae38-40662a92b95a' for API Gateway 'apigw-sandbox'.

entry.name: apiprobe_get_capture_setting_kconfigapiprobe_descr_1696
entry.text: Get the details of the specified capture setting in an API Gateway

entry.name: apiprobe_download_all_kconfigapiprobe_help_1697
entry.text:
Download the captured probe data for the specified capture setting.
apigw Specifies the API gateway that the capture setting is applied to. captureId Specifies the ID of the capture setting. startIndex Specifies the index position of the first transaction to return. The index starts with 1 instead of 0.
For example: apiprobe-download-all apigw-sandbox 2c3b10b3-728a-4923-ae38-40662a92b95a Downloads the captured probe data of the capture setting '2c3b10b3-728a-4923-ae38-40662a92b95a'

entry.name: apiprobe_download_all_kconfigapiprobe_descr_1697
entry.text: Download the captured probe data for the specified capture setting

entry.name: apiprobe_get_data_kconfigapiprobe_help_1698
entry.text:
Get the probe data by the capture and debug transaction ID.
apigw Specifies the API gateway that the capture setting is applied to. captureId Specifies the ID of the capture setting. probeId Specifies the ID of the probe data to be download.
For example: apiprobe-get-data 2c3b10b3-728a-4923-ae38-40662a92b95a 2452252224-Landlord-sandbox-f45f65aa-98e5-46c7-a844-40662a92ba87 downloads the probe data of ID '2452252224-Landlord-sandbox-f45f65aa-98e5-46c7-a844-40662a92ba87' for the capture of '2c3b10b3-728a-4923-ae38-40662a92b95a'

entry.text: Get the probe data by the capture and debug transaction ID.

entry.name: dpmon_kdiag_help_1701
entry.text:
The dpmon command pauses, resumes and terminates the collection of performance metrics by the dpmon process. The parameter 'on' resumes the data collection if it had been paused, 'off' pauses the data collection and 'terminate' stops the data collection permanently until the system is rebooted.
The following dpmon options are configurable: dir: Output directory. Must be in "local:". rotations: # of rotations of output file. Valid range: [1-10]. interval: # of seconds between snapshots. Valid range: [1-1000000]. snapshots: # of snapshots per rotation of output file. Valid range: [10-100000]. max-output: maximum # of storage bytes of dpmon output. buffer: size of output buffer. Valid range: [2000-1000000] or 0 to turn off buffering. timezone: the record timestamp will be in local timezone or default (UTC) time.
Additional parameters are as follows: save-settings: makes the configured options persist across reloads. reset-settings: resets the options to the default values. show: outputs the current dpmon settings.

entry.name: dpmon_kdiag_descr_1701
entry.text: Controls dpmon performance monitoring

entry.name: gateway_peering_slow_log_kdiag_help_1708
entry.text: Enable slow log system to log queries that exceeded a specified execution time. name Gateway peering name. slower-than The execution time of command that takes more than the specified threshold will be logged. Enter a value in the range 0 - 9223372036854775807. The default initial value is 10000. Zero forces the logging of every command. max-length The length of the slow log. When a new command is logged and the slow log is already at its maximum length, the oldest one is removed from the queue of logged commands in order to make space. Enter a value in the range 0 - 9223372036854775807. The default initial value is 128.

entry.name: lldiag_kdiag_help_1718
entry.text:
The lldiag command starts or stops the collection of a variety of low level diagnostic information. The parameter 'on' or 'off' starts or stops data collection, respectively. An optional mode value can be specified with 'on'.
The mode value is one of the following:
miniwd, or 1 Start a "mini-watchdog" to report worker thread events taking longer than the time specified with the 'timeout' parameter but less than 60 seconds. The interval at which to check for events is specified with the 'check' parameter. lowmem, or 2 Report all low memory events. sched, or 4 Report scheduler activity at intervals specified with the 'monitor' parameter. queues, or 8 Report scheduler work queue activity at intervals specified with the 'monitor' parameter. workers, or 16 Report worker thread activity at intervals specified with the 'monitor' parameter.
Modes can be combined in two ways. Numeric values can be added together as a single number. String values can be added together using the plus sign ('+'). For example the following commands specify the same mode:
lldiag on 3 lldiag on miniwd+lowmem
The default value is 3.
Additional parameters are: timeout milliseconds Specifies the mini-watchdog threshold. Events taking longer than this value but less than 60 seconds are reported. The default value is 1000. check milliseconds Specifies the mini-watchdog check interval. The default value is 1000. monitor milliseconds Specifies the monitor interval for reporting sched, queues, and workers events. The default value is 1000. dir directory Specifies the directory where the output log files are written. The default value is "lldiag:". Log files contained in the default directory are automatically included in the error report. If the directory is changed using this parameter then the resulting log files must be manually collected. fsize bytes Specifies the size of the output log files in bytes. The default value is 1M. rotation n Specifies the number of log file rotations. The default value is 3 show Shows the current set of lldiag parameters.

entry.name: lldiag_kdiag_descr_1718
entry.text: Enables collection of low level diagnostic information

entry.name: memory_debug_kdiag_help_1724
entry.text:
The size-from and size-to parameters set the bounds of memory allocation sizes. All memory allocations between these two sizes, inclusive, are subject to the specified debugging mode.
The mode parameter is one of the following. none No padding or sentinel pages are added to the allocated area. However, the debug suffix that is used for all modes is added, and checked for corruption when the memory is freed. pad-before In addition to a debug suffix, padding is added before the start of the allocated area. The debug suffix and padding bytes are checked for corruption when the memory is freed. pad-after In addition to a debug suffix, padding is added after the end of the allocated area. The debug suffix and padding bytes are checked for corruption when the memory is freed. pad-both In addition to a debug suffix, padding is added before and after the allocated area. The debug suffix and padding bytes are checked for corruption when the memory is freed. ros-before In addition to a debug suffix, a read-only sentinel page is added before the start of the allocated area. Any attempt to write into the sentinel page causes a SIGSEGV signal to be generated. The debug suffix is checked for corruption when the memory is freed. ros-after In addition to a debug suffix, a read-only sentinel page is added after the end of the allocated area. Any attempt to write into the sentinel page causes a SIGSEGV signal to be generated. The debug suffix is checked for corruption when the memory is freed.
The optional padding parameter specifies the minimum size of the padding areas. The default is 32 bytes. The range is 1 - 4096, except for the pad-before and pad-both modes, where the range is 16 - 4096.

entry.name: memory_debug_kdiag_descr_1724
entry.text: Establishes memory debugging for a range of allocation sizes

"report" A file is created that captures the entire system memory state. "usage" A smaller file is created that contains processed and categorized results. report-destination The destination where the file is saved. If omitted, the file is saved to the 'nbleak' nfs static mount if available.

entry.name: set_bgleak_kdiag_help_1736
entry.text:
percent The value, expressed as a percentage of total memory, at which to set the background leak detection threshold. When free memory falls below the requested threshold, background leak detection is automatically activated. It remains active until the amount of free memory rises above the requested threshold. Higher thresholds (larger percentage of free memory) activate background leak detection earlier. To activate background leak detection permanently set the threshold to 100. To deactivate background leak detection permanently set the threshold to 0. reset Resets the background leak detection threshold to the system default.
Use the "show bgleak" command to display the current background leak detection threshold. Use the "show status" command to display the current background leak detection state.

entry.name: set_bgleak_kdiag_descr_1736
entry.text: Set the background leak detection threshold

entry.name: set_bgleak_sample_interval_kdiag_help_1737
entry.text:
interval_kb The interval, expressed in KB (kilobytes) of allocated memory, at which to sample. reset Resets the background leak detection sampling interval to the system default.
The setting takes effect the next time background leak detection is activated. For a given workload, as the interval value decreases the number of samples taken increases. Large intervals have very low runtime overhead but may not gather the desired sample coverage. Smaller intervals have more runtime overhead. The default interval is a balance between these extremes, but may not be ideal for all workloads and configurations.
Use the "show bgleak-sample-interval" command to display the current background leak detection sampling interval.

entry.name: set_bgleak_sample_interval_kdiag_descr_1737
entry.text: Sets the background leak detection sampling interval

entry.name: set_dfdl_service_trace_kdiag_help_1738
entry.text:
Enables DFDL Service Trace mode. DFDL Service Trace mode is not intended for use in a production environment, as it uses resources that can slow down transaction processing. Use the "show dfdl-service-trace" command to display the status of DFDL Service Trace mode. DFDL Service Trace output is intended for IBM Support. For customer-directed DFDL trace information, instead enable DFDL User Trace in the DFDL Settings.
on Enables DFDL Service Trace mode. DFDL processing produces large levels of Service Trace data in DataPower log messages, which can then be sent to IBM Support. These log messages come out at various levels. If the log level is higher than the message level, the messages are not logged, but time is spent tracking the DFDL state more closely. In-progress DFDL parses and serializations are not affected. New DFDL parses and serializations track extra state and log DFDL Service Trace log messages. off Disables DFDL Service Trace mode. In-progress DFDL parses and serializations are not affected. New DFDL parses and serializations do not track extra DFDL state and do not log DFDL Service Trace log messages.

entry.name: set_dfdl_service_trace_kdiag_descr_1738
entry.text: Enables DFDL Service Trace Mode

entry.name: set_ext_backtracer_var_kdiag_help_1739
entry.text:
Sets the value of variables that control the information generated by the extended backtracer. If no value is specified, the variable will be reset to its default value.
Supported variables include: DP_MEMDUMP_DIR This variable specifies the destination of where the memory dumps are to be written. Memory dumps can only be to written to the local file system. For example: set-ext-backtracer-var DP_MEMDUMP_DIR local://ondisk/mem_dumps. If no value is specified, then the memory dump feature is disabled. Memory dumps are created on system failure or when the command "save extended-backtrace" is executed. The memory dumps will be written to file mem_[procid] in the specified directory. NOTE:If the destination memory dump file already exists, it will not be overwritten.
DP_PRINT_ARRAY_ELEMS This variable specifies the number of array elements to include in the extended backtrace. The supported values are between 1 and 200. For example: "set-ext-backtracer-var DP_PRINT_ARRAY_ELEMS 5" will result in extended backtraces where the first 5 characters of strings are displayed. The default value is 1.
Use the "show ext-backtrace-config" command to display the current variable settings. Only updated variables will be displayed.

entry.name: set_ext_backtracer_var_kdiag_descr_1739
entry.text: Sets the value of extended backtracer variables

entry.name: set_failsafe_thresholds_kdiag_help_1740
entry.text:
Sets one or more of the router failsafe threshold values, or resets all values to their default value. There are two failsafe thresholds, each of which establishes the consecutive number of router failures within two minute intervals each that cause the router to enter the associated failsafe mode:
Management Mode Threshold In failsafe management mode, only the default domain is initialized, and only management interfaces are brought up. All other configuration commands are ignored.
Console Mode Threshold In failsafe console mode, only the default domain is initialized, and only the serial console is brought up. No user configuration files are read.
The default threshold values are 10 for management mode and 11 for console mode. The maximum value is 12, and the values must be specified in increasing order. If the console threshold is not specified, it is set to the management threshold value plus one.
Use the "show failsafe-thresholds" command to display the current failsafe threshold values.

entry.name: set_failsafe_thresholds_kdiag_descr_1740
entry.text: Sets the router failsafe threshold values

entry.name: set_gatewayscript_kdiag_help_1741
entry.text:
enable Enables GatewayScript. GatewayScript is enabled by default. disable Disables GatewayScript. When disabled, GatewayScript action could not be executed.
The setting is persisted. After enable or disable GatewayScript, a system reload is required to make the change effective. Use the "show gatewayscript" command to display the current state of GatewayScript.

entry.name: set_gatewayscript_kdiag_descr_1741
entry.text: Enables or disables GatewayScript

entry.name: set_gatewayscript_cache_kdiag_help_1742
entry.text:
enable Enables GatewayScript cache. GatewayScript cache is enabled by default. disable Disables GatewayScript cache. When disabled, GatewayScript action won't cache any user scripts or modules. Disabling GatewayScript will impact runtime performance.
Use the "show gatewayscript-cache" command to display the current state of GatewayScript cache.

entry.name: set_gatewayscript_cache_kdiag_descr_1742
entry.text: Enables or disables GatewayScript cache

entry.name: set_memory_kdiag_help_1743
entry.text:
The keywords "default", "debug", and "nbleak" are mutually exclusive. The memory module selected is valid for only the first reboot after execution. Subsequent reboots use the default memory module.
The optional immediate parameter can be used in conjunction with the nbleak memory module to dynamically enable the module without a restart.

entry.name: set_memory_kdiag_descr_1743
entry.text: Sets the memory module to be used by the device

entry.name: set_memory_trimming_kdiag_help_1744
entry.text:
percent The value, expressed as a percentage of total memory, at which to set the memory trimming threshold. When free memory falls below the requested threshold, memory trimming is automatically activated. It remains active until the amount of free memory rises above the requested threshold. Higher thresholds (larger percentage of free memory) activate memory trimming earlier. To activate memory trimming permanently set the threshold to 100. To deactivate memory trimming permanently set the threshold to 0. reset Resets the memory trimming threshold to the system default.
Use the "show memory-trimming" command to display the current memory trimming threshold. Use the "show status" command to display the current memory trimming state.

entry.name: set_memory_trimming_kdiag_descr_1744
entry.text: Sets the memory trimming threshold

entry.name: set_tracing_kdiag_help_1745
entry.text:
Enables or disables the tracing capabilities on the DataPower Gateway. The keywords on|off|flush are mutually exclusive. The descriptor, memory, portspin, c14n, and sql-runtime properties are optional.
When performing SQL tracing, you need to include sql-runtime in the capabilities list and include the file-url property.
When performing descriptor tracing, you need to include descriptor in the capabilities list. Descriptor tracing causes file descriptors to be placed on a quarantined list for a period of time instead of actually being closed. You can control this time period using the optional lifetime property to specify the lifetime in seconds. The default value is 10 seconds. After the lifetime period elapses for a given file descriptor, it is then closed.

entry.name: set_tracing_kdiag_descr_1745
entry.text: Enables or disables the tracing capabilities

entry.name: test_password_alias_kdiag_help_1746
entry.text: Checks an input string against the currently configured password alias password value. If no test-password is provided on the command, then the user is prompted for the value.

entry.name: test_password_alias_kdiag_descr_1746
entry.text: Tests a password string against a password alias.

entry.name: xml_accelerator_kdiag_help_1747
entry.text: Enables ("on") or disables ("off") the DataPower XML accelerator. The keywords "on" and "off" are mutually exclusive.

entry.name: xml_accelerator_kdiag_descr_1747
entry.text: Enables or disables the XML accelerator.
